DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Friday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
President Lee Teng-hui vows to build new cities and townships in quake-stricken areas in three years.
The China Times:
Stricter regulations will be imposed on examination of quake-damaged houses.
The United Daily News:
Taiwan's economic growth rate is projected at 5.5 percent this year; no pay raise for government employees next year.
The Liberty Times:
The Ministry of Transportation and Communications "drafts" 1,417 private heavy-duty trucks to join post-quake reconstruction work.
The Commons Daily:
US Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky uses the term "both countries" to describe Taiwan's and mainland China's WTO bid for the first time during a Wednesday congressional hearing.
The China Post:
Uranium leak triggers nuke emergency in Japan.
The Taiwan News:
Is your building safe? Architects, engineers join inspections, issue ratings.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Oct. 1, or the 22nd day of the eighth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1868: Mongkut, king of Siam, dies at the age of 64. In only 17 years he implemented sweeping political, economic and social changes with western help.
1880: The Edison Lamp Works begins operating in New Jersey to manufacture the first electric light bulbs.
1903: European railroads link with Russia.
1908: America's Ford Motor Company begins to produce its Model T, a simple, sturdy car affordable to large numbers of people.
1916: A proposal by National Peking University Professor Hu Shih, that literature be written in vernacular language rather than in the classical style, wins quick acceptance.
1918: T. E. Lawrence, the British officer known as "Lawrence of Arabia" and the Arab forces of Emir Faisal capture Damascus from the Turks.
1920: The Peking government recovers Russian settlements in China.
1921: The Chinese Communist Party sets up its branch in Hunan Province with Mao Tse-tung as its secretary.
1924: Jimmy Carter, an American peanut farmer who became the 39th president of the United States, is born. He was instrumental in getting Israel and Egypt to sign the Camp David agreement ending hostilities between the two countries.
1936: General Francisco Franco Bahamonde, 44, is proclaimed "Chief of the Spanish State" by the nationalist military junta trying to seize power in Spain.
1946: The International War Crime Tribunal in Nuremberg sentences 12 Nazi leaders to death.
1947: The Japanese Ministry of Education abrogates the name of Kyoto Imperial University.
1949: The Chinese communists set up a regime in Peking with Mao Tse-tung as party chairman. The regime was recognized by the Soviet Union the next day.
1956: The ROC government implements regulations governing distribution of land to retired servicemen.
1958: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA), a US government agency that conducts and coordinates research of flight within and beyond the earth's atmosphere, is formally set up as an independent agency, with headquarters in Washington, DC.
1960: The Republic of China recognizes Nigeria.
1964: Japan's "bullet train" makes its first journey from Tokyo to Osaka.
1965: A coup attempt by Indonesian communists is crushed by Suharto, an army officer who becomes president of Indonesia two years later.
1969: The sound barrier is broken by the Concorde 001 during a test flight in France.
1972: Louis Leakey, British archaeologist and anthropologist, dies in London at the age of 69. He discovered the 1,750,000-year-old Zinjanthropus fossil at Olduvai Gorge and the contemporaneous "Homo habilis" at Lake Natron in Tanzania between 1959 and 1964.
1974: The Watergate trial begins in Washington.
1975: Muhammad Ali beats Joe Frazier in a rematch in Manila. Ali won the world heavyweight title after defeating the fearsome George Foreman in a sensational upset in 1974. Frazier beat Ali in 1971.
1982: Helmut Kohl is sworn in as West Germany's sixth chancellor, succeeding Helmut Schmidt.
1987: Am earthquake rocks Los Angeles for 20 seconds, killing seven people and injuring at least 100 others.
1991: President Jean-Bertrand Aristide of Haiti, who was elected in December 1990, is forced into exile in Venezuela after a military coup.
1997: Gul Mohammed, the world's shortest man at 56 cm tall, dies.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Every system of moral law must be based upon man's own consciousness. It must be verified by the common experience of men."

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA TO HELP MANUFACTURERS IN INDUSTRIAL ZONES IN CENTRAL TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will soon send a service group to industrial zones in central Taiwan to learn first hand the damage sustained by manufacturers during the devastating earthquake ten days ago.

A survey conducted by MOEA found that the Fengyuan, Taiping, Tali and Wufeng District Administrative Centers in Taichung, the Chaotun and Nankang Industrial District Administrative Centers in Nantou County as well as the Chuanhsing Industrial District Administrative Center in Changhua County were all badly damaged in the 7.3-magnitude earthquake which has killed more than 2,200 people to date.
The industrial zones, the production centers of traditional machine tools, manual machine tools and bicycles, have seen their exports suffer in the wake of quake.

MOEA officials said that the effect of the earthquake can be summarized as follows: power outages and rationing have led to production disruption, production equipment was damaged in the earthquake, foreign importers have switched their orders to other destinations and the warehouses that store imported materials were damaged by the quake.
The officials said that they are currently mulling various strategies to cope with the above in order to help the manufacturers in the district administrative centers tide over present difficulties.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOREAN AIR AIRLIFTS 30 TONS OF RELIEF GOODS TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A Korean Air all-cargo plane airlifted 30 tons of relief goods to earthquake-plagued Taiwan on Friday, marking the first direct flight to the Republic of China by a South Korean carrier since the two countries cut direct airlinks in 1992.
The ROC's Ministry of Foreign Affairs sent staff members to receive the relief goods at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, the main gateway to Taiwan.

The goods, including 300 tents, 1,000 sleeping bags, 1,000 blankets and 1,200 cases of mineral water, will soon be transported to hardest-stricken disaster zones in central Taiwan which bore the brunt of the 7.3 magnitude earthquake which rattled the island on Sept. 21.
The ROC cut direct airlinks with South Korea on Sept. 15, 1992, three weeks after Seoul switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing on Aug. 24, 1992.

Over the past seven years, South Korea has repeatedly expressed hopes to resume direct flight services between the two countries. The two sides, however, have so far failed to come to terms on conditions for resuming direct airlinks.

Diplomatic sources said one main obstacle is South Korea's reluctance to upgrade the level of bilateral negotiations on the issue for fear of offending Beijing. Moreover, South Korea's handling of its switch of diplomatic allegiance more than seven years ago deeply hurt the ROC's national dignity and feelings of its people.
Observers said Friday's landing of the Korean Air plane at CKS Airport may offer a ray of hope for resumption of direct airlinks between the two countries in the future.

South Korea has shown goodwill to the ROC since last Tuesday's deadly earthquake wreaked havoc on the island. In addition to sending an elite team to Taiwan to assist in search and rescue operations in quake-stricken areas, many civic South Korean groups and individuals have also donated money to help surviving quake victims.
The strong earthquake has claimed more than 2,100 lives, injured over 8,700 others and left some 100,000 people homeless.

DOC.HEADLINE: US WORLD VISION TO RAISE US$5 MILLION FOR TAIWAN QUAKE VICTIMS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Sept. 30 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: World Vision of the United States is in the process of raising US$5 million for Taiwan to use for reconstruction and rehabilitation efforts in the wake of the devastating earthquake that struck the island on Sept. 21, said Richard Sterns the relief organization's chairman on Thursday.
In a letter to the top Republic of China representative in Washington, Steven Chen, Sterns said so far some US$1 million has been raised with more donations expected to arrive in the following days.
According to Chen, the World Vision of the United States has kept in close contact with his office since the deadly earthquake hit Taiwan 10 days ago.

After the 7.3-magnitude earthquake devastated central Taiwan, the World Vision of Taiwan has also established 12 rescue centers in stricken areas to help survivors resettle and rebuild their homes, Chen said.

He said members of the Chinese communities around the United States are welcome to offer their donations through World Vision of the United States. The organization's US address is: World Vision, P.O. Box 9716, Federal Way, Wash. 98063-9716.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL, EVA AIRWAYS FLIGHTS TO MANILA OPERATE NORMALLY
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 1 (CNA) (By David Hsu and Timothy Sun)

TEXT.P: Due to a statement on Thursday by Philippine President Joseph Estrada expressing his hope that current negotiations covering the Taiwan-Philippine aviation agreement would be prolonged an extra day, Taiwan airlines' flights to Manila operated normally Friday.
China Airlines (CAL) has already completed its preparations for the suspension of all its Taipei-Manila and Kaohsiung-Manila flights once the government here makes a formal announcement.
Until an agreement on the renewal of the Taiwan-Philippine 1996 aviation accord is reached, CAL is only accepting individual passenger reservations.
At present, CAL operates 21 weekly flights from Taipei to Manila and Kaohsiung to Manila.

EVA Airways said that prior to the government formally announcing the suspension of Taiwan-Philippine flights, it will continue to make reservations. However, because the government's announcement is expected at any time, EVA is only accepting a limited number of reservations.
EVA Airways operates 11 Taipei-Manila flights per week.

The Far East Air Transport Corp. (FAT) said it too would immediately stop its Taiwan-Manila route once the government makes the announcement. At present, FAT operates five Kaohsiung-Subic Bay flights per week.
Beginning Friday, Philippine Airlines (PAL) suspended all its Manila-Taipei flights.

CAL Manila bound flight CI637 took off from Kaohsiung at 7:40 a.m. and landed on time at the Manila international airport at 9:20 a.m. CAL flights CI631 and CI633 from Taipei to Manila took off at 8:10 a.m. and 1 p.m. respectively and landed on time at the Manila international airport.

The CAL manager at the Manila international airport, Lin Tsu-keng, said the airport's authorities have yet to receive instructions from their government telling them to refuse CAL flights' requests for landing rights at the airport.
On Friday, all scheduled EVA Taipei-Manila flights also made normal taking offs from Taiwan and landings at the Manila airport.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN TIES WITH INDONESIA, MALAYSIA SEEN WORSENING

TEXT.P: Bilateral relations between Australia and its two neighboring countries -- Indonesia and Malaysia -- are worsening at a surprisingly rapid pace over East Timor thanks to Canberra's provocation against Jakarta and Kuala Lumpur.

The threat of "hot pursuit" by Defense Minister John Moore, who said the Australian-led UN peacekeeping force might cross the East Timor border to pursue attacks from pro-Indonesian militias has prompted warnings from Indonesia of "adverse consequences" and forced the commander of the peace keepers, Major-General Peter Cosgrove, to clarify his role and insist that it was limited to East Timor only.

It also prompted Indonesia's outgoing ambassador to Australia to warn Canberra against its provocation and aggressive behavior in its role in East Timor. He said tensions between Indonesia and Australia were climbing "like a ladder and had reached the top step."

Australia's role in East Timor also caused a friction between Canberra and Kuala Lumpur after Prime Minister Mahathir demanded that Australian troop presence in East Timor be reduced because of its "heavy-handed dealing" with the problem in the former Portuguese colony.

Mahathir made the complaint to UN Secretary General Kofi Annan at a meeting in New York, saying: "I have seen pictures of Australian troops pointing guns at almost everybody. Is it necessary to point guns at people who are obviously unarmed?"
But Prime Minister John Howard on Thursday "emphatically and categorically" rejected Mahathir's accusation that Australian troops were behaving belligerently.

U.S. Defense Secretary William Cohen, now in Jakarta, defended Australian troop behavior, saying the peace force needed to act in a "very aggressive manner" to confront militia elements threatening violence.
In a meeting with President B.J. Habibie, Cohen warned Habibie and other senior government officials that Indonesia would suffer "severe damage" if the army failed to disarm the militias.

Meanwhile, Commandant Cornello Gama of the resistance force Falintil on Thursday came down from the hills in East Timor to open negotiations with the UN peacekeeping force and handed a truckload of weapons to the Australian-led force as a gesture of collaboration with the peace keepers.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLITICAL REFORM SEEN AS CHINA'S PRESSING PROBLEM

TEXT.P: While marking its 50th anniversary of founding the Communist regime, mainland China has succeeded in its economic reform in the past 20 years, but it has failed in its political reform, which is one of many pressing problems for the mainland.

In an editorial headlined: "China Faces Revolutions of the Future," the Australian on Friday says: "Over the past 20 years, China has thrown off much of the dogma associated with Marxism-Leninism and has made big strides in its efforts to modernize its economy." "The modernization of China, and its emergence fully into the international community, is one of the most important dynamics of the century," it adds.

But the editorial says "political reform seems to have ground to a halt. This is the uncompleted half of the reforms of the past 20 years." "The Chinese authorities have argued that by pursuing economic rather than political reform they have avoided the fate of (Mikhail) Gorbachev's Soviet Union."

"But this process can only go so far. Eventually even economic performance requires greater political space. This is particularly true as the information industries increasingly dominate modern economies," the editorial says.

It says China also faces other problems because its state-owned enterprises "remain beyond effective reform. The banking system is a mess. Unemployment is a threat to social stability. The environmental problems are catastrophic."
"None of this is to deny the many pressing problems which afflict China today," the editorial says.

DOC.HEADLINE: COX: CLINTON ADM. QUIETLY ADMITS CHINA STOLE SECRETS

TEXT.P: While the Federal Bureau of Investigation and a Senate penal are respectively investigating the allegations that Communist China has stolen US nuclear weapons secrets, Rep. Chris Cox (R-CA) pointed out that the Clinton administration has quietly admitted in writing that the House Cox Committee report was correct in concluding that spies working for Communist China stole US nuclear warhead designs.
"It's not alleged, it's a fact," stressed the California Republican congressman in an interview with the editors of Human Event monthly magazine, which will be published in its latest issue.

Cox, who chaired the House select committee that investigated Communist Chinese theft of US weapons technology, pointed to the little-noticed National Security Estimate, titled "Foreign Missile Developments and the Ballistic Missile Threat to the United States Through 2015," which was released earlier in September 1999.

The National Security Estimate stated for the first time that it is the judgment of the entire intelligence community that the three new long-range weapons systems that the People's Liberation Army is going to roll out in the next few years "will contain US warhead information," and that is "what we stated in our report," noted Cox.

"The media keep saying that there is no proof that anything was really stolen, they say the Cox report is overstated." But the facts are, the congressman said, "that the PRC had acquired classified information about every currently deployed nuclear warhead in the US arsenal."

The National Intelligence Estimate stated that "with the JL-2 submarine-launched missile," Cox added, "the PRC will be able to hit the United States from Chinese territorial waters, which is exactly what we stated in our report. In addition, these three weapons platforms will likely be fitted with miniaturized nuclear warheads influenced by stolen US designs acquired through espionage. So every single piece of this is now officially the public view of the intelligence community."
Cox pointed out that the Central Intelligence Agency chairs the committee that published the National Security Estimate, but that the panel includes all US intelligence agencies.

Most of the security breaches perpetrated by the PRC have taken place during the Clinton years, said Cox. "In our report, we have given either exact or approximate dates for most of the thefts. With the exception of one that is pinned down at the end of the Carter administration and another that probably occurred during the Reagan or Bush administration, all the rest of them, as outlined in our report, occurred during the Clinton administration," he added.

Meanwhile, the FBI was ordered earlier this week to widen its probe of the allegations that Communist China has stolen US nuclear weapons secrets after it failed to file any charges against suspected Taiwan-born scientist Wen Ho Lee following an investigation.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCIENTISTS SEE DIAMONDS HAILING DOWN FROM SOME SOLAR PLANETS

TEXT.P: If experiments at the University of California, Berkeley, are any indication, future explorers of our solar system may well find diamonds hailing down through the atmospheres of Neptune and Uranus.
These planets contain a high proportion of methane, which UC-Berkeley researchers have now shown can turn into diamond at the high temperatures and pressures found inside these planets.
"Once these diamonds form, they fall like raindrops or hailstones toward the center of the planet," said Laura Robin Benedetti, a graduate student in physics at UC Berkeley.

The team, led by Benedetti and Raymond Jeanloz, professor of geology and geophysics, produced these conditions inside a diamond anvil cell, squeezing liquid methane to several hundred thousand times atmospheric pressure. When they focused a laser beam on the pressurized liquid, heating it to some 5,000 degrees Fahrenheit, diamond dust appeared.
They're reporting their experimental findings in a paper in the Oct. 1 issue of the journal Science.

The demonstration that methane can convert to diamond as well as other complex hydrocarbons in the interiors of giant planets like Neptune hint at a complex chemistry inside gaseous planets and even brown dwarf stars. Brown dwarfs are small, dim stars barely larger than the largest gas giant planets.

"This is opening the door to study of the interesting types of chemical reactions taking place inside planets and brown dwarfs," Jeanloz said. "Now that technology is able to reproduce the high pressures and temperatures found there, we are getting much better quality information on the chemical reactions taking place under these conditions."
Our solar system's other gas giant planets -- Jupiter and Saturn -- may also contain diamonds produced under such conditions, though they contain proportionately less methane than Neptune and Uranus.

"As more planets are found in unexpected orbits around other stars, the effects of internal chemical processes will need to be further clarified in order to obtain a general understanding of planet formation and evolution," the authors concluded in the Science paper.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMMUNIST RULE IN CHINA BRANDED AS "FIFTY YEARS OF EVIL"

TEXT.P: The past half century of communist rule in China was branded as "fifty years of evil" by a leading British newspaper as Beijing's leaders prepare to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the people's republic.
The paper went on to say it is a shame that Western democracies have been woefully reluctant to denounce these evils.

The mass-circulation Daily Telegraph noted Thursday in an article by Graham Hutchings, its correspondent in China from 1987 to 1998, that the anniversary is the "Party's party not the people's", and Beijing's leaders do feel the need to "camouflage the calamities of half a century of communist rule and show their determination to stay in power."

While not denying the achievements made during the past 50 years in China, Hutchings said they "pale alongside the terrible toll in human sufferings, destruction, waste and folly exacted under Chinese communism."

The Daily Telegraph wrote in an editorial under the headline, "fifty years of evil", that over 30 million people have died during the past 50 years under Chinese communist rule, which have seen the Tiananmen Square massacre, the Great Proletarian Cultural Revolution, the Great Leap Forward movement, the anti-rightist campaign against intellectuals, the invasion of Tibet and the killing of landlords in the first years of the revolution.

"As it has aged, the People's Republic may have become less murderous, but it remains exceptionally oppressive", the Daily Telegraph comment observed. It is under this context that the comment drew attention to the different route chosen by Taiwan, the other China across the Taiwan Strait.

It noted that while communist China remains "an odious leviathan", Taiwan has transformed itself from a polity run on Leninist lines to a full democracy and an economic powerhouse, "an exemplary modern Asian state".

The comment said the track record of communist China is "an affront to what passes for civilized behavior." It is with this conclusion that the comment called it a shame that the liberal democracies stand in awe of the communist China and shun Taiwan.
In a related report from Hong Kong by its correspondent David Rennie, the Daily Telegraph also debunked the propaganda of Beijing's "one country two systems" formula for the former British colony.

It is clear after the return of Hong Kong to China that "one country has been placed above any idea of two systems," said the report. It quoted Margaret Ng, a member of Hong Kong's Legislative Council, as saying that the former colony may looks the same outwardly, but the soul has changed; "if you live here then you can feel the difference."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT INSPECTS CONSTRUCTION OF SHELTERS FOR QUAKE VICTIMS

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui arrived at Tungshih Township in Taichung County on Friday to inspect the progress of the construction of shelters for quake victims in central Taiwan.
He was given a briefing by the military personnel who are carrying out the construction of prefabricated houses for the victims of the earthquake which devastated central Taiwan on Sept. 21.
Lee told temblor victims upon his arrival in Taichung City that the government will do its best to take care of those whose homes and belongings have been destroyed.
According to the president, the government has planned a three-phase rehabilitation program:
-- Completion of prefabricated houses for the homeless by the end of October will be the main task in the second phase; and
-- The final phase will be achieving the goal of rebuilding new townships within two to three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: 70% TAIWAN PEOPLE FEEL BEIJING INSINCERE IN QUAKE AID: POLL

TEXT.P: The majority of local people feel that Beijing was not sincere in offering aid to Taiwan after the island was hit by a devastating earthquake on Sept. 21, according to the results of a public opinion poll released on Friday.

The telephone poll of 1,070 adults, conducted by Sanlih Entertainment Television from Sept. 29-30, found that 70 percent of the respondents said they are dissatisfied with mainland China's aid to quake-plagued Taiwan.

Survey results also show that some 40 percent of those interviewed said Taiwan should only accept mainland China's cash aid, while a roughly equal number of the respondents said the government should only accept mainland China's relief goods.

Mainland China's Red Cross Society has donated US$100,000 in cash to its Taiwan counterpart and offered to send 500,000 renminbi (about US$60,000) worth of relief goods to help Taiwan's quake victims.

According to the poll, 46 percent said they were satisfied with the government's overall post-earthquake relief performance, but 37 percent said they were discontent with the government's performance.
Moreover, 60 percent said they feel that the government failed to take swift post-earthquake relief actions in the initial stage.
In contrast, 92.9 percent said they were satisfied with private groups' participation in post-quake relief operations, and 92 percent said they were content with the military's relief performance.

Meanwhile, 87 percent gave positive evaluation of local news media's coverage of disaster scenes and post-quake rescue and relief actions, and 64.9 percent said they believe that media coverage is helpful to the government's relief effort.

As for top government leaders' performance, 36.2 percent gave President Lee Teng-hui a score of 60-to-69 points on a zero-to-100 rating system, while 25.5 percent said they feel Lee's performance failed to live up to their expectation.

While 34 percent gave a positive evaluation of Vice President Lien Chan's performance in quake-relief operations, 27.6 percent said they feel Lien's performance failed to meet the minimum passable level of 60 points.
As for Premier Vincent Siew's performance, 36.4 percent gave a lower-than-60-points rating, while 30 percent gave his performance a grade of 60-to-69 points.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN THANKS INTERNATIONAL COMMUNITY FOR ITS HELP (I)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has offered its heartfelt thanks to the international community for its help and sympathy at a time of unprecedented hardship resulting from the devastating earthquake which struck the island on Sept. 21.

The quake, which measured 7.3 on the Richter scale, rattled central Taiwan in the early hours of the morning, killing at least 2,100 people, injuring 8,700, and leaving some 100,000 others homeless. The quake was one of the deadliest in the world this century and the strongest ever on the tremor-plagued island.

Rescue workers from Singapore, South Korea and Japan arrived in Taiwan within hours of the disaster, followed over the next few days by search and rescue teams from around the world -- Austria, Australia, Britain, Canada, the Czech Republic, France, Germany, Hungary, Hong Kong, Mexico, New Zealand, Russia, Slovakia, Spain, Switzerland, Thailand, Turkey, the United States and the United Nations.
None of those countries maintain formal relations with the diplomatically isolated Republic of China on Taiwan.

Japan, which has a uniquely sentimental attachment to Taiwan that stops short of diplomatic recognition, sent the largest search and rescue group, comprising 145 people including 10 doctors, as well as 19 sniffer dogs and two truckloads of gear.

Sympathetic to the cultural sensitivities of the people of Taiwan, the Japanese rescue workers saluted the dead bodies for five seconds before moving them. They also changed their coarse work gloves for finer ones before moving the corpses to avoid "hurting" the deceased for a second time during their retrieval.

The Japanese, who have been professionally trained and are advancedly equipped, also moonlighted as toilet cleaners in earthquake-stricken areas when they had finished with rescue work in order to prevent the spread of disease from the filthy portable toilets installed at the temporary settlement camps for survivors.

Two Japanese doctors virtually climbed and crawled to a mountain village in Nantou, the hardest-hit county in central Taiwan, to save several elderly people left injured and homeless after their homes vanished in landslides triggered by the massive temblor.

Meanwhile, the 73-member US rescue team, made up of technical experts from the United States Agency for International Development's Office of Foreign Disaster Assistance, and Fairfax County Urban Search and Rescue Team from the state of Virginia, was one of the most elite and advanced teams to pitch in with the rescue operation.
The US team found and rescued one man who had been trapped for 48 hours but didn't even seem to know about the earthquake.

"What happened to my apartment?" 33-year-old survivor Hsu Tse-kai asked after crew members spent eight hours digging him out of a four-story chunk of building that had been compressed into about three meters of rubble.

In addition to the team's swift response and tireless rescue efforts, cash donations and relief goods sent from the United States in the week following the quake topped all the relief aid from any other country.

Jack Brown, leader of the US team, said in addition that if Taiwan decides to set up a disaster relief corps similar to the US team, he and his colleagues will be very pleased to offer needed assistance.

Perhaps the most media attention, however, was directed at a 16-strong South Korean team who detected a six-year-old boy alive in a massive pile of rubble, all that remained of a 12-story residential building in the city of Tali in Taichung County, four days after the earthquake.
The child was pulled alive from the rubble of the demolished building after a painstaking nine-hour effort.

The leader of the Korean team was seen on local and international TV breathlessly and excitedly describing the progress of the unearthing of the child, the only survivor of the toppled building. Unfortunately, however, the boy had become an orphan because both his parents and two younger siblings were killed in the disaster. (To be continued....)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN THANKS INTERNATIONAL COMMUNITY FOR ITS HELP (II)

TEXT.P: The French emergency workers, who flew halfway around the world to get here, spent a whole week in the town of Puli in Nantou County working around the clock to save and find possible survivors under hunks of fallen concrete and piles of bricks in toppled buildings.
Although they did not discover any survivors, the French rescuers found new friends among the people of Taiwan.

Thierry Bruge, who was injured by falling concrete during a search mission, and was confined to a wheelchair with casts on his right hand and right leg, said the warmth and hospitality shown by the people of Taiwan were so overwhelming that he hated to leave.
Team leader Pierre Bansart said he was highly impressed with the brotherhood and compassion the people of the island shown to each other during their trying time.

Despite the fact that the team managed to grab just a few hours f sleep during their five-day rescue mission, Bansart and his crew traveled to Taiwan's National Police University before leaving the island to demonstrate their rescue gear and lend their experience and expertise to their Taiwan counterparts.
They also expressed hope that Taiwan will stand on its own feet again soon, and that it will establish its own rescue system before long.

Deputy team leader Dominique Autant, who saved an 18-month-old baby girl from earthquake debris in India in 1993, said that when one frees himself from psychological and material bondage and walks into a calamity, he will find just how insignificant man is. "You will face the world with a new attitude," he said.
"You will not find a perfect life until you reach out to help others," Autant added.
From Russia came 73 emergency workers, three sniffer dogs, three heavy-duty vehicles and some 30 metric tons of gear aboard a giant Iluyshin military transport aircraft.
The Russians pitched in with search and rescue work immediately upon arrival at an air force base in Central Taiwan, working nonstop for three days and three nights.
A total of 21 emergency workers came from Germany, with 18 sniffer dogs and 1.5 metric tons of gear.

Upon leaving for home after finishing their mission, the Germans received thunderous applause from Taiwan people who gathered at the airport to see them off, an act of gratitude that reduced some of the team to tears.

The team leader said that although he and his team have been to many places around the world to carry out post-disaster rescue and relief work, they found the esprit de corps and compassion in Taiwan to be the most overwhelming.
Germany also sent a funeral service delegation aimed at offering Taiwan help with handling corpses and related sanitation issues.

A member of the delegation, who alone handled 500 dead bodies in one week in Turkey following the devastating earthquake there a month ago, said he found there was actually little they could do in Taiwan's quake-stricken areas.

The people of Taiwan are respectful of the deceased, he said, adding that they tried their utmost to store the dead bodies on ice, but were unwilling to have the bodies of their relatives treated with disinfectant.
The rescuers from Spain greatly impressed their Taiwan counterparts with their skills in handling emergency work.

Showing no trace of the stereotypical "carefree" Latin temperament, the Spanish emergency workers traveled quietly and joined the rescue work professionally and solemnly, making the local people, particularly the relatives of the victims, feel that they were sincerely helped and respected.

Perhaps the most highly praised team, however, was the group of Mexican rescue workers. Although they arrived with only ropes and hammers, the 14-strong Mexican team worked like their nickname -- "the moles" -- burrowing beneath debris and wreckage, sometimes digging with their bare hands. The crew members, which include doctors, lawyers, sailors and company executives, did not seem to mind that they were mostly working only to retrieve bodies.

One thing is for certain, though. None of them, from whichever country, will ever be forgotten by those they toiled so hard to help, and they will carry with them forever the gratitude and thanks of the people of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEREMONY HELD IN TAIPEI TO MARK EARTHQUAKE DEATHS

TEXT.P: Whistles blew and car horns blared in downtown Taipei on Friday as an expression of the sorrow local people are feeling over the victims of the devastating earthquake which struck on Sept. 21.
A ceremony to pray for the dead to rest in peace was held at the scene of the Tunghsing building which collapsed in the 7.3-magnitude earthquake, killing more than 80 people.
Presiding over the ceremony, Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou extended his deepest sympathy to the families of the victims in an emotional and choking voice.
Ma said that although rescuers had worked day and night for the past 10 days, they were unable to save more than 80 people buried by the quake as they slept, which he said was his deepest regret.

Ma also extended his appreciation for the search and rescue workers for their strenuous efforts during the past 10 days. The rescuers succeeded in rescuing 107 people, including a pair of brothers who miraculously survived after being trapped for 130 hours beneath tons of rubble.
Saying that the end of the search effort will mark the beginning of the reconstruction work, Ma vowed to provide every possible support and assistance to the families of the victims.
He also expressed the hope that the loss of life will lead to an awakening of the people to the danger of earthquakes and the need to be prepared.

Around 1,500 people from Taipei City Hall, police and military personnel who took part in the search and rescue operations, families of the victims, and religious groups took part in the ceremony to soothe the souls of those who passed away in the quake.

Workers began to clear the wreckage in preparation for reconstruction work on Thursday evening, but they will continue to search for about a dozen more bodies believed to be still trapped under the wreckage.
A police traffic cordon around the building since the quake was lifted on Friday as work began to spray disinfectant and restore sanitary conditions in the surrounding area.

DOC.HEADLINE: MALAWI, SWAZILAND TO OPEN EMBASSIES IN ROC

TEXT.P: Two of the Republic of China's allies in Africa will soon set up embassies here, an official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Friday.
Tao Wen-lung, MOFA director-general of the Department of African Affairs, said that Malawi and Swaziland have decided to set up their embassies to further strengthen relations with the ROC.

He noted that Malawi is now consulting with the ROC about who it will station in the ROC, and added that Malawi officials are planning to visit Taiwan later this month to prepare for the opening of the embassy.
He also said that M.D. Lamini, Swaziland's permanent representative to the United Nations, has been approved by the ROC to serve as the country's ambassador to the ROC.
Swaziland's move demonstrates that it attaches great importance to its relations with the ROC, Tao said, adding that the embassy is expected to open in November.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR EDGES UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar closed firmer against the greenback on the Taipei market on Friday, rising 0.001 to 31.786.
The currency opened at 31.784, and was traded between 31.773 and 31.789. Interbank US dollar trading reached US$189 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: RED CROSS APPROPRIATES FUNDS TO FEED QUAKE VICTIMS

TEXT.P: The Red Cross Society of the Republic of China (RCSROC) announced on Friday that it had appropriated NT$50 million from the disaster relief and reconstruction fund to buy food for the victims of the Sept. 21 earthquake.
At present, there are more than 11,000 quake victims being sheltered at 19 reception centers in central Taiwan, the hardest-hit part of the island.
RCSROC had already earmarked NT$120 million to build 1,000 prefabricated houses for the victims, but officials said that expenditure for food is a heavy burden for the reception centers.
It is estimated that the NT$50 million will provide emergency food for two months.

DOC.HEADLINE: URGENT!

TEXT.P: Taiwan on Friday announced the termination of flights to and from the Philippines after negotiators from the two sides failed in a last-ditch effort to address a stormy dispute over passenger quotas.

DOC.HEADLINE: THE ANIMALS KNEW!

TEXT.P: Zoologists in the Yushan (Jade Mountain) National Park said on Friday that they found that almost all the animals vanished from vast tracts of the national park after the century's deadliest earthquake struck Central Taiwan on Sept. 21.

Yushan National Park, which makes up part of the Central Mountain Range, the backbone of the island, is the largest national park in Taiwan and home to the park's namesake, at 3,952 meters the highest peak in Northeast Asia.
Finding no trace of the animals, nor any dead bodies or remains, the zoologists believe that the animals did not fall victim to the devastating quake but escaped.
After conducting further tracking efforts, they found that the animals fled in an easterly direction, to mountainous areas in the eastern counties of Hualien and Taitung.
The bigger the animals, the earlier they left, said the zoologists.

They believe that black bears, an endangered species and the island's largest mammal, led the east-bound exodus before the earthquake shook the earth, followed by deer, Formosan serow, Formosan muntjac, wild boar, brown wood owls, field mice, squirrels, birds and even butterflies.
The zoologists said it is possible that long before an earthquake the earth discharges certain elements noticeable to animals but not to humans.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALLIES SPEAK FOR TAIWAN OVER UN MEMBERSHIP
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Sept. 30 (CNA) (By K.C. Huang and Amanda Chang)

TEXT.P: The prime ministers of Solomon Islands and Belize on Thursday stressed the legitimacy of the Republic of China's desire to be part of the United Nations.

Speaking at the United Nations General Assembly general debate session, Solomon Prime Minister Bartholomew Ulufa'alu reiterated his country's support for Taiwan's membership in the UN and UN-related organizations.

Ulufa'alu said that Taiwan's brilliant economic achievement allows it to play a positive role in promoting international trade and annihilating poverty, citing the fact that Taiwan has long provided assistance in terms of skills training and technology transfers to his country and many other developing countries.

Taiwan has often worked with the UN to help countries devastated by natural disasters or wars to rebuild, and so deserves diplomatic recognition from the international community, Ulufa'alu said, adding that UN membership would be good for the security and stability of the Asian-Pacific region and the would.
He said the Korean model could be used for Taiwan's membership, which would allow both mainland China and Taiwan to have UN membership. Rivals North and South Korea each have UN membership.

Belize Prime Minister Said Musa also called on the UN to accept Taiwan's participation in the global organization and to respect the expectations and right of all Chinese, not only those in mainland China.
Musa also expressed his condolences to the victims of the earthquake which shook Taiwan on Sept. 21.

DOC.HEADLINE: TROOPS MOBILIZED FOR RECONSTRUCTION EFFORT
DOC.DATELINE: Nantou, central Taiwan, Oct. 1 (CNA) (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Army personnel were mobilized on Friday for a new mission: to demolish within one month all houses and buildings in dangerous condition in Nantou County, the hardest-hit area in the "921 earthquake."

The commanding officer in charge of the military's post-quake reconstruction efforts, Army Commander-in-Chief Chen Chen-hsiang, issued the order, and also commanded his men to complete the construction of 5,000 prefabricated houses in three weeks, to provide temporary homes for thousands of homeless quake victims.

More than 100,000 residents -- nearly 20 percent of the total population of the county -- lost their homes in the 7.3-magnitude temblor which ripped through central Taiwan on Sept. 21, taking more than 2,100 lives and leaving over 8,700 injured, according to statistics released by local governments.

County officials say that a total of 30,000 housing units will be needed to accommodate the homeless, but as of Thursday, the county government could only ensure the construction of 9,500 temporary housing units, 6,000 of which have been donated by public and private relief groups.
The local government is calling for more aid for the housing reconstruction, the official added.
Meanwhile, in order to speed up the post-disaster reconstruction in Nantou County, the central government has also commandeered privately owned specialist vehicles such as cranes and tow trucks.
More than 300 various heavy vehicles arrived on Friday in six different relief centers in the mountainous county.

The move was the result of the first order under an emergency decree to commandeer 1,417 vehicles and heavy construction machinery, as well as the personnel to operate the equipment, from the private sector.

The emergency decree, promulgated last Saturday by President Lee Teng-hui and ratified by the legislator on Wednesday, empowers the government to mobilize resources to speed recovery in the hardest-hit regions.

For each commandeered vehicle, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications will pay around NT$10,000 (US$314.47) per day for at least one month, officials said. Under the terms of the decree, they added, private sector individuals who refuse to cooperate with the order will face punishment of up to seven years, and a possible fine of up to NT$5 million (US$157,000).

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES, INDEX FUTURES UP

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices climbed 1.3 percent on Friday, the result of strong buying on construction material stocks and plastics and chemical issues.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index rose 96.2 points to close at 7,694.99.
A total of 2.96 billion shares changed hands on a turnover of NT$107.2 billion (US$3.37 billion).

Buying focused on construction material shares as investors are expected to benefit from the post-quake reconstruction programs that will boost demand. The cement category led Friday's rally, with most issues closing at the daily maximum, and an average gain of 5.1 percent.
The financial sector stopped its downward trend as capital flowed into certain issues, leaving the sector with a 0.8-percent gain.

Strong foreign institutional buying helped restore investor confidence, but selling pressure remained heavy since many companies suffered losses from power rationing which might result in decreased earnings in the long term, dealers said.
Advancers led decliners 320 to 149, with 58 shares remaining unchanged.
The over-the-counter market rose 0.3 points to close at 174.53 on a turnover of NT$6.9 billion.

TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for October moved up 108 points to close at 7,648, with 2,507 contract transactions, while those for November rose 124 points to finish at 7,679, with 68 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for December climbed 84 points to close at 7,643, with 11 contract transactions; those for next March advanced 26 points to end at 7,666, with one contract transaction; and June futures rose 199 points to end at 7,730, with six contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Friday were 7,540 points for October, 7,555 points for November, 7,559 points for December, 7,640 points for next March, and 7,531 points for next June.

DOC.HEADLINE: 4.5-MAGNITUDE QUAKE RATTLES EASTERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: An earthquake measuring 4.5 on the open-ended Richter scale hit Hualien in eastern Taiwan at 12:39 p.m. on Friday, according to officials of the Central Weather Bureau (CWB).
The temblor occurred 14.5 kilometers northwest of Hualien, and originated 20.8 kilometers beneath the earth's surface, said the CWB officials.
The quake had an intensity of 3 in the city of Hualien, 2 in Silin township, Hualien County, 1 in Sankuan township of Taoyuan County, and 1 in Suao City of Ilan County, bureau officials added.
The magnitude of a quake is a measure of the amount of energy released by an earthquake, while the intensity indicates the strength of the temblor at various distances from the epicenter.

A tremor with a magnitude of 7 and above is classed as extremely dangerous, while a quake with a magnitude of 8.2 will release an amount of energy equivalent to 1,000 times that of the atomic bomb blast that destroyed Hiroshima during World War II.
Zero intensity indicates movement that cannot be felt by people but is measurable on seismographs, while an intensity level of 6 represents very strong movement that can cause buildings to collapse.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEXICAN RESCUERS LEAVE TAIWAN AMID REPORTS OF QUAKE IN HOMELAND

TEXT.P: Nine rescue experts from Mexico left Taiwan for home on Friday amid reports that their own country was jolted by a 7.4 magnitude earthquake on Thursday.
They were the last group of foreign rescuers to leave the quake-stricken island, and the ones who stayed the longest.

The Mexicans apparently left Taiwan with worries about their families and compatriots' safety, saying that they were anxious to fly home to join post-earthquake rescue and relief operations in their homeland.

Mexico sent 18 rescue specialists to Taiwan in three groups shortly after Taiwan was rattled by a devastating earthquake on Sept. 21 which has so far claimed 2,100 lives and injured over 8,700 others. Nine other members of the elite Mexican team left earlier this week.
Mexico formed a 30-member rescue brigade nicknamed "Topos" -- the Spanish word for mole -- after it was hit by a 8.3 magnitude temblor in 1985 which resulted in more than 10,000 deaths.

All Topos members have received stringent professional rescue and relief training. Armed with enormous experience and superb skills, the Mexican rescuers had given their all to the rescue and relief operation upon their arrival in Taiwan.

Over the past eight days, the team has taken part in search and rescue work in several hard-hit townships in central Taiwan, including Taichung County's Tali and Kukuan as well as Nantou County's Chushan, Puli and Chichi. They managed to help rescue five survivors trapped in the wreckage of toppled buildings, as well as helping to unearth buried bodies.
The Mexicans often worked like moles, burrowing beneath debris with primitive gear such as ropes and hammers. Sometimes, they even dug with their bare hands.

On the eve of their departure, the nine Mexicans still joined forces with two local firefighters to dig a passage into a caved-in tunnel along a mountainous stretch of central Taiwan's Cross-Island Highway near Kukuan to search for a buried car believed to contain two or three women. Although they failed to find the vehicle, their bravery, devotion and professionalism won the respect of local rescuers and much praise from members of the public.

After more than a week of working in each other's company, the Mexican rescuers and their local counterparts have developed bonds of true friendship, and they prayed together for the well-being of Taiwan and Mexico before the Topos team's departure from the central Taiwan disaster zones on Thursday evening.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL FINDS QUAKE IMPACT ON UPCOMING PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION

TEXT.P: The results of a Gallup opinion poll released on Friday show that a devastating earthquake that rattled Taiwan on Sept. 21 has had a strong impact on the island's next presidential election scheduled for March 2000.
The telephone poll of 1,070 adults residing throughout the island was conducted from Sept. 29-30 by Gallup Taiwan Co. at the request of Sanlih Entertainment Television, a local cable TV service.

Survey results found that nearly 50 percent of the respondents said they have yet to make a decision on whom to vote for in next year's presidential election. The ratio was far higher than those recorded in similar polls conducted before the deadly earthquake, which has claimed more than 2,100 lives and injured over 8,700 others.
According to the poll, more than 60 percent said they oppose the proposal that the presidential election be postponed due to the recent killer quake.

The poll also found that former Governor James Soong, a ruling Kuomintang member who is running a rival campaign challenging the party's presidential candidate, incumbent Vice President Lien Chan, continued to lead the pack, with a 35.3 percent support rate.
Chen Shui-bian, the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) presidential candidate, trailed behind Soong, with 16.9 percent of the respondents throwing support behind him.

Only 10.5 percent said they would vote for Vice President Lien if the presidential election were to take place the following day. The three other presidential hopefuls -- Lee Ao, Hsu Hsin-liang and Cheng Pang-chen -- only received marginal support rates of 0.3 percent, 0.2 percent and 0.2 percent, respectively.
Meanwhile, 34.4 percent said they have not yet decided for whom to vote and 12.2 percent refused to answer the question.

Liu Yi-chun, a research fellow with Academia Sinica, Taiwan's highest academic institution, said the high ratio of swing voters indicate that the powerful earthquake has had a profound impact on the forthcoming presidential election.
"The impact includes making voters who originally had decided on their choices change their minds or decline to express their intentions," Liu said.
Poll results also show that every presidential candidate's personal reputation has declined significantly in the wake of the deadly earthquake, Liu said.

While 70 percent of those interviewed said they support the promulgation of an emergency decree to facilitate post-earthquake relief and reconstruction work, 62 percent said they nix the suggestion by some lawmakers that next March's presidential election be postponed.

Asked who they think will be most competent to lead the country in carrying out various post-quake reconstruction programs after the 2000 presidential election, Soong still led the pack, with a 30.6 percent support rate; followed by DPP's Chen, 16.9 percent; and Lien, 14.2 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: US EXPERTS TO VISIT TAIWAN EARTHQUAKE SITE

TEXT.P: A US delegation of experts from Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) Urban Search & Rescue (US&R) working groups and California Task Force 3 is scheduled to arrive in Taiwan on Sunday to gain first-hand knowledge of Taiwan's handling of the aftermath of the Sept. 21 earthquake.

Unlike other foreign rescue teams, such as the US rescue team from Fairfax County, Virginia, the goal of the FEMA and California Task Force 3 experts will be fact-finding, not involvement in any rescue or reconstruction program.

David Hammond, chairperson of the FEMA US&R Technical Working Group, said on Thursday that the team's visit to Taiwan is completely private and voluntary, albeit with full cooperation from FEMA, which hopes that the group will bring back useful information about the earthquake.

David Sze, a structural engineer, is not a formal member of the delegation but will travel to Taiwan with the group. Sze will participate in evaluating the safety of buildings in Nantou County. Sze's father, Vincent Sze, is a judge of Taiwan's Supreme Court.

During the three-day fact-finding mission in Taiwan, the US delegation, with support from the National Science Council, will focus on reviewing rescue work and studying the durability of buildings during earthquakes. (by Neil Lu)

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE BEGIN CRACKDOWN ON HOARDING OF RELIEF, RECONSTRUCTION GOODS

TEXT.P: The National Police Administration (NPA) on Friday ordered police islandwide to begin a sweeping crackdown on hoarding of materials badly needed for relief and reconstruction work following the massive earthquake that shook Taiwan on Sept. 21.
The NPA issued the order after receiving tips that some retailers were attempting to corner the market on daily necessities and other goods in high demand after the 7.3-magnitude earthquake.
An investigation team under the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) and the Cabinet-level Fair Trade Commission have combined efforts to look into several such cases.

The CIB said the materials vulnerable to price-rigging are mainly those badly needed in post-quake reconstruction work. Prices of some of materials were reportedly even inflated to double the usual prices.
Police said that in addition to small shops, some large-scale convenience stores, supermarkets and shopping malls are also subject to checks by police.

Police said retailers found hoarding materials in attempts to sell them at higher prices will be punished with jail terms of one to seven years, with possible maximum fines of NT$5 million to be determined at judges' discretion.

DOC.HEADLINE: URANIUM LEAKAGE WILL NOT HAPPEN IN TAIWAN: TAIPOWER

TEXT.P: A uranium leakage such as the one which occurred in Japan will not happen in Taiwan because the uranium used in local nuclear power plants is imported from foreign suppliers, Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) officials said on Friday.
The officials said in addition that Japan's uranium leak originated from a fuel processing plant of a type not used in Taiwan.

According to foreign news reports, a private uranium fuel processing plant located 140 kilometers northeast of Tokyo leaked high-grade uranium, sending radiation levels soaring to 4,000 times greater than normal, in an unprecedented emergency.
Three nuclear workers were hospitalized, more than 160 people were evacuated, and thousands of nearby residents were reported to be sheltering indoors.
The fuel used in Taiwan is encased in inert metal when it is imported, making it very stable, and the officials stressed it cannot leak or contaminate the environment.

Furthermore, they went on, the nuclear fuel does not reach its critical point until it is treated in the reactor of the nuclear power plant, and each plant has a double-separated electrical protection system to further decrease the possibility of radiation contamination.

DOC.HEADLINE: HYOGO PREFECTURE DONATES 500 PREFABRICATED HOUSES TO TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Oct. 1 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Toshitami Kaihara, governor of Japan's Hyogo Prefecture, presented on Friday a register of 500 prefabricated houses to be donated by Hyogo Prefecture to Taiwan.
Kuo Ming-shan, director of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Osaka, accepted the donation on behalf of the government of the Republic of China.
During the donation ceremony held at the governor's office, Kuo expressed his heartfelt thanks to the Japanese government and Hyogo Prefecture.
Japan previously announced it will donate 1,000 prefabricated houses to Taiwan for victims of the Sept. 21 earthquake. Those donated by the Hyogo Prefecture represent half of that total.

A prefectural official said that the first batch of 43 prefabricated houses will be shipped to Taiwan Saturday and should arrive at Taichung Port on Oct. 9. The remaining 957 units will be sent to Taiwan in separate shipments scheduled to be completed by the middle of November.
Japan has so far donated $300 million yen, including a US$500,000 relief fund.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI ANNOUNCES SUSPENSION OF TAIWAN-MANILA FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan on Friday announced suspension of flights to and from Manila, effective Tuesday, after negotiators failed in a last-ditch effort to address the stormy dispute over airline seat quotas for each side.

Shih Ting, director general of the East Asian and Pacific Affairs Department under Taiwan's Foreign Ministry, said at a press conference that flight resumption will depend on the result of future negotiation.
Shih said that Taiwan will adopt "a series of necessary measures to cope with the latest development and that the Philippines should take responsibility for all subsequent developments."

Shih said that the measures will include a gradual reduction in the number of Philippine workers in Taiwan, of whom there are currently more than 100,000. He added that Taiwan will seek to import labor from other foreign countries, possibly including Vietnam and Nicaragua, to fill the vacancy left by Filipinos.
He accused mainland China of "manipulating the incident," and said that Taiwan has lodged a protest with the Philippines.

Shih said that Beijing has driven a wedge between Taiwan and the Philippines by complicating the purely commercial bilateral talks on the renewal of a 1996 air accord. Shih based his accusation on information collected through diplomatic and other channels, but he did not elaborate.

In an effort to save its poorly-managed flagship carrier, Philippines Airlines (PAL), the Philippines demanded at the first round of negotiations, held in Manila July 29-30, that the weekly quota, stipulated in the 1996 pact as 9,600 passengers for each side, be lowered to 4,000, but that reduction was rejected.

During the second round of talks in Taipei between PAL and the two Taiwan airlines flying the Taipei-Manila route, China Airlines (CAL) and EVA Airways, Taiwan agreed to cut the weekly passenger number to 6,500, but the Philippines then demanded a further cut to 3,000, resulting in a breakdown in negotiations.

Manila on Thursday unilaterally announced termination of the Taiwan-Philippines route, but at the request of Philippine President Joseph Estrada, both sides held one additional day of negotiations Friday, though it yielded no concrete results.
The termination of flights may cost CAL and EVA Airways NT$2 billion (US$62.5 million) annually in lost revenue.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE THAN 10,000 AFTERSHOCKS RECORDED

TEXT.P: More than 10,000 aftershocks have been recorded as of Friday, the 10th day after the devastating earthquake that struck central Taiwan on Sept. 21, seismologists said.

However, the average number of aftershocks has declined from 150 per hour right after the main shock to between 10 and 20 per hour, according to the Seismological Center under the Central Weather Bureau.
Saying that the figure of 10,000 aftershocks doesn't mean anything special, the center said the existence of gradually subsiding aftershocks follows expected seismological patterns.
They said that it will take two months, or perhaps six at the longest, for Taiwan to be completely free from the shadow of aftershocks.

The temblor, measuring 7.3 on the open-ended Richter scale, has killed about 2,100 and injured nearly 9,000, in addition to totally destroying more than 8,200 buildings and partially ruining another 6,100, making it the deadliest quake for the island this century.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S MAINLAND POLICY REMAINS UNCHANGED, SAYS MAC OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan's policy to pursue a democratic unification with the mainland remains unchanged, said a spokesperson for the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) on Friday.

The spokesperson, Sheu Ke-sheng, told the media that Taiwan's mainland policy is stipulated in the Guidelines for National Unification, and Taiwan hopes both sides of the Taiwan Strait will attain freedom, democracy and equal wealth in the future.
Sheu made the remarks in response to a statement by mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin marking the 50th anniversary of the establishment of the Beijing government on Friday.
Jiang stated that following the return of Hong Kong and Macau to mainland China, Beijing's next goal is to realize a complete unification of the fatherland.

When asked to comment on Jiang's statement, Sheu reiterated that Taipei's mainland policy to seek a democratic unification remains unchanged, adding that the goal should be attained through peaceful means.
The MAC spokesperson pointed out that cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges and negotiations have been the two pillars of Taiwan's mainland policy.

He stressed that the most important means to peacefully resolve bilateral problems is negotiation, and the two sides should strive for a democratic unification through peaceful negotiation rather than military force.

Meanwhile, Sheu expressed Taipei's gratitude for humanitarian concern from Hong Kong and mainland China regarding the devastating Chichi earthquake that struck central Taiwan on Sept. 21 and caused heavy casualties.
But he also expressed regret over politically-intended statements by some mainland authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING MILITARY SHOW NOT A THREAT TO TAIWAN: MND

TEXT.P: An official of the Ministry of National Defense (MND) stressed on Friday that the military show held for Beijing's 50th anniversary celebration did not constitute a serious threat to the security of Taiwan.

The Beijing government on Friday celebrated the 50th anniversary of its foundation with a military parade, which included displays of the domestically-manufactured Flying Leopard Fighter Bomber and other new weaponry.
According to news reports, more than 12,000 military personnel participated in the National Day military parade, which also marked the debut of the Flying Leopard Fighter Bomber.

The show demonstrated that Beijing has changed its strategy by adopting a policy of domestic military research, development and production combined with some purchases from abroad in order to carry out high-tech weaponry replacement following the Persian Gulf war, the official commented.
The official, however, stressed that Beijing's military does not constitute a threat to Taiwan at the present time since the Armed Forces of the Republic of China still maintain a superior position.
However, it was duly noticed that Beijing's research and development in the field of missile technology has improved to a certain degree, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTRY GRATEFUL FOR ISRAELI MEDICAL RELIEF SUPPLIES

TEXT.P: Uri Gutman, director of the Israeli Economic and Cultural Office in Taipei, on behalf of the Israeli government on Friday donated relief supplies for victims of the Sept. 21 earthquake.

Chen Kuo-huang, director general of the West Asian Affairs Department of the Foreign Ministry of the Republic of China, accepted the donation. The donated materials were immediately sent to Nantou, one of the central Taiwan areas most affected by the quake.
Israeli President H.E. Ezer Weiman issued a statement the day after the earthquake to express the grief of the people of Israel and their condolences for the quake victims.
The Israeli government then decided to donate food for children and medicine for heart patients.
On behalf of the government and the people of the Republic of China, Chen expressed heart-felt thanks for the benevolence of the government and people of the Israeli Republic.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INVESTMENT IN PHILIPPINES WILL BE AFFECTED

TEXT.P: The termination of Taiwan's air links with the Philippines is certain to affect Taiwan businesses' willingness to make investments in the Philippines, said Taipei officials on Friday.
Because of the failure to resolve the dispute over seat quotas, Taiwan on Friday announced the suspension of its aviation relationship with Manila.

Officials with the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said that in a short period of time, this will increase operating costs for Taiwan investors in the Philippines as the electronics industry relies heavily on airplanes to transport its products.
They said that in the long run, the willingness of Taiwan businesses to invest will be affected, causing losses for the Philippines.
Official statistics showed that of all foreign investment in the Philippines, Taiwan's share is the fifth largest.
The value of Taiwan investments in Subic Bay amount to US$310 million, while the figure for all other areas is tallied at US$753 million.

Meanwhile, according to a Central News Agency report from Manila, the Federation of Taiwan Businesses Associations in the Philippines issued a statement on Friday to call on Taipei and Manila to resume air links as soon as possible.

Saying that the suspension of air links will cause inconvenience and losses for both sides and will affect the two countries' friendly relations, the statement urged the two governments to reopen negotiations soon.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Saturday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The government has spent over NT$10 billion in quake-relief.
The China Times:
Military servicemen suspected of committing crime will be subject to three trials.
The United Daily News:
Those who are convicted of manipulating consumer prices can be fined up to NT$25 million.
The Liberty Times:
The legislature passed an amendment bill to the military court law on Friday.
The Commons Daily:
A so-called Taiwan delegation appeared in a rally in Beijing marking PRC's 50th anniversary.
The China Post:
ROC-Philippine direct flights halted indefinitely.
The Taiwan News:
62 builders probed in quake collapses.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING SCHEME UNDERMINES TAIWAN'S LAUNCH OF SATELLITE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's launch of the ROCSAT-2, the island's second satellite for scientific research, was again delayed due to interference from Beijing, sources from the National Science Council (NSC) said on Saturday.

The project is doomed to be delayed because the contracted German builder of the ROCSAT-2 -- Dornier Satellite System GmbH -- can not obtain an export permit from the German government, according to NSC officials.
NSC Chairman Huang Cheng-tai declined to comment whether the ROCSAT-2 development project will consequently be aborted. His only comment was, "let's do our utmost for the country."
According to sources, Dornier has made out a contingent proposal that aims to keep the launch plan in place while simultaneously avoiding direct confrontation with Beijing over the issue.
NSC and Dornier signed a contract on Feb. 8 of this year to jointly build the ROCSAT-2 spacecraft as well as one of the two payload systems to be installed on the satellite.

Under the agreement, NSC's Space Program Office (SPO) and Dornier will form a concerted team of specialists to jointly complete the spacecraft's design and make up, develop and manufacture spacecraft parts and components, as well as assist relevant Taiwan companies develop sub-system parts and components.

According to the agreement, Dornier will develop a payload system -- a remote sensing instrument -- for the satellite. The payload system will have a high resolution and varied-band spectra to give the research and communications satellite high-performance capabilities. The capabilities include the scanning and identifying of objects two meters from the ground surface.
It is known that Beijing has constantly interfered with the project. Beijing claims the ROCSAT-2 will be used to conduct espionage activities as it will carry a high-performance camera.

The ROCSAT-2 was originally scheduled to be launched in late 2002. However, due to Beijing's interference, the German government beginning early this year, has on three separate occasions postponed giving Dornier an export permit.
According to the agreement, Dornier must return the US$600,000 deposit to Taiwan if it fails to obtain an export permit by the end of August.
As of Saturday, the SPO has yet to receive its deposit back from Dornier. Huang added that the space office has already suspended payments for any further costs concerning the satellite.

Despite the absence of an export permit, SPO and Dornier actually began their development cooperation in March, when an eight-member SPO mission was sent to Germany to work in a Dornier-contracted laboratory in the southern German town of Friedrichshafen.
Several Taiwan companies, including Shihlin Electric & Engineering, Acer and Yung Tay Engineering, have also joined part and component development plans for ROCSAT-2, according to Huang.
Taiwan's first commercial satellite, ROCSAT-1, was successfully launched in January of this year.
Taiwan originally planned to have three scientific and communications satellites in orbit by the year 2006, at an estimated cost of US$500 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC NOT TO HIKE PETROLEUM PRICE IN OCTOBER

TEXT.P: The state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) said on Saturday that despite the rising cost of crude oil, it is not planning to hike the price of petroleum this month.
CPC officials said that the corporation imported 22.55 million barrels of crude oil in September at a cost of US$20.13 per barrel. This compared with US$18.15 per barrel in August.
They noted that during the past week, West Texas crude averaged US$24.5 per barrel, adding that with the surge of world crude oil prices, CPC is under pressure to hike its price.
However, in order to stabilize domestic prices in the wake of the 7.3-magnitude earthquake that hit Taiwan on Sept. 21, CPC has temporarily decided not to hike the price of petroleum.
The CPC officials said that they will review the domestic price situation and reconstruction progress before making a decision on whether to rise the price of petroleum in November.
To reflect rising import costs, CPC has hiked the price of petroleum four times since April of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PROVIDING MODEL OF DEVELOPMENT TO CHINA: EDITORIAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan is an alternative model for mainland China in Beijing's drive towards further economic and political development into the 21st century, the Australian Financial Review said Saturday in an editorial.

The editorial, titled "Time Is Ripe for Some Soul Searching in China, said "Taiwan provides an alternative model of political and economic development to the communist model. China needs to recognize this to avoid conflict over Taiwan's future."
It says two decades of market-oriented economic reform under the Communist Party have brought wealth and stability to some Chinese.
"But the inefficiency of state-owned enterprises and the difficulty of burying losses in a modernizing banking system are putting a brake on future economic growth," the editorial says.
It says despite its economic reform, China still needs more reforms in order to join the World Trade Organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA PRESSING FOR EARLY UN ADMINISTRATION IN EAST TIMOR

TEXT.P: Australia is pushing for an early UN administration in East Timor so that the former Portuguese colony can return to normal following its recent sufferings from violence and killings by pro-Jakarta militias.

Australia's Defense Force Chief -- Admiral Chris Barrie -- is expected to visit the United States next week as part of a broad drive by the Australian government to speed up the establishment of a UN transitional administration in East Timor, according to local news report.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN COUPLES USE IVF TO CHOOSE SEX OF THEIR BABIES

TEXT.P: Wealthy fertile couples in Australia are undergoing IVF and paying a US$6,500 fee to choose the sex of their babies, the Sydney Morning Herald reported on Saturday.

The daily quoted Professor Robert Jensen, medical director of Sydney IVF, as saying that doctors are using genetic analysis to determine whether embryos produced using IVF are male or female before transferring one or two embryos of the preferred sex to the mother.

DOC.HEADLINE: TREASURER SEES AUSTRALIA'S LONG-TERM ECONOMIC GROWTH AT 3.5-4 PCT

TEXT.P: Federal Treasurer Peter Costello has an optimistic view of Australia's economic performance, saying the country's gross domestic product could grow between 3.5 and 4 percent a year in the coming decade.

The new forecast is higher than the earlier projection of about 3 percent because the global economy is expected to improve, which will help maintain Australia's economic growth at high levels, Costello said on Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOTHING NEW IN JIANG ZEMIN'S 50TH ANNIVERSARY SPEECH

TEXT.P: Despite Beijing reiterated on Friday that it would push ahead toward peaceful unification with Taiwan under the "one country, two systems" policy, its strategy of achieving the goal by military threat has not changed, a ruling Kuomintang (KMT) official said Friday.

Chang Jung-kung, director of the KMT's mainland affairs department, made the remarks in reaction to mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin's speech at Tienanmen square marking the 50th anniversary of the founding of the People's Republic of China.
Chang said there was nothing new in Jiang's speech, stressing that Beijing's strategy of "forcing a peaceful unification through military intimidation" has not changed.

Commenting on Jiang's claim that "... socialism is the only way to save and develop China," Chang said that in light of historic developments, Jiang's wording should be corrected to "only China is saving socialism from collapse."
Chang noted that only when mainland China accelerates economic development and pushes for democratic reforms can cross-strait relations be harmoniously developed.

He said President Lee Teng-hui's proposal last week that the proper way for cross-strait relations to develop would be under the precepts of "ruling separately while standing at parity," "peaceful competition," and "unification under the principle of democracy." Chang said the precepts definitely defined the contents of Taiwan's policy toward mainland China.

Chang suggested that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait resolve their disputes through dialogue and warned that if Beijing continues to impose military threats on Taiwan, the alienation across the strait would only widen.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO TAIWAN CARRIERS CONTINUE CHARTERED FLIGHTS TO PHILIPPINES

TEXT.P: The sky over the Bashi Channel between the Republic of China and the Philippines was quiet on Saturday as the two countries have suspended scheduled direct flight services.

The Manila downtown and airport offices of the two Taiwan carriers -- China Airlines (CAL) and EVA Airways -- which originally operated scheduled flights between Taiwan and the Philippines remain open on Saturday to handle the aftermath.
The two carriers arranged for Taipei-bound passengers who had made reservations to take a Cathay Pacific Airways (CPA) flight from Manila to Taipei via Hong Kong.
CAL and EVA executives said their service counters at the Manila airport will continue operations for at least one week to arrange for passengers to transfer to other airlines.
Travel agencies in Manila have long not accepted reservations for Manila-Taipei and Manila-Kaohsiung flights and demanded that passengers take CPA flights to Taipei or Kaohsiung via Hong Kong.

According to airline sources, a CPA flight ticket from Manila to Taipei via Hong Kong costs about US$400, nearly 60 percent higher than the price offered by CAL and EVA for a direct flight from Manila to Taipei.

Meanwhile, in the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung, CAL arranged for 70-plus passengers who originally planned to take its CI-637 flight to Manila early Saturday morning to transfer to other flights due to the suspension of direct Taiwan-Philippine airlinks.

Thirty-one of those passengers took CAL's CI-623 flight to Hong Kong at 8 a.m. They would then took a British Airways flight to Manila from Hong Kong. The remaining 42 passengers took CAL's CI-625 flight to Hong Kong at 1 p.m. This group of passengers then took a CPA flight to Manila. As CAL didn't exact additional charges for such transfers, all passengers accepted the carrier's arrangements.

CAL said those who made reservations and purchased tickets before Saturday will all be exempted from paying additional charges for "detoured" flights. However, those who purchase tickets after Saturday will have to pay differentials between direct and indirect flights.
In contrast, EVA has chosen to offer refunds to its clients as it only has limited number of flights to Hong Kong.

The ROC's Civil Aeronautics Administration on Friday announced suspension of scheduled flights between Taiwan and the Philippines, effective Saturday, after negotiations failed in a last-ditch effort to address disputes over airline seat quotas for each side.
For the time being, bilateral airborne traffic will only rely on chartered flights operated by two Taiwan carriers -- Far East Air Transport Corp. and U-Land Air Lines.

Far East now only operates chartered flights between Kaohsiung and the Subic Bay, a stronghold for Taiwan-invested companies in the Philippines. An airline executive said the company will suspend chartered Kaohsiung-Subic Bay flights a month later.

U-Land Air Lines currently operates chartered flights from Taiwan to two Philippine tourist resorts -- Cebu and Laoag. The company said it has yet to decide when to suspend its chartered flight services to the two Philippine cities.
