DOC.HEADLINE: CHARITY SALE AND BONSAI EXHIBITION OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A four-day charity sale of valuable bonsai and a collection of stones depicting scenery began on Saturday at the Taipei International Convention Center to benefit the victims of the "921 Earthquake."
The charity activity came as part of the 5th Asia-Pacific Bonsai, Suiseki, Chinese Old Pottery Convention and Exhibition, which opened Saturday and will last until Tuesday.

It was the first time that the biannual international exhibition of bonsai and ornamental stones was held in Taiwan. The exhibition is jointly-sponsored by the China External Trade Development Council and the Bonsai Art Association of Republic of China.

Bonsai gardeners and ornamental stones collectors from 23 nations around the world participated in Saturday's exhibition by displaying hundreds of examples of exquisite bonsai works and collected stones with natural and story features. Japanese collectors call the art of collecting the stones "Suiseki."

Over 100 pieces of antique Chinese bonsai pottery, from the Sun, Ming, Yuan, and Ching dynasties, are also on display. In addition to the exhibition, there will be workshops, in which bonsai artists, as well as stone and old pottery collectors, from Germany, Indonesia, Japan, South Korea and Taiwan, will deliver speeches regarding their experience and involvement in collecting and/or creating the unique art form.

The first Asia-Pacific bonsai, stone and Chinese antique pottery exhibition and convention was initiated by former Indonesian Minister of Justice Ismail Saley, a bonsai and ornamental stones lover, in June of 1991 on Bali Island, Indonesia.
The unprecedented activity, entitled "Friendship through Bonsai," attracted more than 1,000 participants from over 20 countries during its first day.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose 0.3 cent against the US dollar in thin trading on the Taipei foreign exchange market Saturday, closing at 31.783.
Saturday's closing level was the highest in 15 days.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$80 million, the lowest level in a single day in four months.
The local currency opened at 31.784, the lowest level of the day, and was traded between 31.775 and 31.784.
Trading was thin on Saturday mainly because investors apoted a wait-and-see attitude on the eve of weekend holiday.
US dollar's bearishness and Japanese yen's bullishness on international markets have prompted major Asaian currencies to an upward trend.

Dealers said despite Taiwan suffers from the massive earthquake that severely hit the central part of the island on Sept. 21, foreign capital continue to inject into Taiwan stock market. This is helpful for NT dollar to maintain its bullish trend against the US dollar, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING MAY USE QUAKE TO DRIVE WEDGE BETWEEN GOVERNMENT AND PEOPLE: MND

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) on Saturday urged the public to be on guard against attempts by Beijing to use the devastating "921 earthquake" to drive a wedge between the government and the people here.

MND officials said that local people should remain alert to any attempt by Beijing to use the tragedy to undermine the public's trust toward the government, saying that in the past Beijing has systematically used ploys to undermine the government.

They said that local people should be aware that the government has devoted all its effort to relief and reconstruction efforts since the massive quake hit Taiwan on Sept. 21. The killer tremor has claimed more than 2,200 lives and injured over 8,700 others to date.
The officials also said that military police will increase patrols in the earthquake-stricken areas to ensure order and security is maintained.

Although large numbers of military personnel have contributed to rescue and reconstruction efforts in the wake of the massive quake, the defense officials said the combat readiness of the military has not been compromised.
They reported that the military continues to closely monitor the mainland Chinese military to prevent any attempt to ambush or infiltrate Taiwan while the island recovers from the earthquake.

They said that Beijing's military movements have remained normal in the wake of the quake. Intelligence reports do not indicate that Beijing will attempt any military move, since any action would risk international condemnation.

The MND officials added that immediately after the massive earthquake the ministry set up a contingency center. The center's responsibilities are to keep abreast of all relief efforts, heed the needs of the quake stricken people, maintain order and collect public opinion.
In addition, four advance command posts have also been set up in the most seriously damaged areas of Nantou, Hsinser, Sungshan and Hsinchuang in order to increase all-out rescue and relief efforts.

DOC.HEADLINE: 4.7-MAGNITUDE QUAKE HITS EASTERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: An earthquake measuring 4.7 on the open-ended Richter scale rattled Hualien in eastern Taiwan at 12:54 p.m. on Saturday, according to officials of the Central Weather Bureau (CWB).
The tremor occurred 31.5 kilometers west of Hualien, and originated one kilometer beneath the earth's surface, said the CWB officials.
The epicenter of the quake was located at 23.94 degrees of latitude north of the equator, and 121.30 degrees of longitude east of the prime meridian.
The temblor had an intensity of 4.0 in Hualien County, 3.0 in the city of Hualien, 2.0 at the Sun Moon Lake in Nantou County and 1.0 in Gookang Township of Yunlin County.

A slightly-less powerful quake, with a magnitude of 4.6 on the Richter scale occurred at 2:25 a.m. on Saturday, 13.7 kilometers east of the Sun Moon Lake in central Taiwan. That quake originated 10.2 kilometers beneath the surface of the earth.
The epicenter of the minor temblor was located at 23.91 degrees of latitude north of the equator, and 121.03 degrees of longitude east of the prime meridian.
It registered an intensity of 3.0 at Sun Moon Lake in Nantou County, 2.0 in Ilan County and Taichung City and 1.0 in Yunlin County and the city of Hualien.

Many geologists and legislators from the opposition New Party worried about the island's geological education in terms of the relevant department's indifference to earth science. This indifference they said has resulted in the general public lacking fundamental geological common sense.
The island's geological experts suggested, among other things, that all daily seismometrical work be placed under the Central Geological Investigation Institute, instead of under the CWB.

DOC.HEADLINE: 157 PEOPLE BENEFITED FROM VICTIMS PROTECTION LAW

TEXT.P: A total of 157 people had benefited from the Victims of Crime Protection Law as of the end of September, the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) reported on Saturday.
The ministry released the tally in connection with the celebration of the first anniversary of the enforcement of the Victims of Crime Protection Law.
Justice Minister Yeh Chin-fong told a news conference that the law has provided rays of light and hope for victims of crime by offering them protection and financial compensation.

Noting that each application for protection or financial compensation implies a hard-to-heal wound to the victim and his or her family, Yeh said measures taken under the protection law have helped warm up their broken hearts.

Yeh went on to say that the implementation of the crime victims protection law also symbolizes a change in the government's criminal policy, shifting from solely emphasizing investigation of evidence of crime to seeking a balance between probing evidence and protecting victims of criminal activities.

Since the law took effect on Oct. 1, 1998, Yeh said local people have gradually become familiar with its provisions and that the number of applicants for benefits of the law has also increased steadily.

"The accumulated amount of compensation given to those who were seriously injured or crippled due to other people's criminal activities and to bereaved families of those who were murdered now approaches NT$10 million per month," Yeh said.
Quoting MOJ tallies, Yeh said accumulated financial compensation offered to crime victims had reached NT$54.23 million as of Sept. 30.

To establish a comprehensive judicial protection network for crime victims, Yeh said the MOJ pushed for the formation of an independent crime victims protection association in January this year. The association has so far set up 21 branch offices throughout the island to offer timely services and protection for crime victims.

In addition, Yeh said the ministry has pooled resources with other government agencies, including the Ministry of Education, the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Ministry of Finance, the Council of Labor Affairs and the Government Information Office, to offer necessary support and assistance to victims of domestic violence, rape and traffic accidents.

DOC.HEADLINE: EARTHQUAKE FURTHER SADDENS LESS-PRIVILEGED ABORIGINES

TEXT.P: The Sept. 21 devastating earthquake that gave Central Taiwan a geographical facelift by flattening peaks and creating lakes, has also uprooted aboriginal homes and shattered their fates.

After the deadliest earthquake this century struck Taiwan, all roads leading to aboriginal villages in the Hsinyi and Jenai townships of Nantou County, just near the epicenter, were blocked and damaged, stranding members of the Atayal and Bunun tribes on a completely isolated island.

Most of the survivors were elderly, women and children. To keep them alive in the wake of the earthquake, physically strong young men toiled round-the-clock on collapsed mountains, carrying water and food back to the village.
Because the roads the younger men of the tribe used had rocks continually falling from toppled mountains, each trip took at least six hours.
Aboriginal policemen, numbering a mere five in the Hsinyi and Jenai areas, became one of the last-remaining hopes of the stranded tribal people.

Two of the policemen, Chuan Chung-ming and Sung Chao-tien in their Han Chinese names, climbed onto demolished mountains in an effort to save seven elders. Since roads and adjacent mountains had been washed away by landslides, the duo braved a turbulent river using ropes to connect them to reach the elders. They helped the weak elders swim to the opposite bank and to safety before carrying them on their backs one by one to their police station for settlement.

Representatives of 16 aboriginal and supporting groups met in Taipei Saturday to solicit relief and reconstruction assistance for the Atayal and Bunun people who have made the mountains of Central Taiwan their homes for centuries.

At the gathering, which carried the theme of "Meihomisan, Muhuaishu," the participants encouraged the Atayal and Bunun tribes people to "live well" and to "hang on." "Meihomisan," a Bunun phrase, means to live and survive well, while "Muhuaishu," an Atayal group of words, means to hang on and be strong.
The representatives said the aborigines were not only the last groups of survivors to receive relief goods, they also received the least amount of the least-wanted supplies.

According to Army sources, units of which have been assigned to take up reconstruction and rehabilitation responsibilities in earthquake-stricken areas, there is only enough food in the aboriginal Jenai Township to feed stricken people there for three to five more days.
A scarcity of food and clean water coupled with deteriorating sanitation are threatening to worsen the overall post-disaster condition in the two mountainous townships, according to the military.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES, INDEX FUTURES HEAD SOUTH

TEXT.P: Selling pressure on electronics issues outplayed the strong buying of construction material stocks, resulting in a decline of share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Saturday.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index slid 35.44 points to close at 7,659.55.
A total of 3.29 billion shares changed hands on a turnover of NT$118.22 billion (US$3.72 billion). Friday's turnover was NT$107.2 billion.
Advancers led decliners 251 to 220, with 54 shares remaining unchanged.
The over-the-counter market dropped 2.27 points to close at 172.26 on a turnover of NT$5.42 billion.

TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for October moved down 49 points to close at 7,599, with 2,083 contract transactions, while those for November declined 89 points to finish at 7,590, with 60 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for December sank 109 points to close at 7,521, with six contract transactions; those for next March slipped 6 points to end at 7,650, with one contract transaction; and June futures declined 140 points to end at 7,590, with 12 contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Saturday were 7,648 points for October, 7,679 points for November, 7,630 points for December, 7,656 points for next March, and 7,730 points for next June.

DOC.HEADLINE: RED CROSS SOCIETY PRESENTS US$ 1.55 M. TO MILITARY TO FEED PEOPLE

TEXT.P: The Red Cross Society of the Republic of China on Saturday presented a check of NT$50 million (US$1.55 million) to the military to feed thousands of people in earthquake-stricken regions currently living in military shelters.
Henry Hsu, president of the Red Cross Society, said the money will be used to buy food for the estimated 11,000 people taking refuge in 19 military shelters.

Hsu noted that donations from all walks of life have been pouring in to the society since the killer quake hit Taiwan on Sept. 21. Hsu stressed the relief society wants to send the money to those most needy.
The Red Cross Society earlier appropriated NT$120 million (US$3.72 million) for the construction of 1,000 temporary housing units for quake-stricken people.
Minister of National Defense Tang Fei expressed his appreciation to the Red Cross Society, saying that the money is urgently needed to carry on reconstruction work.
Tang also said that the military would soon cease participating in search and rescue efforts, but emphasized that military personnel would remain at quake-stricken areas for the time being.

DOC.HEADLINE: US URGES PRC, TAIWAN NOT TO HEIGHTEN TENSIONS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 1 (CNA) (By Jay Chen & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: The spokesman for the US Department of State, James Rubin, said on Friday that mainland China and Taiwan should refrain from any action that might raise tensions across the Taiwan Strait.

He made the remarks while answering a question concerning the statement by mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji on Thursday that US support for Taiwan had emboldened President Lee Teng-hui and was making war inevitable.
Zhu reportedly told a group of foreign business leaders in Shanghai that "sooner or later, an armed resolution will settle the question, because the Chinese people will become very impatient."

Rubin noted that "it is not a new position for China to view the US implementation of the Taiwan Relations Act or any other aspects of our policy as one of the reasons Taiwan does not proceed on a course that China would prefer on any given subject."

"So there is nothing new," he pointed out, adding that "we are aware of these remarks attributed to him. We believe both sides should have a sense of responsibility for peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait, and should refrain from statements or actions that raise tensions."

Rubin went on to say that "our statements and actions have been designed to reduce tensions and promote a peaceful resolution of differences. That is what we have been doing and we certainly hope others do the same."

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR MORE ALLIES SPEAK FOR ROC'S UN BID
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 1 (CNA) (By K. C. Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Four more countries -- Malawi, the Commonwealth of Dominica, Haiti and Grenada -- voiced support for the Republic of China's bid to re-join the United Nations at a UN General Assembly debate session on Friday.

Malawi Foreign Affairs and International Cooperation Minister Brown Mpinganjira said at the session that the United Nations should consider issues related to the ROC's representation in the world body based on the principle of membership universality and respect for national equality.
Noting that the ROC is a democratic country with a population of more than 21 million, Mpinganjira said the United Nations should not continue to ignore its existence.
The Malawi minister stressed that he believes the ROC's re-entry to the UN and its affiliated organizations will be an important factor to international peace, stability and cooperation.

Speaking on the same occasion, Dominica Foreign Minister Norris Charles said the ROC is democratic model in Asia and has the capability and willingness to fulfill the obligations stipulated in the UN Charter.

Over the past decades, Charles said the ROC has scored remarkable achievements in economic development, which has enabled it to help other developing countries to fight against poverty through various aid programs.

Charles said his country is concerned that the United Nations has rejected the admission of such an industrialized country which has a democratically elected government to exercise sovereignty on a clearly defined territory.
The United Nations must take steps to correct this unfair situation to ensure that the people of the Republic of China on Taiwan have a voice in the world body and its affiliated organizations.

Meanwhile, Haitian Foreign Minister Emmanuel Fritz Lonchamp expressed his country's concern about the development of relations across the Taiwan Strait, urging the two sides of the strait to take appropriate measures to create an environment for forging mutual trust, respect and goodwill. By so doing, Lonchamp said he believes that people on both sides of the strait will benefit.
Lonchamp also expressed regards for victims of recent natural catastrophes in Turkey, Taiwan, the Bahamas and the United States.

Vice Foreign Minister of Grenada Mark Isaac also said at the session that the United Nations should review its Resolution No. 2758 adopted in 1971, which gave the China seat to mainland China at the expense of the ROC.

Praising the ROC as a democratic country fully upholding humanitarianism, Isaac said the ROC has generously used its hard-earned money to help other developing countries. "The ROC has assisted in manpower training and provided professional expertise and capital aid to help other countries become self-reliant," he noted.
Isaac further said that the ROC has created an economic miracle, becoming the world's 14th largest trading power and holding one of the world's largest foreign exchange stash.

Stressing that the international community should not ignore such a vibrant and generous country, Isaac said the United Nations should respect the 22 million ROC people's basic right to take part in UN activities.
During the UN General Assembly's two-week general debate session, many other countries, mostly the ROC's diplomatic allies, have also spoken for the ROC's UN bid.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT LEADERS INSPECT QUAKE STRICKEN AREAS IN NANTOU
DOC.DATELINE: Nantou, central Taiwan, Oct. 2 (CNA) (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Amid breathless reconstruction efforts in areas of Nantou County severely damaged by the "921 Earthquake," ranking government officials on Saturday overseed how reconstruction works are being carried out.

President Lee Teng-hui on Saturday visited Puli, Nantou County, the town near the epicenter of the 7.3-magnitude earthquake, which occurred Sept. 21, claiming more than 2,100 lives around Taiwan and leaving over 8,700 injured.

After being briefed at Puli's relief headquarters concerning military relief operations, Lee appeared concerned about how quake victims were being sheltered, waste eliminated, houses and buildings in dangerous condition dismantled, and temporary houses built for those who lose their home in the massive earthquake.
The president asked local authorities to listen to the people's voice, as well as to the opinions of experts and scholars, when rebuilding Puli.

Meanwhile, Vice President Lien Chan, accompanied by Chairman Chau Shuo-puo of the Taiwan Provincial Government, inspected the site chosen in Shueili village for the establishment of a shelters complex for quake victims.

Lien called the 16-hectare land, owned by the state-run Taiwan Power Company, perfect for the planned shelter. The land will eventually hold more than 1,500 prefabricated houses. Lien instructed that the work continue without hesitation.
"There is no need for you to ask for instructions or approvals of upper authorities on the works that should be done immediately," Lien stressed to Shueili village leadership.

At another quake stricken area in Nantou, Premier Vincent Siew revealed that a private donation quake fund management foundation will soon be set up to assist on-going governmental efforts in relief and post-quake reconstruction.
Siew noted Koo Chen-fu, leader of the Koo's Group and a prominent business tycoon who is also Taipei's top negotiator to Beijing, is considered the best man to chair the planned foundation.

In related news, Vice Premier Liu Chao-hsuan announced in Taichung that the government has finished a short-term employment plan, aimed at providing work opportunities to quake victims, allowing them to have a chance to "earn their own relief aid."

Liu said that 20 job introduction centers around the island, run by the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs, have been mobilized for the mission. So far more than 1,300 quake victims have responded to the employment program, by seeking a temporary job, he noted.
The vice premier is also the executive-in-chief of the Executive Yuan's commission for the promotion of post-quake reconstruction works.

DOC.HEADLINE: DONATIONS FROM OVERSEAS CHINESE COMMUNITIES TOP US$ 16.9 MILLION

TEXT.P: Cash donations for victims of the Sept. 21 Chichi earthquake from overseas Chinese communities around the world have topped NT$540 million (US$16.9 million), said Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission Vice Chairman Hung Teng-kuei on Saturday.
"This indicates the unity and oneness of the Chinese people at home and abroad," Hung told the media.
After the devastating temblor, registered 7.3 on the Richter scale, rocked central Taiwan before dawn on Sept. 21, overseas Chinese communities started to raise fund for the displaced people.
As of Saturday, Hung said, overseas Chinese communities in 37 countries and areas have contributed NT$540 million.

Meanwhile, according to a Central News Agency report from Los Angeles, donations from the Greater Los Angeles alone exceed US$6.84 million. Of the figure, US$3.6 million was raised by local chapters of the Hualien-based Buddhist Tzu Chi Association.
In addition to cash donations, several Chinese-American engineers and physicians residing in Los Angeles will leave for Taiwan in the next few days to join post-quake reconstruction and medical work.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO HOLD MEMORIAL SERVICE FOR QUAKE VICTIMS ON OCT. 11

TEXT.P: The central government has decided to hold a national memorial service at the Linkou Stadium on Oct. 11 to mourn the victims of the Sept. 21 Chichi earthquake.

A special committee for the memorial service will be organized under the direction of Vice President Lien Chan. During the service President Lee Teng-hui and civic leaders will deliver condolence messages.
Because of the devastating 7.3-magnitude temblor, the government canceled this year's National Day celebrations on Oct. 10.

The memorial service will be attended by government leaders, 2,000 representatives from religious and political groups, 500 representatives of industrial and commercial groups, 1,000 from educational groups and 2,000 civic group representatives.
More than 2,100 people were killed in the pre-dawn quake, and over 8,700 others were injured.

Meanwhile, the Kuomintang Business Management Committee and the ROC Tibetan Association announced they will jointly-sponsor a religious rite for victims of the quake at the Central Daily News building Sunday afternoon.
Leaders of the four sects of Tibetan Buddhism will be invited to preside over the rite.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Sunday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
President Lee Teng-hui said the assessment of quake-damaged houses must be completed in a week.
The China Times:
Yuan T. Lee, president of Academia Sinica, will head a national reconstruction alliance to coordinate relief efforts and reconstruction works in the wake of the killer earthquake.
The United Daily News:
Banks will only assume housing mortgages of quake victims if they rebuild their houses on the original sites.
The Liberty Times:
A third electricity transmission network will be completed next February to ease the present power shortage.
The Commons Daily:
Liu San-chi, deputy director general of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting & Statistics, lashed out at Nantou County Magistrate Pang Pai-shien for withholding some of the money earmarked for quake victims.
The China Post:
Taipei-Manila air link cut leaves travel agents hurting.
The Taiwan News:
Villagers return to roots after losing their homes.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE THAN 8,000 ROUNDS OF AMMUNITION GO MISSING

TEXT.P: More than 8,000 rounds of ammunition went missing from an air force base in northern Taiwan, the Air Force General Headquarters confirmed on Sunday.

The ammunition for 65K2 rifles of the logistics squadron stationed at Taoyuan Air Force Base were found to be missing during a check on Sunday morning. Someone had apparently broken into the munitions depot by tampering with the steel chain on the door.
The Air Force is working with police to investigate the case.
Police were informed of the theft at about 8:00 Sunday morning, but did not publicly announce the incident in the hope that the ammunition could be quickly retrieved.

Police said that as the quantity of missing ammunition is large, and the depot's location is somewhat secret, they suspected that someone familiar with the area around the depot, such as active or retired military personnel of the air force base, were responsible.
Taoyuan Air Force base recently staged the 1999 air show with performances and displays of various aircraft for public viewing.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA EXPRESSES APPRECIATION TO COUNTRIES THAT SUPPORT ROC IN UN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Sunday extended appreciation for the efforts of countries that support membership in the United Nations for the Republic of China.

During the UN General Assembly's general debate session from Sept. 20 to Oct. 2, 25 countries supported the ROC's UN bid, urging admission based on the principles of universal membership and respect for national equality.
The countries also expressed concern about a peaceful resolution of cross-strait issues and extended condolences for victims of the killer earthquake that rocked Taiwan Sept. 21.

MOFA officials noted that since the commencement of separate government of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait in 1949, the ROC has practiced democracy and become the legitimate representative of 22 million people residing in Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu.
They said that Beijing is trying to create a facade that Taiwan is only a local government by claiming that it represents Taiwan in the international community.

The officials said that Beijing's request that other countries get its approval before lending support to rescue operations in the wake of the Sept. 21 earthquake is a gross violation of humanitarian principles and a move that they said has demonstrated how ridiculous and unreasonable is the exclusion of Taiwan from the UN.
They said the unfair treatment of Taiwan needs to be addressed and corrected.

The officials noted that the bid to join the UN has been a common aspiration of the people of Taiwan, and a long-term goal of the government. They urged the public to be prepared to strive toward that goal.

The 25 countries, mostly ROC allies, that supported the ROC during the UN General Assembly session were: Belize, Burkina Faso, Chad, Costa Rica, the Commonwealth of Dominica, El Salvador, Gambia, Grenada, Guatemala, Haiti, Honduras, Liberia, Malawi, the Marshall Islands, Nicaragua, Paraguay, Saint Kitts and Nevis, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, Senegal, the Solomon Islands, Swaziland, Macedonia, the Czech Republic, Papua New Guinea, and Micronesia.

DOC.HEADLINE: COLOMBIA TO SIMPLIFY BUSINESS VISA APPLICATION FOR ROC NATIONALS

TEXT.P: Colombia has decided to simplify the procedure for Republic of China nationals to apply for business visas for the South American nation, the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) said on Sunday.
The new simplified procedure requires an application fee of US$150 and just three working days, BOFT officials said.
The officials said Colombia's move will help step up substantial trade relations and boost bilateral exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Oct. 3, or the 24th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1226: St. Francis of Assisi, founder of the Franciscan Order, dies at the age of 45. He displayed the wounds of Christ (the stigmata) and endured great pain during the first two years of his life.
1863: US President Abraham Lincoln officially designates the last day in November a national holiday, to be called Thanksgiving Day.
1867: Elias Howe, US inventor and manufacturer who designed early sewing machines, dies at the age of 48. He patented the sewing machine and made US$2 million from it and subsequently won patent-infringement suits against a number of manufacturers, including Isaac M. Singer.
1888: Carl von Ossietzky, German journalist and pacifist who won the 1935 Nobel Peace Prize, is born. He was imprisoned for exposing Germany's military buildup.
1896: William Morris, British poet, painter, designer, craftsman and social reformer, dies at his London home at the age of 62. He put much of his considerable energy into promoting socialist ideals through his writing and, later, the formation of the Socialist League.
1906: SOS is established at the Berlin Radio Conference as the international distress call, replacing the call sign CDQ which was supposed to mean "all stations--urgent," but was sometimes interpreted as "come damn quick!"
1929: Yugoslavia becomes the official name of the Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes.
1932: Iraq becomes independent after the British mandate ends.
1941: Chubby Checker, US signer whose song "The Twist" becomes an international dance hit and was followed by more hits such as "Let's Twist Again" and "Slow Twistin'," is born.
1941: L.D. Goodhue and W.N. Sullivan patent their aerosol in the United States.
1952: The first British atomic weapon is exploded today off the Monte Bello Islands, west of Australia.
1957: The Berlin city assembly makes history today by voting in 44-year-old Willy Brandt, its youngest ever "oberburgermeister," or mayor.
1963: President Ramon Villeda Morales of Honduras is overthrown by a military coup.
1966: Lesotho, which was formerly governed by Britain as the protectorate of Basutoland, becomes independent.
1968: President Ferdinando Belaunde Terry of Peru is overthrown in a coup by the National Revolutionary junta led by Velasco Alvarado.
1970: "Yu Chao," the first 100,000-ton oil tanker built in Taiwan, is launched. "Yu Chao" is the name of a legendary Chinese ruler who taught the people to build tree houses for protection against wild beasts.
1972: US President Richard M. Nixon and Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko sign pact limiting the number of defensive missiles of each of the two countries to 200.
1977: Former Indian Prime Minister Indira Gandhi is arrested on corruption charges.
1984: Some 7,100 reindeer drown while trying to cross a river in northern Quebec in Canada.
1989: Troops loyal to Panamanian strongman General Manuel Antonio Noriega crush a coup attempt by junior officers.
1990: Singapore and communist China establish diplomatic relations.
1990: East and West Germany formally unite and becomes the single nation of Germany with Berlin as its capital and Helmut Kohl as provisional chancellor.
1995: Manuel Saturnino da Costa, prime minister of Guinea-Bissau, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1997: A powerful earthquake rocks central Italy, causing more damage to the frescoed interior of the 13th-century Basilica of St. Francis in Assisi.
1997: Japan's magnetically levitated train breaks the world speed record for a manned train when it clocks 451 kph on an experimental track west of Tokyo.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Confronted with the spiritual powers of the universe a man must be able to maintain it without any doubt. He must be prepared to wait a hundred generations after him for the coming of a man of perfect divine nature to confirm it without any misgiving."

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT CALLS ON PUBLIC TO LOOK FORWARD TO REBUILD FAMILIES

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Lien Chan on Sunday called on the island's public to look forward in the wake of the devastating Sept. 21 Chichi earthquake that caused more than 2,100 deaths.
He made the statement while delivering his condolence message at a Buddhist memorial rite for quake victims organized by the Nantou-based Chungtai Temple.
Extending condolences to families of those who died and to displaced residents, Lien said that he attended the rite with a very heavy heart.
He expressed the hope that the people of the island will "roll up sleeves and look forward to rebuild our families and gardens."
The religious memorial service, held in Taichung City and presided over by venerable master Weichueh, was attended by more than 1,000 Buddhist followers. It lasted 13 hours from 8 a.m. to 9 p.m.

Several political heavyweights also attended the rite, including Premier Vincent Siew, Legislative Yuan President Wang Chin-pyng, Vice President Yao Eng-chi, Kuomintang Secretary-General John Chang, former Taiwan Governor James Soong, former Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian, and former Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL: JAMES SOONG STILL LEADS IN POLL

TEXT.P: The results of an opinion poll conducted by the Global Broadcasting Co. showed former Taiwan Governor James Soong still led five other candidates, with support from 28.1 percent of respondents.

Soong was followed by the ruling Kuomintang's presidential candidate Vice President Lien Chan, backed by 17.9 percent of those interviewed. Trailing Lien was Chen Shui-bian, candidate of the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), supported by 15.1 percent of interviewees.
The telephone poll of 1,137 adults residing throughout the island was conducted by a local cable TV station between Sept. 30 and Oct. 1.

On the performance of the government and presidential candidates after the Sept. 21 earthquake that jolted Taiwan on Sept. 21, results show that Lien, head of the Postquake Relief Supervising Committee, was given an average of 63.27 points out of 100, compared to Soong's 64.27 and Chen's 60.14.

The same results showed that 28.1 percent of respondents said they would vote for former governor James Soong if the presidential election were to be held the following day. Soong was followed by Lien at a 17.9-percent support rate, and Chen trailed with backing from 15.1 percent of respondents.
The two other presidential hopefuls, Hsu Hsin-liang and Lee Ao, only received marginal support rates of 1.1 percent and 0.8 percent, respectively.
The poll showed that those interviewed awarded the central government 62.33 points for its performance in earthquake relief, while local governments received 64.4 points.

As for the performance of President Lee Teng-hui in earthquake relief efforts, 10 percent of interviewees reported "much satisfaction," 41.9 percent "satisfaction"; 25.7 percent "dissatisfaction" and 13.7 percent "complete dissatisfaction."

Only 4.4 percent reported "much satisfaction" with the performance of Premier Vincent Siew in earthquake relief efforts, 32.9 percent "satisfaction", 27.4 percent "dissatisfaction" and 13.6 percent "complete dissatisfaction".

More than 58.7 percent of the respondents said they were "very unhappy" with Beijing's attitude toward relief assistance from the international community after Taiwan's deadly earthquake, which has so far claimed over 2,200 lives.

DOC.HEADLINE: QUAKE-DAMAGED SUN MOON LAKE UPGRADED TO NATIONAL SCENIC AREA

TEXT.P: To facilitate reconstruction of Sun Moon Lake, the central and Nantou County governments decided to upgrade it from a provincial-level scenic area to a national one, Nantou County Magistrate Peng Pai-hsien said on Sunday.

The lake area suffered damage in the devastating earthquake that rocked Taiwan on Sept. 21. The national scenic area will be jointly managed and operated by the central government and the Nantou County government.

Kuanghua Island, situated in the center of the lake, will be renamed as Lalu Island, which is the name used by the local aboriginal Shao tribe, with the hope of honoring the souls of the Shao's ancestors, said Peng.
Several renowned hotels in the area that were damaged during the quake are not allowed to rebuild on their original sites until an overall reconstruction plan can be established, Peng added.
Sun Moon Lake, located in Nantou County in central Taiwan, was one of Taiwan's most famous tourist spots before the earthquake struck on Sept. 21.

In order to raise enough funds for the cash-strapped county that has relied heavily on agricultural products for tax revenue, the county magistrate said it is essential to develop the tourism industry to broaden the county's tax revenue source.

As a result, the lake was chosen as an important source of revenue, and Premier Vincent Siew has promised to pour in a considerable amount of capital to rebuild the lake which was once flooded with tourists.
As for Kuanghua Island, Peng said it was originally used by the Shao to worship their ancestors and renaming it Lalu Island actually restores its original name. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: BOND MARKET TRADING HIT US$1 TRILLION IN 8 MONTHS

TEXT.P: Local bond market transactions hit NT$33.8 trillion (US$1.04 trillion) in the first eight months of this year, according to statistics from the Central Bank of China (CBC).
The figure represents an increase of NT$548.8 billion (US$16.88 billion) over the same period last year.
CBC said that if the trend continues, bond market trading for the whole of this year is expected to again reach a new high.
Local bond market trading reached a record high of NT$54.95 trillion last year (US$1.7 trillion), a 15-fold increase from that of 1991, which totaled only NT$3.74 trillion.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN MEDICAL TEAM ARRIVES IN TAIWAN TO HELP QUAKE VICTIMS

TEXT.P: A Canadian government official and a 15-member private medical team from Canada arrived in Taipei to help people displaced by the Sept. 21 Chichi earthquake.

Raymond Chan, Canadian vice minister in charge of Asia-Pacific affairs, told the media at CKS International Airport that he came to Taiwan at the instruction of Canadian government leaders to see what kind of assistance Taiwan requires from Canada.
Chan said he has to leave Taiwan on Oct. 5 for an international conference, but the Canadian medical team will stay in Taiwan for about 10 days.
If Taiwan requires any assistance from Canada, he noted, he will consult with the Canadian government.

Shortly after their arrival at the airport, the Canadians proceeded to quake-stricken Nantou and Taichung areas to join local medical groups in providing medical assistance to those affected by the quake.
The team consists of four physicians, 10 nurses and one administrative assistant. Taiwan's Fo Kuang Shan Association is providing administrative help for the Canadian team.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Monday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Scope of bank buyout of housing mortgages in quake-stricken areas will be expanded to houses rebuilt in non-original sites.
The China Times:
Power rationing for industrial use was lifted from Monday as the quake-damaged power transmission line in central Taiwan resumed operations.
The United Daily News:
Starting Monday, power supply to manufacturing industries in northern Taiwan was not rationed as transmission of electricity generated in southern part of the island has resumed.
The Liberty Times:
US missile interceptor passes crucial test.
The Commons Daily:
DPP presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian calls for concerted efforts in post-earthquake relief and reconstruction operations.
The China Post:
Cooler weather eases islandwide power shortage.
The Taiwan News:
Outage times ease but rains hit hard.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPOWER LIFTS INDUSTRIAL POWER RATIONING

TEXT.P: Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) lifted its rationing of electricity on the industrial sector on Monday, one day earlier than promised, in the wake of the devastating Sept. 21 earthquake.

The end of the ration allowed some 1,000 high-voltage users in 12 industrial zones in northern Taiwan to resume full production. Power to the 12 zones was disrupted immediately after the killer earthquake struck central Taiwan. Even though some power was restored to Taiwan's industrial sector shortly after the earthquake, until Monday the industrial sector had been subject to the Taipower-imposed power rationing.

The killer earthquake, measuring 7.3 on the open-ended Richter scale, ruined high-voltage substations near the quake's epicenter in central Taiwan, resulting in widespread disruption of electricity to northern Taiwan.

Taipower, Taiwan's sole electricity supplier and distributor, managed to transmit 700,000 kilowatts of electricity generated from the Taichung Thermal Power Plant near the Taichung Harbor to northern Taiwan Monday by bypassing collapsed substations. It sent the power directly through the Omei Ultra-High Voltage Transmission Line near Hsinchu.
The north-bound transmission is expected to increase to 1.3 million to 1.5 million megawatts Tuesday, Taipower officials said.
Taipower officials meanwhile attributed cooler weather as another factor enabling Taipower to lift the industrial power rationing earlier than scheduled.

Monday's lift of industrial power rationing will help hundreds of electronic and high-technology companies in northern Taiwan located beyond the famous Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park to recalibrate their sensitive equipment and facilities.

The majority of Taiwan's computer and high-tech companies are located in northern Taiwan. The island produces more than half of the world's chip sets and motherboards, plus 45 percent of all notebook computers.

With more electricity expected to be transmitted from southern and central Taiwan to the north in following days, Taipower officials said household power rationing is expected to be lifted on Oct. 10.
Full power restoration for the entire island is expected on Oct. 12, they added.
Meanwhile, Taipower is striving to build the Third North-South 345 KV Ultra-High Voltage Transmission Line in order to ensure a steady supply of electricity in the long run, they said.
