DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Oct. 4, or the 25th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1669: Rambrandt van Rijn, Dutch painter whose works are unmatched in their portrayal of subtle human emotions, dies at the age of 63. His masterpieces include historical and religious scene, group portraits, such as "The Anatomy Lesson of Dr. Tulp," and "The Night Watch," as well as a series of self-portraits.
1777: US forces led by George Washington attack the British at Germantown but were repulsed.
1822: Rutherford B. Hayes, the 19th President of the United State, is born. Winning the controversial election of 1876 by one electoral vote, he pacified the South by removing federal troops in 1877 and supported the welfare of minority groups and reformed the civil service.
1824: Mexico becomes a republic.
1830: Belgium becomes an independent state after being part of the Netherlands since 1815.
1853: Turkey declares war on Russia after Russia refused to withdraw from the Danubian principalities (now Romania). Later, France, Britain and Sardinia join the Crimean War on Turkey's side.
1878: China opens its first embassy in the United States when Chen Lan-pin presents his credentials to President Rutherford B. Hayes.
1904: Frederic Auguste Bartholdi, French sculptor and the creator of the Statue of Liberty, dies at the age of 70.
1905: Orville Wright, American aviator, is the first person to fly an aircraft for more than 33 minutes.
1910: Portugal is proclaimed a republic as King Manuel II flees to Britain.
1924: Charlton Heston, American actor, is born. He was best known for his appearances in such film epics as "El Cid" and "Ben Hur", for which he won an Oscar.
1947: The Russians successfully launch Sputnik I, the world's first artificial satellite.
1947: Max Planck, German physicist, dies in his home in Gottingen at the age of 89. He won a 1918 Nobel Prize for discoveries in connection with the quantum theory.
1949: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with the USSR.
1949: The US State Department reaffirms its recognition of the Nationalist government as the only legal government of China.
1952: The pacemaker, an external device developed by Dr. Paul Zoll of the Harvard Medical School, is for the first time fitted to a human, David Schwarts, to control his heartbeat.
1969: Anthony Grey, a correspondent of Reuters, is freed from Beijing house arrest after being held by the Chinese communists for 20 months.
1978: The ROC Ministry of National Defense announces the successful development of the "Hsiung Feng" (male bee) missile.
1983: Richard Noble, a London businessman, wins the title of the world's fastest driver when his jet-powered Thrust 2 car smashes the existing record of American Gary Gabelich driving a Blue Falmes, by 11 mph with a run of 633.47 mph in the Black Rock Desert in Nevada.
1986: A 12-member political reform group of the Central Standing Committee of the Kuomintang (KMT) decides to announce the lifting of the emergency decree at a proper time and passed legislative principles for the National Security Law during the Period of Communist Rebellion.
1992: An Israeli cargo plane crashes into a residential area in Amsterdam, killing more than 200 peoples.
1993: Russian troops loyal to President Boris Yeltsin capture the parliament building in Moscow after two days of fighting in which more than 300 die. Vice President Alexander Rutskoi and other parliament leaders are herded into Lefortovo prison.
1994: An undersea earthquake rocks Russia's Kuril Islands, killing more than 16 people.
1995: O. J. Simpson, former American football star, is cleared by a jury of his murder charge. Simpson was charged with murdering his wife and her male friend.
1997: Princess Cristina of Spain marries Olympic handball star Inaki Urdangarin.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is true of the really great moral man, that every act of his life becomes an example for generations; everything he does becomes a statute for generations, and every word he utters becomes a law for generations."

DOC.HEADLINE: JIANG DROPS RHETORIC AGAINST TAIWAN FORM SPEECH: REPORT
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 4 (CNA) (By Ben Wu) (By Ken Su)

TEXT.P: Hong Kong, Oct. 04 (CNA)Mainland Chinese President Jiang ze-min scrapped a statement repeating Beijing's threats to use forces against Taiwan from his National Day address, taking the advice of his top advisers, the Hong Kong Standard reported today.

According to the report, Jiang refrained from repeating the tough stance in an effort to avoid further backlash from Taiwan after reports there of widespread public anger over Beijing's response to the earthquake in central Taiwan which killed more than 2,000 people and injured over 8,000 others.

DOC.HEADLINE: IOC SEEN MAKING BIG PROFIT FROM SYDNEY 2000 OLYMPIC GAMES

TEXT.P: The International Olympic Committee (IOC) is expected to milk big profits from the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games as Australian organizers continue their efforts to fill the US$91 million shortfall.

IOC vice president Dick Pound, who also serves as chairman of the IOC's marketing commission, told reporters in Athens on Sunday that the marketing drive in Sydney was the best in Olympic history, the Australian reported on Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRIVATE COMMISSION TO BE FORMED TO MANAGE DONATIONS FOR QUAKE RELIEF

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew said on Monday that the Cabinet will push for the establishment of a non-governmental commission to manage private donations for post-earthquake relief and reconstruction programs.

Siew made the statement at a meeting of a Cabinet special task force overseeing progress in post-quake rehabilitation work, which focused discussion on the management of private donations for helping surviving quake victims rebuild their homes and lives.

Preliminary tallies show that the special bank account opened by the Cabinet to accept private donations has so far received more than NT$4.63 billion from domestic corporations, civic organizations and individuals.

In addition, many local residents have also donated relief funds to various non-governmental organizations, with the accumulated amount estimated at NT$4 billion. Cabinet sources said the government still lacks a clear picture about this part of donations.
Noting that there are currently many channels to collect private donations, Premier Siew said he sees a need to integrate all these donations to ensure their effective use.

Siew said the Cabinet should take actions to organize an independent private commission to manage the huge funds, adding that the commission can be led by C. F. Koo, a respected business tycoon and senior adviser to President Lee Teng-hui.

Other social celebrities or elected representatives, including Academia Sinica President Yuan T. Lee and Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, can serve as the commission's board members, Siew said, adding that the proposed non-governmental fund management commission should manage the donations in line with the principles of justice, openness and transparency.
An earthquake, measuring 7.3 on the Richter scale, rattled Taiwan on Sept. 21, claiming more than 2,200 lives, injuring at least 8,700 others and leaving over 100,000 people homeless.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEGAWATI SEEN HEADING FOR INDONESIAN PRESIDENCY

TEXT.P: Indonesia's parliament -- People's Consultative Assembly (MPR) -- has decided to bring forward the presidential election by three weeks to October 20 in a bid to cut short the dangerous period in which Jakarta has a power vacuum.

In a dispatch from Jakarta, the Australian Financial Review reported the move is expected to give Megawati Sukarnoputri the chance of grabbing the presidency, replacing the current lame-duck President B.J. Habibie. (By Peter Chen) ENDTIEM ZCZC CEP009 10-04-99 UN READY TO AIRLIFT E. TIMORESE FROM WEST TIMOR

Canberra, Oct. 4 (CNA) The United Nations is preparing to airlift about 100,000 Timorese to Dili from West Timor after Indonesia agreed to allow them to return home while more bodies were found as a result of atrocities by pro-Jakarta militias against pro-independence supporters of the former Portuguese colony. The Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) on Monday noon reported the Australian-led UN peacekeeping force was tightening its grip on East Timor so that more East Timorese could return safely to their homeland.

The ABC reported the peace keepers discovered more bodies of East Timorese being dumped into wells, showing signs of atrocity by the militias when they pulled out to West Timor prior to the arrival of the UN force.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMED FORCES WILL CONTINUE TO AID POST-QUAKE RECONSTRUCTION: TANG

TEXT.P: The armed forces will stay in earthquake-stricken areas to help out with post-disaster reconstruction although the uniformed men and women have ceased participating in search and rescue efforts, Defense Minister Tang Fei said on Monday.
Tang added that the military will continue to provide stricken people with all the resources necessary to facilitate post-quake reconstruction.

On Monday the top defense official again made fact-finding tours of military bases in central Taiwan which bore the full blunt of the Sept. 21 devastating earthquake, the deadliest to hit Taiwan this century, with a death toll exceeding 2,200.

Tang visited two military bases in the hardest hit areas which are currently being used as makeshift relief camps as well as two temporary shelter bases built by the military several days after the deadly quake struck on Sept. 21.
Tang said since the killer quake rocked Taiwan, the military has mobilized 200,000 men to pitch in with rescue, search and emergency assistance work.
Now, 13 days after the quake, the military is focusing its work and attention on reconstruction, as well as accommodating and resettling survivors and people who were made homeless by the quake.
Some 11,000 people are currently taking refuge in 19 military shelter bases across central Taiwan, according to Tang.

Meanwhile, the Ministry of National Defense is preparing to build 235 temporary housing units in the now-demolished Tungshih Hospital. The former hospital's land will be converted into a rehabilitation complex for stricken people with convenient stores, an activity center, nursing homes, medical clinics and an amusement park for children in its vicinity, Tang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE QUAKES JOLT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: An earthquake measuring 4.7 on the open-ended Richter scale rocked central Taiwan at 5:13 a.m. Monday amid countless aftershocks from the devastating earthquake that struck the island Sept. 21, said sources from the Central Weather Bureau on Monday.

The temblor, with an epicenter some 21.5 kilometers northeast of scenic Sun Moon Lake in Taiwan's geographical heart, was found originating 4.5 kilometers beneath the earth's surface, the weather bureau's seismologists reported.
The temblor had an intensity of 3.0 in Mingchien in Nantou County and at Alishan (Mt. Ali) in Chiayi County, and 2.0 in Sihu in Yunlin County and in Chiayi City.

Later, at around 7:40 Monday morning, a magnitude-4.8 earthquake jolted the Central Mountain Range, the backbone of Taiwan, with an epicenter some 29.8 kilometers south of Yushan (Jade Mountain), the island's and Northeast Asia's highest peak, according to the weather bureau.
The temblor, believed to be unrelated to the catastrophic Sept. 21 earthquake and its aftershocks, also sent tremor waves to southern and eastern Taiwan, the seismologists said.

The quake had an intensity of 4.0 in Taoyuan in the southern county of Kaohsiung, 2.0 at Alishan and in Chiayi City, and 1.0 in Nanshi in Tainan County and in Chengkung in the eastern county of Taitung, according to the weather bureau.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNEXPECTED VISITORS RAISE IRE OF QUAKE-STRICKEN VICTIMS

TEXT.P: Unexpected visitors swarming into earthquake-stricken regions in central Taiwan caused gridlock on roads connecting the areas to the rest of the island over the weekend and hampered relief efforts.

The Nantou quake relief command post said that the large number of visitors to Nantou county has caused serious traffic jams, resulting in gridlock entrapment of many of the heavy trucks and vehicles that are being mobilized for reconstruction work.

Command post officials urged the public not to travel to the stricken areas out of curiosity, adding that this is a critical time for reconstruction in the wake of the devastating earthquake that rocked Taiwan Sept. 21.
Nantou County, which in the past has been a popular tourist destination due to its idyllic scenery, tasty rice wine and lush green mountain ranges, suffered heavy losses in the massive quake.
Many roads, bridges, historical buildings and scenic spots were badly damaged or destroyed by the 7.3-magnitude temblor and aftershocks, as well as by the mudslides they triggered.

Visitors, after watching days' worth of television images of the quake's aftermath, have obviously decided to see for themselves, resulting in serious traffic jams on only the second weekend after the killer quake.

Some stood on the side of the embankment of Chuoshui River to look at the ruptured Mingchu Bridge. Some watched the office of the Fenghuang Bird Center being covered by a mudslide, and some took pictures of tilted or collapsed buildings, especially the landmark buildings of the Chichi Train Station and the Lantien Institute.

Some even came to the temporary shelter centers for people who were made homeless by the quake. The visitors were in high spirits and well-dressed. Their appearance raised the ire of many stricken victims.
Police said that some of the outsiders were spending the weekend visiting relatives and friends in the stricken areas, but most other visitors just came out of curiosity.

Local reports said that travel agents have taken advantage of the worst earthquake in decades in Taiwan to try to reap benefits from the terrible tragedy, which has to date claimed the lives of more than 2,200 and injured more than 8,300.
Some travel agents offered a one day tour of the stricken area in Puli, with departure points in Kaohsiung, Taichung and Taipei.
The tour includes the hardest hit areas of several townships and villages, such as Chaotun, Kuohsin and Puli.

The tilted and collapsed Puli Winery, Township Hall, police stations, and Chichi Rail Station have been the favorites of the throng of tourists. Some of them even crossed police lines to take photographs.
Puli Township chief Chang Hung-ming said that the town is planning to preserve collapsed landmark buildings to bear witness to the catastrophic quake.

But he said that this is hardly the time for tourism as the town is currently occupied with reconstruction work. He urged tourists to have more patience, saying that they will be heartily welcomed after one or two months of reconstruction.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES, INDEX FUTURES UP

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices climbed 0.3 percent Monday, boosted by purchases of post-quake reconstruction material shares.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index rose 25.93 points to close at 7,685.48.
A total of 3.28 billion shares changed hands on a turnover of NT$106.12 billion (US$3.34 billion).

Buying focused on construction material shares, as the post-quake reconstruction program is expected to boost demand; while selling pressure on technology and financial issues also began to ease after massive sell-offs in the past week, dealers said.

Investors' concern over the impact of an unstable power supply on information technology companies started to fade with power rationing of industries in northern Taiwan coming to an end, dealers added.
Meanwhile, recent strong buying by foreign investors helped boost the index, and the market is not likely to suffer heavy losses as long as foreign institutional investors keep buying, dealers noted.
Construction shares took the lead among the eight major stock categories, ending the day with 4-percent gains.
Chemical and plastics issues, despite posting a 0.4-percent loss, accounted for 11 percent of total turnover, making future developments in that sector worthy of attention.
Advancers led decliners 276 to 150, with 48 shares unchanged.
The over-the-counter market dropped 1.31 points to close at 170.95 on a turnover of NT$4.8 billion.

TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for October moved up 19 points to close at 7,618 with 1,787 contract transactions; those for November climbed 30 points to finish at 7,620 with 67 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for December rose 64 points to close at 7,645 with two contract transactions; those for next March advanced 13 points to end at 7,620 with one contract transaction; those for next June moved up 60 points to end at 7,650 with one contract transaction.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Monday were 7,599 points for October, 7,590 points for November, 7,581 points for December, 7,607 points for next March, and 7,590 points for next June.

Electronics futures and financial futures, which are sub-index futures and based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares (TE) and financial shares (TF), reported gains and losses, respectively.
October TE futures rose 0.5 point to close at 349 with 421 contract transactions; November TE futures declined 2.8 points to end at 347.2 with nine contract transactions.
There were no transaction records for other months TE futures.

October TF futures dropped 7.6 points to close at 985.2 with 46 contract transactions, November TF futures rose nine points to close at 994 with three contract transactions; while TF futures for other months had no transaction records. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: 'MIRACLE' BROTHERS PITCH IN WITH QUAKE RELIEF EFFORTS

TEXT.P: Two brothers who were miraculously saved after the killer earthquake that hit Taiwan last month have pitched in with volunteer relief work in central Taiwan to repay the debt they feel they owe the Goddess of Mercy.

The two brothers, Sun Chi-kuang, 20, and Sun Chi-feng, 25, accompanied by Buddhist monks and their father, Sun Cheng, on Sunday went to Chungliao Village in Nantou County, one of the areas hit hardest by the Sept. 21 magnitude-7.3 earthquake, to help prepare meals for those affected by the quake.

Facing the bright lights of the media, the two brothers did not say much, only that they felt so sorry when watching TV reports or reading newspaper accounts of the miserable situation in quake-stricken areas.

They added that coming back from near death, they hope to do something for society. They were encouraged by their mother, a devout Buddhist, to join volunteer projects of Fokuangshan, a large Buddhist group based in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan.

The Suns said that though what they can do is little, they will do their best to help every quake-stricken area. The brothers will be joined by their father on their journey through all areas affected by the quake.
The two men were rescued after being trapped for 130 hours under tons of rubble after the 12-story building in which they lived in Taipei collapsed during the devastating temblor.

Chi-kuang actually walked out of the wreckage on his own. According to his account, he emerged after hearing the Goddess of Mercy tell him to escape from a tiny hole in the wreckage. He said that he had clung to life by eating some rotten apples found in a nearby refrigerator, and by drinking water sprayed over the rubble by firefighters and drinking his own urine. Chi-fong was later rescued to the great excitement of rescue workers.
When they were in the hospital for treatment after their ordeal, the two brothers vowed to devote the remainder of their lives to doing good deeds.

DOC.HEADLINE: YEN'S RISE TO BOOST TAIWAN EXPORTS TO JAPAN: BOFT

TEXT.P: The yen's strong resurgence against the dollar and Japan's recent robust economic performance are expected to result in spectacular growth for Taiwan's exports to Japan, said government economic officials on Monday.

Officials with the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs pointed out that the total value of Taiwan's exports to Japan has registered growth of nearly 20 percent since the beginning of this year.
However, exports from South Korea, Singapore and mainland China to Japan have also shown sizable increases; the competition has thus become extremely harsh, indicated BOFT officials.

It is evident that Japan's economic situation has bottomed out and is rebounding. According to an estimate by the Wharton Econometric Forecasting Association, Japan is expected to register 0.8 percent economic growth in 1999, thanks to the economic rehabilitation policy implemented by the Japanese government.

A comparison among the values of Asian countries' exports to Japan, based on the year's first seven months' export volume, shows that South Korea ranked at the top with export growth of 17.48 percent, followed by Taiwan with 17.38 percent; Singapore ranked third with growth of 12.29 percent, while mainland China registered an increase of 8.19 percent, noted BOFT officials.

The officials further stated that export of machine goods and electrical equipment, which are staples among Taiwan exports to Japan, registered growth of 50 percent and 20 percent, respectively, in the first seven months of the year, compared with last year's figures.

Meanwhile, Japan's demand for personal computers is expected to increase by 8 percent for 1999 to cope with the Y2K crisis, thus perhaps resulting in growth for Taiwan's exports in the telecommunications sector, economic officials said.

It is noteworthy, pointed out the officials, that machinery, electrical and electronic products, as well as plastic and fishing goods made in mainland China, have outshone those made in Taiwan in the Japanese market to date, while machine equipment made in South Korea also crowded out many of those products made in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR EDGES UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar closed firmer against the greenback on the Taipei market Monday, gaining 0.1 cent to close at the two-week high of 31.782.
The currency opened at 31.78 and experienced a fluctuation between 31.778 and 31.792. Interbank US dollar trading reached US$184.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: QUAKE-RELIEF DONATIONS FROM ABROAD REACH NT$620 MILLION

TEXT.P: Donations from abroad have reached NT$620 million (about US$19.5 million) since Taiwan was jolted by a devastating earthquake on Sept. 21, an official with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Monday.

Chang Chi-ping, an official from the MOFA's Information and Cultural Affairs Department, made the statement at a public hearing on post-earthquake relief work chaired by Legislator Chin Hui-chu (KMT-Taipei City).
Of the amount, Chang said, more than NT$500 million was contributed by overseas Chinese, and the remaining was donated by 11 foreign countries.

Quoting statistics compiled by the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission, Chang said ethnic Chinese from around the world have donated more than NT$500 million to help quake-affected people in Taiwan. Donations from Chinese descendants residing in the United States and Canada alone exceeded NT$450 million.

Chang further said the United Nations and 21 countries around the world sent a total of 41 rescue teams, composed of 767 cave-in and logistics experts and 99 sniffer dogs, to assist in post-quake search and rescue operations.

Meanwhile, Chang said, 90 countries and nine international organizations sent messages, expressing their regards and condolences for local quake victims. In addition, 11 foreign governments donated a total of NT$9 million in cash to help finance relief and reconstruction programs here.
At present, only the Singapore rescue team is still in Taiwan, while all other foreign rescue teams already returned to their own countries.

Chang said the MOFA has through various channels expressed the ROC government and people's heartfelt gratitude for all the aid and assistance offered by foreign countries in post-earthquake relief operations here.
Chang said all the donations from abroad will be managed by the Cabinet.

Speaking on the same occasion, Chang Lin-cheng, a National Taiwan University political science professor, said the MOFA should set aside "humanitarian aid" budget for offering first aid to other countries hit by natural disasters.

Noting that humanitarian concern and aid should be offered to needy countries without bias or discrimination, Chang said Taiwan should not include too much political consideration in offering humanitarian aid to avoid affecting the ROC's international image.

DOC.HEADLINE: 15 CLIMBERS FOUND; ALL DEAD
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung County, Central Taiwan, Oct. 4 (CNA) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Fifteen mountain climbers from the Taipei City Flying Eagle Alpinist Association were found dead at the 61.5-kilometer mark of the Central Cross Island Highway in central Taiwan, police reported on Monday.

Police said that the climbers had taken a minibus to climb Mountain Chilai in central Taiwan and were buried under falling rocks when the earthquake jolted Taiwan on Sept. 21, claiming more than 2,200 lives and injuring more than 8,900 people.

The accident occurred 500 meters from a station of the Tehchi Dam power generating plant, reported police, who speculated that the group might have been saved if the minibus had been able to continue along its route for two more minutes.
The Chinese Taipei Alpinist Association had asked authorities to carry out a rescue attempt after losing contact with the group.

Military and civilian rescue teams had sent helicopters several times to fly over possible accident sites but failed to find anything. Police and the Taichung County Rescue Team had formed two groups to search for the ill-fated climbers.
The rescue teams had uncovered no trace of the missing group over the past ten days until the minibus was found on Monday morning.
The rescue team tried to dig out the climber's bodies by hand as rocks and debris continued to fall around the site, police said.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVERGREEN GROUP DENIES BUSINESS WITHDRAWAL FROM PANAMA

TEXT.P: The Panamanian branch of Taiwan conglomerate Evergreen Group on Sunday categorically denied the company has any plan to withdraw its diversified businesses from the country.

Currently Evergreen Group has businesses in shipping, air cargo transport and real estate, as well as a container terminal, in Panama; and officials of the company's branch office said in a news release that all the businesses are in operation, in response to the Panamanian port authority's recent announcement that Evergreen was planning to pull out of Panama.

According to the news release, Evergreen owns a fleet of 120 cargo vessels in Panama, of which half sail under the flag of that country, and EVA Airways is continuing regular service along its Taipei-Panama City route. The group has also poured over US$100 million into Panama's Colon Container Terminal which is operating as usual.

The news release also revealed that the rumor of Evergreen Group's withdrawal might have been sparked by the group's negotiations on cooperative investments with several international business groups, which might have been misunderstood as intent to withdraw.
Aside from the existing businesses, Evergreen Group is planning to invest in the hospitality industry in Panama, the news release said. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT TO HOST NEWS CONFERENCE ON POST-QUAKE RELIEF

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui will give a press conference on Tuesday to explain progress in various post-earthquake relief and reconstruction programs, the Presidential Office announced on Monday.

Lee is expected to detail his feelings and views about what he has heard and seen during his inspection tours of hardest-hit areas of central Taiwan over the past two weeks, a Presidential Office official said, adding that the president will also answer questions from journalists.

The official noted that Lee has made frequent visits to central Taiwan since the 7.3-magnitude earthquake wreaked havoc in the region on Sept. 21, and has personally helped some surviving quake victims to resolve their problems.
By now, the first-stage post-quake rescue and relief operations have finished, and the even more tough reconstruction work is set to begin.
The official said that in the process of the initial-stage relief work, the government came under fire for its lack of coordination and low efficiency.

"We feel there is a need for President Lee to explain what the government has had to do after the promulgation of an emergency decree to speed up post-earthquake resettlement and reconstruction work, as well as what the government can do under the emergency decree," the official said, adding that Lee will also reaffirm the government's determination to do its utmost to help quake-affected people rebuild their homes and lives as well as improve the country's infrastructure to ensure a safer living environment.

The official further said that as head of state, Lee must explain the government's determination and its plans for coping with the aftermath of the devastating earthquake, in order to ease the public's misgivings and restore its confidence and trust in the government.

As Lee has criticized some of the local media's handling of earthquake-related news events, interaction between the president and the media during Tuesday's press conference is expected to be the focus of much attention and interest.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, VIETNAM AIRLINES COOPERATE ON TAIPEI-HO CHI MINH ROUTE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's U-Land Airlines on Monday forged a cooperation relationship with Vietnam's Pacific Airlines (PA), to operate flights between Taipei and Ho Chi Minh City.
Under the terms of the cooperation agreement, U-Land will rent PA airplanes and pilots, which will fly the route from Oct. 10, U-Land spokesman Chen Ming-jen said.

The deal presents the Taiwan carrier's second cooperation move with PA, after leasing one MD-82 airplane and crew to the Vietnamese carrier to ply the route between Ho Chi Minh City and Kaohsiung, in southern Taiwan, Chen said.
U-Land at present services Taipei, Kaohsiung and Kinmen, Taiwan's front-line island off the southeastern coast of mainland China.
Forging cooperation with foreign air companies through leasing agreements is the best strategy for U-Land to enhance its operational efficiency, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INVESTIGATION BUREAU HELPS JAPAN UNCOVER BIGGEST DRUG HAUL

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Investigation Bureau said on Monday that it supplied information to the Japanese police authorities which allowed them to uncover a record haul of 560 kg of amphetamines from a Taiwan fishing boat on Sunday.
According to news reports, Japanese police made the bust during a raid on a Taipei County-based fishing boat in the Kurosei Sea off Japan's Kagoshima Prefecture.
Ten suspects, including a Taiwan national, were arrested.

The bureau said in a news release that the suspects had been the subject of a year-long joint investigation by the Investigation Bureau and the Military Police Command under the direction of the Taipei and Keelung prosecutor's offices.
The bureau passed their findings on to the Japanese police authorities after discovering that the drugs were being shipped to Japan to avoid a domestic crackdown on illegal drugs.
The investigation by the Taiwan authorities has won respect from Japan and other international police authorities, according to the bureau.

DOC.HEADLINE: QUAKE DONATIONS FROM OVERSEAS CHINESE TOP US$ 20.82 MILLION

TEXT.P: Cash donations for victims of the Sept. 21 earthquake from overseas Chinese communities around the world have topped over NT$662 million (US$20.82 million), according to the Cabinet-level Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC).
The donations have come from overseas Chinese living in 43 countries and areas in all five continents.

As of Monday, donations from overseas Chinese communities in North America amounted to NT$550 million (US$17.3 million), while NT$28 million has come from South America, NT$57 million has flowed in from Europe, and NT$71 million has come from Asia, OCAC statistics show.
The overseas Chinese communities started raising funds for the thousands of displaced people in Taiwan as soon as news of the 7.3-magnitude earthquake began filtering out on Sept. 21.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCE MINISTRY MULLS RAISING CEILING ON TREASURY BONDS

TEXT.P: Bracing for a surge in service charges on government debts because of treasury bonds issued to fund the earthquake reconstruction, a Ministry of Finance (MOF) official said on Monday that the ministry is mulling whether to raise the limit on the amount of such bonds.

Wang Jung-chou, vice minister of finance in charge of treasury affairs, said that his ministry is studying the options of either raising the limit of 15 percent of the government's budget, or lifting it completely.

Although the government is not bound by the 15 percent limitation under the six-month emergency decree declared by President Lee Teng-hui on Sept. 25, the outstanding government debt will surpass the limit until long after the six-month period has elapsed.

The amount of government bonds currently stands at about 14.71 percent of the government budget, and Lee is instructing the ministry to raise another NT$80 billion via bond issuance or borrowing to finance the earthquake relief operation.

In light of the NT$1 trillion (US31.25 billion) price tag for the reconstruction after the 1995 Kobe-Osaka earthquake in Japan, the Taiwan authorities estimate that it will take NT$160 billion (US$5 billion) to reconstruct the earthquake-stricken areas of the island.

In addition to bond issuance, the government will temporarily divert money from back-burner projects to the relief operation for the time being, and will prepare a budget for next year according to the reconstruction needs, said Wang.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER INDONESIAN PRESIDENT TO FACE GRAFT CHARGES

TEXT.P: Former Indonesian President Suharto will be named as a defendant in corruption charges before the end of this month, a senior Indonesian government official said last week.

Romli Atmasasmita, director-general of the Indonesian Ministry of Justice, said: "By the end of October, the Attorney-General will make an announcement on Suharto's status as a defendant. Then it is up to the new Cabinet whether to continue with the charges or not."
Romli was speaking to Singapore's Business Times while attending a conference in Manila last week on combating corruption in Asia.
Last week, Indonesian President B.J. Habibie told the German weekly Rheinischer Merkur that "from the reports I have, the prosecutor should indict Suharto."

The impending charges will climax more than one year of investigation, during which 50 witnesses were questioned, but many Indonesians are skeptical as to whether he will be tried. Critics have accused the government of dragging its feet and showing a reluctance to prosecute the 78-year-old ex-strongman, whose 32-year reign ended in riots and mayhem in May 1998.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO MORE RENTED MISSILE FRIGATES ARRIVE IN TAIWAN FROM US

TEXT.P: Two American-made Knox-class missile frigates rented from the US Navy sailed into a Republic of China naval base in southern Taiwan on Monday.

The ROC Naval Command said that the "Ning Yang" and the "Yi Yang" are the seventh and eighth frigates the ROC Navy has rented from the US Navy, and added that they will be commissioned in the near future to improve the navy's anti-submarine capability.
The two frigates were brought to Taiwan from the United States by ROC naval personnel after a 40-day voyage across the Pacific Ocean.
ROC Navy Commander-in-Chief Hu Tsai-kuei and other ranking officers were on hand to greet the arrival of the two frigates at the naval base.
The Knox-class missile frigates were constructed for the US Navy in the 1970s. So far, the ROC Navy has rented eight such vessels for anti-submarine duties.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT STABILITY PARAMOUNT: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Oct. 3 (CNA) (By Tzou Ming-jhie & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Minister Jason Hu said in an interview with Le Monde newspaper on Sunday that what is of greatest concern to Taipei is peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait.
Hu was asked by the French paper to comment on Beijing's celebrations to mark the 50th founding anniversary of the People's Republic of China.
Saying it is not a bad thing for a country to celebrate its national day, Hu stressed however that if the occasion is used to propagate nationalism, it is certainly not helpful.
The paper interpreted Hu's remarks to indicate Taipei's concern that Beijing's display of military power in its national day military parade constitutes a threat to Taiwan.
The foreign minister refuted Beijing's claim that "Taiwan is a trouble-maker," asking: "We have already had too many troubles of our own. Why would we seek to bring more troubles upon ourselves?"
Hu admitted, however, that Beijing was angered by ROC President Lee Teng-hui's recent redefinition of cross-Taiwan Strait relations as a "special state-to-state relationship."
The paper noted that Taipei officials have defended Lee's statement by pointing out that he was just stating the undeniable fact that the PRC's sovereign power has never extended to Taiwan.
In the interview, Hu also expressed Taipei's disappointment over France's lack of support when the Taiwan issue was discussed recently at the United Nations.

DOC.HEADLINE: EARTHQUAKE DOES LITTLE TO DENT TAIWAN'S ECONOMY: RATING AGENCY

TEXT.P: Increased government expenditure on earthquake reconstruction will stimulate Taiwan's mid-term economic growth according to a report by the rating company Standard and Poor's and its Taiwan's affiliate the Taiwan Rating Corp. on Monday.
This growth will occur despite the devastating Sept. 21 earthquake which dampened the island's production somewhat, according to the rating report.

Although the quake caused widespread property damage on the island, and although ensuing power outages have disturbed the island's industrial production, the report said these factors will trim Taiwan's gross domestic product growth by only 0.25 percent, bringing it down from 5.74 percent to 5.5 percent, but still better than the 4.65 percent recorded for the previous year.

The report noted that the power outages led to rationing, which is expected to end by Oct. 12, just three weeks after the disaster. The rationing has caused some 19,000 factories around the island to lie idle, not least those in the semiconductor industry in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, which has suffered losses of an estimated US$1 billion per week since the disaster.

The banking industry is another sector which is bearing the brunt of the temblor because of the collapse of many mortgaged buildings and the expected large-scale defaulting on loans extended to owners whose property has been damaged, said the report.
It predicted that the non-performing debt ratio will rise from 5 percent to more than 6 percent next month given that more than 10,000 houses were destroyed by the temblor.
However, the extra expenditure on rebuilding of infrastructure and buildings will boost the demand for construction materials, and this will stimulate economic growth, the report continued.
In light of Taiwan's small foreign debt and its huge foreign currency reserves, the report foresees no problem for the island to come up with the extra cash required for rebuilding.

The insurance industry, which earned huge profits in the first three quarters of this year, was not badly hit by quake claims, because earthquake insurance policies had not been popular among Taiwan clients prior to Sept. 21. Rather, insurance companies are expected to get a windfall from the disaster with an expected surge in demand for life and property insurance, said the report.

The petrochemical and steel industries, the backbone of the island's economy, have hardly been affected by the tremor at all, and are expected to enter a boom period because of the island's reconstruction efforts, said the report.

However, the government's economic index, which in August indicated that the island's economy was recovering from the Asian financial crisis, is expected take a blow in September with the island's export orders dipping by 15 percent-20 percent, compared to the same period of one year ago, the report concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: US HOUSE ADOPTS BILL FAVORING WHO MEMBERSHIP FOR TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The US House of Representatives on Monday passed a bill in favor of Taiwan's participation in international organizations, especially the World Health Organization.

The bill, easily passed by a voice vote, requires Secretary of State Madeleine Albright to report to the Congress before Jan. 1, 2000, on US efforts to support Taiwan's participation in international organizations, especially the WHO.

Calling on other members to support the bill, Rep. Sherrod Brown (D-Ohio), who sponsors this legislation, said the denial of Taiwanese participation in the WHO is "an unjustifiable violation of its people's fundamental human rights".

Douglas K. Bereuter (R-Nebraska), chairman of the House Asia and Pacific subcommittee, said it "defies logic to exclude (Taiwan's) 20 million people from this international disease prevention organization".
"There is no doubt that Taiwan can offer much in terms of medical and pharmaceutical expertise," he added while speaking on the floor.
The Senate will have to pass a similar bill and then a presidential signature will be required for the bill to become law.

In 1997, the Republic of China on Taiwan applied, to no avail, for an observer status at the Geneva-based WHO. Taiwan lost its membership at all UN-affiliated agencies after withdrawing from the United Nations in 1971.
Monday's action in the House represents another effort by Taiwan's supporters in US Congress to help the island take part in more international activities.
The measure, H. R. 1794, does not call for membership for Taiwan but said the island should have "appropriate and meaningful participation in the World Health Organization".
At the request of Beijing, the US administration has adopted a policy of not supporting membership for Taiwan in international organizations where statehood is required, such as the WHO.
It promised in a 1994 policy review, however, to help Taiwan's voice to be heard in such organizations and to help Taiwan join organizations where statehood is not a prerequisite for membership.
