DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Oct. 5, or the 26th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1796: Spain declares war on Britain and forms an alliance with revolutionary France by signing the Treaty of San Ildefonso.
1830: Chester A. Arthur, the 21st president of the United States, is born. Arthur became president after the assassination of James A. Garfield. He supported the 1883 Pendleton Act, which created the Civil Service Commission to regulate federal appointments.
1882: Robert H. Goddard, American inventor of the modern rocket, is born. In 1926, he developed and built the first liquid fuel rocket.
1908: Bulgaria declares its independence from the Ottoman Empire with Ferdinand I assuming the title of czar of Bulgaria.
1922: Tsao Kun is elected president of the Peking government.
1930: The British R-101 rigid airship crashes on its first flight on the edge of a wooded area near Beauvais, France, killing 48 of its 54 passengers, including British Air Minister Lord Thompson.
1930: The first Balkan Conference is held in Athens, with representatives from countries from the Balkan Peninsula and Turkey taking part.
1936: Vaclav Havel, Czech playwright and human rights spokesman, is born. He was jailed four times before he became the nation's president, after the collapse of the Communist regime in December 1989.
1936: Some 200 unemployed British workers from the ship-building town of Jarrow begin their hunger march to London. They were attempting to bring public attention to the plight of the unemployed in depressed areas of the country.
1941: Chinese forces heavily defeat Japanese invaders near the Milo River in northern Nanan Province, killing and wounding nearly 80,000 Japanese troops.
1946: Chiang Kai-shek accepts General George C. Marshall's proposal for a 10-day cease-fire to pave the way for resumption of peace talks. Marshall arrived in Chungking on Dec. 22, 1945 as US President Harry Truman's special envoy.
1947: The Calcutta area in India is heavily flooded, leaving thousands of people dead from hunger and some one million others homeless.
1951: The ROC's Legislative Yuan passes regulations providing farmland to the soldiers.
1958: The United States delivers a batch of "Hercules" ground-to-air missiles, known in Taiwan as the "Goddess of Victory" missiles, to help improve the ROC's national defense.
1962: A consortium of European countries, including Belgium, Denmark, France, West Germany, the Netherlands and Sweden, agree to set up an observatory in the southern hemisphere.
1970 Anwar Sadat becomes president of Egypt, following the death of Gamal Abdel Nasser.
1972: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Togo.
1973: Taiwan's first case of coronary artery surgery is performed at National Taiwan University Hospital.
1983: Poland's Solidarity leader Lech Walesa is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.
1989: The Dalai Lama, Tibet's spiritual leader, wins the Nobel Peace Prize.
1991: Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev pledges to match the United States in scraping tactical nuclear weapons.
1991: Cheng Kung, the first guided missile frigate built in Taiwan, is launched.
1993: Communist China breaks its moratorium on nuclear testing.
1996: Some 50 countries adopt a declaration calling for the earliest possible agreement on a global ban on anti-personnel land mines.
1998: The Judiciary Committee of the US House of Representatives votes to recommend an impeachment inquiry into President Bill Clinton's action during the Monica Lewinsky case.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The fact that a man is able to confront the spiritual powers of the universe without any doubt, shows that he understands the will of God. The fact that he is prepared to wait a hundred generations after him for the man of perfect divine nature without any misgiving, shows that he understands the nature of man."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DOES NOT PROPOSE RESUMPTION OF AVIATION TALKS WITH PHILIPPINES

TEXT.P: The Republic of China has not asked the Philippines to resume aviation talks after the two countries suspended direct airlinks on Oct. 2, the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) said on Tuesday.
The CAA was responding to a Philippines Airlines (PAL) statement that Taipei has called for resumption of negotiations on direct flight services between the two countries.

Noting that the Philippines had never responded to the ROC's bottom line for maintaining bilateral direct airlinks proposed on Sept. 23, the CAA said the Philippines instead unilaterally proposed that the weekly quota be cut to 3,000 passengers for each side from 9,600 stipulated in the 1996 Taipei-Manila air agreement.
After a breakdown in negotiations, Taipei was forced to announced on Oct. 1 that direct Taiwan-Philippines flight services would be suspended from Oct. 2.

The CAA said unless the Philippines agreed to the ROC's proposal that the weekly quota be lowered to 6,500 passengers, not the PAL-proposed 3,000 passengers, the ROC has no plans to re-open aviation talks with the Philippines.
According to Tuesday's PAL statement, the Philippine flagship carrier said because of its poor structure, it cannot withstand free competition.

The PAL then urged the two Taiwan carriers -- China Airlines (CAL) and EVA Airways -- which until recently operated scheduled Taiwan-Philippines flights to "sympathize" with its plight and accept its proposal to cut the weekly quota to 3,000 passenger for each side to pave the way for early resumption of direct airlinks.

The Philippine carrier went on that it is currently burdened with a debt of US$2.2 billion. If the airline fails to take immediate measures to boost its business, the PAL said it will go bankrupt and that its 8,000 staff members will lost jobs, which will eventually lead to a serious social problem in the Philippines.

The PAL further said the Philippines had agreed to cut the weekly quota from 9,600 passengers to 3,000 mainly because it wanted to maintain airborne traffic between the two countries. In fact, the airline claimed that the new quota far exceeds the actual demand. According to the PAL, the number of travelers between Taiwan and the Philippines totals an average of 3,800 per week.
Commenting on the PAL statement, the two Taiwan carriers -- CAL and EVA -- said the Philippine carrier's demand is unreasonable, saying the PAL cannot ask them to "bail it out" at their expense.
CAL and EVA executives said the PAL-proposed weekly quota is unacceptable because it does not possess any economic value for them.

Moreover, the two carriers said the PAL's tally of passengers between the two countries is incorrect. According to statistics compiled by Taiwan's two international airports -- Chiang Kai-shek International Airport and Kaohsiung International Airport, the number of travelers between Taiwan and the Philippines reached an average of 21,000 passengers per week in the first seven months of this year.
During the seven-month period, CAL's average weekly passenger volume was more than 7,000 while EVA's exceeded 5,000, according to airline records.

DOC.HEADLINE: US SENATE PASSES SYMPATHY RESOLUTION FOR TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Following the suit of the House of Representatives, the US Senate has also passed unanimously a resolution expressing its deepest sympathies to the people of Taiwan for the tragic losses suffered as a result of the Sept. 21 earthquake.
The resolution calls upon the United States and other members of the international community to do everything possible to assist Taiwan in recovering rapidly from the terrible natural disaster.

When submitting the resolution to the Senate last Friday, Senate Majority Leader Trent Lott (R-MS) said he wanted to express his personal sadness and deepest sympathy for the victims of the devastating earthquake and asked that the Senate convey to the people of Taiwan its most sincere sympathies about their tragic losses in both lives and property.

The Senate then voted unanimously for the resolution to express its deepest sympathies to the people of Taiwan, especially those in Nantou and Taichung, for the tragic losses suffered as a result of the Sept. 21 earthquake, as well as its support for the people of Taiwan in their efforts to rebuild their cities and their life.

Senate Resolution 194 also expresses support for disaster assistance being provided by the United States Agency for International Development and other relief agencies and recognizes and encourages the important assistance that also could be provided by foreign countries to alleviate the suffering of the people of Taiwan.
On Sept. 29, the House of Representatives passed a similar resolution by a 424-0 vote.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar moved slightly down against the greenback on the Taipei market on Tuesday in cold trading.
The local currency opened at 31.78 against the US dollar, and was traded between 31.78 and 31.789 before closing at 31.785. It suffered a drop of 0.3 cents during the session.
Affected by a wait-and-see sentiment on the market, interbank US dollar trading shrank to US$16 million, the lowest daily turnover over the past six months.

DOC.HEADLINE: INMATES JOIN RECONSTRUCTION WORK

TEXT.P: Some 50 inmates went to central Taiwan on Tuesday to pitch in with quake relief work in the wake of the massive Sept. 21 earthquake.
The Ministry of Justice said that the group went to a park and a gateball field in Tunghsih, Taichung County, to clean up areas badly damaged during the killer quake.

Ministry officials noted that, in view of the extensive damage from the temblor, the ministry has acted in line with a law that allows inmates to leave institution grounds in order to engage in agricultural work, road and building construction, and other activities that are deemed beneficial to the public.
The officials said that they have chosen inmates who have experience in construction, plumbing and painting to form this first group of 50 to join reconstruction efforts.

Vice Minister of Justice Tseng Yung-fu said that in order to be eligible for reconstruction work, inmates must possess a related area of expertise, must have demonstrated good behavior while incarcerated, and must pose no risk of escape.

In addition to actual participation in relief work, the ministry said inmates of various prisons, penitentiaries and juvenile delinquent correctional centers have also chipped in NT$33.58 million (US$1.05 million) for relief efforts in the aftermath of the earthquake, which has claimed more than 2,200 lives and injured more than 8,300 to date, and has resulted in extensive damages.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES, INDEX FUTURES DOWN

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed 1.7 percent lower Tuesday as heavy selling pressure from profit-taking pulled the index down.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index shed 128.47 points to close at 7,557.01.
A total of 2.75 billion shares changed hands on a scaled-down turnover of NT$93.65 billion (US$2.75 billion).

Investors took profits from construction material shares which had climbed greatly after the Sept. 21 earthquake. Construction material issues have posted strong gains amid hopes that the sector would enjoy a boom from the repair and reconstruction of buildings damaged or collapsed by the quake.
Strong sales of technology stocks by mutual fund managers also contributed to today's plunge.
Only foodstuff issues registered gains, ending the day with 0.4-percent gains; the rest posted losses, with cement issues reporting the largest losses of 3 percent.

The financial sector, dragged down by the news that banks must shoulder all the mortgage loans of quake victims whose homes were ruined by the quake, continued its downward trend, ending the day with 2.2-percent losses.
Advancers lagged behind decliners 87 to 395, with 47 shares unchanged.
The over-the-counter market dropped 1.64 points to close at 169.31 on a turnover of NT$5.14 billion.

TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for October moved down 108 points to close at 7,510 with 1,889 contract transactions; those for November shed 110 points to finish at 7,510 with 114 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for December dropped 50 points to close at 7,550 with five contract transactions; those for next March declined 26 points to end at 7,600 with one contract transaction; those for next June remained unchanged to end at 7,609 with one contract transaction.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Tuesday were 7,618 points for October, 7,620 points for November, 7,600 points for December, 7,626 points for next March, and 7,609 points for next June.
Electronics futures and financial futures, which are sub-index futures and based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares (TE) and financial shares (TF), both reported losses.

October TE futures shed 4.5 points to close at 344.5 with 363 contract transactions; November TE futures declined 0.2 point to end at 347 with one contract transaction; December TE futures dropped 7.5 points to close at 343 with four contract transactions.
There were no transaction records for next March TE futures or next June TE futures.

October TF futures fell 29.2 points to close at 956 with 74 contract transactions, November TF futures dropped 28 points to close at 966 with two contract transactions; TF futures for other months had no transaction records. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO REVIEW RESCUE AND RELIEF OPERATIONS: PREMIER SIEW

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew said on Tuesday that the government will review its rescue and relief efforts in the wake of the massive Sept. 21 earthquake.
Siew made the remark when he gave his first administration report to the Legislative Yuan since the killer earthquake which has to date killed more than 2,200 and injured more than 8,300.

Cheng Lung-shui of the opposition New Party lashed out at the government for its chaotic rescue and relief operations, overlapping command centers, and serious shortage of professionals for rescue operations.

Siew said that after the catastrophic temblor hit central Taiwan, many roads were impassable, electric and telephone lines were cut, and government response in handling the crisis did seem a little bit slow.

But he said that the government then rapidly mobilized 200,000 people to pitch in with rescue and relief operations. CNN television reporters and many foreign rescue teams that came to Taiwan have praised Taiwan's efficiency. Even so, he said that this is no reason for the government to not review the overall operation.

Legislator Chien Hsi-kai of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party questioned that as early as 1996, experts warned that massive earthquakes measuring higher than seven on the Richter scale would hit Taiwan, but the government has turned a deaf ear to repeated warnings.
The inefficiency of government rescue and relief efforts added to the misery in quake-stricken areas, Chien noted.

Siew said that Taiwan is located in an earthquake-prone region, and the government has always attached great importance to calamity control, so therefore stricter construction codes should be established.
Siew also said that the lack of advanced equipment for rescue efforts, as evidenced in rescue attempts last month, is due to the government's tight budget.
In reviewing relief operations, the government will support increasing related budgets, Siew said.

Legislator Chang Hsih-liang of the opposition New Party noted that President Lee Teng-hui had said the reconstruction work will be completed in three years and questioned why Siew had given a five-year timetable.
Siew said that experts, in considering the aftermath of the massive Kobe earthquake in 1995, have concluded that a five-year time frame is appropriate due to the extensive damage from the quake.

Regarding the appeal for the government to establish a lottery to help raise money for relief efforts, Siew said the Cabinet is studying the feasibility of the proposal, saying he believes a one-time lottery could be held and proceeds earmarked for relief operations.
Siew also said that reconstruction work will be implemented in stages, and that more than NT$100 billion (3.14 billion) has been designated for that purpose.

The reconstruction of townships and villages will be conducted according to the "build, operate and transfer" (BOT) model, by which the private sector will build in those areas, operate the areas for a certain period of time, and then transfer them to the government, in order to reduce the financial burden on the government, Siew said.

He also said that the government is already coordinating the more than 70 donation accounts in the private sector with more than 40 similar accounts set up by the government, hoping that all donations will be administered by a committee headed by Senior Presidential Adviser Koo Chen-fu.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S UNEMPLOYMENT RATE SEEN FALLING TO 5% IN 2001

TEXT.P: Australia's unemployment, buoyed by strong economic performance, is expected to plunge to 6 percent next year and to as low as 5 percent by the year 2001, according to a new survey by the Australian Financial Review.
The daily reported the survey of business economists shows the unemployment rate would fall to 6 percent or lower over the next year or two due to long economic expansion of this country.
Australia's gross domestic product is expected to grow between 3.5 and 4 percent in the current fiscal year which ends on June 30, 2000.
The daily quotes John Edwards, chief economist at the HSBC Markets, as predicting the jobless rate to plunge to around 5 percent in 2001, the most optimistic expectation in the survey.

It reported higher interest rates are expected to accompany the fall in unemployment. Some economists expect the Reserve Bank of Australia to raise the official interest rates at least by 0.25-0.5 percentage point within the next six months.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRC'S 50TH BIRTHDAY PARTY NOISY AS TENSION WITH TAIWAN REMAINS

TEXT.P: Mainland China has just celebrated its 50th anniversary of founding the communist regime, but there won't be any quite time in Asia due to the tensions in the Taiwan Strait, Indonesian archipelago and the Korean Peninsula, according to the head of the Sydney Institute.

Gerard Henderson, executive director of the prestigious institute, on Tuesday noted the tension between China and Taiwan has been underestimated in Australia, saying the Australian government only focused on the East Timor problem and Indonesia.

He reminded that Canberra should look beyond Indonesia because other issues remain and these problems could cause instability in the Asian Pacific region. He cited the tensions between Taiwan and China and the Korean Peninsula.

In his article headlined: "Let's Look Beyond East Timor" published in the Sydney Morning Herald on Tuesday, Henderson said: "Despite last week's military exhibition, it is unclear whether China has the capability to invade and subdue Taiwan. Yet, without question, it is able to create a significant amount of instability in the region."
He believed Prime Minister John Howard was most anxious to obtain as much backing from the United Stats as possible in support of Australia's peace-enforcement role in East Timor.
"In view of this, it is timely to remember that if tension develops in the Taiwan Strait, it is likely that the US will expect Australia's support," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANNUAL INCREASE IN CONSUMER PRICE INDEX TO REMAIN UNCHANGED: DGBAS

TEXT.P: The annual increase in the domestic consumer price index for 1999 is expected to remain unchanged at 0.5 percent, an estimate made by the government in August, said officials on Tuesday.

Officials of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) pointed out that although the devastating earthquake which occurred on Sept. 21 would surely affect consumer prices in the central Taiwan areas that were hit hard by the temblor, the island's annual consumer price index as a whole is likely to remain as previously assessed.

Chen Chang-hsiung, director of the Third Bureau under the DGBAS, said that according to a survey made by the DGBAS, nationwide consumer prices in late September, after the temblor, were even lower than those of early September. Domestic consumer prices are not likely to fluctuate much in the near future; however, costs in the transportation and communications sectors, as well as housing costs in quake-affected areas, may rise, observed Chen.

The grand total consumer price index for September is 103.40, an increase of 0.07 percent from the previous month, mainly as a result of the rise in tuition fees nationwide and the Mid-Autumn Festival which occurred in September, said the DGBAS official.

The grand total wholesale price index for September is 95.84, an increase of 0.25 percent from August; but it showed a drop of 4.28 percent as compared with the same period last year, according to DGBAS figures.

As for details of price increases in various sectors, there was an evident rise in the funeral sector, which raised September prices 25 percent over the previous month's, an increase of 13 percent as compared with the same period last year, according to statistics released by the DGBAS.

Among the 564 items considered for the consumer price index by the DGBAS survey, watermelon ranked at the top by registering a price increase of 43 percent, followed by pineapple's 28 percent; the 25 percent rise in funeral fees ranked third, followed by baby-sitting fees with an upward move of 11 percent, and by increases of 9 percent each for high school tuition fees and parking fees, the DGBAS figures showed.

DOC.HEADLINE: USA TODAY PUBLISHES "THANK YOU" FROM ROC GOV'T

TEXT.P: USA Today published Monday a letter from C.J. Chen, ROC government spokesman, expressing Taiwan's gratitude to the rest of the world for their support and sympathy as well as humanitarian assistance following the Sept. 21 earthquake.
"We would much prefer that anything but disaster be the basis for closer cooperation with the rest of the world," he said.

The director-general of the ROC Government Information Office wrote that "The tremendous warmth and generosity shown us following the earthquake Sept. 21 have made the people of Taiwan feel they are not alone, that they are indeed an integral part of our global village."

Chen told the American readership that messages of support and sympathy quickly came from President Bill Clinton and many other world leaders. And more than 20 countries generously responded to the devastating earthquake by providing humanitarian assistance in the form of rescue teams and equipment.

When time was of the essence, he said, "it was heartening to have teams of search-and-rescue professionals from the USA, Japan, France, Russia, Singapore and many other countries helping alongside our rescue teams. We know for a fact that lives were saved as a result of our joint efforts."

Of course, Chen noted, "even expert assistance from the international community cannot mend broken hearts or bring back missing loved ones: The loss for the people of Taiwan is very real. We would much prefer that anything but disaster be the basis for closer cooperation with the rest of the world."

But this event has brought all citizens of the Republic of China on Taiwan closer together than ever -- "and more determined to build new links to the international community, even as we rebuild collapsed bridges in Taiwan," he stressed.

Chen went on to say that the minutes in which the news of the earthquake's magnitude spread around the world and the hours within which international experts were already arriving by air, "underscored just how small our planet has become at the end of the 20th century."

Yet, Chen wrote, "it doesn't have to take a disaster to remind us that Taiwan is very much a part of the international community -- and that we matter to each other. The government and people of the Republic of China on Taiwan are grateful for the kind assistance of the international community. We shall never forget."

DOC.HEADLINE: TEMPORARY HOUSES TO BE COMPLETED BY END OF OCTOBER
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung County, central Taiwan, Oct. 5 (CNA) (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan said on Tuesday that construction of temporary houses for the 921 earthquake-affected people should be completed by the end of October.
Lien made the directive during an inspection tour of the military's post-earthquake reconstruction commanding center in Taichung County's Taiping City in central Taiwan.

Noting that timing is very important in post-disaster relief and reconstruction work, Lien said he hopes all prefabricated houses for homeless quake victims can be completed before the end of this month to facilitate resettlement programs.

Lien also reminded military servicemen participating in post-quake reconstruction work to pay special attention to their own safety while demolishing quake-damaged buildings or infrastructure facilities.
Quoting President Lee Teng-hui, Lien likened the military's contributions to post-earthquake relief and resettlement to "winning a battle."

Lien said he has always been moved during his extensive inspection tours of quake-stricken areas over the past two weeks when he saw so many soldiers, policemen, civil servants and volunteers work diligently to rescue survivors, unearth buried bodies, take care of the injured and arrange shelters for the homeless.
Lien encouraged all military officers and enlisted men to continue assisting in post-quake relief work so that various resettlement and reconstruction projects can be completed quickly.

The vice president also urged the military to continue transporting daily necessities and relief goods into villages or townships whose transport networks were damaged in the Sept. 21 devastating earthquake.

A 7.3-magnitude earthquake ripped through mountainous central Taiwan's Nantou County at 1:47 a.m. Sept. 21, claiming more than 2,250 lives, injuring over 8,700 others and leaving some 100,000 people homeless.
Lien said he believes that with concerted efforts of the government, military and members of the general public, tough post-quake reconstruction work can be finished smoothly.
Meanwhile, Premier Vincent Siew also praised the military's performance in post-earthquake rescue and relief operations during a Legislative Yuan question-and-answer session.
With the military's assistance, Siew said, more than 4,900 people trapped in toppled buildings and 4,600 others stranded due to damaged roads were rescued islandwide after the deadly tremor.

In related news, the Ministry of National Defense said since Oct. 1, all military hospitals have offered psychological counseling services and physical checkups for military officers and conscripts who have taken part in rescue and relief operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA STEEL RECEIVES A NEW CARGO VESSEL

TEXT.P: Taiwan's state-run China Steel Corp. on Tuesday took delivery of a new ship from its Japanese builder; the "Bonnanza Express," registered in Panama, joins China Steel's fleet as its ninth cargo vessel.

The 10,000-ton cargo ship arrived in Kaohsiung Harbor Tuesday afternoon, completing its maiden voyage from Japan. It was then docked at the harbor's eighth pier to unload 7,000 kilotons of metal materials.
The ship, 110 meters long and 22 meters wide, will sail on Friday to a deep-water wharf owned by China Steel, where it will be loaded with steel products for a voyage back to Japan.
The Bonnanza Express will mainly serve the Taiwan-Japan route, according to China Steel.
China Steel's other eight cargo ships mainly sail between Taiwan and Australia, the corporation's source of raw metals.

DOC.HEADLINE: SWEDEN TO PROVIDE HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Swedish government will supply relief materials for Taiwan's earthquake victims, according to the Swedish Trade Council in Taipei.
Tents, sleeping bags and other materials will be sent to victims of the devastating earthquake that jolted Taiwan on Sept. 21 and has claimed more than 2,200 lives and injured more than 8,500 people.

A news release from the Swedish Ministry of Foreign Affairs indicated that the equipment was scheduled to be collected on Oct. 1 in Sweden and then transported to Amsterdam to be loaded onto a Taiwanese aircraft and flown to the island.
The Swedish government has decided to provide this humanitarian assistance to Taiwan as one measure to bring about a return to normal life in quake-stricken areas as soon as possible.

The Swedish Rescue Services Agency is coordinating the operation and will deliver the materials in Taiwan. A Taiwanese airliner will take care of the transport, while the Swedish International Development Cooperation Agency will meet the costs of Swedish personnel, according to the news release.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PRESIDENTIAL HOPEFUL VISITS JAPAN TO STUDY QUAKE-RELIEF MEASURES

TEXT.P: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidate Chen Shui-bian left for Japan on Tuesday to learn from that country's experience in post-earthquake reconstruction work.
Chen said prior to his departure that he is visiting Japan in his capacity as convener of a DPP post-earthquake reconstruction coordination committee.

Japan's port city of Kobe was rattled by a 7.2-magnitude earthquake on Jan. 17, 1995. Chen said he believes that Taiwan has much to learn from Japan in coping with the aftermath of a devastating earthquake that wreaked havoc in Taiwan on Sept. 21.

Chen said he most wants to study how the Japanese government and people have cooperated closely to help quake-affected people rebuild their homes and life as well as to complete various reconstruction programs in a short period of time.

During his tenure as Taipei mayor, Chen said he also made a visit to Kobe in March 1995 to study Japan's post-quake relief and resettlement measures in the first one-and-half months after the quake, which killed some 6,000 people and left one-fifth of Kobe residents homeless.

Following his return from that visit, Chen said he pushed for the establishment of Taiwan's first firefighting bureau under the Taipei City Hall and took the initiative to set up a disaster-relief mechanism with the mayor or deputy mayor as the chief commander.

"This mechanism has functioned well in the relief center at Taipei's main disaster site in the Sept. 21 earthquake -- the Tunghsing Building," Chen said, adding that he hopes that his current visit will focus on studying how Japan's civic groups have coordinated with the Japanese government in post-quake reconstruction projects.
Chen was accompanies by several DPP members, including Legislator Chen Chi-mai, on his current Japan visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON DAN THREATENS QUAKE VICTIMS WITH DOWNPOURS

TEXT.P: Typhoon Dan, which hammered northern Luzon in the Philippines with winds gusting up to 170 kph on Tuesday, is seriously threatening quake victims in camps in central Taiwan with torrential downpours that may trigger landslides.

Some 100,000 people in the central counties of Nantou and Taichung were left homeless by a devastating magnitude-7.3 earthquake on Sept. 21, which also killed over 2,200 people and left more than 8,700 others injured.

Weather forecasters from the Central Weather Bureau feared that those staying in camps and taking refuge in military shelters and temporary houses must brace themselves for strong winds and heavy rains on Tuesday and the following two days as Typhoon Dan moves westward toward the South China Sea.

Although the typhoon is not heading for Taiwan, and its wind strength subsided from the previous 170 kph to 126 kph on Tuesday afternoon after making landfall in northern Luzon, Dan is expected to bring strong winds and torrential rains to the entire island of Taiwan, particularly its western and southern areas, the weather forecasters said.

Heavy rains are likely to trigger further landslides in the fragile and volatile mountainous areas in Nantou, Taichung and Yunlin counties that were hit hardest by the Sept. 21 earthquake, the deadliest to strike Taiwan this century.

Meanwhile, Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) warned that power rationing, which was imposed in the wake of the deadly earthquake, may resume if temporary high-voltage transmission lines are damaged by the typhoon.

Taipower was forced to impose power rationing on industrial and household electricity users in northern Taiwan after several of its substations and high-voltage transmission lines were ruined by the earthquake, interrupting north-bound transmission of electricity from the Taichung Thermal Power Plant in central Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT PROBLEM POLITICAL, CAN NOT BE SOLVED BY FORCE: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew said Tuesday the problem between Taiwan and mainland China is political in nature, so there is no way to solve it by military force as the mainland has long proclaimed.

Siew made the remark during the legislative general questioning session in response to a lawmaker who asked whether Taiwan had heightened combat readiness to counter reported mainland Chinese intentions to take one of Taiwan's offshore islands by force before Taiwan was hit by the devastating Sept. 21 earthquake.

Democratic Progressive Party legislator Chien Hsi-kai, who raised the question, said sources indicated that the mainland had planned a military drill near Taiwan and could have made use of the drill to take over one of our offshore isles in retaliation against Taiwan's "special state to state relationship" theory.

Chien also asked Siew whether armed forces authorities had ordered all army personnel stationed at offshore islands to refrain from taking leave so as to be prepared for confrontations with mainland Chinese.

Instead of answering the question directly, Siew said the mainland has never renounced the use of force in dealing with Taiwan. Taiwan has continued to strengthen combat ability in order to confront potential military threats from the mainland, he added.
Siew said he believed the mainland would hesitate to start a war since Taiwan has consistently improved its combat ability.

The premier went on to say that Taiwan does not support the idea of resolving cross-strait problems by force, and in handling cross-strait issues, will continue to uphold the principles of non-provocation and non-evasion, but reserves the right of self-defense. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL ANNUITY PROGRAM TO BE POSTPONED FOR ONE YEAR: CEPD

TEXT.P: Plans for the much-discussed National Annuity Program will be suspended for one year, as the country is now in dire need of vast quantities of cash to finance post-earthquake reconstruction, officials from the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said on Tuesday.
The postponement means that the timetable for implementing the national annuity program remains unclear, said Liu Yu-lan, director of CEPD's Manpower Planning Department.

President Lee Teng-hui estimated that it will take about NT$250 billion (US$7.86 billion) to finance post-disaster reconstruction. A devastating earthquake measuring 7.3 on the open-ended Richter scale struck central Taiwan on Sept. 21, leaving at least 2,200 people dead, more than 8,800 injured and some 100,000 others homeless.

The quake, the deadliest to hit Taiwan this century, gave Taiwan a geological facelift by flattening mountains, creating new lakes, and ruining most of the roads and infrastructure in the central Taiwan counties of Nantou, Taichung and Yunlin, where numerous buildings and houses have collapsed.

The national annuity program was originally scheduled to be launched in 2000, with estimated per capita monthly contributions of NT$870 (US$27) to be paid by eligible ROC nationals between the ages of 25 and 64. People aged 65 and over could receive a monthly pension of NT$2,000 (US$63) for the rest of their lives, according to preliminary CEPD plans.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT TIES MARKED BY AWAKENING AND WANING OF BROTHERHOOD
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 5 (CNA) (By Chang Hui-yen and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Political confrontation has stained relations between the two governments on either side of the Taiwan Strait, but under the surface, an awakened brotherhood has bridged the gap between the people of each side.

Compassion for each other has arisen since the late 70s, when the sweet and tender voice of the late popular Taiwanese singer Teng Li-chun penetrated the bamboo curtain and soothed thousands of mainland Chinese souls. Renewed contact and curiosity gave both sides opportunities for reconciliation.
The late 70s also became a turning point in Beijing's 50-year history when the reform-minded communist leader Deng Xiaoping allowed some openness toward the outside world.

In the 80s, Chinese people on the mainland were able to hear some undistorted stories about Taiwan. In 1987 when Taiwan permitted its people to visit relatives on the mainland, and mainlanders were allowed to come to the island for the same reason, direct contact between people first became possible. A long-forgotten brotherhood was reawakened.
Over the past 10 years, both Taipei and Beijing have gradually relaxed controls on visits between Taiwan and the mainland. Such visits have become more and more frequent.
The rekindled brotherhood could be witnessed with numerous academic and cultural exchanges and extensive economic activities by Taiwanese businesses in mainland China.

Nevertheless, a waning of such sentiment among the people of Taiwan could be sensed during the past two years. A mainland official even complained to a Central News Agency (CNA) reporter about Taiwan people's indifference when Beijing's embassy in Belgrade was bombed by NATO.

Between 1987 and 1998, people from Taiwan made a total of 19.5 million visits to mainland China. Most travel consisted of brief visits to relatives or sight-seeing tours. Few chose to settle there, not even those retired servicemen who withdrew to Taiwan with Chiang Kai-shek's troops, leaving their families behind in 1949 when the Chinese communists took over the mainland.

Nearly 214,000 mainlanders visited Taiwan between 1987 and 1997. Through the end of last August, a total of 29,258 mainlanders had been allowed by Taipei to resettle in Taiwan, and some 10,000 mainland women had married Taiwanese men.

Stowaways from the mainland have been a big headache for Taipei authorities. More then 35,000 were caught between 1987 and 1997, and authorities estimate that there are now some 1,400 in hiding across the island.
Polls conducted in the past few months indicate that indeed the people of Taiwan are drifting away from the aspiration of reunification.

In 1992 when northern China suffered from massive flooding, people in Taiwan responded immediately by sending handsome relief resources. The 1998 Yangtze flood did not give rise to comparable compassion "because the Taiwanese people's feelings were hurt by Beijing's arrogance and its untiring battering of Taiwan," said the CNA reporter.

She added that when people in Taiwan extend a helping hand to their compatriots on the mainland, they do not mix the gracious compassion arising out of brotherhood with politics. Furthermore, they can not accept Beijing's jeering comment that rescue and relief assistance from the international community is a result of Taiwan's "earthquake diplomacy."

The reporter said that after 50 years of separation, people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait require much goodwill as a basis for mutual trust. In pursuing a long-term goal of reunification, the people of Taiwan would demand such a reunion occur under a system based on liberty, democracy and economic equality.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S 1999 CPI GROWTH TO POST AT 0.5 PERCENT

TEXT.P: The annual growth rate of Taiwan's consumer price index (CPI) will amount to 0.5 percent this year, predicted the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) on Tuesday.
Director-General Shih Yen of the central bank's economic research department labeled the prediction as "reasonable," indicating that the figure suggests stable consumer prices in 1999.

The impact of the Sept. 21 earthquake and subsequent islandwide power rationing on the prices of goods will be limited, although there has been increased demand for certain items since the earthquake devastated Taiwan, claiming more than 2,200 lives, Shih noted.

During the first nine months of the year, the average CPI annual growth rate registered 0.27 percent, while September CPI growth was posted at 0.59 percent, according to statistics released by the DGBAS on Tuesday.
The statistics also show that in September, wholesale prices declined 4.28 percent and prices of imported goods dropped 2.5 percent, compared to the same period last year.

Shih said that there are several factors contributing to the stability of consumer prices this year, including Taiwan's tariff cuts for imported goods, the New Taiwan dollar's appreciation against the greenback, limited growth of domestic demand, and the real estate market's continued sluggishness.

DOC.HEADLINE: BIGGER JOLT UNLIKELY NEAR GROUND ZERO OF THE MAJOR QUAKE: EXPERTS

TEXT.P: It is unlikely that an earthquake stronger than the magnitude-7.3 temblor that wreaked havoc on the island Sept. 21 will strike the ground zero area in the next couple of years, seismologists from the Central Weather Bureau predicted on Tuesday.

The earthquake experts said although current science is still unable to predict earthquakes, they believe that a jolt bigger than the one on Sept. 21 is unlikely in the same area over the next couple of years.

Seismological data collected by the weather bureau showed that the frequency of aftershocks from the deadly Sept. 21 earthquake has gradually subsided, with less than 10 per hour on Tuesday, compared with the approximately 150 per hour detected in the first several days following the quake.
As of Tuesday afternoon, two weeks after the devastating quake, 11,131 aftershocks had been detected, and 104 of them were temblors of magnitude 4 or greater, the earthquake experts said.
They discouraged the general public from believing recent rumors that bigger earthquakes are bound to shake Taiwan again in the near future.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRES. LEE SAYS TAIWAN RELIEF ACTION THREE TIMES FASTER THAN JAPAN'S

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Tuesday quoted a member of Japan's Diet as saying that Taiwan's relief action for earthquake victims was three times faster than Japan's.
Taiwan also issued an emergency order more quickly than Japan, Lee said.
Therefore, Lee considered "we have done well" in dealing with relief efforts for earthquake victims.

He went on to say that the central government was performed well in issuing the emergency order. The government issued the order in only five days, whereas it had taken 37 days to issue a similar order to assist victims of a flood on Aug. 7, 1959, Lee said.

The Japanese Diet member quoted by Lee had become vice political minister of the Economic Planning Agency of Japan in Monday's Cabinet reshuffle. She donated 1,000 prefabricated houses to Taiwan and told Lee that Taiwan's relief action was three times faster than that of Japan.

Lee quoted the Diet member as reporting that Japan required a month to finish relief work, while Taiwan needed only 10 days. She was elected to the Diet from Hyogo Prefecture, where she rode a motorbike to the quake-stricken area every day after the 1995 Kobe earthquake. She spoke highly of Taiwan's "efficiency in dealing with the disaster."

Lee called on the populace to have confidence in "the government's disaster-handling capability" and to stand united so that reconstruction of quake-stricken areas may be accomplished as soon as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: REPAIR OF SOULS TOPS ALL ACTIONS, SAYS PRESIDENT LEE

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui said on Tuesday that efforts to repair souls as well as homes take priority among all post-earthquake work.

In his first press conference after a cataclysmic earthquake struck Taiwan on Sept. 21, Lee said his sorrow over those killed and injured and sympathy for others affected by the quake are no less than anyone's in the country.

Lee said he knows that the post-earthquake reconstruction work, laborious and challenging, could not possibly be done to everyone's satisfaction, but he is confident that the government is determined to accomplish the tasks in the shortest possible period.

The administrative agencies have since day one embarked on all-out rescue and relief efforts, hoping that reconstruction and rehabilitation will be carried out in the most efficient manner with the greatest possible speed, Lee noted.

He said it has been 15 days since the devastating earthquake struck the island. Over the past days, he said, he has visited the stricken areas several times to see the damage and hear the pleas from survivors.
The military and local fire-fighting units were the first forces to initiate rescue and emergency work after the deadly earthquake rattled central Taiwan at 1:47 a.m. on Sept. 21, Lee said.

The armed forces established advance emergency commands in the earthquake-stricken areas at 4 a.m. the same day, followed by the Executive Yuan, which mapped out contingent rescue and relief measures in the evening of that day, Lee added.

On Sept. 22, he said, the government declared the establishment of a post-earthquake supervisory headquarters, headed by Vice President Lien Chan, to coordinate efforts from the central and local governments and to see that the 15 emergency measures be carried out.

Over the past two weeks, the military and the public, as well as private emergency teams from home and abroad, have shed sweat and blood to search for and rescue victims, saving 4,963 lives and helping 4,685 others who were stranded, the president said.
However, he said, unfortunately there were still 2,256 people dead, 55 buried alive and 53 unaccounted for as of Tuesday.

Lee said that after he was briefed by the Executive Yuan on Oct. 2 regarding the progress of overall post-earthquake emergency and relief work, he issued a six-point reconstruction order, hoping that relevant agencies will complete their assigned tasks as follows:
-- Complete assessment of damaged and dangerous houses and buildings in earthquake-stricken areas in one week;
-- Complete erection of prefabricated housing units in hard-hit areas in 10 days;
-- Finish handling waste disposal in one month;
-- Help survivors repair their souls and free them from sorrow through the help of religious organizations;
-- Assign work to surviving victims, allowing them to repel fear through work so as to help them lead normal lives as soon as possible; and
-- Effectively carry out the orders of the emergency decree.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT: GOVERNMENT TO HELP AFFECTED PEOPLE REBUILD FAMILIES

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui said on Tuesday that the government is making all-out efforts to help earthquake-affected people rebuild their families.
"The government is confident and is determined to complete the reconstruction work," Lee told a press conference at the Presidential Office.
He said that the most important task at present is "how to help the affected people walk away from grief and rebuild their families and gardens."
The president expressed his sorrow over the casualties and losses incurred in the 7.3-magnitude temblor that ripped central Taiwan before dawn on Sept. 21.
More than 2,250 persons were killed and more than 8,000 others were injured in the strongest quake to hit Taiwan in nearly 100 years.

He extended his gratitude, on behalf of the ROC government and the people, for the concern and assistance from the international community, the armed forces, and fire-fighting and rescue personnel, as well as philanthropic groups throughout the island.
In the wake of the quake, Lee said, the government took swift action to rescue trapped victims and to resettle displaced people.
The government's first-phase tasks have been going smoothly and are almost finished, and ongoing second-phase tasks are focused on reconstruction work, he said.

To expedite implementation of related government measures, Lee pointed out, the government set up a center to coordinate rescue and relief efforts on Sept. 22, headed by Vice President Lien Chan, and the president promulgated an emergency decree on Sept. 25.

Lee went on to say that he further issued a six-point order on Oct. 2, with the main points being: completing checks on dangerous buildings within one week, completing establishment of prefabricated housing units in hard-hit areas within 10 days, and completing disposal of waste and rubble within one month.
Although not all the people were satisfied with the government's measures, the president said, he was satisfied with what the government has done.
He quoted a Japanese Lower House member as having said that "Taiwan's rescue operations were three times faster than those of Japan," when compared with the 1995 Hanshin earthquake.
Lee also stressed the importance of training and equipment for fire-fighting and rescue personnel, saying that the government should increase the budget for the National Fire-Fighting Agency.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Wednesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
President Lee Teng-hui calls for new vision in rebuilding homes after the 921 earthquake.

Leave the shadow of sadness behind us and rebuild our homes, urges President Lee.

DOC.HEADLINE: THINK TANK SAYS 'AMERO' MONETARY UNION WOULD BENEFIT CANADA

TEXT.P: A Canadian research institute says a common North American currency would bring about lower long-term interest rates, greater price stability and improved trade.

A report released by the Fraser Institute calls for a North American Monetary Union that includes Canada, the United States, and Mexico. Such an arrangement would benefit Canada, as its productivity and living standards would increase, the study says.
It proposes a common currency, called the "amero," which would have its own distinctive emblem on one side and national symbols on the other.
The study's author, Herbert Grubel, argues that flexible exchange rates have not brought Canada the benefits promised by its advocates.
Instead, he says, they have reduced labor market flexibility and delayed Canada's adjustment to declining world prices for natural resources.
"This system has contributed to Canada's high and excessive reliance on the production of natural resources," says Grubel, a senior fellow at the Vancouver-based institute.

"A monetary union will ensure that we move to the high-tech and other profitable and expanding industries at a more optimal pace, and Canadians' productivity and living standards will increase correspondingly."

The study also argues that Canada's cultural sovereignty and political independence would not be affected by monetary union, because it would not inhibit Canada's ability to pursue its own tax, spending, social, regulatory and foreign policies.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN RED WINE SET AUCTIONED OFF AT WORLD RECORD PRICE

TEXT.P: A rare set of 44 bottles of Penfolds Grange Australian vintage red wine, bottled between 1951 and 1994 has scored a world record price, fetching A$123,200 (approx. US$81,060) at an auction in Adelaide on Tuesday night.
The previous record price of A$85,000 (US$55,920) for a full set of Penfolds Grange was set in Sydney early this year.
A spokesman for the auction told reporters that the set, comprising one vintage bottle from each year between 1951 and 1994, was sold to an Adelaide businessman, who declined to be identified.
The Adelaide businessman beat off two phone bidders to win the rare set collected by a Melbourne-based private collector.

There are only between 10 and 15 complete sets of Penfolds Grange in existence in the world, some of which carry the personal signature of Max Schubert, the creator of the Penfold Grange, according to the wine industry here.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE AUSTRALIANS TURN TO INTERNET FOR SHOPPING

TEXT.P: Australians are increasingly turning to the Internet to buy everything from CDs, flowers, and books to holidays, causing on-line sales to grow at a rate of 500 percent a year with the figure expected to top A$10 (US$6.58) billion by the year 2001.

In 1998, on-line sales of books, computers, CDs and other consumer products totaled only A$200 (US$132) million. That figure is expected to rise to almost A$1 billion (US$658 million) by the end of this year, before jumping to A$5 (US$3.3) billion by the year 2000, according to a Sydney-based internet sales analyst.
The analyst told reporters that the lion's share of Internet transactions are done by businesses which buy computers, travel and other services directly from suppliers.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN STEEL GIANT ANNOUNCES MASSIVE SALES OF ITS OPERATIONS

TEXT.P: Australia's largest mining and industrial giant has announced massive sales of its steel operations, cutting in half the number of its plants, in a bid to reduce losses due to increased competition from imports.

The announcement was made Tuesday by the chief executive of Broken Hill Proprietary Ltd., Paul Anderson, who said the sell-off marks a historic decision to pull out of the steel industry after the company closed its steel plant in Newcastle, New South Wales last week, laying off 1,500 workers.

He told reporters the company would sell three more steel plants worth A$3 billion (US$1.97 billion) and would only retain its profitable steel mill in Port Kembla, New South Wales, which produces steel sheeting for use in car manufacturing construction and packaging.
Anderson said the massive sales could result in the layoff of 3,500 workers and help reduce BHP's steel operations losses.
BHP exports its products to about 30 countries around the world, including Taiwan.
