DOC.HEADLINE: RAYS OF COMPASSION AT EARTHQUAKE-STRICKEN SITES
DOC.DATELINE: Nantou, central Taiwan, Oct. 6 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A young Japanese female survivor of the 1995 Kobe quake came to Taiwan to pitch in with relief efforts three days after the island was hit by a devastating jolt on Sept. 21.

Lin Hsia-mei, using her Han Chinese pseudonym, put aside her own studies at an international studies graduate school to join a Japanese emergency team sent to Taiwan to aid in search and rescue operations.

She ended up staying after the Japanese emergency team pulled out, joining the volunteer forces sponsored by Tzu Chi, the island's largest Buddhist and philanthrophic organization founded by Taiwan's Mother Teresa -- Master Cheng Yen.
In the first week after her arrival, Lin helped by cooking at a shelter center in Chungliao, a township in central Taiwan severely affected by the quake.

Later, she transferred to Nantou City, located in the hardest hit county, pitching in with masonry work on the playing field of a baseball stadium where some two hundred prefabricated housing units were built to house people made homeless by the deadly earthquake.

Lin, whose own home was ruined during the Kobe quake in 1995, said it took her years to forget the horrible memories that used to repeatedly run through her mind. The earthquake-stricken scene she saw in central Taiwan brought back those nightmares.

At the same time, she said she was overwhelmed by the spirit of community involvement the Taiwanese people demonstrated and the compassion they showed toward their fellow countrymen in the wake of the catastrophe.

After the deadly quake struck Taiwan, most of the roads and bridges in the most affected areas were damaged. As a result, the military Seagull Rescue Operation Squadron served as the only means of transportation to and from earthquake-stricken areas
Hung Ai-wen, an Air Force helicopter pilot and a graduate from the ROC Air Force Academy, has toiled day in and day out since the quake hit by flying search, logistics and air-drop operations.
Even though her wedding was only three days away, Hung continued her flying missions over the disaster areas. "My wedding's nothing compared with running missions to save lives," she said.
Liu Shui-yuan, owner of a metal plate factory in Chushan, also one of the hardest hit townships in central Taiwan, received a new nickname in the wake the quake -- Uncle Water.
Liu, 61, had a deep-water well drilled in his backyard in downtown Chushan just days before the quake struck.

The Chushan Township, as well as all the hardest hit counties of Nantou, Taichung and Yunlin, were left with no water and electricity after the quake when the Shihkang Dam, the major water and power supplier in the region, partly burst and several conveying pipes were damaged.
Liu's well, with precious water flowing all day long, turned out to be the sole water source in the vast neighborhood.
Liu not only offered free water to his neighbors, but also asked the local police station to broadcast to the entire town where the people could go to receive clean water free of charge.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE THAN 5,500 STUDENTS SOJOURNED AFTER QUAKE

TEXT.P: The devastating earthquake of Sept. 21 damaged a large number of schools in central Taiwan, forcing more than 5,500 youngsters to be sojourned to other cities and counties in order to continue their schooling, Education Minister Yang Chao-hsiang said on Wednesday.
A total of 5,518 teenagers and children from the earthquake-stricken areas have been moved out of their demolished towns to continue their studies in safe places around the island, Yang noted.
The sojourned students have either been consigned to the care of their adopted parents, or are staying with their adult relatives or in boarding schools, Yang added.
Yang said the sojourned youths, who may have suffered lingering emotional damage in the wake of the destructive earthquake, need extra care and guidance in their new study environment away from home.

Taichung, the closest city to the earthquake-stricken central Taiwan counties of Nantou, Taichung and Yunlin, received the greatest number of the sojourned youths islandwide -- a total 1,091 junior high and primary school students.
Taipei City and Taipei County in northern Taiwan followed, receiving 742 and 692 students respectively.

Other teenagers and children were relocated to Changhua County (685), Taichung County (586), Taoyuan County (330), Kaohsiung County (255), Miaoli County (239), Chiayi County (184), Hsinchu County (136), Yunlin County (116) and Tainan City (109), according to Yang.
Meanwhile, about 4,100 additional servings of lunch are needed daily in schools in less seriously damaged earthquake-affected areas, Yang said.
He added that the Buddhist Tzu Chi Compassionate Relief Foundation and the Fuokuangshan Monastery are currently assisting those schools by serving additional meals for students.

DOC.HEADLINE: US SHOULD CLEARLY STATE TAIWAN DEFENSE POLICY: EXPERT

TEXT.P: Beijing should be made to understand that the United States will intervene militarily on Taiwan's behalf if Communist China attacks, according to an American expert.

Ross H. Munro, director of Asian studies at the Center for Security Studies in Washington, wrote in the National Review that Beijing's dramatic statements on Taiwan, aimed primarily at the American audience, are designed in part to hide the fact that Communist China's policy on Taiwan is "the product of a careful weighing of China's strategic interests."

In the eyes of PRC leaders, Munro pointed out, Taiwan is first and foremost a strategic target that must soon be subjugated if Communist China is to realize its goal of becoming Asia's dominant and unchallenged power. But the Clinton administration, unfortunately, with its persistent obtuseness, has failed to recognize Communist China's policy as a clear challenge to the vital strategic interests of the United States.

Munro noted that in fact, the Taiwan issue would not be incendiary today if there had not been a momentous shift in Communist Chinese "Grand Strategy" in the first half of the 1990s. Just as Taiwan was reaching a democratic consensus in favor of continued autonomy, the post-Deng Xiaoping generation of younger and more ambitious political and military leaders in mainland China was adopting a new grand strategy. The goal is to dominate Asia as every Chinese dynasty at the height of its power had done throughout history.

Suddenly, he said, the Beijing regime saw Taiwan's autonomy in a new and adversarial light: as a barrier preventing Communist China from achieving its strategic ambitions. The new generation of political and military leaders had concluded by 1994 that, in order to achieve the goal of dominating Asia, it must first seize control of Taiwan.

In December 1994, Munro wrote, the Communist Chinese military establishment held what amounted to a closed-door "Invade Taiwan!" pep rally. Sponsored by the Ministry of National Defense and the PLA's General Staff Headquarters, the gathering was characterized by officials as a "report session on strategic policy on Taiwan."

The main themes of the four-day meeting were that it would be necessary to use military force to achieve reunification and that "it will be better to resolve the issue of Taiwan earlier than doing it later. This will help develop the entire country and stabilize Asia and the whole world." It was also stated that "the most appropriate time" to attack Taiwan was between 2000 and 2005.

The timing of these events is significant, according to Munro, because they all preceded by many months the announcement of President Lee Teng-hui's visit to Cornell University, the event that most US Sinologists identify as the turning point in Communist China's Taiwan policy. Obviously, the Communist Chinese leadership, particularly military leaders, seized on this event as an excuse to bare their real intentions towards Taiwan.

But perhaps the clearest evidence of Beijing's new strategic ambitions, Munro said, appeared in a March 1996 article published by "Taiwan Affairs," a PRC journal. The title alone -- "Taiwan's Geostrategic Value Makes Reunification Essential" says it all. After reiterating the usual argument that Taiwan has always been part of China, author Lu Junyuan made it plain that Communist China's real interest in Taiwan is as a strategically valuable piece of real estate, saying "We can thus see that Taiwan occupies a unique and advantageous spot on the geostrategic map."

Yet, Munro pointed out, President Bill Clinton and his top officials refused to recognize that there is a fundamental strategic conflict of interest between Communist China and the United States: Beijing wants to dominate Asia, while Washington is still committed to maintaining a balance of power in Asia and preventing any single power from dominating the whole region. They also blamed Taiwan for preventing US-PRC relations from being dramatically and permanently improved.

Munro is convinced that the United States should first learn from Communist China. The Communist Chinese are right in attaching enormous strategic importance to Taiwan, he said. The United States has no military forces based in Taiwan, nor does it need them, as long as Taiwan's own robust forces continue to control its territory. The American military should remain the back-up force -- ready to intervene on Taiwan's behalf if the island is unable to counter a Communist Chinese military offensive.
Second, Washington should reduce "strategic ambiguity." For many years, Munro wrote.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DOWN, INDEX FUTURES MIXED

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed 0.7 percent lower Wednesday while heavy selling pressure amid profit-taking continued.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index shed 55.38 points to close at 7,501.63.
A total of 1.82 billion shares changed hands on a turnover of NT$69.17 billion (US$2.18 billion).
Construction material shares suffered from serious losses as investors were worried that removal of the daily lower-limit on fluctuations, which is scheduled for next week, could spark bigger losses.

The Ministry of Finance on Sept. 27 slashed the daily limit for stock market drops from the standard maximum drop of 7 percent to the current 3.5 percent to help stabilize the bourse following the devastating Sept. 21 earthquake that claimed more than 2,200 lives.
The adjustment was only effective for two weeks, and the daily upper-limit of 7 percent remained unchanged.
Cement issues reported the largest losses, ending the day with 3.2-percent losses, while share prices dropped and closed at the limit across the board.
Financial issues remained weak amid concerns over a growing amount of mortgage-related losses sustained by banks after the quake. The sector closed with 1.9-percent losses.
Only electronics shares reported gains among the eight major stock categories, listing 0.1-percent losses.
Decliners outnumbered advancers 388 to 80, with 59 shares unchanged.
The over-the-counter market dropped 2.14 points to close at 167.17 on a turnover of NT$3.78 billion.

TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for October moved up 25 points to close at 7,535 with 1,781 contract transactions; those for November rose 10 points to finish at 7,520 with 75 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for December climbed eight points to close at 7,520 with three contract transactions; those for next June shed 10 points to end at 8,080 with one contract transaction.
No transaction records were registered for next March futures.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Wednesday were 7,510 points for October, 7,510 points for November, 7,512 points for December, 7,600 points for next March, and 7,609 points for next June.

Electronics futures and financial futures, which are sub-index futures and based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares (TE) and financial shares (TF), reported gains and losses, respectively.
October TE futures rose 3.1 points to close at 347.6 with 427 contract transactions; November TE futures declined 1.8 points to end at 345.2 with eight contract transactions.
There were no transaction records for other months' TE futures.

October TF futures fell 5.4 points to close at 950.6 with 114 contract transactions, November TF futures dropped 26.6 to finish at 938.2 with two contract transactions, while TF futures for other months had no transaction records. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO LAUNCH RELIEF SALES OF AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) under the Executive Yuan is to launch a program to sell agricultural products as a relief project for earthquake victims in the island's agricultural zone, said the head of the COA on Tuesday.
The worst temblor in a century, which struck Taiwan on Sept. 21, greatly damaged central-island harvests, noted COA Chairman Peng Tso-kwei.

The Cabinet-level COA will sponsor three events in the near future to promote the sale of "earthquake tea" and "earthquake pears," among other agricultural products, to help quake-affected growers weather their harsh plight, said Peng.
The killer quake has resulted in devastating losses for growers of pears, bananas, tea and oranges; this year's orange harvest is likely to sustain losses of 30 percent, Peng pointed out.

Although the damage attributed to the quake is limited to a few kinds of fruit and tea, and thus will not affect the supply of fruits and vegetables islandwide, the government still hopes that the public will show their love and generosity by purchasing agricultural products from quake-affected growers.

The agricultural products sales program sponsored by the COA will focus on the sale of pears and persimmons from Tongshih Township, star fruit from Choulan Township, and oranges from the townships of Fungyuan and Daikaug, said COA officials.
Public supermarkets run by the local governments of Taipei County and Taipei City will cooperate with the COA's relief program.
Purchases totaling over NT$1,000 can be delivered to customers' homes, said COA officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA WANTS TO BUY OLD US WARSHIPS

TEXT.P: Australia is seeking to buy four old destroyers from the United States in a bid to enhance its deteriorating strategic security environment following tension with its neighbors over East Timor.
The Australian Financial Review on Wednesday reported that a proposal to buy four US Kidd-class destroyers or four Arleigh Burke-class destroyers was made to the Defense Department.

The daily quoted industry sources as saying that the Pentagon was offering the destroyers to Australia at bargain-basement prices. The US offer includes completely upgrading the Kidd-class destroyers and leasing them to Australia for about US$38 million each for three years. The sources described the offer as attractive.
Admiral David Shackleton, the chief of the Australian Royal Navy, is understood to favor the purchase of the US destroyers, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: UN TO BOOST MILITARY PRESENCE IN E. TIMOR
DOC.DATELINE: Canberra, Oct. 6 (CNA) (By Peter Chen) (By Pete Chen)

TEXT.P: Canberra, Oct. 6 (CNA): The United Nations will increase the international military presence in East Timor to 9000 troops and boost the police force to 1640 officers as part of its plan to convert the Australian-led force into a peacekeeping mission.

Meanwhile, Bishop Carlos Belo, spiritual leader of East Timor and pro-independence leader Xanana Gusmao are expected to return to Dili on Wednesday. Both will fly to the capital of East Timor from Australia.

The UN plan is laid out in a special report on East Timor by Secretary General Kofi Annan, who is going to present it to the Security Council members this week, according to the Sydney Morning Herald on Wednesday.
Under the plan, the UN will allow Australia to begin scaling down its military presence as early as next month as the transition to a UN force begins, the daily reported.

In Dili, the Australian-led UN force has struck a temporary deal with pro-independence Falintil guerrillas under which the Timorese fighters could keep their weapons so long as they stay away from international forces, according to a dispatch by the Herald from the capital of East Timor.

But Major General Peter Cosgrove of Australia, commander of the UN force, warned that he would be pressing "in the strongest possible terms" for the guerrillas to hand over their arms, the daily reported.
Gusmao, who many see as the president after East Timor becomes independent, said it was too early for Falintil forces to disarm and he urged the UN to retrain them for a new security force.
The Australian-led UN force on Tuesday moved into East Timor's southern region on a mission to disarm two of the last remaining militia strongholds.

The Australian troops will be bolstered by Thai soldiers who are scheduled to arrive in East Timor on Wednesday, led by Major General Songkitti Chakkabatr, who will take up his position as deputy commander of the multinational forces, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Oct. 6, or the 27th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1014: Basil II, emperor of Byzantine, brings his country's 28-year war with Bulgaria to an end by blinding Tzar Samuel's defeated army of 15,000 men, an act of unprecedented savagery.
1536: William Tyndale, English reformer and Bible translator, is strangled and burned at the stake at Vivarde near Brussels on orders from King Henry VIII.
1552: Mateo Ricci, Italian Jesuit missionary to China, is born. He spent the last 30 years of his life in China.
1807: Sir Humphrey Davy, English chemist, discovers a new metallic chemical element and calls it potassium.
1860: The Franco-British force captures Peking. The Ching court was thus compelled to make further concessions in the 1860 Treaty of Peking.
1908: Crete, conquered and ruled by the Ottoman Empire since 1669, declares its merger with Greece.
1908 Austria annexes Bosnia and Herzegovina.
1913: Yuan Shih-kai forced the Congress to elect him president of the Republic of China.
1925: Chiang Kai-shek becomes commander-in-chief of the Canton military government and begins to launch the second eastern expedition.
1927: The International Stock Exchange Center of the New York Stock Exchange is formally opened.
1927: New York is abuzz with the latest entertainment phenomenon -- a film with sound, called a "talkie," when Warner Brothers premieres their revolutionary film, "The Jazz Singer," starring Al Jolson, at the Warner Theater.
1937: The League of Nations condemns Japanese aggression against China.
1937: The State Department of the United States condemns Japan's invasion of China.
1939: Chinese troops win the first battle of Changsha in Hunan Province against invading Japanese forces.
1946: The Chinese communists turn down General George C. Marshall's cease-fire proposal.
1951: Sir Henry Gurney, British high commissioner in Malaya, is killed in an ambush by communist terrorists in the Pahang Hills.
1958: Seawolf, a US nuclear submarine, surfaces off New England's coast after setting a world record by remaining submerged for two months.
1963: President Hubert Maga of Benin and his wife arrive in Taipei for a six-day state visit.
1963: Cyclone hits Haiti, killing nearly 4,000 people.
1964: The Republic of China and Uruguay sign a treaty of amity in Taipei.
1973: As Israelis are beginning Yom Kippur, one of the holiest days in the Jewish calendar, a joint Egyptian-Syrian invasion force is attacking their country on two fronts, triggering the fourth Middle East war.
1976: A coup in Thailand results in military takeover following violent clashes between police and students.
1980: The first World Congress of Chinese Medicine and Pharmacology sponsored by the National Union of the Chinese Medical Doctors' Association opens in Taipei.
1981: Egyptian President Anwar Sadat is assassinated by Islamic extremists while reviewing a military parade in Cairo. He was succeeded by Vice President Hosni Mubarak on Oct. 13.
1986: The ROC's Ministry of Economic Affairs decides to invest NT$1.2 billion in developing anti-pollution technology over the next three years.
1987: The National Chiang Kai-shek Cultural Center (National Theater, Concert Hall), is inaugurated after six years of construction which cost NT$7.5 billion.
1989: Typhoon Angela hits northern coast of Luzon in the Philippines, killing more than 100 people.
1991: An Indonesian military plane crashes into a government building in Jakarta, killing 102 people and injuring more than 5,000 others.
1993: Russian President Boris Yeltsin demands the resignation of his opponents in the provinces after putting down rebellious legislators.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only the man with the most perfect divine moral nature who is able to combine in himself quickness of apprehension, intelligence, insight, and understanding: qualities necessary for the exercise of command."

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar moved slightly down against the greenback on the Taipei market Wednesday in a thin trading.
The local currency opened at 31.781 against the US dollar, and was traded between 31.781 and 31.795 before closing at 31.787. It reported a drop of 0.2 cents during the session.

Affected by a strong US dollar, the major currency in Asia suffered from losses. Despite so, NT dollar is expected to remain stable as the Central Bank of China has vowed to maintain a stable foreign exchange market.
Interbank US dollar trading shrank to US$13.6million, the lowest daily turnover, except for the weekend,over the past six and half months. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: US WINERY, KINMEN CO. PLAN TO JOINTLY MARKET 'KAOLIANG SAKE'

TEXT.P: The popular Kinmen kaoliang (sorghum) wine has attracted interest from a US winery that intends to cooperate with the Kinmen County government-run distillery to produce a sorghum-rice blended liquor for markets worldwide.

American United Distilled Products Co. (AUDP) President Douglas Mangine paid a courtesy call on Kinmen County Magistrate Chen Shui-tsai, who concurrently serves as Kinemen Wine Co. chairman, on Wednesday to discuss possible cooperative projects.
Kinmen, a Taiwan-held frontline island group, lies closer to mainland China than to Taiwan.
Mangine was accompanied by Masanobu Shinohara, head of the AUDP's Tokyo office, and Yuichiro Hamada, chairman of Japan's Hamada Wine Co., an AUDP subcontractor, during his Kinmen trip.
Mangine told Chen that they have tasted the Kinmen-produced kaoliang wine and were impressed by its fine quality and special flavor.
Mangine said his company hopes to cooperate with Kinmen Wine Co. in producing and marketing sorghum-rice blended wine, or kaoliang sake, around the world.
Chen said Kinmen Wine Co. welcomes the AUDP cooperation proposal, adding that making inroads to the world market is Kinmen Wine Co.'s long-term business goal.
In fact, Kinmen Wine Co. has produced three flavors of kaoliang sake, with alcohol contents ranging between 12 percent and 15 percent.
Chen guided his guests in touring Kinmen Wine Co.'s second distillery, where kaoliang sake is produced. After savoring a cup of kaoliang sake, Mangine gave it the thumbs up for good flavor.

Kinmen kaoliang has long commanded a large share of Taiwan's highly competitive spirits market. Chen said Kinmen kaoliang also enjoys a warm welcome in mainland China, where its black market price is twice the retail price in Taiwan.
Noting that former Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev is a kaoliang wine fan, Chen said Gorbachev bought a dozen bottles of Kinmen kaoliang when he visited Taiwan a few years ago.

Chen said Kinmen Wine Co.'s board of directors will meet in the next few days to discuss the AUDP cooperative proposal. If all goes smoothly, Kinmen Wine Co. will form a strategic alliance with the US firm to jointly explore new markets for its kaoliang sake.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN POISED TO BECOME WORLD'S WAFER FOUNDRY HUB, SAYS TSMC CEO
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 6 (CNA) (By Jennifer Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: With continued growth in semiconductor design capability and expansion of OEM production techniques, Taiwan will undoubtedly turn out to be the world's wafer foundry hub in the years ahead, a leading electronics industrialist said on Wednesday.

Morris Chang, chair and CEO of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC), said it will still take some 20 to 25 years for the world's semiconductor industry to mature. During that period before the industry becomes saturated with producers, the sky is the limit for semiconductor makers and foundry services to continue to flourish, he noted.

Taiwan's domestically-developed IC chips are expected to account for 30 percent to 40 percent of the world market in the next 20 to 25 years, Chang said. Currently, Taiwan makes about 10 percent of the world's IC chips.
Chang made the remarks during a speech upon receiving an honorary doctorate in mechanical engineering from the New York Institute of Technology on Tuesday.

Chang, who holds a doctorate in electrical engineering from Stanford University, has successfully built TSMC into one of the top silicon wafer producers in the world in about 14 years, providing microchips to clients worldwide.
TSMC, Taiwan's biggest foundry, is catching up with Intel in the development of cutting-edge microchip technology.

Regarding the devastating earthquake that struck Taiwan on Sept. 21, Chang said disruption of electricity in the wake of the quake has forced TSMC to suspend production for about 10 days, incurring an overall loss of no more than NT$1 billion (US$31.44 million).
Now, some two weeks after the quake, 98 percent of TSMC'S production lines in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, Taiwan's Silicon Valley, have been recalibrated, Chang said.

Chang said TSMC is expected to upgrade its current techniques for manufacturing eight-inch IC wafers to be able to produce 12-inch models by the end of 2001 or early 2002. He said Intel, the first company in the world to use 12-inch wafers, is not expected to commercially produce the larger wafers until 2001.

Dr. Chang Chung-jui, a Taiwan-born scientist and president of the New York Institute of Technology, on Tuesday presided over a brief ceremony to offer a silent salute to the victims of Taiwan's Sept. 21 quake. The institute has regular annual enrollment of students from Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARAGUAYANS EXPRESS CONCERN FOR TAIWAN QUAKE VICTIMS
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, Paraguay, Oct. 6 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Paraguayan political and civic leaders and overseas Chinese in Paraguay expressed their deep concern over the earthquake that jolted Taiwan Sept. 21, claiming more than 2,200 lives and injuring more than 8,500 people.
They have so far collected more than US$300,000 for quake relief in an on-going fund drive.

The day after the earthquake, President Luis Gonzalez addressed the General Assembly of the United Nations. In addition to firmly supporting the Republic of China's bid to join the world body, he expressed sorrow and support for quake victims.

The Paraguayan acting foreign minister cabled the ROC government with condolences for victims' families. The Senate passed a resolution in support of those affected by the quake, and sent representatives of the three main political parties to present it to ROC Ambassador Agustin Liu. Sympathy poured in from civic leaders who expressed their concern to Liu through telephone calls and letters.

A series of earthquake-aftermath photographs and news reports will be exhibited at shopping centers, business centers and universities on Oct. 10 with the aim of collecting signatures to support quake victims in spirit.

Overseas Chinese in Paraguay and religious organizations, such as Tzu Chi and Buddha's Light Fo Kuan Shan, will hold a charity sale on Oct. 10. and Paraguay's national radio station will hold a women's choral concert on Oct. 13, with all proceeds to be added to the relief fund.
Wang Shan-tsai, publisher of a Chinese-language newspaper in Paraguay, presented US$4,400 on behalf of the newspaper to Liu as a donation for victims in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOURISM BUREAU, TRAVEL AGENTS JOIN FORCES TO WOO FOREIGN TOURISTS

TEXT.P: The Tourism Bureau said on Wednesday it will invite senior editors and journalists of major foreign news media to visit Taiwan as part of its efforts to help foreigners better understand the island's post-earthquake situation.

The bureau said extensive coverage by international news media of a devastating earthquake that ripped through mountainous central Taiwan's Nantou County on Sept. 21 has prompted many prospective foreign tourists to cancel their Taiwan travel plans.

Many foreigners mistakenly thought that Taiwan, a small and densely populated island, had all been affected by the 7.3-magnitude earthquake, the bureau said, adding that their cancellation of visits to Taiwan has dealt a serious blow to all travel-related industries here, including airlines, hotels, tour bus companies, giftware shops and the like.
To help travel-related services weather their current difficulties, the bureau called a meeting on Wednesday to discuss concrete tourist promotion measures.

During the meeting, several carriers operating scheduled flight services to and from Taiwan, including China Airlines, EVA Airways and Japan Asia Airways, promised to offer free tickets and Grand Hotel agreed to offer free accommodations for foreign media executives, editors and reporters.

The Tourism Bureau said it will invite media professionals from Japan, Hong Kong, the United States, Singapore and other areas around the world to visit earthquake-stricken central Taiwan and other parts of the island to help them better understand the island's true situation.

"We hope that through their reports, prospective foreign travelers will come to understand that except for central Taiwan's Nantou and Taichung counties, all other parts of the island were hardly affected by the 921 earthquake," said a bureau official.

DOC.HEADLINE: VEEP LIEN CALLS FOR FAST HANDLING OF LAW-BREAKING BUILDERS

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan said on Wednesday that law enforcement authorities should accelerate investigation of suspected violations of building codes by some property developers in order to ease homeless earthquake victims' grievances.
Lien made the demand in his capacity as a vice chairman of the ruling Kuomintang at a weekly meeting of the party's decision-making Central Standing Committee.

Lien, also the KMT's presidential candidate for the 2000 presidential election, said the recent devastating earthquake has exposed many shortcomings and deficiencies in enforcing the country's building codes.

"We have added strict anti-seismic provisions to our national building codes in 1972. However, some buildings didn't meet the updated codes," Lien said, adding that many crumbled structures in quake-stricken areas had been erected by unscrupulous builders who used empty plastic bottles and tin cans as filler to save concrete and bricks.
Lien said conversion of buildings originally designed for residential use into office complexes has also proved to be a big problem.

Noting that lax enforcement of building codes was one of the major factors behind the collapse of several high-rise buildings built after 1972, Lien said the government should make an overall review of the existing building codes and tighten enforcement of the provisions to prevent recurrence of similar tragedies.

Lien said although some contractors, property developers, architects or civil engineers involved in construction of buildings which crumbled in the quake have been banned from leaving the country, none of them have been indicted. "I hope prosecutors responsible for probing those cases will speed up investigations and bring all those who have violated existing codes to justice," he added. The 7.3-magnitude temblor that ripped through mountainous central Taiwan's Nantou County on Sept. 21 has claimed more than 2,200 lives, injured over 8,300 others and left some 100,000 people homeless.

Lien said all relevant government agencies should cut red tape and simplify procedures in handling post-quake relief work. Moreover, Lien said banks should offer the best possible terms for loans applications from quake-affected people.

In addition, Lien suggested that those who had any family members killed or severely injured in the tremor or whose houses were toppled or seriously damaged be given a six-month exemption from National Health Insurance payment. Farmers and blue-collar workers in the quake-stricken areas who had endured either of the above-mentioned misfortunes should also be exempted from labor or farmers insurance premium payments for six months, he added.
The Cabinet is expected to approve the proposals to exempt those quake-affected people, laborers or farmers from relevant insurance payments for six months at its weekly meeting on Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-US AIR FORCE SQUADRON HOLDS REUNION IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Confidentiality was the name of the game for the 34th Squadron of the Republic of China Air Force and its numerous missions over the China mainland in the 1950s and 60s. For many years, the flying unit remained a mystery, and no participants in the ROC-US project could imagine an eventual reunion in Taipei.

A reunion was finally realized after 40 years, under the initiative of retired Col. Donald Jackson of the United States and retired Gen. I Fu-en of the Republic of China. Some 40 retired pilots, navigators and electronic warfare officers belonging to the US Central Intelligence Agency-supported project had a warm and nostalgic get-together at the Grand Hotel on Oct. 6.

The attendants at the Oct. 6 lunch meeting, all in their 70s, represent no more than 30 percent of the gallant airmen who participated in the daring project, which came to an end in the early 1970s with the advancement of spy satellite technology.

According to the ROC general, the 34th Squadron suffered the heaviest toll in action among the ROC Air Force units. Between the early 1950s and the mid-1960s, the squadron carried out 838 missions, including 585 sorties over the China mainland and 253 over Vietnam. A total of 140 airmen lost their lives in the low-altitude flight missions over vast areas guarded by strong air defense systems.

The ROC general said that during the years of confrontation between the United States and the Chinese Communists, the information collected in the missions "opened a window over the China mainland." He pointed out that this information and aerial photos were important for the Bomber Defense Analysis Center in Hsinchu, a unit that studied critical targets for US strategic air force bombers and missiles in the event of war.
He added that the information "indeed strengthened the position of the leaders in Washington when dealing with the Chinese Communists at that time."

On behalf of the US veterans attending the luncheon, the US colonel said that the reunion in Taipei was a sweet and sorrowful gathering. It took two years for him to establish contacts with his old colleagues, and after finally deciding to fly to Taipei for the occasion, they heard about the tragic earthquake disaster.

Wondering whether the reunion could still be realized, he called the ROC general and was impressed to learn that all details for the reunion were being taken care of. Over the past few days, the US veterans flew to Taipei in groups, and the reunion party was held on Oct. 6 as planned.

At the luncheon, the US colonel and other US electronic warfare officers who had spent between three to five years in Taiwan in the 1950s and 60s recalled how the project was designed and how dangerous missions were planned. The Chinese pilots and navigators, on the other hand, recounted the tremendous dangers of the missions.
On this joyful occasion, however, all attendants nevertheless remembered the many airmen lost in action and some others who had passed away over the past few years.

The 40-year wait for the reunion might be a little long, but better late than never. "As a matter of fact, this kind of reunion was not possible for many years due to the confidential characteristic of the organization and its missions," explained the ROC general.
In the past two decades, stories about the squadron were gradually revealed. A get-together was not seen as a problem, but for a long time it did not occur to anyone to organize such a reunion.

With the efforts of all surviving members of the squadron, the reunion was realized at last. The ROC general discussed the significance of the gathering, saying that "our reunion today ostensibly is a happy get-together of old friends, but in essence, it is a testimony of the contribution made by the 34th Squadron to the free world."

DOC.HEADLINE: M'LAND DISSIDENT, LEE COULD BE NOBEL PEACE PRIZE WINNER
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Oct. 6 (CNA) (By Stanley Chang and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Mainland dissidents Wang Dan and Wei Jingsheng and Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui are possible recipients of this year's Nobel Peace Prize, a Hong Kong-based human rights organization said Wednesday.

"A key person in Norway who knows the recipient's identity unintentionally revealed that the recipient 'has something to do with China,' and, based on this remark, Wang Dan and Wei Jingsheng are likely recipients," the Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China said.
The center quoted well-informed sources as saying that this year's Nobel peace award laureate was selected at a meeting on Sept. 29, and only a few key people know the result.

"The Chinese authorities will be unhappy with this year's Nobel Peace Prize," one of the key people said in a speech recently, which the center said is "unusual," and likely refers to Wang Dan or Wei Jingsheng.
But the center also said that President Lee has been recommended as an award candidate for the last two consecutive years, and selecting him for the award would also make Beijing unhappy.

DOC.HEADLINE: APEC RELEASES STUDY ON E-COMMERCE USE

TEXT.P: The Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) Telecommunications Working Group on Wednesday released results of a survey by PricewaterhouseCoopers on the adoption and use of electronic commerce by small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in APEC member economies.

PricewaterhouseCoopers polled SMEs, companies with 500 or fewer employees, in all 21 APEC economies and received responses from more than 1,300 businesses. Research also included more than 40 focus group meetings to identify real and perceived barriers to e-commerce use by SMEs.
Such enterprises are key to economic growth in APEC economies, accounting for nearly 50 percent of total GDPs and 35 percent of exports.

"This study provides us with strong indicators of how our governments might further facilitate the use of e-commerce. It also shows us that SMEs welcome the involvement of APEC governments in addressing perceived barriers and facilitating adoption through a wide range of measures," explained Peter Ferguson, APEC Telecommunications Working Group representative for e-commerce issues.
Nearly 70 percent of responding SMEs identified the need to raise confidence levels and establish national and international legal frameworks as important for fostering increased use of e-commerce.
More than 60 percent of respondents viewed limited access to information about suitable business models and technologies for e-commerce as a barrier to be overcome.
Also highlighted among the findings was a call for more government use of e-commerce in areas such as procurement and provision of services.
Most responding SMEs saw improved customer relations, improved supply chain integration and reduced input costs as real or potential benefits of their e-commerce initiatives. (by Sherman Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S MOST NOTORIOUS CRIMINAL EXECUTED

TEXT.P: Taiwan's most notorious criminal was executed Wednesday evening after being sentenced to death for his crimes that panicked the general populace, the Justice Ministry said.

Chen Chin-hsing, 40, was shot to death by a firing squad in Taipei prison, and his body was immediately rushed to Chang Gung Memorial Hospital in Linkou, northern Taiwan, where Chen's organs, including his heart, lung, kidneys and corneas, were removed by a team of surgeons for transplantation. His liver, because of a hepatitis-B infection, could not be used.
Chen had expressed his willing to donate his organs after his death as a "way of showing regret and compensating society."
Chen, along with two others, Kao Tien-min and Lin Chun-sheng, kidnapped, raped and killed the 17-year-old daughter of famous TV celebrity Pai Ping-ping in April 1997.

The trio then committed a string of kidnappings, murders and rapes while they were at large, resulting in the resignation of then Interior Minister Lin Feng-cheng and National Police Administration Director-General Yao Kao-chiao after public outcry mounted against the authorities' inability to apprehend the gang.
Lin and Kao were killed separately in shootouts with police.
Chen, after the death of his companions, broke into the house of a South African diplomat in November 1997, holding him and his family at gunpoint. Chen later surrendered to police.
Chen became a devout Christian during his detention in prison.

Chen's organs will be transplanted to six patients at Chang Gung Memorial Hospital, National Taiwan Hospital and Veterans General Hospital. But hospitals will not notify recipients of the source of their new organs to avoid "unnecessary troubles."
A patient awaiting a lung transplant at National Taiwan University Hospital risked life by refusing to accept a new lung after speculating that it could be from the nation's No. 1 "bad man."
His brother-in-law, Cheng Chih-hui, was sentenced to life in prison for his involvement in the Pai case. (by Bear Lee)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AGAIN JOLTED BY QUAKE

TEXT.P: An earthquake measuring magnitude 5 on the open-ended Richter scale rocked north-central Taiwan at 1:34 a.m. Thursday amid numerous aftershocks from the devastating earthquake that struck central Taiwan on Sept. 21, according to Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reports.

The tremor was detected about 19.9 kilometers southeast of the north-central city of Chupei with its epicenter located 24.65 degrees latitude north of the equator and 121.07 degrees east longitude, said CWB earthquake experts.
It originated 11 kilometers beneath the earth's surface, the seismologists said.
The temblor had an intensity of 4.0 in nearby Nanchuang Township in Miaoli County.

The seismologists were not sure that Thursday morning's tremor near Chupei was an isolated earthquake or one of the aftershocks from the deadly quake on Sept. 21 which killed at least 2,200 people and left more than 8,700 injured and some 100,000 others temporarily homeless.

As of Wednesday, two weeks after the devastating quake, more than 11,000 aftershocks had been detected, although most of those were imperceptible except to monitoring instruments. Of the total, 105 were temblors of magnitude 4.0 or greater, the earthquake experts said.

Meanwhile, seismological data collected by the CWB showed that the frequency of aftershocks from the deadly Sept. 21 earthquake has gradually subsided, with less than 10 per hour on Wednesday, compared to approximately 150 per hour in the first several days following the quake.

DOC.HEADLINE: US HOUSE RESOLUTIONS INTRODUCED TO HELP TAIWAN IN EMERGENCY

TEXT.P: US Rep. Chris Cox has introduced a joint House resolution stating that US agencies should not ask Beijing for approval before providing Taiwan with emergency assistance after natural disasters.

Cox has also introduced another resolution saying that the US President shall take all necessary steps to support Taiwan's membership in the International Committee of the Red Cross and the World Health Organization.

When the devastating Sept. 21 earthquake that struck Taiwan was discussed on the House floor on Sept. 28, the Republican Policy Committee chairman pointed out that "Sometimes it takes an enormous tragedy such as this earthquake to bring home how futile it is for us to maintain the political differences that we do have across the globe."

"I think everyone watching on television saw that the people of Taiwan are not the dangerous splitists so often derided by the Communist government in Beijing, but men and women and children fighting for a better life, just like all of us," said Congressman Cox.
He noted that "The American Red Cross felt it necessary to check first with Beijing, and that slowed down getting aid to people when they most needed it."

Speaking to remedy this situation, Rep. Cox concluded his remarks by stating that "I think we need legislation to make sure that every non-governmental organization in America, every charity in America understands that if there ever is another medical emergency or natural disaster in Taiwan, they can get their relief there right away without having to check with Beijing first."

The California Republican also introduced House Joint Resolution 70 on Tuesday stating that the US president shall take all necessary steps to ensure that US government agencies as well as US and international non-governmental organizations providing emergency humanitarian, disaster relief or medical assistance, be notified that when an emergency necessitates the provision of such assistance to Taiwan, they may provide it as quickly as possible without first seeking the approval of the Beijing government.

Since direct and unobstructed participation in international health cooperation forums and programs is crucial to help ensure good health and access to emergency assistance for every citizen of the world, the resolution also requires that the president shall take all necessary steps on behalf of the US government to support the membership of Taiwan in the International Committee of the Red Cross, the Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs, and the World Health Organization.
The resolution further requires that President Clinton shall submit a status report to Congress by Nov. 1 on the administration's efforts to accomplish these objectives.

DOC.HEADLINE: TORONTO ESCORTS MAY HAVE SPREAD HIV TO HUNDREDS OF MEN

TEXT.P: Hundreds of men in Toronto, including perhaps some National Hockey League (NHL) players, may have been exposed to HIV after using the services of an escort agency.

Three women who worked at Sweet Escorts, the Exotica and Sweet Sensations escort agencies between 1993 and 1998 are suspected of having providing sexual services while being HIV infected, according to crown documents filed Tuesday.
A list of customers the women may have infected is expected to come out during the trial of Mark Lukacko, who allegedly owns the agency.
That list is expected to include men from Toronto's more affluent neighborhoods as well as a number of NHL players.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA WAGES WAR AGAINST ILLEGAL IMMIGRANTS

TEXT.P: Australia, hit by increasingly sophisticated illegal immigrant smuggling operations, is boosting spending on new equipment, such acoustic sensors, imaging and radar satellites, surveillance airships and tethered balloons to counter this trend.
Coastwatch it is employing new technology and improved communications and better use of military and other information as key tools in policing the 37,000 km of Australian coastline.

Coastwatch director general Russ Shalders was seconded to lead the Coastwatch in July as part of a US$82 million, four-year revamp of the surveillance agency, prompted by record numbers of illegal arrivals into Australia.

He said Coastwatch aircraft have so far detected 45 illegal boat arrivals carrying more than 1200 illegal immigrants, including those from China and the Middle East. About 600 of those have arrived since June, alone, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA TAKING STEPS TO AVOID ILLEGAL IMMIGRANTS

TEXT.P: Australia, hit by increasingly sophisticated illegal immigrant smuggling operations, is boosting spending on new equipment, such as acoustic sensors, imaging and radar satellites, surveillance airships and tethered balloons to counter this trend.
Coastwatch is employing new technology and improved communications as key tools in policing the 37,000 km of Australian coastline.

Coastwatch director general Russ Shalders said Coastwatch aircraft have so far detected 45 illegal boat arrivals carrying more than 1200 illegal immigrants, including those from China and the Middle East. About 600 of those have arrived since June, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: POWER GAME BETWEEN US, JAPAN, CHINA EXAGGERATED: EXPERT

TEXT.P: The great power game among the United States, Japan and mainland China has been exaggerated, says a leading Australian expert.

In his article published by the Australian Financial Review on Thursday, Gary Klintworth, visiting fellow at the Australian National University's northeast program, said: "The so-called flash points in the (Asian) region have stopped flashing. In the South China Sea, China and the Philippines are considering joint naval patrols."
"In the Korean peninsula, a more nuanced U.S. diplomatic effort has reassured Pyongyang of the benefits of freezing its ballistic missile tests," he said.

Klintworth said the suggestion of an intensely competitive great power game between the US, Japan and China in northeast Asia is exaggerated. "More work has to be done on the Theater Missile Defense (TMD). But China and the US share vital strategic interests and continue to cooperate on the Korean peninsula and the easing of tension and misunderstanding in the Taiwan Strait," he said. (Peter Chen)

DOC.HEADLINE: UN TROOPS KILL 2 PRO-INDONESIA MILITIAMEN IN 1ST CLASH

TEXT.P: Two Australian-led UN peacekeeping (Interfet) troops were slightly injured while killing two pro-Indonesia militiamen during an ambush as they pushed into the former stronghold of the pro-integration base of Maliana in southwestern East Timor.

The Australian Broadcasting Corporation on Thursday afternoon quoted Major General Peter Cosgrove, commander of the Interfet, as warning the militiamen that the UN troops would deal with them with deadly weapons until they are disarmed.

He said two UN troops were slightly injured during their first encounter with the militiamen who ambushed the Interfet force during its push to Maliana, one of the strongholds of the pro-Jakarta militia groups. (by Peter Chen)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FOREIGN EXCHANGE RESERVES HIT NEW HIGH

TEXT.P: Taiwan's central bank on Thursday announced that Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves amounted to US$101.65 billion at the end of September, up US$17.45 billion from the level of a year ago.

The amount marked the highest level Taiwan has achieved since June, 1995. It put Taiwan in third place in the world, behind Japan and mainland China, according to a report released Thursday by the Central Bank of China (CBC).

This new high is due to the continuing flow of foreign funds into Taipei's stock market and the island's increasing foreign trade surpluses, said CBC Director-General Tsai A-ting of the Foreign Exchange Department.
At the end of August, Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves reached US$100.13 billion, breaking the US$100 billion-barrier for the first time this year, according to CBC.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE ENVOY PRESIDES OVER DONATION OF READY-MADE HOUSES

TEXT.P: The Japanese head liaison officer in Taiwan presided over a ceremony in Taipei on Thursday marking Japan's donation of 1,000 ready-made houses to earthquake victims made homeless by the destructive tremor.

Shintaro Yamashita, director-general of the Taipei Office of the Interchange Association, the de facto Japanese embassy in the Republic of China in the absence of formal diplomatic relations, officiated at the ceremony marking the donation worth around 250 million yen (approximately US$2.33 million), including transportation and other handling fees.

Lin Chin-ching, president of the Association of East Asian Relations (AEAR), received the donation on behalf of the people of Taiwan. AEAR is a quasi-official Taipei organization authorized to handle exchanges with Japan after Tokyo shifted its diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1972.
During the ceremony, Yamashita stated his admiration for those people who worked around the clock in the earthquake-stricken areas to rescue trapped victims and to rebuild homes.

Yamashita said that as soon as his office received an appeal by Lin for possible acquisition of the Japanese prefabricated housing units used to house victims of the 1995 Kobe quake, he notified the authorities in Tokyo.
The donation followed quickly upon Japanese government approval thanks to the rapid response by authorities in the Hyogo Prefecture near the port city of Kobe, Lin noted.
For his part, Lin expressed Taiwan's gratitude to the Japanese government and people for pitching in with timely and invaluable help in post-earthquake rescue, relief, and reconstruction efforts.
Lin said Taiwan's thanks should be directed particularly towards Japan's Diet members, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Hyogo Prefecture government for their assistance.
A Japanese search and rescue team was the first emergency group to arrive in Taiwan from abroad after the devastating magnitude 7.3 earthquake struck central Taiwan at 1:47 a.m. on Sept. 21.

More emergency teams from Japan, including medical groups, volunteers and teams of seismologists and structure specialists, have arrived in Taiwan in the following days to help facilitate relief and reconstruction work.

Also present at Thursday's ceremony were Tetsuro Yano, Upper House dietman in charge of defense and foreign relations, Sanzo Hosaka, vice minister of international trade and industry, Takao Koyama, vice minister of labor affairs, and Michio Hasekawa, chairman of the Upper House's Disaster Handling Committee.
The first batch of 47 ready-made houses left Kobe on Oct. 2 and is expected to arrive at the port of Taichung in central Taiwan on Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: MALAYSIA DONATES US$ 100,000 WORTH OF MEDICAL GOODS TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Malaysian government donated US$100,000 worth of medicine and medical goods to Taiwan on Thursday to help treat the Sept. 21 quake victims and to bolster disinfection efforts in affected areas.
The donation was presented to Taiwan by the top Malaysian representative in Taipei, Yusof Ahmad, during a ceremony held at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, upon arrival of the shipment.

During the ceremony, Ahmad, acting president and economic director of the Malaysian Friendship and Trade Center in Taipei, said the Malaysian government and people feel the same sorrow as that of the quake victims in Taiwan, which prompted them to make the donation out of humanitarian considerations.

Shih Ting, director of the Department of Asia-Pacific Affairs of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, on behalf of the Republic of China government and people, received the donation at the ceremony. Shih expressed Taiwan's gratitude to Malaysia, saying that the Malaysian deed of kindness further bolsters the close ties between the two countries.
The Sept. 21 earthquake, the deadliest to hit Taiwan this century, killed some 2,200 people and left more than 8,700 injured, 100,000 others homeless, and huge amounts of property damage.
Arriving at the CKS airport on Thursday was the first batch of 16 cartons of the Malaysian donation. The remainder is expected to arrive on separate flights in the days ahead.
