DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose 0.3 cents against the greenback on the Taipei market on Thursday, closing at 31.784.
The currency opened at 31.784, and was traded between 31.783 and 31.798. Interbank US dollar trading reached US$181 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIA TO TURN TO BEIJING FOR ARMS

TEXT.P: Indonesia's armed forces have expressed a desire to explore military ties with mainland China to help their country procure arms and spare parts, the latest issue of the Far Eastern Economic Review reported Thursday.

The report quoted a close aide of Indonesian President B.J. Habibie as saying that the proposal to approach mainland China came in the wake of cancellation of the Indonesian-Australian defense agreement.
"That was the result of Jakarta's anger over Australia leading the United Nations-sanctioned multinational force in East Timor," it said.
The aide also reportedly said that Indonesia is likely to seek closer cooperation with mainland China in a bid to counterbalance reliance on the West. (by Stanley Cheung)

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-PANAMANIAN TIES REMAIN FIRM: MOFA

TEXT.P: Relations between the Republic of China and Panama remain firm and solid, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Thursday.

The ministry made the statement in response to a Hong Kong-based business newsweekly report that Panama, an important ROC ally, may be close to establishing formal diplomatic relations with mainland China.

MOFA spokesman Henry Chen said ROC Ambassador to Panama Lan Chih-ming told Hu Cheng-yao, director of the ministry's Central and South American Affairs Department, via telephone early Thursday that there won't be any change in ROC-Panamanian relations.

"Lan told Hu that new Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso de Gruber and Foreign Minister Jose Miguel Aleman had assured him on many occasions that Panama will maintain its longstanding relations with the ROC and will even further strengthen bilateral ties in the future," Chen said.

Noting that Panama's trade and economic exchanges with mainland China will not affect or disrupt its relations with the ROC, Chen said he would not make any comment on a former Panamanian vice president's visit to Beijing in August. "We focus our attention to substantive relations between our two countries," he added.

Chen went on to say when Premier Vincent Siew headed an ROC delegation to attend Moscoso's inaugural ceremony on Sept. 1, the new Panamanian president repeatedly assured Siew that her administration will continue expanding cooperative ties with the ROC.

"Moscoso also told Siew that she hopes to visit the ROC in the near future," Chen said, adding that the MOFA is arranging exchanges of high-level visits between the two countries. New Panamanian ambassador is scheduled to arrive in Taipei late this month to assume his post.

The Far Eastern Economic Review (FEER) reports in its Oct. 14 issue, which hit newsstands on Thursday, that a high-level Panamanian delegation recently visited Beijing, a sign that a diplomatic shift could be in the works.
Commenting on the report, a MOFA official, who preferred anonymity, said the news was provided by Juan Pablo Pereira, Panama's chief representative in Hong Kong.

According to the MOFA official, Pablo is a pro-Beijing politician. Pablo was once placed on a list of candidates for the foreign minister post. However, senior Panamanian authorities dropped him from the list because of his left-leaning stance.
The MOFA official further said Cesar Pereira Burgos, who led a Panamanian delegation to visit Beijing from late September to early October, is Pablo's father.
In the FEER report, Pereira was referred to as president of Panama's Foreign Affairs Commission. In fact, the MOFA official said, Pereira is just one of the commission's 15 advisers.

The official said even though mainland China-Panamanian economic links are growing steadily, the Panamanian government has repeatedly denied reports that there may be changes in its relations with the ROC.

Moreover, the official said Panama's second vice president is scheduled to visit the ROC either in December this year or next spring and that President Moscoso is also likely to visit Taiwan next year.

Quoting Pablo, the Far Eastern Economic Review describes Pereira's weeklong visit to Beijing from late September to early October as "doing the diplomatic introduction of the new government" of President Moscoso.
The weekly also quotes Pereira as saying that Panama "will not close doors on the possibility" of establishing relations with mainland China as economic links between the two grow.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Oct. 7, or the 28th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1571: A "holy league" of naval forces from Spain, Venice and the Vatican explodes the myth of Turkish military invincibility by annihilating their fleet at the Battle of Lepanto in the eastern Mediterranean.
1849: Edgar Allan Poe, 40, US poet, writer and critic, dies in Baltimore after a heavy drinking bout. He was known especially for his macabre poems, such as "The Raven," and short stories, including "The Fall of the House of Usher."
1900: Heinrich Himmler, German head of the Gestapo, and from 1929, Adolf Hitler's second-in-command, is born.
1904: Isabella Bird Bishop, the first woman to be made a Fellow of the Royal Geographical Society of London, dies at the age of 73.
1913: Henry Ford, the leading manufacturer of US automobiles in the early 1900's, creates the world's first assembly line to build Model T cars.
1919: KLM, national airline of the Netherlands and the world's first airline, is established, and flights are scheduled for 1920.
1931: Desmond Tutu, South African archbishop of Cape Town, is born. He later became the general secretary of the South African Council of Churches and was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1984.
1937: The Council of the League of Nations adopts a resolution pledging moral support for China in the wake of Japanese aggression in that country.
1949: East Germany, or the German Democratic Republic, is proclaimed with Wilhelm Pieck as president and Otto Grotewohl as prime minister.
1950: Chinese communist troops enter Tibet.
1953: Microfilm, a kind of photographic film on which reduced images of printed and other materials are recorded, is first shown at an office machinery trade exhibition held in Paris.
1958: Chinese communists begin to launch a mass movement in Tientsin to make iron and steel, in which about 100 million people participated. The movement, which proved to be a waste of both human and material resources, resulted in a loss of 100 billion yuan in industrial production.
1959: Pictures of the far side of the moon are relayed back to Earth for the first time by Lunik III, the Soviet spacecraft.
1959: Mario Lanza, US tenor and film actor, dies at the age of 38. His films included "The Great Caruso."
1961: Two defecting Chinese communist pilots, Shao Hsi-yen and Kao Yu-tsung, arrive in Taipei from Seoul.
1965: The International Olympic Committee decides that starting from the 1968 Olympic Games to be held in Mexico City, East and West Germany may send separate teams to the international athletic competition.
1976: Wu Cho-liu, a noted writer in Taiwan, dies at the age of 77.
1976: US President Gerald Ford, already under fire for pardoning the disgraced Richard Nixon, tells the public on prime-time television that "There is no Soviet domination of eastern Europe and there never will be under a Ford administration."
1977: The Soviet Union adopts a new constitution, replacing the one introduced in 1936.
1982: Jimmy Wei, national policy advisor to President Chiang Ching-kuo and former president of the Central News Agency, dies of heart attack at the age of 77.
1985: The Achille Lauro, an Italian cruise liner, is seized by Palestinian terrorists, endangering the lives of more than 400 passengers on board. The passengers were freed on Oct. 9 when the hijackers surrendered.
1986: President Chiang Ching-kuo tells Katherine Graham, head of the board of the Washington Post and Newsweek, in an interview that the ROC government would soon propose lifting martial law to actively promote democracy, but new political parties should abide by the Constitution and anti-communist policy. He also emphasizes that the ROC would never negotiate with the Chinese communists.
1990: The National Unification Council is established under the Office of the President to help plan the policy framework for national unification, and to integrate various opinions about the issue at all levels of society.
1998: Thousands of Russians take to the streets to protest against unpaid wages and to call on President Boris Yeltsin to resign.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only the man with the most perfect divine moral nature who is able to combine in himself quickness of magnanimity, generosity, benignity and gentleness: qualities necessary for the exercise of patience."

DOC.HEADLINE: SEPTEMBER FOREIGN TRADE DECLINE DUE TO EARTHQUAKE IMPACT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economic and trade activities in September were significantly impacted by the massive Sept. 21 earthquake and subsequent large-scale power rationing, as shown by recessionary foreign trade performance for the month.

Taiwan exports grew 0.9 percent in September compared to the same period last year, while imports declined 0.1 percent. The figures contrast with double-digit growth of both exports and imports in July and August, according to statistics released on Thursday by the Ministry of Finance (MOF).
In September exports reached US$9.56 billion, while imports amounted to US$8.4 billion. As a result, the island enjoyed a US$1.16 billion foreign trade surplus, the statistics revealed.

MOF Statistics Department Director Hsu Kuo-chung said that although the killer earthquake severely damaged the island, the ministry predicted Taiwan would still enjoy a foreign trade surplus of some US$10 billion for the year.
Hsu said MOF experts will not be certain how the "921 earthquake" has affected Taiwan's 1999 export until mid-October, but they predicted export growth would reach a level between 6.5 and 7 percent.

The temblor's impact appeared no more serious than the previous MOF assessment, according to the daily export volume clearing customs, Hsu said. He noted that the September daily volume averaged US$476 million before the earthquake, and merely shrank to US$449 million after the quake.

Thanks to continued growth of the US economy and recovery of Asian economies, Taiwan exports registered 6.2 percent growth in the first nine months of the year, while imports posted a 1.4 percent rise, according to the MOF statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES, INDEX FUTURES UP

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices soared 1.5 percent Thursday due to bargain-hunting among financial shares.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index rose 110.37 points to close at 7,612.
A total of 2.12 billion shares changed hands on a turnover of NT$85.9 billion (US$2.7 billion).
After almost two weeks' downward trend, the relatively low-priced financial sector attracted bargain-hunting investors and pushed up the index by 23.8 points, ending the day with 2.5-percent gains.

Yet the rebound of financial shares was expected to be short-lived amid underlying concerns over mounting mortgage losses and claims faced by banks and insurance companies after last month's devastating earthquake.

Electronics shares also posted gains, reporting 2.2-percent advances, while cement issues, which had been bullish for several sessions, started to drop amid profit-taking. The sector reported 2.6-percent losses.
Advancers led decliners 261 to 205, with 62 shares unchanged.
The over-the-counter market rose 2.11 points to close at 169.28 on a turnover of NT$4.68 billion.

TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for October moved up 45 points to close at 7,580 with 1,790 contract transactions; those for November climbed 60 points to finish at 7,580 with 104 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for December advanced 86 points to close at 7,606 with four contract transactions; those for next March hiked 58 points to end at 7,683 with four contract transactions; those for next June rose 51 points to end at 7,581 with three contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Thursday were 7,535 points for October, 7,520 points for November, 7,520 points for December, 7,625 points for next March, and 7,530 points for next June.
Electronics futures and financial futures, which are sub-index futures and based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares (TE) and financial shares (TF), both reported gains.

October TE futures rose 4.15 points to close at 351.75 with 352 contract transactions; November TE futures climbed 5.8 points to end at 351 with 14 contract transactions; December TE futures advanced 8.9 points to close at 355 with one contract transaction.
There were no transaction records for next March TE futures or next June TE futures.

October TF futures rose 17.2 points to close at 967.8 with 122 contract transactions, November TF futures advanced 44.8 points to close at 983 with six contract transactions; TF futures for other months had no transaction records. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING CONFIRMS PURCHASE OF 20 SU-30MK JET FIGHTERS FROM RUSSIA
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Oct. 7 (CNA) (By Huang Kuei-mei & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Beijing has confirmed it purchased 20 Russian-made Su-30MK jet fighters, priced at US$2 billion, reported Japan's Sankei Shinbun on Thursday.
The newspaper noted that Beijing was originally reported to have purchased 40 Su-30MK fighters. The confirmed quantity was half that figure.
The advanced jet fighters were equipped with mid-range AA-12 air-to-air missiles.

DOC.HEADLINE: 8 WORKERS DIE IN CAR ACCIDENT IN NANTOU COUNTY
DOC.DATELINE: Nantou, Central Taiwan, Oct. 7 (CNA) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: A car carrying 13 workers plunged to the bottom of a 200-meter deep valley, killing eight and injuring five early Thursday morning in Nantou county, according to police.
The accident occurred after the driver reportedly swerved to avoid fallen rocks.

Police said the five injured workers, three of whom sustained critical injuries, were rushed to Nantou Christian Hospital. Those injured critically were later transferred to Changhwa Christian Hospital and the Taichung Veterans General Hospital in Taichung.
Police said the victims are tea harvesters and were on their way to pick tea-leaves in Jenai Hsiang when the accident occurred.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEMORIAL SERVICE TO BE HELD ON OCT. 11 FOR QUAKE VICTIMS

TEXT.P: A memorial service is scheduled to be held on Oct. 11 to mourn the victims of the killer earthquake that struck central Taiwan on Sept. 21, said officials of the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) on Thursday.

Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui will deliver a speech in commemoration of the dead during the service, which will be held in the gymnasium of the National College of Physical Education and Sports in Linkuo Township. At the ceremony, Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh will lay a wreath on behalf of all levels of Taiwan society.
All official celebrations of the anniversary of the nation's founding, which falls on Oct. 10, will be canceled as a result of the devastating temblor, the island's worst in a century.

Officials of the MOI, who are responsible for preparation work for the memorial service, said that the main purpose of the ceremony is to offer condolences to bereaved families and lead victims out from under the shadow of the quake, so that they will be confident in the reconstruction of their homes and the rehabilitation of their new lives.

According to the MOI plan, people from various religious groups as well as delegates from all walks of life, totaling about 10,000, will be invited to the memorial service to say prayers for the dead.
Heads of all five branches of the central government and all Cabinet members, together with members of Congress and municipal officials, led by President Lee Teng-hui, will mourn for the dead.

"If You Open the Inner Window of Your Heart," a soprano solo by Chien Wen-hsieu, is slated as a prelude to the memorial service, which will be followed by a moment of silence with all attendants standing.
The memorial service is expected to conclude in the midst of choir songs, said MOI officials.
A committee was formed to coordinate preparation work for the service. It is presided over by Vice President Lien Chan.
Meanwhile, there are no plans to erect a monument in memory of the 921 quake, MOI officials disclosed.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA REFUSES TO SHOULDER FARMERS CREDIT UNIONS' HUGE LOSSES

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) said Thursday that it can not shoulder all losses incurred by farmers credit unions, and definitely can not buy out quake victims' collateral or bear total costs for credit union reconstruction.
The COA rejected petitions by farmers credit unions at a conference, for which central Taiwan credit union officials had specifically come to Taipei in order to request government assistance.
The credit unions suggested measures which include:
-- joint finance of a fund totaling NT$60 billion to be used to revitalize farmers credit unions and to buy out collateral losses;
-- allocation of NT$67.5 billion for credit union office reconstructions and for making new loans;
-- awards of preferential loans for reconstruction of credit union offices, requested on the grounds that the financial institutions be given the same benefits as individual quake victims,
-- assumption of all credit union operational costs.

Credit union demands, exceeding NT$100 billion, were rejected by COA officials, saying the amount was beyond government reach and that the COA has already allocated NT$3 billion for farmers living in earthquake-affected areas.

According to a report by credit unions, 38 farmers credit unions located in Miaoli County, Taichung County and Nantou County were seriously damaged by the Sept. 21 earthquake, and reported NT$10.9 billion in collateral losses, while their total reconstruction costs reached NT$26.2 billion.

The report also revealed that loans worth NT$27 billion among the overall NT$135 billion in loans made by those credit unions were at risk of becoming dead loans after the quake, which damaged vast amounts of collateral, land and agricultural products.

A domino-effect financial crisis looms at the grassroots level and threatens to strike if the government fails to take measures to help the cash-strapped farmers credit unions and respond to their requests, warned credit union officials. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: SWEDEN DONATES RELIEF GOODS TO TAIWAN'S QUAKE VICTIMS

TEXT.P: Sweden on Thursday donated NT$50 million (about US$11.57 million) worth of relief goods to help earthquake-affected people in the Republic of China on Taiwan.
The 80 tons of relief materials, including 354 large tents, 1,485 sleeping bags and 10,000 blankets, were airlifted to Taiwan by the ROC's largest carrier China Airlines free of charges.
The Swedish government sent John Pehrson, a parliamentarian, and Claes Goran Karlsson, an official with Sweden's Rescue Services Agency, to Taiwan to present the relief goods on its behalf.
Shaw Yu-ming, a deputy secretary-general of the ROC's ruling Kuomintang, received the donation in a ceremony held at the party's headquarters in downtown Taipei.
Pehrson said he has come to Taiwan on behalf of the Swedish parliament and government to express concern and support for the people of Taiwan at the time of their grief.

Noting that Swedish and Taiwan people share common values and ideals of upholding freedom, democracy and human rights, Pehrson said he hopes the Sweden-donated goods can help those who have become homeless after a 7.3-magnitude earthquake rattled Taiwan on Sept. 21.
For his part, Shaw thanked the Swedish government for its generous donation on behalf of the ROC government and the ruling party.
Noting that Sweden spends 1 percent of its gross national product (GNP) on international humanitarian aid annually, Shaw said Taiwan should learn from Sweden in helping other developing countries.
The tents donated by Sweden can accommodate 20 people each and have lighting equipment. Residents can also cooking in those tents.
Shaw said the tents will be sent to hardest-stricken aboriginal villages in mountainous central Taiwan's Nantou and Taichung counties.

In the company of several officials from the Cabinet's Aboriginal Affairs Commission and the KMT's Youth Affairs Department, Pehrson and Karlsson visited Taichung County's Tungshih and Shihkang townships, two of the hardest-hit areas, in the afternoon.
The 921 earthquake was the worst natural disaster to hit Taiwan in a century, which has claimed more than 2,200 lives, injured over 8,500 others and left some 100,000 people homeless.

DOC.HEADLINE: US RESCUE TEAM PRAISES ROC GOVERNMENT'S PREPAREDNESS IN RELIEF WORK
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 6 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The leader of the US rescue team from Virginia that came to Taiwan to save victims of the Sept. 21 earthquake, on Wednesday praised the professional preparedness of Taiwan's government in quake rescue efforts.

Mike Tammillow, leader of Virginia Task Force One (VA-TF1) of the Fairfax County Urban Search and Rescue Team, delivered the compliment during a dinner party hosted by Stephen Chen, Republic of China representative to the United States, to honor the task force's good deeds in Taiwan.
Tammillow, who participated in two major rescue operations, in Turkey and Taiwan, during a one-month period, said that his team learned a lot on the Taiwan mission.

When the team's advance detachment arrived in Taipei soon after the destructive temblor struck in the early morning hours of Sept. 21, Tammillow said, they were met by Taiwanese officials who were prepared with detailed information about quake-stricken areas, including blueprints of buildings that had collapsed, burying numerous sleeping dwellers.

The VA-TF1 had never had such experiences when offering disaster assistance in foreign countries, Tammillow added, also noting that the US rescue team is willing to provide know-how to help Taiwan authorities form their own search and rescue teams.

Members of the rescue team who participated in the Taiwan relief mission are obliged to submit reports on the Asian operation within three months after returning home in order to review and document response to the disaster, according to Tammillow.

More than 90 members of the rescue team, which includes the Fairfax task force, disaster response experts from the US Agency for International Development (USAID), and search and rescue specialists from Miami and Dade County, attended the party. At the gathering, which was also attended by many team members' spouses, Chen presented each member a certificate of appreciation expressing the heartfelt gratitude of the government and people of Taiwan.

The team began rescue operations on Sept. 22 in Touliu, an urban area that is approximately 32 miles from the 7.3-magnitude earthquake epicenter, in Nantou County. On the following day, the team dug out a 32-year-old male survivor from amid the rubble of his former residence.

The US crew had also saved four lives in Turkey, after that country's devastating temblor, before going to Taiwan. The group is commissioned by USAID to provide international aid, and the government pays for training and equipment and handles costs associated with missions.

The "921 Earthquake," Taiwan's largest this century, claimed more than 2,200 lives islandwide and injured more than 8,700 people. Puli township in Nantou County, the epicenter of the massive temblor, was almost entirely destroyed, leaving tens of thousands of people homeless.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC WILL THANK FOREIGN RESCUE TEAMS ON CNN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs plans to express heartfelt thanks from the government and people of the Republic of China to members of 41 foreign rescue teams via the Cable News Network (CNN), a ministry official said on Thursday.

The teams had come to Taiwan to assist in rescue and relief operations in the wake of a devastating earthquake that jolted Taiwan on Sept. 21, claiming more than 2,200 lives and injuring more than 8,500 people.

The official said that President Lee Teng-hui instructed the ministry to express the ROC's gratitude to members of 41 foreign rescue teams, organized by 21 countries, regions and international organizations.
The Foreign Ministry plans to present each rescue team a plaque of gratitude, while each team member will receive a set of memorial coins, he said.
The ministry plans to air Taiwan's thanks in a 30-second broadcast on CNN in mid-October, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE MAINLAND SPOUSES TO BE ALLOWED TO SETTLE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Cabinet on Thursday approved a proposal to raise the annual quota for mainland Chinese spouses of Republic of China nationals to be allowed to settle in Taiwan to 3,600 people from current 1,800.

The proposal to double the annual quota for mainlanders to live here with their Taiwan husbands or wives was initiated by the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China.
MAC Chairman Su Chi said at the Cabinet's weekly meeting that the relaxation was made on humanitarian considerations.

"An estimate based on figures provided by civic groups and individual scholars shows that the number of marriages across the Taiwan Strait exceeds 50,000," Su said, adding that some 30,000 mainland spouses are still on the waiting list for permits to settle in Taiwan.
Su said the MAC has proposed the large increase in hopes that the quota will not be changed again in the next three years.
The new quota will take effect with the endorsement of the Legislative Yuan, the ROC's lawmaking assembly, which is expected to approve the proposal soon.
Su went on to say that the government will offer easier access for mainland spouses to the National Health Insurance coverage once they are allowed to settle on the island.
Meanwhile, Su said the government will also take measures to prevent mainlanders from working here under fake marriage arrangements.
The two sides of the Taiwan Strait were separated politically in 1949 at the end of a bitter civil war. The two rivals have since maintained no official-level contacts.
Civilian exchanges have expanded since Taipei permitted mainland-bound visits in late 1987. Bilateral trade has been booming and the number of cross-strait marriages has also been rising steadily.
Under current Taiwan regulations, mainland spouses can apply for settlement in Taiwan after two years of their marriages.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER SAYS ROC-PANAMANIAN TIES STABLE AT PRESENT

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Jason Hu said on Thursday that relations between the Republic of China and Panama are stable.
The Hong Kong-based Far Eastern Economic Review reported on Wednesday that Panama might switch diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing.
Hu said that rumors always exist, and this one indicates that Beijing is continuing its attempts to lure away countries that are friendly toward the ROC.

The magazine quoted Juan Pablo Pereira, Panamanian representative in Hong Kong, as reporting that Cesar Pereira Borgos, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee of Panama's Legislative Assembly, headed a delegation to Beijing with the aim of "diplomatic introduction of (Panamanian President) Moscoso's new government." Cesar Pereira is Juan Pablo Pereira's father.
The publication also quoted the elder Pereira as saying that Panama "will not close the door on the possibility" of establishing relations with mainland China as economic links between the two grow.
Answering questions raised by the press, Hu said that it is natural that conflicting information sometimes arises in democratic nations.

Hu said that the magazine article reveals Beijing's unchanged intention to destroy ties between the ROC and countries with which it has diplomatic relations. Hu stated that Beijing has especially strengthened its pressure on ROC allies in Central America, adding that Beijing's efforts will never cease.

After double checking, Hu deemed ROC-Panamanian ties to be stable at present, and said that rumors are only rumors. He urged the public to carefully consider the credibility of those who leaked the news.

In related news, the younger Pereira said on Thursday that the Panamanian government has deeply treasured its diplomatic relations with the Republic of China and hopes that relations will be further expanded in the future.

In an interview with a Central News Agency correspondent, he clearly declared that Panama and mainland China have not yet negotiated establishment of diplomatic relations. He did, however, admit that Panama-mainland China relations were steadily growing.

The younger Pereira did not rule out the possibility that Panama and mainland China would begin official negotiations to establish diplomatic relations in the future. At present, the contact between Panama and mainland China is leading in this direction, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE SALVATION ARMY TO AID TAIWAN QUAKE VICTIMS
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Oct. 7 (CNA) (By Sherman Wu & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Singapore's Salvation Army sent a four-member delegation to Taiwan on Thursday to speed the psychological recovery of victims of the earthquake that struck the island on Sept. 21.

The team of three Salvation Army members and one volunteer will join others from the Salvation Army now working in Nantou and Taichung before proceeding to remote areas to assist victims' psychological recovery.
The team was also carrying 30 sleeping bags and 200 tents, the last batch of relief materials donated by Singapore's Salvation Army.

Chen Tien-sheng, commander of the Salvation Army in Singapore, Malaysia and Myanmar, said that the Singaporean team will help those members of the Salvation Army who are working day and night to assist earthquake victims.

Chen said that though the quake-affected areas were under control, many victims need psychological assistance so as to overcome the difficulties resulting from the quake. The group will take over the work of Salvation Army members now in Taiwan.

Many victims could not handle the blow of losing their relatives overnight, but they should face the reality of the quake's aftermath, Chen said. Members of the Salvation Army will assist victims' psychological recovery in accordance with each individual's situation, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE PATIENTS RECEIVE ORGANS DONATED BY CONVICT

TEXT.P: The heart and kidneys donated by a death-row convict were received by three patients at two Taipei hospitals on Thursday.

The body of Chen Chin-hsing, a kidnapper-rapist who was executed Wednesday night, was sent to Linkou Chang Gung Memorial Hospital for organ removal shortly after the execution at a Taipei penitentiary.
Surgeons at the hospital completed kidney transplants on Thursday morning, with two patients receiving one kidney each.
The two patients have begun to discharge urine, indicating that the transplanted kidneys were functioning well, said the surgeons.
Chen's heart was received by a 28-year-old patient at Taipei Veterans General Hospital Thursday morning. The operation lasted 11 hours.
Surgeons said it will take five to six days to determine whether the surgery was successful.

A patient at National Taiwan University Hospital refused to receive the lungs to be donated by the convict; therefore, Chen's lungs were not removed. As for his corneas, they will be transplanted to suitable patients in one week.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUSTICE MINISTER COMMENTS ON CHEN'S EXECUTION

TEXT.P: Justice Minister Yeh Chin-feng said on Thursday that the execution of kidnapper-rapist Chen Chin-hsing was conducted in accordance with the normal operations of her ministry.
She said the Justice Ministry had no intention of deepening the public's scars from death at a time when the island was just shocked by the devastating Sept. 21 Chichi earthquake.
Chen, who had murdered four people and was involved in more than a dozen rape cases in 1977, was branded as Taiwan's most notorious criminal.
Saying that she had no feeling of happiness over Chen's execution on Wednesday night, Yeh expressed regret and sorrow for the protracted pain suffered by Chen's victims and their families.
She urged the public to review this case seriously and cautiously, and not to make snap judgments merely based on a few comments.
Regarding the plan by a pastor to publish a 500,000-word book by Chen, to be named "I Repent, Please Pardon Me," Yeh said the book should not cause additional pain for the victims and their families.
During his imprisonment, Chen converted to Christianity. However, many doubt that Chen had really repented.

Actress Pai Ping-ping, whose daughter was kidnapped and murdered by Chen, and a prosecutor said they wonder why Chen, if he had really repented, refused to reveal the mastermind of the kidnap case and the source of the guns he used to commit more crimes during his life as a fugitive.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON WARNING ISSUED FOR KINMEN, PENGHU

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau Thursday issued a typhoon warning for the islands of Kinman and Penghu (Pescadores).
The bureau said that mid-sized typhoon Dan was located 310 kilometers southwest of Hengchun, the southernmost tip of Taiwan, at 9 p.m., moving northward at a speed of eight kilometers per hour.
Weather forecasters cautioned residents, especially those of Penghu and eastern, southern, southeastern and mountainous areas of the island, to brace themselves for occasional heavy downpours.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT'S BOOK WINS AWARD IN JAPAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Oct. 7 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui's book "With the People Always in My Heart" has been named the recipient of the eighth Nanahei Yamamoto Award, it was learned on Thursday.
Lee will be presented a certificate and 3 million yen at the award ceremony to be held at a Kyoto hotel on Nov. 11.
The Japanese version of "With the People Always in My Heart" hit bookstores in June. So far, more than 140,000 copies have been sold.

DOC.HEADLINE: US OFFICIAL WARNS AGAINST CONFLICT IN TAIWAN STRAIT

TEXT.P: In the worst case, conflict across the Taiwan Strait "could affect the future of the entire region for years to come, with everyone a major loser," a senior US official said Wednesday.

Calling the situation "perhaps the single most dangerous issue in Asia" in the coming decades, the official said the US role is to promote stability by maintaining the current framework governing relations between Washington, Beijing and Taipei.

While Kenneth Lieberthal, senior director for Asian Affairs at the National Security Council, stood by the existing framework, scholars went further and called on both Beijing and Taipei to show more flexibility.

During a discussion on the future of US-PRC relations, David Lampton, director of China Studies at the Paul H. Nitze School of Advanced International Studies (SAIS), suggested that both sides "take the worst fear of the other off the table."
"I'd like to see them ... suspend the threats of either independence or force, and work on cooperation," he said.
The expert also said that the Beijing leadership has to come up with a formula that attracts the people of Taiwan.
"Deterrence can keep them from going independent but deterrence will never achieve unification for the Chinese people," he said.

For the United States, Lampton said, in addition to opposing the use of force by mainland China, Washington has to make it clear to Taiwan that it should not engage in "excessively provocative behavior."
Paul Wolfowitz, dean of the SAIS, agreed that mainland China should adopt a more positive approach and offer inducements to Taiwan rather than threats.

When asked whether Beijing would consider renouncing the use of force in exchange for a promise from Taiwan not to declare independence, the mainland China envoy to Washington did not give a direct answer.

Instead, Li Zhaoxing reiterated Beijing's position that the threat of military force is not aimed against the people of Taiwan and that there can be no compromise on the issue of sovereignty. (by Jay Chen)

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Oct. 8, or the 28th day of the eighth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1805: Outnumbered French troops defeat invading Austrians at Ulm.
1820: Henri Christophe, the Haitian leader who believed that despotism was the only form of government for his people, shoots himself and dies at the age of 53.
1836: John Hay, US statesman and diplomat, is born. As secretary of state from 1898 to 1905, he promoted the "open door" policy with China.
1858: The "Arrow Incident" occurs, in which a Hong Kong-registered ship, the Arrow, is searched in Kwantung by Ching soldiers, and 12 of its sailors are arrested. The incident led to an Anglo-French expedition against Peking and the burning of the imperial summer palace by invading troops.
1869: Franklin Pierce, 14th president of the United States, dies at the age of 65. He was unable to reconcile the issue of slavery that divided his country.
1895: Queen Min of Korea, who had tried to stem the tide of Japanese domination, is assassinated in her palace at Japanese instigation.
1895: Juan Peron, Argentinian general and president who was deposed in 1955 and returned to office in 1973, is born.
1897: Dow Jones & Co., Inc., a New York news agency, comes up with the novel idea of charting general trends in the trading of stocks and bonds on Wall Street. The agency computes a daily industrials average by using a list of 12 stocks and dividing their total price by 12.
1912: Montenegro declares war on Turkey, starting the first Balkan War.
1927: Cesar Milstein, British molecular biologist, is born. He shared a 1984 Nobel Prize for Medicine for his work on techniques to produce antibodies in order to immunize against specific diseases.
1928: Chiang Kai-shek is elected chairman of the National government of the Republic of China.
1941: Jesse Jackson, US politician and African-American civil rights campaigner, is born.
1952: A rail crash in Harrow, northwest London, involving three trains, kills 112 people and injures more than 200 others.
1954: Communist Vietnamese forces occupy Hanoi.
1960: Lei Chen, publisher of the "Free China" monthly magazine, is sentenced to 10 years in prison for involvement in an insurrection case.
1964: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Senegal.
1965: The Asian Christian Anti-Communist Conference is opened in Taipei.
1967: The first British speeding motorist is breathalyzed to test his alcohol consumption.
1967: The federation government of Yemen collapses following a military coup. The National Liberation Front (NLF) emerges as the most powerful group in the federation.
1967: Clement Attlee, British politician, dies at the age of 84. As Labour prime minister from 1945 to 1951, he established the National Health Service, expanded public ownership of industry, and granted independence to India and Burma.
1970: Russian novelist Alexander Solzhenitsyn is awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature.
1974: Eisaku Sato, Japanese politician who served as prime minister from 1964 to 1972, is awarded the 1974 Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts toward nuclear disarmament.
1981: A team of 10 divers recover 431 gold bars worth US$83 million from the wreckage of "Edinburgh," a British cruiser sunk by German destroyers and a U-boat in 1942 in the Barents Sea.
1984: Beijing announces plan to make primary school education compulsory by 1990 and to eradicate adult illiteracy by 1995.
1990: United Germany signs its first international treaty, agreeing with Czechoslovakia on a program for cleaning up the polluted River Elbe.
1992: A chartered plane carrying tourists from Taiwan, Europe and China crashes in northeast China, killing 13 people and injuring four others.
1995: Strong earthquake rocks Sumatra, Indonesia, killing more than 100.
1997: Tung Chee-hwa becomes the first Chinese leader to address Hong Kong's legislature, 100 days after Britain ceded the territory to communist China.
1997: Scientists report the Pathfinder probe's exploration of Mars has yielded evidence that the planet was once hospitable to life.
1997: Severest drought in half a century hits New Guinea, leaving more than 400 people dead from hunger.
1998: The US House of Representatives approves launching a formal impeachment inquiry against President Bill Clinton, only the third such investigation in US history.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Friday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Trust fund to be formed to protect rights of elderly people and children orphaned in the 921 earthquake.
The China Times:

DOC.HEADLINE: CENTURY QUAKE SHATTERS CENTRAL TAIWAN'S CADASTRAL MAP
DOC.DATELINE: Fengyuan, central Taiwan, Oct. 8 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Sept. 21 earthquake has not only given central Taiwan a geological facelift by flattening peaks and creating lakes, it has also shattered the cadastral map of the mountainous region, said Taiwan's top land administrator on Friday.

Chang Yuan-hsu, director of the Land Administration Department under the Ministry of the Interior, who returned to the hardest hit areas to inspect on Thursday, said the temblor and its powerful aftershocks have made a large-scale land resurvey in central Taiwan inevitable.

Land surveyors found that Tungshih and Hsinshe Townships of Taichung County have shifted several kilometers in a northwesterly direction while Tiehchanshan, located in Tachia Township, shifted south-southeast as a result of a collision between two sections in the earth's crust along a deadly fault line.
It is estimated that in Taichung County alone, some 340,000 pieces of land will have to be re surveyed to decide their cadaster in the wake of the deadliest quake to hit Taiwan this century.

Tseng Teh-fu, director general of the Interior Ministry's Land Survey Bureau, said he saw a rice paddy at the juncture of Fengyuan City and Shihkang Township that used to be level with the adjacent road become a terraced field after the jolt shook the land.

Tseng said a pear orchard on a 1,000-ping (6,000 square feet) tract of land in Tungshih became a hill after the land shifts caused by the quake, reducing the tract to a 60-ping stand -- a geostratic sabotage he has never seen in his 30 year career.

Taichung County has become smaller cadastrally after the deadly quake while neighboring Nantou County has become larger, said Tseng. Taichung and Nantou counties were the hardest hit areas in the Sept. 21 quake.

DOC.HEADLINE: ETHNIC CHINESE BECOMES GOVERNOR GENERAL IN CANADA

TEXT.P: Adrienne Clarkson, the first ethnic Chinese and second woman to become Canada's governor general, Thursday sought Canadians' help in her effort to build a "color-blind" Canada.
In her installation speech, Clarkson stressed the idea of inclusiveness and her idea to make Canada a "color-blind" society.

"The essence of inclusiveness is that we are part of a society in which language, color, education, sex and money need not, should not divide us, but can make us more aware and sensitive to difference," she said.
Prime Minister Jean Chretien praised the new governor general as "a person of singular talent, discernment and achievement, who today becomes the representative of our Head of State in Canada."

"She and her family were initially turned away when they sought refuge in Canada because they were Chinese. Her presence here today tells us how far we have come as a nation. A nation built by immigrants. By those who sought our national dream and our safe haven," Chretien said.

He stressed that her becoming governor general is a telling sign of the way times have changed in Canada, sending a powerful message that Canadians are resolved to share their experiences and keep a strong and distinctive Canadian presence in the global village.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONGRESSMAN CALLS FOR US WITHDRAWAL FROM UN

TEXT.P: US Congressman Ron E. Paul introduced a resolution to end US membership in the United Nations on Thursday after UN threats to deprive the United States of its voting right in the UN General Assembly.

UN Undersecretary for Management Joseph Connor has warned the United States that its voting right at the UN General Assembly would be revoked if Washington refused to repay its debts totaling $1.2 billion to the international organization as soon as possible.

To counter this threat, Rep. Paul introduced a House Resolution, titled the "American Sovereignty Restoration Act of 1999, which calls on the US government to repeal The United Nations Participation Act of 1945. It adds that the president shall terminate all participation by the United States in the United Nations and any of its affiliated agencies.

The resolution also calls for the US to withdraw from its agreement with the United Nations regarding the UN Headquarters in New York, ban the appropriation of any funds or voluntary contributions to the United Nations or its affiliated agencies, terminate U.S. participation in UN peacekeeping operations and its contribution to any UN military operation, prohibit the United Nations from occupying or using any U.S. government property or facility, and revoke the diplomatic privileges and immunities enjoyed by UN personnel and members of any mission to the United Nations of any foreign government.

In addition, the proposed bill requires the United States to withdraw from the UN Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization and the World Health Organization, as well as repeal the UN Environmental Participation Act and all conventions and/or agreements with the United Nations and its affiliated agencies.

The resolution states that effective on the date of its enactment, the Secretary of State shall notify the United Nations and its affiliated agencies of the provisions of this act. Unless otherwise provided, it says this act and its amendments shall take effect two years after the date of its enactment.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CONSIDERS ITS OWN ANTI-MISSILE DEFENSE: REPORT

TEXT.P: Tang Fei, Taiwan's defense minister, said the island is determined to proceed with a plan to develop its own anti-missile defense even with no outside aid in the face of Beijing's growing missile threat.

In an interview with the Financial Times, Tang said, "The Chinese communists on the mainland have M-9 and M-11 missiles at seven different bases pointed at us." "We now feel we have no choice but to undertake an anti-missile defense program."

Tang also stressed that the new strategy did not mean Taipei had decided to push for participation in a proposed US-led Theater Missile Defense system (TMD), a system fiercely opposed by Beijing, the Financial Times said. (by Mark Ou)

DOC.HEADLINE: PRO-INDONESIA MILITIAS ATTACK UN TROOPS IN E. TIMOR

TEXT.P: Pro-Indonesia militiamen have been using Chinese-made semi-automatic assault rifles in their ambushes on the Australian-led UN peacekeeping troops, who have so far retaken about 70 percent of East Timor in their effort to secure the whole territory.

In a dispatch from Dili, The Australian on Friday reported the militia ambushed the UN convoy escorting suspected members of the militia to within 5 km of the West Timor border. The UN troops are not ruling out a possible escalation in gun battles with militiamen as they thrust deeper into strongholds of the pro-integration groups.
The militiamen have been using semi-automatic assault rifles, including Chinese-made SKS and Indonesian FN rifles.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S UNEMPLOYMENT RATE UP TO 7.4 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Australia's unemployment rate jumped to 7.4 percent in September from 7.2 percent in August, despite government and private sector forecasts of a lower jobless rate due to a strong performance in the country's economy, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics.

The ABS figures show the economy created 12,600 new jobs in September, lower than earlier expected. Government officials and private economists had earlier predicted the unemployment would fall to 6 percent by the year 2000 and as low as 5 percent by 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: PANAMANIAN FOREIGN MINISTER DENIES REPORT ON TIES WITH BEIJING

TEXT.P: Panamanian Foreign Minister Jose Miguel Aleman has denied a report that Panama is considering establishing diplomatic relations with mainland China, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said on Friday.

Hu Cheng-yao, director of the MOFA's Central and American Affairs Department, said Aleman clarified and denied the report during a meeting with Republic of China Ambassador to Panama Lan Chih-ming on Thursday.
The Hong Kong-based Far Eastern Economic Review reported on Wednesday that Panama might switch diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing.

The weekly business magazine quoted Juan Pablo Pereira, Panamanian representative in Hong Kong, as reporting that Cesar Pereira Borgos, president of the Foreign Affairs Commission of the Panamanian parliament, headed a delegation to Beijing with an aim of "diplomatic introduction" of Panamanian President Moscoso's new government. Cesar Pereira is Juan Pablo Pereira's father.
The weekly also quoted the elder Pereira as saying that Panama "will not close the door on the possibility" of establishing relations with mainland China as economic links between the two grow.

"During his meeting with our ambassador, Aleman said Cesar Pereira is just an adviser to the Foreign Affairs Commission," said Hu, adding: "Aleman also stressed that Cesar Pereira's visit to Beijing from late September to early October was of a private nature and didn't carry any diplomatic significance."

Hu said Aleman also expressed his regret to Ambassador Lan over improper remarks made by the Panamanian Hong Kong representative, adding that Aleman has asked Pablo Pereira to refrain from making public speeches on issues other than the economy or trade-related topics.
According to Hu, Aleman also asked Lan to convey to the ROC government and people that relations between the two countries remain stable and friendly.
Just a few days ago, Hu said, Aleman told Lan that Panama will maintain formal diplomatic ties with the Republic of China while forging closer commercial and trade links with mainland China.
Panama remains one of the ROC's important diplomatic allies as mainland China continues its efforts to further isolate the ROC diplomatically in the international community.

DOC.HEADLINE: FREIGHTER CREW RESCUED AMID STORM
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, Oct. 9 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: All 15 crew members of the Panamanian freighter Fukuo Shin, which suffered mechanical failure amid stormy weather, were safely rescued by Taiwan military personnel just before noon on Friday, according to Kaohsiung Harbor authorities.

The ship carried a Japanese captain and 14 Philippine crew members, who broadcast an S.O.S. for urgent help around 7:30 Friday morning after the vessel's engines failed. The crew then anchored the ship about half a nautical mile offshore from Kaohsiung's Chiching Port.
Kaohsiung Harbor authorities immediately requested assistance from the air rescue division of the Kaohsiung police department and from the Seagull Emergency Operation Squadron of the armed forces.

Braving strong winds and torrential rain brought on by Typhoon Dan, the Seagulls managed to save two crew members on their first try. The rescue attempt was suspended for about two hours due to dangerous weather conditions, according to the harbor authorities.
The Seagulls resumed the rescue mission around 11:00 a.m., and with several difficult flights in the storm, they transported all stranded crew members to safety at Kaohsiung Harbor.
The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) on Friday set up an emergency task force as Typhoon Dan threatened the entire island with downpours and strong winds.

According to weather forecasters, as of 3:00 p.m. Friday, Dan was centered 220 kilometers southwest of Penghu Island in the Taiwan Strait, with a radius of 200 kilometers and packing winds of 33 meters per second. Dan was moving northward at a speed of 12 kilometers per hour.
The whole island is expected to come under Dan's outer perimeter as it was continuing to move in a northerly direction, weather forecasters said.

People on the offshore Penghu and Kinmen islands in particular should brace themselves for strong winds, while those in eastern, central and southern parts of Taiwan should be prepared for torrential rains, they warned.
Residents of central Taiwan areas that are now fragile and volatile in the wake of the devastating Sept. 21 earthquake should be on full alert for landslides and mudslides triggered by floods.
In low-lying coastal areas of the southern counties of Chiayi and Tainan, residents should prepare for possible inundation by sea water, the weather forecasters said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose 0.6 cents against the greenback on the Taipei market on Friday, closing at 31.778.
The currency opened at 31.780, and was traded between 31.771 and 31.782. Interbank US dollar trading reached US$271 million. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL AFFAIRS HAVE IMPLICATIONS FOR TAIWAN: AUSSIE SCHOLARS

TEXT.P: Australian scholars suggested that international incidents and military alliances, such as the Kosovo crisis and a US-initiated Theater Missile Defense (TMD) system, could have implications for Taiwan.

Three scholars presented papers on Australia's strategic and defense policy, its perspective on TMD, and implications of the Kosovo crisis for Taiwan, at the "International Conference on Australia and East Asian Security into the 21st Century" held at the National Chengchi University on Friday.

Scholars from Australia, the Republic of China, the United States and South Korea were invited to present papers at the one-day conference which was cosponsored by the ROC's National Chengchi University, the Australian Commerce and Industry Office in Taipei, and the Taiwan Research Institute.

Pointing out that Australia is concerned about the prospect of a "missile and counter-missile" arms race in Northeast Asia, Dr. Gary Klintworth of the Australian National University said that "we do not want a contest in which there can only be losers and a likely risk of a nuclear standoff between China and the US."

The Australian scholars said that TMD at mainland China's doorstep is seen as a challenge by Beijing. "China already has a basic anti-missile system of its own, and therefore by implication it recognizes the benefits of ... missile defense," he added.

Emphasizing that "both China and Taiwan are important members of the APEC community and they rank among our top export markets," Dr. Klintworth said that "we see Taiwan's continued independence from mainland Chinese control -- within a one-China framework -- as being in the best interests of China, Taiwan and the region."

To do away with the prevailing spirit of distrust and avoid missile and counter-missile proliferation in Northeast Asia, the scholar suggested that huge diplomatic efforts are required to establish constructive dialogues.

Dr. Greg Austin, research fellow at the Australian National University, in his paper pointed out that the NATO war against Serbia earlier this year and the subsequent occupation of Kosovo by NATO forces created new optimism and new fears around the world. "Political leaders in China, Russia and the Third World talked of a threat to world order and international law posed by the West's new doctrine."

A series of symposia discussing the Kosovo crisis as "a new threat to strategic stability" was held over the past few months. "Kosovo has created a new Zeitgeist (spirit of the times) throughout major capitals of the world," said Austin.

While the NATO war against Serbia represented, according to Chinese perceptions, the first military manifestation of the Clinton doctrine of expansion of democracy, the Australian scholar warned of the implication of the Kosovo Zeitgeist for Taiwan.

He said that most of mainland China's leaders suspected that they might need to go to war to oppose military interference, such as the NATO action against Serbia. He feared that "sentiment in the leadership has been moved -- above all by the Kosovo Zeitgeist -- closer to the desire to teach Taiwan a lesson."
Calling on both Taipei and Beijing to work beyond rhetoric, Austin opined that "if Taiwan pushes China further, appeal to the USA will not save it from severe punishment."

He added that "Once the punishment action occurred, the spirit of deterioration in China-US relations would end, and bottom out at sustained military confrontation of a Cold War type with the Taiwan Strait as the dividing line similar to the inner German border during the US-Soviet stand-off."
Dr. Desmond Ball of the Strategic and Defense Studies Center of the Australian National University gave a briefing on the evolving security architecture of the Asia-Pacific region.

Speaking on principal features of the emerging regional security environment, the scholar pointed out that "China has emerged as the country of most concern in the region." He further stated that "It is essential that China be engaged in multilateral dialogues, confidence-building arrangements, preventive diplomacy, and other forms of security cooperation in the region."

DOC.HEADLINE: ELECTRONIC COMPONENTS & EQUIPMENT EXHIBITION OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Representatives from some 970 foreign and domestic businesses in the electronics sector on Friday attended the opening of a five-day international electronic components and equipment exhibition at the Taipei World Trade Center.
More than 1,800 booths were set up by the business companies to display products, which include high-tech electronic components and a range of precision electronic equipment.
Taiwan's semi-official China External Trade Development Council and the Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers Association (TEEMA) jointly sponsored the fair that will run through Tuesday.

TEEMA Chairman Wu Si-chung indicated that the fair is part of the Taipei International Electronics Show of 1999, which also includes an exhibition of finished electronic products, scheduled for Oct. 16-20.
The sponsors decided to divide the show into two separate exhibitions because there is not enough display space at the Taipei trade center to accommodate all relevant businesses at one time, Wu said.
The lack of display venues is a challenge for Taiwan's electronic sector, which requires more channels to promote and demonstrate their products, Wu noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO BECOME WORLD'S NO. 1 NOTEBOOK COMPUTER MAKER

TEXT.P: Taiwan will become the world's No. 1 notebook computer maker in the year 2000.
According to statistics compiled by IDC Co., Taiwan will produce 9.5 million units of notebook computers in 1999, representing 49 percent of total world production.
Taiwan will become the top producer next year, cranking out 13 million units to account for 58 percent of global notebook computer production.
IDC President Rindy Giusto said that world production of notebook computers was estimated to have a 23.8 percent growth rate in 1999. The growth rate for the year 2000 was projected at 15.7 percent.
IDC said that global production of PCs will break the 100 million mark at the end of this year, representing a 23.5 percent increase compared with the previous year.
Worldwide production will reach 130 million units next year, an increase of 16.5 percent from that of 1999.
IDC also predicted that PC production will grow 24.8 percent in the third quarter of the year and 20.6 percent in the fourth quarter.
Global 1998 sales in the information technology (IT) market totaled US$765.6 billion, of which Asia's share accounted for US$128.4 billion, a decrease of 7.1 percent in comparison with that of 1997.
However, Asia's share was projected to grow 11.7 percent in 1999.

In the global IT market , Taiwan is predicted to advance from No. 21 in 1998 to the No. 16 position in 2002, far ahead of South Korea and New Zealand. The United States is currently ranked No. 1 worldwide.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES, INDEX FUTURES DOWN

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices dropped 0.8 percent Friday on thin trading as investors anticipated more stock market losses after the lower-limit on fluctuations is lifted next week.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index shed 59.02 points to close at 7,552.98.
A total of 1.86 billion shares changed hands on a turnover of NT$65.85 billion (US$2.07 billion).
Investors were reluctant to buy shares due to an absence of new leads, which led to shrinking turnover.
The financial sector posted the largest losses of 1.9 percent, a result of anxiety stemming from banks' mortgage losses following last month's earthquake.
Dealers said the government's policy on mortgage loans keeps changing, producing great uncertainty in the market.
The plastics and chemical sector posted minor gains, the only upward movement among the eight major stock categories, ending the day with 0.4-percent gains.
Decliners outnumbered advancers 304 to 142, with 83 shares unchanged.
The over-the-counter market rose 0.32 points to close at 169.6 on a turnover of NT$5.18 billion.

TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for October fell 60 points to close at 7,520 with 1,178 contract transactions; those for November shed 60 points to finish at 7,520 with 98 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for December dropped 37 points to close at 7,575 with four contract transactions; while those for next March and those for next June had no transaction records.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Friday were 7,580 points for October, 7,580 points for November, 7,612 points for December, 7,646 points for next March, and 7,646 points for next June.
Electronics futures and financial futures, which are sub-index futures and based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares (TE) and financial shares (TF), both registered losses.
October TE futures shed 2.95 points to close at 348.8 with 204 contract transactions; November TE futures declined 2.75 points to end at 349 with eight contract transactions.
There were no transaction records for December TE futures, next March futures or next June TE futures.

October TF futures shed 15.8 points to close at 952 with 77 contract transactions, November TF futures fell 31 points to close at 952 with six contract transactions; while TF futures for other months had no transaction records. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN POLICE CRACK DOWN ON TRANSNATIONAL ILLICIT GAMBLING

TEXT.P: Police from Taiwan's Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) and a local law-enforcement task force on Friday raided the headquarters of a gambling ring that allegedly organized illegal betting on baseball games and lotteries in both Taiwan and the United States.

The police arrested the alleged leader of the ring, Shi Jung-chung, 31, at the Kaohsiung-based headquarters in southern Taiwan, while another squad nabbed Wu Jung-tih, 41, at the ring's branch in Pingtung County on a charge of running an illicit gambling operation.

At the raided headquarters, the police also seized six computers, 24 fax machines, 24 video cassette recorders, five telephone units, 20 calculators, two needle cameras, five monitors, a number of gambling tickets, and several account books, all of which are regarded as evidence supporting alleged illicit gambling, according to the police.

After checking the account books, the CIB found that the ring had accepted more than NT$10 billion (US$314.47 million) a year from gamblers in Taiwan and the United States since the ring was established in December 1996, the police said.

The gambling activities were allegedly conducted through the Internet, the world's largest communications network, with gamblers betting on professional baseball games in Taiwan and the Unites States or buying lottery tickets using home computers, the police added.
The ring erected over 30 branch sites around the island, which together averaged over NT$174.63 million (US$5.49 million) in illicit gambling transactions per day, the police noted.
Acting on tips, the CIB launched the mission to crack down on the transnational illicit gambling, resulting in the largest raid of its kind on the island. Police are investigating the case further.

DOC.HEADLINE: GAS PRICE TO BE REVIEWED BY END OF OCTOBER: CPC

TEXT.P: Officials of the state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) said that the issue of whether to raise the domestic gasoline price will be reviewed and discussed by the end of October.

The CPC was referring to the dilemma it faced owing to the fact that it has not met the government's projected profit target since July, and is thus under increasing pressure to raise the price. On the other hand, with an eye to stabilizing consumer prices in the wake of the killer earthquake, it would be painful to raise the gas price.
The CPC made public Friday its pre-tax profit in September, which was NT$1.49 billion short of the projected profit target.

The business turned over NT$33.25 billion in September, with a pre-tax profit of NT$332 million, according to figures released by the CPC. Since the projected profit set by the government budget for the CPC is NT$1.82 billion, the shortfall totals NT$14.9 billion.

As the international gas price has surged in recent months, the CPC, not reflecting the cost in its current gas price, did not meet its profit goal for three months in a row: shortages of NT$178 million in July, NT$112.4 million in August, and NT$148.9 million in September resulted in heavy pressure for the CPC to adjust its price upward.

The CPC originally planned to raise the gas price in October. However, since stabilizing consumer prices was set as one of the top priorities of the government, the CPC thus decided not to raise the gas price in October.

What matters most for the CPC in weighing the price issue, said head of the CPC, is not its petroleum import cost, but rather the island's social situation after the temblor, and stable consumer prices.

The CPC is to review and discuss the current gas price by the end of October, said the CPC official, adding that a decision will be made after issues concerning domestic consumer prices, quake rehabilitation and social conditions have all been taken into consideration.
Were it an issue of sheer reflection of purchase cost, the CPC would have adjusted the gas price upward much earlier, stressed the official.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA DOESN'T COMMENT ON PAPUA NEW GUINEA'S DIPLOMATIC RELATIONS

TEXT.P: Australia's representative to Taipei Sam Gerovich said Friday at an academic conference that Australia's concerns over Papua New Guinea related only to the issue of economic governance in that country, not to the possible establishment of diplomatic relations with Taiwan.

Gerovich of the Australian Commerce and Industry Office in Taipei, told attendants at the "International Conference on Australia and East Asian Security" that "the Australian government did not make any comment about choices on diplomatic recognition between Beijing and Taipei by Papua New Guinea, nor does it do so with any other country."

He said that Australia was only concerned that Papua New Guinea might have been seeking funds from Taiwan as an alternative to committing itself to necessary economic disciplinary measures under an IMF/World Bank program.

Stressing that successive Australian governments have for nearly three decades maintained a "one China" policy, Gerovich said that "it has been Australia's consistent view that the relationship between the two sides of the Taiwan Straits is for the PRC and Taiwan to resolve."

He elaborated that during Chinese Communist President Jiang Zemin's recent visit to Australia, Australian Prime Minister John Howard had made it clear in public and in private that Australia believed the current tensions should be resolved peacefully, without any resort to military force.
The trade representative said that "Taiwan remains an important partner for Australia, and the Australian government is committed to promoting the development of bilateral relations."
"Prime Minister Howard reaffirmed this in his speech at Parliament House during President Jiang's visit," Gerovich added.

Since 1992, the Republic of China and Australia have signed seven important bilateral agreements. Last year, two-way trade between the ROC and Australia totaled US$4.5 billion, making the ROC Australia's seventh largest export market and its ninth largest supplier of imports, according to Timothy Yang, secretary-general of the ROC's Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

Invited to address the conference's opening ceremony Friday morning, Yang said that "our external relations and foreign policy are very much geared to cooperation with all countries and we have every interest in working together for peace, security and economic prosperity for all nations."

DOC.HEADLINE: 83% OF FIRMS IN QUAKE-STRICKEN AREAS RESUME PRODUCTION: POLL

TEXT.P: The majority of manufacturing companies in earthquake-stricken central Taiwan have resumed normal operations, according to the results of two surveys released on Friday.

The surveys of manufacturing firms in hardest-stricken areas, including Nantou, Taichung and Yunlin counties as well as Taichung City, were conducted by the China Productivity Center at the request of the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).

The first poll was conducted on Sept. 23, two days after the 921 earthquake that ripped through mountainous central Taiwan's Nantou County and claimed more than 2,200 lives islandwide. A total of 109 companies were surveyed and 92 of them responded to the questionnaire.

By industry, the electric appliances industry was worst affected, with 33.3 percent saying their production facilities were damaged; followed by the machinery manufacturing industry, with 16.7 percent of companies in the line damaged; and the metal processing industry, with 13.3 percent affected.
By areas, 70 percent of damaged manufacturing firms were located in Taichung City and Taichung County.
The second survey was conducted from Sept. 24 to Oct. 4, with 170 of the 201 firms questioned responding to the poll, which focused on exploring their financial losses.
Survey results showed that 42.4 percent of the companies interviewed said they had suffered financial losses in the devastating quake.

Among them, 23.5 percent said their financial losses were estimated at below NT$1 million (US$31,447); 4.7 percent said they lost NT$5 million to NT$10 million in the killer quake; 3.5 percent estimated their losses at NT$10 million to NT$30 million; and 3.4 percent said their financial losses ranged between NT$1 million to NT$3 million.

Among those whose production facilities were damaged, 23.9 percent said the damage was mainly done to their plants; 23.4 percent said their production machines were damaged; 21.4 percent said their production line was affected; 21.4 percent said they saw their orders and the number of clients decline; 19.4 percent said they had difficulties obtaining parts supplies after the quake; 20.9 percent said they have been troubled by raw materials supply problems since the quake; and 20 percent said they have suffered all kinds of the above-mentioned damage and problems.

Asked about their post-earthquake situation, 83.5 percent said they have resumed normal operations; 5.9 percent said they need one more week to resume normal production; 4.1 percent said they expect to resume normal operations in two weeks; and another 4.1 percent said they can resume normal production in one month.
The figures show that 97.6 percent of the firms can resume normal operations in a month, while only 2.4 percent said they need more than three months to resume full production.

Analyzing survey results, Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu said most companies in the disaster zones hope that the government will offer low-interest loans and tax deductions or exemptions to facilitate their recovery from the damage.
Lin said the MOEA has asked the Finance Ministry to offer NT$50 billion in low-interest loans for companies to repair their damaged production facilities.
Lin further said the ministry will ask the Finance Ministry to consider quake-affected firms' requests for tax exemptions and deductions.

DOC.HEADLINE: GUATEMALAN CONGRESS PASSES RESOLUTION TO BACK ROC UN BID
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Panama, Oct. 7 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: The Guatemalan Legislative Assembly recently passed a resolution to support the Republic of China's bid for membership in the United Nations and other international organizations, including the World Health Organization (WHO).

The resolution, which was passed by the Legislative Assembly last month, also called on Guatemalan administrative departments to back the ROC's bid for membership in the international organizations. The resolution will be presented to the Central American Parliament and Panama for their support.

The resolution said that the ROC was the first republic in Asia and one of the founding members of the United Nations. The ROC was also one of the first countries to sign the charter of the United Nations. The United Nations, however, passed Resolution No. 2758 at its 26th General Assembly to expel the Republic of China.

The Guatemalan resolution went on to say that Resolution No. 2758 had not completely resolved the China problem. It also said the UN resolution deprived the more than 2.2 million people of Taiwan of their rights to education and environmental and cultural protection under the United Nations system.

Meanwhile, the international situation has changed greatly since Resolution No. 2758 was passed 29 years ago. Therefore, the resolution should be amended, the Guatemalan Legislative Assembly's resolution said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE PROMISES TO HELP PRIVATE RESCUE TEAM IMPROVE EQUIPMENT

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Friday promised to help Taiwan's largest private disaster relief team obtain more funds for improving personnel training and purchasing advanced equipment.

Braving drizzling rains, Lee toured the Republic of China Search and Rescue Corps' training center in Sanhsia, Taipei County to express his gratitude for the group's assistance in relief operations in the wake of the Sept. 21 earthquake, Taiwan's worst natural disaster in a century.

Over the past 17 days, Lee said, he has spent 13 days in the quake-stricken areas. "During those inspection tours, I have often seen members of the corps striving hard to rescue trapped survivors from the wreckage of crumbled buildings," Lee said.
Lee said he admires all team members' bravery and devotion. "I also appreciates your assistance in post-earthquake relief operations," the president added.

The non-profit rescue team was founded 18 years ago. Its members come from different walks of life, including teachers, drivers, construction workers and white-collar salaried people. All of them are volunteers.
The corps mobilizes more than 2,000 members to join search and rescue operations in the wake of the deadly 921 earthquake.

Lu Cheng-chung, head of the corps, told President Lee that the group has been troubled by a lack of funds for sending members abroad to receive advanced search and rescue training and improving its own facilities and equipment.
In response, Lee said he will ask relevant government authorities to help the team resolve its financial problems.

DOC.HEADLINE: QUALITY OF LIFE IN KINMEN IMPROVED AFTER OPENING TO TOURISM

TEXT.P: The quality of life on the outpost island of Kinmen has improved substantially over the past decade since it opened for tourism, the Kinmen County government reported on Friday.
The government made the report based on its analysis of various indexes, showing that opening to tourism has helped the prosperity of the island opposite mainland China's coastal city of Xiamen.
The report said that Kinmen's population increased to 51,060 in 1998 from 43,294 in 1989, reversing the downward trend of the past.

Kinmen County's share of the gross national product grew to NT$13.32 billion in 1998 from NT$4.86 billion in 1989, up 174.14 percent, and averaged NT$260,000 per capita, an increase of 135.34 percent over the past decade.
The literary rate among people over six years of age was 87.23 percent in 1998, up 4.64 percent from 1989.
In terms of transportation, car ownership numbered 20.8 cars per 100 people, up from 4.95 a decade ago. Telephone ownership increased from 17.2 telephones per 100 residents to 41.67.
Travelers between Taiwan and Kinmen made 1.12 million visits in 1998, up from 136,573 in 1989.
Water and electricity consumption and usage of household electrical appliances have also shown substantial increases.
Regarding medical care, there was only one doctor for every 10,000 people in 1989, but 11 in 1998.

On the other hand, the report also found that social order has declined, as the number of fires and traffic accidents increased with the rapid economic growth, a problem that the government said must be addressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: TEENAGE DISSIDENT JAILED IN CHINA

TEXT.P: An 18-year-old student was sentenced Friday to one year in prison on charges of "inciting to overthrow state power," a human rights group said.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China said Friday that the student, Yuan Yongbo, was arrested by police on June 7, four days after he put up three posters in his school, the Jianli County Normal School in the northern Chinese province of Hebei.

One of the posters called for commemoration of the 10th anniversary of "the June 4 Patriotic Movement." The second one said the "corrupt dictatorship" of the Communist Party has caused a tremendous disaster to China. The third one said "the patriotic spirit" of the June 4 movement will enlighten new generations forever, and urged "patriotic youths of the new generation" to unite together so as to generate "new revolutionary force."
The "June 4 movement" usually refers to the pro-democracy movement that led to the 1989 Tiananmen Massacre on June 4 of that year in Beijing.
The information center added that Yuan was put on trial on Sept. 10 by the Jinzhou City Intermediate People's Court in Hebei province, and that he wanted to appeal the verdict.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA TO MOBILIZE 10,000 ARMED PERSONNEL FOR MACAU HANDOVER

TEXT.P: Mainland China will mobilize some 10,000 armed police and border guards for Macau's handover in December, in order to ensure the territory's smooth transfer, Lusa News reported Friday.
