Colonel Lin Jie-yuan, commander of the Guangdong Province Public Security Bureau's border guard, reportedly said that 140 marine police units and 90 armored vehicles would be part of the operation on the Chinese side of the Macau-Zhuhai border and in other areas in the Pearl River delta in the run-up to the handover.

Lin said the operation, preparations for which were planned to be completed one month before the establishment of the Macau Special Administrative Region on December 20, was meant to ensure Macau's smooth transfer from Portuguese to Chinese administration.
In addition, Lin said all areas of the estuary near Macau would be under tight border control measures December 19-20.

He added that mainland China was paying the same degree of attention to the handover of Macau as it did to the return of Hong Kong in 1997, irrespective of the large size discrepancy between the two territories.
Macau's handover ceremony is set to take place at midnight on December 19, 1999. (by Belle Chou)

DOC.HEADLINE: LOSSES FROM HOUSING LOANS IN QUAKE-AFFECTED AREAS TOTAL NT$ 40 BILLION

TEXT.P: Losses from housing loans in earthquake-affected areas totaled NT$40 billion, Vice Finance Minister Chen Tsung said on Friday.

Chen said that although financial institutions had estimated the losses at NT$110 billion, actual losses would not surpass NT$40 billion after subtracting the value of loans for land purchases from the estimate.

Wang Kao-chin, vice president of the Bank of Taiwan (BOT), said that the BOT had a total of NT$26.9 billion in outstanding loans as of the end of September, and that the BOT had accumulated NT$15.4 billion in bad loans. The preliminary estimate of BOT housing loan losses in quake-stricken areas was only around NT$3.8 billion, an amount not expected to affect the BOT's financial situation in the period to come.

Even if the estimated figure does indeed turn out to accurately reflect the amount that victims can not pay back, it would not have a such a great impact since quake-stricken areas represent only a small part of Taiwan, Wang said. He further stated that there would be no financial crisis.
Chen and Wang made these statements at a public hearing held by the Caucus of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) at the Legislative Yuan on Friday afternoon.

Legislator Shen Fu-hsiung (DPP-Taipei City) presented a DPP proposal on how to resolve the problem of quake victims' housing loans. In the proposal, the DPP called for victims, banks and the government to share the burden of losses from housing loans.

DOC.HEADLINE: PLANS TO USE KUANFU JR. HIGH AS NAT'L QUAKE MEMORIAL HALL COMPLETED

TEXT.P: Plans to use Kuanfu Junior High School in Taichung County as a National Earthquake Memorial Hall have been completed, said Dr. Lee Yuan-tze, president of the Academia Sinica, on Thursday.
Lee informed Minister of Education Yang Tsao-hsiang via telephone that the planning work was finished.
The Ministry of Education had asked Dr. Lee to make plans for the establishment of the hall.
Construction costs for the proposed National Earthquake Memorial Hall were estimated at NT$150 million, Lee said.
Lee called on the ministry to construct the memorial hall as soon as possible so that students and the general public may obtain information about the earthquake and related events.
The magnitude-7.3 earthquake jolted Taiwan on Sept. 21, claiming more than 2,200 lives and injuring more than 8,500 people.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPOWER CLARIFIES MISGIVINGS ABOUT NUCLEAR POWER PLANTS ON FAULT LINES

TEXT.P: The state-owned Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) on Friday clarified misgivings about its nuclear plants being located on fault lines.
Taipower was responding to a report by the latest edition of the Chinese-language weekly Yazhou Zhoukan, which said that Taiwan's nuclear plants are all located on fault lines.

The report said that Taipower's first nuclear plant was built on the Chinshan fault line in Taipei County, and the second one is located on the Hsinchuang Fault line in Taipei County. The third plant is located on the Hengchun fault line in Taiwan's southern county of Pingtung, and the fourth is on the Chuchi fault line in Taipei County.
Taipower was asked about the safety of its nuclear plants in the wake of the Sept. 21 earthquake, which badly damaged the power transmission system in central Taiwan.

Taipower Vice President Hsu Chin-tang said that earthquake monitoring systems were installed in all nuclear plants, and if a tremor registering more than five on the Richter scale occurs, a safety feature will be triggered to shut down the plant.

Hsu also said the Taiwan's choices of nuclear plant sites and the plants' anti-quake design plans were made according to the nuclear energy regulations of the Untied States, meaning that within an eight kilometer radius of a nuclear power plant, there should not be an active fault line.

In the initial stage of choosing a site for a nuclear plant, the company must check the terrain within a 200-kilometer radius from the proposed site and collect geological data on previous earthquakes so as to avoid the threat of active fault lines, Hsu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI TO HOST 14TH CONTINENTAL CUP BASEBALL TOURNEY IN NOVEMBER

TEXT.P: The 14th Continental Cup Adult Baseball Championship Tournament will be held in Taipei on Nov. 3, the Chinese Taipei Baseball Association announced on Friday.

A spokesman for the association said that although the host Republic of China team will be comprised of amateur members, the association will summon seven players from professional teams to reinforce the strength of the ROC team.
Teams from the United States, Cuba, Japan, South Korea, the Netherlands, Italy, Australia and the host ROC will take part in the tourney.
The Chinese Taipei adult team will take part in the "Four Nation" Baseball Invitational Tournament to be held in Osaka Oct. 20-24.
Teams from Japan, Cuba and South Korea will join the ROC team in that invitational tournament.

DOC.HEADLINE: QUAKE-STRICKEN RESIDENTS TO STAGE PROTEST AT PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE

TEXT.P: An alliance formed by quake-stricken residents in central Taiwan will camp out in front of the Presidential Office Saturday night, an alliance official said on Friday.
Su Jen-lung, president of the alliance in Taichung County, said that he estimated that more than 10,000 people will take part in the protest activity.
Vice Premier Liu Chao-shiuan traveled to Taichung Friday to meet with Su and try to dissuade him from staging the protest.

But the meeting between Liu and Su ended inconclusively after Liu said that he would only study Su's proposal that the government and construction companies undertake the responsibility of returning houses dangerously damaged in the massive Sept. 21 earthquake to their original state.
Su has therefore decided to stage the protest as planned.

Su said in an afternoon press conference that the night protest will only be an appeal in a peaceful and rational manner, and expressed the hope that President Lee Teng-hui will receive the group's representative and respond substantially to the requests of the quake-affected residents.

Regarding Lee's scheduled trip to inspect Taichung quake-stricken areas again on Saturday, Su said that the president and other high-ranking officials have already inspected the areas so many times, and the people have repeatedly expressed their hopes, and he lamented that the government has not heard the voice of the people.

DOC.HEADLINE: WIVES OF GOVERNMENT LEADERS SUPPORT BAZAAR FOR DISPLACED PEOPLE

TEXT.P: The first lady of the Republic of China and the wives of other government leaders will support a two-day bazaar on Saturday and Sunday to raise funds for earthquake-displaced people.
The event is jointly organized by the ROC Women's Industrial and Commercial Management Association and the Yuanchi Shopping Center.
A spokesperson for the bazaar said that more than 700 items have been collected from supporters, among whom are wives of government leaders and women television news broadcasters.

Tseng Wen-hui, the first lady, donated glassware that she and her husband had received on their 50th wedding anniversary. Vice President Lien Chan's wife, Fang Yu, donated a work of graphic art that she herself made. Chu Shu-hien, whose husband is Premier Vincent Siew, donated a diamond necklace that was a birthday gift from their three daughters.
Other bazaar supporters include the wives of Control Yuan President Fredrick Chien, Foreign Minister Jason Hu and Kuomintang Secretary-General John Chang.

Chen Yueh-ching, whose husband is Mainland Chinese Affairs Chairman Su Chi, initiated the idea of organizing the bazaar. She said that she was impressed by the enthusiastic support from wives of government leaders and TV personalities.

She said the goal of the bazaar is raise NT$5 million (US$156,000) for the Cabinet's account for relief in the wake of the Sept. 21 earthquake and for Puli Christian Hospital, which was almost destroyed by the quake.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALL NATIONAL DAY CELEBRATION ACTIVITIES CALLED OFF

TEXT.P: All national day celebration activities have been called off as the nation has been striving to accomplish reconstruction of earthquake-stricken areas, a representative of the event organizers committee said on Friday.
The representative said that President Wang Chin-ping of the Legislative Yuan was originally scheduled to hold a press conference for the celebration activities on Friday, but it was also canceled.

Wang proposed at the organizers committee meeting on Sept. 22, the day after the earthquake struck Taiwan, that all celebration activities for National Day on Oct. 10 be canceled to mourn for those who died as a result of the quake.
Wang called people from on all walks of life islandwide to make efforts to help the quake-stricken victims to reconstruct their homeland.

DOC.HEADLINE: QUAKE-RELIEF STAMPS TO BE ISSUED NEXT MONTH
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 8 (CNA) (By Edward Chen) (By Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taipei, Oct. 8 (CAN) The Postal Office will issue a set of quake-relief stamps next month to help raise money for quake relief efforts.

Postal officials said that the set will consist of two stamps with a face value of NT$25 each, and the set will sell for NT$100, with half the total serving as a donation. The officials said they hope to raise NT$100 million for quake relief and reconstruction efforts.

The stamps will be designed by famous philatelic artist Lee Kuang-chi, with the first one featuring a Taiwan map showing that the epicenter of the massive Sept. 21 earthquake was located in Puli, Nantou County, and buildings that collapsed in the killer temblor.
The second stamp will highlight quake rescue and relief efforts from all walks of life, postal officials said.

The officials said that the postal office issued calamity-relief stamps in 1920 and 1942, and that it issued stamps in 1954 to help refugees in northern Vietnam, but the office has not previously issued stamps for quake relief.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC GOVERNMENT DECIDES TO SET UP SEARCH-RESCUE SQUAD

TEXT.P: The Fire-Fighting Agency under the Ministry of the Interior on Friday decided to set up a special search-rescue squad to deal with emergencies during earthquakes and other natural disasters.

The Ministry of the Interior has received a donation of NT$70 million (US$2.18 million) from several news organizations, including the Min Sheng Pao daily, the Broadcasting Corporation of China and China Television Company, to support the project.
In the initial period, 64 firefighters from the Fire-Fighting Bureau of the Taipei City Government will be sent to the United States for relevant professional training.
Following the devastating Chichi earthquake that rocked the island on Sept. 21, 38 rescue teams from 21 foreign countries rushed to Taiwan for search and rescue operations.
That prompted Taiwan authorities to realize the urgent need for establishing a special well-trained search-rescue squad under the Fire-Fighting Agency.

Of the donation, about NT$54 million will be used for procurement of related equipment, with the remaining NT$16 million going for training of the Taiwan firefighters in three areas -- search and rescue, mechanical assistance, and medical logistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Saturday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
President Lee Teng-hui continues inspection tours of earthquake-stricken central Taiwan townships.
The China Times:
Three-to-five year construction bans or stricter restrictions will be imposed in disaster zones.
The United Daily News:
The government may compensate Changhua residents whose land has liquefied.
The Liberty Times:
Power rationing for household use will be lifted from Saturday.
The Commons Daily:
Quake-affected people threaten to stage sit-in in front of the Presidential Office.
The China Post:
Quake damage to banks less than expected.
The Taiwan News:
Landslides, floods block key roadways.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Oct. 9, or the first day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1192: King Richard the Lion-hearted abandons the Holy Land after an unsuccessful Crusade, leaving Jerusalem in Muslim hands.
1651: The Navigation Act is passed, allowing only English ships to import goods from Africa, America and Asia to England.
1701: Yale University is founded in New Haven, Connecticut.
1760: Russians and Austrians pillage Berlin.
1835: Camille Saint-Saens, French Composer and pianist, is born. He is best known for his opera "Samson and Delilah" and his symphonic poem "Dance Macabre."
1870: Rome is incorporated into Italy.
1871: Big fire devastates Chicago, destroying four square miles of the city and leaving about 300 people dead and 90,000 others homeless.
1934: King Alexander of Yugoslavia and French Foreign Minister Louis Barthou, who are negotiating an alliance, are killed by Croatian terrorist Vlada Chernozamsky in Marseilles.
1940: John Lennon, English pop singer, songwriter, and musician is born. He rose to fame with the Beatles and later formed the Plastic Ono Band with his wife Yoko Ono.
1944: British Prime Minister Winston Churchill arrives in Russia to talk with Joseph Stalin in the Third Moscow Conference.
1944: China, the US, the UK and the USSR promulgate the draft for the Charter of the United Nations.
1958: Pope Pius XII, originally Eugenio Pacelli, dies at the age of 82. He headed the Roman Catholic Church during World War II.
1960: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with the Congo (Leopoldville) Republic.
1962: Uganda gains formal independence after nearly 70 years of British rule.
1963: A rock slide badly damages the Vaiont Dam in the Italian Alps, killing some 3,000 people.
1965: ROC Ambassador to the United States and Representative to the United Nations Tsiang Ting-fu dies of liver cancer in New York at the age of 71.
1967: Ernesto "Che" Guevara, the Argentine-born revolutionary who helped Fidel Castro win power in Cuba, is shot dead after being captured by Bolivian Army troops. He was 39.
1967: Indonesia severs diplomatic relations with communist China.
1970: Dissident Soviet writer Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, winner of 1970 Nobel Prize for Literature, turns down invitation to Stockholm to attend the award ceremony in December.
1970: Cambodia declares itself the Khmer republic.
1975: Soviet dissident and human rights activist Andrei Sakharov is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.
1983: South Korean President Chun Doo Hwan escapes unharmed when 17 members of his entourage, including Foreign Minister Lee Bum Suk, are killed in a bomb blast in Rangoon.
1984: Famed Cantonese opera actress from Mainland China, Hung Hung, 40, announces her defection in a press conference held at the Free China Relief Association in Taipei.
1984: A five-year severance of relations between Amman and Cairo ends today with the visit of President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt to Jordan.
1986: The Executive Yuan passes the Program for Taroko National Park, in which NT$4 billion is to be invested in developing the park over six years.
1987: Clare Boothe Luce, American writer and public official, dies at the age of 85. She wrote several plays, including "The Women" and served as ambassador to Italy.
1997: Hurricane Pauline hits the Mexican tourist resort of Acapulco, killing more than 200 people.
1998: Italian Prime Minister Romano Prodi's government resigns after losing its 31st confidence vote.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is only the man with the most perfect divine moral nature who is able to combine in himself quickness of dignity, noble seriousness, order and regularity: qualities necessary for the exercise of self-respect."

DOC.HEADLINE: MOTORCYCLE USERS MAY SOON HAVE TO PAY PARKING FEES: MOTC

TEXT.P: Motorcycle owners might soon be required to pay parking fees in the future according to a white paper released by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC).
The Institute of Transportation under the MOTC recently completed the white paper dealing with problems resulting from too many motorcycles on the island.

MOTC officials said that as of August of this year, there were 18 million motorcycles in Taiwan, or just under one for every two citizens. Although the previously rapid growth in the number of new motorcycles on the road has slowed in recent years, the number is still steadily increasing by 3.56 percent each year.

MOTC officials lamented the fact that the increased use of compact passenger cars has not replaced the use of motorcycles, adding that more motorcycles on the road has created such problems as chaotic traffic and a lack of parking spaces.
The MOTC has therefore set a three-stage goal in its white paper to deal with the problems resulting from the huge number of motorcycles.

The short-term goals will be to gradually cut the number of motorcycle parking spaces in arcades and on sidewalks, to convert some car parking spaces into motorcycle parking spots, to increase parking space around public transportation sites, to crack down more on violators of motorcycle parking regulations, and to push for motorcycle parking fees in certain zones.

The middle-term goal will be to encourage the public to use the public transportation network more. The government hopes that public transportation use will rise to more than 40 percent of people's total transportation requirements during this stage.
When the public transportation network can meet more than 50 percent of the public's needs, the government will begin to push for the long-term goal, MOTC officials said.

The officials said that during the last stage, the ministry will consider increasing the cost of possessing and using motorcycles and automobiles and will push for the creation of `off-limit' areas for vehicles during certain times of the day, hoping that the public transportation system will eventually take the place of private vehicles.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIA LETS AUSTRALIAN MPS SEE REFUGEES IN W. TIMOR CAMPS
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 9 (CNA) (By Lilian Wu) (By Peter Chen)

TEXT.P: Canberra, Oct. 9 (CNA): Indonesia has allowed four members of the Australian Parliament to inspect the conditions in West Timorese camps holding hundreds of thousands of East Timorese refugees amid US calls for the UN to reduce the size of its proposed peacekeeping force.

In a dispatch from Dili, the Sydney Morning Herald on Saturday reported that Labor MP Kevin Rudd has received an approval from the Indonesian government to visit West Timor but that Jakarta has limited the number of Australian MPs to four. The Australian MPs are expected to leave for West Timor some time next week for a weeklong inspection tour.

DOC.HEADLINE: INVADING TAIWAN NOT IN BEING'S BEST INTERESTS SAYS COHEN

TEXT.P: The United States has indicated to Beijing that a military move to take Taiwan would be inconsistent with the Taiwan Relations Act, and also inconsistent with China's best interests, US Defense Secretary William Cohen recently said in Bangkok.

"We think China should resolve its problem with Taiwan peacefully and Taiwan should not try to separate and become an `independent' state or country" said Cohen in an interview last weekend with The Nation, a Bangkok-based English language daily.

Responding to whether the US is determined to defend Taiwan in case of a Chinese attack, Cohen said "We have a `One-China' policy. But we also have a Taiwan Relations Act in which we are required and obligated to provide a defensive capability to Taiwan."

He said, "We have indicated to Taiwan and to China that we expect their disagreements to be resolved peacefully. That's our commitment. So, we are hoping that the rhetoric will be reduced and the tensions will be reduced."

DOC.HEADLINE: US BUSINESS LEADERS ACCUSED OF KOWTOWING TO BEIJING

TEXT.P: US Republican presidential hopeful Gary Bauer on Friday called on American businessmen to put US interests and values ahead of trade with Communist China and stop kowtowing to Beijing's "thuggish leadership."

The former Reagan administration official said in a statement that "Coming as it did in the midst of the worst Communist Chinese crackdown on human rights since the Tiananmen Square massacre, the sight of 300 of the world's leading capitalist businessmen kowtowing to Beijing's thuggish leadership was chilling and deeply troubling."

Even as Beijing put its aggressive new militancy on display in a missile-rattling parade of weaponry to mark the 50th anniversary of Communist dictatorship, scores of American CEOs attended the Fortune Global Forum in Shanghai. "Here again we witnessed the spectacle of US businessmen putting profits ahead of the principles of freedom and democracy," said Bauer.

As an example, The Republican conservative leader pointed out that Maurice Greenberg, chairman of the insurance giant American International Group, "obediently toed the Communist line by denouncing the notion that China needs more democracy."

Especially troubling, Bauer noted, was the presence in Beijing of top executives from media conglomerates, such as media giant Time Warner's Gerald Levin, who calls Communist dictator Jiang Zemin "my good friend," and Viacom's Sumner Restone, who suggested at a press conference in Beijing that American journalists should avoid being "unnecessarily offensive" in covering news in other countries.

Mr. Redstone even told the beaming Communist Chinese dictators that "We do not view it as our role to tell the government of China how to run China. We want to do business. We cannot succeed without being a friend of the Chinese people and the Chinese government."

But Bauer stressed that "I believe that the best demonstration of our friendship for the Chinese people is pressing the Chinese government to respect basic human rights and stop oppressing its citizens."

"Will American news organizations be pressured to pull their punches on reporting China's human rights abuses in order to serve the commercial interests of their parent companies? This prospect is both real and disturbing," said Bauer.

"Are American businessmen so beguiled by profits that they are willing to abandon their country's most cherished ideals of freedom, democracy and human rights? If true, that is a sad commentary on our times. These gentlemen seem to have forgotten that they are Americans first and businessmen second," added the presidential hopeful. (By Nelson Chung)

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON PRAISES TOLERANCE AMONG PEOPLE

TEXT.P: US President Bill Clinton praised Canada's tolerance toward people and reiterated his country's support for a strong and united Canada Friday.

In a speech he made while opening the new US embassy in Ottawa, Clinton talked about how much richer a society can be when all members work together to build each other up instead of trying to gain political advantage.
"Early this year (April), we in the United States were pleased to see Canada's rich tradition of democracy deepen with the creation of the new territory of Nunavut," he said.
"We are proud to be your partners and allies, and we deeply value our relationship with a strong, united, democratic Canada."
"We have learned from you, a parliamentary democracy with two official languages, many distinct cultures, an inspiring commitment to social justice and solidarity," Clinton said in Ottawa.

He praised Canada's tolerance and commitment to justice. "It is no surprise that the word multicultural actually comes from Canada. For two centuries you have shown the world how people of different cultures can live together in peace, prosperity and mutual respect, in a country where human differences are democratically expressed, not forcefully repressed."

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE DOLLAR AND BOURSE CLOSE LOWER

TEXT.P: The Australian currency and stock market closed lower on Friday amid uncertainties over interest rates in the United States and lower prices in gold and commodities in the global market.
The Australian dollar closed at 65.75 U.S. cents, erasing gains made earlier as a result of lower prices in gold and commodities on the world market, brokers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: UN BOOSTS PEACEKEEPING FORCE TO 7000 TO COUNTER MILITIA VIOLENCE

TEXT.P: Canberra, Oct. 9 (CNA): The Australian-led UN peacekeeping force will increase to 7000 troops by this weekend to counter possible militia attacks and violence as it moves to secure the remaining areas, including pro-Jakarta militia strongholds, in East Timor.

Australian Defense Minister John Moore told reporters in Brisbane on Friday that most of the soldiers to join Australia's 4500 troops will come from New Zealand, with some coming from South Korea and the Philippines.
"The possibilities of militia incursions are probably higher between now and the vote in the Indonesian parliament," he said. "The next couple of weeks will be critical."
Moore said he would press the United Nations to launch the third phase of its operation- to bring in blue-helmet UN workers to oversee civil administration and peacekeeping. (by Peter Chen)

DOC.HEADLINE: PROSECUTOR OFFICE ISSUES ARREST WARRANT FOR CONSTRUCTOR

TEXT.P: The Prosecutor's Office in Taichung has issued an arrest warrant for the constructor of a building complex which collapsed in central Taiwan during the massive earthquake last month.

Prosecutor Hsu Wan-hsiang said he issued the warrant after Chang Ming-chen, owner of the construction company that built the "golden Paris" community complex in Tali, Taichung, refused to answer questions about alleged violations of building codes.
Several high-rise buildings in the complex either cracked, tilted, or collapsed, resulting in 79 deaths during the magnitude 7.3 earthquake that hit central Taiwan Sept. 21.

Chang and his family emigrated to Canada prior to the killer quake and a task force to trace down wanted criminals is now coordinating efforts with judicial authorities in Canada to help revoke Chang's resident permit and repatriate him to Taiwan.
The Taichung Prosecutor's Office has also asked the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Taiwan to revoke Chang's ROC passport.

Chang has faxed a message to the Taichung Prosecutor's Office through his friends in Taiwan on Friday, saying that although he would take moral responsibility for the victims of the quake, the collapse of the building should be blamed on incomplete construction codes. He also said that he would not return to face questions, local reports said.

Chang claimed that it was never expected that an earthquake as strong as the one on Sept. 21 could hit Taichung, and that the complex had been built to withstand a magnitude 5 earthquake, as specified in the construction codes. Therefore, he says he should not take the blame.

In the wake of last month's killer jolt, the Prosecutors' Offices in Panchiao, Taipei County, Taichung and Changhua have begun to probe cases concerning deaths and casualties caused by buildings that collapsed or were badly damaged in the quake.

It is estimated that the Prosecutors' Offices have already frozen the properties of 53 building contractors, construction companies and architects since the Sept. 21 quake. Presently, 19 people are under arrest, 20 have been released on bail and a total of 52 people are barred from leaving Taiwan due to faulty construction cases related to the earthquake.

DOC.HEADLINE: FRUIT BAZAAR HELD FOR QUAKE-AFFECTED FARMERS

TEXT.P: A fruit bazaar was held in Taipei on Saturday for the benefit of farmers in mountainous central Taiwan which was rattled by a devastating earthquake on Sept. 21.

The bazaar was organized by the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) to help sell fruits and vegetables from quake-stricken Miaoli, Taichung, and Nantou counties, which produce many cash crops, including pears, persimmons and pomelos.

COA Chairman Peng Tso-kwei said the fruit harvest in central Taiwan is bountiful this year. However, the 921 earthquake disrupted traffic networks in the region, hindering fruit harvesting and affecting market demand.

Many fruit and vegetable growers in disaster zones were saddened to see their cash crops rotting on their battered farms. Peng said the bazaar was aimed at helping farmers get over their current difficulties and encouraging them to redouble efforts to rebuild their shattered businesses and lives.
Premier Vincent Siew, accompanied by Peng, arrived at the square in front of the COA office at 9 a.m. to kick off the charity sale, dubbed the "Thank You for Your Love" bazaar.

Siew said Taichung and Nantou counties bore the brunt of the 921 earthquake. Noting that many residents there saw their homes and businesses shattered in the tremor, Siew said he hopes people residing in other parts of the island will pool resources to help quake-affected compatriots rebuild their homes and lives.
Led by Siew and Peng, many COA officials joined the promotional drive to sell agricultural products from disaster zones. Their efforts won a warm response from the spectators.

A case of pears from Taichung County's Hoping village, with a normal market value of NT$1,000 (US$31.45), managed to fetch NT$15,000 and a case of guavas from Nantou County's Chichi township, located at the epicenter of the killer earthquake, sold for NT$5,000, 33 times its normal market price.
Also on sale were star fruit, dried longans, processed plums, sweet persimmons, pomelos, vegetables, flowers and other agricultural products.

At noon, Vice President Lien Chan arrived at the site, fueling another high point in the bazaar. In addition to purchasing a large quantity of fruits himself, Lien helped auction off many cases of high-quality pears, with each fetching NT$40,000 to NT$50,000. Three specially designed floral postcards with Lien's signature managed to fetch NT$160,000 in total.
COA officials said the bazaar is expected to attract many other buyers before it ends on Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: STOCK TRANSACTION TAX REVENUE DOWN SHARPLY IN SEPTEMBER

TEXT.P: Stock transaction tax revenues totaled only NT$7 billion (US$220.12 million) in September, a sharp decrease from NT$8.3 billion in the previous month, the Ministry of Finance said on Saturday.

MOF officials attributed the marked decrease to the massive earthquake on Sep. 21 and also to the Moon Festival which fell on Sept. 24 this year. As a result, the Taiwan stock exchange was closed from Sept. 21 until Sept. 27.
With the reduced number of trading days after the killer jolt and the resulting power rationing, production and trading activities were seriously affected, they said.
The officials said that the extensive damage caused by the quake means housing tax revenue will be severely affected.
The large-scale power shortage and rationing in the wake of the earthquake also means that manufacturers have suffered heavy losses and business tax revenues will also decrease.

The officials said that the MOF is scheduled to unveil its statistics on national tax revenue on Monday. But they mentioned that the real effect of the killer quake on tax revenue may really only emerge in October or November

DOC.HEADLINE: MODERATE QUAKES CONTINUE TO ROCK CENTRAL TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Several moderate earthquakes rocked central and eastern Taiwan on Saturday, but no casualties were reported, according to the Central Weather Bureau.
As of Saturday evening, eight quakes with magnitudes between 4.1 and 4.9 on the Richter scale were recorded.
The epicenters of four quakes were located around the Sun Moon Lake area of Nantou County, with the remaining ones located in Taichung, Hualien, and Chiayi.

Since the devastating Chichi earthquake ripped central Taiwan before dawn on Sept. 21, more than 11,000 aftershocks have been registered. Over 2,200 people were killed in the strongest quake to hit Taiwan in nearly 100 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: FULL TEXT OF PRESIDENT LEE'S NATIONAL DAY MESSAGE (I)

TEXT.P: The following is the full text of President Lee Teng-hui's Double Ten National Day message. Ladies and Gentlemen:

Today is the 88th National Day of the Republic of China. Each year, we greet this day with boundless joy. Today, however, we must solemnly and seriously review our nation's founding principles and forge a consensus of unity to overcome sorrow and pain and to create a bright future for us all.

In the early hours of September 21, a major earthquake with a magnitude of 7.3 hit the Taiwan area, causing severe casualties and immense losses. The earthquake not only shocked the international community, but also left us in lasting sorrow.

During the past 20 days, I went deep into the devastated areas, to determine the full scope of the disaster and the progress of the relief work. Seeing the destruction of our homeland and our suffering fellow countrymen, I am grief-stricken; however, I am even more determined to work together with the entire populace to rebuild our homeland.

In fact, since the September 21 earthquake occurred, the government, the private sector, and all the citizens have shown their best capabilities and devoted their utmost efforts to the relief and rescue work. Showing deep compassion for their compatriots and brothers, they have made it possible for the disaster victims to receive timely care and feel warmth. The collective efforts, the courage, and the faith in surmounting difficulties together will provide the greatest momentum for us to begin the reconstruction of our beautiful homeland.

In the aftermath of the earthquake, we are especially heartened and comforted by the concern and assistance we received from the international community, as well as the generous donations from our overseas compatriots. A total of 38 rescue teams, with over 700 members, from the United Nations and 20 countries in Asia, Europe, and America, arrived in Taiwan to participate in our rescue mission. On behalf of the government and people of the Republic of China, I would like to express my most sincere appreciation to the world community for its concern and support. Let me also reiterate here that the Republic of China will strive even more vigorously to fulfill its international responsibilities and make substantive contributions to the development of the global community.

Ladies and gentlemen: Tempering through adversity creates an opportunity for rebirth. Although the earthquake has left scars on this land that cannot be healed, we are confident and determined that we shall accomplish our reconstruction projects within the shortest possible time under the concerted efforts of every one of us. Giving consideration to both the characteristics of each area and the needs of the people, we shall implement a renovation that will bring harmony to our homeland, so our people can enjoy a safe, new life. We will also advance more steadily and firmly to expand new opportunities for national development as we enter the next millennium.

In domestic affairs, we will continue to promote reengineering of the government, along with judicial and educational reforms, to realize the ideals of democracy, increase government effectiveness, and encourage the vitality of the private sector. We will thereby enhance the overall strength of our nation and lay a favorable foundation for our national development, to meet the intense international competition of the future. (more)

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL DAY MESSAGE (II)

TEXT.P: In economics, we will focus on liberalization, internationalization, and pluralization, actively removing barriers to investment, accelerating the modernization of industry, and strengthening the economic structure, in order to maintain economic stability and growth. Concurrently, we will utilize our advantages of the present to build Taiwan into a technology island and thereby, launch a new era for Taiwan's future economic development.

In the area of social development, we must improve our social welfare system to protect the minority and disadvantaged groups, in order to implement social justice and establish a humanitarian and caring modern society. We must effectively carry out the rule of law, take strict precautions against natural calamities, and strengthen law and order to protect the lives and properties of the people.

On national security, we must consolidate our defense and the strategy of effective deterrence. We must continue to streamline the military and regenerate a modern military force. Meanwhile, we must also actively participate in Asia-Pacific regional security mechanisms to jointly promote world peace, cooperation, and prosperity.

In cross-strait relations, we acknowledge that the nation has not yet been unified, and the two sides of the Taiwan Strait still maintain different views on the definition of "one China." However, we deem that the relationship between the two sides to be a special state-to-state relationship, which is a historical and legal fact. Both sides should squarely face this reality. They should use it as a foundation to promote constructive dialogue. Through parity, divided rule, and peaceful competition, the two sides should seek peaceful unification in the future. On Taiwan, the Republic of China has created a dominion of democracy unprecedented in Chinese history, a model for the Chinese mainland on its way toward modernization. We hope that the Chinese mainland authorities will soon implement democratic reforms, which will create conditions conducive to the gradual unification of the two sides.

Ladies and gentlemen: The Republic of China has weathered many difficulties and challenges since its establishment. It was only through the perseverance and unceasing efforts of all ROC citizens that we could surmount these adversities and bring our nation into a new era. Particularly, in the past five decades, the unity of purpose and effort of the government and the people has made Taiwan an island of freedom, democracy and prosperity.

Today, we face tremendous destruction of property and loss of life from this devastating earthquake. But, we believe that hardship will bring us closer together and adversity will regenerate our strength. Only if we have an iron will and cooperate fully can all the pain and sorrow be transformed into that new strength, and the unity of purpose become a force for rebirth. At the threshold of the new century, let us take that brave step forward to rebuild our beautiful homeland.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Oct. 10, or the second day of the Ninth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1911: A revolt against the Manchu (Ching) dynasty erupts in Wuchang and is followed by revolutionary activities throughout China. The government of the Republic of China formally announces on Sept. 28 that The Double Tenth National Day is to observed in commemoration of the Wuchang Uprising which led to the establishment of the ROC on Jan. 1, 1912.
1913: Yuan Shih-kai, who forced the Congress to elect him president of the Republic of China on Oct. 6, formally assumes the presidency.
1919: The Chung-hua ke-ming tang (Chinese Revolutionary Party) is reorganized by Dr. Sun Yat-sen as the Chung-kuo kuo-min tang (abbreviated as Kuomintang or Nationalist Party).
1921: Dr. Sun Yat-sen completes the writing of "Plans for Industrial Development."
1925: The National Palace Museum is inaugurated in Peiping (now Beijing).
1928: Chiang Kai-shek assumes the chairmanship of the National government in Nanking.
1934: The main forces of the Chinese communist troops flee northwest from their bases in Kiangsi, starting their so-called "Long March."
1942: The US and UK governments announce their intention to relinquish extraterritoriality and related rights in China.
1943: Chiang Kai-shek is sworn in as chairman of the National government.
1954: Ho Chi Minh returns to Hanoi as the French evacuate.
1957: A major radiation leak is detected at the Windscale Atomic Power Station in Britain following a nuclear accident on Oct. 7.
1958: The ROC Air Force shoots down five communist MiG-17s and damages two others off the mainland coast but losses one Saber jet in the battle.
1962: Taiwan Television Enterprise, Ltd., the first commercial television station in the Republic of China, goes into operation.
1970: Fiji, a British colony in the southern Pacific sine 1874, becomes an independent member of the Commonwealth.
1973: Spiro Agnew, 54, twice chosen by President Richard Nixon to be his vice president, resigns before appearing in a federal district court in Baltimore to face charges of income tax evasion.
1980: A strong earthquake rocks Algeria, killing more than 12,500 people.
1985: Yul Brynner, American film and stage actor, dies of lung cancer at the age of 65. He won an Oscar for his role in the musical "The King and I."
1986: An estimated 250 thousand people gather before the Presidential Building to celebrate the 75th anniversary of the Republic of China. President Chiang Ching-kuo addresses the nation in person and states that the ROC will accomplish the ultimate objective of reunifying China.
1993: An overloaded ferry capsizes off the coast of Puan county, south of Seoul, South Korea, killing 292.
1993: The Pan Hellenic Socialist Movement (PASOK) party wins elections in Greece. As head of the party, Andreas Papandreou again becomes prime minister.
1997: An Australian DC-9 airliner from Argentina crashes into a swamp in Uruguay, killing all 74 people on board.
1997: The International Campaign to Ban Landmines and the American Campaign coordinator Jodie Williams win the Nobel Peace Prize.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Sunday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
President Lee Teng-hui urges unity and determination to rebuild the homeland after the devastating earthquake in his National Day message.
The China Times:
The Prosecutor's Office will prosecute corrupt and negligent constructors for their involvement in the buildings collapsed during the Sept. 21 jolt within a month.
The United Daily News:
President Lee urges the people to solemnly and seriously review the nation's founding principles.
The Liberty Times:
Lee urges the people to overcome sorrow and begin reconstruction work.
The Commons Daily:
Lee said that tempering through adversity creates an opportunity for rebirth.
The China Post:
President Lee reiterates 'two states' in National Day speech.
The Taiwan News:
Lee outlines plans in talk with quake victims.

DOC.HEADLINE: RECONSTRUCTION EFFORTS NOT TO AFFECT DIPLOMATIC WORK: HU

TEXT.P: Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu said on Sunday that the ministry will not allow reconstruction efforts to affect diplomatic work.

Hu was responding to questions on whether the diplomacy budget will be reduced after cancellation of large-scale festivities that included invitations to foreign dignitaries for the 88th anniversary of the founding of the Republic of China, a measure taken in order to redirect funds to post-quake reconstruction.

Hu said that the ministry has not yet felt any effect on the budget for foreign aid, but that in the next fiscal year, the ministry will review which expenses can be cut and channeled into reconstruction efforts in the years ahead.
He said the ministry will reduce whatever spending necessary as long as diplomatic work is not affected and the nation can maintain its stature and friendly relations with allies.

On whether the US$300 million in aid to Kosovo promised by President Lee Teng-hui earlier will be cut, Hu said that the aid program had been planned to span a period of up to seven years, averaging US$40 million a year.

Hu said the ministry had earlier stated that the aid in the first year would not exceed US$20 million. So far, it is estimated that only US$6.5 million is required in the first year, an amount well below the original estimate.

As for aid during the second year, Hu said that deliberations over government spending will be made, and added that the most urgent task now is relief and reconstruction work in the wake of the devastating Sept. 21 earthquake.
Hu said that the ministry will be pragmatic in making a balanced consideration of diplomatic efforts and domestic reconstruction needs.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMY GETS HIGHEST MARKS FOR RESCUE, RELIEF EFFORTS: POLL
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 10 (CNA) (By Lilian Wu) (By Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taipei, Oct. 10 (CNA The army won the loudest applause for its role in rescue and relief operations after the devastating earthquake last month, according to a poll released on Sunday.

The poll, conducted by Academia Sinica, the highest research institute in Taiwan, took into account physical and psychological damages, rescue and relief efforts, and reconstruction projects in the wake of the Sept. 21 earthquake.
The survey showed that in quake-stricken areas, people who were polled gave the army the highest marks of 76.1 percent for its contribution to rescue and relief efforts.

The army was followed by the Buddhist group Tzuchi and Christian groups (71.7 percent), private rescue teams (70.3 percent), foreign rescue teams (62.1 percent), and firefighters and their co-workers (54.5 percent).
Only 33 percent of respondents said the central government has been helpful in rescue and relief operations, with the local governments being deemed helpful by just 32.2 percent of those polled.
The result of the survey was a far cry from the view held by the government, which had earlier given its rescue and relief performance a much better assessment.
The survey also found that people are still suffering from "post-quake" trauma after the earthquake, which registered a magnitude of 7.3 on the Richter scale.
Nearly three out of four people polled said they could not get rid of the rocking feeling and were prone to nervousness.
Of those surveyed, 54.1 percent said they were worried about the safety of family or friends, and 44.6 percent said they had become more aware of the vicissitudes of their lives.
One third of respondents also said they planned to change their previous way of living and try to bring more meaning to their lives.
Researchers said the figures showed the importance of psychological rehabilitation and the changes in values after the killer jolt.
Three of every four respondents said they had not taken the right measures to avoid calamities; only 23 percent said they woke up family members immediately and ran outdoors.
The poll also found that 82.6 percent of those surveyed have donated money to quake-stricken areas and 55.5 percent planned to donate money for reconstruction.
The researchers said this revealed that the government has backing and financial support from the public and should make good use of it.

They also said that after the quake, the mobilization of citizens by private groups and the efficiency displayed by such groups became a major force in the rescue and relief effort. Their speedy mobilization was in contrast to that of the government.
The survey was based on telephone calls made between Oct. 4 and Oct. 8 to 1,110 people over the age of 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: CETRA POSTS MANUFACTURING INDUSTRY'S POST-QUAKE SITUATION ON WEBSITE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) proclaimed on its website Sunday that Taiwan's manufacturing industry has recovered from the Sept. 21 earthquake.

The council further stated that industry operations have resumed with hopes of restoring foreign buyers' confidence in Taiwan's manufacturing ability before any decisions are made to shift orders to other countries.

The CETRA website contained a link to a report on the complete resumption of manufacturing industry production line activity after last month's devastating temblor. Posted information included a statement that all trade fairs will take place as scheduled.

At the related website, CETRA offered space for local manufacturers to report on their reconstruction work in an effort to help international buyers have a better idea of the actual post-quake situation. It is hoped that such information will help protect Taiwan's manufacturing industry from being hurt by rumors that exaggerate losses caused by the quake.

The council stressed that the temblor occurred in central Taiwan's mountainous area, where no manufacturing centers have ever been located. Economic losses stemming from the quake were estimated at US$10 billion, accounting for less than 0.1 percent of Taiwan's annual GDP.
One hundred percent of production lines resumed operation in less than 20 days after the earthquake, CETRA said, a speed that the council believed amazed the world. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER THANKS O'SEAS CHINESE LEADERS FOR PATRIOTIC DEEDS

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew met with overseas Chinese community leaders from around the world to express heartfelt thanks from the government and people of the Republic of China for their patriotic deeds and generous donations after the Sept. 21 earthquake.

Overseas Chinese community leaders returned to Taipei to mark the Republic of China's National Day, which falls on Oct. 10. All celebration activities were called off due to the earthquake that caused tremendous losses of life and property.

Siew told the overseas Chinese leaders that due to the devastation, all National Day celebrations have been canceled so as to transform Taiwan's grief into strength to carry out reconstruction work in quake-stricken areas.
Siew expressed the gratitude of the government and people of the Republic of China for the generous overseas Chinese donations, which had accumulated to NT$860 million as of last Friday.
"Your deep concern and generous donations were one of the strong forces of support for the reconstruction work of the quake-stricken areas," Siew said.

Siew stressed that although the quake brought grief and pain to the people of Taiwan, thanks to post-quake relief efforts, Taiwan has been filled with love and concern. This kind of love and concern is vital to the life of the nation.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLARS URGE PSYCHOLOGICAL REHABILITATION IN QUAKE-STRICKEN AREAS

TEXT.P: Scholars on Sunday urged the nation to pay equal attention to physical and psychological recovery in the wake of last month's massive earthquake.
The scholars made the appeal during a seminar on psychological rehabilitation in the post-quake period. The seminar was sponsored by the non-profit Chinese Learned Society.
The Sept. 21 quake, recorded at magnitude 7.3 on the Richter scale, has to date claimed the lives of more than 2,300 and led to extensive losses and damages in central Taiwan.
The presenters at the seminar noted that the government has now shifted its focus from relief to reconstruction, but they stressed that psychological recovery should receive the same attention.

Lan Shan-yin, a professor at National Chengchi University, said that physical damages could be repaired in two or three years, but many people in quake-stricken areas, faced with the sudden loss of family members, could develop a sense of fear and hopelessness.

Lan urged the government to form a systematic counseling network of experts to help those quake-affected people emerge from the shadow of mistrust and a sense of helplessness, and move forward into the future.
The government should also pay attention to the employment situation of those affected by the quake, said both Lan and Lin Hsien-chung, another professor at the same university.
Lan said that temporary job assignments will only provide short-term relief, and the government's main consideration should be helping people reestablish regular employment.
Professor Lin said that the government should be more active in providing job opportunities for affected people to keep them from becoming pessimistic and helpless.
Professor Cheng Shih-yen, who has provided psychological counseling in quake-stricken areas, said that natural disasters force changes in society, influencing the behavior of affected people.

After experiencing a crisis, people require a stronger sense of security, Cheng said, citing the following example: Even if survivors understand that four bottles of mineral water is sufficient for one day's use, they may request double that amount in order to feel psychologically safe.
Cheng said that some have criticized quake survivors as being greedy, but their mentality requires a deeper understanding.

Cheng also suggested that the government pay attention to the education of children in quake-stricken areas and provide them with psychological counseling, as many of them lost family members in the earthquake.
Cheng also advised people to stay active during the post-quake period to help ward off depression.

DOC.HEADLINE: QUAKE SURVIVORS LONGING FOR PRAGMATIC HELP AND ESCAPE FROM SORROW

TEXT.P: With tears in their eyes, survivors of the "921 Earthquake" silently watched and saluted as the national flag was raised over the Presidential Office Sunday morning.
Sadness dominated the flag-raising ceremony, which was very different from that held last year on Oct. 10, the "Double Ten" National Day of the Republic of China.

Neither colorful decorations nor joyful crowds were present outside the Presidential Office on the tenth day of the tenth month, when Taiwan's people were supposed to be enthralled in a series of celebrations of the ROC's 88th birthday, starting with the flag-raising ceremony.
"While watching the flag, I made a wish that I could bid farewell forever to the sorrow that has lived in me since the earthquake took away everything I had," said one of the survivors.

The magnitude-7.3 temblor jolted Taiwan on Sept. 21, leaving more than 2,200 people dead, over 8,700 injured, and thousands of residential buildings collapsed. Central Taiwan's Nantou and Taichung counties sustained the severest damage and losses due to their proximity to the epicenter of the devastating earthquake.

More than 100 quake survivors participated in the morning ceremony. They were members of the 921 Earthquake Victims Alliance, who, along with hundreds of others from quake-stricken areas, had camped since Saturday night at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall.

The group had attempted to stage a peaceful overnight demonstration by camping on Kaitakelan Blvd. in front of the Presidential Office on Saturday, with the hope of calling more serious government attention to their grave suffering from earthquake damage. The plan, however, was called off after a six-hour stand-off between representatives of the alliance and police, who treated the demonstration as illegal.
After the Sunday morning ceremony, some alliance members proceeded to Academia Sinica, hoping to meet President Lee Yuan-tseh of the insititue to demand "real" assistance in rebuilding their homes.
Lee recently convened a national private group to monitor government use of a large amount of money donated for post-quake reconstruction work.

Claiming that they have not received one dime of the government's promised financial aid for housing, the quake survivors tried to submit a statement to the prominent academic leader. Their statement consisted of an appeal that the government unconditionally help rebuild their homes and compensate them for living in temporary housing.

However, the group failed to meet with Lee, but was received by Lee's special assistant Hsie Hsing-kuo, who accepted the statement on the president's behalf from Su Jen-long, leader of the 921 Earthquake Victims Alliance. Hsie promised that Lee will personally communicate with the quake survivors after hearing their voice.

DOC.HEADLINE: DAILY LOWER-LIMIT ON DOMESTIC BOURSE RESUMES TO 7% MONDAY

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) on Sunday announced that the daily lower-limit for fluctuation of stocks trading on the domestic bourse will resume to 7 percent from 3.5 percent on Monday.
The MOF restricted the maximum daily decline for listed stocks to 3.5 percent on Sept. 27, six days after the "921 Earthquake" that severely battered the central part of the island.

The MOF took the measure in a bid to prevent the local stock market from suffering heavy losses after the disastrous temblor damaged central Taiwan's electricity distribution system, forcing the Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) to ration electricity in northern Taiwan in the last two weeks.
The MOF made the decision because Taipower announced on Sunday that it will formally conclude electricity rationing for eight counties and cities in northern Taiwan on Monday.
The weighted stock price index, the Taiwan Stock Exchange's key barometer, only fell 206 points during the 11 trading sessions from Sept. 27 to Oct. 8.

DOC.HEADLINE: QUAKE RECONSTRUCTION TO BE FINISHED AS SOON AS POSSIBLE: PRES. LEE

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui stressed in his National Day message that the train of suffering was at the point of turning.

President Lee said that although the island's biggest earthquake jolted Taiwan on Sept. 21 and left the nation with a scar incapable of healing, "through the concerted efforts of the government and the people, we have confidence and determination and will accomplish the reconstruction work of the quake-stricken areas as soon as possible."

The Chinese head of state said that the reconstruction work will be accomplished by paying attention to the character of each individual piece of land and to individual demands so as to rebuild the affected areas into a harmonious landscape and let the people enjoy a new life.
At the same time, "we should build the country with more firm steps and develop our country to meet the needs of the coming century," Lee said.

Lee presided over a central government ceremony marking the 1999 Double Ten National Day at the Presidential Palace on Sunday morning. More than 300 government and civic leaders, including Vice President Lien Chan, as well as overseas Chinese representatives took part in the ceremony.

The president said that Sunday was the 88th National Day of the Republic of China. "We always celebrated our nation's birthday with a joyful mood every year. However, we marked this year's national day with sorrow and grief."
Lee called on the people to stand united by reconsidering the founding spirit of the nation and overcoming sorrow and grief to build a new nation to be able to meet the needs of the next century.

The president went on to say that after the earthquake, the government, civic organizations and the people had concentrated their efforts to implement relief and rescue work. The determination and courage to surpass hardships were the biggest factor in rebuilding quake-affected areas into a beautiful homeland.

Lee, on behalf of the government and the people of the Republic of China, also expressed heartfelt gratitude to more than 38 rescue teams from 20 countries around the world, religious organizations, and the United Nations for rushing to Taiwan to help with relief work after the earthquake jolted the island on Sept. 21, claiming more than 2,200 lives.
"The Republic of China will positively carry out its international obligations by making more contributions to the development of the international community in the future," Lee stressed.

The president pointed out that the Republic of China has met various challenges and difficulties since it was established in 1912. Under the concerted efforts of the government and the people, "we have broken through hardship and built a new era."

"We have built our nation into a democratic, free and prosperous nation over the past five decades," Lee said, adding that "though the biggest earthquake in history brought grave losses of life and property, we believe the suffering will make us closer and more united as well as bringing us power."
"We should transform our sorrow and grief into strength and stand united to rebuild the nation into a nation able to stand whatever disasters come in the next century, " Lee added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON DAN RAVAGES KINMEN

TEXT.P: Kinmen is facing its largest disaster in the past two decades, after typhoon Dan left the front-line island with a total power blackout and severed water supply.

On Sunday both the Kinmen military defense headquarters and the county government were fully mobilized to repair damages, a military officer said, noting that all regular military exercises had been suspended and personnel had been assigned to relief work.

At least 200 millimeters of rain fell in Kinmen, as Dan blew away trees along streets islandwide, tore signboards from stores, and damaged the telecommunications system and more than 20 critical power transmission lines around the isle.

Fallen trees and floodwaters blocked transportation on main roadways, and the local airport was forced to shut down due to poor visibility for take-off and landing. The terminal was expected to reopen Sunday afternoon.
No casualties were reported on the island. However, a report from another of Taiwan's offshore islands, Penghu, indicated that Dan claimed one fisherman who drowned when his boat capsized.
Three others aboard the fishing vessel were rescued, according to the report, which said that the typhoon cut off the power supply to more than 5,000 Penghu households.
Typhoon Dan claimed nine lives and left more than 400 injured in Fujian, mainland China, which took a direct hit from the storm.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING TO CONTINUE ISOLATING ROC, TAIPEI DOCUMENTS SAY

TEXT.P: Internal documents of Taipei's Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) indicated that mainland China will continue to contain and isolate Taiwan in the international community.
According to the documents, Beijing's current Taiwan policy was worked out in the second half of last year.
Under that policy, Beijing would take a "soft" posture on some cross-Taiwan Strait matters, while intensifying containment of Taiwan in international affairs.
Owing to the "soft" posture, the documents said, Chairman Koo Chen-fu of Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation was invited to visit Shanghai and Beijing last fall.
But at the same time, Beijing stepped up its efforts to isolate Taiwan, and that was why the Kingdom of Tonga switched its diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing.

The OCAC said that mainland China will continue to create a false image in the international community that the Taiwan issue is China's internal affairs with an aim to prevent intervention by foreign countries.
The documents noted that Beijing is expected to continue promoting the so-called "reconciliation diplomacy" and "big-country diplomacy," to set up "strategic partnership" with major countries.

They indicated that mainland China's intention is to try to deny the fact that Taiwan and the mainland are equal political entities, so as to place the Taiwan issue under the Beijing-fixed frame and to force Taiwan to engage in "political negotiation" with Beijing. (By Victor Lai)

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC'S CURRENT ACCOUNT SURPLUS TO TOP US$ 10 BILLION THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: Taipei, Oct. 10 (CNA): Generated by the steady growth of exports, the current account surplus of the Republic of China will break the US$10 billio mark again in this year and the nation's international balance of payments will also set new record in 17 years, an official of the Central Bank of China said on Sunday.

According to CBC statistics, the current account surplus amounted to US$7.5 billion in the year's first three quarters, more than doubling that of the whole year of 1998. This indicated that the nation's economic situation was recovering from the recession.

The nation's balance of payments netted US$10,347 million surplus in the first half year. The nation was expected to post a record surplus of the balance of payments this year surpassing the US$28,093 million registered in 1988.
The same CBC statistics show that the balance of payment had netted US$4,887 million and US$5,465 million in surplus in the year's first and second quarters, respectively.

Meanwhile, according to statistics compiled by the Customs Office, the trade surplus in the first nine months of this year had accumulated to US$8,660 million, an increase of US$4,030 million as compared with the like period of a year ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE RESCUE SQUAD RETURNS HOME

TEXT.P: A 40-member rescue squad from Singapore, that came to Taiwan to join rescue mission immediately after the Sept. 21 devastating Chichi earthquake, returned to Singapore on Sunday.
The squad flew to Taipei on the night of Sept. 21 with 14 metric tons of rescue equipment, and moved to Taichung County shortly after their arrival.
It was among the first foreign rescue teams to arrive in Taiwan, and was the last to leave.

The Singaporeans focused their operations at the collapsed Yungchao Building and Golden Paris Building located in Fengyuan City and Tali City respectively. They rescued two survivors, and helped dig out scores of bodies.
Their well-trained rescue operations were highly appraised by Taichung County's Fire-Fighting Bureau, the Interior Ministry's Fire-Fighting Agency, and related civil rescue groups.

A total of 38 foreign rescue teams, with over 700 members, had come to Taiwan for the rescue mission. At the request of local fire-fighting authorities to provide assistance in case of emergency, the Singapore squad extended its stay until Sunday.

In order to let local fire-fighters learn more practical rescue skills, the Fire-Fighting Agency organized a two-day seminar in Taichung during the weekend for the Singaporeans to report their experiences and demonstrate their skills. More than 100 people attended the seminar.
The Sept. 21 pre-dawn quake, measuring 7.3 on the Richter scale and the strongest temblor to hit the island in nearly 100 years, killed more than 2,200 people.
Republic of China Presdient Lee Teng-hui on Saturday expressed his most sincere appreciation to the foreign rescue missions that rushed to Taiwan immediately after the quake.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS GROUP SENDS OPEN LETTER TO BEIJING, TAIPEI, HK

TEXT.P: The Hong Kong and Kowloon Trades Union Council Sunday issued an open letter to the government leaders in Beijing, Taipei, and Hong Kong.

The council said in the letter that Beijing leaders should recognize that Taiwan and mainland China are being ruled by two separate political entities, because Taiwan is in fact ruled by the government of the Republic of China, which was founded in 1912; while the mainland is ruled by the government of People's Republic of China, which was established in 1949.

The letter, issued on the "Double Tenth" National Day of the Republic of China, said that since most Taiwan people detest the "one Country, two systems" formula proposed by Beijing, other unification formulas should be studied in order to facilitate the development of the Chinese nation.

The council also said that mainland China should not threaten Taiwan with military force. The biggest obstacle to their unification lies in the difference in their systems and ways of life, which can not be resolved by military force, it pointed out.

The council expressed the hope that Taiwan will continue to implement its "Guidelines for National Unification" after the Presidential election is held in March, and that Taiwan's major opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will give up its pro-independence party platform.

The council also urged the government of Hong Kong to set up a "representative office" in Taipei and maintain friendly relations with Taiwan. The government should allow the people to fly the national flag of the Republic of China in public places on the "Double Tenth" national day as they did before Hong Kong's handover to Beijing on July 1, 1997, it added.

Meanwhile, Lee Kwok Leung, president of the council, said he was appalled that Hong Kong police removed a national flag of the Republic of China from a public place Sunday morning. Some Hong Kong people have a passion for the flag of nationalist China, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Monday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The government may offer public land for people along fault lines to rebuild their homes.
The China Times:
The government will help resolve land acquisition problems for quake-affected people.
The United Daily News:
The government considers bartering public land lots for private lands in the fault line areas to prevent quake damage.
The Liberty Times:
Geological surveys must be conducted before building houses or bridges.
The Commons Daily:
A large memorial service will be held Monday for 921 quake victims.
The China Post:
The ROC's National Day passes quietly.
The Taiwan News:
An unusual mood for National Day.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOBEL LAUREATE TO LEAD ACADEMICIANS TO EARTHQUAKE-STRICKEN AREAS

TEXT.P: Nobel laureate and Academia Sinica President Yuan T. Lee will lead a group of academicians to earthquake-stricken areas in central Taiwan to collect on-the-spot post-disaster data and to understand the plight of victims.

Lee will lead the heads of 15 institutes of Academia Sinica, the top research institution in the Republic of China, to the earthquake affected areas next week to see how and what the academia sector can do to facilitate reconstruction and rehabilitation, Academia Sinica sources said on Monday.

The magnitude 7.3 earthquake that struck central Taiwan on Sept. 21 killed at least 2,200 people, injured 8,700 and left over 100,00 others homeless. The jolt, the deadliest to hit Taiwan this century, also shifted geological structures and ravaged major attractions in the scenic central part of Taiwan.

Lee and his group, expected to visit the hardest hit areas, including Tungshih, Puli, Wufeng and Chichi, will also meet the local people there to find out exactly what they want from the government and society to help them rebuild their homes, the sources said.
Lee, 63, Nobel Prize winner in chemistry in 1986, was elected to the Academia Sinica in 1980 as a member and was appointed head of the top research institution by President Lee Teng-hui in 1994.
