DOC.HEADLINE: QUAKE CHANGES THE FACE OF 0.26 PERCENT OF TAIWAN'S LAND

TEXT.P: Roughly 7,285 hectares of land, or 0.26 percent of Taiwan's territory, was affected by the killer quake of Sept. 21 which left 2,200 people dead and 8,700 injured, sources from the Council of Agriculture (COA) reported on Monday.

Surveying the land with satellite photography, specialists from the COA's Water and Land Conservation Bureau found that in the scenic mountainous region of central Taiwan, peaks were toppled, rivers were blocked by shifting land and roads and playgrounds were raised into hills or terraced fields.

Topping the geological facelift list was the Chiuchiufeng (99 Peaks) mountain range in Nantou County, where 5,900 hectares of land crumbled. In Yunlin County, the Chingshuichi (Clear Water Brook) was blocked by slided land triggered by mountain runs, making it a land-locked lake.

In addition to the lost lands, 1,807 other locations in Taichung, Nantou, Yunlin and Chiayi counties were reported to have experienced shifts in position or changes in topography, according to COA officials.
The COA estimated that at least NT$6 billion (US$188.68 million) will be needed to restore the land, manage the land mass and correct the sabotaged landscape in the earthquake-stricken areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, MAINLAND CHINA PERMITTED TO ATTEND WTO SEATTLE TALKS
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Oct. 10 (CNA) (By Tzou Ming-jhie and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and mainland China will be permitted to attend the ministerial level meeting of the World Trade Organization (WTO) slated to be held in Seattle from late November through early December, Le Figaro newspaper said Sunday.

Le Figaro quoted officials of the Geneva-based WTO as reporting that those countries or customs territories that have entered the final stage of talks on WTO entry, can send representatives to attend the meeting without waiting until joining the WTO and are invited to attend the new round of talks on trade liberalization.
At present, 31 countries or customs territories, including Taiwan and mainland China, have entered the final stage of talks on WTO entry and have become quasi-members of the WTO.

Trilateral talks among mainland China, the United States and the European Union (EU) on mainland China's WTO entry have dragged on for 14 years without any significant breakthroughs mainly because Beijing cannot propose a plan on tariff concessions and the opening of its market that is in accordance with world trade norms.
Beijing has completed bilateral talks with Japan and reached a trade agreement with Japan. Its talks with the US and the EU are still under way.

It was reported that the new EU commissioner responsible for foreign relations will meet with mainland Chinese representatives next week in Berlin to start crucial talks on mainland China's WTO entry. It is expected that the EU will loosen its standards in the hope of letting mainland China enter the world trade regulatory body as soon as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: WOMEN SEEN MORE LIKELY TO BE DEPRESSED

TEXT.P: Women are nearly twice as likely as men to suffer anxiety and depression because of a genetic predisposition to these conditions, according to an Australian mental health expert.

Professor Gavin Andrews of St. Vincent's Hospital in Sydney told reporters that of the 2.4 million people with one or more mental illnesses in Australia, the number of women was higher than men, with women dominating anxiety and depression related disorders categories by almost two to one.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE MONARCHISTS SUPPORT DIRECT PRESIDENTIAL ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Australian monarchists, seeing slim chances for the success of their cause, are no longer defending the UK queen as head of state and are instead emphasizing direct popular presidential elections if Australians vote to become a republic in the November 6 referendum.
The Australian Election Commission has sent out an official referendum pamphlet explaining to Australians the "yes or no" vote in deciding the future status of their country
Voting for the November 6 referendum is compulsory in Australia.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN-LED UN TROOPS EXPECT ESCALATION IN CONFLICT

TEXT.P: The UN peacekeeping troops, continuing their push toward the border of West Timor, are expecting an escalation in the conflict with pro-Indonesian militias, according to local news reports.

Australia's Channel Nine TV Network on Monday morning reported that UN troops were attacked by 12 to 15 militiamen during their push toward the border. They killed one militiaman and wounded two others in separate clashes over the weekend. (BY Peter Chen)

DOC.HEADLINE: REP. CAMPBELL OPPOSES MAINLAND CHINA'S MEMBERSHIP IN WTO

TEXT.P: In the midst of the heated debate over Mainland China's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO), US Republican Congressman Tom Campbell expressed strong opposition to China's admittance, saying that it would have a negative impact on America's industry and global competitiveness, and would ultimately hurt the American consumer.
In contrast, Campbell highly recommended Taiwan's membership in WTO, citing Taiwan's free-market economy and transparent economic institutions.
In his commentary published in the San Jose Mercury on Sunday, Campbell said the question of allowing mainland China and Taiwan into the WTO should be decided on economic merits.

Pointing to the example of WTO member Hong Kong, which is now part of China, Campbell said that customs regions, not necessarily countries, are admitted into WTO. So it is "entirely appropriate" that Taiwan be admitted based on economic merits, without thereby reaching any conclusion that Taiwan is a separate nation.

Campbell stressed that his observation that China's economy still does not qualify for the WTO is a "dispassionate judgment," made without regard to any animosity toward communism or to human rights conditions in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Oct. 11, or the third day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1727: George II, King of Great Britain and Ireland and elector of Hanover, is crowned in London. His 1743 victory at the Battle of Dettingen was the last time that a British monarch led his troops in the field.
1821: Sir George Williams, English social reformer who founded the Young Men's Christian Association (YMCA), one of the largest nonprofit voluntary organizations in the world, is born.
1834: Sir William Napier, Britain's Chief Superintendent of Trade in China, dies in Macao at the age of 48. He had recently returned from Canton after a disastrous attempt to persuade the imperial government of China to trade directly with Britain rather than through the Hong merchants.
1871: The Great Fire of Chicago is finally extinguished. About 300 people are estimated to have lost their lives, and a further 90,000 their homes. In all, four square miles of the city had been destroyed, including the business sector, at a cost of US$200 million.
1896: Dr. Sun Yat-sen is enticed into and placed in confinement at the Ching embassy in London. He was later rescued by his British friends.
1900: Winston Churchill, British politician and writer, is elected a member of the House of Commons to begin his long political career. As prime minister, he led Great Britain through World War II. He published several works, including "The Second World War" and won the 1953 Nobel Prize for Literature.
1939: US scientists, including Albert Einstein, outline to President Franklin Roosevelt the possibility of developing an atomic bomb.
1945: A joint declaration announces that an agreement between the government and the Chinese communists had been reached after six weeks of negotiation and that unsolved problems were to be settled by a political consultative conference.
1946: ROC government troops capture Kalgan (Changchiakow) in Inner Mongolia from the Chinese communists.
1957: The world's largest steerable radio-telescope goes into operation at the Jodrell Observatory of the British University of Manchester. The instrument has an 81-meter diameter parabolic bowl mounted on a trunnion 58 meters above ground level.
1968: Apollo 7 is launched, carrying US astronauts Walter Schirra, Don Eiselle and Walter Cunningham.
1972: West Germany establishes diplomatic ties with communist China.
1976: Qiang Qing, the third wife and widow of Mao Tse-tung, is arrested with three associates. The so-called "Gang of Four" are charged with plotting a coup to seize power after Mao's death.
1977: President Colonel Ibrahim al-Hamdi of North Yemen is assassinated during a military coup.
1979: Fidel Castro, who became the head of the Cuban government in 1959 after he and his supporters overthrew the dictatorship of Fulgencio Batista, arrive in the United States for a visit.
1980: Strong earthquake rocks the city of El Asnam in northern Algeria, killing some 20,000 people.
1980: Soviet cosmonauts return to Earth after a record 185 days in space in the Salyut 6 spacecraft.
1986: A National Development Exhibition in celebration of the centennial of late President Chiang Kai-shek's birthday is opened at the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall in Taipei.
1986: US President Ronald Reagan and Soviet Communist Party General Secretary Mikhail Gorbachev hold a summit meeting at Reykjavik in the Republic of Iceland.
1986: A display of ROC military power in the "Kuo-kuang Maneuvers" is held at the Hukou Army Base in Hsinchu.
1990: The Ministry of the Interior reiterates that the Tiaoyutai island group belongs to the Republic of China. The chain of eight uninhibited islets, located in the East China Sea, also is claimed by Japan and communist China.
1990: Some 150,000 people packed the May 1 Stadium in Pyongyang to see North Korea defeat South Korea 2-1 in a historic soccer match, the first sports competition between halves of the divided nation on home soil.
1991: Direct air service begins between Australia and the Republic of China.
1992: President Lee Teng-hui and Panamanian President Guillermo Endara sign a joint communique to expand bilateral cooperation.
1997: Leaders of some 40 nations end a rare Council of Europe summit with pledges regarding human rights and human cloning.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE THAN 100 BUILDERS ARRESTED OR UNDER INVESTIGATION

TEXT.P: A total of 108 builders and architects have been arrested or are under investigation on charges of murder or endangering public safety since the devastating magnitude 7.3 earthquake struck Taiwan on Sept. 21.

Islandwide, 12 people in the construction and real estate business were arrested, 40 were released on bail and 56 others were restricted from leaving the country in the wake of the deadly quake, which wreaked havoc on central Taiwan and caused immeasurable damage to property, including buildings and houses.
Personal or company assets of 69 individuals or firms among the accused were declared temporarily frozen by law enforcement officials, sources within the Ministry of Justice reported on Monday.

Following the quake and its powerful aftershocks, investigators in Yunlin County discovered that three crumbled buildings had been built by a construction company that had used empty plastic and tin oil containers as filler to save on concrete and bricks.

In the hardest hit townships in central Taiwan, as well as in Taipei City and Taipei County in the north, where the Sept. 21 quake registered at magnitude 4, poor construction caused relatively new buildings to tip over despite the strict anti-seismic provisions that were added to the national building code in 1972.

An 11-story building in Tahli that was uprooted and fell backward and a 12-story apartment building in Fengyuan that peeled off from an adjoining tower and landed on its side were among the damage alleged to have occurred because of poor construction.

"If you have 51 fault lines running across your country, you need to be more careful about building," said Hideo Ishikawa, a civil engineer from Osaka who came to Taiwan to pitch in with assistance after the quake.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES, INDEX FUTURES BOTH RISE

TEXT.P: Strong buying on electronics issues prompted the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) to rally Monday, with the weighted price index, the market's key barometer, gaining 54.13 points to close at 7,607.11.
A total of 1.60 billion shares changed hands on a turnover of NT$61.08 billion (US$1.92 billion).
The electronics sector posted the largest gain of 1.5 percent, followed by the plastics and chemical sector, up 0.5 percent, and the financial sector, up 0.2 percent.

Those registering losses were cement stocks, down 2 percent; foodstuff stocks, down 1 percent; construction shares, down 0.9 percent; textile shares, down 0.2 percent; and pulp and paper shares, down 0.2 percent.
Decliners outnumbered advancers 239 to 215, with 69 shares unchanged.
The over-the-counter market was down 1.28 points to close at 168.32 on a turnover of NT$3.60 billion.

TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for October rose 66 points to close at 7,586 with 1,242 contract transactions; those for November gained 60 points to finish at 7,580 with 135 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for December were up 50 points to close at 7,590 with one contract transaction, while those for next March remained unchanged at 7,586 with one contract transaction; next June futures climbed 79 points to close at 7,665 with three contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Monday were 7,520 points for October, 7,520 points for November, 7,540 points for December, 7,586 points for next March, and 7,586 points for next June.
Electronics futures and financial futures, which are sub-index futures and based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares (TE) and financial shares (TF), both posted gains.
October TE futures were up 5.7 points to close at 354.5 with 312 contract transactions; November TE futures rose 6.2 points to end at 355 with 13 contract transactions.
There were no transaction records for December TE futures, next March futures or next June TE futures.

October TF futures gained eight points to close at 960 with 55 contract transactions, November TF futures rose 10.8 points to close at 962.8 with two contract transactions; TF futures for other months had no transaction records.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS CHINESE MARK ROC'S NATIONAL DAY TO SHOW PATRIOTISM
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 10 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Chinese communities in the United States marked the Republic of China's Double Ten National Day on Sunday with a solemn mood as Taiwan is still struggling to overcome last month's devastating earthquake.

While festivities were canceled or toned down, Chinese residents in major US cities held sunrise flag-raising ceremonies, bazaars and fund-raising lunches or dinners to celebrate the ROC's 88th National Day.

In Washington, D.C., all overseas Chinese associations in the US capital held a joint evening party to mark the Double Ten National Day and raise funds for post-earthquake relief and reconstruction projects in Taiwan.

Speaking on the occasion, ROC Representative to the United States Stephen Chen said donations for helping Taiwan's quake-affected people had exceeded US$850,000 as of Oct. 9 in the great Washington area alone.

Meanwhile, Chen said, the Washington-based World Vision has raised an additional US$1 million in relief funds. On behalf of the ROC government and people, Chen expressed gratitude and respect for generous donations from overseas Chinese and American friends.

Noting that the ROC government has worked out a detailed blueprint for rebuilding damaged infrastructure and helping quake-affected people rebuild their shattered lives and homes, Chen said Taiwan will overcome sorrow and pain and will create an even brighter future.

American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Richard Bush also attended the evening party. Bush said Dr. Sun Yat-sen, the ROC's national founding father, established Asia's first republic 88 years ago. At that time, Bush said, the world expected to see democracy take roots in China. "Today, democratic rule at least has been realized in Taiwan."

Recalling that overseas Chinese gave enormous support for Dr. Sun's drive to overthrow the corrupt Ching dynasty, Bush said he believes that overseas Chinese will again pool their wisdom and resources to help the ROC on Taiwan weather hardships and difficulties caused by the recent calamity.

In the San Francisco and Bay areas, sunrise flag-raising ceremonies were held in Chinatown and on the square in front of the Santa Clara City Hall, attracting the participation of more than 1,000 people.

Victor C. Y. Tseng, head of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in San Francisco, who attended both events, said the flag-raising ceremonies symbolize overseas Chinese people's unswerving support for the ROC and their concern for Taiwan's earthquake victims.
Some 30 other traditional National Day celebration activities in the Bay area, including a float parade and a cocktail reception, were all called off in deference to Taiwan's quake victims.
Ethnic Chinese residents in the Bay area has so far donated a total of US$7.39 million for post-quake relief and reconstruction programs in hardest-stricken central Taiwan.

In New York, more than 2,000 Chinese residents turned out for a colorful parade in Chinatown to mark the ROC's National Day. Chinese community leaders said they want to express their loyalty and support for the ROC with the traditional festive activity.

"The event was also aimed at inspiring people in Taiwan to shed the shadow of the 921 killer earthquake as soon as possible and to rebuild their homeland with confidence and courage," said an organizer of the parade.
In the evening, all overseas Chinese associations jointly sponsored a dinner to raise funds for post-quake reconstruction projects in Taiwan.

Charles Teng, head of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New York, attended various National Day celebration activities in Chinatown to express his admiration and gratitude for overseas Chinese people's patriotism and support for Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESSES ENLIST FOREIGN COMPANIES' HELP TO CLARIFY QUAKE SITUATION

TEXT.P: The leader of a business association said on Monday that the group is contacting foreign enterprises in Taiwan to explain the island's post-quake situation to the world.

Chen Fei-lung, chairman of Namchow Chemical, said that since the massive quake on Sept. 21, which has to date claimed more than 2,300 lives and has resulted in extensive losses, local businesses have seen a number of orders lost to other countries, and the number of tourists has declined sharply.

Chen said the association has taken the initiative to contact foreign enterprises, hoping those companies will use the Internet to tell the world that the hardest-hit areas are in the agricultural counties and cities in central Taiwan, such as Nantou, Taichung and Changhua, and that the manufacturing and tourism industries have not been affected.
Chen and other business leaders toured the hardest-hit areas over the weekend and decided to give long-term support to those areas.

Business leaders from Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. (TSMC), Chung Hwa Telecommunications Co., China Steel Corp. and other enterprises toured the affected areas on Saturday and Sunday to see if those enterprises could do anything to assist reconstruction efforts.

They visited areas where the devastating Sept. 21 earthquake struck hardest: Chichi, Shueili, Sun Moon Lake and Puli in Nantou County; and Fengyuan, Shihkang and Tungshih in Taichung County. Though they did not witness the shocking scenes that immediately followed the magnitude-7.3 quake, they understood the destructive power of the killer jolt after observing heavy machinery being used to demolish badly damaged houses.

Lin Wen-kuei, president of Feng Hsin Iron & Steel Co. and a member of the group, said he was shocked to see that a row of houses had simply "kneeled down," with the first floor slumped to the ground because of collapsed beams.

Chen fei-lung said that after viewing the quake-stricken areas, the group's members have decided to form a permanent association, adding that all of them will volunteer in reconstruction efforts and will use their expertise to provide ongoing support.
Chen expressed the hope that more business leaders will join the association.

Kuan Yung-shih, chairman of China Petrochemical Development Corp., said the members do not believe they have fulfilled their responsibility simply because they donated money to quake-stricken areas. He urged more business groups to get organized and provide much-needed assistance to the quake-stricken areas.

Central and local government officials have expressed the hope that business leaders, with extensive resources at their disposal, would serve as foster-patrons for affected areas, either by providing employment opportunities for residents or, better still, by setting up factories there.

But business leaders countered that this is not the answer to the problem; they said reconstruction work should not be conducted rashly, and that it will require overall planning by the government and professionals.

Jack Sun, chairman of Taiwan Cellular Corp., echoed the idea, saying that the government should set up a long-term body to direct reconstruction and the private sector would rally behind the government to contribute money and resources.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar closed higher against the greenback on the Taipei market on Monday, rising 0.006 to 31.772.
The currenccy opened at the day's low of 31.774 and experienced a high of 31.766. Interbank US dollar trading reached US$174.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALTERNATIVE MILITARY SERVICEMEN TO ASSIST WITH RECONSTRUCTION FIRST

TEXT.P: The proposed alternative military service will start July 1 next year, with a term of two years, according to a decision made Monday by a committee under the Executive Yuan.

Vice Premier Liu Chao-shiuan, presiding over the committee meeting, said that after the launch of alternative military service, the top priority will be for alternative military servicemen to pitch in with quake-related reconstruction work.
Liu said that getting more people to take part in the reconstruction effort is paramount.

Alternative military service has been in the works for some time, a measure considered by the Ministry of National Defense to alleviate the oversupply of conscripts in the military, which has resulted in some draftees having to wait a long time before serving in the army.
Those who choose alternative service over the traditional two-year military service will be assigned to firefighting, police or other social work.

DOC.HEADLINE: RUSSIAN AIRLINE TO INAUGURATE MOSCOW-MACAU-TAIPEI SERVICE
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Oct. 11 (CNA) (By Chou Chia-hung & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Domodedovo Airlines of Russia will begin service between Moscow and Taipei via Macao on Oct. 15, according to the English-language publication Macau Travel Talk.
The airline will use a 252-seat IL-96-300 wide-body passenger jet to serve the new route once a week.

The report said the plane will leave Domodedovo Airport, about 40 kilometers southeast of Moscow, at 4:30 p.m. on Fridays, reaching Macao in the early morning hours on Saturdays and then proceeding to Taipei the same day.
Domodedovo Airlines has a fleet of 25 passenger jets to fly routes connecting Moscow with Far Eastern and Central Asian cities, the publication said.
It also operates charter flights to Europe and mainland China.
Macao and Russia signed an aviation agreement last January to pave the way for the new service.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSAO CHIN-HUI JOINS COLORADO ROCKIES BASEBALL TEAM

TEXT.P: Tsao Chin-hui, ace pitcher from Kaoyuan Commerce and Industry School in Kaohsiung, formally joined the Colorado Rockies baseball team on Monday.
In a brief ceremony held at a Taipei hotel, Charles Monfort, president of the US team, personally put the team's uniform shirt on Tsao in a gesture of welcome.

Monfort said that players from the Dominican Republic account for 20 percent of baseball players in the US professional leagues. He hoped that more Taiwanese players would follow Tsao in joining the National League West.
Tsao is the second Taiwanese player to join a U.S. professional baseball league in the last ten years.
Tsao will formally sign his contract with the Rockies after arriving in the United States.
The Rockies, formed seven years ago, managed to lead the National League in hitting at 0.279 and broke 69-year-old NL records for total bases (2,696) and extra-base hits (567).

Monfort said in a press conference, held in conjunction with the ceremony, that he has confidence in Tsao. He believed that Tsao would be able to adapt to the Colorado climate. The Rockies' Coors Field is situated at a high altitude, where the air is thin compared that of lower elevations.
Yu Cheng-hsian, magistrate of Kaohsiung County, described Monday as a historic day for Tsao and hoped he would take his place on the pitching mound as soon as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: 70% OF VICTIMS NOT CLEAR ON GOV'T RESETTLEMENT PLAN: POLL

TEXT.P: A survey conducted by TVBS showed about 70 percent of earthquake victims do not clearly understand government resettlement measures, while nearly half have not yet received any relief aid subsidies for collapsed houses.
TVBS, a popular television station in Taiwan, conducted the poll last Saturday. The survey was answered by 733 people, all from the island's hardest-hit counties of Nantou and Taichung.

The questionnaire covered issues concerning: assessment of building damages and reconstruction, cash received as relief aid, victims' fears and confidence in future life, government quake-relief performance and policy, and the upcoming presidential election.

Although the government has come up with a series of resettlement measures, only 33 percent of those polled said they were clear about the government plan, while 52 percent indicated they were not quite clear, and 14 percent did not even know there were any resettlement measures offered by the government.

Regarding provisional housing for temblor victims, three options were offered by the government: a rent subsidy of NT$3,000 per victim per month, which may be drawn in a 12-month lump sum; residence in provisional or prefabricated houses; or residence in public apartments built by local governments or in military barracks.

About 56 percent of those polled noted that they would select the rent subsidy relief measure, 23 percent would like to take up residence in the provisional or prefabricated houses, and 10 percent would choose to reside in public apartments or military barracks, according to the survey.
As for the reconstruction issue, 51 percent hope to have houses planned and rebuilt by experts, while 38 percent would choose to rebuild by themselves on the original sites.
Three weeks after Taiwan's most devastating quake in a century, which struck the island on Sept. 21, the sorest need of victims now is cash, said the survey.

Excluding funds allocated for casualties as condolence money, which has been paid already, 47 percent of victims whose houses collapsed or partially collapsed have not yet received relief aid to rebuild, the survey showed.

About 70 percent of victims do not want to leave the township or village where their original residences were located, while 26 percent would choose to leave those places that are full of sorrow and consternation, the survey also showed.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL MEMORIAL SERVICE HELD FOR '921 EARTHQUAKE' VICTIMS

TEXT.P: Some 7,000 people gathered at a stadium in Linkou on the outskirts of Taipei on Monday to mourn the victims of a devastating earthquake that rattled central Taiwan on Sept. 21.

The memorial service, organized by the Ministry of the Interior, began with an elegy sung by local soprano Chien Wen-hsiu. All participants then observed a moment of silence to commemorate those killed.
President Lee Teng-hui laid a wreath before a 12-meter-high temporary monument, which was situated on a stage with dim blue lighting, in memory of those who died, and then he bowed three times.
In a brief speech to the audience, President Lee said that in the earthquake, many people lost their homes, dearest family members and friends.

"The 921 Earthquake caused losses that will be difficult to recover from, and it left a wound in the hearts of all citizens that can never be healed," Lee said, adding that his heart is filled with profound sadness.
Citing remarks by a noted Buddhist master, Lee said: "The quake victims are all Buddhas and teachers. They died for the other 22 million residents on the island and they saved our next generations."

The president ended his speech on a hopeful note, saying: "As long as there is life, there is hope. I hope that during our suffering we don't lose confidence, and that when we face obstacles we become more courageous."

Lee further said he hopes the prayers and introspection can help the victims rest in peace and that those who lost their loved ones can transform their sadness to strength and love for their homeland.
The president also encouraged all fellow citizens to work together and join hands to build an even brighter tomorrow for future generations.
Following Lee's speech, Vice President Lien Chan took the podium and read a message commemorating the quake victims.

Lien said the 921 Earthquake was an unforgettable tragedy, which claimed 2,321 lives. "In the massive quake, we lost our loved ones. ... Although we can't see you, we feel your presence, your eternal presence."

Noting that the nation wants to bid farewell to the quake victims through the memorial service, Lien said Taiwan will achieve rebirth through rebuilding. "We'll rebuild our homeland with strength and love. This is our common promise."
In the memorial service, many senior government officials, academics, religious leaders, business executives and representatives from all walks of life paid tribute to the quake victims.

The memorial service helped bring a sense of closure for quake survivors, an interior ministry official said, adding that it let those who lost family members and friends know that the nation mourns with them.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CARRIERS COMPETITIVE IN WORLD AIR CARGO MARKET

TEXT.P: Taiwan's two largest carriers -- China Airlines (CAL) and EVA Airways -- are competitive in the world air cargo market, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) said on Monday.

Quoting statistics released by a world air freight transport magazine, the MOTC said CAL ranked 12th among the world's 492 major airline companies in terms of its 1998 freight tonne-kilometers, which equals the sum of products obtained by multiplying the number of tonnes of freight carried on each flight stage by the stage distance.

Meanwhile, EVA ranked 14th in the same world rating. MOTC officials the combined freight tonne-kilometers (FTK) of the two Taiwan carriers in 1998 even exceeded the total transport volume of mainland China's eight largest air companies. "This indicates that our carriers remain highly competitive in the world air freight market," said an MOTC official.
A total of 73 airlines in the Asia-Pacific region were included in the magazine's 1998 global passenger and cargo business ratings.
In the passenger services, no Taiwan airline managed to make the world's top 25 list. Nevertheless, Taiwan carriers' business records remained good in comparison with other Asia-Pacific airlines.
In 1998, All Nippon Air (ANA) and Qantas Airways topped all other Asia-Pacific carriers in terms of the size of their fleets, with each having 143 passenger planes.

Taiwan's China Airlines ranked 13th, with 57 planes; UNI Airlines ranked 22nd with 37 planes; and EVA ranked 24th with 32 planes. Compared with their 1997 fleets, CAL increased eight planes and EVA acquired three additional aircarft.
In terms of the number of passengers, ANA still ranked top by carrying a total of 41.49 million passengers in 1998; followed by Japan Airlines with 31.36 million.

CAL ranked 13th among Asia-Pacific airlines by carrying 7.32 million passengers last year; Far Eastern Air Transport Co. ranked 19th, with 5.08 million passengers; EVA ranked 25th, with 3.66 million; and UNI Airlines ranked 26th, with 3.33 million. Compared with their 1997 records, UNI registered the largest trowth rate of 49.4 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BASKETBALL STAR TO JOIN MAINLAND TEAM

TEXT.P: Taiwan professional basketball star Chen Chih-long announced Monday that he will join the Oriental Sharks of the mainland Chinese professional baseball league in November so he can play through Taiwan's off-season, which may be extra-long this year.
Considering his career as a professional basketball player and the needs of his family, he has made the decision to play in the mainland, said the popular player during a press conference in Taipei.
He feels deep gratitude to his Taiwanese fans who cheered for him in numerous games on the island over the past years, Chen said.
Chen hosted the press conference in the company of his wife and a friend, Chiang Feng-nien, who played the role of intermediary in leading the 30-year-old player to the Oriental Sharks of Shanghai.

Chen said his contract with the Hungkuo team, one of the six teams in Taiwan's professional basketball league, expired Aug. 31. As a basketball player, he will "go where there are games," the freelancer said.
He believes that there is ample room in mainland China for him to practice his "Taiwan skill," the Taiwanese basketball great noted.

Chen added he is scheduled to fly to Shanghai next Tuesday, where he will join Oriental Shark players for a practice program and physical capability testing in Beijing. Not until then, Chen said, will he sign the contract.
Chen said he is looking forward playing in the mainland's next season, which starts Nov. 21 and ends in mid-March, and expects he will join Taiwan's National Games in December 2000.
If Taiwan's professional basketball games resume next year, he will return, but only after completing his mainland contract, Chen added.
Asked whether or not he will rejoin the Hungkuo, the sports star said he was still uncertain about that, but reaffirmed he will always return to Taiwan if there are games here for him to play.
Chen's wife, Lu Chu-ying, stressed that Chen's future job in the mainland is nothing but part-time, and she, along with their two sons, will remain in Taiwan while her husband works in Shanghai.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI RESIDENTS CAN APPLY FOR FREE E-MAILBOXES FROM MONDAY

TEXT.P: Residents of Taipei City can apply for electronic mailboxes provided free of charge through the Taipei City government starting Monday, said Mayor Ma Ying-jeou.
Ma, on behalf of the municipal government, and China Telecommunications Corp. signed an agreement Monday on the formation of an e-mailbox service for Taipei residents.
Ma said from Monday, e-mailboxes will become more popular among citizens in Taipei.
People who intend to apply for free e-mailboxes may do so through the website found at www.tpemail.net.tw.

Ma said Taiwan has an on-line population of four million, adding that as the island's major metropolis, Taipei City cannot lag behind other Taiwan cities in development of information technology. It is an important milestone for Taipei City to take this stride to become a new network city, Ma said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO PERCEPTIBLE EARTHQUAKES SHAKE TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A modest earthquake of magnitude 4.4 on the open-ended Richter scale shook Taiwan on Monday, reported the Seismology Center of Taiwan.

The perceptible tremor occurred at 5:12 p.m., with the quake's epicenter 27.8 kilometers northeast of Sun Moon Lake in Nantou County, and its focus, or underground center, 17.7 kilometers below the earth's surface, according to seismologists.

Nantou County was also the epicenter of the devastating magnitude-7.3 temblor that occurred in the early morning hours of Sept. 21, claiming more than 2,200 lives around the island, and leaving more than 8,700 injured and even more homeless.
On Monday, in addition to the magnitude-4.4 earthquake, there was another temblor in Hualien, eastern Taiwan, which registered a magnitude of 4.5 on the Richter scale, the Seismology Center said.
The jolt occurred at around 12:00 p.m.; the quake's epicenter was 32 kilometers west of Hualien, with an underground center at a depth of nine kilometers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSE TRANSACTION VALUE IN AUG. RANKED FIFTH WORLDWIDE

TEXT.P: Taiwan Stock Exchange (TSE) transactions in August totaled US$87.3 billion to occupy fifth place worldwide, ranking only behind New York, London, Tokyo and Germany.
According to statistics compiled by the TSE, the bourse's turnover rate was 26.17 percent, representing second place worldwide, led only by South Korea.

The TSE statistics also show that the August transaction values of the world's top five stock exchanges were as follows: New York (US$678.3 billion), London (US$224 billion), Tokyo (US$139.5 billion), Germany (US$104 billion) and Taiwan (US$87.3 billion).
As for the turnover rate, South Korea ranked first with 31.06 percent, followed by Taiwan's 26.17 percent. Other nations' rates were all below eight percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHI-NAN UNIVERSITY STUDENTS RESUME STUDIES AT NTU

TEXT.P: Some students of the Puli-based National Chi-Nan University in Nantou County on Monday resumed their studies on the campus of the National Taiwan University (NTU).

Chi-Nan University President Lee Chia-tung on Monday delivered a letter to the students, whose education had been disrupted by the "921 Earthquake," encouraging them in their studies in temporary classrooms in Taipei.

Lee also extended certificates of appreciation to a number of official and private groups, including the Taipei City government and the Ministry of Education, which have assisted his university's efforts to reopen classes after the devastating temblor severely damaged Chi-Nan classroom buildings on Sept. 21.
Puli was the epicenter of the quake, which killed more than 2,200 people around the island, and injured more than 8,700 others. The town was almost entirely leveled by the massive temblor.

Other Chi-Nan students will be able to resume their studies thanks to accommodation by the National Chiao Tung University in Hsinchu, central Taiwan, and the National Sun Yat-sen University in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan.
Lee said he expected all students would be able to return to their home campus on Feb. 20, 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TAX REVENUE IN SEPT. DOWN 8.8 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's tax revenues in September totaled NT$116.5 billion, down NT$11.2 billion, or 8.8 percent, from the same period last year, according to statistics released by the Finance Ministry on Monday.
The devastating Chichi earthquake that rocked the island on Sept. 21 was blamed for the decline in the month's tax revenues.
Of the tax income in September, business taxes accounted for NT$40.8 billion (down NT$7.5 billion), and income taxes accounted for NT$32.7 billion (down NT$4.1 billion).
Revenue from securities trading amounted to NT$7.06 billion, up NT$500 million.
Accumulated tax revenue for the first half of fiscal 1999 (April-September) was tallied at NT$338.6 billion, up NT$3.6 billion, or 1.1 percent, over the same period of last fiscal year.

DOC.TEXT:

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T TO COMPLETE DISTRIBUTION OF CONSOLATORY MONEY BY SATURDAY

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Tuesday assured that the government will complete the distribution of consolation monetary aid to quake victims whose houses collapsed during the "921 Earthquake" before this Saturday.
Siew made the assurance when formally responding to questions from the Legislative Yuan concerning issues related to the government's post-quake reconstruction efforts.

Siew said he had received promises from officials on Monday at a meeting of the Post-Quake Rehabilitation Promotion Committee that they could complete the distribution of the monetary aid before Saturday.
If the officials concerned fail to accomplish their mission, they will be given administrative punishments, Siew said.
Siew said the government has sent 700 technicians to quake-stricken zones to help finalize the number of houses that fully collapsed or partially collapsed during the disastrous temblor.
It is expected that the technicians will complete their work by Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA WANTS TALKS AFTER UN TROOPS IN W. TIMOR ATTACKED

TEXT.P: Prime Minister John Howard is seeking urgent high-level talks with Indonesia after its soldiers attacked the Australian-led UN peacekeeping force on the border of West Timor.

Howard told reporters on Monday Australia was seeking urgent high-level discussions in Dili and Jakarta on measures to reduce the chances of similar incidents and planned to voice its concerns to UN Secretary General Kofi Annan after Australian soldiers exchanged hundreds of rounds with pro-Jakarta militias in the company of Indonesian police and troops about 800 meters from the border of Motaain near Balibo in West Timor.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD'S BIGGEST BULLION FIRM MAKES INROADS INTO AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: South Africa-based AngloGold, the world's largest bullion company, made inroads into Australia after beating other bidders to acquire Acacia Resources with a US$555 million takeover offer.

AngloGold chief executive Bobby Godsell on Monday told reporters in Melbourne that the acquisition of Acacia gave his company "an excellent chance to establish a strong base in Australia with a management team of excellent track record."

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC PERFORMANCE GIVES AUSTRALIA HIGHER INT'L STATURE

TEXT.P: Australia has been asked to join a group of 20 nations to discuss measures to improve the stability of the international financial system and also to chair the ministerial council of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development next year.
The G20 was formed earlier this year by G7, the world's seven leading industrialized nations, to create a forum on international economic and financial policy issues.
Federal Treasurer Peter Costello confirmed that Australia had been asked to join the G20.
He told reporters that the OECD ministerial council will be held in Paris next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANSETT AUSTRALIA GAINS APPROVAL FOR DAILY FLIGHTS TO HK

TEXT.P: Ansett Australia, the country's second largest airline operator, has won an agreement to increase its services to Hong Kong from five days a week to daily flights, enabling it to better compete with Qantas Airways and Cathay Pacific Airways.
A spokesman said Ansett won the approval for daily flights between Australia and Hong Kong through a series of negotiations between the two governments last week.
Ansett abandoned its services to both Shanghai and Beijing last year due to operational losses, but has maintained its flights between Australia and Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-PANAMA TRADE SURGES
DOC.DATELINE: Canberra, Oct. 12 (CNA) (By Peter Chen) (By Hai tai Chung)

TEXT.P: Panama Oct. 11 (CAN} Two-way trade between Taiwan and Panama totaled 21.9 million US dollars over the first eight months of this year, an increase of 372.6% over the same period last year, according Panamanian economic ministry statistics.
During this period, Taiwan exports to Panama fell by 13.3 percent to 15.4 million US dollars. Meanwhile, its imports from Panama increased by 386 percent to 6.4 million US dollars.

Panama's economic minister said that the statistics don't include the free trade zone of COLON. During the first six months of this year, Taiwan exported 165.8 million US dollars worth of products to COLON's free trade zone.

DOC.HEADLINE: EARTHQUAKE DAMPENING DEVICE TESTED

TEXT.P: As recent devastating earthquakes in Turkey, Greece and Taiwan point to the need for structural controls that could reduce the seismic impact on structures, a professor of civil engineering at Washington University in St. Louis has tested a new device that shows promise in minimizing damage by earthquakes.

Shirley Dyke, assistant professor of civil engineering at Washington University's School of Engineering and Applied Science, tested an earthquake-damping device called a magnetorheological (MR) damper on a six-foot tall metal structure. The test was performed in the university's Structural Control and Earthquake Engineering Laboratory, which she directs. She applied the data from a quake that hit El Centro California in 1940 to reproduce the effects on the model. She then compared the resulting impact on the structure with and without the MR dampers.
Measuring responses on every floor of the building, Dyke found that the MR dampers reduced the peak acceleration by 50 percent.

"That's very encouraging," says Dyke in an article carried by the University's feature service. "Our purpose was to demonstrate that these devices are effective for response reduction, and we showed it clearly at this scale. Our idea is to start with small-scale tables and then to try it with a large shake table. Now, we're also working on defining which types of structures would benefit from MR dampers, and we eventually will design guidelines for them."

The MR damper is a device that acts like a shock absorber on a structure. The MR damping technology is inexpensive, relatively straightforward and will operate on just 20 to 50 watts of power--the amount used by a household light bulb. And if electrical power is cut in a major quake, the device would still work because it's powered by a battery.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY

Today is Tuesday, Oct. 12, or the fourth day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1492: After a month of experiencing mirages of land, explorer Christopher Columbus and his three ships sight "terra firma" at dawn today.
1822: Brazil becomes independent from Portugal.
1866: Ramsey McDonald, Scottish statesman and first Labour prime minister of Britain, is born.
1870: Robert E. Lee, Confederate general in the US Civil War, dies in Lexington at the age of 63. He won victories at Bull Run (1862), Fredericksburg (1863), and Chancellorsville (1863), before surrendering to Gen. Ulysses S. Grant at Appomattox in 1865.
1899: The Boer states respond to Britain's despatch of troops to South Africa by issuing a declaration of war, and the British military garrison at Mafeking, under Colonel Robert Baden-Powell, is under siege by Boer forces.
1901: Theodore Roosevelt, the 26th president of the United States, renames the Executive Mansion "The White House." He won the 1908 Nobel Peace Prize for his mediation in the Russo-Japanese War.
1920: Bertrand A. W. Russell, British philosopher, mathematician, social critic, and writer who won the 1950 Nobel Price for Literature, arrives in Shanghai as a visiting professor. He had profound influence on the development of symbolic ligic, logical positivism, and the set theory of mathematics.
1935: Adolf Hitler bans American jazz from German radio, calling it decadent.
1949: The ROC government moves its seat from Canton to Chungking.
1949: Euginie Anderson is appointed US ambassador to Denmark, becoming the first female US envoy.
1951: Florence Chadwick, US swimmer, breaks the cross-English Channel record with a time of just 13 hours 33 minutes.
1959: The United Nations General Assembly votes for a full-scale debate on Chinese communist bloodshed in Tibet.
1960: Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev, angered during a debate on colonialism at the United Nations General Assembly, takes off his shoe and ponds his desk with it several times.
1964: The Republic of China and the Republic of Korea sign a frienship treaty in Taipei.
1968: The 19th Olympic Games opens in Mexico City, capital of Mexico.
1968: Equatorial Guinea becomes independent after 190 years of Spanish rule.
1968: Omar Torrijos Herrera, a military officer, takes control of Panama and bigins to rule as a dictator.
1971: Dean Acheson, US politician and secretary of state from 1949 to 1953, dies at the age of 78. He promoted the Marshall Plan and helped established NATO.
1974: Juan Pao-shan, a Chinese student from Taiwan, is stabbed and killed in Los Angeles by leftists at a party in celebration of the Double Ten National Day of the Republic of China.
1976: Communist China's Prime Minister Hua Guofeng becomes chairman of the Chinese Communist Party.
1979: Fidel Castro, head of the Cuban governdment, deliver a speech at the United Nations General Assembly, requesting more UN aid for third world countries.
1983: A Tokyo district court sentences former Japanese Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka to four years' imprisonment for his part in the Lockheed bribery scandal.
1984: In a move to further expand bilataral trade and economic relations, the ROC-Australia Trade Association and the Chinese-New Zealand Business Council are formally inaugurated in Taipei.
1986: A summit meeting between US President Ronald Reagan and Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev ends in Reykjavik without any agreement on arms control being reached.
1986: During a display of ROC military power in the "Kuokuang Maneuvers," a combat skills exercise is held at a southern naval base.
1987: South Korea adopts a new constitution allowing direct election of the president by the people rather than by the electoral college.
1989: The Republic of China and Belize announce the establishment of diplomatic relations.
1989: Direct telephone links between Taiwan and the offshore islands of Kinmen and Matsu are completed.
1989: King Mswati III of Swaziland arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1992: Strong earthquake rocks Cairo, killing 552 people and injuring nearly 10,000 others.
1992: Premier Hau Pei-tsun receives Austrian Minister for Economic Affairs Wolfgang Schussel.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The life of the moral man is unobstrusive and yet it grows more and more in significance; whereas the life of the vulgar person is ostentatious, but it losses more and more in significance until it becomes nothingness."
