DOC.HEADLINE: POLL FINDS 80% OF QUAKE VICTIMS NOT YET RECEIVE ANY AID

TEXT.P: Nearly 80 percent of Taichung County residents whose houses were toppled or severely damaged by the 921 earthquake have not yet received any relief aid from the government, according to the results of a survey released on Tuesday.
The face-to-face survey of 1,167 residents in various disaster zones in the central Taiwan county were conducted by the non-profit Humanistic Education Foundation from Oct. 10-11.

The foundation mobilized 200-plus volunteers to interview people either on streets or at temporary shelters for homeless quake victims. Each randomly selected resident was interviewed for about 30 minutes.

Survey results show that 79.69 percent of the respondents whose homes were completely destroyed or seriously damaged in the Sept. 21 earthquake have not yet received any "consolatory money" from the government.

Meanwhile, 55.22 percent of those who themselves were seriously injured or whose family members died or were severely wounded in the devastating temblor also said they have not yet received any penny from the government.

The central government has promised to offer NT$200,000 (US$6,289) for each family whose house totally collapsed and NT$100,000 for each of those whose houses partially collapsed. In addition, the government promised to offer each of these quake-affected households NT$3,000 in housing rent subsidy per month for a year.
Moreover, the government agreed to offer NT$1 million in "consolatory money" for the bereaved family of each quake victim and NT$200,000 for each of those who were seriously injured.

According to the poll, many surviving quake victims complained that even though they have filled in many, many application forms over the past two weeks, they are still unable to get any "relief money" from the government.
As a result, many quake-affected people are still reluctant to leave their crumbled or damaged houses and have to rely on "relief goods" for survival.

Twenty-three percent cited "taking care of their houses and properties" as the top reason for their refusal to leave the disaster zones after the deadly quake; 22 percent said the main reason behind their reluctance to depart is that they don't think they can find suitable places to live or find new jobs outside their hometown; while 15 percent said they don't want to leave simply for emotional or sentimental reasons.

Asked about who should be held responsible for slow distribution of relief funds, 27 percent said grassroots-level authorities should be blamed; 20 percent cited the central government as the culprit; 10.7 percent said the main reason lies with the county government.

Other reasons cited by the respondents included a lack of information, a lack of time and energy to apply for "relief funds" on the part of quake victims themselves, low efficiency of various self-help organizations, quake victims' failure to cooperate and help each other.

As for quake-affected people's current living conditions, 70 percent of those interviewed said they can acquire relief goods within 30 minutes, indicating that basic demands for people in most disaster zones can now be met. Nevertheless, 2 percent of the respondents said they have to spend two hours getting relief goods.
The poll also found that 24 percent said they have to pick up relief goods everyday or once every two to three days, indicating that they have not yet settled down.

Survey results showed that 34 percent of quake-affected people in Taichung County's Tali City have taken part in at least one self-help organization, more than double the number recorded in the mountain township of Tungshih. County-wide, 70 percent of all quake victims have not participated in any self-help organization.

Eighty-six percent of those interviewed said they have experienced emotional changes after the deadly earthquake. For instance, 23 percent said they have often feel anxiety after the quake; 11 percent said they can be enraged easier; 5 percent said they often feel powerless and don't want to do anything.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROPERTY LOSSES IN TAIWAN FROM MAJOR QUAKE TOTAL US$ 9.2 BILLION

TEXT.P: Property losses in Taiwan resulting from the "921 Earthquake" totaled US$9.2 billion (NT$29.2 million), according to statistics released Monday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
The figure is far below that of losses incurred by the 1994 Northridge earthquake in California and by the 1995 Kobe quake in Japan.
A strong temblor measuring 6.8 on the Richter scale jolted the Northridge area on Jan. 17, 1994. A magnitude-7.2 quake rocked the Kobe area on the same date the following year.
The recent major earthquake that struck the central part of Taiwan occurred on Sept. 21, with a magnitude of 7.3.
Property losses from the Northridge quake and the Kobe quake were estimated to be US$47 billion and US$100 billion, respectively.

However, Taiwan's property losses account for 3.3 percent of the gross domestic product (GDP), a much higher figure than the 0.7 percent registered in the United States and 2 percent in Japan, DGBAS statistics show.

According to DGBAS data, authorities in the United States issued a disaster-relief order within 15 minutes after the earthquake there, while Japan and Taiwan authorities issued such orders within six hours and two hours, respectively.

DGBAS data also indicated that seven hours passed before the last survivor was pulled from the rubble after the temblor in the United States, while the last such rescues were made on the fifth day after the quake in Japan and the sixth day after the earthquake in Taiwan.
Seventy-two people died and 11,846 were injured in the Northridge quake; 6,430 people died, 43,782 were injured and three were unaccounted for following the Kobe temblor.
The "921 Earthquake" claimed 2,321 lives and injured 8,722; 40 were presumed dead after being buried beneath the rubble.
There were 114,000 houses damaged in the Northridge temblor, 250,000 in the Kobe quake, and 51,000 in the "921 Earthquake," according to DGBAS data.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES SOAR 3 PERCENT, INDEX FUTURES UP

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices soared 3 percent Tuesday to reach the 7,800-point level in hot trading buoyed by positive corporate results for September and overnight gains on the US NASDAQ index.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index rose 228.26 points to close at 7,835.37.
A total of 2.44 billion shares changed hands on a turnover of NT$116.86 billion (US$3.68 billion), up sharply from NT$61.08 billion in the previous session.
Trading focused on technology stocks with related transactions accounting for over 70 percent of Tuesday's turnover. Government-affiliated funds were also buying in order to shore up the index.

All eight major stock categories posted gains, among them electronics issues with the largest gains of 3.8 percent, followed by financial issues at 2.8 percent, and the plastics and chemicals sector at 2.6 percent.
Advancers led decliners 407 to 83, with 40 shares unchanged.
The over-the-counter market climbed 7.36 points to close at 175.68 on a turnover of NT$6.66 billion.

TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for October moved up 240 points to close at 7,826 with 2,914 contract transactions; those for November rose 265 points to finish at 7,845 with 526 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for December hiked 230 points to close at 7,820 with 17 contract transactions; those for next March jumped 208 points to end at 7,860 with six contract transactions; those for next June advanced 165 points to end at 7,830 with four contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Tuesday were 7,586 points for October, 7,580 points for November, 7,590 points for December, 7,652 points for next March, and 7,665 points for next June.
Electronics futures and financial futures, which are sub-index futures and based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares (TE) and financial shares (TF), both reported gains.

October TE futures rose 16.2 points to close at 370.7 with 760 contract transactions; November TE futures advanced 16 points to end at 371 with 58 contract transactions; next June TE futures climbed 3.45 points to close at 365 with two contract transactions.
There were no transaction records for December TE futures or next March TE futures.

October TF futures rose 24 points to close at 984.8 with 152 contract transactions, November TF futures advanced 22.4 points to close at 979.8 with six contract transactions; TF futures for other months had no transaction records. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar closed higher against the greenback on the Taipei market on Tuesday, rising 0.004 to 31.768. The currenccy opened at 31.768 and experienced a high of 31.762, and a low of 31.770.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$153 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: 51% GIVE THUMBS UP TO VEEP LIEN'S POST-QUAKE PERFORMANCE

TEXT.P: A recent survey showed that many local people admire Vice President Lien Chan's performance in the wake of the 921 earthquake, but such admiration does not seem to have been translated into support for his presidential bid.
The survey of 1,159 randomly selected adult residents was conducted from Oct. 7-8 by Focus Survey Research Co. at the request of Global Television Co. and The Journalist magazine.
Survey results found that 51 percent of the respondents give a thumbs-up to Lien's post-earthquake performance, while 29.7 percent said they don't admire his performance.

Even though Lien receives more praise for his post-quake performance than his two major rivals in the 2000 presidential election, he still lags behind them in the support rate. Lien has been nominated by the ruling Kuomintang to run for the next presidency.

If the election were to take place the following day, 27.8 percent said they would vote for former Taiwan Governor James Soong; 18.2 percent threw their support behind opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidate Chen Shui-bian; and 18.1 percent said they would choose Lien. Soong, a former KMT powerhouse, is running a rival campaign with Lien.
While Soong continued to lead the pack, his support rate fell from a level of well over 30 percent in numerous polls conducted before the Sept. 21 earthquake.
The poll also found that the gap between second-ranking Chen and third-ranking Lien has been narrowed to a marginal 0.1 percent.

Asked who they think to be most capable of leading post-earthquake relief and reconstruction work, 27.3 percent choose Soong; 25 percent opt for Lien; and 13.7 percent select Chen; while 28.4 percent either decline to answer the question or said they don't know.

Meanwhile, 45 percent said they admire Soong's post-earthquake performance, compared to 19.7 percent who gave a thumbs-down. In contrast, 36.4 percent praised Chen's performance, while 25.2 percent said they disliked his performance.

The same survey further showed that 47.3 percent agree with President Lee Teng-hui's remarks that the government has performed well in post-quake relief work, while 35.2 percent said they disagree with Lee's evaluation.
According to the poll, 50.7 percent said they were satisfied with the KMT's post-quake performance, but 33.3 percent said they were discontent.
In comparison, 28 percent endorsed the DPP's performance, while 27.7 percent nixed the main opposition party's post-quake operations.
As for the minor opposition New Party's performance, 14 percent said they were satisfied, while 33 percent said they were discontent with the pro-unification party's performance.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS VISIT US TO SAY THANKS FOR QUAKE RELIEF, EXCHANGE VIEWS

TEXT.P: A group of Taiwan legislators visited a US think tank in New York on Monday to express gratitude for US assistance in post-quake rescue and relief operations and to exchange views on US-Taiwan-mainland China relationships.
The group, led by Legislative Yuan Vice President Rau Yin-Chi, comprises legislators from the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and opposition Democrative Progressive Party (DPP).

The lawmakers arrived in New York Sunday night and on Monday visited the National Committee on American Foreign Policy, a US think tank that has sponsored many unofficial conferences on Taiwan and mainland China.

During the meeting, the first for the legislators after the July 9 pronouncement by President Lee Teng-hui of the "state-to-state relationship" theory, Rau explained Taiwan's stance in dealing with the cross-strait relationship, saying that the theory did not constitute a change in Taiwan's mainland policy, but merely spelled out an existing fact.

Rau went on to say that a vague definition of Taiwan's position in terms of the cross-strait relationship does not benefit Taiwan, since the mainland spares no effort in worldwide dissemination of the falsehood that Taiwan is part of the People's Republic of China (PRC).
"Taiwan definitely is not a province of the PRC, nor can it become another Hong Kong or Macau," said Rau.
Rau urged the United States to support Taiwan's stance and also invited members of the committee to visit Taiwan.

However, committee officials stressed the importance of maintaining "vagueness" in dealing with cross-strait relations, despite saying that they better understood Taiwan's theory after Rau's explanation.
The group was slated to proceed to Washington, D.C. for other meetings before returning to Taiwan on Oct. 14. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTER ISSUES APOLOGY FOR AMMUNITION THEFT FROM AIR BASE

TEXT.P: Minister of National Defense Tang Fei on Tuesday apologized to the public after another theft at an air force base in northern Taiwan.
Tang issued the apology at the Legislative Yuan to assuage public uneasiness resulting from the theft. He also stressed that all armed forces will step up munitions control and inspection.

The Air Force General Headquarters confirmed on Tuesday that 121 rounds of ammunition, consisting of 60 flare bombs, 22 cartridge impulses, 22 smoke bombs and 17 grenades, were found to be missing from an air force base in Taoyuan during a routine check Monday morning.

Spokesman Lai Ching-chun of the air force said that it has alerted a task force that had been formed at the base in the wake of a previous theft on Oct. 3, in which more than 9,000 rounds of ammunition for 65K2 rifles went missing.
The Criminal Investigation Bureau has sent agents to assist with investigation work.

Lai said that right after the Oct. 3 theft, the air force beefed up security measures and started adjustments in munitions depot operations. But because there is so much ammunition, it is difficult to take an accurate inventory and move it all to secure locations, he added.
With two thefts occurring in only nine days, the air force is not ruling out the possibility that the two incidents are somehow linked, according to Lai.

Police have targeted three suspects in connection with the Oct. 3 theft, said Lai, adding that there is some discrepancy between their statements and the facts, and police are still investigating the case.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE ORGANIZES LEGAL SERVICE TEAM

TEXT.P: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian said on Tuesday that he has organized a 100-member legal service team to provide counseling for surviving victims of the 921 devastating earthquake.

Chen, himself a lawyer-turned-politician, said the "All People Legal Service Group" will travel deep into quake-stricken areas in central Taiwan from Wednesday to offer free legal counseling services to all quake-affected people.

Chen, a former Taipei mayor, said he has found through various inspection tours of disaster zones over the past two weeks that many quake-affected people, including those whose houses collapsed in the Sept. 21 temblor, have little knowledge about the government's quake-relief measures.

Chen reminded surviving quake victims to collect and keep evidence if they want to sue builders for shoddy buildings after the quake. "Without enough evidence, those who have lost their houses in the quake may still lose lawsuits against contractors," he cautioned.

Chen said the voluntary service team will compile a manual detailing all earthquake-related legal problems, regulations and tips for resolving relevant legal problems. Copies of the manual will be distributed free of charge, he added.

Chen also urged those whose parents were killed in the earthquake and had more debts than assets should give up their inheritance rights before Nov. 20. Otherwise, Chen said, they may have to inherit their parents' debts.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC DAMAGE FROM QUAKE DOUBLE PREVIOUS ESTIMATE: TIER

TEXT.P: Industrial losses in central Taiwan resulting from the devastating earthquake will be double the previously estimated figure, said members of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) on Tuesday.

Losses in the manufacturing industry will total NT$360 billion, or 4 percent of industry products' total value for 1999, which will result in a 0.5 percent decline in economic growth for the year, noted researchers with the TIER after an assessment of actual damages.
In addition to the losses of industrial products, there was a slump in the tourism industry and a sharp increase in unemployment, the researchers observed.

The previous TIER economic assessment on Sept. 26, five days after the killer temblor, said that the damages caused by power outages in the manufacturing sector amounted to "a week's suspension of operations." That amount of impact would result in a loss of NT$180 billion, or 2 percent of total production value, thus leading to a plunge of 0.1 percent to 0.2 percent in economic growth -- with 5.5 percent growth for 1999 still likely to be achieved.

However, after an on-the-spot survey by the TIER work team, which was led by institute President Wu Rong-I, conducted in the hardest-hit counties of Taichung and Nantou, a more accurate estimate was made.

The TIER decided to make public its formal quake-damage estimate by the end of October, when a monthly report on the island's economic prospects will be presented at the institute's monthly news conference.
The island's economic performance in August and September was robust, a sure indication that Taiwan has left the Asian financial turmoil far behind, according to TIER.

The annual economic growth forecast made by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting & Statistics (DGBAS) in August raised the figure to 5.74 percent from 5.5 percent. However, if the brisk economic performance of the third quarter is taken into consideration, the growth may be even higher than 5.74 percent, said TIER officials.
Nevertheless, in light of the earthquake disaster, a decline of 0.5 percent in economic growth is expected, amounting to annual growth below 5.5 percent, the TIER researchers predicted.

DOC.HEADLINE: DISPOSAL OF CONSTRUCTION WASTE A BIG TASK FOR ENVIRONMENT OFFICE

TEXT.P: Debris from dismantled buildings damaged by the Sept. 21 earthquake is estimated to exceed 30 million metric tons, creating a big headache for environmental authorities, who face a shortage of dumping grounds and strong resistance from the public.

An official of the Environmental Protection Administration under the Executive Yuan said Tuesday that the volume of construction waste from the devastated buildings is almost two times that of Taiwan's industrial waste for a whole year.

An island with extremely high population density and growing environmental consciousness, Taiwan has in recent years had difficulty finding suitable dumping grounds for refuse from industry and households, not to mention the huge quantity caused by the earthquake.

The government has assigned the armed forces to help with clean-up operations. In the past two weeks, soldiers have dismantled and cleared more than one million metric tons of concrete and scraps of furnishings. Before suitable dumping grounds are found, the material will be kept at temporary sites near the disaster regions.
So far, authorities have succeeded in finding 54 temporary sites for storing the debris. These open-air storage grounds are mostly located along riverbanks and valleys.

Environmentalists and geologists voiced their concerns that the earthquake and aftershocks have changed the hydrodynamics of many waterways in central Taiwan, and the quake-jolted dikes might burst with heavy flooding. Floods would move the temporarily-stored waste downstream, damaging river beds and surrounding areas.

For long-term disposal, some experts have discussed the Japanese model. Japanese authorities used most of the concrete waste after the 1995 Hanshin earthquake to create reclaimed land; scraps the mostly wooden furnishings were burned in controlled open-air fires. However, many residents neighboring the burning grounds experienced eye irritation.
Some environmentalists suggested that the Japanese model might not be suitable for Taiwan in this regard, because not much of the material used here for construction and furnishings was made of wood.

The Environmental Protection Administration is currently drafting legislation for compulsory recycling of construction materials, which is slated for screening by the Executive Yuan next June and will not be in force until receiving subsequent approval by the Legislative Yuan.

Refraining from going into details about forces governing the construction industry, an environmental official lamented that without a legal basis for handling the issue, the disposal of earthquake debris will become a huge controversial issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITORS' NOTE:

TEXT.P: Property losses in Taiwan resulting from the "921 Earthquake" totaled US$9.2 billion (NT$29.2 billion), according to statistics released Monday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
The figure is far below that of losses incurred by the 1994 Northridge earthquake in California and by the 1995 Kobe quake in Japan.
A strong temblor measuring 6.8 on the Richter scale jolted the Northridge area on Jan. 17, 1994. A magnitude-7.2 quake rocked the Kobe area on the same date the following year.

The recent major earthquake that struck the central part of Taiwan occurred on Sept. 21, with a magnitude of 7.3. Property losses from the Northridge quake and the Kobe quake were estimated to be US$47 billion and US$100 billion, respectively.

However, Taiwan's property losses account for 3.3 percent of the its gross domestic product (GDP), a much higher figure than the 0.7 percent registered in the United States and 2 percent in Japan, DGBAS statistics show.

According to DGBAS data, authorities in the United States issued a disaster-relief order within 15 minutes after the earthquake there, while Japan and Taiwan authorities issued such orders within six hours and two hours, respectively.

DGBAS data also indicated that seven hours passed before the last survivor was pulled from the rubble after the temblor in the United States, while the last such rescues were made on the fifth day after the quake in Japan and the sixth day after the earthquake in Taiwan.
Seventy-two people died and 11,846 were injured in the Northridge quake; 6,430 people died, 43,782 were injured and three were unaccounted for following the Kobe temblor.
The "921 Earthquake" claimed 2,321 lives and injured 8,722; 40 were presumed dead after being buried beneath the rubble.
There were 114,000 houses damaged in the Northridge temblor, 250,000 in the Kobe quake, and 51,000 in the "921 Earthquake," according to DGBAS data.

DOC.HEADLINE: PANAMANIAN CONTAINER SHIP RUNS AGROUND IN KAOHSIUNG HARBOR

TEXT.P: The container ship Fukuoshin, which experienced mechanical difficulty and was subsequently anchored and abandoned when Tyhpoon Dan struck Taiwan, has run aground in Kaohsiung harbor.

Representatives from the shipping agency Chenghwa Co., along with personnel from its insurance company, on Tuesday surveyed the site and discussed measures for removing the vessel, which sails under the Panamanian flag.

The ship was originally scheduled to leave for Hualien on Oct. 6 to load and transport gravel. However, during bad weather conditions caused by Typhoon Dan, the engine failed and the vessel drifted at sea. While the 15 crew members on board were rescued by helicopter, the ship was towed by a tugboat and anchored off Kaohsiung harbor.
But because of high waves in the stormy sea, the ship dragged anchor and drifted until running aground by the Chichin seashore at Kaohsiung harbor.
Staff members of the Chenghwa Co. are optimistic that the vessel can be dislodged with the use of a tugboat because the ship is currently empty.
The Fukuoshin weighs 4,556 tons, with a length of 101 meters and a width of 18 meters. The Japanese captain and 14 Philippine crew members have been taken care of by the shipping agency.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S INT'L COMMUNITY TO HOST CHARITY CONCERT FOR QUAKE SURVIVORS

TEXT.P: The international community in Taiwan has decided to sponsor a charity music concert on Oct. 22 at the Grand Hotel in Taipei for relief aid for 921 earthquake survivors, a representative from the organizers committee said on Tuesday.

A number of noted musicians from home and abroad will be invited to participate in the concert with the hope of collecting NT$10 million in relief funds to help survivors reconstruct their homeland, he said.

The concert will be co-sponsored by the Pearl Buck Foundation for Culture and Education, the Taipei Rotary Club, the International Community Foundation for Culture and Education, the Grand Hotel, the Turkish Trade Office, the American Club in China, the Broadcasting Corp. of China, International Community Radio Taipei (ICRT), the Chinese Public Television Co., and others.

More than 200 musicians will be invited to participate in the concert, including pianists Azusa Fujita and Chen Jui-pin, violinist Su Hsian-da, tenors Ma Lan-chi and Hsieh Ying-tung, sopranos Lu li-li and Chien Wen-hsiu, baritone Lin Chia-wen, dancer Fan Chieh-hsi and orchestras and choirs from Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CONTINUES TO SHAKE

TEXT.P: Taiwan continued to shake on Tuesday as at least three perceptible earthquakes were detected rocking the mountainous central-north and eastern parts of the island, but no casualties were reported, according to the Seismology Center of Taiwan.

At 3:10 a.m., a jolt measuring 4.7 on the open-ended Richter scale was detected about 31.8 kilometers west of Hualien City on the east coast, with its epicenter located at 23.96 degrees north latitude and 121.29 degrees east longitude, said the center's earthquake experts.
The tremor's focus, or underground center, was 3.8 kilometers beneath the earth's surface, according to the seismologists.
The temblor had an intensity of 4.0 in nearby Shilin Township in Hualien County, 3.0 in Hualien City and 2.0 in Nanshan Township in the eastern coastal county of Ilan.
Later, at around 7:56 Tuesday morning, a magnitude-4.5 quake jolted the central-north mountain range, about 36 kilometers south of Chupei Township.
The jolt, with its epicenter at 24.48 degrees north latitude and 120.91 degrees east longitude, was found originating 1.4 kilometers beneath the earth's surface, according to the seismologists.
The temblor, believed to be unrelated to the catastrophic Sept. 21 earthquake and its aftershocks, also sent magnitude-3.0 tremor waves to nearby Nanchuang Township in Miaoli County.
At 12:17 p.m., another temblor measuring 4.7 on the Richter scale was detected 42.9 kilometers east of the central city of Taichung, with its focus only 1 kilometer beneath the earth's surface.
The jolt had an intensity of 3.0 in Ilan County's Nanshan Township, 2.0 in Liyutan in Miaoli County, and 1.0 in Hualien City.

As of Tuesday, 22 days after the devastating quake, more than 11,500 aftershocks had been detected, although most of those were imperceptible except by specialized monitoring instruments. Of the total, 105 were temblors of magnitude 4.0 or greater, the seismologists said.

Meanwhile, seismic data collected by the Seismology Center showed that the frequency of aftershocks from the deadly Sept. 21 earthquake has gradually subsided, with less than 10 per hour this week, compared to approximately 150 per hour in the first several days following the quake.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMY CONTINUES TO HELP KINMEN RESIDENTS CLEAN UP AFTER TYPHOON DAN

TEXT.P: Soldiers stationed on the offshore island of Kinmen continued to help residents clean up roads and other areas ravaged by Typhoon Dan, which swept through the isle last Saturday.
No casualties have been reported so far.
According to a preliminary estimate by Kinmen's forestry authority, 216,000 bonsai and 544,000 other trees were damaged by the tropical storm. The authority estimated total losses at NT$206 million.

Lt. Gen. Chu Kai-sheng, commander of the Kinmen Defense Command, said his troops, while following the principle of maintaining military preparedness, will continue to aid in the relief and reconstruction work.
Chu noted that the most urgent work is to restore smooth traffic flow after many roadside trees were uprooted by typhoon Dan.
He expects that soldiers will complete the clearing of roads on the island resulting in regular traffic flow within one week.
Since Sunday, the Kinmen Defense Command has dispatched more than 9,000 soldiers and mobilized more than 200 trucks to aid in the relief and reconstruction work.
At present, Kinmen armed forces have completed at least one-fourth of the post-typhoon relief and reconstruction work.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIGER WOODS TO PLAY IN JOHNNIE WALKER CLASSIC GOLF CHARITY TOURNEY

TEXT.P: World-famous golfer Tiger Woods has confirmed his participation in the Johnnie Walker Classic Golf Charity Tournament at Ta Shee Golf and Country Club in Taoyuan Nov. 9-14, a representative of the organizers committee said on Tuesday.
Ed Shyurng, managing director of the United Distillers & Vintners, Asia Pacific Region, said that President Lee Teng-hui will be invited to play with ace US golfer Tigers Woods.
Shyurng said that Woods will offer his clubs and personally give pointers to local golf fans as a means to raise relief funds for 921 earthquake survivors to reconstruct their homeland.

Shyurng said that the organizers committee has decided to change the original Johnnie Walker Classic Golf Tournament to a charity tournament after Taiwan's biggest earthquake of the century devastated central-island areas on Sept. 21, claiming more than 2,200 lives.
Others golf stars invited to the tourney include Veejay Singh of Fiji, US player Jim Furyk, Australia's Nick Faldo and Ernie Els of South Africa, said Shyurng.
The "Taiwan Keep Walking" charity activities are expected to raise NT$300 million for reconstruction of two hospitals in quake-stricken areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITORS' NOTE:

DOC.HEADLINE: FALUN GONG WEB PAGE DESIGNER INDICTED IN CHINA

TEXT.P: Zhang Haitao, an engineer who set up a web page for Falun Gong in May, was indicted Monday by Jilin Provincial People's Procuratorate on charges of "inciting the overthrow of state power," a human rights group said here Tuesday.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China said that Zhang, 30, used the web page to urge his fellow practitioners to protest against the nation-wide government crackdown on Falun Gong, which began on July 21. The web page was closed by the authorities on July 24 and Zhang was arrested on July 29 as a result.

The information center said that Zhang could be sentenced in a month to a long prison term, and that about 50 other leaders of Falun Gong have been detained by police. All of them might be indicted in this month, it added.

Falun Gong is a huge but amorphous organization with tens of millions of followers in mainland China. It combines the ideas of Buddhism and Taoism with a Chinese traditional breathing technique called "qi gong." The mainland Chinese government began to crack down on the quasi-religious sect after more than 10,000 sect members staged an unusual demonstration around the Zhungnanhai leadership compound in central Beijing in April.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T PLANS TO ISSUE NT$ 80 BIL. IN PUBLIC BONDS FOR RELIEF FUND

TEXT.P: The government plans to issue NT$80 billion worth of public bonds in two separate stages as reconstruction and relief aid for 921 earthquake victims, an official of the Central Bank of China (CBC) said on Tuesday.

Lee Chien-cheng, deputy director of the Treasury Department of CBC, said that the Ministry of Finance sold NT$40 billion worth of public bonds via the CBC on Tuesday. The ministry was expected to issue another NT$40 billion in public bonds in mid-November.
The bonds will mature in 15 years, Lee said.

Lee said that in order to raise funds for relief aid and reconstructing quake-stricken areas, the government issued public bonds to increase capital inflow to the market without causing an increase in banks' short-term interest rates.
Lee went on to say that the bonds are always issued in the second half of the month since the money supply is more abundant at that time.
The total amounts of bidding and buying both set new records, indicating that the market is still filled with abundant capital, Lee added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NORWEGIAN 'GRANDPA' AND 'GRANDMA' RETURN TO PULI CHRISTIAN HOSPITAL
DOC.DATELINE: Puli, central Taiwan, Oct. 12 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The famous "Ah-Kung" (Grandpa) and "Ah-Mah" (Grandma) of the Christian Hospital in Puli in Nantou County, who returned to their mother country of Norway after retirement last year, flew back to Taiwan Tuesday to their "real home."

Bjarne and Alfhild Jensen Gislefoss, two Norwegian doctors who have devoted some four decades of their lives to providing medical care to Taiwan's aboriginal people in central Taiwan, said they just cannot sit idly by while the Puli Christian (Puchi) Hospital is braving an unprecedented test and mission in the wake of the devastating Sept. 21 earthquake.
The couple have both served as presidents of the hospital over a period spanning more than 30 years, and have cared for numerous aborigines in times of illness.

Seeing the return of Ah-Kung and Ah-Mah, a teary hospital secretary said their arrival is a genuine shot in the arm for Puchi, at a time when it is striving to care for both regular patients and those injured in the deadly earthquake -- around-the-clock arrivals who have poured in since early Sept. 21 with never-ending frequency.
Mr. and Mrs. Gislefoss managed to collect 3,000 blankets in a charity drive in Norway for Taiwan's cause before flying halfway around the globe to the island.

The Gislefosses, who have received numerous certificates of recognition from the government and from private groups in Taiwan over the past several decades, have always said that "Norway is our mother country, but Taiwan is our home."

Puchi, located in mountainous Puli, sustained considerable damage to its main administration building during the devastating quake which battered the central counties of Taichung, Nantou and Yunlin, killing 2,300 people and leaving 8,700 injured and some 100,000 others homeless.

With the continual influx of patients, Puchi, with its own buildings shaking, never turned away any incoming injured. It first used tents and stretchers and then containers donated by a shipping company to accommodate patients.
Puchi, a general hospital famed for its care of aboriginal people in central Taiwan, was established in January 1956 by Lillian Ruth Dickson, a US missionary working with limited church donations.

In 1960, Dr. Bjarne Gislefoss, who helped train 150 local nurses for the hospital, became the second president of the institution. In 1963, Gislefoss married Alfhild Jensen, a graduate of Oslo Medical School who had worked as an anesthetist in the United States and was dispatched to Taiwan on a missionary and medical mission.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHRISTIAN GROUP FROM N. AMERICA JOINS TAIWAN'S REHABILITATION WORK

TEXT.P: A Christian group from North America will soon join the rehabilitation effort for people in quake-stricken areas of central Taiwan.
Fifty-two members of the Local Church in North America, who come from all walks of life, arrived in Taipei Monday night, bringing with them 10,000 consolation letters written in many languages.

The group, comprising doctors, nurses, engineers and psychological counselors, will work with their counterparts in the Local Church in Taiwan for the rehabilitation effort in quake-stricken areas. They plan to travel to five hard-hit regions Wednesday.

The Christian group hopes to accompany quake-affected people, hearing their sorrows, praying with them and providing them with psychological counseling. They will also help with house damage assessment and construction work to create solid building foundations and safe structures.
A representative of the group said that the reconstruction mission will continue until the end of the year.
Meanwhile, leaders from five religions gathered Monday to tape a message to the public to be aired on television as a means to try to soothe the sorrow of the Taiwan people.

The five leaders -- Reverend Chow Lien-hwa, Ti Kang of the Catholic Taipei Archdiocese, Buddhist Master Hsindao, Muslim leader Wang Chun-shan, and Secretary General of the Taoist Association of the ROC Chang Sheng -- recited a prayer for Taiwan in the wake of the massive quake Sept. 21.
The religious leaders expressed the hope that the devastating quake, which has claimed more than 2,300 lives and wreaked extensive damages on the island, will help society reflect deeply.
Seeing the outpouring of cash donations and sympathy from all walks of life after the 7.3-magnitude quake, the leaders said that they have seen hope in the midst of the terrible tragedy.
They said they hope that the catastrophe will bring out the love and goodness in people, and that the newly developed sense of community will help Taiwan work toward a brighter future.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY TO RESTRICT BETEL NUT CHEWING IN PUBLIC

TEXT.P: The Taipei City government's Health Department held a seminar on Tuesday to discuss restrictions on chewing betel nuts in public.
Yeh Chin-chuan, director of the department, said the government has no intention of banning betel nut chewing, but considering public sanitation, his department must impose restrictions.
The plan to restrict chewing of betel nuts has received wide support from the public, but has met resistance from betel nut planters and sellers.

The sellers said that betel nut consumption is a matter of individual choice, and it would be too rigid if the government imposes a ban at government institutions, department stores, tourist hotels, railway stations and airports.
In consideration of the sellers' views, the Health Department made some concessions on the places where chewing betel nuts will be prohibited.

Areas of prohibition will include schools, nurseries, kindergartens, social education halls, libraries, museums, performance halls, gymnasiums, swimming pools, children's playgrounds, zoos, medical and nursing institutions, buses and trains.

As for government institutions, department stores, tourist hotels, railway stations and airports, their managers will be free to decide whether to ban or to set aside special areas for betel nut chewing.
Meanwhile, Council of Agriculture (COA) officials said on Tuesday that betel nut plantations on the island sustained very little damage in the devastating Sept. 21 Chichi earthquake.
But they reiterated that the COA will further crack down on some 8,000 acres of unlawfully planted betel nut plantations.
There are about 54,000 acres of betel nut plantations that were planted without violating government regulations. However, the COA will not encourage any farmers to plant betel nuts.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEGAWATI MAY BE GUS DUR'S VICE-PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Charismatic Islamic leader Abdurrahman Wahid and opposition front-runner Megawati Sukarnoputri are working out a plan for a joint ticket in next week's Indonesian presidential polls that could prove insurmountable for President B.J. Habibie, who looked set Monday night to hold on to the ruling Golkar party's nomination, The Business Times reported Tuesday.

Party insiders say Wahid, or Gus Dur as he is popularly known, will head a ticket with Megawati as his running mate. But in a compromise deal, the ailing Gus Dur will step down after a period of time and hand over power to his deputy. Megawati's Indonesian Democratic Party-Struggle (PDI-P) holds 153 seats in the People's Consultative Assembly (MPR), the most of any party, but not enough to form a majority in the electoral college that will choose the president on Oct. 20.
In a symbolic gesture of unity, the two leaders journeyed to East Java over the weekend to pay respects at the graves of their respective fathers.

With his nomination by the Reform faction in the 700-seat MPR last week, Gus Dur has emerged as the front runner among the three presidential candidates. He is now seen as the ideal candidate for the nation's top job becuase he can act a bridge between the nationalists and the conservative Muslims within the MPR.

Political observer Sukardi Rinarkit, who has close ties with the PDI-P, said any plan for a Gus Dur-Megawati ticket needs to be sold to the millions of Megawati supporters who are threatening to stage massive demonstrations if she is not elected.

"Megawati will accept the vice-president post, but they have to sell the idea to the masses, and the visit to East Java was classic Javanese politics," said Rinarkit. "The symbolism of that visit was to show the people that the two of them are still together."

Gus Dur showed that he is the man who is pulling all the strings when his crucial backing for the Central Axis faction's nomination helped Amien Rais win the chairmanship of the MPR over the PDI-P candidate. The behind-the-scenes negotiations will make it harder for the ambitions of incumbent president Habibie.

Late last night the ruling Golkar party appeared set to stick to its earlier decision to nominate Habibie as its sole presidential candidate. Sources told the Business Times that the ruling party is also likely to nominate armed forces chief and Defense Minister General Wiranto as his running mate during its two-day meeting which ended Tuesday.

Habibie also alluded to his possible vice-presidential choice in an interview with Tempo magazine when he said the general is well suited for the job, given his Javanese ethnicity. Habibie comes from South Sulawesi.

Public opinion polls show Habibie trailing his opponents. A readers' poll conducted by the respected Kompas daily in four major cities showed Megawati the strong popular choice with Wahid running second.

Kompas said 52 percent of respondents chose the daughter of the country's first president as the next head of state, while Wahid and Habibie mustered support from only 11 and 10 percent, respectively.

Even within his own party, the incumbent is facing some opposition from a group led by deputy chairman Marzuki Darusman, who heads the Golkar faction in the MPR. But party insiders told the Business Times that a sizable number of Golkar members, especially the regional representatives, are still solidly behind Habibie. (by Sherman Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINES PROTESTS VIETNAMESE ACTION IN SPRATLYS

TEXT.P: The Philippines on Tuesday filed a diplomatic protest against the improvements being made in the two atolls in the Spratly island group by the Vietnamese government.
Foreign Affairs Undersecretary Benjamin Domingo informed Vietnamese Ambassador Nguyen Thac Dinh of the protest at 11 a.m. at the Department of Foreign Affairs, where the envoy was summoned.
Vietnamese Embassy First Secretary Ho Xuan Phong disclosed that the Philippine government expressed its concern over the repairs being made by Vietnam on Cornwallis south reef and Allison reef.

For its part, Vietnam said in a statement that its "relevant agency repairs (on) structures which were built a long time ago so as to ensure safety of people working there" are normal activities falling within Vietnam's sovereignty and completely conforming with international law and practice.

The Vietnamese ambassador said the areas were hit by a typhoon, so the repairs were needed. But he stressed there were no new structures being constructed and that they were adhering to ASEAN declarations calling for restraint of claimants' movements in the South China Sea.
"We assert our indisputable sovereignty over Truong Sa (Spratly) as well as Hoang Sa (Paracel) archipelagos," Vietnam averred.
But it stressed it had been cooperative in coming up with a long term solution to the dispute through negotiations among claimants.
Vietnam supported the Philippines' stand that "pending such a solution, the parties concerned should refrain from taking any actions that would further aggravate the situation."
It explained its action in the Spratlys was not in violation of the status quo principle that should be adopted by the claimants.
Vietnam further said its "position on issues relating to the Eastern Sea (South China Sea) has been clearly stated on many occasions."

Vietnam and the Philippines were asked by the Association of Southeast Asian Nations to draft the regional code of conduct for the South China Sea calling for a moratorium on construction in the area.
The Spratlys are claimed in whole or in part by the Philippines, Mainland China, Malaysia, Vietnam, Brunei and the Republic of China. (by Timothy Sun)

DOC.HEADLINE: `THREE ARE NOT TOO MANY' SAY TAIWAN DEMOGRAPHERS

TEXT.P: Taiwanese couples are being encouraged to have more than two children under a slogan of "Three (babies) are not too many."

As Taiwan's population ages and the birth rate continues to decline, official demographers say the current national policy is to encourage married couples to have more children in order to help increase the proportion of the population that will be under the age of 40 several decades from now.

The slogan has been altered as the government's population policy has changed, said the demographers. Less than 10 years ago, the government's slogan was "Two (babies) are just fine and one is not too few."

According to tallies from the Ministry of the Interior, Taiwan's population totaled 22,048,356 as of the end of September. Of the total, 11,293,654 are male and 10,754,702 are female, making up a ratio of 105:100 between the two sexes.
The birth rate in the Taiwan, Penghu, Matsu and Kinmen areas averaged 0.683 percent in 1998, slightly lower than expected, the demographers said.
In September, 22,843 babies were born in these areas, marking an annual birth rate of 1.26 percent, or approximately one new-born baby every minute.
Meanwhile, 10,462 people died in September, averaging one death every four minutes or a death rate of 0.577 percent, according to the tallies.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Oct. 13, or the fifth day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
A.D. 54: Claudius I, 64, the Roman emperor and historian, dies after supposedly consuming poisoned mushrooms dished up by his fourth wife, his niece Agrippina. Shortly before his death, Claudius had agreed to acknowledge Nero, Agrippina's son by a former marriage, as his heir instead of his natural son, Britannicus.
1399: Coronation of Henry IV, the first King of the House of Lancaster. He was banished from England by Richard II, who confiscated his estate. Henry returned, raised an army, and compelled Richard to abdicate.
1792: US President George Washington lays the foundation stone of the White House.
1812: British forces under Sir Isaac Brock defeat the Americans at the battle of Queenston Heights, Ontario, helping to put an end to the US attempt to invade Canada.
1884: Greenwich, England, is adopted as the universal meridian from which standard times throughout the world are calculated.
1913: Representatives from China, Britain and Tibet attend a meeting held at Simla, India to discuss various problems concerning Tibet.
1923: Ankara (formally Angola) becomes capital of Turkey.
1925: Margaret Thatcher, British Conservative politician and prime minister from 1979 to 1990, is born. Her administration was marked by anti-inflationary measures, a brief war in the Falkland Islands (1982), and the passage of a poll tax.
1939: Adolf Hitler tries without success to persuade US President Franklin Roosevelt to mediate peace between Germany, France and Britain.
1940: Princess Elizabeth, 14, daughter of King George VI, makes her first public contribution to Britain's war effort by making a broadcast to the children of Britain and the Commonwealth.
1943: Italy declares war on Germany, its former Axis partner.
1949: ROC government troops evacuate Canton.
1960: The Institute of History and Philology of Academia Sinica begins excavations at dwellings of the Yin people in Anyang County, Hunan Province, once the capital of the dynasty before 1200 BC.
1964: Three Soviet cosmonauts operating Voshkod, the world's first multi-seat spacecraft, land safely after a 24-hour journey.
1968: Liu Shao-chi, state chairman of communist China, is purged at the 12th Plenum of the 8th Chinese Communist Party Central Committee held in Beijing.
1970: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces the severance of diplomatic relations with Canada.
1972: A Soviet Ilyushin-62 crashes near Moscow airport, killing all 176 on board.
1980: President Pieter W. Botha of South Africa is presented with the Key to the City of Taipei by Mayor Lee Teng-hui upon arrival for a state visit.
1988: The Shroud of Turin, for centuries regarded as the burial cloth of Jesus Christ, is shown by carbon-dating tests to date from between 1260 and 1390 during the Middle Ages, a period rife with forgeries.
1993: The United Nations Security Council decides to resume an oil-and-arms embargo against Haiti after Haitian military leaders fail to follow an agreement to allow President Jean-Bertrand Aristide to return to office and restore a democratic government.
1995: Joseph Rotblat, the nuclear physicist who devoted his life to trying to ban the bomb he helped create, wins the 1995 Nobel Peace Prize.
1995: France rejects appeals to abandon nuclear tests in the South Pacific.
1997: Adil Carcani, who served as the last communist prime minister of Albania under late Stalinist dictator Enver Hoxha and his successor Ramiz Alia, dies at the age of 75.
1998: Daniel Chee Tsui, professor of Princeton University and a member of Academia Sinica, becomes one of the three co-winners of the 1998 Nobel Prize for Physics.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The life of the moral man is plain, and yet not unattractive; it is simple, and yet full of grace; it is easy, and yet methodical."

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES CLOSE MARGINALLY HIGHER, INDEX FUTURES MIXED

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed only 1.57 points higher Wednesday on consolidation as investors were affected by a report that Taiwan Power Company was preparing to impose another phase of power rationing on the manufacturing industry.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index rose 1.57 points to close at 7,836.94.
A total of 2.92 billion shares changed hands in a turnover of NT$125.13 billion (US$3.94 billion).
The market opened lower on overnight losses on the US NASDAQ index, but later buying emerged in plastics and chemical issues as well as construction shares, pushing up the index.
The plastics and chemical sector remains the primary target for investors because they expect that rising prices in raw materials will boost earnings, dealers said.
Strong buying in shares of DRAM (dynamic random access memory) chip makers also helped sustain the index, dealers added.
Among the eight major stock categories, only construction shares, plastics and chemical issues and textiles enjoyed gains, reporting 0.6 percent, 0.5 percent and 0.1 percent increases respectively.

Electronics shares and financial issues remained unchanged while the rest, foodstuff issues, cement issues and paper-making stocks suffered minor losses, listing 0.8 percent, 0.6 percent and 0.2 percent decreases respectively.
Declining stocks led advancing stocks by a margin of 278 to 168, with 83 shares unchanged.
The over-the-counter market climbed 2.42 points to close at 178.1 on a turnover of NT$8.6 billion.

TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for October moved up 2 points to close at 7,828 with 1,723 contract transactions. Those for November shed 10 points to finish at 7,835 with 425 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for December rose 5 points to close at 7,840 with 10 contract transactions while those for next March climbed 20 points to end at 7,880 with seven contract transactions. Those for next June advanced 50 points to end at 7,880 with six contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Wednesday were 7,826 points for October, 7,845 points for November, 7,835 points for December, 7,860 points for next March, and 7,830 points for next June.

Electronics futures and financial futures, which are sub-index futures and based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares (TE) and financial shares (TF), reported gains and losses, respectively.

October TE futures rose 0.3 points to close at 371 with 406 contract transactions; November TE futures advanced 0.8 points to end at 371.8 with 56 contract transactions; December TE futures dropped 3.95 points to finish at 370 with three contract contractions; next June's TE futures climbed 13.9 points to close at 378.9 with one contract transaction.
There were no transaction records for next March's TE futures.

October TF futures shed 4.8 points to close at 980 with 86 contract transactions, November TF futures declined 3.2 points to close at 978.2 with four contract transactions; December TF futures shed 28.8 points to finish at 983 with one contract transaction; TF futures for other months had no transaction records. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: QUAKE-HIT AREA CONSCRIPTS GIVEN MORE OPTIONS

TEXT.P: Young men close to conscription age from earthquake-stricken areas in central Taiwan are now allowed easier access to the Selective Service System (SSS) and the Voluntary Officers' Program (VOP), sources from the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said on Wednesday.

The initiative is designed to help alleviate unemployment pressures and the loss of educational opportunities in central Taiwan in the wake of the devastating Sept. 21 earthquake which killed at least 2,300 people, injured 8,700 and left 100,000 homeless, while causing approximately US$9.2 billion worth of property damage, said MND officials.

The military currently needs about 4,000 new recruits for the SSS and VOP, and enlistment priorities will be given to draft-eligible young men from the central counties of Taichung, Nantou and Yunlin -- the hardest hit areas, the officials said.

Of the 4,000-some openings, 2,385 will be in the Army, with 673 openings for low-ranking officers and 1,712 for soldiers. The Military Police Command will offer 35 positions for officers and 210 for soldiers, while the Military Management Command will make 28 positions available for officers and 127 for soldiers, according to the MND.
The newly-introduced SSS is designed to allow would-be-conscripts to perform community service rather than active military duty.
The SSS will allow the draft-eligible young men to serve in the fields of law enforcement, education or defense technology, instead of joining active-duty military units.

The would-be inductees who are chosen to enter the SSS will face a two-and-a-half-year obligation, six months longer than the standard term for conscription into military service. This is because SSS recruits will work on a nine-to-five basis, in contrast to ordinary draftees who are ostensibly on call around the clock, the officials said.

The SSS conscripts may be required to work as nurses in retirement homes or for elderly persons who live alone in the earthquake-stricken areas. They may also serve as policemen or assistants in educational or medical institutions.

Meanwhile, the VOP provides nine different divisions, including artillery, telecommunications, transportation, chemical and aviation, for college graduates to choose from, allowing them to join the army as officers for military service periods ranging from five years to 14 years, according to the officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: JORDAN DONATES RELIEF GOODS TO TAIWAN'S QUAKE SURVIVORS

TEXT.P: A Jordanian Royal Air Force transport plane airlifted 14,600 kilograms of relief goods to Taipei on Wednesday to help surviving victims of a devastating earthquake which rattled mountainous central Taiwan on Sept. 21.
Jordan was the first Middle East country to offer assistance to the Republic of China in the wake of the 921 earthquake, the worst natural disaster to hit Taiwan in decades.
The C-130 Jordanian military transport arrived at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, the main gateway to Taiwan, at 3 a.m. Wednesday.

ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials received the goods at the airport on behalf of the government. The relief goods included pharmaceuticals, tents, blankets, baby foods, powdered milk and sleeping bags.

The relief goods will be sent to three hardest-stricken disaster zones in central Taiwan, including Nantou County's Puli township, Taichung county's Tungshih township and Taichung City's Takeng district.

Despite the absence of formal diplomatic relations, the ROC and Jordan have maintained close substantive ties. ROC President Lee Teng-hui and Vice President Lien Chan made private visits to the Middle East country in 1995 and 1998, respectively.

Foreign Ministry officials said many countries around the world, including those which do not maintained official ties with the ROC, have offered assistance to Taiwan since the 921 temblor wreaked havoc in the central part of the island.

"We appreciate all this humanitarian aid," said a MOFA official, adding that Taiwan has never hesitated to extend a helping hand to needy countries in the past and will even increase its humanitarian aid to other countries in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA SEEN TO PLAY KEY ROLE IN US-PLANNED THEATER MISSILE DEFENSE

TEXT.P: Australia is set to play a major role in the US-planned theater missile defense (TMD) system in its bid to strengthen ties with America but at the risk of angering mainland China, the Australian on Wednesday reported.

The newspaper reported the new role may also reinforce Southeast Asian perceptions of Australia as a US surrogate in the region after US Secretary of the Air Force F. Whitten Peters on Tuesday emphasized the vital role of Australia's Pine Gap joint facility in a new generation space-based infra-red missile defense system called SBIRS.
The daily quoted Peters as saying that SBIRS would be critical to the operation of the controversial TMD system being considered for Japan and Taiwan.
The US-proposed system has deeply angered China because Beijing regards it as aimed at the mainland and it does not want Taiwan to be included in the planned system.

The daily quoted Professor Stuart Harris of the Australian National University in Canberra as saying on Tuesday night that the US theater missile defense plans had not only angered China, but were likely to destabilize relations between regional powers.
The daily reported that the Australian government, however, takes the opposite view, reflecting the heated debate among security analysts.
The daily quoted a spokesman for Defense Minister John Moore as revealing that the government considered TMD to be an intrinsically defensive system that did not threaten the security of any nation.

"The government's policy is one of strong opposition to the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. Our involvement in the joint facility of activities is designed to counter the destabilising effects of ballistic missile proliferation," the spokesman told the daily. The daily reported Peters made the remarks at a ceremony marking the closure of the US-Australian Joint Defense Facility at Nurrungar, near Woomera in South Australia on Tuesday.

Peters said there would be "absolutely" no weakening in the Australia-US defense ties over the base closure. New technology has, since October 1, allowed satellite information to be transmitted to the US from a new relay station at Pine Gap, near Alice Springs, rendering the Nurrungar base redundant, the daily reported.
The daily reported Peters as saying that Australia retained full access to the information.

The improved technology enables satellites to detect launches of smaller, theater missiles, using satellites of the 30-year-old Defense Support Program, the daily reported. This system will be replaced by the new SBIRS system in 2004, it said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA ATTRACTS MORE ASIAN TOURISTS IN JULY

TEXT.P: Australia has succeeded in luring back tourists from Taiwan, South Korea, Thailand and other Asian countries in July, helping to prop up its recently flagging tourist industry.

The latest figure released by the Australian Tourist Commission shows the number of tourists from Taiwan, Korea and Thailand, once the fastest growing sources of tourists for Australia, surged by between 6.7 percent and 58.5 percent in July from a year ago.
Tourist arrivals from India, Singapore, Malaysia, the Philippines, China and Hong Kong also showed increases, ranging from 4.7 percent to 41.9 percent in the same month compared with a year earlier.
ATC officials said the Australian tourism industry is showing signs of recovery from the effects of the Asian financial crisis over the past two years.
"Australia's performance was exceptional and on track to meet a forecast doubling of inbound tourists by 2008," said Australia's Federal Tourism Minister Jackie Kelly.

"This sustained, strong growth augurs extremely well for continued economic and employment growth across the country. Already Australia's top export industry, tourism's foreign exchange earnings are expected to reach more than A$33 (US$22) billion annually within eight years," she said.

"On-going government investment in tourism promotion, through the Australian Tourist Commission is paying dividends in all markets. This is particularly evident in Asia where ATC strategies have resulted in double-digit growth from all but a handful of major markets," she added.
In the same statement, ATC managing director John Morse said international arrivals in the first seven months of this year were up nearly 6 percent from a year earlier.

"This result indicates arrivals should exceed the official forecast growth of around 4 percent. The Asian economic crisis and the decline in outbound travel from Japan has made the global competition for the tourist dollars stronger than ever. Australia is performing extremely well in these circumstances," Morse said, adding "Our promotional strategies in the Asian markets in particular have been highly effective, ensuring a rapid return to growth."
He said foreign tourist arrivals between January and July 1999 totaled more than 2.47 million, up 5.9 percent from the same period in 1998.

Except for Japan, Hong Kong and Taiwan, tourist arrivals from other Asian countries showed increases from 0.1 to 81.3 percent in the first seven months of this year against the same period last year, according to the ATC.

Arrivals from Japan, the biggest source of tourists for Australia, plunged 6.4 percent to 412,281 in the January to July period from a year ago while the number of tourists from Hong Kong and Taiwan fell 4.6 percent and 1.6 percent respectively, according to the same source. But ATC officials expect more tourists from the ROC, mainland China and Hong Kong will visit Australia in the months ahead despite a devastating earthquake which killed more than 2200 people on Taiwan.

Tourist industry sources said Taiwan and Hong Kong have strong purchasing power and many people there are increasingly fond of traveling overseas to enrich their knowledge. And Australia, with its wilderness, large open spaces, and different scenic spots and attractions can offer a different experience to Asian tourists, they said.
