The local currency opened Wednesday at 31.765 and was traded between 31.763 and 31.774.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$157 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA LIKELY TO RAISE INTEREST RATES DUE TO STRONG GROWTH

TEXT.P: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) is likely to raise its current official interest rate of 4.75 percent to help combat inflationary pressure from heated economic growth, economists predicted.

Economists from Westpac and other major banks in Australia believe the RBA could hike the interest rate by at least 0.25 percent as soon as next February because of a number of factors, including faster than expected growth in the second half of this year and the recovery of the global economy.
Westpac has predicted that Australia's gross domestic product will grow at around 4.7 percent in fiscal 2000-01. Other banks also made similar projections for the country's economic growth rate.
The government has forecast the fiscal 1999-2000 growth rate at around 3.25 to 3.5 percent, but private economists believe it could reach 4 percent or higher in fiscal 1999-2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA VOWS TO STEP UP FIGHT WITH US OVER LAMB EXPORTS

TEXT.P: Australia on Wednesday vowed to step up its fight with the United States over Washington's curb of its lamb exports by seeking a solution at the World Trade Organization, Trade Minister Mark Vaile said.

In a statement faxed to the CNA, Vaile said: "We have not been satisfied with the US government's responses to our requests on their totally unjustified decision to impose tariff quotas on our lamb exports. We have no option but to seek a World Trade Organization dispute settlement panel. Discussions to date have failed. We now have no option but to seek to have the matter heard before a dispute settlement panel."
"The US import restrictions imposed in July on our unsubsidized lamb exports are unfair and unjustifiable under WTO rules, and are simply bad policy for US consumers and US lamb producers," he added.
Australia's lamb exports to the US previously were worth around US$100 million, but the restrictions will reduce its exports sharply.

DOC.HEADLINE: 90% OF CANADIAN STUDENTS HAVE INTERNET ACCESS AT SCHOOL

TEXT.P: Nine out of 10 Canadian students attend schools that are connected to the Internet, according to Statistics Canada figures released Tuesday.

A survey taken last January and February shows that while a majority of schools have access to the Internet, principals and teachers said they need more terminals and more training if they are to expand the use of computers in schools.

The statistics agency said there is, on average, one computer for every seven students in Canadian high schools, one for every eight intermediate (middle high) students and one for every nine elementary students.
Only 12 percent of elementary students and less than three percent of secondary students attend schools without Internet access, Statscan noted.

In Prince Edward Island and New Brunswick, every school was connected to the Internet at the time of the survey. About 65 percent of Island students used e-mail during the last school year, as did 31 percent of New Brunswick students. Nationally, about four students in 10 had used e-mail by the end of the school year.
Computers are mainly used in teaching mathematics and geography, the survey indicates.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMMERCE DEPARTMENT MAKES FINAL DETERMINATIONS IN ANTI-DUMPING CASE
DOC.DATELINE: Ottawa, Oct. 12 (CNA) (By S.C. CHANG) (By Herman Pan)

TEXT.P: Washington, Oct. 22 (CNA The US Department of Commerce (DOC) made its final determinations in the antidumping investigation of DRAM chip producers from Taiwan on Tuesday. The result will be announced at midday of the next business day.
In its preliminary status report, the DOC found that the dumping margins of Taiwan DRAM producers ranged from 4.96% to 30.89% .

"I expect the final weighted-average dumping margin to be higher (than preliminary determinations)", said Christopher Corr, a trade lawyer based in Washington, D.C., who represented several of Taiwan's semiconductor companies.

A DOC official involved in the investigation told CNA that the recent price surge in DRAMs on the global market and the tragic earthquake that happened last month in Taiwan played no role at all in the DOC investigation.

"Don't forget the investigative period of this case is the fourth quarter of 1997 to the third quarter of 1998," the official said. Whatever happened afterwards in Taiwan or in international markets will have no impact on the DOC determinations, he maintained.

If the DOC holds up in its final determinations , the case will go back to the US International Trade Commission (ITC) for final ruling. The ITC has scheduled a final hearing for Oct. 19 and will make the final injury determinations no later than November 26, before the dumping orders can be issued.
The dumping charge against Taiwan chip makers was filed last October by Boise, Idaho-based Micron Technology Inc. , which is the US's largest maker of computer chips.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSERVATIVE MAGAZINE URGES TAIWAN SECURITY ENHANCEMENT ACT PASSAGE

TEXT.P: An American conservative magazine is urging the US Congress to pass the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act without delay and daring President Bill Clinton to veto it, because the legislation is nothing more than an honorable gesture of support for democratic Taiwan.

The Weekly Standard wrote in an editorial in its latest issue that representatives of the World Trade Organization will meet in Seattle at the end of November and the Clinton administration would like to strike a deal for Communist China's accession to the WTO before the meeting begins.

But bilateral negotiations have been going badly and Beijing has lately withdrawn even those necessary trade concessions it initially offered in April. All those American CEOs who went to Shanghai in late September to attend a global forum sponsored by the Fortune magazine were also looking for some signs from the Communist Chinese of a renewed willingness to bargain. Instead, the editorial said, they got bluntly lectured about Taiwan.

In a public speech on September 27, Jiang Zemin reminded his American visitors that "we will not undertake to renounce the use of force" to absorb now-democratic Taiwan into the still-Communist mainland, the Weekly Standard reported. Nor will Beijing "allow" any foreign country to "support" a continued mainland-Taiwan "split."

Three days later, in a private interview in Beijing with these same American executives, Zhu Rongji made explicit Jiang's barely veiled threat, saying the US must "quit emphasizing" that the question of Taiwan should be settled only by peaceful means and Washington must also stop "implying that it would help defend Taiwan" in the event of war. "Otherwise," Zhu warned, "sooner or later it will lead to an armed resolution."

During mainland China's National Day celebrations on Oct. 1, 10,000 People's Liberation Army troops marched under a banner that read "The issue of Taiwan cannot be delayed indefinitely" while nuclear missiles capable of reaching California rumbled through Tiananmen Square. The American government responded to this provocation by immediately capitulating, asserted the editorial.

Less than 24 hours after the Tiananmen Square military parade, the Weekly Standard pointed out, the Clinton White House was leaking word to the Washington Post that it had "mobilized the business community" in an emergency effort to defeat a previously almost invisible piece of legislation called the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act, now pending in both houses of Congress.

The editorial stressed that the legislation is mostly "a restatement of traditional rationale for American support of a free and secure Taiwan. It certainly poses no practical threat to Communist China, nor on its face does it threaten US business activity in China. The legislation authorizes or requires the president to do little on behalf of democratic Taiwan that he is not already authorized or required to do under current law. TSEA is thus an honorable gesture of support for Taiwan, but nothing more."

"The only reason the American business community has to weigh in against such a gesture is to please the government of Communist China. So what started as an effort to build a trade relationship with the mainland has become American eagerness merely to placate Beijing. And US relations with a democratic ally have been corrupted," added the editorial.

Weekly Standard concluded that "the essential nature of engagement with China is revealed. Call it appeasement. There is one institution that can salvage some honor from this disgraceful farce. That is the US Congress, which should pass the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act without delay and dare the president to veto it."

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PREMIER: NO CRIMINAL RING INVOLVEMENT IN POST-QUAKE RESETTLEMENT

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Liu Chao-shiuan on Wednesday announced four principles for post-earthquake resettlement, in which he vowed to prevent underground criminal rings from taking part in post-quake reconstruction projects.
Liu, head of the post-quake reconstruction committee of the Executive Yuan, made the statement during the ruling Kuomintang's (KMT) Central Standing Committee conference.

He stressed that by no means will he allow criminal rings to take advantage of reconstruction projects to financially exploit quake victims and thereby offset efforts the government has been making for resettlement in the aftermath of the devastating Sept. 21 earthquake.

All law enforcement officers have been ordered to comprehensively thwart any plans by criminal rings to participate in reconstruction projects or manipulate bidding for projects of that kind, Liu noted.

In order to keep the difficult and complicated reconstruction work on track, the government has to play the role of locomotive to assure that all quake victims are settled and every victim has a house to live in, Liu noted.

Liu said the following four principles have to be upheld to facilitate the process of reconstruction: respect for human dignity in resettlement, as opposed to merely rebuilding houses and infrastructure; cooperation with the public to jointly carry out the necessary work; prevention of any penetration by underground criminal rings in post-quake reconstruction projects; and concern for victims' psychological recovery.

In collaboration with 47 other experts, the committee has drafted an overall practical plan for people and areas affected by the earthquake, and Premier Vincent Siew will again visit the stricken areas to listen to people's opinions as a complement to the plan, Liu said.

Priority tasks to be carried out by Friday are: inspecting houses; deciding which homes are to be torn down; and determining how much financial aid is to be received and by whom. Demolition of collapsed high-rise buildings will start as soon as next week, and temporary housing will be ready next week. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND MEN OBTAIN RESIDENCY BY MARRYING ELDERLY ROC WOMEN

TEXT.P: At least 300 young men from mainland China have obtained legal residency in the Republic of China over the past six months by marrying elderly Taiwan women, a senior mainland affairs official said on Wednesday.

Liu Teh-hsun, director of the Legal Affairs Department of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said official documents and field surveys show that 300-plus single elderly ROC women in Taipei and Taichung areas have married mainland men 30-to-40 years younger than them during their pleasure trips to mainland China.

Under current ROC regulations, mainland spouses of ROC nationals aged over 65 can stay in Taiwan up to three years and six months for each visit. In comparison, the maximum duration of each visit by mainland spouses of ROC nationals below that age is only six months.
Quoting findings of MAC surveys, Liu said the elderly Taiwan women made trips to mainland China along with tour groups or religious pilgrimage groups under the arrangement of brokerage houses.

"Their marriages with young mainland men were also arranged by brokers," Liu said, adding that the main purpose of the mainland bridegrooms is to obtain residency in Taiwan so that they can legally work here.

Once the mainland bridegrooms are allowed to reside in Taiwan and find suitable jobs, they have to pay their "better halves" NT$5,000 (US$157.23) to NT$10,000 a month, depending on their marriage contracts.
In some cases, mainland bridegrooms can receive monthly pay from their Taiwan "wives" for their caring services, according to MAC surveys.
The number of marriages between the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait has increased steadily since the ROC government lifted a ban on civilian cross-strait exchanges in the late 1980s.

According to MAC tallies, the number of cross-strait marriages has exceeded 50,000. As Beijing authorities remain hostile toward Taiwan, the ROC government has adopted a quota system to regulate the number of mainland spouses to be allowed to reside on the island.

Based on humanitarian considerations, the MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward the mainland, recently decided to double the annual quota from 1,800 people to 3,600 so that more mainland spouses can stay in Taiwan.
In the past, many young mainland women had come to Taiwan to work as prostitutes through bogus marriage arrangements with Taiwan men.
MAC officials said they have asked immigration officers under the Ministry of the Interior to tighten checks of relevant travel papers of mainland visitors.

The MAC and the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) also said they will tighten screening of entry applications by mainlanders with marriage ties with local people to prevent irregularities.
The SEF is an intermediary body authorized by the ROC government to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: INCREASING PUBLIC CONSUMPTION BENEFICIAL TO REHABILITATION: TIER

TEXT.P: The best way to help quake-stricken areas is to increase consumption and economic growth, said the head of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) on Wednesday.
TIER President Wu Rong-I called on the general public during a press conference, asking them to leave their sorrow far behind and do something concrete for the temblor victims.

Wu also urged the government to adopt an expanded financial policy. The issuance of government bonds totaling NT$80 billion for disaster relief and reconstruction may not be adequate, said Wu, adding that the government can take advantage of the emergency order to increase the limits on bond issuance established by the Public Debt Act.
As for how much money would be adequate to fund the overall reconstruction effort, the amount is still being assessed by TIER researchers, Wu disclosed.

In view of the fact that public consumption accounts for 67 percent of the island's GNP, a consumption slump would only slow economic growth, which would be good for no one, the TIER president observed.

He was referring to a general decline in public consumption in the wake of the devastating quake, since most of the public deemed that "joy is a sin" and thus dared not dine out or entertain; all celebration activities were canceled, and no sales promotions were sponsored by any department stores.
The TIER work team made an on-the-spot survey last week following the "921 Earthquake," with assessment focused on the agricultural region and manufacturing areas.
The temblor exerted a negative impact on the island's economic growth, indeed, said the survey. However, economic performance in the year's third quarter was better than expected.
In light of the quake disaster, a decline of 0.5 percent in economic growth is expected, and the government's projected annual growth of 5.5 percent may not be achieved, the survey showed.

Nevertheless, if the brisk economic performance of the third quarter and the increasingly robust economic prospects of the fourth quarter are taken into consideration, the annual growth would still maintain a level of 5.4 percent, the TIER researchers predicted.
A formal report of the investigation will be made public within a month, said Wu, who is the organizer of the survey work team.

Other members of the survey team include: Hong Teh-sheng, vice president of the TIER; Chen Bou-chi, professor of economics at the National Taiwan University; and Professors Wang Lien Chang-fu and Wang Tu-fa of the National Chungshing University.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'MOTHER OF CHIMPANZEES' CONCERNED ABOUT QUAKE-STRICKEN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Renowned British primatologist Dr. Jane Goodall has written a letter to President Lee Teng-hui expressing her concern for Taiwan's situation after a devastating earthquake rattled the central part of the island on Sept. 21.

According to Presidential Office sources, Goodall, better known as "Mother of Chimpanzees," told President Lee in her letter that she is scheduled to arrive in Taiwan on Nov. 10 for her fourth visit to the island in as many years.

In addition to meeting with President Lee, Goodall will travel to various earthquake-stricken areas to express her concern for the well-being of quake-affected Taiwan people during her four-day visit.
Goodall will also inspect operations of the Jane Goodall Institute's Taiwan chapter, which was established in May in 1998 to help promote the "Roots & Shoots" campaign here.

The "Roots & Shoots" campaign, launched by the Jane Goodall Institute, was a conservation program for children. May local elementary and junior high schools have set up "Roots & Shoots" centers to promote natural resources conservation.
During her upcoming visit, Goodall will convey concern and regards for Taiwan's quake-affected people from "Roots & Shoots" promotional centers around the world.

Goodall has achieved fame for her 35 years of devoted research into chimpanzees. She has spent nearly two decades in Africa, in what is now Tanzania's Gombe National Park, researching chimpanzees and baboons. She began promoting global education on wildlife and conservation in 1977 when she set up the Jane Goodall Institute.

In recent years, Goodall has traveled around the world to promote her "Roots & Shoots" campaign. Through the program, Goodall said, "The world's children are taught that to care for the earth and each other is our hope for the future."

DOC.HEADLINE: DALAI LAMA SENDS CONSOLATION TO QUAKE-STRICKEN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Dalai Lama, the exiled spiritual leader of Tibet, prayed for Taiwan's people one day after the devastating earthquake struck Taiwan on Sept. 21, said officials of the Taipei-based Tibet Religious Foundation on Wednesday.

Foundation officials said that they just received a video tape sent by the exiled Tibetan government from Dharmsala, India, showing the Dalai Lama extending his consolation to the people of Taiwan for their suffering caused by the quake.
During a religious ceremony in India on Sept. 22, the Dalai Lama said he was deeply saddened by the extensive loss of life and property in Taiwan resulting from the killer quake.
The Dalai Lama prayed for those who were injured physically and psychologically, wishing them a speedy recovery, and for Taiwan's people to be released from sadness to begin rehabilitation soon.

Regarding repeated requests by followers in Taiwan that the Dalai Lama visit the island again, foundation officials revealed that he said he is most happy to visit Taiwan if his tight schedule allows.
The Tibetan spiritual leader visited Taiwan in March 1997 and has attracted a large following on the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: NETHERLANDS WOOS TAIWAN STUDENTS
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Oct. 13 (CNA) (By P.C. Tang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Netherlands is making efforts to increase cooperation with Taiwan's institutes of higher learning and to entice more Taiwan students to study in the Netherlands, a Dutch education official said on Wednesday.

The official in charge of Asian affairs at the Netherlands Organization for International Cooperation in Higher Education said the organization will hold a series of promotion activities in Taiwan and the Netherlands.

The organization has decided to target Taiwan for its promotion following previous cooperation with Indonesia. The organization had also intended to target Hong Kong, Malaysia, Singapore and South Korea, but after the Asian financial storm in mid-1997, it decided to focus on Taiwan, according to the official.
The official said, "We had not expected the Netherlands to be the top choice of Taiwan students among European countries, but we do hope that it will be one of the top three."
The official remarked that it is common for Taiwan students, who are both diligent and intelligent, to study overseas, and that is the reason for the Netherlands to try to lure more Taiwan students.
Due to the lack of sufficient information in Taiwan about advanced education in the Netherlands, he said less than 100 Taiwan students are currently studying in the Netherlands.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC URGES BEIJING NOT TO HINDER TOP MAINLAND ENVOY'S VISIT

TEXT.P: Mainland China should not set any prerequisites to hinder its top envoy's planned visit to Taiwan, a senior ROC negotiator with the mainland said on Wednesday.

Shi Hwei-yow, vice chairman and secretary-general of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), made the appeal on the eve of the first anniversary of SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu's ice-breaking visit to mainland China.
Shi said the Republic of China government didn't set any conditions for Koo's mainland visit last year.
"We earnestly hope that Beijing authorities will also not impose any prerequisites for top mainland negotiator with Taiwan Wang Daohan's planned Taiwan visit," Shi said.

Wang, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), promised to make a reciprocal visit to Taiwan this year when he met his Taiwan counterpart, Koo, in Shanghai last October.
After two rounds of negotiations between SEF and ARATS officials held earlier this year, the two sides reached a preliminary agreement that Wang would visit Taiwan either in September or October.

However, Beijing broke the promise after ROC President Lee Teng-hui said in an interview with a German radio station in July that relations across the Taiwan Strait should be defined as a "special state-to-state relationship."

Beijing leaders interpreted Lee's declaration as a move to promote Taiwan independence and has since launched saber-rattling against Taiwan. Beijing softened its intimidation and belligerent rhetoric against Taiwan only after the island was rattled by a devastating earthquake on Sept. 21.
Nevertheless, Beijing leaders still insist that Wang would visit Taiwan only after President Lee formally retracts the "special state-to-state relationship" theory.
Shi said Lee's "special state-to-state" remarks only affirm a long-existing reality. Against this backdrop, Shi said, it's unrealistic to ask Lee to retract the "special state-to-state" statement.
As for Taiwan's status and China's future, Shi said the two sides already reached a consensus that each side can have its own definition of the "one China" principle.

For Beijing, the "one China" principle means that the People's Republic of China (PRC) represents whole China and that Taiwan is a province under the PRC. For Taipei, the "one China" is a historical and cultural concept at the moment. It insists that the two sides of the Taiwan Straits have been ruled by two separate and equal governments since 1949 and that "one China" will become a reality only after the two sides are unified under freedom and democracy.
SEF and ARATS are quasi-official intermediary bodies authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.
SEF Chairman Koo made a high-profile visit to the mainland from Oct. 14-19 last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT CHAIRMAN OPPOSES TAIWAN SECURITY ENHANCEMENT ACT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 12 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) on Tuesday said he opposes the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act (TSEA) proposed in the US Congress because it would severely impact trilateral ties among Washington, Taipei and Beijing.
AIT Chairman Richard Bush outlined his position while meeting with members of a Republic of China legislature delegation at a luncheon he hosted to exchange views on the TSEA.
The delegation, led by Yao Eng-chi, vice president of the ROC Legislative Yuan, arrived in Washington on Monday and is scheduled to return to Taipei on Thursday.
No reporters were invited to the luncheon, but some ROC legislators revealed the content of their discussion with Bush to the Central News Agency (CNA).

It was learned that Bush is opposed to legislation of the act because it is not in accordance with current US policy. Bush said the Taiwan Relations Act has been operating well for the past 20 years, and the executive branch should retain the right to deal with diplomatic and military affairs.

The TSEA was proposed by Jesse Helms (R-NC), chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, and by Thomas DeLay (R-TX), House of Representatives' Republican party whip, in the US Senate and House of Representatives, respectively.

The main features of the TSEA are: establishment of a direct contact channel between the US Pacific Command and Taiwan's military, submission of an annual report by the executive branch on Taiwan's arms procurement needs, and authorization by Congress of executive branch intention to sell sophisticated weapons to Taiwan.

The US State Department and Defense Department have openly opposed legislation of the TSEA, claiming that there is no need for such a law, that it probably violates the Constitution, and that it will have a negative effect on Taiwan's security.

It is believed that the act will probably be passed by the House of Representatives. However, it will be hard to achieve the two-thirds majority in both the Senate and the House of Representatives that is needed to override a presidential veto.

Yao told CNA that people from all walks of life in the United States have speedily provided assistance to Taiwan following the "921 Earthquake" that caused significant casualties, and that both the US Senate and House of Representatives have adopted resolutions to express their sympathy and support for the Republic of China.

Yao said he led the delegation to visit the United States mainly to express the ROC government and people's gratitude for post-quake assistance and because he hopes that the relationship between both countries' legislative branches can be further enhanced.

While talking with ROC legislators, Bush praised the ROC government for its efficiency in the quake-relief efforts and lauded overseas Chinese for their enthusiasm in providing monetary and material aid to Taiwan's quake victims.
ROC legislators also called on Sen. Mary Landrieu (D-LA) later on Tuesday. They discussed Taiwan's post-quake relief and reconstruction efforts and Beijing's politicization of the earthquake.

Beijing's Foreign Minister Tang Jiaxuan had stated at a press conference held in New York following the quake that Taiwan will always be an unseverable part of China and that he represented the people of Taiwan in thanking the international community for providing assistance to the island. His remarks angered Taipei.
Sen. Landrieu was surprised by Beijing's action and promised to pay more attention to the matter in the future.
ROC lawmakers will call on other heavyweights at the US Senate and House of Representatives on Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN COOPERATIVE BANK'S MANILA BRANCH TO FORMALLY OPEN FRIDAY

TEXT.P: The Manila branch of Taipei-based Taiwan Cooperative Bank will start operations on Friday, it was announced here on Wednesday.
Lee Wen-hsiung, president of Taiwan Cooperative Bank, will preside over the opening ceremony to be held at a hotel in downtown Manila.
Taiwan Cooperative Bank will be the third Taiwan bank to open a branch in Manila. The International Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) and Chinatrust Commercial Bank (CTCB) already have Manila branches.

Taiwan's First Commercial Bank, the United World Chinese Commercial Bank and E. Sun Bank, which have set up representative offices in Manila, have applied to set up branch banks in the Philippine capital.

Tsai Cheng-chieh, manager of the Manila branch of Taiwan Cooperative Bank, said that because operations will be confined to OBU (offshore banking unit) services, the branch will only conduct transactions in foreign currencies.
In the initial stage, the bank will concentrate its services on loans and bond transactions. The branch will cooperate with ICBC and CTCB to provide greenback loans to business leaders from Taiwan.
Taiwan Cooperative Bank set up its representative office in Manila on Nov. 6, 1995. (Timothy Sun & Edward Chen)

DOC.HEADLINE: QUAKE HELPS TAIWAN PEOPLE REGAIN FORGOTTEN STRENGTH: BUDDHIST MASTER

TEXT.P: Taiwan people have recuperated their forgotten strength and have found countless rays of kindness in the wake of the cataclysmic earthquake that struck the island on Sept. 21, said Buddhist Master Sheng Yen on Wednesday.

Although the devastating quake dealt a deadly blow to the island, which was formerly considered socially and politically chaotic, the experience enabled Taiwan to demonstrate its true colors -- highlighting the good-heartedness of its people and its solid resources and strong vitality, Sheng Yen said.

Founder of the well-known Dhama Drum Mountain Cultural and Educational Foundation, Sheng Yen said that after weathering the devastating quake, people in Taiwan, particularly those in earthquake-stricken areas, need a shot in the arm to help them repel fear and regain peace of mind.

The urgent need prompted him and his organization to print 1 million copies of "At Ease DIY" pamphlets to be distributed to people in quake-affected areas and to others elsewhere who might benefit from them, Sheng Yen said.
He added that the pamphlets will help people with easy do-it-yourself approaches to mental rehabilitation, allowing injured souls to heal by themselves.
Sheng Yen made the donation of the 1 million pamphlets at a ceremony at the Ministry of Education.

Recognizing the Buddhist group's compassionate deed, Education Minister Yang Chao-shiang said he would personally be a mail carrier for Dhama Drum Mountain and deliver the pamphlets to people in quake-stricken areas.

Sheng Yen said that in order to facilitate mental and spiritual rehabilitation efforts, the Dhama Drum Mountain Foundation will train 5,000 volunteers to work with people, mainly in the quake-affected areas, to help them become free from fear and grief, and find for themselves their lost power and confidence.

DOC.HEADLINE: SELECTION OF CLOUD GATE TO DANCE AT OLYMPICS BIG HONOR FOR TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The selection of the Cloud Gate Dance Theater to perform during the 2000 Olympic Games in Sydney is a big honor and encouragement for the Republic of China on Taiwan, Lin Hwai-min, founder and head of the world-renowned company, said on Wednesday.

In an interview with the Central News Agency, Lin said only a few top dance companies have been chosen to perform during the Olympic Arts Festival from August 18 to September 30 next year. Troupes were selected from Australia, Britain, Germany, Taiwan and the United States.

"The selection of our dance troupe to perform during the Olympic Games is very significant and encouraging for Taiwan because it's a top honor," he said. "This will be the first time for our company to perform at the Olympic Games," he added.

Lin said all dance companies chosen to perform during the Olympic Games are top-notch troupes well-known all over the world. "I feel very glad that my troupe can have the chance to perform with other well-known dance companies in Sydney next year," he said.

Other famous dance companies chosen to perform are Pina Bausch from Germany, Bill T. Jones and Amie Zane Dance Company from the United States, and DV8 Physical Theater from Britain. Lin said the Cloud Gate Dance Theater is the only Asian troupe selected.

He said Cloud Gate will stage nine performances, to be held between August 19 and 22 and from August 25 to 27. The performances will feature the company's latest productions of "Nine Songs" and "Moon Water" at Her Majesty's Theater in Sydney.

The performances will mark the Australian premiere of the two productions, Lin said, adding, "We were well-received in Berlin in August when we performed in front of the German audience." He believed the two productions would receive the same reception in Australia when the troupe makes its fourth visit to that country.
Since its establishment 26 years ago, the Cloud Gate Dance Theater has had numerous performances in the United States, Europe and Asia, Lin said.

But he said the Cloud Gate Dance Theater will grace Taipei with its performance to greet the dawn of the new millennium. "Burning the Pine Branches" will be performed starting at 10:20 p.m. on December 31 and ending at the very beginning of the year 2000.
The company will then travel overseas to stage more performances before continuing to Sydney in August.

During its 26-year history, Lin said the troupe has trained many dancers for Cloud Gate so that new blood can achieve a high standard of dancing techniques in order to perform in many countries around the world.
"We will continue to move on and maintain our high standard of performances in the years to come," he added. (by Peter Chen)

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIAN MILITARY TO DISARM MILITIAS, COOPERATE WITH INTERFET

TEXT.P: Indonesia's Defense Minister General Wiranto has indicated that his military will disarm pro-Jakarta militias and cooperate with the Australian-led UN peacekeeping troops (Interfet) along the West Timorese border.

Australia's Channel Nine TV Network on Wednesday morning quoted Wiranto as saying that his troops would be cooperative with the UN peace keepers to "avoid miscommunication and misunderstanding" along the 250-kilometer border between East and West Timor.

"My troops would like to invite Interfet for a joint patrol ... on the border ... to avoid miscommunication, etc. that could cause casualties and international problems," he told reporters in the border hamlet of Motaain, the scene of a fatal clash between the Indonesian army, militias and the Interfet in which one Indonesian policeman was killed and two others wounded on Sunday.
The network reported that the Indonesian army would disarm militiamen in order to avoid similar incidents from happening again.

In Jakarta, the Sydney Morning Herald on Wednesday quoted Major-General Sudrajat, a military spokesman, as saying that Wiranto's comments meant that hundreds of pro-Jakarta militias in West Timor would be disarmed.
"We do not want this area to become a stronghold or base for the pro-integrationists," he said.
Channel Nine also quoted an Interfet spokesman as saying that the UN peace keepers would be very cautious in their patrol so that they did not cross West Timor's border.

In Jakarta, newly elected chairman to the People's Consultative Assembly (MPR) Dr. Amien Rais told a business breakfast on Tuesday that Indonesia's next president would lose many of the authoritarian powers built up by former President Soeharto and would be made accountable to the parliament once a year and could be impeached if the circumstances justified it.

"So we will hold an annual session to listen to the accountability speech of the president. If accepted, the president can then go ahead with his or her programs. But if we see that there are a lot of deviations, a lot of wrong doings, a lot of corruption, collusion and nepotism, we may vote for a special session of the assembly to impeach the president or to call a new election," Rais said.
In Sydney, the East Timorese independence leader Xanana Gusmao urged Timorese people not to kill in revenge despite the past mistakes of the Indonesian army and its pro-Jakarta militias.

Gusmao said he would go home next week to a new country where he would ask his people to look forward, not back. "Of course, it will be with sadness that I return home, because my country has been destroyed and I remember the same destruction in 1975 when the Indonesians invaded." he told reporters on Tuesday.
In Dili, however, Bishop Carlos Belo, who returned home last week, said the Indonesian army must admit their mistake in a show of regret for destroying East Timor and killing people.
He said he would ask the United Nations to install a civilian administration to help East Timor in nation building.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIALS CONCERNED ABOUT SITUATION IN KINMEN AFTER TYPHOON

TEXT.P: John Chang, secretary general of the ruling Kuomintang, on Wednesday traveled to Kinmen to assess the situation faced by the typhoon-ravaged offshore outpost.
Chang said he wants to convey the concern of KMT Chairman and ROC President Lee Teng-hui to the people of Kinmen after its worst disaster in the past three decades.
Chang was briefed by Kinmen County Magistrate Chen Shui-tsai on the havoc wreaked by typhoon Dan and the official's request for assistance from the central government.

Chen has asked that the Ministry of Transportation and Communications help rebuild Liaolo Harbor, provide technicians to repair damaged power and water lines, and use special funds to reconstruct major infrastructure. He also requested that the Department of Health supply disinfectant and medicine and that the army support post-typhoon construction projects for three months.
Earlier, former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong and Minister without Portfolio Yang Shih-chien also went to Kinmen to inspect the damage caused by the typhoon.
Though no casualties were reported during the typhoon, more than 300 houses collapsed from strong winds, and half of the island is still without water supply.

Forestry efforts over the past 30 years went down the drain overnight, with 390,000 trees felled by powerful winds. It is estimated that it will take at least 10 years for the lush landscape to recover.
The Council of Agriculture (COA) has proclaimed Kinmen a disaster area after losses in production value of agricultural products were estimated at NT$80 million (US$2.51 million).

The island's sorghum was so badly damaged that the autumn harvest will fall 2 million kilograms short of the previous estimate. The Kinmen County government is planning to apply for imports of red sorghum from mainland China to make up for the shortage.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO ARISE FROM QUAKE RUINS: ROC REP. IN FRANCE
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Oct. 13 (CNA) (By Chow Ming-jie & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Kuo Wei-fan, the Republic of China's representative in France, on Wednesday expressed the ROC government and people's gratitude for French assistance after the Sept. 21 Taiwan earthquake that claimed more than 2,300 lives.
The envoy assured his French audience that Taiwan will arise from the ruins of the quake's aftermath.
Kuo made the statements during an exclusive online live interview with Alain Wang of the French internet enterprise Canal Web on Tuesday.
Kuo, on behalf of the ROC government and people, expressed heartfelt thanks for the humanitarian assistance rendered by French people from all walks of life for the earthquake victims.

In the same interview, Kuo explained President Lee Teng-hui's redefinition of relations between the two sides of Taiwan Strait as a "special state-to-state relationship" and stressed that Taiwan will rise up from the quake ruins.
Kuo said that after the earthquake, more than 80 countries around the world expressed their condolences and concerns through every means to the ROC government and people.
A total of 41 rescue teams -- representing 21 countries, the United Nations, and various religious organizations -- came to Taiwan to help rescue survivors. France sent three rescue teams.
After the earthquake, the estimate for the island's economic growth rate, which had been projected to reach 5.74 percent for this year, was readjusted to 5.5 percent, Kuo said.
Taiwan has experienced both economic and political miracles in the past five decades and will undoubtedly rise up from the quake ruins, Kuo stressed.
Kuo went on to say that a great majority of Taiwanese have expressed their displeasure with Beijing's politicization of the international community's assistance to quake victims.

Beijing even forced an airliner carrying a Russian rescue team to make a detour around mainland airspace, delaying its arrival in Taiwan for many hours and thereby preventing the chance to save more quake survivors, Kuo noted.

Referring to President Lee's redefinition of cross-strait relations as a "special state-to-state relationship," he said that the peaceful reunification of China requires patience and time. China should be reunited in the future under the principles of democracy, liberty and economic equality. However, Kuo pointed out that Beijing's refusal to renounce taking Taiwan by force is the main obstacle to future negotiations for China's reunification.
As for process of economic development, Kuo said that Taiwan has been developing a hi-tech industry that now accounts for 40 percent of its total exports.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE CHAMBER OF TRADE AND COMMERCE DONATES US$ 69,180 TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Noboru Deura, president of the Japanese Chamber of Trade and Commerce in Taipei, on Wednesday presented a check for NT$2.2 million (US$69,180) to the government of the Republic of China.
Interior Minister Huang Chu-wen accepted the check on behalf of the ROC government.
Deura also supplied information on measures taken in the wake of the 1995 Kobe earthquake and on the subsequent analysis of the effectiveness of those measures.

Deura was positive about the speedy rescue and relief work by the government and private sector, adding that he believed the speed and efficiency of quake rescue and relief efforts here were better than those of Japan after the Kobe temblor.

He also said that he was impressed by the repeated visits of President Lee Teng-hui, Vice President Lien Chan and Premier Vincent Siew to quake-stricken areas to learn about the situation and help solve problems of the people there.
Lee also signed the emergency decree soon after the killer temblor to facilitate reconstruction work, Deura said.

Huang expressed appreciation for the monetary donation and also for the efforts of Japanese rescue teams that rushed to Taiwan right after the quake and for the temporary housing units provided by Japan for the resettlement of quake-affected people.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE CRITIC URGES JAPAN TO ENGAGE IN COOPERATION WITH TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Oct. 13 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: A Japanese military commentator said in an article published by Sapio magazine that Japan should engage in security cooperation with Taiwan and South Korea, while maintaining its ally relationship with the United States as an axis.

Junhiko Kawamura said mainland China's ambition to invade Taiwan is being checked by the presence of the Seventh Fleet of the US Navy, the Japan-US Security Treaty and Taiwan's efforts to improve its defense capability.

However, the former vice president of a Japanese military academy noted that nobody can foretell when the present military equilibrium might collapse, and if mainland China made a miscalculation, it might use military force against Taiwan, forcing Japan to take self-defensive action.

In case Taiwan is attacked, Kawamura said, the US is obliged to intervene to defend Taiwan in accordance with the Taiwan Relations Act, and Japan could not sit idly by because to do so would be a breach of the Japan-US Security Treaty.
Because the Japan-US Security Treaty cannot be replaced at present, he said, Japan should make the treaty a top priority and strengthen cooperation relations with South Korea and Taiwan.

The commentator said that Japan is unlikely to forge direct ally relationships with South Korea and Taiwan now because of political realities, and the best way to enhance relations with the two neighbors is through Japan's ally relationship with the US.

DOC.HEADLINE: STANDARD AND POOR'S POSITIVE ON TAIWAN RATINGS

TEXT.P: The credit rating institution Standard and Poor's on Wednesday gave a positive rating to Taiwan and said that its long term prospects remained "stable."
The New York-based rating group gave a "AA plus" for long-term credit ratings and an "A-1 plus" for short-term ratings on the island.

It said that the positive ratings reflect strong foreign assets and paltry foreign debt, noting that the foreign assets of banking institutions in Taiwan and the Central Bank of China should outnumber the nation's foreign debts by NT$100 billion this year.
Taiwan also has huge foreign reserves, ranking third in the world next only to Japan and mainland China. It is estimated that Taiwan's foreign reserves will top US$100 billion by the end of the year.
Huge foreign reserves and the island's creditor position also helped Taiwan emerge from the recent financial storm unscathed.

The rating institution also cited the strong export-oriented economy of Taiwan, saying that Taiwan has a flexible labor force and lively small- and medium-sized enterprises to sustain the economy and employment growth.
Though the massive Sept. 21 earthquake had a negative impact, the outlook for Taiwan growth is still favorable.

But the good ratings were constrained by the potential vulnerability posed by cross-strait relations, saying that mainland China's demands for unification and its sporadic military intimidation oblige Taiwan to maintain a high degree of military preparedness and huge defense spending.
Standard and Poor's estimated that Taiwan will adopt some measures to alleviate the impact of the earthquake in two years, but they are not expected to erode its advantages.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Thursday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
President Lee Teng-hui reiterates post-quake compensation pledge.
The China Times:
Suspect nabbed for murder, dismembering three women -- a mother and her two daughters.
The United Daily News:
Police arrested a suspect for allegedly killing and dismembering three women.
The Liberty Times:

The Commons Daily:
Taiwan Fertilizer Co. and Hua Hsia Leasing Co. were implicated in financial scandals.
The China Post:

Academia Sinica chief quits reconstruction post.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Oct. 14, or the sixth day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1066: Duke William of Normandy becomes new ruler of England after defeating English under King Harold of England in a hard-fought battle near Hastings.
1890: Dwight D. Eisenhower, US military commander in Europe in World War II, and twice president of the United States after the war, iss born.
1909: The Ching court sets up government counsellor bureaus in each of its 22 provinces except Sinkiang, marking the beginning of the House of Commons in China.
1912: Theordore Roosevel, the 26th president of the United States, is shot in an attempted assassination before assuming the presidency. He wan the 1906 Nobel Peace Prize for his mediation in the Russo-Japanese war.
1913: An explosion at Universal Colliery in South Wales kills 439 miners in Britain's worst mining disaster.
1915: The Interior Ministry of the National government orders a halt to the bad practice of binding the feet of women. times.
1920: Oxford University, the oldest universities in Britain and one of the world's most famous institutions of higher learning, grant degrees to women for the first time.
1933: Nazi Germany walks out of the Geneva Disarmament Conference and the League of Nations.
1939: The Royal Navy battleship Royal Osk is torpedoed and sinks in Scapa Flow, killing 810 people.
1944: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the National government, summons 100,000 young intellectuals to join the army and organizes them into an expeditionary force of 10 divisions.
1944: Field Marshall Erwin Rommel, one of Nazi Germany's finest military leaders, known as "Desert Fox," dies at the age of 53. He commanded the Afrika Korps with distinction during the North African campaign from 1941 to 1943.
1947: The Bell X-1 becomes the first aircraft to fly faster than sound when the rocket-powered craft, piloted by Major Charles Yeager, USAF, is taken to a height of 9,700 meters under a B-29 Superfortress mother-plane. The test begins at 22,700 meters and the maximum speed achieved is Mach 1.05, held for several seconds.
1977: The construction of the Shihkang Dam, capable of supplying 420,000 metric tons of water daily, is completed in central Taiwan.
1977: The much-loved entertainer Bing Crosby collapses and dies after completing a round of golf near Madrid. He was 73. One of his most successful films was "High Society," with Grace Kelly and Frank Sinatra.
1958: Madagascar becomes a self-governing state in the French Community, It gained independence in 1960. French influence remains strong in the country, which was called the Malagasy Republic.
1964: Martin Luther King JR., American cleric who formed the foundation of the civil rights movement of the 1950's and 1960's, is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize. He was assassinated in Memphis, Tennessee, four years later.
1973: Thanom Kittikachorn is forced to resign as prime minister of Thailand, after violent clashes between troops and student protestors. He is succeeded by Sanya Thammasak.
1991: Aung San Suu Kyi, Burmese pro-democracy leader, held under house arrest for more than two years by Burmese military rulers, wins the Nobel Peace Prize.
1992: Shin Kanemaru, Japanese political leader, resigns from Japan's parliament following criticism of his role in a scandal tying the Liberal Democratic Party to organized crime.
1993: The United Nations General Assembly ends a two-week general debate during which a total of 23 nations express their support for ROC membership in the world body.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The moral man knows that accomplishment of great things consists in doing little things well. He knows that great effects are produced by small cuases. He knows the evidence and reality of what cannot be perceived by the senses. Thus he is enabled to enter into the world of ideas and morals."

DOC.HEADLINE: AGE RANGE OF TAIWANESE STUDENTS IN US KEEPS EXPANDING: AIT

TEXT.P: The age range of Taiwanese students seeking an education in the United States has been found to be expanding upward and downward, sources from the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) reported on Thursday.

The fact that more Taiwanese people in various age groups are seeking an education in the United States indicates that "studying in America" is no longer exclusively the dream of fresh college graduates from Taiwan, said Kaohsiung-based AIT officials in charge of educational and business affairs.

They noted that more Taiwanese people aged over 40 are now seeking advanced studies in the US as the "life-time learning" trend takes off. The number of Taiwanese children studying in the States has also been found to be steadily increasing, the officials said.
In addition to an expanded age range, the goals of Taiwanese students and what they are studying have also become more diversified, they said.

The United States has always been the top choice of most Taiwanese students, absorbing an average of 13,000 of them each year in recent years, or about 49 percent of all the Taiwanese students seeking an education overseas.
In 1998, 30,855 Taiwanese went to the United States to study, making them the fifth largest group of foreign students in that country.

Among the 3,600-odd colleges and universities in the United States, the University of Southern California has been the most popular school for Taiwanese students, attracting 726 of them to enroll last year, according to the AIT officials.
An American education exposition week is scheduled to kick off in the southern port city of Kaohsiung on Sunday with over 50 educational institutes from the United States participating.

DOC.HEADLINE: US SHOULDN'T TRY INFLUENCING TAIWAN QUESTION SAYS EXPERT

TEXT.P: The United States should not be trying to influence the outcome of the Taiwan question and should not express an opinion as to whether reunification is the right answer for mainland China and Taiwan, said a renowned American China specialist Wednesday.

Ross Terrill, a research associate at the Fairbank Center for East Asian Studies at Harvard University, told the "Voice of America" radio station that the Taiwan question is "no longer just a matter of finishing the Chinese civil war by reuniting the country."

The transfer of Taiwan to the People's Republic of China today would change the balance of power in Asia -- something that would not have happened in 1949, stressed Terrill. He agrees with those who say Beijing's desire for reunification with Taiwan now "is a matter of strategic interest, not purely an emotional desire to reunify the motherland."

Therefore, the China expert pointed out, the United States should not be trying to influence the outcome of the Taiwan question. "Our role is not to solve the Taiwan problem, but to prevent it from being solved in the wrong way and to prevent it from being interpreted in the wrong way," said Terrill.

VOA reported that the US Congress is considering legislation that would upgrade the American military relationship with Taiwan and such an action would be sure to anger Communist China, which is considering changes in its own approach to Taiwan.

But China expert Stephen Yates said the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act being considered by Congress is not intended to change US policy. The pending bill "would provide a more specific interpretation of the 1979 Taiwan Relations Act," said the senior policy analyst at the Washington-based Heritage Foundation.

"It calls for an increase in contact between the Taiwan military and the US military, not for the purposes of creating an alliance, but for the purpose of delivering on the intent, or at least the understood intent, of the Taiwan Relations Act -- to help Taiwan be capable of defending itself," added Yates.

Yates said the bill is designed to ensure Taiwan has access to high technology weaponry, on which he believes Taiwan is going to have to rely more than conventional forces to defend itself. And this may mean that the United States could stay on the sidelines and not be directly involved in defending Taiwan, he pointed out.

"The United States intent is not to interpose itself between Taiwan and the mainland. And it's not necessarily sending a political signal to Taiwan by considering this legislation, but for our own interests finds these moves to be necessary," stressed the senior policy analyst.

However, Hong Kong journalist Willy Wo-Lap Lam cautioned the United States against upgrading the level of weapons it sells to Taiwan. Beijing has said it will not tolerate the US sale to Taiwan of high technology related to a theater missile defense, and it would hurt PRC-US relations and could spark another round of anti-American protests in Beijing and Shanghai, said the China editor of the South China Morning Post.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE THREATS COUNTERPRODUCTIVE SAYS EXPERT

TEXT.P: The more Beijing tries to intimidate Taiwan, the more "likely the result would be to kill any desire among Taiwan's people for reunification," said American China specialist Stephen Yates on Wednesday.

Yates, a senior policy analyst at the Washington-based Heritage Foundation told the "Voice of America" radio station that Communist China is making a mistake if it tries to take even limited military action against Taiwan, because every military scenario that Beijing might be contemplating is likely to be counterproductive. He said he hopes Communist China would instead focus on sending more favorable signals to Taiwan.

VOA reported that as Taiwan's presidential elections approach in March of next year, the government in Beijing is watching closely and, some observers believe, preparing for a possible limited military action against Taiwan.

The radio station quoted Hong Kong journalist Willy Wo-Lap Lam as saying that Communist China's top leaders were making preparations for some kind of military action as a way to punish Taiwan President Lee Teng-hui for saying in July that mainland China and Taiwan should treat each other as equal states.

"It would be along the lines of the 1979 so-called punitive expedition against Vietnam, which means that if they were to do it this time against Taiwan, they would just go in for a few days, take over one or two outlying islands -- for example Quemoy or Matsu -- and then there would be no long-term occupation. They would just be there for a few days. As a result, the Taiwan economy would collapse, they would teach Lee Teng-hui a lesson, and then afterwards withdraw," said Lam.

The Chinese editor of the South China Morning Post and a former corespondent in Beijing noted that Communist Chinese army leaders were convinced that such a limited action would not draw in US forces in defense of Taiwan, but mainland China's top leaders could not agree on what action to take and at what time during their annual meeting at the seaside resort of Beidaihe in August.

So, Lam said, they decided to wait until after Taiwan's presidential elections in March, when they will have a better sense of what policy the next Taiwan leader will adopt. If the new president distances himself from Lee Teng-hui's so-called "two states" statement, the Communist Chinese army may drop its plan for a punitive strike against Taiwan.

Nevertheless, he pointed out, President Jiang Zemin has instructed military officials to continue their preparations for war and make sure that they are totally prepared and have total confidence in winning the war against Taiwan.

But Lam said the recent devastating earthquake in Taiwan gave authorities in Beijing another reason to delay military action. In his words, it would not look good for Communist China to stage provocative war games when the world is seeing such a natural disaster in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOBEL-WINNING CANADIAN ECONOMIST HELPED INSPIRE EURO

TEXT.P: The winner of this year's Nobel Prize for economics, Canadian Robert Mundell, was one of the inspirations behind the creation of the single European currency, the euro.
Although Mundell didn't participate directly in its planning, he did develop one of the first plans for a European common currency. His work was hailed by economists as groundbreaking.

His theories clarified how exchange rates fluctuate when a government shifts from a flexible to a fixed monetary policy. The Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences said Mundell's most important work was done in the 1960s.

Mundell told the Canadian Broadcasting Corp.'s Newsworld that he concentrated on examples within the Canadian economy. The issue of whether the Canadian dollar should have a fixed or flexible exchange rate against the US dollar led him to believe that more than one country could be optimum for a single currency because different areas have different economic cycles.
Mundell said he was pleased and surprised by the announcement. He heard the news second-hand from his son in Los Angeles on Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA OFFICIALS MUM OVER PNG FOREIGN MINISTER'S BEIJING VISIT

TEXT.P: Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) officials on Thursday declined to comment on remarks made by Papua New Guinea (PNG) Foreign Minister Michael Somare in Beijing Wednesday concerning Taiwan.

Reports said that during a meeting with mainland Chinese Vice President Hu Jintao, Somare reiterated PNG's "one China policy" and declared that his country "will not develop official relations with Taiwan." Somare, who arrived in Beijing on Oct. 11, has also met with mainland Chinese Foreign Minister Tang Jaixuan.

MOFA officials said they are closely monitoring the Beijing visit by Somare, the highest-ranking PNG official to visit mainland China since the Republic of China and PNG established formal diplomatic relations on July 5.

Controversy been brewing ever since the forging of the diplomatic ties as Beijing continues trying to bring PNG under its fold in an obvious attempt to further alienate the South Pacific nation from Taiwan.
MOFA officials declined to speculate on how the ambiguous Taipei-PNG-Beijing relations will develop, but they are certain that Beijing will continue attempting to lure PNG away from Taiwan.

Former PNG Prime Minister Bill Skate and Foreign Minister Roy Yaki struck an agreement with ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu on July 5 in Taipei for the establishment of formal diplomatic ties between the two countries.
Skate resigned from office two days later, casting a shroud over the already volatile diplomatic situation.

Astounded by Skate's move, ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu, regarded as the driving force behind the deal, told a local television station that Taipei has "nothing to lose" even if the new PNG government spurns the ROC.
On July 7, ROC government spokesman Chen Chien-jen said the Taiwan-PNG ties "never involved monetary aid or loans."

Despelling rumors that Taiwan bought the new ties at a cost of US$2.5 billion, Chen stressed that Taiwan "will not, is unwilling to, and cannot afford" such a massive amount of cash aid to PNG, stating that MOFA has an annual budget of only US$1 billion.

PNG, which maintains formal diplomatic ties with mainland China, was following a "dual recognition" formula when it struck the diplomatic deal with Taiwan. The ROC and PNG signed an accord in 1995 for "mutual recognition," a step short of formal diplomatic relations between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA'S CITIC MAKES INROADS IN AUSTRALIAN REAL ESTATE

TEXT.P: Mainland China's key investment corporation CITIC has made inroads into Australia's real estate industry with its first purchase of a small apartment block on the fringes of central Sydney for A$10 (US$6.3) million.

In a joint venture with a Chinese property developer in Sydney, CITIC, which has widespread investments outside China, is buying the Old Waterloo Tavern in order to develop a 30-unit residential apartment block plus four commercial suites, according to local news reports.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE STUDENTS PROTEST EDUCATION DEREGULATION PROPOSAL

TEXT.P: Thousands of Australian students in Melbourne, Sydney and Brisbane marched towards the offices of Federal Education Minister David Kemp and the Liberal Party on Thursday in protest over a government plan to deregulate education, copying a US-style system.
Student union leaders told reporters that they were very angry with Kemp's sweeping shake-up of the university sector that would introduce a "voucher" fees system for students.
Prime Minister John Howard on Thursday denied that his government would introduce the US-style educational system in Australia, saying the plan was only a proposal by the education minister.

DOC.HEADLINE: TENSIONS BUILD AS MILITIAS REGROUP, CROSS INTO E. TIMOR

TEXT.P: Tensions are resurfacing after pro-Indonesia militias were reported to have regrouped and crossed into the buffer zone between East and West Timor in preparation for a full-scale war with the Australian-led UN peacekeeping force (Interfet).

Channel Nine TV Network on Thursday morning reported that hundreds of militiamen were crossing the buffer zone along the border of West and East Timor after the Interfet troops were ordered by its commander Major General Peter Cosgrove to keep at least one kilometer away from the West Timor border in a bid to smooth relations with Indonesia.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA STEPS UP PUSH TO BECOME REGIONAL FINANCIAL CENTER

TEXT.P: The Federal Government is stepping up its push to turn Australia into a regional financial center to compete with Singapore, Hong Kong and Japan, according to the Department of Financial Services.

Financial Services Minister Joe Hockey on Wednesday night told reporters that the Federal Government has initially made successful attempts to appoint Les Hosking, chief executive of the Sydney Futures Exchange, to head a full-time post with the Australian Center for Global Finance in January.
