DOC.HEADLINE: ROC HAS REALIZED CONSCIOUS EVOLUTION UNDER LEADERSHIP OF PRES. LEE
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Oct. 13 (CNA) (By Kuo Wu-hueng and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China has realized a conscious evolution and the achievement of being ranked as a rich country under the leadership of President Lee Teng-hui, said an ROC official Wednesday at an international forum in Prague.

Clement Chang, senior adviser to ROC President Lee, made the remarks during a speech at the "Year 2000 Forum," which was held in the capital of the Czech Republic and attended by more than 1,000 business leaders, government officials, scholars and religious leaders.
The forum's topic was titled "The Process of World Integrity -- Visions That Are Available for Choice."
Chang gave the speech in his capacity as president of the World Federation of Freedom and Democracy.
Analyzing world trends for the 21st century, Chang indicated that conscious evolution and spiritual and material wealth are common goals of humankind.
He urged that with the arrival of an era of globalization, all peoples should work hand in hand to establish a common global standard of ethics.

Chang also stressed that the ROC, under the leadership of President Lee, has realized a conscious evolution and has made the achievement of being considered one of the world's rich countries. He said the ROC is willing to share its experience in various developments with developing nations.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES, INDEX FUTURES UP

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed only 0.5 percent higher Thursday after opening lower due to overnight Wall Street losses and the final US ruling to impose anti-dumping duties on Taiwan DRAM producers.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index rose 42.97 points to close at 7,879.91.
A total of 2.63 billion shares changed hands in a turnover of NT$103.3 billion (US$3.25 billion).
The market opened 59.24 points lower but later bargain-hunting pushed up the index. Heavy buying by government-affiliated funds and institutional buyers also helped lift up the index.

Among the eight major stock categories, the paper-making sector took the lead, ending the day with 2.3-percent gains, followed by textiles issues at 1.1 percent and by plastics and chemical issues and electronics shares, both at 1 percent.
Financial issues, gradually emerging from the shadow of mortgage loan losses, listed minor gains of 0.5 percent.
The rest -- plastics and chemical shares, construction stocks and foodstuff shares -- all reported losses ranging from 0.3 percent to 0.8 percent.
Declining stocks led advancing stocks 236 to 217, with 80 shares unchanged.
The over-the-counter market climbed 5.83 points to close at 183.93 on a turnover of NT$7.84 billion.

TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for October moved up 72 points to close at 7,900 with 1,646 contract transactions. Those for November climbed 92 points to finish at 7,927 with 532 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for December rose 50 points to close at 7,890 with seven contract transactions while those for next March climbed 60 points to end at 7,940 with nine contract transactions. Those for next June advanced 60 points to end at 7,940 with five contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Wednesday were 7,828 points for October, 7,835 points for November, 7,840 points for December, 7,880 points for next March, and 7,880 points for next June.
Electronics futures and financial futures, which are sub-index futures and based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares (TE) and financial shares (TF), both reported gains.

October TE futures rose 4 points to close at 375 with 338 contract transactions; November TE futures advanced 5.2 points to end at 377 with 49 contract transactions; December TE futures remained unchanged to close at 370 points with one contract transaction.
There were no transaction records for next March or next June TE futures.

October TF futures rose 5 points to close at 985 with 73 contract transactions, November TF futures advanced 12 points to close at 990 with seven contract transactions; TF futures for other months had no transaction records. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: ALLIANCE FORMED TO DETER GANGLAND FINGERS IN RECONSTRUCTION PROJECTS

TEXT.P: An alliance of legislators, scholars and structural engineers was formally established Thursday aiming at guarding against gangland involvement in post-earthquake public reconstruction projects.

The Post-Earthquake Public Reconstruction Projects Supervisory Alliance became operational immediately after it came into being Thursday, vowing to ensure the integrity of open bidding for projects, of construction quality and of verification that construction jobs are completed, said opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislator Lee Wen-chih.

Lee said the alliance is not confident of the integrity of relevant officials in the central and local governments in terms of quality and safety of public construction, citing the fact that the number of public structures, including public-run hospitals and schools, ruined or damaged by the devastating Sept. 21 earthquake was much larger than that of private buildings and structures.

Independent legislator Chen Chen-sheng said underworld figures were believed to already have their fingers in certain reconstruction projects, citing that when military engineering forces approached the severely-damaged Mingchu Bridge in Nantou County to try to repair it late last month, a certain "contractor" warned that he had already been awarded the project and the military should leave.
Chen said the gangland community has had its eye on the huge pie of reconstruction projects worth hundreds of billions of NT dollars.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLAR PAINTS GLOOMY PICTURE OF CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: The possibility of seeing a dramatic breakthrough in relations across the Taiwan Strait is slim, predicted a Taiwan-born scholar in the United States recently.
Kao Ying-mao, a political science professor at Brown University, made the forecast in a recent interview with a French radio station.

Kao said cross-strait dialogue is unlikely to resume in the near future as the chance of top mainland Chinese envoy Wang Daohan making an unprecedented visit to Taiwan either in October or November is thin, if not nil.

The two sides tentatively agreed earlier this year that Wang, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), would visit Taiwan either in mid-September or in mid-October.

However, Beijing broke the promise after Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui said in an interview with a German radio station in July that cross-strait relations should be defined as a "special state-to-state relationship."

Lee's statement drew furious reaction from Beijing which interpreted the declaration as a move to promote Taiwan independence. Mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin then set two preconditions for Wang's long-talked-about Taiwan visit -- the top Taiwan leader publicly retracts the "special state-to-state relationship" theory and receives Wang only in his capacity as chairman of Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang.
Noting that Taiwan is unlikely to accept Jiang's preconditions, Kao said Beijing apparently has shut the door for resumption of cross-strait high-level contact or dialogue.

Wang, a former Shanghai mayor and mentor to Jiang, promised to make a reciprocal visit to Taiwan this year when he met his Taiwan counterpart Koo Chen-fu, chairman of Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), in Shanghai last October.

Kao said Wang's Taiwan visit could serve as the first step for resumption of cross-strait dialogue. "The shelving of Wang's travel plan has dampened hopes for improving cross-strait relations in the near future," he noted.

Kao went on to say that no matter who wins in the ROC's presidential election scheduled for March 2000, he will find it difficult to retreat from the "special state-to-state" stance as the majority of Taiwan people support the definition.

"Most ROC citizens think that the 'special state-to-state' statement just affirms a long-existing reality and does not rule out the possibility of eventual unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait," Kao said, adding that many Taiwan people believe if the ROC wants to survive in the international community and ensure parity in negotiations with mainland China, it must insist on the "special state-to-state" principle.
Against this background, Kao said he sees little possibility that any future ROC president would retract the theory.

As for long-term cross-strait relationship, Kao said the status quo will continue at least for another 10 years. "From the viewpoints of internal developments on both sides of the Taiwan Strait and of the general international situation, I don't expect any dramatic changes or breakthroughs in cross-strait ties over the next decade," he said.

In mainland China, Kao said, while its political system may change and economic reforms may increase, its overall evolution in the years ahead will remain slow. "As to Taiwan, as most people want peace and stability, no Taiwan politician would make any dramatic compromise with the mainland."
Meanwhile, Kao said, as the United States is firm on its security commitment to Taiwan, the possibility of mainland China using military force against Taiwan is slim.

Against this backdrop, Kao predicted that cross-strait relations would basically remain almost the same in the coming decade. "My observation is that cross-strait economic and cultural exchanges may increase in the years ahead, but no major progress could be seen in the political field," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR EDGES UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar closed firmer against the greenback on the Taipei market on Thursday, rising 0.001 to close at 31.771.
The currency opened at 31.77, and experienced fluctuation between 31.769 and 31.777. Interbank US dollar trading amounted to US$275 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPOREAN TRADE REPRESENTATIVE TOUCHED BY TAIWANESE GENEROSITY

TEXT.P: For the Lin family of Dali, a township on the outskirts of Taichung City, the best way to express their gratitude was to provide the best accommodations they could offer for the rescuers from afar who had dedicated their expertise and efforts to saving Taiwanese people trapped by the killer earthquake.

The Lin family's hospitality was reported in Singaporean newspapers, which have provided insight into the genuine friendship established between the Singaporean rescuers and an ordinary family in earthquake-devastated central Taiwan.

"Much has been said by Taiwan's media regarding the bravery of foreign rescue teams in the wake of the devastating earthquake; less coverage was provided on the generosity of Taiwan's public towards the rescuers from afar." Singaporean Trade Representative to Taipei Joseph K.H. Koh told a CNA reporter that before their departure the Singaporean rescuers particularly mentioned the hospitality and genuine friendship they had found in addition to the sorrow they shared with the Taiwanese people.

Singapore Civil Defense Force's Disaster Assistance and Rescue Team was the first foreign group to arrive in Taiwan after the disaster to help with rescue operations. The 39-member group was composed of rescuers and medical personnel.

Upon their arrival on Sept. 21, the rescuers started their round-the-clock work in Dali. Considering that the accommodations arranged for them in Taichung were much too far away from the rescue site, the Singaporeans were ready to camp nearby.

The residents of Dali would never allow these helpers to sleep under the open sky. On the other hand, it was not easy to find suitable accommodation in the neighboring area. Having heard of the situation, the Lins, a large family owning a string of housing units in Dali, decided to offer empty housing units to accommodate the Singaporeans, including reporters from the Straits Times and the Chinese-language daily Lianhe Zaobao.

During the week-long stay with the Lins, the Singaporeans were very impressed that the Lins not only tried hard to prepare hot meals and daily necessities for them, but also arranged telecommunications and other services to meet their various requirements. The family also refused to accept any payment from their "honored guests."
These seemingly trivial gestures were the best way the Lin family could express the deepest gratitude of the Taiwanese people, and it was greatly appreciated by the Singaporeans, according to Koh.

The trade representative said he met members of the Lin family at a farewell party for the Singaporeans at the airport on Oct. 3. Extending his appreciation, Koh presented the Lins with a framed newspaper clipping of a brief report and photo of the Lin family and their guests.

Koh said that the Singaporean rescuers described their stay in Taiwan as a "very emotional experience." They pointed out that the rescue operations were well-coordinated with the participation of Taiwanese as well as foreign teams. It was actually a harmonious team spirit that had made any contribution by the Singaporean team possible, he added.

Weeks after the earthquake disaster, rescue work has come to a close and all foreign helpers have departed for home. Taiwan will remember the warm embrace of the world when it was in urgent need of help.

The Singaporean representative said that he himself was deeply touched by the many nameless heroes participating in rescue operations and by the friendly gestures of the Taiwanese people as well as their persistence. He was pleased that people in Singapore were able to learn of the demonstration of humanism through the media report.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DRAM MAKERS IN DISADVANTAGEOUS POSITION: BOFT

TEXT.P: Taiwanese makers of dynamic random-access memory (DRAM) chips were thrust into a disadvantageous position after the US government made a determination Wednesday to hike the proposed import tariffs on Taiwan businesses accused of dumping, said an economics official on Thursday.

Director-General Chen Ruey-long of the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) said, however, that the manufacturers, accused of dumping DRAMs in the United States at prices below fair market value, could appeal to the US International Trade Commission (ITC) for reduction of the punitive import taxation.

The US Department of Commerce (DOC) announced the determination, in which it reconfirmed dumping by several Taiwanese companies and accordingly raised punitive tariffs on Mosel Vitelic to 35.58 percent from the 30.89 percent suggested in its initial ruling in late May.
Nan Ya Technology faced an import-duty hike from 9.03 percent to 14.18 percent, and Etron Technology from 4.96 percent to 69 percent.

Only Vanguard International Semiconductor's duty was reduced, from 10.36 percent to 8.21 percent, while nine other Taiwanese microchip producers -- including Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, Winbond Electronics and United Microelectronics -- were slapped with higher weighted-average duties of 21.35 percent, up from the initial 16.41 percent, according to the DOC's report.
The United States has been one of Taiwan's major buyers of DRAMs, importing chips worth US$279 million last year, accounting for 36 percent of the island's total DRAM exports in 1998, Chen said.

To reduce the impact, Chen suggested local companies take measures to enhance their cooperation with foreign counterparts, while appealing and seeking Washington's through review of the case through both juridical and administrative channels in the United States.

Under US anti-dumping legislation, after the DOC makes its determination on a case submitted by the ITC, the case goes back to the ITC for a final ruling. The ITC has scheduled the ultimate hearing for Oct. 19 and will make its final injury determination no later than Nov. 26.

If the ITC ultimately determines that the companies were at fault, the DOC can issue anti-dumping orders within seven days after the final ITC ruling. Such orders would include notifying customs authorities to transfer deposits out of temporary holding accounts. Those deposits had to be paid by the involved Taiwanese DRAM makers for their continued imports to the United States -- a requirement following the DOC's initial ruling against the companies in May, Chen said.

The dumping charge against Taiwan chip makers was filed last October by Idaho-based Micron Technology Inc., the largest US computer chip maker, with an output that accounts for some 50 percent of total annual US DRAM production.

Meanwhile, representatives of more than 80 local manufacturers in the semiconductor, textile, and steel and metals sectors participated in a meeting hosted by BOFT to forge strategies against the United States' anti-dumping move.
Several DOC officials were also invited to attend the meeting to explain US anti-dumping laws and regulations, Chen said.
Over the past several years, the aforementioned sectors have often faced accusations by US businesses of pouring products into the United States at below-market prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DELEGATION ATTENDS INTERNATIONAL SMALL BUSINESS CONGRESS

TEXT.P: A delegation from the Republic of China took part in the 26th International Small Business Congress (ISBC) which opened Wednesday in Toronto, Canada.
More than 950 delegates from more than 60 countries are attending the three-day gathering.

The opening ceremony was presided over by Canada's minister of industry, who urged leaders of small businesses worldwide to play a more positive role over next five years, when the Internet is certain to exert a more powerful impact on the global economy.

The 25-member delegation from Taiwan was led by Dai Sheng-tung, chairman of the ROC's Small and Medium Enterprises Association. The annual ISBC gathering has been held twice in Taipei -- the 12th meeting and the 24th, which took place two years ago.

The Steering Committee of the ISBC held an election Tuesday, in which some of its commissioners were re-elected. John C.I. Ni, director-general of the Medium and Small Business Administration under the ROC's Ministry of Economic Affairs, was elected to replace Liu Chin-cheng, who has retired.
Ni and Lu Fang-yeou, another delegate from Taiwan, presided over panel discussions on human resources and on experiences in founding businesses, respectively, as part of Wednesday's program.

"Small business -- smart business" is the main theme of the current ISBC forum, for which Taiwan has much to offer and share in terms of its dexterity and wisdom in running and operating small businesses.
ISBC Chairman John Bullock had high regards for Taiwan's participation.

During the meeting, the ROC delegation took the chance to express its deep appreciation for the assistance and concern shown by the international community after the devastating earthquake that struck the island last month.

The delegates from Taiwan also sought exchanges with their counterparts from the Netherlands, Poland and the host country in order to enhance bilateral cooperation, trade, and even the possibility of investment, moves which received responses of goodwill.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL FINDS MANY LOCALS FEEL BLUE

TEXT.P: More than half of Taipei residents responding to a recent survey said they often feel depressed in their everyday life.

The survey of 2,000 adult residents in the greater Taipei area, comprising both Taipei City and Taipei County, was conducted by the John Tung Foundation, a non-profit organization dedicated to promoting public health.
Survey results showed that 53 percent of respondents said they often feel depressed.

The percentage of adolescents who often feel depressed was even higher, reaching 80 percent, according to the results of a similar poll conducted by the foundation in early September. The survey was administered to 2,000-plus senior high school and vocational school students.
The surveys found that those who make less than NT$40,000 (US$1,257.87) a month and do not have any religious beliefs are more vulnerable to depression.
Survey results also showed that teenagers who sleep less than seven hours a day and have lackluster academic records feel depressed more easily.
According to the polls, major causes of depression included setbacks in human relations, a sense of uncertainty about life, and job frustrations.

The two polls were conducted before the devastating Sept. 21 earthquake, which claimed more than 2,300 lives islandwide and left tens of thousands homeless. The foundation said the number of people troubled by depression will surely increase after the 921 earthquake.
Quoting poll results, the foundation said marital status, economic level, religious beliefs and living habits are all closely related to respondents' feelings about life.

The percentage of people who often feel depressed is higher among unmarried respondents than among married ones; people with religious beliefs are less likely to feel depressed than those without such beliefs; and those with monthly income of less than NT$40,000 are more apt to feel blue.
The polls also found that those who get up late are more prone to feel depressed.
Poll results further indicated that adolescents who engage in exercise other than physical education classes are less likely to suffer from depression.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAT TO OPEN TAIPEI-KOTA KINABALU ROUTE FROM OCT. 21

TEXT.P: Far East Air Transport Corp. (FAT) will formally open a new route between Taipei to Kota Kinabalu, Malaysia, from Oct. 21, the board chairman of FAT said Thursday.
The Taipei-Kota Kinabalu route is the third FAT international route after the Taipei-Palau and Taipei-Subic Bay routes.
Kota Kinabalu is the capital of the Malaysian state of Sabah, with a population of 300,000.

Lee Yun-ning, board chairman of FAT, said the opening of international flight routes in the Asia-Pacific region has been a goal of the airline in recent years, with the hope of providing nationals with much better travel service.
Kota Kinabalu was once destroyed in World War II. The rebuilt city includes many tourist resorts.
From Oct. 21, FAT will fly the Taipei-Kota Kinabalu route on Mondays and Thursdays. Flights will depart Taipei at 10:30 a.m. and arrive in Kota Kinabalu at 1:45 p.m.
In the past, FAT flew domestic routes exclusively.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE CONFISCATE CONTRABAND WEIGHT-LOSS PILLS

TEXT.P: Airport police on Thursday announced the arrest of two women for allegedly importing unlicensed pharmaceuticals into Taiwan from Thailand, including weight-loss pills laced with contraband amphetamine.
The police bureau at Chiang Kai-shek (CKS) International Airport also confiscated more than 700,000 Thai-made diet pills, contraception pills, flu capsules, painkillers and other pharmaceuticals.

Although all those drugs are legally marketed in Thailand, none of them has been licensed by the Republic of China's Cabinet-level Department of Health. Moreover, four kinds of weight-loss pills contain amphetamine.
The two suspects, identified as Wu A-chiao, 41, and her younger sister Wu Ni-chin, 36, have been transferred to the Taoyuan Prosecutor's Office on charges of violating the ROC's pharmaceutical law.

Police said as a large number of Thai nationals are working in Taiwan, the market demand for Thai drugs is enormous here. Many local groceries specializing in selling Thai articles also sell pharmaceuticals from Thailand. However, most drugs sold at those shops were illegally imported.

Police first uncovered more than 400,000 contraband weight-loss pills at CKS Airport's luggage claim division and bonded warehouse on June 21 and again discovered 300,000-plus other unlicensed Thai drugs in private houses in Taoyuan County and Keelung City on Aug. 20.

Initial investigations showed that the two arrested suspects had hidden a large portion of those drugs in their luggage and deposited only a small portion at the airport's bonded warehouse for claiming after taxation.
Police said the two suspects might have used similar ways to import Thai drugs for distribution to local wholesalers in the past.

Police said as Thai-made weight-loss pills contain amphetamine, they are harmful to human health, adding that local consumers should not take any drugs other than those prescribed by qualified medical doctors.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE TELLS INDUSTRIES TO MOVE TO E. TAIWAN

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui inspected the Central Weather Bureau on Thursday and recommended that local enterprises move their factories to the eastern part of the island after he was briefed on the earthquake situation in Taiwan.

The Chinese head of state visited the Central Weather Bureau in the company of Huang Kuen-hui, secretary general to the Presidential Office, and Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Feng-cheng on Thursday morning.

Hsieh Hsin-liang, director of the Central Weather Bureau, briefed Lee on the bureau's work and programs. Hsieh said the bureau located the epicenter and scale of the 921 Earthquake within three minutes and released news of the quake within five minutes. The bureau's report was issued more quickly than those of the United States and Japan. Seismologists released reports 30 minutes after the 1989 Northridge, California, earthquake and one hour after the 1995 Kobe quake, Hsieh said.

Lee inquired about the epicenter of the 921 Earthquake, which the bureau placed at 12 kilometers west of Sun Moon Lake in central Taiwan. Hsin Tzai-chin, deputy director of the bureau, replied that the temblor's range was very vast and that the earth's surface broke not at a single point but in a long line. Chichi was the first breaking point.

Lee suggested that the bureau propagate more correct concepts about the earthquake. Although temblor frequency in the eastern part of Taiwan has been greater than that of the western part, quake epicenters have usually been located at sea, without much effect on buildings on the island.
Local enterprises operating in the western part of Taiwan could move their plants to the eastern part of the island, Lee suggested.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE-TAIWAN AIR AGREEMENT TO BE RENEGOTIATED: SAIZON

TEXT.P: The Philippines and the ROC on Taiwan have no choice but to renegotiate their abrogated air agreement, since they will both benefit from a compromise, Foreign Affairs Secretary Domingio Siazon Jr. said Thursday.

"For sure there will be negotiations again. But of course, both parties will have to abide by whatever aviation pact will be drafted," Siazon said, adding that the Philippines had to terminate the Philippine-Taiwan air agreement due to violations by China Airlines and EVA Airways.
"But we should compromise -- there is no way we can allow the airlines of both countries to bleed. I think it's better to have a 3,000- or 4,000-seat capacity entitlement than zero," Siazon said.

Philippine authorities offered Taiwan a 3,000-seat capacity entitlement, but it refused to accept that amount and insisted that it be given 6,500 seats. Philippine Airlines (PAL) said there were not enough passengers to fill the seats requested by Taiwan, due to a decline in Taiwanese tourists visiting the country.
Foreign Affairs Assistant Secretary Franklin Ebdalin said Taiwan had not yet hinted any desire to renegotiate.

Ebdalin stressed that the Philippine aviation officials were ready to sit down and talk anew, but only if Taiwanese carriers would agree to the terms and conditions of PAL, the Civil Aeronautics Board and the Manila Economic and Cultural Office.
The Philippine-Taiwan air pact was terminated by the Philippines on Sept. 30, apparently to save the ailing PAL. (by Timothy Sun)

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF CHAIRMAN WANTS TO VISIT MAINLAND CHINA AGAIN IF NECESSARY

TEXT.P: Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), said Thursday that he wants to visit mainland China again if necessary.
Koo made the remarks while reviewing the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations in the past 12 months after his visit to the mainland.

The top negotiator for Taiwan, who visited mainland China Oct. 14-19 last year, said Taipei still welcomes Chairman Wang Daohan of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) to visit Taipei this fall.
If it is difficult for Wang to come, Koo said, he wants to visit the mainland again to invite him.

Wang was originally scheduled to visit Taipei this month to reciprocate Koo's mainland visit, but this plan has been shelved since Taiwan's President Lee Teng-hui redefined cross-strait relations as a "special state-to-state relationship" in early July.
Beijing leaders insisted that unless Lee retracted his "special state-to-state relationship" statement, cross-strait exchanges, including Wang's Taipei visit, would be frozen.
Koo told the media that he is younger than Wang, and therefore, if necessary he wants to visit the mainland again to extend Taipei's invitation to Wang.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT INSPECTS RELIEF OPERATIONS IN NANTOU
DOC.DATELINE: Nantou, central Taiwan, Oct. 14 (CNA) (By Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Lien Chan on Thursday inspected relief operations in Nantou County and attended a vehicle-donation ceremony there.
Lien went to Hsinyi Township in the morning to see the earthquake-incurred damages of the Farmers Association Building and the Aikou Building.
He comforted displaced townspeople, encouraged reconstruction workers, and listened to briefings on relief operations from township officials.
Later, Lien attended a ceremony marking the donation of four vehicles to four aboriginal townships in Nantou, Taichung and Miaoli Counties by China Motor Corporation.
Speaking at the ceremony, Lien expressed his appreciation for Japanese civilian groups and their government providing prompt assistance to quake-affected people through various channels.
He said that Japan's Mitsubishi Motor Corp. and Mitsubishi Shoji Corp. donated NT$10 million and asked their Taiwan partner, China Motor Corp., to purchase 10 vehicles for quake-affected townships.
Lien also praised China Motor Corp. for having actively supported government projects for aboriginal welfare in the past.

Shortly after the devastating Sept. 21 Chichi earthquake, he noted, China Motor Corp. established a relief center in central Taiwan and provided 60 vehicles for groups to transport much-needed relief materials to disaster areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC SINCERELY HOPES WANG DAOHAN WILL VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan still sincerely hopes that top Beijing negotiator Wang Daohan will visit Taiwan, Chang Jung-kung, director of the Kuomintang's Department of Mainland Research, said on Thursday.
The sincerity of Taiwan has not decreased but increased, Chang said.

A Taiwan visit by Wang as soon as possible will help improve Taiwan people's perception of Beijing, Chang said, adding that mainland China President Jiang Zemin's recent statement of two preconditions for Wang's visit was too severe and that the statement would only create obstacles to meetings between Wang and Koo Chen-fu, his Taipei counterpart.
Chang made the statements Thursday while commemorating the first anniversary of the Koo-Wang meeting in Shanghai, for which he served as vice spokesman for the Taipei delegation.

Chang said that Wang's visit would help relieve the Taiwan people's mood of displeasure toward Beijing after it tried to bully Taiwan in the wake of island's biggest earthquake of the century on Sept. 21.
He hoped that Beijing would grab this golden opportunity.

Chang went on to say Jiang recently said that Taiwan should revoke President Lee's "special state-to-state relationship" theory, and that Lee should receive Wang in his capacity as Kuomintang chairman, as two preconditions for Wang's Taiwan visit. These preconditions are not only too severe but also create obstacles to future Koo-Wang meetings, Chang noted.

It was understood that Beijing could not accept Taipei's "special state-to-state relationship" theory and Taipei could not accept Beijing's "one country, two systems" formula. Both mainland China and Taiwan should minimize the differences by means of wisdom and negotiation, Chang said.

Referring to the differences between Taiwan and mainland China on the "one China" issue, Chang said that interpretations of "one China" by each side were agreed upon in 1992 and still exist today, Chang said.
Exchanges relating to non-political issues have been conducted across the strait based on each side's interpretation of "one China" since then, Chang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMD PLEDGES US$ 1 MILLION TO HELP TAIWAN QUAKE RECONSTRUCTION

TEXT.P: The Silicon Valley-based company Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) on Thursday pledged to donate US$1 million to Taiwan to help finance post-earthquake rehabilitation efforts, industrial sources from the west coast reported.
The AMD donation so far is the largest cash donation by any single company in the United States to Taiwan's cause.

A check for the first US$500,000 has already been sent to the "Silicon Valley Alliance for Taiwan Earthquake Relief," a charitable organization established recently in the science and technology heart of the United States, according to the sources.
AMD maintains close links with semiconductor companies in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park -- Taiwan's version of Silicon Valley, located in the northern county of Hsinchu.

Since the cataclysmic magnitude 7.3 earthquake struck Taiwan on Sept. 21, firms in the Silicon Valley have expressed a high-degree of concern by providing much assistance for the victims -- a fact reflecting a common sense of community involvement shared by the hi-tech corridors in the two countries, the sources said.

Before AMD made the donation announcement on Thursday, a great number of Silicon Valley-based companies, including IBM, Intel, Sisco and AT&T, vowed to contribute to the cause of helping the Taiwanese people in the earthquake-stricken areas.
Meanwhile, the Connecticut-based United Technology Corp. also donated US$50,000 on Thursday to Taiwan to help bolster Taiwan's post-earthquake rehabilitation efforts.

Louis Chenevert, president of Pratt & Whitney, one of the offshoots of United Technology, said staff members of the conglomerate are expected to make more cash donations in a fund-raising drive scheduled for Oct. 18 to Nov. 19.
The United Technology management will then make an additional donation equivalent to the sum raised by the staff in order to further beef up the donation for Taiwan's cause, said Chenevert.

At a simple ceremony marking the initial donation, Chenevert said the donations are meant to express United Technology's concern and support for the Taiwanese people who are striving to rebuild their homeland in the wake of the devastating earthquake that left 2,300 dead, 8,700 injured and 100,000 homeless.
Chenevert added that United Technology is an active enterprise and a partner of the world community. "Our staff is always there to offer support when people are in need," he said.

In addition to a wide range of high-technology products, United Technology also provides services in construction systems and the aerospace industry, with products ranging from HP aircraft engines and Carrier air conditioning systems, to Otis elevators and Sikorsky aircraft.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Oct. 15, or the seventh day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
70 BC: Virgil, Roman epic, didactic, and pastoral poet, is born. His greatest work is the epic poem "Aeneid," which tells of the wanderings of Aeneas after the sack of Troy.
1821: The Central American Federation wins independence from Spain.
1844: Friedrich Wilhelm Nietzsche, German philosopher, is born. He developed the idea of the "Ubermensch," or superman, in his book "Thus Spake Zarathustra."
1925: During the warlord era in China, Sun Chuan-fang, superintendent of Chekiang Province, appoints himself as the commander-in-chief of a military alliance force of five provinces in central China to launch an expedition against Chang Tso-lin's army in the Manchuria.
1928: The airship "Graf Zeppelin" lands in New Jersey after making its first transatlantic crossing from Germany.
1945: Pierre Laval, the French politician who led the Vichy government which collaborated with Nazi Germany during World War II, is executed.
1946: Nazi war criminal Hermann Goering commits suicide by poison one day before his scheduled execution.
1950: The first popular elections of magistrates in Taiwan Province are held in Hualien and Taitung with poor voter turnout and re-elections are scheduled for Oct. 22.
1955: A single ROC Air Force Saber jet, piloted by Captain Sun Szu-wen, shoots down one MiG-17 in a dogfight with 12 Chinese communist MiG17s north of Matsu.
1962: The coffin of Dr. Hu Shih, the late president of the Academia Sinica, is buried at a cemetery in Nankang.
1964: Nikita Khrushchev is replaced by Leonid Brezhnev as First Secretary of the Soviet Communist Party with Alexei Kosygin becoming prime minister.
1964: Harold Wilson of the Labour Party becomes the youngest British prime minister of the 20th century after his Labour Party wins British elections with a majority of just four seats.
1969: The biggest antiwar demonstration in US history is staged when millions of Americans take part in organized rallies and marches to register disapproval over their country's continuing involvement in the Vietnam War.
1969: Abdirashid Ali Shermarke, president of Somalia, is assassinated.
1973: US Secretary of State Henry Kissinger and Vietnamese political leader Le Duc Tho share the Nobel Peace Prize for negotiating the US-North Vietnam cease-fire. But Le refuses it on the grounds that peace is not yet established in South Vietnam.
1990: Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev wins the Nobel Peace Prize.
1993: South African President F. W. de Klerk and African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela share the Nobel Peace Prize for their work to end apartheid and lay the foundations for a democratic South Africa.
1986: The Central Standing Committee of the Kuomintang, presided over by Chairman of the KMT Chiang Ching-kuo, unanimously pass a resolution of political reform to institute the National Security Law during the period of Communist Rebellion and allow the formation of new political parties and organizations.
1986: Lee Yuan-tseh, a member of the Academia Sinica, wins the 1986 Nobel Prize in chemistry. President Chiang Ching-kuo sends a letter of congratulations to Lee on Oct. 17.
1987: The ROC Executive Yuan passes regulations governing the applications of local residents wishing to visit relatives in mainland China.
1994: President Jean-Bertrand Aristide returns to Haitian soil amid a joyous welcome, ending three years of exile that began when he was deposed in 1991.
1997: Steven Chu, a member of the Academia Sinica and a professor at Stanford University, becomes one of the two co-winners of the Nobel Prize for physics.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The moral man must examine his own heart and see that he has no cause for self-reproach, that he has no evil thought in his mind. Wherein the moral man is superior to other men consists even in that which is not seen by men."

DOC.HEADLINE: JIANG SAID TO BE GROOMING NEXT GENERATION OF LEADERS

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese President Jiang Ze-min has formed a top-level personnel committee to look at the issue of "cross-millennium" succession, the South China Morning Post reported today.
The report quoted a party source as saying that the committee consisted of only three people- Jiang Ze-min, Vice-President Hu Jin-tao and alternate member of the Politburo Zeng Zing-hong.
"Next year, Jiang Ze-min will devote much of his time to issues of personnel and party construction," said the source.
The report quoted other sources as saying that Jiang was grooming proteges including Zeng zing-hong, Vice-Premier Wu Bang-guo and the party secretaries of Guangdong, Shandong and Shanghai.
For the three regional party bosses to be considered for the Politburo standing committee, Jiang will have to transfer them to a senior position in the capital well before the 16th Party Congress.

The political fortunes of cadres not included in the selection process are set to decline. The report quoted diplomatic sources as saying that given the relative eclipse of Premier Zhu Ron-ji since April, it was not surprising that he was not made a member of the high-level personnel committee.
The promotion prospects of Zhu's proteges, such as State councilor Wu Yi, are also deemed dismal.

DOC.HEADLINE: BAY AREA RED CROSS TO DONATE NEARLY ONE MILLION TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The American Red Cross announced on Thursday that a delegation of Bay Area staff members will deliver nearly $1 million in earthquake relief aid to Taiwan.

The presence of the Bay Area chapter of the American Cross in Taiwan carrying $1 million in donations will refute Mainland China's claim that all Red Cross' assistance to Taiwan must be transferred through the Mainland Chinese Red Cross.

"The community's response, support and compassion has been overwhelming," said Harold Brooks, Red Cross Bay Area Chapter chief executive officer. "There is a great concern for the well-being of the victims of this earthquake in the Bay Area."

The Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in San Francisco has arranged the trip. Members of the Bay Area Chapter will meet with their Taiwanese Red Cross counterparts to determine how they can continue to help aid victims of the Taiwanese quake now and in the long term.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING SIMULATES LONG-RANGE MISSILE LAUNCH: REPORT

TEXT.P: Mainland China has successfully completed laboratory simulations of a launch of its latest multi-warhead intercontinental ballistic missile which can reach targets in most parts of the United States, the Hong Kong standard reported today.
Computer simulations of launches of the solid-fueled Dongfeng-41 ICBM have been completed and proven to be successful, the report quoted a mainland source as saying.
According to the report, the three-stage DF-41, an improved model of the older single-head DF- 5, can carry five to eight nuclear warheads, greatly increasing its striking capacity.
In addition to the increase in carrying capacity, the DF-41 has much greater mobility because it uses solidified fuel.
With the same 12,000 km range of the DF-5, the DF-41 can reach Europe and many parts of the United States.

The report quoted military and diplomatic sources as saying that the acquisition of technology to manufacture missiles capable of reaching most parts of American territory will force Washington to adjust its defense strategy and speed up the development of anti-missile defense systems.
The new missile could be deployed in five years if the central leadership decides to go ahead with the program, using the DF-41 to replace the older DF-5 model, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MONSTER SIMILAR TO LOCH NESS EXCAVATED IN AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: Australian scientists have excavated the rock-encased fossilized skull of a 112 million-year-old plesiosaur -- a five-meter long reptile that hunted in a giant inland sea on the super continent of Gondwana, the Sydney Morning Herald reported on Friday.
The daily reported that scientists, until now, had excavated all but the head of the plesiosaur -- similar to the mythical Loch Ness monster -- from beside a river in the Gulf of Carpentaria.

They said about 20 plesiosaur skeletons had been previously found in Australia and it is thought that at least three different species of the predators once inhabited the region now known as the Great Artesian Basin.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESTORATION OF AUSTRALIA-INDONESIA TIES URGED

TEXT.P: Bilateral relations between Indonesia and Australia, strained by the East Timor crisis, should be restored before they drift further apart, one of the most influential retired military chiefs during the Suharto era said.

In a dispatch from Jakarta, the Australian reported the call was made by retired General Benny Murdani, former armed forces commander and defense minister, who described the souring of relations between the two countries over East Timor as a "pity."

In an interview with the Australian, Murdani warned that unless determined efforts towards reconciliation are made by the two governments, the rift between Australia and Indonesia would continue to widen.

DOC.HEADLINE: QUAKE SHOWS TAIWAN NOT ALONE SAYS US REP

TEXT.P: The silver lining to the latest earthquake tragedy in Taiwan is that "it proves Taiwan is not alone in the world. Taiwan has many friends here and around the world who stand willing and ready to help," said US Rep. Lindsey Graham on Wednesday.

The congressman, speaking on the floor of the House of Representatives, congratulated Taiwan on its National Day, which fell on Oct. 10, extended his condolences to the people of Taiwan who lost loved ones during the earthquakes, and prayed that Taiwan would soon return to normalcy.

The ROC government has been trying its very best to help all the victims and their families with financial and psychological assistance whenever and wherever it is needed, said Graham, adding that he was pleased that they have received so much assistance from around the world.

The South Carolina Republican noted that the people of the United States have been very generous with their donations of time and materials in an effort to help Taiwan cope with the devastation caused by the earthquake. "We hope that Taiwan will have fully recovered in time to celebrate their next National day," he said.

Rep. Solomon P. Ortiz also spoke on the House floor Wednesday to convey his best wishes to the people of Taiwan, congratulating them for their successes in the past and extending his sympathies to all the earthquake victims and their families on the occasion of the ROC National Day.

"Taiwan is a model of success in Asia. Through hard work and ingenuity, Taiwan has emerged as one of the strongest economies on the Pacific Rim and is a showcase democracy in the world. The accomplishments of Taiwan, whether economic or political, are truly impressive," said the Texas Democrat.
Despite the recent earthquake which severely damaged Taiwan's economy and infrastructure, Rep. Ortiz said "I am confident that Taiwan's future successes will remain impressive."

DOC.HEADLINE: WASHINGTON, BEIJING STILL CANNOT REACH ACCORD ON BEIJING'S WTO ENTRY
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 14 (CNA) (By Jennifer Huang and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Washington and Beijing still have not reached a concrete agreement on mainland China's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO), said US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright on Thursday.
Albright made the remark during a speech at the annual meeting of the Conference Board, a US think tank, held at the New York Palace Restaurant in midtown New York City.

Washington and Beijing failed to reach a concrete agreement on mainland China's entry into the WTO mainly because both sides still cannot reach a consensus on some important business issues, Albright said.

She said leading mainland China to become a member of the world trade regulatory body is not only an important economic affair, but also will result in the introduction of democracy, open market economy, legal standard and peace into mainland China, thus making members of the whole of the international community get along more closely.
She called on economists and heads of large-scale enterprises participating in the meeting to urge the US Congress to offer mainland China normal trade relations status.
Albright told some 100 audience members that Washington is well prepared for the WTO's ministerial-level meetings slated to be held from late November through early December.

She has actively pushed for cooperation between the US and other WTO member economies in supporting a new round of market openings for agricultural, service and industrial products, as well as the increasing the transparency of government procurements.
She said that in the last two years, the global trading system has not been as transparent and open as it was in the past.

She also took the opportunity to raise funds for the US State Department from businesses, saying that, in the last five years, the US government budget for diplomatic affairs has been cut by about 20 percent, while international affairs and the danger of these affairs have not decreased by 20 percent.
She added that the international community requires US leadership in the fields of democracy, peace and prosperity, she added.
She urged business leaders to protest the US Congress decision to cut US$2 billion earmarked for diplomatic affairs from the administration's budget for the fiscal year 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF MUM ON CHAIRMAN KOO'S FUTURE

TEXT.P: The spokesman for the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) on Friday would not comment on whether Chairman Koo Chen-fu will continue his leadership in the foundation after his fourth term expires.

Koo's tenure expiration is now a focus of attention, at a time when a visit to Taiwan by his mainland Chinese counterpart Wang Daohan remains up in the air, and a SEF personnel reshuffle, scheduled for December, is approaching.

Lin Chung-ping, vice chairman and acting spokesman for SEF, declined to speculate on Koo's future, only saying that the foundation highly respects and values Koo's contribution to cross-strait interactions.
Koo is widely and keenly expected to stay with SEF longer to "work a little bit more and contribute a little bit more to cross-strait negotiation efforts," Lin noted.

Koo, 83, a business tycoon-turned-presidential adviser, was appointed SEF chairman -- top Taiwan negotiator with mainland China -- nine years ago. He has filled the SEF Chair for four terms since SEF was founded in 1990.

Koo's mainland Chinese counterpart Wang Daohan, chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), was scheduled to visit Taiwan this fall to complement Koo's mainland visit a year earlier.

The visit, however, is unlikely to take place as Beijing has expressed indignation toward President Lee Teng-hui's "special state-to-state" theory in redefining cross-strait relations, which Beijing considered a move promoting Taiwan independence.

Koo on Thursday offered to travel personally to either Beijing or Shanghai to meet with Wang in an effort to resume the shaky and fragile cross-strait dialogue, as well as to invite Wang in person to visit Taiwan.

In April 1993, Koo and Wang met for the first time in Singapore for a three-day meeting, marking a landmark rendezvous between top negotiators appointed by governments of the two rival sides after a nearly four-decade hiatus of formal contacts.

During the historic meeting, SEF and ARATS signed four agreements on technical issues arising from increased exchanges between people across the Taiwan Strait, including verification of documents and compensation for lost registered mail.
The two quasi-official bodies also agreed that SEF and ARATS officials, including Koo and Wang, would meet on a regular basis in years to come.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOP MAINLAND NEGOTIATOR WELCOME TO VISIT TAIWAN: MAC OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top negotiator with the mainland Koo Chen-fu has displayed goodwill by saying that he would like to visit the mainland to invite his counterpart Wang Daohan to Taiwan, said a mainland-policy official on Friday.

Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Lin Chong-pin was referring to Koo's remarks on Thursday, the first anniversary of Koo-Wang talks in Shanghai, saying that if there is such a necessity, he is willing to visit the mainland to personally invite Wang to visit Taiwan.

Koo, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), said that Taipei sincerely hopes that Wang, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), could visit Taiwan as agreed upon during their Shanghai talks.
Koo said that "only by both sides of the Taiwan Strait engaging in high-level constructive talks, can cross-strait issues be resolved peacefully."
Lin noted that Koo's offer contained "a lot of goodwill," and that Wang is welcome to visit Taiwan, whether it is this winter or at a later date.

Lin said that Taiwan has always been active in promoting communication and dialogue between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, and urged Beijing to look forward at the dawn of the next millennium to reach "stable, harmonious and mutually beneficial" cross-strait relations.
Lin said he hoped that both sides of the Taiwan Strait could continue their "ice breaking" dialogue and work for the improvement of cross-strait relations.
MAC Chairman Su Chi also said that communication and dialogue between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should not be affected by political difference.

Su said that President Lee Teng-hui's statement on cross-strait relations is a description of fact, adding that cross-strait talks should continue through the existing communication channels, meaning SEF and ARATS, two semi-official agencies set up by their respective governments to deal with exchanges in the absence of official ties.

Taiwan and mainland China resumed high-level talks in 1998 after a hiatus of three years, during which Koo and Wang reached a four-point consensus that included plans for Wang to pay a reciprocal visit to Taiwan in the winter of 1999.
Taipei-Beijing relations were strained again after Lee redefined cross-strait ties as a "special state-to-state relationship" during an interview on July 9.

DOC.HEADLINE: PORTUGAL RESUMES ACCEPTANCE OF TAIWAN IPR APPLICATIONS

TEXT.P: Portugal has since Wednesday re-opened its doors to trademark registration applications from Taiwan, marking a happy ending to a seven-month-old intellectual property right (IPR) dispute, said a foreign affairs official on Friday.
Liu Hsiang-pu, director of European affairs of Taiwan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), revealed the news at a regular MOFA press conference.

Liu affirmed that the Portuguese Institute of Industrial Property has formally notified Taipei authorities that beginning Oct. 13, it resumed acceptance of IPR-related registration applications filed by Republic of China nationals.

In early May, Portuguese authorities rejected an application filed by Taiwan motorcycle giant San Yang Industrial Corp. to register a trademark, on the grounds that San Yang is from a country that lacks "legitimate status," and because there are no official diplomatic relations between Portugal and Taiwan.

Citing that the Republic of China is not a signatory to the IPR Treaty of Paris, nor is it a member of the World Trade Organization, nor does it have diplomatic ties with Portugal, Lisbon in May closed its doors to any Taiwan IPR-related applications.
"Mutual benefits" pushed Lisbon to reopen its arms to Taiwan, Liu said.

Many Taiwan businesses have applied for trademark rights in Portugal because its registration fees are lower than those of other member-states of the European Union (EU), the largest single market in the world. A number of Portuguese companies are also endowed with trademark rights in Taiwan.
If the two sides want to boost bilateral trade and economic relations, the IPR registration dispute is the first thing to be resolved, Liu said.

Taiwan last year signed a mutually beneficial trademark priority agreement with the 15-member EU, of which Portugal is a member. Under the agreement, approval of a Taiwanese company's IPR registration application by EU central authorities is binding in all EU member states.

But registering trademarks with the EU's executive body is expensive and time-consuming, therefore some Taiwan businesses with export outlets or manufacturing plants in certain European countries register directly with individual EU members.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar closed higher against the greenback on the Taipei market on Friday, rising 0.002 to 31.769.
The currency opened at 31.768, and was traded between 31.765 and 31.771. Interbank US dollar trading reached US$194 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES, INDEX FUTURES DOWN

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed 0.8 percent lower Friday as investors locked in profits after four consecutive days of gains.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index shed 60.82 points to close at 7,819.09.
A total of 2.45 billion shares changed hands on a turnover of NT$106.55 billion (US$3.35 billion).

The market opened 43.28 points higher but later strong selling in technology stocks and profit-taking in the plastics and chemical sector helped erode earlier gains despite an overnight rally on Wall Street.

Among the eight major stock categories, the paper-making sector again took the lead, ending the day with 2.6-percent gains, followed by foodstuff issues at 0.6 percent. The rest all posted losses, among which plastics and chemical issues and cement shares both registered 1.1-percent losses.
Declining stocks led advancing stocks 280 to 170, with 82 shares unchanged.
The over-the-counter market dropped 1.45 points to close at 182.48 on a turnover of NT$8.89 billion.
Shadowed by a shoddy performance in the stock market, all TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) posted losses.
TAIEX Index Futures for October moved down 90 points to close at 7,810 with 1,296 contract transactions. Those for November shed 83 points to finish at 7,844 with 560 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for December declined 18 points to close at 7,872 with six contract transactions while those for next March shed 40 points to end at 7,900 with two contract transactions. Those for next June dropped 120 points to end at 7,820 with three contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Wednesday were 7,900 points for October, 7,927 points for November, 7,890 points for December, 7,940 points for next March, and 7,940 points for next June.
Electronics futures and financial futures, which are sub-index futures and based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares (TE) and financial shares (TF), both reported losses.
October TE futures shed 3.5 points to close at 371.5 with 322 contract transactions; November TE futures declined 5.4 points to end at 371.6 with 76 contract transactions.
There were no transaction records for December, March or June TE futures.

October TF futures moved down 4.4 points to close at 980.2 with 58 contract transactions, November TF futures shed 4 points to close at 986 with 16 contract transactions; TF futures for other months had no transaction records. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: MIRAGE FIGHTER DISAPPEARS FROM RADAR SCREEN

TEXT.P: A Mirage 2000-5 fighter jet of the Republic of China Air Force disappeared from the radar screen while on a routine training mission of the coast of Hsinchu in northern Taiwan Friday afternoon, informed sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 44% OF LOTTERY PROFITS TO FINANCE POST-QUAKE REHABILITATION

TEXT.P: Forty-four percent the public welfare lottery's first three months' of profits will be used to finance "921 Earthquake" relief efforts, said officials of the Ministry of Finance (MOF) on Friday.

The number of lottery tickets to be issued will be increased by 40 percent for the first three months, with each issuance totaling 30 million tickets. The monthly issuance of tickets will begin in December.
The decision was made in a meeting, presided over by Finance Minister Paul Chiu and attended by heads of local governments, aimed at raising relief funds for quake victims.
The National Pension program, originally scheduled to start at the beginning of next year, has been postponed indefinitely in the wake of the temblor.

Regarding the allocation of lottery profits, it was decided during the meeting that 1 percent of profits will be retained to fund annuities, 50 percent will be allocated to city and county governments, while 5 percent will support the National Health Insurance program, and the remaining 44 percent will go toward financing post-quake rehabilitation, noted MOF Vice Minister Yen Ching-chang.

However, said Yen, according to Article 6 of the Public Welfare Lottery Issuance Statute, lottery profits should be allocated for the funding of annuities. Now that only 1 percent of the profit is earmarked for that purpose, Yen said he was afraid the change might be against lottery establishment regulations.
Nevertheless, since only three months' lottery profits are to be allocated for quake relief efforts, the move can be seen as a sort of expediency, and may thus be acceptable.
Meanwhile, since additional lottery tickets will be issued for the first three months, a total of NT$800 million can be raised from the measure for quake relief, the MOF official observed.
Procedures for allocation of the funds to quake-stricken cities and counties will be discussed in a meeting to be convened by the MOF and attended by all relevant parties, Yen revealed.
Determination of amounts to be distributed is likely to be based on the total numbers of casualties and collapsed houses in the various quake-affected areas, the MOF vice minister added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC GROWTH THIS YEAR PREDICTED AT 5.07 PERCENT: CIER

TEXT.P: A research institute said Friday that due to effects of the massive Sept. 21 earthquake, the economic growth rate for the fourth quarter will be 1 percent lower than the previous estimate, reaching only 5.07 percent.
But the Chung-Hwa Institute for Economic Research (CIER) predicted that the economic growth rate will reach 6.05 percent next year due to post-quake reconstruction work.

CIER predicted in July that economic growth in the fourth quarter would be 6.01 percent. But CIER said Friday that the greatest effects of the quake impact will emerge in the fourth quarter, and the institute therefore adjusted its prediction downward.
Fortunately, economic growth in the second quarter reached 6.54 percent, higher than the earlier prediction of 5.03 percent. This will make up for slower economic growth in the fourth quarter.
CIER said that the overall economic growth rate this year will reach 5.32 percent, down from the earlier prediction of 5.5 percent.
Looking forward to next year, the institute said that economic growth in 2000 could reach 6.05 percent if reconstruction efforts go smoothly.
But as the amount to be spent on reconstruction is so huge, major public construction projects, such as the high-speed railway, could be affected.
If domestic investment falls by NT$40 billion (US$1.26 billion) next year, economic growth in 2000 will only reach 5.18 percent.
Institute President Mai Chao-cheng said that the research body has formed a team to study the effects of the killer quake on the Taiwan economy.
Mai said the earthquake cut this year's fourth quarter exports by NT$3 billion. From the first quarter through the third quarter next year, exports will decrease by US$2.5 billion per quarter.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUSPECT IN MURDER OF FORMER TAOYUAN MAGISTRATE WANTED
DOC.DATELINE: Taoyuan, northern Taiwan, Oct. 15 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Taoyuan prosecutors office issued a manhunt circular Friday amid efforts to pursue a suspect in the murder of former Taoyuan Magistrate Liu Pang-yu.

The prosecutors office issued the circular to arrest Yang Shih-kang following tips that he sneaked into mainland China recently. The office is now investigating the situation and has entrusted Interpol to apprehend Yang.

Yang was arrested by police in September. He resolutely denied he was responsible for the Liu case, but was willing to provide police with clues to recover guns that had been buried at various locations.
He escaped from police custody on Sept. 18 while leading officers to a site where he claimed guns had been buried.

Liu was murdered on Nov. 21, 1997, at his residence. Police suspected that the case involved a conflict of interests regarding public construction projects. Seven other people were also killed and one severely injured in the incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: MIRAGE FIGHTER DISAPPEARS FROM RADAR SCREEN, PILOTS RESCUED

TEXT.P: A Mirage 2000-5 fighter jet of the Republic of China Air Force lost contact with ground controllers while on a routine training mission off the coast of Hsinchu in northern Taiwan Friday afternoon, the Air Force Headquarters said.
Rescue and search operations were launched immediately, said the headquarters.
The two pilots, Squadron Leader Wu Pin-fu and Flight Lieutenant Wu Shih-feng, ejected to safety and were rescued by Air Force helicopters, the headquarters said.

The twin-seat fighter suffered damage after a bird was caught in the engine during takeoff from the Hsinchu Air Base, and the plane was ordered to return immediately. It disappeared from the radar screen while approaching the base, it added.
This will be fourth major accident involving Taiwan's fleet of advanced fighter jets.

In March last year, a two-seater F-16 fighter went missing off the coast of the Penghu islands while on a training mission; in June this year, another two-seater F-16 aircraft plunged into the sea 35 kilometers southeast of Green Island off the coast of eastern Taiwan; and then in August, an F-16 single-pilot jet crashed near an air base in Chiayi, Central Taiwan.

As part of its military modernization effort, Taiwan purchased 60 Mirage 2000-5 fighters from France in 1993 at a total price of US$3 billion. It also purchased 150 US-built F-16 MLU (mid-life upgrade) jets and 130 locally-produced indigenous defense fighters (IDFs).

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE-AMERICAN FORENSIC SCIENTIST HONORED BY US ALZHEIMER SOCIETY
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 14 (CNA) (By David Wang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Noted Chinese-American forensic scientist Dr. Henry Lee was awarded a certificate in New York Thursday in recognition of his contribution to US efforts in taking care of elderly citizens, particularly Alzheimer's disease patients.

Lee, a native son of Taiwan who graduated from the island's Central Police Academy, is currently commissioner of the Public Safety Department of the Connecticut state government -- the highest-ranking police officer of Chinese origin in the United States.

Upon receiving the award at a ceremony, Lee said one of several newly-launched programs in the Connecticut police department since he assumed the commissionership some one-and-a-half years ago, is the "Home Safely" project to look for lost seniors and send them home safely.
Lee was awarded the certificate by John Jager, administrative CEO of the New York Chapter of the American Alzheimer's Association.
Other award recipients included heads of the police departments of New York City, Long Island and the upstate city of White Plains.

Lee, 60, has maintained close links with the ROC government and people. He was last in Taipei in early September to witness a ceremony marking the establishment of sisterhood ties between Taiwan Province and the US State of Connecticut.

DOC.HEADLINE: NORTHERN TAIWAN'S LACK OF POWER EXPECTED TO BE RESOLVED BY 2005

TEXT.P: The problem of insufficient power supply to northern Taiwan areas could be thoroughly resolved by the year 2005, according to an assessment by the Energy Commission (EC) of the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

EC Executive Secretary Chen Chao-yih revealed the assessment on Friday at a public hearing on liberalization of Taiwan's electrical power industry. He added that the problem could not be solved until four planned or ready-for-operation private power plants in northern Taiwan start power generation.
During this year the island has sustained two large-scale power failures: one on July 29, and the other on Sept. 21, when a killer earthquake devastated Taiwan, claiming more than 2,300 lives.

The outage incidents revealed that northern Taiwan is not capable of electrical power self-sufficiency. Chen pointed out that 45 percent of the island's entire power demand comes from the northern regions, which together account for a mere 26 percent of total power supply capacity.

The North has been relying on power from the South, but the South's support faced an extreme challenge when major power transmission cables, erected by the state-run Taiwan Power Company (Taipower), were damaged by heavy rains in July and later by the earthquake that almost razed central Taiwan.
The magnitude-7.3 temblor also resulted in large-scale power rationing for two weeks.

Chen said that several years ago, in order to develop sufficient power resources, the EC formed a three-stage project to encourage private enterprises to join the power business. Since then, Chen noted, 43 businesses have applied to establish power generating facilities.
Eleven private companies have been granted permission to build, and Formosa Plastics Group has completed construction of a thermal power plant in Mailiao, southwestern Taiwan, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOBEL PRIZE NOMINATION PER SE IS HELPFUL: DISSIDENT

TEXT.P: It may spur Beijing to respect human rights if mainland Chinese democracy campaigners are nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize year by year, a well-known dissident said here Friday.

Frank Lu, founder of the Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China, said that, although no mainland Chinese democracy campaigners have won the prize, he is not disappointed. The 1999 Nobel Peace Prize was won by Doctors Without Borders Friday.
The Beijing government was very sensitive to a recent press speculation that dissidents Wei Jingsheng and Wang Dan might be awarded the prize this year.

Beijing is so sensitive to the speculation that it warned Norway and the Nobel Committee against such an award. Therefore, it could be possible to spur Beijing to respect human rights by nominating democracy campaigners for the prize each year, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOFT OK'S INDIRECT IMPORT FOR 59 MORE M'LAND-MADE PRODUCTS

TEXT.P: The Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) decided Friday to open the local market to indirect import of 59 more mainland China-made products.
The BOFT's permission will bring the number of mainland Chinese-made products being indirectly imported to a total of 5,704.

BOFT officials and representatives of the Ministry of Finance, the Industrial Development Bureau of the Ministry of Economic Affairs and related industrial and business associations, met Friday at the BOFT to screen mainland goods recommended by industrial associations for indirect import.
The newly-approved 59 products included: frozen string beans, sunflower seeds, oyster sauce, engine oil filters, plastic bottle caps, nylon, badminton and tennis rackets.

DOC.HEADLINE: MIRAGE FIGHTER CRASHES, PILOTS RESCUED

TEXT.P: A Mirage 2000-5 fighter jet of the Republic of China Air Force crashed while on a routine training mission off the coast of Hsinchu in northern Taiwan Friday afternoon, the Air Force Headquarters said.
Rescue and search operations were launched immediately, said the headquarters.

The two pilots, Squadron Leader Wu Pin-fu and Flight Lieutenant Wu Shih-feng, who ejected to safety and were rescued by Air Force helicopters and marine police, respectively, were rushed to two hospitals for treatment, the headquarters said. Wu Pin-fu was reported to be in good condition; Wu Shih-feng sustained slight injuries to his lower back.

The pilots of the twin-seat fighter reported engine damage to controllers after flying into a flock of birds during takeoff from Hsinchu Air Base. The jet was ordered to return immediately but crashed into sea at 6:11 p.m., the headquarters said.
This was fourth major accident involving Taiwan's fleet of advanced fighter jets.

In March last year, a two-seater F-16 fighter went missing off the coast of the Penghu islands while on a training mission; in June this year, another two-seater F-16 aircraft plunged into the sea 35 kilometers southeast of Green Island off the coast of eastern Taiwan; and then in August, an F-16 single-pilot jet crashed near an air base in Chiayi, Central Taiwan.

As part of its military modernization effort, Taiwan purchased 60 Mirage 2000-5 fighters from France in 1993 at a total price of US$3 billion. It also purchased 150 US-built F-16 MLU (mid-life upgrade) jets and 130 locally-produced indigenous defense fighters (IDFs).
The headquarters said that the Air Force will not ground its Mirage fleet if no mechanical problem or human error is found to have been involved in the accident.

DOC.HEADLINE: MONEY TO BE RAISED FOR QUAKE VICTIMS

TEXT.P: Hsi Lai Temple, a nonprofit religious organization, is scheduled to host its first-ever charity fundraising dinner on Oct. 15, with a portion of proceeds to be donated to victims of the Taiwan Earthquake.

"The Songs of Compassion Charity Dinner," to be held at a hotel in downtown Los Angeles, was endorsed by Los Angeles County Supervisor Michael Antonovich to benefit quake victims and other worthy charities.

Organizers hope the event will awaken society's appreciation of life and also heighten public awareness of abuse suffered by children. Money raised will benefit various programs at the University of Southern California(USC)Center for the Vulnerable Child and the Five Acres Aid Society, established to help nurture abused children and prepare them for a better future.
Part of the proceeds will go to the Taiwanese people, so that they may rebuild their lives and homes after the devastating earthquake that took everything away from them on September 21, 1999.

The event will include entertainment by Sammo Hung, star of the CBS program "Martial Law," and renowned entertainers from Taiwan. Sammo hopes to convey his concern for the welfare of the next generation by sharing the hardships of his childhood.

Bai Bing Bing, a famous Taiwanese singer and actress whose 17-year-old daughter was kidnapped and brutally murdered two years ago, will share her personal tragedy with the hope of raising public awareness of crimes against children.

Other participants, despite their busy schedules and damaged homes in Taiwan, hope to express their gratitude to the American people and the overseas Chinese community for their generous support of the people of Taiwan. In addition, a charity auction will be held to raise more money for the beneficiaries of those killed by the Taiwan Earthquake. (by Lu-sheng Chu)

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER WILL VISIT THREE FRIENDLY COUNTRIES

TEXT.P: The spokesman for the Republic of China's Foreign Ministry, Chen Ming-cheng, confirmed on Friday that Foreign Minister Jason Hu is planning to visit friendly countries in the near future.
But he said that it is not convenient for him to disclose when Hu will leave Taipei.
According to reliable sources, Hu will travel via the United States to visit three countries for about 10 days.
It has been widely speculated that diplomatic ally Panama is trying to improve its relations with the People's Republic of China.
Therefore, the sources say, a Panama visit by Hu at this time would be of special significance. Hu vowed recently that he "would not allow the devastating earthquake to shake Taiwan's diplomacy."
Hu may discuss his foreign travel plans during a previously-scheduled press conference on Saturday morning.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN HOUSE LEADER CONFIDENT OF ROC RECOVERY FROM QUAKE DISASTER

TEXT.P: Don Boudria, Canadian minister of state and leader of the government in the House of Commons, said Friday he believes that with their strong energy and buoyancy, the people of Taiwan will soon recover from the Sept. 21 earthquake.

When meeting a ranking ROC official, the legislative leader again extended his government's sympathy for the people of Taiwan, who are busy rebuilding their country after the disastrous earthquake hit the central part of the island.

He told Thomas Chen, director of public affairs at the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Canada, during a breakfast gathering at the National Press Club, that Canada has tried hard to help with rescue and rehabilitation efforts after the disaster and that the people and government of Canada are still concerned about the relief work there.

Canada announced a donation of C$500,000 for emergency humanitarian aid to victims in Taiwan soon after the deadly Sept. 21 quake. It also dispatched a team of experts to help with Taiwan's reconstruction efforts. The team was scheduled to meet with the press on Friday to report on their findings while in Taiwan.
