DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Oct. 16, or the eighth day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1758: Noah Webster, American lexicographer responsible for the first American dictionary, is born.
1793: The execution of Marie-Antoinette, 38, queen-consort of the late King Louis XVI, and the prospect of further deaths by guillotine of both counter-revolutionaries and revolutionaries suggest that France is slipping even deeper into anarchy.
1846: American dentist William T. G. Morton successfully uses an anesthetic (diethyl ether) for the first time and removes a tumor from a young man's jaw at Massachusetts General Hospital.
1886: David Ben-Gurion, first prime minister of Israel, is born in Poland. He was the leading force in the creation of the state.
1906: British New Guinea becomes part of Australia.
1933: The ROC government troops launch the fifth all-out offensive against communist rebels by adopting a fort-blockade policy to move carefully every step of the way and proceed steadily and step by step.
1946: Ten leading Nazis found guilty a fortnight ago of crimes against humanity by the International War Crimes Tribunal are hanged in the gymnasium of Nuremberg Prison.
1946: Chiang Kai-shek presents the Chinese communists with eight conditions for a nationwide cease-fire.
1949: The Kuomintang establishes the Revolutionary Practice Institute with party leader Chiang Kai-shek as its president.
1951: Liaquat Ali Khan, prime minister of Pakistan, is shot dead while addressing a public meeting in Rawalpindi.
1959: George C. Marshall, American soldier, diplomat, and politician, dies at the age of 78. As US secretary of state, he organized the European Recovery Program often called the Marshall Plan, for which he received the 1953 Nobel Peace Prize.
1963: Ludwig Erhard succeeds Konrad Adenauer as chancellor of West Germany.
1964: Communist China explodes its first atom bomb at the Lop Nor test site in Sinkiang.
1972: President Dawda Kairbr Jawara of Gambia arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1978: Polish Cardinal Karol Wojtyla is elected pope, the first non-Italian pope since 1542 and the youngest this century.
1979: Wei Jingsheng, noted human rights activist in mainland China, is sentenced to 15 years imprisonment by a "people's court" in Beijing for being "anti-revolutionary."
1981: Moshe Dayan, Israeli politician and minister of defense, dies of a heart attack at the age of 66. He directed the 1956 Sinai campaign and the 1967 Six-Day War.
1982: Wu Jung-ken, a 25-year-old pilot of the communist Chinese air force, flies his MiG-19 to a US military base outside Seoul in South Korea.
1982: Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, 1970 Nobel Literature Prize winner, arrives in Taiwan from Tokyo at the invitation of Wu San-lien of the Literary Foundation of the Republic of China.
1984: Chiang Nan, pen name of Chinese writer Liu Yi-liang, is shot and killed by an assassin at his home in San Francisco.
1987: The Force-11 storm, the worst storm to hit Britain in 300 years, lashes southern Britain, demolishing buildings, blackening London and killing 18 people.
1989: A committee of the Convention in International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES) meeting in Lausane, Switzerland, votes 76-11 in favor of a ban on the international trade in ivory.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The moral man, even when he is not doing anything, is serious; and, even when he does not speak, is truthful."

DOC.HEADLINE: DOCTORS WITHOUT BORDERS TO COME TO TAIWAN NEXT WEEK

TEXT.P: Several members of Doctors Without Borders (Medecins sans Frontieres, MSF) are scheduled to arrive in Taiwan next week to pitch in with post-earthquake medical and psychological assistance, local charity sources said on Saturday.

They are expected to proceed to Nantou County's Chungliao Township in central Taiwan, one of the hardest hit areas, to join a Tzu Chi medical team which has been stationed there since arriving hours after the magnitude 7.3 earthquake struck, according to Lu Fang-chuan, a spokesman for the Buddhist Tzu Chi Compassionate Relief Foundation.

The team from MSF, a charitable group which was awarded the 1999 Nobel Peace Prize on Friday, is expected to stay for 10 days in Chungliao, mainly to help in rehabilitative medical and psychological efforts, Lu said.
The Republic of China's top health official Chan Chi-shean offered his congratulations to the French medical aid charity group for receiving the prestigious Nobel Prize.

Chan, director-general of the Cabinet-level Department of Health, met with MSF members, including co-founder Bernard Kouchner, when Chan led a Taiwan medical group to the World Health Organization meeting in Geneva in May of this year.
Chan said he talked with Kouchner about Taiwan-France collaborative efforts to provide medical aid to AIDS victims in Vietnam.

Dr. Pan Fu-shih, a local plastic surgeon who is also a member of the international group Physicians for Peace, gave a thumbs-up to the MSF for its unselfish contribution to the world's sick and needy.

Pan said he has had contact with MSF doctors in stricken areas in Honduras and Lithuania and knew that once members of Doctors without Borders commit to a war-torn or natural disaster-ravaged area, they remain for at least one year.
The Luchuhuei, or the Roadside Bamboo Society, Taiwan's version of the MSF, is considering joining the French-based group to further expand its charitable services, said founder Liu Chi-chun.
Liu said he has become familiar with MSF operations since he met with its doctors in Macedonia where he joined in cross-border charity medical aid efforts.

DOC.HEADLINE: PANAMA CANAL REVENUES HIGHER THAN EXPECTED IN 99

TEXT.P: Panama Canal traffic and tolls revenue for the fiscal year 1999, which ended September 30, have exceeded budget forecasts, according canal administrator Alberto Alemen Zubieta.
Tolls revenue for the fiscal period totaled $ 568.9 million, up 4.2 percent from 1998 figures.

An increase in the average vessel size and in the number of transits by full container ships, dry-bulk carriers, vehicle carriers, and roll on/roll off vessels, contributed to the increase in tolls revenue.

The positive performance was also partly due to a five percent transit increase in Panamax vessels, the largest vessel able to pass through the waterway , from 3,998 in 1998 to 4,198 in 1999, representing 31.9 percent of all oceangoing transits in 1999.
The total cargo tonnage passing through the Panama canal also rose during the fiscal year 1999, from 192.1 million long tons in 1998 to 195.8 million long tons this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE STOCK MARKET JITTERY OVER GREENSPAN COMMENTS

TEXT.P: Australia's stock market plunged to an eight-month low after comments by US Fed chairman Alan Greenspan and imminent moves by the Reserve Bank of Australia to raise official interest rates by as early as November, economists said.
The Australian currency also continued its downward slide over growing fears of a hike in the interest rate, closing at 64.98.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA DEMANDS PAKISTAN BE KICKED OUT OF COMMONWEALTH

TEXT.P: Canada on Friday raised its voice in opposition to the military coup d'etat in Pakistan, demanding that the military controlled country be kicked out of the Commonwealth.
Canada's Foreign Affairs Minister Lloyd Axworthy said he will be pushing for Pakistan's temporary removal from the group at an emergency meeting of Commonwealth foreign ministers on Monday.
He has urged the United Nations to put pressure on Pakistan's army to restore democracy.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOBLE COMMITTEE COMMENDED FOR CONSIDERING CHINESE ACTIVISTS

TEXT.P: US House Policy Committee Chairman Christopher Cox commended the Nobel Committee on Friday for considering awarding the Peace Prize to mainland Chinese democracy advocates Wei Jingsheng and Wang Dan, saying the Nobel Committee has "served the cause of human freedom" with this gesture.

While congratulating the humanitarian relief organization Medecins Sans Frontieres (Doctors Without Borders) for winning the 1999 Nobel Peace Prize, Rep. Cox said the Committee also considered awarding the Noble Peace Prize to Wei and Wang.

But on news that the two might receive the prize, Communist Chinese authorities arrested members of their families living in mainland China and an official PRC spokesmen condemned the Nobel Committee for "flagrant interference in China's internal affairs" when it sought to honor the two advocates now in exile in the US, said Cox.

"These Chinese patriots understand their nation's future lies in greater democracy, not greater tyranny," stressed Rep. Cox. "By considering them for this honor, the Nobel Committee served the cause of human freedom."

Cox also chaired a House select committee that accused Communist China of stealing US nuclear weapons secrets over more than two decades in its investigation report made public in late May of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA COULD ATTACK U.S. IN TAIWAN CONFLICT: PENTAGON REPORT

TEXT.P: Communist China is building up its missile forces in preparation for possible attacks against Taiwan and the United States if its military comes to Taiwan's aid, according to a Pentagon report.

The Washington Times on Friday quoted the Pentagon report as saying that the large number of regional offensive missile systems, backed by space-based spying systems, will be the "cornerstone of the People's Liberation Army early in the 21st century."

"Beijing's drift toward a force dominated by offensive theater missiles could have significant implications on regional stability," said the report. "In the most likely scenario of any future conflict with Taiwan, the PLA's growing arsenal of highly accurate and lethal theater missiles, and a preemptive doctrine could give Beijing a decisive edge."
Regarding US involvement in a war between mainland China and Taiwan, the report makes clear that Beijing won't hesitate to attack.

"The PLA has indicated a willingness to use highly accurate short-range ballistic missiles, medium-range ballistic missiles and land attack cruise missiles against US assets, including key bases in Japan and aircraft carriers operating in the Western Pacific," the report said, noting that Communist Chinese weapons planners are working hard at preparing missiles designed to attack US carriers.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHARITY GROUPS FEELING PINCH IN WAKE OF QUAKE

TEXT.P: Some social groups are feeling a pinch in their budgets after most of the donations over the past three weeks have gone to relief efforts in the wake of the Sept. 21 earthquake.
The extensive loss of life and property damage in the killer quake last month has moved many people in Taiwan to generously donate to the relief and reconstruction.
It is estimated that the total amount of donations has reached more than NT$16 billion (US$503.14 million) so far.

Officials of some social groups noted that it was inevitable that most social resources would go to earthquake relief efforts first, yet they are worried that the government may cut subsidies to them and that private donations could also decrease.
Some of the groups are already feeling the pinch of dwindling funds, with the most seriously affected being those groups which have been devoted to low profile charity work.

Taiwan's Red Heart Society, established a decade ago to care for the elderly and led by movie director Lee Hsing, is pessimistic about meeting its goal of collecting NT$5 million in its first public solicitation now that some enterprises that had agreed to cooperate with the group have canceled and redirected their money to quake-relief efforts.
Society officials said their present budget can only be sustained for three more months.

Chien Huei-lan, deputy secretary general of an association promoting the welfare of the elderly, said that charity groups will face difficulties over the next one or two years as the government cuts subsidies and private sector donations remain scarce.

Tsai Mei-hua, a volunteer group official also predicted that it will not be easy for her group to solicit donations over the next three years, and that it will even have difficulties recruiting volunteers in the wake of the quake.

As the latter half of each year is conventionally the best time to solicit donations, Tsai said that she will join forces with other minority social groups to appeal to the public to resume their traditional support soon.

DOC.HEADLINE: PENGHU COUNTY ANNOUNCED AS TYPHOON-AFFLICTED AREA

TEXT.P: Penghu, an off-shore county to the east of Taiwan, was announced as an area affected by natural disaster by the Council of Agriculture (COA) on Saturday.
Penghu was hit by typhoon Dan last weekend, resulting in heavy damages to agriculture. Typhoon victims can apply for cash relief and loans within 10 days starting from Saturday, said COA officials.

According to statistics released by the COA, total agricultural losses to Taiwan and its offshore islets caused by typhoon Dan totaled more than NT$140 million, with damage to crops accounting for over NT$67 million in losses, and fishing product related losses totaling NT$54 million. The damage to Penghu County's agriculture accounted for NT$24 million worth of losses.
The agricultural damage suffered by Penghu County has reached a level that qualifies it for aid based on the government's relief statutes, pointed out COA officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1ST BATCH OF JAPANESE-DONATED PREFABS INAUGURATED
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, central Taiwan, Oct. 16 (CNA) (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The first batch of Japanese-donated prefabricated houses were inaugurated on Saturday in Tungshih, a central Taiwan mountain township noted for its fruit production.

Shintaro Yamashita, director-general of the Taipei Office of the Japanese Interchange Association, presented the 43 newly assembled temporary housing units to ROC Vice Premier Liu Chao-hsiuan in a ceremony marking the completion of the ready-made houses.
Liu then handed the houses over to Tungshih Township Chief Chang Chin-hu for distribution to local residents made homeless by the Sept. 21 devastating earthquake.

The 43 prefabricated houses were shipped to Taiwan from the Japanese port city of Kobe on Oct. 7 and the ROC military assisted in assembling the housing units which were once used to shelter victims of the 1995 Kobe earthquake.

Tseng Wen-hui, wife of ROC President Lee Teng-hui, was also present at the presentation ceremony. The first lady said she was attending the ceremony on behalf of President Lee to express gratitude for individuals and groups from home and abroad who have devoted money or energy to helping the 921 earthquake survivors.
Tseng said her heart was filled with admiration and gratitude when she saw the completion of Hsinyuan No. 1 Community, composed of the newly assembled Japanese prefabricated houses.

"What touches me most is the quake-affected people's courage to stand up from the ruin," an emotional Tseng said, adding that she also deeply appreciates the assistance offered by foreign friends, military servicemen and ordinary people around the island in post-quake relief and resettlement work.

The Japanese government has donated 1,000 prefabricated houses to the Republic of China to help shelter homeless quake victims in central Taiwan. The remaining 957 prefabs will be sent to Taiwan in several shipments in the near future.

The ROC Red Cross Society has donated NT$40 million (US$1.26 million) for building peripheral facilities surrounding the Hsinyuan Community. All those facilities, including a large reading room, public bathrooms and recreational facilities, were also inaugurated on Saturday.
Speaking on the occasion, Defense Minister Tang Fei said the military will continue to build temporary housing units for homeless quake victims.

Each Japanese-donated prefab covers an area of eight pings (one ping equals 36 square feet.) It has two rooms, a kitchen, a storage room, a locker room and a telephone. The second batch of Japanese prefabs will arrive on Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC AIR FORCE VOWS TO DEAL WITH BIRD PROBLEM

TEXT.P: The Air Force on Saturday vowed to deal with birds that have apparently jeopardized the safety of Taiwan's military planes, as highlighted by the latest accident in which a Mirage jet fighter was downed by the avian menace on Friday.

A French-made Mirage 2000-5 interceptor crashed off the northwest coast of Taiwan about 15 minutes after taking off from the northern Hsinchu Air Base. The two pilots ejected before the plane plunged into the Taiwan Strait.
According to the Air Force, engine failure occurred after birds were sucked into the jet fighter's engines, causing severe damage to the turbo blades.

In order to decrease the risk of accidents due to encounters with birds, some warplanes have avoided taking off during high times of bird activity except for emergency missions. In addition, a ban on pigeon-raising in the vicinity of many air bases has also been announced, the Air Force said.
Despite these preventive measures, the Air Force sources said nearly 100 warplanes ran into or nearly ran into birds last year, damaging several engines.

In light of the Mirage 2000-5 crash, the first of its kind since the Air Force commissioned 60 of the high-performance fighter planes in 1997, bird prevention efforts will be accelerated to avoid a recurrence of similar accidents, said Defense Minister Tang Fei.
Tang said the civilian sector, including the legislature, were unaware of the genuine threat to the warplanes posed by birds.

He said the Ministry of National Defense had proposed a plan allocating a certain amount of the budget to curbing bird numbers and scaring them away in an attempt to increase safety for the nation's military planes, but he noted that it was shelved by the legislators.

The bird issue also touched off debate between the Air Force and wildlife conservationist groups. A group leader challenged the Air Force's explanation for Friday's crash, saying that if a bird can down such an advanced and expensive jet fighter so easily, how can the air force defend Taiwan?

Meanwhile, Major General Lee Kuei-fa, in charge of discipline and supervisory affairs in the Air Force, recognized the performance of the two pilots during the emergency. He referred to Squadron Leader Wu Pin-fu and Flight Lieutenant Wu Shih-feng's joint handling of the Mirage fighter as "proper and dutiful."

As part of its military modernization effort, Taiwan ordered 60 Mirage 2000-5 fighters from France in 1993 at a cost of US$3 billion. Taiwan also purchased 150 US-built F-16 MLU (mid-life upgrade) jets and 130 locally developed defense fighters (IDFs) to replace its aging fleet of American F-104s and F-5Es.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-NETHERLANDS TRADE CONSULTATIONS TO OPEN IN TAIPEI MONDAY

TEXT.P: Bilateral business and trade consultations between Taiwan and the Netherlands are scheduled to open Monday in Taipei with trade officials and industrial leaders from both sides participating.
The meeting will be jointly presided over by Vice Economic Affairs Minister Lin Yi-fu and his Dutch counterpart F.A. Engering, according to Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) officials.

During the consultations, Taiwan will discuss ways to further bolster cooperative ties with the Netherlands and will seek the European country's help in its bid to join the World Trade Organization (WTO), MOEA officials said.

Lin's delegation will also seek the Netherlands' support for Taiwan's joining the United Nations Chemical Weapons Prevention Treaty and also its entry as an observer into the Competition Laws and Policy Committee under the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), the officials said.

This will be the fourth set of consultations between Taiwan and the Netherlands since the two countries first met in 1980. The consultations had been suspended since 1994 because they overlapped with similar bilateral meetings based on the terms of Taiwan's WTO accession.
Two-way trade between Taiwan and the Netherlands totaled US$4.22 billion in the first nine months of this year, with Taiwan enjoying a surplus of some US$1.93 billion, according to MOEA tallies.
Currently, the Netherlands is Taiwan's largest European export market and the fourth largest source of imports from the continent.
A total of 150 Dutch companies have channeled a combined total of US$1.22 billion into Taiwan for various investment projects, making the Netherlands Taiwan's largest capital source from Europe.
Meanwhile, about 140 Taiwanese companies maintain investment operations in the Netherlands, totaling some US$200 million, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATOR CALLS HEARING OVER FRAUD INVOLVING FOREIGN BRIDES

TEXT.P: A legislator called a public hearing on Saturday to call attention to cases of fraud involving foreign smuggling rings collecting the passports of foreign brides for illegal use.

Legislator Kuo Su-chun of the ruling Kuomintang called the hearing on international fraud involving foreign brides. Participating in the hearing were Taiwanese victims of the fraud and government officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Bureau of Immigration.
Legislator Kuo said that such fraud has compromised the rights of local people and threatened the social order.

Legislator Kuo pointed out that the smuggling rings first act as matchmaking agencies for Indonesian brides and Taiwanese men. The rings then collect the passports of the Indonesian brides after they return to Indonesia within six months according to Indonesian regulations.
The rings then give the passports to others who then use the contraband passports to enter Taiwan shortly thereafter.
The legislator stated that the illegal smuggling rings might be involved in getting jobs for the illegal immigrants after they arrive in Taiwan.

Meanwhile, the Indonesian brides who have handed over their passports cannot leave their country after they have been taken away from them and their husbands in Taiwan are left without both their bride and the large sum of money given as a dowry.
Kuo asked relevant authorities to check the whereabouts of the brides to see if their passports have been converted for illegal use or the women have been sent to serve in the prostitution business.
A Bureau of Immigration official said the law states that foreign brides must report the loss of their passports and reapply for entry before they are allowed to return.
Another official also said that Taiwan cracks about 350 cases of illegal immigration every year with many more illegals entering undetected.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ELECTRONICS SHOW EXPECTED TO DRAW PACKED HOUSES

TEXT.P: The China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) expects that more than 20,000 buyers will visit the Taitronics '99 exhibition -- a showcase of Taiwan's electronics industry -- at the Taipei World Trade Center between Oct. 16 and Oct. 20.

A total of 1,029 electronics manufacturers from here and abroad are presenting their innovations ranging from computers, peripherals, and telecommunications equipment, to consumer electronics and lighting equipment. Among them are 30 manufacturers from South Korea, Hong Kong, Germany, the United States, India and Malaysia.
The electronics industry is the leading force behind Taiwan's trade surplus. The total export value of Taiwan's electronics amounted to US$32 billion in 1998.

A CETRA analysis indicates that the prosperity of Taiwan's electronics industry can be attributed to its rich hi-tech human resources and strong support from related industries. Even in times of global recession, Taiwan's electronics industry was able to maintain a competitive edge in innovation against the United States and Japan.

The major products of Taiwan's electronics industry are computers and communication and consumer products. Taiwan's communication products chiefly consist of linear circuit systems, telephones, wireless equipment and switching equipment. Major consumer products include radios, color TVs, VCRs, and car radios.

October has been a month full of trips to East Asia for electronics buyers from all over the world. In addition to the five-day Taitronics exhibition in Taipei, three other electronics shows took place in Japan, South Korea and Hong Kong in the first half of the month.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAGNITUDE 4.7 QUAKE HITS EASTERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: An earthquake measuring 4.7 on the open-ended Richter scale rattled Hualien in eastern Taiwan at 2:48 a.m. on Saturday, according to officials of the Central Weather Bureau (CWB).

The temblor occurred 33.1 kilometers west of Hualien, and originated 4.3 kilometers beneath the earth's surface, with its epicenter at 24.02 degrees north latitude and 121.28 degrees east longitude, said the CWB officials.
The tremor had an intensity of 3 in the city of Hualien, and in Nansan Township in Ilan County, while measuring 1 in Gookun Township in Yunlin County, bureau officials added.
The magnitude of a quake is a measure of the energy released by an earthquake, while the intensity indicates the strength of the temblor at various distances from the epicenter.

DOC.HEADLINE: NAVY DESTROYER DECOMMISSIONED

TEXT.P: The navy destroyer "Kunyang" was formally decommissioned on Saturday after serving in the ROC navy for 31 years.

Rear Admiral Wang Shan-chun, the captain of the destroyer, presided over the decommissioning ceremony held at Hsinpin Wharf in Kaohsiung Harbor. Past and present captains and navy servicemen who served on the destroyer were invited to bid farewell to the ship.

Wang noted that during its 31 years, "Kunyang" completed 997 missions, including reconnaissance, protection of fishing vessels and escort and transport missions to offshore islands, making an indelible contribution to the ROC navy.
Kunyang, originally a Fletcher-class destroyer from the United States, was launched in July 1943. It served in the Second World War and the Korean War.
Taiwan received the destroyer from the US in 1968 and the ship was commissioned in October of the same year.
The navy has been building its second -generation naval ships in recent years and has begun phasing out the older destroyers which it bought from the US since 1994.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS ASIAN IMMIGRANTS RAISE MONEY FOR EARTHQUAKE RELIEF

TEXT.P: Chinese immigrants from Taiwan and other Asian countries living in Australia have raised more than A$1 million (US$645,000) in donations to be given to relief funds for the victims of the earthquake that struck Taiwan on September 21, according to a survey by the CNA on Saturday.

The Taiwanese migrants now living mainly in Sydney, Melbourne and Brisbane, have raised more than A$1 million in the past three weeks and are continuing their fund-raising campaigns to collect more funds, organizers from the three cities told the CNA.

The major contributors to the fund-raising campaigns came from immigrants from Taiwan, with immigrants from Hong Kong, Singapore, Malaysia and other Asian countries also donating money. In addition, many Australians made donations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Australia pressures Kosovar refugees to leave by October 30

TEXT.P: The Australian government is increasing its pressure on the remaining Kosovar refugees in this country to leave by the end of this month or face either removal or detention. The Sydney Morning Herald on Saturday reported that Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock this week visited ethnic Albanian refugees in Tasmania and New South Wales and made the warning towards the Kosovar refugees, who are numbering less than 1000. Australia received about 4000 Kosovar refugees at its peak in May and more than 3000 have returned home.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER TO VISIT 2 ALLIES

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Jason Hu said on Saturday he will visit two of the Republic of China's diplomatic allies -- the Dominican Republic and Panama -- next week.
Hu told a news conference that he will leave for the Dominican Republic on Oct. 23 for a four-day official visit. On his way, Hu will make transit stops in Seattle and New York.
Following his Dominican visit, Hu will then travel to Panama to meet with the new Panamanian president and foreign minister.
Hu said Dominican President Leonel Fernandez has invited him to visit the Caribbean nation to discuss some bilateral cooperative programs.

Shortly after Taiwan was rattled by a devastating earthquake on Sept. 21, Fernandez made a three-day state visit to the ROC to express his concern for the well-being of people of Taiwan in the wake of the temblor.

As all senior ROC officials were busy with post-quake relief work at that time, several proposed cooperative programs between the two countries were not discussed during his visit. Prior to Fernandez's departure, Hu promised to visit the Dominican Republic within a month to discuss some topics of mutual interest.

High on the agenda will be a proposal that the ROC help the Dominican Republic build a science-based industrial park to boost its high-tech industries. A team of experts in developing and administering science-based industrial parks will accompany Hu on his Dominican visit.
A 10-member trade and investment mission will also visit the Dominican Republic along with Hu to explore possible trade and investment opportunities.

Meanwhile, Hu said he will travel to Panama on Oct. 27 for a four-day visit. Hu said he originally planned to visit Panama immediately after the new Panamanian government was formed in early September. As he was preoccupied with preparations for an ROC-Central America summit meeting at that time, he postponed his Panama visit.

In addition to paying a courtesy call on new Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso de Gruber, Hu said he will meet with other Panamanian officials, including Foreign Minister Jose Miguel Aleman, for wide-ranging talks.

Local political observers said a visit to Panama by Hu at this time is of special significance as it has been widely speculated that the Central American country is endeavoring to improve its relations with mainland China.
Hu vowed recently that he "would not allow the 921 devastating earthquake to shake the ROC's diplomacy."

DOC.HEADLINE: SCIENTISTS SAY ABLE TO GROW BRAIN CELLS FOR HUMANS
NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose 0.4 cent against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Saturday, closing at 31.765.
The local currency opened Saturday at 31.762 and was traded between 31.760 and 31.766.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$58 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC URGES BEIJING TO POSITIVELY RESPOND TO KOO'S REVISIT TO M'LAND

TEXT.P: Taiwan hopes Beijing will give a friendly response to top Taiwanese negotiator with mainland China Koo Chen-fu's willingness to make an ice-thawing tour to the mainland, a high ranking official with Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Saturday.
Lin Chong-pin, vice chairman of the MAC, made the remark when giving a speech at an academic seminar on the future of cross-strait relations.
Saying that it is better to convert an enemy into a friend, Lin also hopes that the cross-Taiwan Strait ties can lead to peace, stability and cooperation.

He said Koo Chen-fu, chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation, on Thursday had expressed his willingness to revisit mainland China to resume a constructive dialogue with Wang Daohan, chairman of the mainland's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait.
Thursday marked the first anniversary of the Koo-Wang talks in Shanghai.
Lin said Taiwan has sufficiently displayed goodwill and is waiting for a friendly response from the mainland.
Wang was originally scheduled to visit Taiwan in the spring of this year but Beijing later decided to postpone the visit to the fall.

Beijing suspended its dialogue with Taiwan in early July after ROC President Lee Teng-hui redefined the cross-strait relationship as a "special state-to-state" one. Beijing claims that after Lee put forward this view of cross-strait relations, the existing basis for bilateral talks no longer exist.
Lin said if Wang cannot visit Taiwan in the fall this year, Taiwan will still welcome his visit at any time.
Koo said on Thursday that he would like to visit the mainland to invite Wang to Taiwan if required.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PREPARING WHITE PAPER ON PARTY'S 'CHINA POLICY'

TEXT.P: The Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is drafting a white paper on the party's "China policy" with the main points echoing DPP presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian's view of conditioned direct contacts between the two sides.

On Sept. 20, Chen announced his view of cross-strait relations. He proposed a relaxing of restrictions on direct shipping, trade and investment on the condition that Taiwan's national security is not endangered.

A DPP source disclosed that the white paper will be released next month, corresponding with the DPP-sponsored "International Conference on China in the 21st Century" to be held at the Taiwan University Conference Hall on Nov. 6-7.
Chen, invited to speak at the closing ceremony, is expected to further elaborate his views on normalizing relations between Taipei and Beijing.

The DPP politician, in a September announcement, summed up his proposals in five points -- negotiation of all topics, including political issues, the establishment of institutionalized exchanges of visits and dialogue, the building of mutual trust to reduce the risk of military confrontation, the relaxing of restrictions on direct shipping, trade and investment on the precondition that they don't endanger national security, and the signing an interim peace agreement that recognizes equal status.

Yen Wan-chin, director of the DPP's Department of China Affairs, said that Chen has succeeded in consolidating different factions within the party and that the five-point announcement reflected a policy of bold advancement and patience.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Oct. 17, or the ninth day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1662: Charles II, King of England, sells Dunkirk to the French.
1849: Frederic Chopin, Polish-born French composer and virtuoso pianist of the romantic era, dies of tuberculosis in Paris at the age of 39. His music, written chiefly for the piano, is noted for its expressiveness.
1855: Englishman Henry Bessemer patents his process for making steel.
1912: The first Balkan War breaks out when Bulgaria, Serbia and Greece declare war on Turkey.
1919: Zhao Ziyang, former Chinese Communist Party chief, is born. As prime minister in the 1980s, he pioneered bold economic reforms. He was swept from power in the political crisis sparked by the 1989 pro-democracy demonstrations centered in Tiananmen Square in Beijing.
1920: Hsieh Wen-ta, Taiwan's first aviator, flies his aircraft over Taichung in central Taiwan.
1945: After being released from custody, Juan Domingo Peron addresses a 300,000-strong crowd from the balcony of the presidential palace in Buenos Aires and tells them of his desire for a just and strong nation.
1945: The first batch of ROC government troops aboard some 40 US Navy ships arrives at Keelung in Taiwan, which reverts back to Chinese rule after 50 years of Japanese occupation.
1956: Calder Hall, Britain's first nuclear power station, is opened by Queen Elizabeth II.
1963: The Hong Kong government sets up the Chinese University of Hong Kong.
1964: Construction of a cross-harbor bridge in Penghu (Pescadores) is started.
1966: Lesotho and Botswana are admitted to the United Nations.
1967: Henry Puyi, formerly Hsuan Tung, the last Ching ruler, dies in Beijing at the age of 61.
1972: President Park Chung Hee declares martial law in South Korea.
1972: British Queen Elizabeth II arrives in Yugoslavia to begin her first tour of a communist country.
1973: The ten Arab members of OPEC announce an enormous 70 percent hike in oil prices and a cutback in production in response to America's support for Israel in the Yom Kippur War.
1977: Akira Nishiyama, former Japanese ambassador to South Korea, arrives in Taiwan to assume his duties as director of the Japan Interchange Association's Taipei office.
1979: Mother Teresa is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for caring for the world's "unwanted and unloved."
1985: The Italian government under Socialist Bettino Craxi falls from power as a consequence of its inept handling of the "Achille Lauro" affair. The cruise ship "Achille Lauro," carrying 454 passengers, was hijacked by Palestinian terrorists ten days before.
1989: An earthquake rocks northern California, killing more than 60 people.
1990: Ukrainians hold a mass demonstration in Kiev protesting Soviet rule and demanding independence.
1994: Israel and Jordan initial a historic peace treaty, ending their 46-year state of war.
1995: The Republic of China and Macau establish a five-year renewable air pact allowing Eva Airways, TransAsia Airways, and Air Macau to fly routes between Taiwan and Macau.
1996: Russian President Boris Yeltsin sacks security chief Alexander Lebed one day after Lebed is accused of building his own army in an attempt to seize power.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The moral man, without the inducement of rewards, is able to make the people good; and without a show of anger, to awe them into fear more than if he had used the most dreadful instruments of punishment."

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY 60% THINK QUAKE WILL AFFECT ELECTION NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: Nearly 60 percent of people surveyed said the massive Sept. 21 earthquake will have an effect on next year's presidential election, according to a poll released Sunday.
The Public Poll Institute of the Republic of China surveyed 1,187 people over the age of 20 between Oct. 13 and 15. The results have a margin of error of 0.029 percent.

Asked whether the killer quake will have an effect on the presidential election next year, 37.9 percent answered "yes," while 21.7 percent said the effect will be big; 25.4 percent said it will have no effect.
The poll also found that younger, more highly educated people tend to think the quake will have a greater influence on the outcome of the election.

Analyzing the results, Professor Pao Chung-ho of National Taiwan University said those who are younger and better educated tend to be more idealistic and therefore may be more critical in their views.

But he pointed out that most respondents refused to answer questions concerning possible effects on the election, showing that most people are still focusing on post-quake relief and reconstruction efforts, and that the real effect of the quake on the election may need some time to surface.
The questionnaire also asked people about their views on relief work by the private sector and the government.
Respondents were most satisfied with the performance of the private sector, followed by those of central and local governments.

The results showed that 92.9 percent of those polled had a positive view of relief efforts by the private sector; 72.9 percent had such views about the performance of the central government, in contrast to the 20.3 percent who viewed it negatively.

Ninety percent of those surveyed had positive views of the government's mobilization of military personnel, police officers, firefighters, electricians and plumbers to join quake-relief efforts. Respondents in quake-stricken areas in central Taiwan had higher approval ratings of the central government than those in areas not greatly affected by the temblor.

The institute said the government's approval rating in this survey was higher than those of previous polls, showing that government quake-relief efforts have become much more organized and have been operating more smoothly.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT EXPRESSES THANKS TO CARDINAL PAUL SHAN

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan called on Cardinal Paul Shan on Sunday to express gratitude for the 921 Earthquake relief assistance launched by the Catholic community in Taiwan.
The cardinal told Lien that the Catholic community had mobilized more than 290 truckers to transport relief goods to earthquake-stricken areas as of Oct. 10.
Shan also expressed his admiration of Lien for his hard work on quake-relief and reconstruction efforts.

The cardinal summoned an emergency meeting one day after the earthquake jolted Central Taiwan on Sept. 21, and launched an islandwide relief collection campaign, he explained, adding that the Catholic community has also sent workers to earthquake-stricken areas to help survivors reconstruct their homeland.
The vice president expressed heartfelt thanks to Catholic and other religious organizations for their relief efforts.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T TO ANNOUNCE GUIDELINES FOR CARRYING OUT EMERGENCY DECREE

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan will soon make known a 15-point set of guidelines for carrying out the emergency decree promulgated by President Lee Teng-hui on Sept. 25, said a government representative Sunday.

Chen Chien-jen, director general of the Government Information Office (GIO), said that in order for various government agencies to clearly understand procedures for implementation of the emergency decree, Premier Vincent Siew convoked a meeting Sunday morning to discuss and review post-earthquake reconstruction carried out since the emergency decree was issued.

The meeting was attended by Hsieh Shen-shan, secretary general of the Executive Yuan, State Minister Without Portfolio Chen Chien-min, Interior Minister Huang Chu-wen, Education Minister Yang Tsao-hsiang and Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang, among others, said Chen.

After hearing reports on reconstruction presented by related ministries, the premier instructed the Executive Yuan to announce guidelines for the concerned ministries to follow in carrying out the emergency decree, Chen said.
Chen said, however, that the guidelines will be subject to approval by the post-quake reconstruction committee at its fifth meeting.

The proposed guidelines concern: environmental protection, use and lease of nationally-owned land, appropriation and use of civilian resources and land, simplification of reconstruction procedures, and other issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC PROFITED US$ 44.6 BILLION FROM OVERSEAS ASSETS IN 8 YEARS

TEXT.P: Data released by the Central Bank of China (CBC) Sunday showed that Taiwan has earned US$44.6 billion in interest generated from overseas assets in eight years.

According to the data, starting in 1991, profits from interest on overseas holdings varied from year to year, with a high of US$6.23 billion in 1991 and a low of US$4.72 in 1998 due to declining international interest rates.

The data revealed that Taiwan's foreign income mainly results from investments, accounting for more than 90 percent of total overseas earnings, and interest on foreign exchange reserves brought in the lion's share of those investment earnings.

However, the percent of total profit being generated from interest on foreign exchange reserves dropped considerably from 80 percent in 1991 to an average 63.5 percent in the last three years, due to lower interest rates, the data showed.

The US interest rate was down slightly from 5 percent in 1991 to 4.9 percent in 1998; that of Japan plunged to 0.5 percent in 1998 from 5.5 percent in 1991; and Germany's rate tumbled from 7.1 percent in 1991 to 2.5 percent in 1998.

Earnings from interest on Taiwan's foreign assets are expected to grow as Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves increase and international interest rates stop declining, said bank officials. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC OPINION POLL GIVES HIGH MARKS TO TVBS FOR QUAKE REPORTS

TEXT.P: Results of a poll conducted by the Mass Communications Institute of National Taiwan Normal University show that nearly 31 percent of respondents felt that among cable TV stations, TVBS had the best news reports following the devastating earthquake that jolted Taiwan on Sept. 21.
The same poll showed that the TVBS rating was followed by ETVS of Eastern Multimedia Group at 14.9 percent, Formosa TV at 6.8 percent and China Television Network at 2.3 percent.

In rating the performance of regular TV stations, 25 percent of interviewees gave their highest marks to Formosa TV, followed by China Television Co. at 12.5 percent, Taiwan Television Co. at 8.9 percent and the Chinese Television Co. at 4.6 percent.

As for the performance of newspapers, 69 percent of respondents expressed satisfaction, followed by 68 percent being satisfied with radio coverage, 72 percent with that of regular TV stations and 72.1 percent with cable TV coverage.

The same results also showed that more than 60 percent of interviewees expressed their displeasure with the live television broadcasting of the recent firing-squad execution of Chen Chin-hsing, who had been given three death sentences for a series of crimes, including murders, kidnappings and rapes.

DOC.HEADLINE: THAILAND TO PRODUCE HANDBOOK ON QUAKE PRECAUTIONS, RELIEF MEASURES

TEXT.P: Thailand is to produce a handbook on earthquake precautions and relief measures for distribution to the public, said the country's Deputy Prime Minister Trairong Suwankhiri Saturday.

A recent earthquake that killed more than 2,300 people, including seven Thai workers, in Taiwan has caused the kingdom to be concerned about the possibility of a strong temblor in Thailand, especially in 10 provinces in the north and northwest.
Those provinces are: Mae Hong Son, Chiang Rai, Chiang Mai, Nan, Phayao, Phrae, Lampang, Lumphun, Tak and Kanchanaburi.
Trairong, who chairs the National Safety Council, ordered the council's anti-earthquake sub-committee to draft the handbook.

He also instructed the council to: focus on roles for emergency direction and coordination; seek legal amendments to ensure safety for amusement park visitors and lift users in high-rise buildings; and work out standard qualifications for operators of potentially hazardous construction machinery.
The Meteorological Department is to seek cabinet approval for a proposal to appoint representatives of the national police office and the Public Health Ministry to the council.
A command center will be set up to ensure speedy disaster relief operations, with the Local Administration Department of the Interior Ministry acting as coordinator. (by Kuo Fang-chih)

DOC.HEADLINE: BAD WEATHER CONDITIONS STALL WORK TO RECOVER MIRAGE JET FIGHTER
DOC.DATELINE: Hsinchu, Northern Taiwan, Oct. 17 (CNA) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Bad weather conditions caused difficulties for recovery of a two-seater Mirage 2000-5 of the Republic of China Air Force that plunged into the sea seven nautical miles south of Hsinchu Air Base on Oct. 15, said an air base officer Sunday.
The officer said, however, that Air Force radar operators were continuing to monitor the position of the crashed aircraft.

The Air Force pinpointed the location of the wreckage -- seven nautical miles south of Hsinchu Air Base at a depth of 17 meters. The jet's two pilots ejected before the crash and were subsequently rescued in good condition.
Strong seasonal waves affected waters off the coast of Hsinchu and prevented the recovery team from salvaging the sunken aircraft, the officer said.
The Air Force hopes that recovery work will continue as soon as weather conditions are good, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 433 CENTENARIANS IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: There are 433 centenarians in Taiwan, according to a survey released by the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) on Sunday, which, according to the Chinese lunar calendar, is the Double Nine Day when people show special respect for their elders.
The survey also found that of the 433 centenarians, more than 70 percent are women, and the eldest is 115 years old.
The survey painted a grim picture of life for those over 65, as a great number of them must rely on support from children or other relatives.
Only 5.6 percent of those older than 65 have full-time jobs, while 5.3 percent work part-time; 0.7 percent engage in volunteer activities.

The results showed that the majority of those over 65 have withdrawn from the mainstream employment force, the MOI said, adding that it is a pity and a waste that such valuable human resources have gone idle.

One of every five, or 20.8 percent, of those seniors said they don't have enough income to make ends meet, compared with 52.7 percent who have sufficient incomes; 26.3 percent said they relied on savings.
The results showed that most people older than 65 have economic problems because they retired too soon.
For this reason, 52.3 percent of them must depend on their children to get by, while 10.6 percent have to rely on support from other relatives or friends or on public assistance.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Monday are as follows:

DOC.HEADLINE: SIX TAIWAN FIRMS MAKE FORBES BEST SME LIST
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 17 (CNA) (By K.C. Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Six Taiwan-based companies made the Forbes list of the best 200 small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in the world beyond the United States, sources from the magazine said on Sunday.
Taiwan was one of 10 countries from around the world to have more than five SMEs listed on the Forbes list, according to magazine staff.

The six Taiwanese companies listed were the semiconductor manufacturers ASE Test and Sunplus Technology; D-Link, an electronic device producer; Microtek International, a computer peripherals maker; China Development Industrial Bank; and Nien Hsing Textile.
Forbes surveyed 12,000 SMEs in 43 countries around the world outside the United States and then selected the best 200 to be published in the magazine's latest issue on Nov. 1.

The business magazine made their choices based on their definition of what constitutes an SME, which is any listed firm with an annual business turnover of less than US$500 million, and certain credentials including a stock dividend rate of no less than 10 percent, and annual transactions and profit growth each totaling at least a 15 percent increase over the previous year, according to Forbes compilers.

The countries with the most companies on the Forbes Best 200 SMEs list were Britain with 30, followed by France with 16 and Germany and Japan with 13 each. The other countries with at least 5 companies represented were Canada with 12, the Netherlands with 11 listed companies, Hong Kong and India each having 7, Denmark with six and Turkey with five SMEs.

In addition to the 200 firms based outside the US, Forbes also chose the 100 best SMEs in the United States, making up the "Forbes World's top 300" for business and investment reference for individuals and companies around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERFET DEMANDS PRO-INDONESIAN MILITIA DISARM

TEXT.P: The Australian-led UN peacekeeping force has demanded that pro-Indonesia militias disarm after a number of them surrendered and others were reportedly regrouping for a major attack against Interfet.

Interfet has increased the number of its troops along the West Timorese border to protect East Timorese people returning to their homeland after being forced to relocate following the August 30 ballot favoring independence for the former Portuguese colony.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN STOCK AND FOREX MARKETS DOWN

TEXT.P: Australian stock and foreign exchange markets took a beating after the Down Jones Industrial Average plunged 630 points last week.
The All Ordinaries Index plunged 34.6 points from Friday's close to 2827.7 on Monday morning, following a loss of 39 points on Friday.
The Australian currency was trading at 64.55 US cents on Monday morning, compared to Friday's close of 64.75 US cents, after a slide of 0.30 US cents on Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: IOC PROBING OLYMPIC TICKET SALE SCANDAL IN AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: The International Olympic Committee (IOC) is investigating the sale of tickets to wealthy people by the Sydney Organizing Committee for Olympic Games (SOCOG) for the purpose of raising the money it needed to host the world's biggest event.
Jacques Rogge, the IOC official in charge of coordinating the Sydney Games, told reporters in Florence that he will look into the SOCOG's latest strategy of raising cash "as soon as possible."

Rogge's comment came in response to Australian media reports last week that 250,000 wealthy Australian citizens were allocated tickets for the Olympic Games on the condition that they paid triple the original prices set by the SOCOG.

DOC.HEADLINE: BLACK BEAR SUSPECTED OF HAVING RAVAGED BEETLE NUT FARM
DOC.DATELINE: Pingtung, southern Taiwan, Oct. 18 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A black bear standing as tall as an average man was suspected of having ravaged a beetle nut farm in a village in Taiwan's southernmost county early Monday morning, the police said.
Police and fire fighters were summoned to a farm located in the Fanhua Village of Pingtung County's Changchih Township, where they found footprints but had no luck finding the four legged suspect.
According to farmer Chao Kuo-sheng, he spotted a black animal about the height of a man tearing the bark of a beetle nut tree on his farm at around 5:00 a.m.
Before he could see it clearly, the animal which Chao believed to be a black bear, fled at full speed upon hearing an approaching motorbike's engine, he said.

Chao's neighbors also complained to police that their farms were damaged by some unknown animals more than 20 days earlier. Previously thought to be dogs, they now believe that the saboteur might have been the same black bear, judging from similar traces of damage.

Lacking relevant knowledge, the Changchih Township police have sought help from the National Pingtung Technology Institute for apprehending the suspected animal. They also called for residents in the area to be on alert against any further encounters with the bear.

Zoologists arriving at the scene could not decide whether or not the the suspected black bear was a Formosan black bear, which is a rare and highly endangered species in Taiwan with an estimated population of only between 100 to 300.

According to zoological experts, Formosan black bears, Taiwan's largest mammal, have no natural enemies other than humans. The bear, indigenous to the island, has five-toed paws with long curbed claws that it uses to dig in search of roots and insects.
The omnivorous animal has large molars designed for grinding vegetables. The bears do not hibernate, and their most distinctive feature is a light-colored V-shape across their chest.
Although they can grow up to 200 kilograms, the Formosan black bears are good tree climbers and efficient predators.

The last time that Formosan black bears were the topic of discussion was shortly after the cataclysmic magnitude 7.3 earthquake struck central Taiwan on Sept. 21. Zoologists in Yushan National Park said that days before the devastating quake hit Taiwan, almost all the animals in the national park evacuated.
They said the national park was virtually empty as few of the regular wildlife residents could be found in the park in the wake of the quake.

They believe that the bigger the animals were, the earlier they left, reckoning that the Formosan black bears led the east-bound exodus, followed by deer, Formosan serow, Formosan muntjac, wild boar, brown wood owls, field mice, squirrels, birds and finally bees.
The zoologists say it is possible that long before an earthquake hits, certain elements are discharged from the earth that are noticeable to animals but not to humans.

DOC.HEADLINE: US TO PLAY INCREASING ROLE IN CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: The United States will play an increasingly important role in relations across the Taiwan Strait in the years ahead, the Republic of China's Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said on Monday.

The MAC, which charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, further revealed that US Under Secretary of State Thomas R. Pickering is scheduled to head a delegation to visit the mainland in the last week of October.

The MAC said in a report that Pickering's forthcoming visit is aimed at resuming friendly relations between Washington and Beijing, which were affected by NATO's mistaken bombing of mainland Chinese embassy in Belgrade in May.

The United States reportedly has paid US$4.5 million in humanitarian compensation for the human casualties or property damage caused by NATO bombing. However, mainland China still declined to compensate the United States for damage caused by mainland Chinese demonstrators to its embassy in Beijing following the NATO bombing.

The MAC said Pickering's mainland visit was decided during a September summit meeting in New Zealand between US President Bill Clinton and mainland President Jiang Zemin. The itinerary of Pickering's visit has not yet been formally announced.

In addition to easing mainland China's animosity toward the United States over the embassy bombing incident and discussing worsening bilateral trade disputes, the MAC said, the Clinton administration also hopes that Pickering's visit can help forge rapprochement with mainland China in other fields, including resuming dialogue on political, military and human rights issues.
The MAC went on to say that as the United States wants to prevent any escalation of tension in the Taiwan Strait, it will play an increasingly important role in cross-strait relations.

For instance, the Clinton administration sent Assistant Secretary of State Stanley Roth and American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Richard Bush to visit Beijing and Taipei, respectively, to reiterate US stances on cross-strait ties when tension in the Taiwan Strait escalated this summer after ROC President Lee Teng-hui defined cross-strait ties as a "special state-to-state relationship" in an interview with a German radio station in July.

Beijing interpreted the definition as a move to promote Taiwan independence and launched saber-rattling against Taiwan. Beijing continued its criticism even after Taiwan was rattled by a devastating earthquake on September 21.

Meanwhile, the MAC report said US Deputy Assistant Secretary of State Susan Shirk has suggested in a recent speech that Beijing adopt a more flexible policy toward Taiwan. For example, Shirk said Beijing can propose a "one country, three systems" formula to attract Taiwan to the negotiation table for discussing reunification issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND SHIPS SPOTTED NEAR JET FIGHTER CRASH SITE

TEXT.P: The ROC military is closely monitoring the sea lanes near the site of a jet fighter crash last week after mainland Chinese ships were spotted in the area off the coast of Hsinchu in northern Taiwan Monday morning.
The military sent two mine sweepers to the area to beef up patrols after observing around a dozen iron-clad ships from the mainland within six or seven nautical miles off Hsinchu.
The Air Force pinpointed the location of the 2000-5 Mirage jet fighter wreckage about seven nautical miles south of the Hsinchu Air base and about 17 meters below the surface of the sea.
The two-seated fighter crashed into the sea on a routine training mission on Friday. The two pilots were able to eject before the jet plunged into sea and later were rescued in good condition.

The Air Force had earlier tried to salvage the advanced jet fighter but was prevented from doing so because of rough seas. They will review the weather conditions for the afternoon to decide whether to begin the salvage effort.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIR FORCE OFFERING CASH AWARD FOR INFORMATION ON AMMUNITION THEFT

TEXT.P: The Air Force is offering a cash reward for information leading to arrests in two recent thefts on an air force base in northern Taiwan.
The Air Force General Headquarters said that anyone who can give information to help crack the two cases will be rewarded with NT$3 million (US$94,340).
On Oct. 3, around 9,000 rounds of ammunition went missing from the Taoyuan Air Force Base. The ammunition was for 65K2 rifles used by the logistics squadron stationed at the base.
On Oct. 10, a total of 121 rounds of ammunition, including flare bombs and grenades, were found missing during a routine check.
The two thefts in just the space of a week led to a public apology by Defense Minister Tang Fei for causing public uneasiness.
Tang vowed to pursue the cases thoroughly and step up the control and check of ammunition on the bases.

DOC.HEADLINE: HK DEMOCRACY PARTY CHAIRMAN CALLS ON TAIPEI MAYOR MA YING-JEOU

TEXT.P: Chairman Martin Lee of the Hong Kong Democracy Party called on Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou Monday morning to convey the concern of the people of Hong Kong following Taiwan's "921 Earthquake" that caused significant casualties.

Accompanied by party Vice Chairman Yeung Sum, Lee delivered a banner with signatures of Hong Kong people who extended their concern for Taiwan's quake victims, and he also presented a consolation card from his party when visiting Ma.

Ma was very touched by the concern from distant Hong Kong and stressed that Lee is well-known in Hong Kong and is a representative figure of those struggling for democracy there. Lee's visit to Taiwan is of great significance, Ma said.

Ma also slammed Beijing for its politicization of Taiwan's earthquake. He referred to Beijing's asking that the International Red Cross indirectly provide relief assistance to Taiwan's quake victims through the mainland Chinese Red Cross Society, an action that displeased the people of Taiwan.

He said that in the past, Taiwan has provided immediate assistance to mainland Chinese flood-stricken people, and private organizations have also proceeded to flood-stricken zones to take part in disaster relief work without any consideration of politics.

Lee said his party began a fund-raising activity soon after hearing news of the major temblor that rattled Taiwan on Sept. 21, and the party has received more than HK$1 million. Hong Kong people's support for fund raising for Taiwan quake victims has been far beyond the party's anticipation, said Lee.
During the meeting, Ma and Lee also agreed that in addition to relief aid regarding humanitarian concerns, both Taiwan and Hong Kong should engage in more extensive exchanges in various fields.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAYOR OF CHIAYI SAID A FAVORITE RUNNING MATE FOR JAMES SOONG

TEXT.P: James Soong, former governor of Taiwan Province and a Kuomintang maverick seeking to run for the year 2000 presidential election, is said to be likely to choose a woman running mate, and Chiayi Mayor Chang Po-ya has been seen as his favorite.

Lee than six months before the presidential election, only the KMT-nominated presidential candidate, the incumbent Vice President Lien Chan, has announced his running mate, the incumbent Premier Vincent Siew.

Lien is facing a fierce challenge from Soong, who continues to lead opinion polls. The Democratic Progressive Party's candidate, former Mayor of Taipei Chen Shui-bian, is also a big threat to Lien. Both Soong and Chen are said to be interested in having female running mates.

Chang, who holds a master's degree in public health from Johns Hopkins University in the United States and a doctorate in the same field from Kyorin University in Japan, has many years of administrative experience as Chiayi mayor, director of the public health department of Kaohsiung Medical College and director-general of the Department of Public Health under the Executive Yuan. In 1990, she was elected to the Legislative Yuan.

A leading figure among nonpartisans in the 1980s before new political parties were allowed to be formed, Chang enjoyed widespread popularity in elections. While her academic achievement and performance in public service are highly recognized, the mayor is also considered an ideal choice for any presidential candidate wishing to lock in votes from women.

Since Soong last visited the mayor in Chiayi City in late August, speculation about Chang being Soong's favorite running mate has not died down, although Chang herself categorically ruled out the possibility.

Chang previously pointed out that she once served as a subordinate to Lien in her position as a Cabinet member; Soong was also once her superior in his former role as Taiwan provincial governor. As a nonpartisan, she was once Chen's comrade before the DPP was founded. Chang said, however, she is not interested in becoming a presidential running mate. She has also declined to make any speeches supporting candidates at election campaign gatherings.

Heated discussion about the presidential election and candidates quieted down after Sept. 21, when a killer earthquake jolted Taiwan and caused severe damage. When Soong's campaign personnel disclosed recently that Soong would announce his running mate in November, Chang's name was again mentioned in local political circles.

The press failed to reach Chang for comment because she has gone on an overseas trip. None of her subordinates sees much possibility of Chang teaming up with Soong. One subordinate said it was hardly a theme for the mayor in discussions with her staff.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2 MORE KNOX-CLASS FRIGATES JOIN ROC NAVY

TEXT.P: Two more Knox-class frigates leased from the United States were commissioned on Monday to help beef up the Republic of China's naval defense capabilities.

A commissioning ceremony for the two warships, christened the Ningyang and the Iyang, was held at a naval base in Tsoying near the southern port city of Kaohsiung, with Navy Commander-in-Chief Li Chieh presiding.
Speaking on the occasion, Li praised naval officers and enlisted men who had traveled to the United States to take delivery of the two frigates.

Li said their diligence and good discipline have won the acclaim of US military personnel. "Your hard work has also helped save costs for repairing and refurbishing the two frigates," Li said, adding that he hopes all naval servicemen will keep this good tradition and system.

Noting that naval officers and enlisted men sent to the United States to receive the warships had been carefully selected, Li said their main missions included integrated training and combat skills training.
After a 40-day training voyage, the two frigates arrived at the Tsoying naval base on Oct. 4. They were the ROC Navy's seventh and eighth Knox-class frigates.
The Navy has leased a total of six Knox-class frigates from the United States since 1992 to reinforce its anti-submarine combat capabilities.

The US Navy built Knox-class frigates in the 1970s. They formed the backbone of the US anti-submarine fleet and also played an important role in accompanying and protecting other warships in the 1970s-1980s.
The Knox-class frigates are equipped with highly sophisticated sonar, torpedoes, deep-sea bombs, anti-ship missiles and many other advanced weaponry systems.

In the face of mounting military threat from mainalnd China, the commissioning of the two additional Knox-class frigates is expected to help upgrade the ROC's defense capability and safeguard peace and security in the Taiwan Strait, military authorities said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UNCHANGED ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar remained unchanged , closing at 31.765 against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Monday.
The local currency opened at 31.763 and was traded between 31.763 and 31.767. Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$158 million. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Oct. 18, or the tenth day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1405: Pope Pius II, originally named Enea Silivio Piccolomini, is born. He was noted for his unsuccessful attempt to lead a crusade against the Turks.
1685: French King Louis XVI turns the screw still further on the Protestants among his people by revoking the Edict of Nantes. Thousands of Protestants fled the country as a result.
1860: Invading British troops burn the Yuanmingyuan, the imperial summer palace in Beijing, to the ground.
1867: The United States purchases Alaska from Russia for US$7.2 million.
1873: Delegates from Columbia, Princeton, Rutgers and Yale universities meet and formulate the rules of American football.
1898: The United States takes possession of Puerto Rico from Spain.
1907: The first plans are announced for an International Court of Justice to be set up in The Hague.
1922: Tsai Yuan-pei, a scholar and the president of Peking University, resigns in the wake of student protest against an extra levy on professor's handouts.
1926: The will of Vladimir Ilich Lenin, Russian founder of the Bolshevik party, leader of the Russian Revolution and first head of the USSR, is made public to the world in the New York Times.
1931: Thomas Alva Edison, America's most prolific inventor, dies at the age of 84. His inventions include the phonograph, the microphone and the Kinetoscope, and he designed a complete electrical distribution system for lightning and power.
1941: General Hideki Tojo becomes prime minister of Japan and begins planning for war against the United States.
1944: US President Franklin D. Roosevelt cables Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the National government and supreme commander of the China theater of war, regarding his decision to appoint General Albert C. Wedemeyer as chief of staff of the China theater of war, succeeding General Joseph Stilwell.
1946: The Chinese communists reject the government's latest peace offer presented by Chiang Kai-shek on Oct. 16.
1967: Venera 4, a Soviet spacecraft, enters the atmosphere of Venus and transmits data back to earth.
1970: Vice President-Premier Yen Chia-kan leaves Taipei for New York to attend the 25th founding anniversary of the United Nations.
1976: Chinese-American scientist Samuel Chao Chung Ting and his colleague Burton Richter share the 1976 Nobel Prize for physics for their discovery of an elementary nuclear particle called the "psi," or "J particle."
1977: The five-day ordeal of passengers aboard a German Lufthansa jet hijacked by Palestinian terrorists ends today when a squad of crack troops storms the aircraft at Mogadishu Airport when it becomes likely that passengers would be killed.
1987: The United States attacks an Iranian oil rig in revenge for strikes against its shipping operations by gunboats.
1989: Erich Honecker, 77, East Germany's hardline ruler who failed to respond to the desire among East Germans for change, is ousted from the job he held for the previous 18 years.
1989: People trample each other as a crowd tries to squeeze through the gates of a stadium to watch a world cup soccer match in Guatemala; 83 are killed and nearly 200 others are injured.
1990: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) is established under the Executive Yuan to formulate and implement mainland policy, with Vice Premier Shih Chi-yang serving as its chairman.
1998: A pipeline explodes in a village in southwestern Nigeria when villagers try to siphon off oil, killing more than 700 people.
1998: Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the ROC's Straits Exchange Foundation, crowns a six-day visit to mainland China by meeting with President Jiang Zemin, marking the highest-level contact between the two sides since 1949.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The moral man, by living a life of simple truth and earnestness, alone can help to bring peace and order in the world."
