DOC.HEADLINE: TURKEY'S RED CRESCENT DONATES 25,000 EURO TO RCSROC FOR RELIEF FUND

TEXT.P: The Turkish Trade Office in Taipei on Monday donated 25,000 euro (about NT$863,000) to the Red Cross Society of the Republic of China (RCSROC) for its Taiwan quake-relief fund.
Turkey had also sent three rescue teams to Taiwan to join relief efforts following the disastrous "921 Earthquake" that caused significant casualties.
Teoman Surenkok, representative of the Turkish Trade Office in Taipei, presented the fund to Henry Hsu, president of the RCSROC, at a ceremony held at the RCSROC office.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-US CIVIL NUCLEAR COOPERATION MEETING TO BEGIN TUESDAY

TEXT.P: An ROC-US joint meeting on civil nuclear cooperation will begin in northern Taiwan Tuesday.

More than 100 nuclear experts and scholars from the Republic of China and the United States will take part in the two-day meeting at the Institute of Nuclear Energy Research (INER) in Lungtang, Taoyuan County.
ROC participants will include representatives of the Atomic Energy Council (AEC), National Tsing Hua University and Taiwan Power Company, as well as INER officials, said AEC officials.

US officials of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, the Department of Energy, the State Department, the Environmental Protection Agency, and related laboratories will also take part in the meeting, AEC officials said.
They noted that since an ROC-US agreement on civil nuclear cooperation was signed in October 1984, the two sides have taken turns holding the annual meeting.

The Republic of China and the United States have to date cooperated on more than 120 research projects relating to thermal hydraulics, applications of radioisotopes, earthquakes, emergency response, and advanced nuclear power plants.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS URGE US ENDORSEMENT OF TAIWAN SECURITY ENHANCEMENT BILL

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Vice President Rau Yin-chi said Monday that the Taiwan Security Enhancement Bill is expected to be passed by the US House of Representatives and that all Congress members are concerned about the security problem between Taiwan and mainland China.

Rau, who just returned from a US trip with the dual purpose of expressing gratitude for rescue and relief assistance after Taiwan's Sept. 21 earthquake and of lobbying Congress for passage of the bill, added, however, that the bill is not likely to be passed by the Senate due to reservations of some Democrats.

Rau made the statement during a press conference held at the Legislative Yuan. Others who accompanied him on the trip said that Democrats are at loggerheads with Republicans in the Senate over the recent rejection of the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty, and therefore the bill might be shelved.

Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislator Parris Chang, who visited the United States with Rau and was present at the press conference, accused the ROC government of having failed to make enough effort in lobbying for passage of the Taiwan Security Enhancement Bill.

Chang noted that some US legislators had revealed that if the Republic of China government had devoted as much effort and resources as it did when lobbying for President Lee Teng-hui's 1995 visit to the United States, then the bill might have passed.

According to Chang, the Taiwan Security Enhancement Bill, designed to increase US arms sales to Taiwan and to construct a more cooperative bilateral relationship in terms of armed forces and security maintenance, is currently under review and has been opposed by some US administrative departments on the grounds that Taiwan's arguments for buying more weapons are not convincing and are not specifically designed to meet the needs of national defense.

Along with eight other legislators from the ruling Kuomintang and the main opposition DPP, Rau departed for the United States on Oct. 1. During the week-long visit, they met with representatives from both the House and Senate, as well as American Institute in Taiwan Chairman Richard Bush, private think tanks and groups of overseas Taiwanese. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ORDERS INTEGRATION OF POST-QUAKE PAYMENTS AND SUBSIDIES

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew ordered the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) on Monday to integrate and simplify the government programs for "provisional work subsidies" and "work in exchange for relief."

The fifth meeting of the government Post-quake Reconstruction Committee was held Monday morning. During the meeting, CLA Chairman Chan Hou-sheng reported on measures to distribute provisional work subsidies and to implement the work-for-relief program.
Premier Siew gave his instructions after Chan's report.

Both Chao Shou-po, chairman of the Taiwan provincial government, and Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), conveyed many quake-victims' feelings of confusion over government work-relief measures, which should be integrated and simplified.
There were reports that some temblor victims have worked but still have not been paid, while others have been paid but have not yet done any work.

Siew indicated that the work-for-relief program is worthwhile for quake survivors, being not only beneficial for their psychological recovery, but also providing them with job opportunities. The measure would thus function as a stabilizing force on the public's mentality and on social order, the prime minister added.

As for problems confronting implementation of the integrated program, Siew remarked that the CLA should make the process easy for local governments to conduct and simple enough for quake survivors to understand.

CLA officials should explain the procedures, after making the necessary adjustments, to local governments, so that they would assist with promotion of government post-quake reconstruction efforts, said Siew.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES, INDEX FUTURES DOWN

TEXT.P: Dragged down by overnight Wall Street losses and the news that the operational tax on banks will not be lowered for the next four years, Taiwan share prices closed 1.1 percent lower Monday.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index shed 84.13 points to close at 7,745.26 on a turnover of NT$75.25 billion (US$2.37 billion).
Due to a lack of new incentives on the local bourse and a likely interest rate hike by the US Federal Reserve Board, the Taipei stock market opened lower and closed lower.
Investors rushed to sell the financial issues they had bought on Saturday, following a Ministry of Finance (MOF) denial of reports that it would cut the operational tax on banks.
After the stock market had closed last Saturday, the MOF announced it would not consider lowering the tax from two percent to one percent within the next four years.

Despite Monday's decline, dealers expected a boom sometime in the future as construction shares, cement issues and construction-related materials issues will likely be boosted by post-quake reconstruction.
Some dealers predicted the market will continue to consolidate in the short term until third-quarter corporate results are released at the end of this month.

Among the eight major stock categories, the plastics and chemical sector took the lead, ending the day with 2.35-percent gains, while financial issues and electronics shares closed lower, posting 2.76-percent and 2-percent losses, respectively.
Declining stocks led advancing stocks 330 to 123, with 82 shares unchanged.
The over-the-counter market rose 0.54 points to close at 183.88 on a turnover of NT$9.94 billion.
Shadowed by the shoddy performance of the stock market, all TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) posted losses.
TAIEX Index Futures for October moved down 77 points to close at 7,735 with 728 contract transactions. Those for November shed 106 points to finish at 7,749 with 1,313 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for December declined 36 points to close at 7,789 with nine contract transactions, while those for next March shed 185 points to end at 7,737 with five contract transactions. Those for next June dropped 12 points to end at 7,810 with three contract transactions. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: 'TAIWAN THANKS THE WORLD' COMMERCIAL TO BE AIRED ON CNN

TEXT.P: A 30-second commercial featuring the Republic of China's gratitude for foreign assistance in its post-earthquake relief work will be aired on Cable News Network (CNN) beginning Oct. 20, a Foreign Ministry official reported on Monday.

The piece, titled "Taiwan Thanks the World," is in English and will be broadcast on CNN during prime time from Oct. 20 through Oct. 24, the official said, adding that Foreign Minister Jason Hu will hold a news conference on Wednesday morning to introduce the commercial.
According to the official, three advertisement agencies had presented production plans and the Foreign Ministry selected the one which expressed Taiwan's gratitude in an abstract way.

Ministry tallies show that more than 110 countries around the world have either sent rescue teams, donated relief goods or funds, or expressed concern via telephone or written messages after Taiwan was rattled by a devastating earthquake on Sept. 21.
"We think that an abstract way will be most effective in highlighting our theme of thanking all those who have offered help or expressed concern for our post-earthquake situation," the official said.

After the piece was completed, the Foreign Ministry invited some staff members, scholars, experts and foreign representatives stationed in Taiwan to a preview. "The brief film has received a warm response from the audience," the official said.

As overseas Chinese have also made generous donations to various post-earthquake relief and reconstruction projects, the official said the commercial has a Chinese version, titled "Taiwan Thanks All Overseas Chinese for Their Assistance and Concern," which will be aired on a Los Angeles-based satellite television station during the same five-day period.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO THOUSAND INVESTORS PROTEST IN CHINA

TEXT.P: Some 2,000 mainland Chinese investors Monday gathered at the railway station of Chongqing and lay down on train tracks to protest against a government plan to clean up the so-called "illegal investment companies" in the city.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China said the investors also staged a demonstration at the city government, believing that the plan announced by it a couple of days before , could wipe out the money they have invested in those companies. There are dozens of them in the city in southwestern Sichuan province.
Hundreds of police helped keep the situation under control, the information center said, adding that 10 people were arrested and three others injured during the protests.

DOC.HEADLINE: NETHERLANDS AGREES TO HELP TAIWAN JOIN WTO

TEXT.P: The Republic of China and the Netherlands reached a series of conclusions at their annual Economic and Trade Consultation Meeting held at the Sherwood Taipei in downtown Taipei Monday.
The two parties agreed to sign the ROC-Netherlands Double Taxation Exemption Accord, the Tax Evasion Prevention Accord, and the ROC-Netherlands Patent Priority Right Reciprocal Accord.

The Netherlands also agreed to support Taiwan in its bid to join the World Trade Organization (WTO) and to become an observer in the Competition Policy Committee of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), the club for the rich countries of the world.
The Netherlands will send an official delegation to Taipei at the end of November to further discuss technical issues regarding the proposed ROC-Netherlands Double Taxation Exemption Accord.
The Netherlands gave its nod to the Patent Priority Right Reciprocal Accord drafted by the ROC delegation, and both sides tentatively agreed to discuss details of the contents in the near future.
Both sides agreed to further promote trade by using the Internet or trade promotion organizations to help businesses of both countries tap economic opportunities.
ROC Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu and Dutch Vice Foreign Trade Minister Frans A. Engering jointly presided over the meeting.
Later in the day, a seminar on energy and environmental protection was held to discuss measures for handling related problems affecting both countries.
Vice Economics Minister Yin Chi-ming and Engering jointly presided over the seminar.
Engering headed a 16-member delegation of officials and business leaders, who arrived in Taipei Sunday to attend the series of meetings.

Members of the Dutch delegation also planned to meet officials of Taiwan Power Co., Nanya Plastics Corp., the Chinese Petroleum Co., China Steel Corp., Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park and Tainan Science-based Industrial Park.

BMT BV (Begemann Milieutechniek), a company specializing in disposal of mercury-contaminated materials, has a keen interest in making contact with Nanya Plastics Corp., of the Formosa Group, to strike a deal to dispose of more than 1,000 tons of contaminated waste, a venture worth NT$100 million.

Representatives of Electron, another Dutch company, which specializes in erecting steel towers for electrical transmission systems, will meet with Taipower officials to help Taiwan replace steel towers destroyed by the 921 Earthquake.
Other Dutch business leaders in the group represent the waste-water management industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OFFICIALS REJECT JIANG'S REMARKS ON REUNIFICATION

TEXT.P: Taiwan officials on Monday rejected mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin's remarks that China's unification will be achieved in the first half of the next century.
"How can there be a timetable for China's unification?" asked officials with the Mainland Affairs Council.
"Jiang's statement just serves to outline Beijing's hegemonic manner and that he totally doesn't understand the feeling of people on Taiwan (toward the unification issue)," the officials said.

Jiang said in an interview with The Times newspaper that by the middle of the next century, mainland China will resolve the question of Taiwan and accomplish the great cause of national reunification by adhering to the policy of "peaceful reunification" and "one country, two systems," after the successful return of Hong Kong and Macau.
Stressing that the Republic of China has never changed its goal of seeking national unification, the officials that there should be no timetable for such a goal.
Under Taiwan's Guidelines for National Unification, China's unification should be a gradual process and eventually be realized when the mainland becomes a free, democratic and prosperous society.

The officials said there is nothing new in Jiang's remarks, as he merely repeated Beijing's term "one nation, two systems," while still refusing to renounce using force against Taiwan and continuing to press for a halt to US arms sales to Taiwan.

But they warned that Jiang's "50-year theory" doesn't mean that mainand China will wait until 50 years from now to start to solve the so-called "Taiwan problem." On the contrary, they said, Beijing will not hesitate to try to annex Taiwan once it is capable of doing so.

However, the statement also reveals Jiang himself is very clear that cross-strait disputes could not be solved overnight and may be left for the next one or two generations of leaders on both sides, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOCTORS WITHOUT BORDERS TO SHARE POST-QUAKE MENTAL HEALTH EXPERIENCE

TEXT.P: A delegation from the Paris-based international humanitarian assistance organization Doctors Without Borders, which won the 1999 Nobel Peace Prize, arrived in Taipei Monday evening to relate psychological rehabilitation experiences to benefit 921 Earthquake survivors in Central Taiwan.
Led by Dominique Leguiller, director of the Far Eastern Affairs Bureau of Doctors Without Borders, the three-person delegation also includes two Japanese doctors, Moto Imaki and Daisuke Sekiguchi.
Leguiller said the organization had sent a four-member mission to Taiwan after the earthquake jolted the island on Sept. 21, in order to gather firsthand information about the devastating quake.

The three will visit Chungliao, Puli, Chushan and Yutzu in Central Taiwan and meet with local medical care organizations and social welfare workers to help them learn from the experience of psychological rehabilitation of survivors of the 1995 Kobe earthquake in Japan.
Leguiller hoped that sharing such experiences would help with the recovery of quake survivors' mental health.

The delegation is visiting Taiwan at the joint invitation of cultural worker Yang Meng-tse, the Kaohsiung City government, the Nanhai Foundation for Culture and Education, Chang Kung Hospital, Huafan University and Tzu Chi Hospital.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S WTO BID FACES BLOCKADE

TEXT.P: The closer Taiwan gets to the final stage in its bid for membership in the World Trade Organization (WTO), the larger the blockade it faces, said the director-general of the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) on Monday.

Chen Ruey-long said several WTO members have never stopped voicing opposition to the idea that Taiwan enter the world trade regulatory body before Beijing does, and BOFT officials may not be able to carry out their plan as expected.

For months, BOFT has spared no effort in seeking the WTO's completion of the process of multilateral review of Taiwan's membership application before the opening of the November WTO ministerial meeting in Seattle, Chen said.

Not until the process is concluded can Taiwan's WTO bid enter the final stage -- the WTO's pragmatic review of the case, which represents the last hurdle facing Taiwan's membership application, said Chen.

However, now the multilateral review process is in a state of almost complete rest, which means that Taiwan might not be able to win WTO membership by the end of this year, as it had targeted as a goal, Chen said.
Taipei had pledged to strive for WTO membership no later than the last day of this year, as part of its effort to boost Taiwan's standing in a widely opening world trade community.

In 1990 Taiwan applied to participate in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), whose successor, the WTO, came into existence in 1995 and expanded efforts to promote trade liberalization globally.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA SEEN FUELING ARMS RACE IN NORTHEAST ASIA

TEXT.P: Australia will likely fuel a regional arms race among Taiwan, mainland China, Japan, and North and South Korea by upgrading its spy base in Pine Gap, Alice Springs, to be used in a scaled-down version of the US Star Wars missile defense system, experts said.

In an interview with the Central News Agency (CNA) on Monday, Dr. Gary Klintworth, a former strategist for the Defense Intelligence Organization and a China-Taiwan expert at Australian National University, said the new Theater Missile Defense (TMD) system would become the first step in a new arms race in Northeast Asian countries because they want to try to outdo each other in missiles and counter-missile technology.
He said Taiwan has already acquired Patriot missiles from the United States, and they could serve as part of the TMD system.
But if Taiwan is included in the TMD system, China is expected to increase production of missiles, creating greater risk to the Northeast Asian region, Klintworth said.
"It will be a big challenge to all countries concerned on how to reduce tensions as a result of such an arms race," he said, adding that "the mutual risk is likely to increase."
He said, "The TMD system will not only fuel an arms race, but also creates instability in the region, which must be handled seriously and carefully."

He said the TMD system could proceed soon because Japan, Taiwan and South Korea have acquired defensive missiles from the United States, and once the TMD system is installed, it would likely be upgraded to a National Missile Defense (NMD) system, which is a major part of the Star Wars program.

The daily newspaper The Australian on Monday also reported that in Pine Gap, Australia could indirectly play a role in fueling the arms race because the spy base there would play a crucial role in the new TMD system.

The daily quoted US Air Force Secretary F. Whitten Peters as revealing that the joint US-Australian base would be more important in the US early-warning system for detecting missile launches than the previous base at Nurrungar near Woomera in southern Australia, which was closed recently.
The new spy base will have a new Space Based Infrared System (SBIRS) installed and is due to begin operations in 2004, the daily reported.
"We see this as absolutely critical to the functioning of theater missile defense and ultimately to national missile defense as well," Peters said.

The daily also quoted other analysts as warning that TMD would spark an arms race as China, Taiwan, Japan and both Koreas scramble to match each other's ability to fire and defend missiles potentially carrying nuclear warheads.

"It's like Russian roulette. The Chinese will say, 'Well OK, we'll give you a few more chambers in the revolver.' They'll just increase their production of tactical missiles, and say, 'Guys, we don't like this, but if you insist on trying to neutralize our deterrent, we'll have to take appropriate steps to make sure you don't become a base for US aggression," a senior analyst told the daily.
Klintworth said the TMD system could undermine the anti-ballistic missile treaty, which has served as a major factor in arms control over the past 25 years.
The US Senate recently rejected the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty, and that could only increase the chance of an arms race rather than decreasing it, Klintworth told CNA. (by Peter Chen)

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Oct. 19, or the 11th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occured on this date in the past:
1216: King John of England, known as John Lackland, dies at the age of 49. During his reign, the English lost most of their possessions in France. The nobility rose against John and forced him to sign the Magna Carta, a cornerstone of English freedom.
1781: General Charles Cornwallis, 46, British commander, unwittingly delivers his 8,000 troops into the hand of the besieging American forces at Yorktown in Virginia, allowing General George Washingon to win the War of Independence for the colonists.
1812: Tsar Alexander's refusal to negotiate, along with renewed Russian military activity to the south of Moscow, leaves Napoleon Bonaparte with no alternative but to begin retreating from Moscow, which was captured by the French six earlier.
1859: Alfred Dreyfus, French army officer, is born. He was falsely accused of treason and sent to Devil's Island, which caused a national scandal.
1864: The Civil War Battle of Cedar Creek in America ends with the victory of General Philip Henry Sheridan over the Confederates.
1872: The Holtermann Nugget, a slab of slate weighing 235.14 kg, is found in New South Wales, Australia. It contains 82.11 kg of gold, the largest mass of gold ever found.
1897: George Mortimer Pullman, American industrialist and inventor of the Pullman sleeping car for the railroad, dies in Chicago at the age of 66. He built the town of Pullman to house his employees.
1901: Alberto Santos Dumont, a Brazilian aviator, circumnavigates the Eiffel Tower in his airship to win the Deutsche Prize, the first aviation prize.
1925: Chiang Ching-kuo leaves Shanghai for Moscow to study at Sun Yat-sen University there.
1935: The League of Nations imposes sanctions against Italy following its invasion of Ethiopia.
1936: Chou Shu-jen, a modern Chinese writer who used the pen name Lu Hsun and was most admired by the Chinese communists, dies of illness in Shanghai at the age of 56.
1937: Ernest Rutherford, New Zealand-born British physicist who won the 1908 Nobel Prize for Chemistry, dies at the age of 66. He is regarded as the founder of modern atomic theory.
1940: The Burma road is reopened after Britain closed the road for three months.
1947: The Taiwan Provincial Government opens Keelung and Kaohsiung as international seaports.
1950: The North Korean capital of Pyongyang falls during the Korean War.
1958: British driver Mike Hawthorn becomes world motor racing champion.
1960: The US State Department establishes an embago on Cuban-bound shipments of all goods except medicine and footstuffs.
1960: Mauritania proclaims independence from France.
1963: Sir Alec Douglas-Home succeeds Harold Macmillan as British prime minister.
1968: ROC athlete Chi Cheng wins a bronze medal in the women's 80-meter low hurdle event with a time of 10.4 seconds at the 19th Olympic Games held in Mexico City.
1983: Maurice Bishop, prime minister of Grenada, is killed in a military coup.
1987: Wall Street experiences the worst day in its history, known as "Black Monday," with the Dow Jones Industrial Average plummeting a record 508.32 points, knocking US$500 billion off share values. The percentage decline is 22.6, almost 10 percent greater than the 1929 big crash, which heralded the Great Depression.
1990: Michael Gorbachev, the last Soviet president, wins parliamentary approval for a plan to switch to a market economy from the old-style communist central planning.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In the Book of Songs it is said: `I keep in mind the fine moral qualities which make no great noise or show.'"

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE EARTHQUAKES JOLT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan was shaken by an earthquake which hit Chia Yi's Ali mountain in southern Taiwan with a magnitude of 3 at 10:27 a.m. on Tuesday, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported.
A moment magnitude of 2 was detected in the township of Kukeng in Yunlin province while Ming Chieng in Nantou registered a magnitude 1, according to the report.
Meanwhile , a magnitude 5.5 aftershock from the devastating earthquake that hit Taiwan on Sept. 21 jolted Nantou County on Tuesday, CWB seismologists reported.

The temblor occurred at around 12 p.m., with its epicenter 23.8 kilometers southeast of Nantou's scenic Sun Moon Lake in central Taiwan. The shake was measured at a magnitude of 5 in Ming Chien township in Nantou.
Nantou County sustained the heaviest damage killer Earthquake," the largest recorded quake to hit Taiwan this century, claiming more than 2,300 lives and injuring over 10,000 people islandwide.
Since Sept. 21, 1,285 perceptible aftershocks and other thousands which could only be detected by precision instruments have been recorded, according to the seismologists.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SIEW THANKS OVERSEAS CHINESE FOR AID TO TAIWAN QUAKE VICTIMS
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 18 (CNA) (By Huang Kwang-chun and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew on Monday thanked overseas Chinese for their enthusiasm in providing assistance to Taiwan's quake victims during a video tape made in advance to congratulate them on Overseas Chinese Day which falls on Oct. 21.

Siew stressed in the six-minute tape that overseas Chinese, with their enthusiasm for supporting their motherland and a spirit of enduring hardships, have made great contributions to the founding of the Republic of China and to the development of the countries which they now reside in.

He said that the Republic of China is now the 15th largest trading country and the 18th largest economy in the world. Due mainly to the support of overseas Chinese, the Republic of China's progress in attaining democracy has won extensive affirmation from the international community, he said.
Siew also indicated that President Lee Teng-hui's proposal in early July that the cross-Taiwan Strait relationship is a "special state-to-state" one reflected the voice of the people of Taiwan.
He also said he hopes that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can create a win-win situation and an atmosphere of co-existence and co-prosperity in the development of cross-strait ties.
Siew took the opportunity to extend the ROC government and the people's deep gratitude to the overseas Chinese for their humanitarian assistance to Taiwan's quake victims.
