DOC.HEADLINE: MANDARIN AIRLINES TO OPERATE TAIPEI-KAOHSIUNG ROUTE FROM NOV. 1

TEXT.P: Mandarin Airlines will take over China Airlines' Taipei-Kaohsiung flight routes from Nov. 1, sources with the airline said on Tuesday.
Mandarin Airlines will offer 40 to-and-fro Taipei-Kaohsiung flights each day beginning Nov. 1, said the sources. The airline operates 16 to-and-fro Taipei-Kaohsiung flights per day at present.
The domestic airline merged with Formosa Airlines on Aug. 8 and took over that airline's original flight routes following the merger.
China Airlines, originally the national carrier, is scheduled to operate international routes exclusively from Nov. 1, the sources said.
At present, Far East Air Transport Corp. offers 60 to-and-fro Taipei-Kaohsiung flights per day, UNI Airlines offers 36 such flights, and TransAsia Airways offers 30 such flights.

DOC.HEADLINE: US EXPERT CALLS FOR TAIWAN-QUESTION MEETING ON NEUTRAL TERRITORY

TEXT.P: To break the ongoing stalemate over cross-strait relations, Beijing should consider another meeting between the two side's negotiators on neutral territory, said an American Asia-Pacific specialist.

Ralph A. Cossa of the Washington-based Center for Strategic and International Studies, recently wrote that Taiwan President Lee Teng-hui's dramatic "state-to-state relations" statement on July 9 had greatly affected regional stability.

President Lee back-stepped slightly by assuring Beijing that his comment referring to how cross-straits dialogue should be viewed would not be embodied in the ROC's Constitution. While this has not satisfied Beijing, it appears highly unlikely that Taipei will back down further. This is sure to keep cross-strait tensions high between now and Taiwan's March 2000 presidential elections, if not longer, noted the editor of the CSIS Pacific Forum.

Cossa pointed out that one consequence of Lee's remarks has been to put future high-level cross-strait dialogue at risk. The planned fall visit to Taiwan of Wang Daohan, the head of the PRC's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, will almost certainly not occur.

With Beijing's insistence on a retraction of the state-to-state comment unacceptable to Taipei, one option might be a meeting on neutral territory such as Singapore or Hong Kong to discuss the meaning of Lee's comments and their implications for cross-strait relations, said Cossa.
"This would demonstrate Beijing's commitment to keep the dialogue process alive without accepting Lee's position," Cossa stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE MPS DECRY US CONGRESS RECEIVING MORE INFO ON MILITARY BASE

TEXT.P: Australian members of Parliament have strongly attacked the Defense Department for giving less information to them than to the US Congress about the Australian-US joint intelligence base located on Australian soil.

The Joint Standing Committee on Treaties complained in a report tabled on Monday that the US Congress has been given much freer access to information about Pine Gap- a base for detecting missile launches and seen as a major site for the proposed Theater Missile Defense system- than Australian MPs have.

The report demanded that Defense Minister John Moore authorize his department to provide more information to them on the purpose and operations of Pine Gap, allow Australian MPs to visit the base, and provide them with a copy of the secret agreement under which the spy base operates.

Under the joint agreement between the US and Australia, the Pine Gap base is to be used up to November 2008. But Australian MPs and senators on Monday threatened that they would not be able to offer their support for the base if they didn't receive sufficient information about its operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: US SHOULD CONSIDER ENHANCING ASIAN DEFENSE DIPLOMACY

TEXT.P: To minimize Communist China's ability to interfere with US interests in the Asia-Pacific region, Washington should explore enhanced defense relations with the nations of southeast Asia and possibly Taiwan, said a former staff member of the US House Armed Services Committee Monday.

Jason Bruzdzinski, in the latest issue of "Defense News" weekly reported that Beijing's recent decision to deny US military access to Hong Kong has complicated important planning for US naval and air operations in the Asia-Pacific, specifically the ability of US forces to rapidly respond to crises.
Since May, at least a dozen US Navy requests for port calls in Hong Kong reportedly have been denied.

If Beijing's closure of Hong Kong to US combatants is an effort by Communist China to complicate American defense strategy in Asia, US policy-makers must shape a multifaceted response, noted Bruzdzinski.

The US government should explore enhanced defense diplomacy with Thailand, Singapore, the Philippines, Vietnam and even Taiwan and coordinate, with regional friends and allies, "the redirection of plans and operations to minimize China's ability to interfere with US regional security and military strategy," concluded Bruzdzinski.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CHAIRMAN COMMENTS ON JIANG'S TIMETABLE FOR CHINA REUNIFICATION

TEXT.P: None of individuals or either side of the Taiwan Strait has the right to decide China's future, said the chairman of Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), after mainland China President Jiang Zemin's revelation on Monday of a timetable for China's reunification.
Su Chi made the remarks during a press interview in Taipei on Monday evening. He stressed that the China dispute can only be settled through bilateral negotiations between Taiwan and mainland China.
The Republic of China government hopes that the two sides will be reunified in a gradual process, rather than in a situation that sees one side swallow the other, Su stressed.

Jiang said in an interview with The Times of Britain that by the middle of next century, mainland China "will resolve the question of Taiwan and accomplish the great cause of national reunification by adhering to the policy of 'peaceful reunification' and 'one country, two systems' after the successful return of Hong Kong and Macau."

Su described the statement as being merely a unilateral opinion of the Beijing authorities, saying if Beijing wants to set up any timetables it should make one that concerns mainland China's democratization.
"We believe it's more pragmatic now for Beijing to formulate a 50 years timetable for the mainland's democratization," Su said.
If Beijing can resolve its democratic problems, it will face no difficulties on China's reunification, Su added.

Jiang seemed to draw a beautiful picture of the mainland's future in his remarks, in which, however, there were no words about the process of mainland China's democratization, Su said, noting Taiwan has been taking the mainland's democratization as the most important matter in the reunification of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: NYSE SLIDE LIKELY TO CONTINUE

TEXT.P: Despite Monday's gain of 96.57 points in the Dow Jones Industrial Index, Wall Street insiders warned that the New York stock market could get a lot worse before it gets better.

At the end of Monday's volatile trading, the Dow Jones industrial average rose to 10116.28 points, while the NASDAQ composite index tumbled 43 points to 2688,83. During the session, the Dow Jones industrial average dipped below the psychologically important 10, 000 level several times.
After last week's devastating 6 percent loss of value, nervous investors and traders are apprehensive about the week ahead. They see no end in sight for the current market downturn.
One reason they pointed to was last Friday's selling pressure which remained unabated all day, having no end-of-day rally to pare the losses.
The scheduled release Tuesday of one of the government's most important inflation statistics--the consumer price index (CPI)--is not expected to reduce market jitters, economists said.
They now expect that the CPI will reflect an inflationary trend in the US economy, which is bad for corporations as their costs will go up.

Higher costs cut into profits, leaving shareholders with lower earnings than they've been accustomed to during the nine-year-long bull market. That, too, could contribute to selling pressure this week.

DOC.HEADLINE: SENATOR SAYS US UNPREPARED FOR GERM TERRORISM

TEXT.P: US Senator Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) warned Sunday that the official US response to New York's encephalitis outbreak showed how "woefully under prepared" the country is to defend itself against biological terrorism.
While praising the overall local response in containing the outbreak and minimizing fatalities, Schumer said the state and federal response was fractured and had revealed "troubling flaws."

Describing the virus, which is carried by mosquitoes, as a "dry run" for a biological terrorist assault on a major American urban center, he said the FBI believes that a biological attack against the US is "not a matter of if but when."
The virus has so far claimed six lives and has infected 55 citizens in the New York metropolitan area.
Schumer disclosed that he will lobby the Feds for a $20 million funding boost for New York City to maximize local authorities' ability to respond to a biological or chemical outbreak.
His comments follow a report in last week's New Yorker magazine suggesting that New York's West Nile-like fever outbreak was an Iraqi bio-terrorist attack. Federal sources have denied that.

He also called on President Bill Clinton to appoint a federal czar to coordinate all local, state and federal responses, saying disease-control experts were not necessarily qualified to identify a possible terrorist threat.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUPPORT FOR QUEBEC SOVEREIGNTY ON THE DECLINE, POLL FINDS

TEXT.P: A new poll released Monday shows support for sovereignty is declining in Quebec while support for federalism is on the rise.

The poll, sponsored by the Center for Research and Information on Canada, suggests that the more that sovereignty is identified with secession and independence, the less likely Quebecers would be to vote "Yes" in a referendum.

The poll found that 24 percent of the "yes" supporters in the 1995 referendum describe themselves as less sovereign-oriented these days. More than 4 out of 10 would switch their vote to "no" if a referendum were held today.

The poll shows support for the "yes" side at 44 percent, with 56 percent voting "no." Also, 35 percent of those polled say Quebec Premier Lucien Bouchard's real motive for campaigning for sovereignty is to renew federalism.

Former Ontario premier Bob Rae, a board member of the Center, said the results indicate Ottawa's "Plan B" on Quebec separatism is bearing fruit. The plan demands that separatists ask a clear question if they want to hold a referendum. It also cites the Supreme Court decision to demand a clear majority of the vote as a prerequisite for negotiating separation.
Such a tough stand has had a "sobering effect" on Quebec's public opinion, telling them that a yes vote in a referendum is not a walk in the park, Rae said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar finished 0.4 cent lower against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Tuesday, closing at 31.769.
The currency opened at 31.763, and was traded between 31.770 and 31.763. Interbank US dollar trading reached US$150 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: DUTCH CO. SEEK BIZ. OPPORTUNITIES WITH TAIPOWER, CPC
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 19 (CNA) (By Shammy Chao) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Taipei, Oct. 19 (CNA): Electron Holdings BV, a Dutch company specialized in erecting steel towers for electrical transmission systems, has expressed its keen interest in doing business with the state-run Taiwan Power Co.
Representatives of Electron Holdings BV will call on high-ranking Taipower officials on Wednesday to sound out business opportunities.

The devastating earthquake that jolted Taiwan on Sept. 21 has caused heavy damages to Taipower's electrical transmission system. More than 150 steel towers have collapsed or been damaged, and while some repairs are expected to take only a few days or weeks to complete, others -- including reconstruction -- may take up to six months.

The Dutch company has manufactured an emergency power transmission system that uses 35-meter-high temporary steel towers, capable of transmitting up to 500 kilowatts, which can be erected within four hours.

Representatives of Shell Global Solutions, a Dutch syndicate specialized in technology consultation and services, will call on officials of the state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. on Wednesday to sound out business cooperation opportunities.
The Dutch businessmen came to Taiwan to attend the one-day Taiwan-Holland Economic and Trade Consultation Meeting held on Monday after six years of hiatus.
Frans A. Engering, the Dutch Vice Foreign Trade Minister, headed the meeting's 16-member delegation.

DOC.HEADLINE: GUIDELINES FOR EMERGENCY DECREE TO BE SUBMITTED TO LEGISLATURE: LEE

TEXT.P: The guidelines for implementing the 921 Emergency Decree will be submitted to the Legislature for a review, and the matter will be discussed by the Cabinet, President Lee Teng-hui told the press on Tuesday.
The passage of the guidelines was aimed at doing a better job, not at bypassing the Legislature on the matter, Lee added.

Lee was on his way to visit the stricken Taichung County, and was very concerned about the process of the post-quake rehabilitation efforts. He said the victims' psychological recovery is more important than material reconstruction.

The 14-point guidelines were passed on Monday by the Cabinet's Post-Quake Reconstruction Committee, headed by Premier Vincent Siew, and scheduled to be handed to the Executive Yuan council for ratification on Thursday.

The Cabinet noted that the straightforward instructions were designed to iron out disputes over hazy areas of the Emergency Decree, which was declared by the president on Sept. 25 to clear financial and bureaucratic obstacles to post-quake reconstruction efforts.
The issues addressed include the bidding for construction projects and the appropriation of civil resources, as well as the allocation of public land to temblor victims.

Lawmakers claimed, however, that the executive body was giving itself free rein to interpret the decree as it pleases, and to dodge parliamentary supervision by using "guidelines for implementation" instead of the original "bylaws for implementation."
The lawmakers were referring to the prime minister's former assertion that there was no need for a legislative review, which has sparked much controversy.

Legislators from the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) insisted that all administrative instructions attached to laws must be submitted to the Legislature as long as they involve civil rights and responsibility.
The DPP have already proposed to turn the issue over to the Council of Grand Justice for an interpretation of the constitution, according to reports.

Although still insisting the guidelines did not surpass the scope of the Emergency Decree, Siew has asked the justice minister to "look into" the question of submitting them to the legislature, said a government spokesman.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL FINDS TAIWAN ADOLESCENTS DO NOT ADOPT CONTRACEPTION MEASURES

TEXT.P: A recent global survey found that 49 percent of adolescents in Taiwan didn't adopt any safety measures the first time they had intercourse, far higher than the world average of 28 percent.

Durex Condom Co. interviewed 4,200 adolescents and young adults aged between 16 and 21 in 14 countries about their sexual experience. Countries covered in the survey included: Canada, France, Greece, Poland, Spain, Taiwan, Britain, Italy, the Czech Republic, Germany, Mexico, Singapore, Thailand and the United States.

This was the first time that the company has concentrated on studying young people's sexual behavior. It was also the first time that the annual Durex global sex survey has included samples from Taiwan.

Of the 19 topics researched, Taiwan ranked first in four categories -- the average age of first sexual activity, the ratio of those who didn't use any contraceptives the first time they had intercourse, the ratio of those who said they lacked access to contraceptives during their first sexual activity, and the ratio of people who expect to wait to have sex until after marriage.
According to the survey, the average age when Taiwan respondents first had sex was 17, compared to the world average of 15.9 years.
Survey results showed that 49 percent of those interviewed in Taiwan said they didn't take any contraceptive measures the first time they had intercourse, compared to the world average of 28 percent.
As many as 62 percent said the main reason behind their failure to adopt contraception measures was that they had difficulties acquiring contraceptives, higher than the world average of 38 percent.
Meanwhile, 43 percent said they expect to have sex only after marriage, far higher than the world average of 16 percent.
Wen Jung-kuang, president of the Republic of China Sexual Education Association, said survey results show that Taiwan's sexual education over the past two decades has been a failure.

Wen said in many other countries, condom purchase is as convenient as purchasing sanitary napkins. Noting that using condoms in sexual activities is just as important as fastening safety belts while driving or aboard airplanes, Wen said Taiwan should legalize the installment of automatic condom vending machines as soon as possible.

The global survey also found that friends were the main source for most young people's initial information about sexual education and relevant information. Only 22 percent said they obtain relevant information from school education programs.

An encouraging finding was that 28 percent of the respondents said they would prefer to receive sex-related knowledge from their parents. Wen said parents should help their children cultivate correct concepts and attitudes toward sex.

DOC.HEADLINE: MSF MEMBERS OFFER EXPERTISE ON QUAKE-RELIEF

TEXT.P: Three members from the Nobel Prize-winning humanitarian group Doctors Without Borders said here on Tuesday that any person with a loving heart can assist earthquake survivors in psychological rehabilitation.

Dominique Leguiller, director of the Paris-based organization's Far Eastern Affairs Bureau, and his two Japanese colleagues -- Moto Imaki and Daisuke Sekiguchi -- made the remarks at a news conference.

The trio arrived in Taipei Monday evening at the invitation of the Kaohsiung City Government in southern Taiwan, They accepted the invitation before their organization was declared winner of the 1999 Nobel Peace Prize.

Noting that the organization stresses a spirit of "without border," Leguiller said since they are in Taiwan, they will put themselves in Taiwan people's shoes. "We hope to help local earthquake-affected people regain a peaceful mind," he added.

Leguiller and his two Japanese colleagues traveled to Tungshih, a mountain township in central Taiwan which was hit hard by the Sep. 21 devastating earthquake, on Tuesday afternoon to meet with local relief workers and officials.

Leguiller, who has joined psychological counseling services in the Kobe area since the Japanese port city was rattled by a 7.1-magnitude earthquake in January 1995, said middle-aged people were the suicide high-risk group after a natural disaster.

"As people aged between 40 and 50 face more difficulties rebuilding thier shattered lives and careers, they are most likely to commit suicide after they lost dearest family members, properties and even jobs in the unexpected calamity," he explained.

The trio will visit local public health bureaus, hospitals, temporary medical service centers and schools to offer their experience and expertise in helping quake-affected people regain confidence and hope.
In addition to Tungshih, the delegation will also visit other hardest-stricken areas in central Taiwan which bore the brunt of the 921 earthquake.
Meanwhile, some other members of the humanitarian relief group, whose French name is Medicins sans Frontieres, will come to Taiwan to assist in psychological rehabilitation services later this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: DRUNK DRIVER KILLS ONE POLICE OFFICER, SERIOUSLY INJURES TWO OTHERS

TEXT.P: One police officer died and two others were seriously injured early Tuesday by a female drunk driver who was speeding.
Huang Chih-teh was killed, and Kuo Chen-chou and Huang Chung-hsiang were seriously injured in the traffic accident.
The three police officers, all members of the public security police battalion, suffered the misfortune when carrying out a road check at 2:10 a.m. on Cheng Teh Road in Taipei City.
According to police, the three officers were cracking down on a motorcyclist driving without a safety helmet, when Hsiao Shu-fei, who was intoxicated, drove her car toward them at high speed.
Hsiao and a male passenger in her car escaped after crashing into the officers. They were arrested later by police patrolling nearby.
Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou expressed his sorrow over the death and injury of the three officers, and he seriously condemned the act of driving while intoxicated.

He said that the Taipei City government will continue its crackdown on drunk driving in the future and will mull over taking legal actions against alcohol vendors who sell liquor to drivers that cause traffic accidents.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES, INDEX FUTURES DOWN

TEXT.P: Concerns over a downward trend on Wall Street and the absence of new leads led Taiwan share prices to close lower Tuesday as investors stayed on the sidelines.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index shed 52.3 points to close at 7,692.96 on a turnover of NT$65.43 billion (US$2.06 billion).

The sluggish recent performance of US technology stocks, together with the expectation of lower demand for personnel computers in the global market hit the mainstream electronics shares, dealers said.

The lack of new positive news to boost the bourse, coupled with the fact that the Ministry of Finance has decided not to cut the operational tax on banks for the next four years, further dragged the stock market down.
According to dealers, the financial sector is not expecting a bullish performance in the near term, and only electronics shares have the potential to lead the index up to the 8,000-point level.

Automobiles issues enjoyed the only gains among other share categories, posting 0.17-percent gains, while the rest all registered losses. The paper-making sector and cement sector suffered the largest losses, both reporting losses of 1.66 percent.
Declining stocks led advancing stocks 320 to 121, with 90 shares unchanged.
The over-the-counter market shed 2.48 points to close at 181.35 on a turnover of NT$7.75 billion.
Shadowed by the shoddy performance of the stock market, all TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) posted losses.
TAIEX Index Futures for October moved down 45 points to close at 7,690 with 759 contract transactions. Those for November shed 50 points to finish at 7,699 with 1,506 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for December declined 84 points to close at 7,705 with 13 contract transactions, while those for next March shed 5 points to end at 7,732 with eight contract transactions. Those for next June dropped 55 points to end at 7,755 with three contract transactions. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA DONATES C$ 50,000 TO TZU CHI FOUNDATION FOR RELIEF EFFORT

TEXT.P: David Mulroney, director of the Canadian Trade Office in Taipei, on behalf of the Canadian government, donated C$50,000 on Tuesday to the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Association for the post-quake relief effort.
The Tzu Chi Association thanked Mulroney by presenting him with an English version of a book that had been dictated by Venerable Dharma Master Cheng Yen.

Mulroney said that Tzu Chi had offered quick and effective assistance to many victims of disasters in numerous countries all over the world in past years and that the Canadian chapter of Tzu Chi has offered much assistance to Canadians since it was founded eight years ago.
"We Canadians have the opportunity to pay Taiwan back," Mulroney said, stressing that "this small donation is not to give but to share."

Canadian Prime Minister Jean Chretien cabled the Republic of China government to express sorrow and condolences for quake victims shortly after the devastating quake jolted Taiwan on Sept. 21, claiming more than 2,200 lives.
The Canadian International Development Agency (CIDA) had donated C$500,000 as relief aid for quake survivors in central Taiwan.
Canada had also sent civil engineers with expertise in building in earthquake zones, a medical team, and others to Taiwan to express their deep concern and to offer support in the recovery effort.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE BUDGET SHOULD ONLY INCREASE, SAYS PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew said on Tuesday that the national defense budget should not be cut further considering Taiwan's situation and future development.

In an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan, Siew admitted that the annual national budget has been relatively low compared with actual needs, but owing to increasingly heavy financial burdens in the social welfare and other sectors, the defense budget must remain at the current level.
He personally believes that the defense budget should only be increased rather than slashed, Siew added when answering a question by Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Parris Chang.

When asked by Chang what the administration thinks about Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu's recent offering to travel personally again to the mainland in an attempt to resume the cross-strait dialogue, Siew said Koo's willingness to make the trip fully demonstrates the Republic of China's sincerity and savoir-faire in exchanges with mainland China.

Last Thursday, Koo, Taiwan's appointed top negotiator with mainland China, offered to travel again to either Shanghai or Beijing to meet his mainland Chinese counterpart, Wang Daohan, so as to resume the long-stalled cross-strait dialogue at a time when Wang is unlikely to come to Taiwan for a fresh round of Koo-Wang meetings. Wang is the chairman of the quasi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) in Beijing.

The two sides have agreed since last year that Wang will come to Taiwan this autumn to return Koo's mainland visit made last October. Wang's proposed visit, however, was killed by Beijing authorities after President Lee Teng-hui redefined the cross-strait ties as a "special state-to-state relationship" in July. Beijing considered the new definition as a move promoting Taiwan independence.
Siew gave a thumbs-up to Koo's offering, saying that it fully reflected the fact that Taiwan remains flexible, rather than being rigid, in cross-strait exchanges.

Answering another question raised by DPP Legislator Tsai Ming-hsien about mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin's Monday remarks in London that China's unification will be achieved in the first half of the next century, Siew said there is nothing new in Jiang's remarks, as he merely repeated Beijing's "one nation, two systems" term, while still refusing to renounce using force against Taiwan.
Siew stressed that Taiwan's long-observed stance -- that the ROC is a sovereign nation seeking gradual and peaceful reunification with the mainland -- has not changed, and never will.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANDARIN AIRLINES TO OPEN TAIPEI-RANGOON ROUTE

TEXT.P: Mandarin Airlines will launch a Taipei-Burma route starting Nov. 2, Mandarin Airlines officials said on Tuesday.

This will be the first international route opened by Mandarin Airlines since it merged with Formosa Airlines on Aug. 8; the new merged company has retained the name Mandarin Airlines, according to officials.
They said the management policy of the new company is geared toward developing new Asian routes, and the opening of this new route aims at targeting rebounding tourism in Southeast Asia.
They also said that Mandarin Airlines will gradually withdraw from its long-distance routes to Australia and Canada.
Mandarin Airlines will have three flights weekly to serve the Taipei-Rangoon route.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING NOT TO USE FORCE AGAINST TAIWAN RASHLY: STRATEGIST

TEXT.P: Beijing will not use force against Taiwan rashly because military action would have a huge negative impact on its plan to realize its strategic goal, said a strategy researcher from the mainland.

The researcher noted that in the wake of Taiwan's massive Sept. 21 earthquake, Beijing had toned down its vitriolic attack on President Lee Teng-hui following President Lee's redefinition of cross-strait ties as "state-to-state relations" in July.
He said Beijing displayed a "goodwill" gesture promptly after Taiwan's killer quake, noting that Beijing President Jiang Zemin expressed his sympathy toward quake-affected victims.
The strategist said Beijing had also cut short both its attack on Lee for his remarks and its new round of military maneuvers slated to take place after Oct. 1.
He told the Hong Kong-based Ming Pao Daily News that all these actions indicate that Beijing is seeking a chance to ease the tension in cross-strait relations triggered by Lee's remarks.

Beijing is doing so because it could pay an exorbitant price for military action, which could lead to a complete moratorium on its economic development and send military spending skyrocketing, he said.

He added that in case of war, the mainland would have to mobilize more than 1.5 million elite troops from among its armed forces, thousands of combat planes, hundreds of combat vessels and submarines, and employ hi-tech equipment.

The researcher said wartime military spending could surpass US$100 billion. The cost of replacing damaged equipment and post-war reconstruction would be huge. Existing and potential foreign investments in the mainland could also disrupted, which he said would deal a heavy blow to mainland China's plan to realize its strategic goal.

He noted that Beijing's military action would invite widespread condemnation of the mainland. Beijing would be deemed as belligerent and would face tough sanctions and blockades from other nations, seriously jeopardizing its political standing internationally.

Beijing's flexing of its military muscle and its determination to use force would cause panic reactions among Southeast Asian nations. They would seek support from western powers while strengthening their solidarity.

The strategist noted that the first step for mainland China to realize its strategic goal is be to become a regional power, but that aspiration might not be realized in the face of strong opposition from Southeast Asian nations.

He also stated that Japan would react strongly to mainland Chinese military action, saying that Japan could strengthen its strategic alliance with the United States, increase the number of US armed forces stationed in Japan, move faster toward becoming a military power, and pressure other countries to cut off sales of much-needed advanced military technology to the mainland.

According to his analysis, the strongest reaction would come from the Untied States, which could intervene by providing information and military assistance. US transport planes and vessels could be hit by their mainland counterparts, triggering direct conflict between Beijing and Washington.
But the strategist also said that though the cost would be huge, Beijing would not care about any negative impact or risks if faced with a Taiwan declaring independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRODUCTION OF MONITORS GROWS 34.4% IN 1ST HALF OF YEAR

TEXT.P: Taiwan's production of monitors grew 34.4 percent in the first half of year, totaling 26.93 million units worth US$4.3 billion, according to statistics compiled by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting & Statistics (DGBAS) under the Executive Yuan.
The DGBAS said that more and more monitor producers have been assembling their monitors in factories abroad. The amount being locally assembled is less than 20 percent of the total.

Taiwan produced a total of 26.93 million monitors in the first six months of 1999, representing an increase of 28.5 percent compared with the same period last year. Of those only 5.35 million units were assembled domestically, a decrease of 17.2 percent in comparison with the same period a year ago; the remaining 21.58 million units were assembled in Taiwanese factories abroad, an increase of 48.8 percent over the previous year.

Taiwan monitor makers used factories in mainland China to assemble a total of 11.16 million monitors in the first half of the year, an increase of 64.8 percent over last year; 7.42 million units were assembled in Southeast Asian countries, an increase of 27.3 percent; and 3 million were assembled in factories in the Americas and Europe, an increase of 57.7 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: 7-ELEVEN TO START DELIVERY SERVICE

TEXT.P: The President Group announced on Tuesday that it is cooperating with a Japanese transport company to start offering delivery services immediately.
C. Y. Kao, chairman of the President Group, and Kenzi Aritomi, chairman of Yamoto Transport Company, signed a cooperation agreement Tuesday afternoon.
Kao said the cooperation will be another breakthrough after the President Group opened the first 7-Eleven convenience store more than 20 years ago.

Kao noted that the President Group only started earning money the seventh year after it opened the first 7-Eleven convenience store, but it has helped introduce convenience to a wide range of customers.

He stressed that though the President Group, which invested NT$500 million (US$15.72 million) in the new enterprise, aims to provide another convenience service to the public, it foresees that it will lose money in the initial stage.

The President Group's new service will target households and individual consumers, offering to pick up goods upon request and send them to designated locations. The service will start immediately at more than 2,000 7-Eleven outlets around the island.
Kao said that the President enterprise is also planning to open a similar service in airports, railway stations and tourist destinations in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND BOAT SEIZED NEAR SITE OF CRASHED JET FIGHTER

TEXT.P: Maritime police seized an iron-hulled boat from mainland China and arrested all aboard Tuesday near the site where an Air Force jet fighter crashed into the sea off the coast of northern Taiwan Friday.
Police took all 18 who were on board, including captain Yang Fuli, to the police station in Nanliao, Hsinchu County, for questioning.

An Air Force Mirage 2000-5 jet fighter crashed into the sea about seven nautical miles off Hsinchu County early Friday evening. Two pilots were able to eject in time and were later rescued in relatively good condition.

Fishermen had reported that after the jet fighter crashed, the number of mainland Chinese fishing boats in the area increased. To prevent Beijing from stealing Air Force secrets, police and navy personnel have been closely monitoring the crash site.
The Navy wanted to conduct operations to salvage the crashed plane, but was prevented from doing so because of rough sea conditions.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOTED JAPANESE ACTORS TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Noted Japanese actors who played important roles in the film "Owl's Castle" will come to Taiwan Friday.
Mayu Tsuruta, Riona Hazuki and Kiichi Nakai will arrive in Taipei to promote their film which debuts in the capital on Saturday.
The traditional Japanese film, directed by Masahiro Fujihara, was made at a cost of 1 billion Japanese yen and took three years to complete.
The film depicts a series of tragic battles between ninjas in the era of Hideyoshi Toyotomi, a noted Japanese warlord of the 18th century.

DOC.HEADLINE: FRENCH PAPER REPORTS PRC ATTEMPTS TO PRESSURE NORWAY
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Oct. 19 (CNA) (By Tzou Ming-jhie & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Attempts by Beijing to pressure Norway to prevent selection of mainland Chinese dissidents as winners of the 1999 Nobel Peace Prize were awkward and caused controversy, said a French newspaper on Monday.
Le Monde said in a commentary that Beijing had warned the Nobel Peace Prize Committee not to "intervene in China's internal affairs" by presenting the award to Chinese dissidents.

According to the paper, Geir Lundestad, chairman of the Nobel Peace Prize Committee, admitted that Beijing had sent emissaries to contact him several times to indicate Beijing's concern over the possible selection of pro-democracy activists Wei Jingsheng and Wang Dan as Nobel laureates.
The paper said the Norwegian ambassador to Beijing had also been summoned by the mainland Chinese Foreign Ministry several times for the same purpose.
Although Beijing is now relieved that the award did not go to mainland Chinese pro-democracy activists, Le Monde said, the behavior of government officials has become controversial.
The 1999 Nobel Peace Prize went to the humanitarian group Doctors Without Borders.

DOC.HEADLINE: CETACEAN KILLER-TURNED CONSERVATIONIST GETS LENIENT PENALTY
DOC.DATELINE: Ilan, northeastern Taiwan, Oct. 19 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: An Ilan-based fish vendor who used to be a cetacean butcher has in recent years become a wildlife conservationist who actively protects fish and other sea animals.

The Taiwan High Court on Tuesday overruled an Ilan District Court verdict and granted Lin Tsung-ho a jail term of eight months with a three-year probation after considering his remorse for his crime of butchering cetaceans, or sea mammals such as whales and dolphins.
The court felt that Lin's remorse is evidenced by his aggressive participation in conservation efforts, including the founding of the Chung Hua Cetacean Society.

Lin, the owner of a small fish shop handed down from his father in the eastern coastal city of Ilan, was prosecuted in 1995 on charges of killing and selling cetaceans, and was sentenced to eight months' imprisonment by the Ilan District Court.

During the trial, Lin admitted that he bought from fishermen fish that could have included whale and dolphin and then resold the products -- mainly fish cuts -- to other fish vendors in central and southern Taiwan as produce for human consumption or as animal feed.
Lin, however, said that he didn't know what fish were endangered species or what were protected animals.

After he was charged, Lin said he realized that he had committed crimes of killing endangered and protected animals that he had not considered for years, prompting him to learn more about the zone where cetacean hunting and killing is prohibited.
Lin then started to educated himself by picking up books about cetaceans, approaching zoologists to learn more, and founding the Chung Hua Cetacean Society.
His efforts led to his becoming a cetacean conservationist in less than four years and earned him fame as cetaceans' friend in Taiwan.

According to Lin's wife, he frequently dropped what he was doing at work or home, day or night, in order to pitch in as a volunteer for rescue efforts at beaches where baby whales or dolphins were grounded.
Now as a fish vendor/conservationist, Lin has called on relevant government agencies to work out policies seeking a balance between commercial fishing and conservation.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN STOCK MARKET FALLS FURTHER ON NERVOUS TRADING

TEXT.P: The Australian stock market suffered a further drop on nervous trading Tuesday, the day after its worst one-day decline in more than a year, as more investors rushed to sell their stocks, brokers said.
The All Ordinaries Index on Tuesday plunged 17.1 points to close at 2779.7. The index had plummeted 65.5 points last Thursday from the previous day's close.

Brokers said uncertainty in the stock market would continue despite considerable gains on Wall Street following its sharp decline due to a possible interest-rate hike by the US Federal Reserve; the Reserve Bank of Australia may follow suit.
"Trading was jittery today and investors are expected to become nervous in the days to come because they could not see a clear direction," one broker said. (by Peter Chen)

DOC.HEADLINE: ADB ASSISTANCE TO EAST TIMOR

TEXT.P: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) said Tuesday it has offered to work closely with the United Nations and the World Bank in the reconstruction and rehabilitation of East Timor.

In a recent letter to UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan and to World Bank President James Wolfensonhn, ADB President Tadao Chino stressed ADB's commitment to working closely with donor agencies in providing assistance to East Timor. "We are all aware of the deep human tragedy that has affected East Timor. And it is appropriate that all concerned donor agencies coordinate to provide both humanitarian as well as development assistance quickly."

The remarks follow a donor's meeting on development assistance to East Timor that was held Sept. 29 at the World Bank in Washington. A joint donor assessment mission to East Timor is planned for later this month.

ADB will focus its assistance on rehabilitation and development, rather than relief. It is interested in supporting governance and public sector management, building capacity for the delivery of essential services such as health, education, power and water, the rehabilitation of infrastructure, and the development of community and local government.

Full-fledged ADB assistance to East Timor would only be possible after East Timor's membership in the Bank could be arranged. In the interim, the ADB is examining a suitable funding arrangement for assistance.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Wednesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
President Lee Teng-hui says the government will adopt a special program to help quake-affected aborigines rebuild their homes.
The China Times:
Heavy fines do not seem to deter drunk driving; police officer was killed while trying to stop a drunk driver.
The United Daily News:
Restrictions on loan applications by quake-affected people for housing reconstruction and repair will be eased.
The Liberty Times:
One police officer was killed and two others injured while trying to stop a drunk driver.
The Commons Daily:
Mainland China's submarines spotted off Taiwan coasts.
The China Post:
President Lee says Jiang is 'fooling.'
The Taiwan News:
Premier defends no review; Siew cites Constitution in saying Legislature doesn't need to check emergency guidelines.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG MAYOR HEADS INSPECTION MISSION TO TUNGSHA ISLAND

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh headed a fact-finding mission to visit the Tungsha Islands, also known as the Pratas, in the South China Sea on Wednesday.

The 50-member mission, composed of municipal officials, oceanographers, journalists and business executives, will inspect tourist resources and facilities on the small islet as reference for drawing up a comprehensive blueprint for Tungsha's future development.
Hsieh said the city government has formed a special Pratas Islands development task force to promote the archipelago's development.

The city hall has also asked the central government to offer NT$29 million (US$911,950) in subsidy for conducting a feasibility study on building a wharf and other tourist facilities on Tungsha Island, the mayor said.
This was Hsieh's second fact-finding trip to Tungsha since he assumed the mayorship late last year.

The Pratas comprise Tungsha Island and two coral reefs, but only Tungsha is always above water. The archipelago is located in a strategically important position some 240 nautical miles southwest of the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung.

On June 30, 1989, the Republic of China government set up a national monument on Tungsha Island to assert its sovereignty over the archipelago and Tungsha has since been under the jurisdiction of the Kaohsiung city hall.
Hsieh said the city government plans to designate special areas for scuba-diving, underwater sighteeing, aquaculture and animal farming. "We'll also develop ocean liner tourist service," he added.

Hsieh went on to say that the city government has tentatively decided to commission the Chinese Diving Development Association to draft a comprehensive blueprint for developing scuba-diving and underwater sighteeing services in the Tungsha area and National Sin Yat-sen University and National Kaohsiung Institute of Marine Technology to come up with a detailed plan for aquacultural development.

Noting that Tungsha not only occupies a strategically important position but also has beautiful scenery, Hsieh said the city government will adopt a "low density" development strategy to preserve its natural environment.
"We'll organize package tours and develop the area into a new tourist paradise in the South China Sea," Hsieh pledged.

As many mainland Chinese and Hong Kong fishing boats have often used illegal fishing methods in the nearby region, Hsieh said the city govenrment plans to seek the assistance of the ROC's marine police to protect fishery resources in Tungsha area.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ARMY ENGINEERING SERVICES HIGHLY COMMENDED BY JAPANESE
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung County, central Taiwan, Oct. 20 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Army's Engineering Services (ESA) work ethic, efficiency, and compassion for the earthquake victims have highly impressed the Japanese who are in Taiwan to join in post-earthquake relief efforts.

A Japanese engineer who came to central Taiwan earlier this month as part of a mission to set-up prefabricated housing units, said he was impressed with the expertise of the ESA, describing their efficiency as five times greater than that of their Japanese counterparts.

According to ESA Chief Chu Yu-ling, members of the Engineering Services succeeded in building several Japanese-made prefabricated houses located in Tungshih Township three hours before any Japanese engineer arrived.

The Japanese fabricated houses, formerly used by Japanese citizens who were left temporarily homeless in the devastating Kobe earthquake on Jan. 17, 1995, were donated to Taiwanese earthquake victims by the Japanese government.

The engineering service members, working in units comprised of 150 persons each, are now capable of building a house within two hours, compared with the three-and-a-half hours it took at first, Chu noted.

Speed was not the only concern, however. The ESA members have also encountered other problems during the building process, including instruction literature written only in Japanese, incompatible fastening structures and the wrong power line systems.

Chu said the job could not have been achieved as quickly 20 years ago. Thanks to the increasingly-higher level of education among new recruits, things have become easier. For example, he said, when the ESA recruits, many of whom majored in engineering in college, realized that all the instructions were in Japanese, they immediately summoned in members who had studied Japanese in college to serve as translators.

The most noteworthy aspect of the ESA team which deserves respect is the high morale that the members have shown, said Chu. The high morale has been reflected in the compassion the servicemen have demonstrated to their fellow countrymen who have endured so much physical and mental suffering in the aftermath of the quake, he added.
A total of 150 prefab housing units are expected to be completed by the end of this month, accommodating some 600 people in the scenic military complex of Hsinyuan near Tungshih.
Some 100 more similar units are then expected to be erected at the same complex in the days that follow, according to Chu.

In addition to these batches of Kobe prefabs, other ready-made houses have also been built elsewhere by other charitable and public interest organizations in central Taiwan, the area that was hardest hit in the Sept. 21 magnitude 7.3 earthquake.
The Buddhist Tzu Chi Compassionate Relief Foundation is building wooden cabins for the earthquake victims, some of whom broke into tears of gratitude upon seeing their cozy new homes.
Other prefabricated houses are also being erected under the auspices of the Taipei-based TVBS.

DOC.HEADLINE: RENAULT REENTERS BIKE MARKET IN PARTNERSHIP WITH TAIWAN'S GIANT
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Oct. 19 (CNA) (By Tzou Ming-jhie and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: After suspending bicycle production for many years, the major French car manufacturer Renault has decided to return to the bicycle market, sources with the automaker said Tuesday.
The sources said Renault has reached an agreement with Taiwan's bicycle manufacturer Giant for the joint development of new types of bicycles in the hopes to wooing bike lovers.
Renault suspended its bicycle production in 1985 and changed the production line to research and develop electric autos.
Bicycles made by Taiwan's Giant are famous in Europe and are popular with French bike lovers.

The sources declined to elaborate on the details of the co-development project. However, according to the Paris-based Le Monde (The World) newspaper, Renault will put forward various types of new bicycles, including recreational, racing and off-road models.
Renault will also develop electric bicycles with prices set between 2,800 and 10,000 francs (US$476 and US$1,700).

At present, the top quality bicycles in Europe are produced by famous manufacturers. Prices of off-road bicycles manufactured by BMW, Mercedes Benz, Audi and Porsche automakers often exceed US$5,000, with Porsche's model reaching as high as US$7,300.
Renault said it will maintain its enterprising culture by putting forth new models of bicycles with prices suitable for the general public.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN URGED TO SHELVE PLANS TO BUILD FOURTH NUKE PLANT

TEXT.P: Taiwan was urged Wednesday to shelve plans to build its fourth nuclear power plant in consideration of the island's high vulnerability to earthquakes.

Ritsuya Okuno, a representative from Japan's anti-nuclear organization, the No Nukes Asia Forum, called on Taiwan to use the Sept. 30 uranium leakage accident in Tokaimura as a lesson to avoid further development of nuclear power plants on the island for the sake of people's safety.

Okuno said that if a leak of lethal uranium can occur at a processing plant in Japan, a nation widely considered to have high safety standards on nuclear safety, this indicates that one cannot be too careful where nuclear power is concerned. Similar accidents could happen in Taiwan, he warned.
Okuno was invited here by Taiwan's anti-nuke group, the Taiwan Environmental Protection Union, to lobby against the Taiwan Power Company's plans to build a fourth nuclear power plant on the island.

The Society Promoting Taiwan's Sustainable Development, a sub group at the Legislative Yuan, on Wednesday sponsored a press conference to review Taiwan's nuclear safety standards in the wake of the devastating earthquake which wreaked havoc on Sept. 21.

According to members of the supra-party group, cracks were found on roads in the vicinity of the proposed site of Taiwan's fourth nuclear power plant after the Sept. 21 quake. And even worse, five fault lines have been discovered within five kilometers of the location. If Taipower insists on going ahead with construction, the company is risking the lives of all Taiwanese people for the sake of questionable business interests, said members.

In addition, they pointed out, Taipower has not followed nuclear safety laws which state that nationwide nuclear safety drills must be held at least once a year. Taipower's three current nuclear power plants have only held a total of five nuclear disaster prevention drills over the last nine years, they noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN LNG FIRMS INCREASING OUTPUT TO MEET NEW ASIAN DEMAND

TEXT.P: Australian mining companies are planning to increase their production of liquefied natural gas (LNG) in preparation for demand from Asian countries outside their traditional markets in Japan and South Korea.

Six major LNG producers, including Shelf Australia, Woodside Petroleum, BP Australia and BHP, are mapping out plans to boost their LNG production as the prospects of exports are getting better due to new markets such as Taiwan, China and India.

Australian resource industry officials believe LNG reserves, located mainly in western Australia, could last more than 100 years and that demand for LNG in Asia could increase by an additional 40 million tones per annum by the end of the next decade.
