DOC.HEADLINE: 'CHICKEN SOUP' AUTHOR PROMOTING SPIRITUAL REHABILITATION IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The author of the best-selling book, Chicken Soup for the Soul, is expected to arrive in Taipei on Wednesday night to embark on a three-day effort to promote spiritual rehabilitation in Taiwan in the wake of the devastating Sept. 21 earthquake.

Mark V. Hansen, who has written an extensive series of books on spiritual renewal -- of which Chicken Soup for the Soul is the best known -- is expected to train some 2,000 Life Line volunteers in Taiwan who will promote spiritual healing around the island, mainly in earthquake-stricken areas in central Taiwan, according to sponsors.

Hansen will preside over a press conference on Thursday and a fund-raising speech luncheon on Friday, both in Taipei for the "Spiritual Reconstruction, Taiwan Rebuilding" Project, said a spokesman for "Success" magazine, co-sponsor of the activity. Another sponsor of the activity is the ROC Life Line International.

Hansen, whose "chicken soup" books have sold over 55 million copies worldwide with versions in more than 50 languages, is also expected to meet with President Lee Teng-hui, Vice President Lien Chan and Premier Vincent Siew during his three-day stay, the sponsors said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES, INDEX FUTURES DOWN

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed 0.3 percent lower Wednesday as the local bourse was overshadowed by the recent gloomy US NASDAQ index, resulting in continual consolidation.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index shed 26.32 points to close at 7,666.64 on a turnover of NT$71.88 billion (US$2.26 billion).

Heavy selling in stocks of microchip makers amid falling DRAM chip prices also invited more losses in the market while the institutional investors were the major sellers of the DRAM chip shares, the amount of selling-off stocks totaling NT$2.2 billion, dealers said.

It was normal to see the bourse consolidating after it had failed several times to break the 8,000-point level and investors could expect a rebound in the near future if the index succeeded in sustaining a 7,600-point level, dealers added.

Iron and steel issues took the lead among other share categories, posting 1.25-percent gains, while the plastics sector, textiles sectors and the chemical issues suffered the largest losses, each reporting losses of 2.39 percent, 1.53 percent and 1.22 percent, respectively.
Declining stocks led advancing stocks 303 to 140, with 81 shares unchanged.
The over-the-counter market shed 4.02 points to close at 177.33 on a turnover of NT$7.34 billion.

Shadowed by the shoddy performance of the stock market, all TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) -- except November futures -- posted losses, among which next March futures suffered the largest losses.
TAIEX Index Futures for October moved down 12 points to close at 7,678 with 841 contract transactions. Those for November climbed 1 point to finish at 7,700 with 1,821 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for December declined 15 points to close at 7,690 with 13 contract transactions, while those for next March shed 125 points to end at 7,720. Those for next June dropped 31 points to end at 7,724 with two contract transactions. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: QUAKE HAS LITTLE IMPACT ON TAIWAN'S FOREIGN TRADE

TEXT.P: The devastating "921 Earthquake" resulted in heavy damages to Taiwan; however, it has had little impact on the island's export and import performance, said Ministry of Finance (MOF) officials on Wednesday.

The island's exports and imports values in the first half of October registered US$5.63 billion and US$5.97 billion, respectively, or a growth of 23.5 percent and 41.9 percent, as compared with the same period last year, according to statistics released by the MOF.
The robust performance of the island's export and import sectors indicated that the impact of the quake on Taiwan's foreign trade was minimal, said MOF officials.

The MOF officials estimated that there will be no problem in the island's imports and exports maintaining a double-digit growth in October as a whole, with the exports expected to register a growth of 20 percent. However, it's too soon to say whether or not a trade surplus can be retained, the officials added.

Assessing Taiwan's foreign trade performance in the first half of October, MOF deemed that the temblor's effect has been limited. The exports value is expected to achieve a growth of more than 6.8 percent in 1999.

Meanwhile, since the import sector is subject to additional factors, its performance will be harder to predict; however, a growth of 4 percent is likely, noted the officials. A trade surplus in 1999 would thus reach the level of over US$10 billion, the MOF officials forecasted.

The island's exports value from Jan. 1 to Oct. 16, 1999 totaled US$92.6 billion, while its imports value totaled US$84.03 billion, or an increase of 7.2 percent and 3.4 percent, respectively, on an year-on-year basis, resulting in a trade surplus of US$8.57 billion.

In view of the fact that the worst havoc occurred in the island's agricultural areas and civilian residences in central Taiwan, the temblor's impact on industrial manufacturing capacity as a whole was rather limited, despite the imposition of a short period of electric power rationing, the MOF officials pointed out.
This being the case, Taiwan's foreign trade has been little affected by the temblor.

The island's foreign trade performance is likely to remain brisk in the near future, as long as the international economic environment maintains its resurgence and the domestic political situation remains stable, the officials remarked.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S MANUFACTURING INDUSTRY BACK TO NORMAL OPERATIONS

TEXT.P: Nearly one month after a killer earthquake jolted Taiwan, Taiwan's stricken manufacturing industry is expected to resume normal operations in the second half of October, according to Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs conducted a questionnaire on earthquake damage among 7,200 manufacturers after the earthquake on Sept. 21. A survey report based on the returned questionnaire indicates that 55.93 percent of the participating manufacturers mentioned damage to their facilities and a considerable drop in business turnover in September and October.
Business turnover of the manufacturing industry in September and October would be NT$69.1 billion less than expected, Wang said.

While many machinery makers in central Taiwan saw their factories damaged by the strong jolt, electronics and information industries in northern Taiwan were not able to maintain normal operations for weeks due to blackouts and rationed power supply following the disaster. Taiwan Power Co.'s North-South power transmission system was severely damaged by the earthquake.

The survey report states that it took the manufacturers an average 24 days to resume their normal operations, and by the second half of October, most disrupted production lines would be able to run again, according to Wang.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UNCHANGED

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar remained unchanged at 31.769 against the greenback on the Taipei market on Wednesday.
The currency opened at the day's high of 31.765 and experienced a low of 31.772. Interbank US dollar trading reached US$176.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATOR URGED TO ADDRESS PROBLEM RESULTING FROM ID LOSS

TEXT.P: The number of people who reported the loss of their identification cards this year could hit 800,000 due to the massive Sept. 21 earthquake, a legislator said on Wednesday.
Independent Legislator Yeh Hsien-hsu urged the related authority to take note of the situation, which he said could endanger social stability and financial operations.
Yeh made the remarks in a press conference, which government officials and people who have lost their ID cards were invited to attend.
According to statistics released by Yeh, the cases of reported ID loss numbered more than 607,000 in 1997 and 1998, respectively.
Yeh said that the number of ID losses is expected to reach a new high due to the magnitude-7.3 temblor, which has claimed more than 2,300 lives and resulted in extensive property damages.
Yeh asked the police, financial and other related agencies to address the question squarely.

Chen Chien-an mentioned that he lost his ID last November, and applied to get a new one in December. But in June this year, he received a subpoena from a district court concerning frauds, which has created great trouble for him.

Chen said that he also received a letter from a cellular phone company asking him to pay huge phone bills or face legal action -- even though he didn't own a cellular phone. His bank accounts were also frozen because of the court cases.

Tsai Tsai-feng, deputy director of the Population Administration Department of the Ministry of the Interior, said that those who lost their IDs should reapply and related agencies could take advantage of the data provided by the ministry to check out the identities of the person.

Liang Yuan-ming, an official of the Investigation Division of the Criminal Investigation Bureau, would not comment on reports that stolen ID cards could be sold on the black market for up to NT$50,000.
He said that the missing IDs were being used to get forged passports, credit cards, bank accounts, and vehicle licenses for criminal activities.
Liang said more careful checking of IDs could help mitigate such incidents.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Oct. 20, or the 12th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1818: Britain and the United States establish a border across the 49th Parallel.
1827: The Battle of Navarino in Greece comes to an end as Britain, France, and Russian fleets annihilate the Turkish and Egyptian fleets.
1890: Sir Richard Burton, British explorer, soldier, diplomat, and scholar, dies of heart attack in Trieste at the age of 69. He discovered Lake Tanganyika and translated the 16-volume "Arabian Nights".
1891: Sir James Chadwick, English physicist, is born. He won the 1935 Nobel Prize for Physics for the discovery of the neutron.
1935: Mao Tse-tung and his communist forces end their so-called "Long March" at Yenan in Shensi Province. On Oct. 10 1934, the main forces of the Chinese communist troops flee their bases in Kiangsi Province to the northwest, launching the "Long March."
1935: Arthur Henderson, British politician and founder of the Labor Party, dies at the age of 72. He won the 1934 Nobel Peace Prize for his contribution as president of the World Disarmament Conference.
1943: The Republic of China signs new Sino-Belgium Treaty and new Sino-Luxembourg Treaty in Chungking.
1943: The United Nations War Crimes Commission is formed.
1944: General Douglas MacArthur returns to the Philippines with 250,000 troops to fulfill the promise he made when his forces retreated from the Japanese.
1944: The US First Army, commanded by General Hodges, announces that the German city of Aachen is now firmly in its control after a battle lasting over a week.
1949: Britain recognizes the People's Republic of China under Mao Tse-tung.
1950: The ruling Kuomintang sets up the Taiwan Province Reform Commission with Nieh Wen-ya serving as its chairman.
1951: Governor Wu Kuo-chen of Taiwan presides over a ceremony marking the completion of the Akungtien Reservoir in Kaohsiung County, Southern Taiwan.
1955: President Chiang Kai-shek permits self-renewal for General Sun Li-jen, former commander-in-chief of the Army, without taking disciplinary action against him after an investigation commission submitted a report on a sedition case.
1957: President Chiang Kai-shek is reelected Tsungtsai (director general) of the Kuomintang.
1958: Theodor Heuss, president of West Germany, becomes the first German head of state to visit Britain in half a century.
1962 Some 20,000 Chinese troops launch an offensive on Indian military posts along the Himalayan border.
1964: Herbert C. Hoover, the 31st president of the United States, dies at the age of 90. After the stock market crash of 1929, he was unwilling to finance employment through federal intervention and lost the presidency to Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1932.
1967: Shigeru Yoshida, Japanese prime minister who dominated Japanese politics in the immediate post-war period, dies.
1968: Jackie Kennedy, widow of the late US President John F. Kennedy, marries multi-millionaire Aristotle Onassis.
1971: Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts to improve relations between communist and non-communist nations.
1973: Queen Elizabeth II officially opens the Sydney Opera House in Australia.
1973: US Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson resigns in connection with the Watergate Scandal.
1982: People trample each other as a crowd tries to squeeze through the gates of a stadium to watch a soccer match in Moscow; 340 are killed.
Confucius lesson of the day: "Among the means for the regeneration of mankind, those made with noise and show are of the least importance."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. SCIENTISTS DISCOVER MORAL COMPASS OF HUMAN BRAIN

TEXT.P: American scientists have discovered the moral compass of the brain -- which helps a person to tell right from wrong -- through a study of two young criminals.

The Sydney Morning Herald quoted Professor Antonia Damasio of the University of Iowa College of Medicine as saying that the criminals, who suffered damage to a vital region of their brains as infants, grew up to become irresponsible, disruptive and unsociable because the damaged region was crucial to acquiring emotional knowledge and to learning from mistakes.

The finding raises important questions about the biological origins of human empathy and is likely to be fodder for creative defense lawyers, who may argue that some criminals cannot be held responsible -- because a brain injury prevented them from learning the normal rules of social and moral behavior, the daily reported.

The vital brain region is the prefrontal cortex, just behind the eye sockets and above the bridge of the nose, according to the finding published in the latest issue of the journal, Nature Neuroscience.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'TAIWAN THANKS THE WORLD' COMMERCIAL PUBLICIZED

TEXT.P: A TV commercial produced by the Republic of China government to express its gratitude for foreign aid to Taiwan's earthquake relief was introduced to the press in Taipei on Wednesday.

Beginning with words in black and white, which convey that Taiwan was hit by a quake measuring 7.6 on the Richter scale on Sept. 21, the commercial features a helpless boy who is assisted by other kids from different races after his construction of toy blocks is shaken, and collapses.
The commercial ends with a single sentence: "Taiwan Thanks the World".
At the news conference, Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu indicated that the 30-second, English-language commercial will be broadcast on Cable News Network (CNN) from Oct. 20, at prime time.

From that day through Oct. 24, the commercial, titled "Taiwan Thanks the World," will be aired worldwide 21 times, Hu said, noting this is the first time that the ROC government has put a commercial on CNN.

Expressing Taiwan's heartfelt gratitude for foreign assistance in its post-quake relief works was the sole goal of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) when producing the commercial; no political images, signs, or language were permitted, Hu stressed.

The island has received much foreign-relief aid and many messages of concern and condolence since it was rattled by the 7.6-magnitude quake on Sept. 21, which killed over 2,400 people, and made thousands injured and numerous homeless, Hu said.

According to ministry tallies, more than 110 countries around the world have either sent rescue teams, donated relief goods or funds, or expressed concern via telephone or written messages in the wake of the killer tremor's ravages.

Many Taiwan people who have benefited from assistance have asked the MOFA to transmit their appreciation to the island's foreign friends, while President Lee Teng-hui has also requested that an official act extending publicly the ROC's gratitude for foreign aid, Hu noted.
Accordingly, the MOFA decided to voice all the thanks through the commercial, and publicize it at the one-month anniversary of the "921 Earthquake", the minister said.

As overseas Chinese have also made generous donations to various post-quake relief and reconstruction projects, the commercial has a Chinese version, titled "Taiwan Thanks All Overseas Chinese for Their Assistance and Concern", which will be aired on a Los Angeles-based satellite television station in the same five-day period, according to MOFA officials.
Meanwhile, French and Spanish versions of the commercial will also be made for broadcast in Latin America, Europe and Africa, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC INVESTMENT IN SEMICONDUCTOR PRODUCTION LEADS THE WORLD

TEXT.P: Taiwan capital investment in semiconductor production is expected to surpass that of the United States to be ranked No. 1 worldwide in the year 2001, according to an estimation by the Semiconductor Producers Association of the United States.

According to the association, Taiwan cast US$4.2 billion into semiconductor production in 1999, an amount only behind those of the United States and Japan. It was estimated that Taiwan will invest US$12.7 billion in such production next year, to follow only US investment. In the year 2001, Taiwan is expected to throw US$15.4 billion into related industries, surpassing the United States to become the No.1 semiconductor investor.

A meeting of 11 Taiwan semiconductor makers, organized by the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA), was held in Silicon Valley, California, on Oct. 19. More than 300 US business representatives also attended the meeting.

One of the meeting's organizers said the production strategy and strong investment power of Taiwan semiconductor producers have drawn the attention of both US and Japanese semiconductor industrialists.

He said Taiwan semiconductor manufacturers have played an important role by producing wafers using the OEM (original equipment manufacture) method. The OEM style of making wafers accounted for 54 percent of global production. It will account for 70 percent next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: DECLINE IN FOREIGN TOURISM TO TAIWAN IN FIRST NINE MONTHS

TEXT.P: About 1.9 million foreign tourists visited Taiwan in the first nine months of 1999, down 8 percent from the same period last year, according to statistics released Wednesday by the Tourism Bureau of the Ministry of Transport and Communications.
Of the total, 670,000 were Japanese tourists, 180,000 of whom visited Taiwan during the month of September.
The same statistics showed that some 530,000 Taiwan visitors toured abroad in September, representing an increase of 20 percent in comparison with the same period last year.
Hong Kong attracted the most Taiwan visitors, who numbered 160,000 in September alone.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLANDER EXECUTED FOR KILLING KAOHSIUNG CITY COUNCILWOMAN

TEXT.P: A man who had been found guilty by the mainland Chinese Anshan City Intermediate People's Court of kidnapping and killing a city councilwoman from Kaohsiung, Taiwan, was executed Wednesday, according to Beijing's official Xinhua News Agency.

Yang Rongsong was executed following rejection of his appeal to Liaoning Provincial Higher People's Court. He and three accomplices had been found guilty of kidnapping and robbing Wei Tien-kang, a Taiwan businessman, and of kidnapping and killing his girlfriend Lin Ti-chuan, a Kaohsiung city councilor, in 1998.
Liaoning Provincial Higher People's Court also upheld the original ruling regarding three other offenders involved in Lin's case.
Huang Shidong, Zhao Chuang and Zhang Shifeng were sentenced to prison terms ranging up to life imprisonment.
Another man, Lee Guangzhi, who is suspected of being the mastermind behind the crime, is still at large.
Lee allegedly encouraged the four to kidnap Lin and Wei while the two tourists were in Dalien City, Liaoning Province, in July 1998, because Lee and Wei previously had a business dispute.

The gang of five brought Wei and Lin to a nearby city and kept the couple in their custody. Lin died during the detention from being injected with an overdose of some kind of drug used to prevent them from escaping.
Wei escaped from the house where they were being held and reported the case to mainland Chinese police.
Anshan City Intermediate People's Court handed down the original ruling on the case on July 15 of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL SHOWS LUKEWARM SUPPORT FOR US SECURITY ASSISTANCE TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: An opinion poll shows that just over one-fourth of US citizens think their government should continue to help Taiwan defend itself against possible attack from mainland China.

When asked whether the United States should continue to help Taiwan defend itself through arms sales and other means, even if it hurts US relations with mainland China, only 26 percent of the American public replied "Yes."
According to the survey, released Tuesday in Washington, 47 percent think the United States should keep a low profile and let the two sides of the Taiwan Strait deal with the problem.
Twenty-one percent favor improving Washington-Beijing relations in order to increase US leverage in influencing both sides to find a peaceful solution.

Susan Shirk, deputy assistant secretary of state for Asia and the Pacific, said she was "struck" by what she considers "a very small percentage of the public" supporting continued security assistance to Taiwan.
"Yet our policy is to continue to transfer defensive articles to Taiwan under the Taiwan Relations Act, and the administration remains very strongly committed to that," she said.

Richard Bush, chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan, said that while these particular survey results do not reflect the true picture, they do show that the American public needs more education.
While nearly half of the public thinks the United States should keep a low profile on the cross-strait issue, only 17 percent of the so-called Luce Scholars believe this is the right approach.

More than half of the current or former scholars, 55 percent, support improving relations with mainland China as a way to achieve a peaceful solution to cross-strait differences. Each of these scholars has spent a year working in Asia at different times since 1974.

The survey, released by the Henry Luce Foundation, also shows that 35 percent of the American public supports US defense of Taiwan if the island comes under attack from the mainland. The majority, 52 percent, disapprove of such action.

Among the Luce Scholars and the "better informed" public, 50 percent think the United States should come to Taiwan's aid. Among the two groups, 26 percent and 40 percent, respectively, think otherwise.
The survey, conducted in June, indicates that 51 percent of Americans consider mainland China "primarily a threat that needs to be contained.
The survey was conducted with telephone interviews of a national sample of 1,200 people aged 18 and older in the United States. The margin of error is plus or minus 2.5 percent.
The foundation also sent questionnaires to 375 current and former Luce Scholars, and 174 responded. (by Jay Chen)

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE AWARD GOES TO PRES. LEE'S BOOK ON TAIWAN STANCE
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Oct. 20 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: The book "With the People Always in My Heart," written by President Lee Teng-hui of the Republic of China, has been announced a winner of Nanahei Yamamoto Prize for its presentation of Taiwan's stance to readers, the award's screening committee said Wednesday.
The award, along with 3 million Japanese yen in prize money, will be presented on Nov. 11 in Kyoto under the sponsorship of the PHP Research Institute of Japan.

A representative of the screening committee said one of the main reasons for the book's selection was that it presented Taiwan's stance to readers clearly. Another reason was Lee's precise, moderate criticism of Tokyo, Beijing and Washington.
The prize was established by the institute in 1991 in commemoration of noted Japanese critic and writer Nanahei Yamamoto, who passed away earlier that year at the age of 69.
Professor Tetsuo Yamaori, rector of Hakuho Women's Junior College, will speak at the award presentation ceremony and detail the reasons why the book was chosen for the award.

The book was translated into Japanese by the PHP Research Institute and put on sale in June 1999. The institute also made an English translation and introduced it in North America and Europe on Sept. 22 of this year.
Lee is the third foreigner to be honored with the prize since it was established eight years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC CONGRATULATES WAHID ON INDONESIAN PRESIDENTIAL VICTORY

TEXT.P: The government of the Republic of China on Wednesday extended its congratulations to Indonesian President-elect Abdurrahman Wahid for his election victory.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs said in a press release that the election, the first multiparty and democratic one since Indonesia gained independence in 1945, has paved a solid foundation for the democratization and liberalization of the world's largest Muslim country.

Indonesia's national assembly on Wednesday elected Wahid, a Muslim leader, as the country's next president. He defeated Megawati Sukarnoputri, the leader of the opposition Indonesia Democracy Party - Struggle.

The ministry attributed the election success to joint efforts by the Indonesian government and people, adding that it greatly admires the democratic savoir-faire and political wisdom of the country as demonstrated by Indonesian political parties in the election process.
The ministry said it believes the new government formed through democratic process will lead Indonesia to stability and prosperity.

Stressing the long-lasting friendship between the Republic of China and Indonesia, the ministry said that Taiwan is willing to share its development experience with the Southeast Asian country and to further enhance their cooperative relations in the fields of agriculture, economy, and small- and medium-enterprises.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING RED CROSS SOCIETY SENDS ADDITIONAL US$ 500,000 FOR QUAKE RELIEF
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Oct. 20 (CNA) (By C. K. Liu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Red Cross Society of mainland China sent an additional US$500,000 to Taiwan Wednesday for post-quake relief, said a mainland official.

Zhang Huaijun, an official of the Taiwan Affairs Office under the State Council, said that China's Red Cross has to date received cash and material aid worth more than 30 million renminbi, adding that a single charity performance in Fuzhou garnered more than 20 million renminbi.
The donated materials included tents, quilts and pharmaceuticals, Zhang said.

He said that if Taiwan allows shipment of the goods from the mainland, it could mobilize people to donate more materials according to the needs of Taiwan, included cement, timber, steel and gravel for reconstruction projects.

Zhang also refuted Taiwan media reports that Beijing has been hindering rescue and relief efforts of foreign countries by saying that they need prior approval before sending aid to Taiwan, saying such reports are "untrue and distorted."

Since the devastating Sept. 21 temblor, which registered a magnitude of 7.3 on the Richter scale, the mainland China Red Cross has sent US$800,000 altogether. The first sum of US$100,000 was sent on Sept. 24, and the second of US$200,000 was sent Oct. 10.
Taiwan accepted cash donations from the mainland but has declined the donated goods.

DOC.HEADLINE: A UNIFIED CHINA CAN ONLY BE ACHIEVED WITH A DEMOCRATIZED MAINLAND

TEXT.P: One unified China can only be realized after the People's Republic of China (PRC) becomes more democratic, like the Republic of China (ROC), said a Taiwan official on Tuesday.

Yu Yuh-chao, director of the Information Division of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New York, said China can be unified only after Beijing has achieved real success in political democratization, economic liberalization and social pluralism, just as the Republic of China on Taiwan has done.
Yu made the remarks in a speech given at the Center of Asian Studies of St. John's University in New York City.

In his speech, titled "Towards a Democratic Unified China: Creating a Win-Win-Win Situation for Taipei, Beijing and Washington," Yu analyzed cross-strait tensions and offered solutions for reaching the ultimate goal of peaceful reunification of China.
It is Beijing's hardball stance that has led to the diplomatic isolation of 22 million people on Taiwan, has stalled reunification talks and has caused unnecessary PRC military threats, Yu contended.
"From historical, legal and political viewpoints," he pointed out, "the ROC on Taiwan has never been a part of the PRC and still isn't."

Talking about the definition of the "one China" principle, Yu touched on the agreement reached in 1992 by Taipei and Beijing as "one China: with each side being entitled to its respective interpretation."

Beijing, however, has twisted this agreement around to fit its view of the situation, sticking to the "one China, two systems" formula that has been applied to Hong Kong and is unacceptable to Taipei, he said.

Until Beijing can acknowledge parity, that the Republic of China is a sovereign state and not a "renegade province," Yu emphasized, reunification talks can neither reach the next level nor the goal of "one China."

President Lee Teng-hui's recent "special state-to-state relations" statement when referring to the cross strait relationship was not an attempt to declare Taiwan independence or incite Beijing, but merely a description of a historical, legal and political reality, he explained.

Yu made it very clear that Taipei is still earnestly committed to its National Guidelines for Reunification, but that "one unified China" can only be realized after the People's Republic of China has achieved real success in political democratization, economic liberalization and social pluralism.
Washington plays an important role in the Taiwan Strait issue to help maintain stability in the region, he added.
However, Washington must also be careful of potential entanglements with its own policy. President Clinton's "three noes" policy is moving US foreign policy closer to Beijing, Yu warned.

He suggests that Washington follow a "parallel engagement policy" that engages both Taipei and Beijing on a balanced and cordial basis to help find a peaceful and democratic solution to this tense situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: JADE MOUNTAIN MOVES A LITTLE

TEXT.P: Jade Mountain, the highest mountain in Taiwan and Northeast Asia, moved 44 centimeters north-northwest following the massive earthquake last month, said an official of the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) on Wednesday.
Chang Yuan-hsu, director of MOI's Department of Land Administration, made the remarks after the island's deadliest temblor this century caused the movement of earth's crust and moved mountains.
But Chang said that the height of the mountain, at 3,798 meters, has undergone no obvious changes.
Recent reports had claimed that the famous mountain grew 28 meters due to compression of the earth's surface plates during the quake on Sept. 21.

Chang also said the magnitude-7.3 temblor resulted in extensive damage in Miaoli, Nantou, Taichung, Changhua and Yunlin counties, adding that the terrain and landscape of quake-stricken areas were seriously distorted due to the moving of mountains, landslides and cracking.
Due to the changes, the MOI has decided to reexamine the terrain and redraw cadastral maps within one month for reference during post-quake reconstruction and urban rejuvenation.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN ROLE IN EAST TIMOR PEACEKEEPING OPERATIONS DEFENDED

TEXT.P: The representative of the Australian Commerce and Industry Office in Taipei, Sam Gerovich, on Wednesday defended Australia's role in leading the International Force in East Timor (Interfet).
He dismissed as "completely baseless and untrue" some media reports from Indonesia and elsewhere that Australian Interfet troops have committed violations of human rights in East Timor.
"Australia acted neither unilaterally nor aggressively in the establishment of an international peacekeeping force," said Gerovich.
He went on to say that Interfet's operations are "helping Indonesia in a period of difficulty" and are "aimed at the restoration of peace and not directed at any one group."

Gerovich stressed that "Australia's central objective is a peaceful and lasting solution in East Timor," adding that "our actions are motivated by concerns about the suffering and destruction in East Timor, and an interest in regional stability."

Regarding the accusations of human rights violations by Australian troops, he pointed out that such rumors are "clearly part of a disinformation campaign by certain elements aimed at discrediting Australia and Interfet, and are patently untrue."

He said "Interfet has clear rules of engagement and regulations regarding criminal offenses by Interfet personnel, and in the event of any such allegations being made, there are transparent and established procedures for investigating them."
Gerovich stated that Australia responded to a United Nations request to lead the multinational force -- a request which was made following the agreement of the Indonesian government.

He said Australia's policy stance does not run counter to Indonesian policy on East Timor, and Australia's hope is that the current Interfet operations will be succeeded quickly by a "Blue Helmet" UN peacekeeping force.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANBERRA-JAKARTA TIES SEEN UNLIKELY TO DETERIORATE UNDER NEW PRES.

TEXT.P: To the surprise of Australia, Indonesia and many other countries worldwide, the Indonesian People's Consultative Assembly (MPR) on Wednesday elected Abdurrahman Wahid to the nation's top post.
The near-blind Muslim leader was chosen to be president of the world's largest Islamic country, in its first democratic election since the nation became independent in 1945.

In an exclusive interview with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation on Wednesday night, Sudjati Djiwandono, a leading political expert in Jakarta, said he believed bilateral relations between Australia and Indonesia, which have worsened over the East Timor crisis, will not deteriorate from their current state.
He said that under Wahid, Indonesia is expected to return to stability not only politically, but also economically.
He said Wahid will be able to restore Indonesia from its current state of chaos, and he expects the new leader will request military reform in the next five to six years.
Popularly known as Gus Dur, the 59-year-old Wahid, described as a long-term democracy campaigner, chairs the largest Indonesian Muslim organization -- Nahdlatul Ulama.
He not only has a good relationship with other Muslim organizations, but also is on good terms with other parties, including the PDI-P led by Megawati Sukarnoputri.
The MPR is scheduled to elect Indonesia's vice president on Thursday, and Djiwandono expected Megawati could be elected to the second highest post in Indonesia.
But Wahid's election to the presidency sent a disturbing signal to Australia because the he has in recent weeks emerged as a trenchant critic and opponent of Australia.
Wahid's criticism led Australian Prime Minister John Howard to say Tuesday that he hoped Megawati would win the election so that Canberra could mend its strained relations with Jakarta.
Australian leaders, including Howard, had not commented on Wahid's victory as of Wednesday night. (by Peter Chen)

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN PM WELCOMES INDONESIAN APPROVAL OF E. TIMOR INDEPENDENCE

TEXT.P: Australian Prime Minister John Howard on Wednesday welcomed the decision by Indonesia's parliament to allow independence for East Timor, ending 24 years of rule that culminated in tumultuous crisis, bringing an Australian-led UN peacekeeping force to maintain law and order.

Howard told the House of Representatives that the Australian government welcomed the decision of the People's Consultative Assembly on Wednesday, saying all parties should look to the future in rebuilding a new nation in East Timor.
In Darwin on Wednesday, Xanana Gusmao, the independence leader tipped to be the president of the new country, said, "I was very glad and it has been a long wait for us on today's results."
Gusmao is expected to soon leave Australia for Dili, where he will install a civil administration under the supervision of the United Nations.

In Bangkok on Tuesday, Australian Foreign Minister Alexander Downer told reporters that Australia's standing in Asia was being enhanced rather than damaged by its leading role in the UN peacekeeping force in East Timor.

His comment was in response to the criticism by Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad that Indonesia had not killed thousands and thousands of East Timorese since its military intervention in 1975.
Downer met Thai leaders, including the prime minister and foreign minister, to express Australia's willingness to relinquish its leading role in the UN peacekeeping force in East Timor to Thailand.

Howard told Parliament on Wednesday that it would cost more than US$330 million for Australia to finance the dispatch of 4,500 soldiers to East Timor and that military experts believed the figure could exceed US$600 million in the current fiscal year, which ends on June 30, 2000. (by Peter Chen)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Thursday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Muslim leader Wahid wins Indonesia's first contested presidential election, beating the people's favorite Megawati 373 to 313.
The China Times:
Wahid sworn in as Indonesia's fourth president amid protests in Jakarta.
The United Daily News:
Wahid takes helm in Indonesia; the ruling Golkar party switched at the last moment behind Wahid after its own candidate, the unpopular Habibie, lost the confidence vote in the Assembly.
The Liberty Times:
Mega defeated in presidential elections, triggering clashes and explosions in Jakarta.
The Commons Daily:
Show off or something. Officials' luxurious limos were seen rove among earthquake-stricken areas.
The China Post:
Wahid sworn in as Indonesia's fourth president.
The Taiwan News:
Wahid takes helm in Indonesia -- Defeated Megawati calls for national unity, though her supporters protest.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TOURISTS CALLED TO TEMPORARILY SHUN INDONESIA

TEXT.P: Taiwanese tourists on Thursday were called to temporarily scrap Indonesia from their overseas travel plans as the Southeast Asian country is experiencing new unrest in the wake of the presidential election.

Riots and clashes between supporters of the newly-inaugurated President Abdurrahman Wahid and his popular rival Megawati Sukarnoputri have been reported in major Indonesian cities, particularly in the capital Jakarta since Wahid was sworn into office on Wednesday.
The Republic of China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs is closely monitoring the situation in post-election Indonesia.
The Tourism Bureau, meanwhile, notified Taiwanese travel agencies to avoid areas plagued by riots and unrest if their travel groups are going to Indonesia or are already there.

According to a spokesman for the Taipei Association of Travel Agents, there have been less Taiwanese tourists going to Indonesia for leisure or sightseeing trips since large-scale riots erupted in that Southeast Asian nation in 1997.

The number of Taiwanese tourists making overseas trips declined further after the devastating magnitude 7.3 earthquake struck Taiwan on Sept. 21, killing 2,300 people, injuring 8,700 and leaving 100,000 others temporarily homeless, the spokesman said.
Meanwhile, Lin Shuei-chi, chief Taiwan liaison officer in Indonesia, on Thursday called for Taiwanese people to avoid traveling to Indonesia for the next several days except for emergency purposes.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1999 TAIWAN TRADE FAIR OPENS IN PORT-AU-PRINCE, HAITI
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Panama, Oct. 20 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The 1999 Taiwan Trade Fair opens in Port-au-Prince, Haiti on Wednesday with the products of 14 Taiwan manufacturers on display.

The Republic of China ambassador to Haiti, Chiou Jong-nan, Haitian Foreign Minister Fritz Lonchamps, and the chairman of the Haitian Chamber of Industry and Commerce jointly presided over the opening ceremony.

The products on display included travel necessities, automobile accessories, sports products, cellular phone accessories, textile products, body building materials, bicycles, motorcycles, refrigerators, air conditioners, wireless telephones and cameras.

Speaking at the opening reception, Chiou said bilateral ties between Haiti and the ROC have achieved great progress in recent years, however, he added, the volume of two-way trade between the two nations has been very small. He hopes that the trade fair can act as a catalyst for the promotion of bilateral trade.
He also hopes that the already stable Haitian-ROC relations will be further strengthened through trade and investment.

Speaking on behalf of the government of Haiti, Lonchamps wished the trade fair success and said he believed that bilateral relations between the two nations would surely be promoted through the trade fair.

ROC Premier Vincent Siew led a delegation of government officials and enterprise representatives to Haiti in January, resulting in contact between the industrial and commercial sectors of the two nations.
The ROC sponsored an international trade and travel fair in February to invite countries it has formal diplomatic relations with, including Haiti, to participate.
ROC exports to Haiti in 1997 totaled US$11 million, while Haitian exports to the ROC in the same year was zero.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIFE SENTENCE FOR MALAYSIAN DRUG TRAFFICKER
DOC.DATELINE: Taoyuan, northern Taiwan, Oct. 21 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Taoyuan District Court on Thursday sentenced a Malaysian man to life in prison on charges of heroin trafficking and possession, according to local law enforcement sources.
Lee Tuck Wah, a Malaysian national, was arrested by police at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan on July 16 for smuggling several bricks of prime-grade heroin from Hong Kong to Taiwan.

Lee admitted that he was working as a courier for a Malaysia-based drug pusher named "Ah Liao" in exchange for 5,000 Malaysian Ring (approximately US$1,300). Lee traveled to Hong Kong on July 14 and there was handed the drugs by a Hong Kong man before flying to Taiwan on July 16.
The defendant was caught red handed by CKS customs officials with heroin bricks weighing about 700 grams located in two pockets of his blue jeans, the Taoyuan judges said.
A life sentence is relatively lenient, according to the judges, who pointed out that the maximum sentence for heroin trafficking under ROC law is death.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESS AS USUAL ONE MONTH AFTER QUAKE

TEXT.P: Just one month after a killer earthquake struck central Taiwan, the manufacturing industry has returned to normal and foreign buyers have been quick to show support for Taiwan's industry, many announcing beefed-up procurement plans, economics officials at the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Canada said Wednesday.

The officials said Taiwan's prudent macroeconomic management and the flexibility and adaptability of its SMEs had helped the island weather the 1997 Asian financial crisis. These very same traits facilitated a return to near pre-quake production levels barely two weeks after the quake, they added.

The Taipei officials said Taiwan's key infrastructure, including ports and highways, were largely untouched by the tremor, so it was possible for the industries to resume shipment schedules very soon after the quake.

As to concerns that Taiwan would lose orders to overseas competitors, they quoted a spokesman with IBM Taiwan Corp. as saying Taiwan manufacturers' ample R&D capabilities, production expertise and close ties with foreign suppliers would assure continued support from international procurement offices. IBM Taiwan itself has announced it will step up procurement in the fourth quarter, fulfilling the company's 1999 purchase projections of more than US$3 billion.

Briefing local media on the post-quake economic situation in Taiwan, the TECO officials said Taiwan's economic fundamentals remain strong. "Industrial losses across the board have been less than expected and have been caused by power outages rather than actual structural or physical damage," they said.

In the longer term, they said, domestic demand will be stimulated by the expansion of the construction sector beginning next month. As Standard and Poor's Taipei-based analyst John Bailey said, "increased government expenditure and investment will provide an impetus for stronger economic growth next year."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WANTS NATIONAL UNIFICATION: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: A ranking Republic of China official was quoted by a group of Canadian MPs Wednesday as saying "Quebec wants a divorce whereas we want a marriage."

The members of Parliament, led by Paul Szabo, chairman of the Canada Taiwan Parliamentary Friendship Group (CTPFG) presented their report to the House of Commons on their visit to Taiwan in early August.
Due to the escalating tensions between Taiwan and mainland China at the time of their visit, the Canadian politicians were presented with substantial information concerning mainland relations.

In their report, they quoted Su Chi, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council of the Executive Yuan, as reaffirming that Taiwan was not seeking independence but rather negotiations on an equal footing with mainland China in its pursuit of eventual reunification with a democratic and free China.

Su told his Canadian guests that he is confident progress will be made in cross-Taiwan Strait relations because both sides share cultural and ethnic origins and the level of civil and commercial exchanges is unparalleled by other divided countries.
Bilateral trade between Taiwan and mainland China in 1998 reached US$31.7 billion, with Taiwan enjoying a surplus of US$19.58 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: US NEEDS EARTHQUAKE ALERT SYSTEM AS GOOD AS TAIWAN'S: EXPERT

TEXT.P: A US geological official asked the US Congress on Wednesday to provide more funding to establish earthquake alert systems as effective as those in Taiwan.

Waverly Person, director of the US Geological Survey's National Earthquake Information Center, testifying before a basic research congressional subcommittee, said that "time is of the essence" when responding to an earthquake.

He cited the contrast between Turkey and Taiwan's earthquake response, saying that "in Taiwan, relief efforts moved much more quickly, aided significantly by the modern seismographic alert system it had in place."
Person pointed out that Taiwan maintains a network consisting of approximately 1,000 digital seismic recording instruments - the highest concentration of modern digital accelerographs in the world.

Person concluded that only southern California's earthquake alert system is "almost as fast and almost as good as Taiwan's." Those in other earthquake prone areas in the US, such as the San Francisco Bay area, Seattle, Portland, and Salt Lake City are all vulnerable.
He said, "in these regions, the US network is comparable to the Kandilli Observatory network in Turkey and is currently far inferior to the network operating in Taiwan."
Person described Taiwan as a "trend setter" in the delivery of earthquake disaster information and called upon the US Congress to provide more funding to establish a model as effective as Taiwan's.

DOC.HEADLINE: E. TIMOR RECONSTRUCTION AND INDEPENDENCE COSTLY: UN CHIEF

TEXT.P: UN Secretary General Kofi Annan said it would take billions of dollars to rebuild the ravaged territory of East Timor and establish an independent country.
Annan on Wednesday warned that the international community would have to carry a heavy financial burden during the transition to a democratically elected government in East Timor.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW INDONESIAN PRESIDENT SAID A DEFENDER OF THE MINORITY

TEXT.P: Newly elected Indonesian President Abdurrahman Wahid is a moderate anti-sectarian and democratic voice of reason and a defender of the minority, the Australian reported on Thursday.
The newspaper reported that although Wahid has no executive experience, he does possess moral authority and represents a vastly different type of president for Indonesia.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN PM OFFERS FRIENDSHIP TO NEW INDONESIAN PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Australia's Prime Minister John Howard, stunned by the presidential victory of the Muslim leader Abdurrahman Wahid, has offered his readiness "to open a new chapter" in the two countries' relationship.

In a message faxed to the CNA on Thursday morning, Howard said: "I can assure Mr. Wahid of the goodwill of the Australian government, our readiness to open a new chapter in our relationship on the basis of mutual respect, and our support as he faces the huge challenge of leading Indonesia through the political transition and achieving economic recovery."

Wahid's election to the top job surprised Howard and many of his senior officials because they had hoped Megawati Sukarnoputri would win due to her party having won the most seats in the People's Consultative Assembly during parliamentary elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD LEADERS URGED TO CONFRONT CHINA ON HUMAN RIGHTS

TEXT.P: The New York-based group Human Rights in China, Wednesday called on world leaders to voice their concerns over China's human rights situation when holding talks with Chinese leader Jiang Zemin during his six-nation tour.

The human rights organization, founded in 1989 by a group of Chinese scientists and scholars, said in a press release that Beijing's authorities are currently conducting the most ruthless repression of dissent since the June 4, 1989 Tiananmen Square Massacre.

The most visible examples of persecution include the crackdown on Falungong members and the harsh sentencing of China Democracy Party members and other activists for up to 13 years, the document stated.

Hundreds of thousands of China's most marginalized people, including migrants, the homeless, street children and the mentally ill, are being arbitrarily detained in ongoing "clean-up" campaigns to rid the streets of those deemed undesirable by urban authorities, said the report.

Jiang's current tour to the United Kingdom, France, Portugal, Morocco, Algeria and Saudi Arabia provide a valuable opportunity for countries to voice their concerns over China's human rights situation and for China to address the issue in an open manner, he stressed.
China must be held accountable for its human rights abuses now, if it is to achieve sustainable development and true acceptance into the global community, he suggested.

DOC.HEADLINE: 13,045 AFTERSHOCKS IN MONTH SINCE `921 EARTHQUAKE'

TEXT.P: As of Thursday, one month after Taiwan's "921 Earthquake" that caused significant casualties around the island, more than 13,000 aftershocks have occurred, the Seismology Center under the Central Weather Bureau said Thursday.
As of noon on Thursday, a total of 13,045 aftershocks, including 134 perceptible ones, have occurred on the island.
At present, the frequency of aftershocks has decreased significantly to under 10 per hour, the Seismology Center said.
The Seismology Center also added that it would probably take two to three months for the aftershocks to totally subside.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR HIGHER

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar closed 0.3 cent higher to 31.766 against the greenback on the Taipei market on Thursday.
The currency opened at the day's high of 31.765 and experienced a low of 31.770. Interbank US dollar trading reached US$113 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER TAIWAN CONSCRIPTS TO TRAVEL TO JAPAN TO DEMAND COMPENSATION

TEXT.P: A group of elderly Taiwanese who were conscripted by the Japanese during World War II will travel to Japan Saturday to demand cash compensation for long-overdue salary payments.
The seniors, most of whom were forced to work as soldiers, wartime engineers or assistants, were issued vouchers by the Japanese military during the war as token payment for their labor.

On the vouchers, which are all of the same denomination of 100 Japanese yen, writing clearly indicates that they can be exchanged for an equivalent value of Japanese currency, said New Party Legislator Chang Shih-liang, who will accompany the group to Japan.
During the war, 100 yen was equivalent to three months' salary for a primary school teacher.
Chang said people from Hong Kong have demanded Japanese ompensation for similar vouchers, based on a rate 200 times the vouchers' wartime face value.

If the former conscripts from Taiwan make the same compensation request to the Japanese government, it would translate into a combined cash compensation of 40 billion yen, based on holdings of the approximately 2,000 surviving former wartime military slaves from Taiwan, whose vouchers have a combined face value of about 200 million yen, Chang noted.

According to Chen Tai-li, an expert in wartime Japanese credit documents, including those of military and civilian postal deposits, life insurance premiums and unpaid wages, the Japanese military vouchers from the 1940s were not circulated in Taiwan, even though Taiwan was under Japanese rule during World War II.

The Taiwanese conscripts received the Japanese military vouchers elsewhere, such as mainland China, Hong Kong and areas in Southeast Asia, where they were forced to fight for and do civil engineering work for the Japanese Imperial Army, said Chen.
Chang and the Taiwanese group are expected to meet representatives of the Tokyo-based Japan-ROC Dietmen's Council and other lawmakers and political heavyweights to lobby for the compensation.

DOC.HEADLINE: EARTHQUAKE DOESN'T CAUSE IMMEDIATE EXODUS

TEXT.P: Despite the heavy loss of human life and property, the Sept. 21 killer earthquake did not cause a panic exodus of Taiwan residents, according to an official of the Ministry of the Interior.

Liu Min-chien, director of the ministry's Department of Population Administration, said that not only could political or economic factors lead to a large number of emigrants, natural disasters could also cause people to move away.

The earthquake and fear for one's life might cause some residents in Taiwan to emigrate. Since it takes time to review documents and compile statistics, the number of such emigrants would not be apparent right away, said Liu.

The official said it was understandable that immediately after the disaster, some people might have wanted to leave the island on a temporary basis for fear of aftershocks. However, the Sept. 21 earthquake didn't seem to have caused such a panic exodus. Statistics released by the Exit & Entry Bureau indicate that between Sept. 20 and 30, the bureau registered 249,356 exits and 255,161 entries.

On average, 24,000 people went abroad each day after the earthquake, mainly for tourism. Only on Sept. 23 was the number of exits higher -- over 30,000 -- because many people had previously booked overseas trips for the Mid-autumn Festival holidays.

In the past few years, worries about the island's political status and social environment have caused quite a few Taiwan people to emigrate. Statistics compiled by the Ministry of the Interior show that between 1990 and 1998, a total of 181,976 people emigrated to the United States, Canada, Australia, New Zealand and South Africa, the five most-favored destinations for emigrants from Taiwan.

The year 1996 registered the largest number of emigrants to the five countries at 22,747. It is believed that Beijing's missile tests using Taiwan as the hypothetical enemy had worried many residents. In 1997, the figure remained high at 20,017. Fear of crime was said to be the reason for that exodus.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPERATION USA SENDS MORE MATERIAL RELIEF AID TO TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Oct. 20 (CNA) (By L.S. Chu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The American charitable and emergency aid group Operation USA on Wednesday donated 44,000 pounds of powdered milk to Taiwan for the nutritional benefit of people in earthquake-stricken areas.
The chief Taipei liaison officer in Los Angeles, Yuan Chien-sheng, received the donation on behalf of the Republic of China government at a ceremony held at the Los Angeles International Airport.

It was the second time that Operation USA has sent material relief aid to Taiwan since the devastating magnitude-7.3 earthquake struck Taiwan on Sept. 21, killing 2,300 people, injuring 8,700 and leaving 100,000 others temporarily homeless. Days after the quake, Operation USA dispatched several hundreds of tons of medicine and medical care items.

During the ceremony, Neil Frame, chief of logistics of Operation USA, said the powdered milk, including 20,000 pounds of whole-fat powdered milk and 24,000 pounds of skimmed, was a token of the friendship and concern that the American people feel for the people of Taiwan.
Frame said an Operation USA mission will go to Taiwan next month to visit quake-affected areas so as to acquire first-hand knowledge about the disastrous aftermath of the devastating earthquake.
He added that Operation USA would not be reluctant to dispatch more relief materials to Taiwan if necessary.

Expressing deeply-felt gratitude for the donation, Yuan said the goodwill and concern for Taiwan shown by US residents, including those of Chinese origin, over the past month have been more than overwhelming.
As of this week, he added, cash donations from the Los Angeles area alone have exceeded US$10 million, with countless items of material relief aid following.
The shipment of powdered milk will soon be transported to Taiwan free of charge by China Airlines, according to Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAT STARTS TO FLY TAIPEI-KOTA KINABALA ROUTE

TEXT.P: Far East Transport Corp. (FAT) on Thursday began flight operations between Taipei and Kota Kinabala in Malaysia. The airline will offer such service on Mondays and Thursdays.
This is the third international route to be operated by the airline, which already flies the Taipei-Palau and Taipei-Subic Bay routes.

FAT Chairman Lee Yun-ning and Wang Teh-ho, director of Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, jointly presided over a maiden voyage ceremony at the airport Thursday morning. A Boeing 757-200 jetliner with 180 passengers aboard took off and headed for Kota Kinabala shortly after the ceremony.
Kota Kinabala is the capital of Sabah State of Malaysia.

DOC.HEADLINE: 3,000 PREFABRICATED HOUSES TO BE FINISHED BY END OF OCTOBER

TEXT.P: A total of 3,000 prefabricated houses can be finished by the end of October for quake-affected victims, said Vice Premier Liu Chao-shiuan on Thursday.

Liu, who is also the executive director of the Cabinet's Post-Quake Reconstruction Committee (PQRC), pointed out that ready-to-be-built residences currently under construction totaled 4,900 units, which seems to indicate a slight oversupply.

However, a miscalculation was made regarding distribution of prefabricated houses in quake-stricken areas, Liu noted, adding that the government will coordinate distribution and make readjustments so that a better balance can be achieved.

A meeting was held by the PQRC Wednesday on issues concerning the assembly of prefabricated houses as well as their distribution. Officials of the Council of Agriculture under the Executive Yuan also delivered a briefing at the meeting on the situation of dangerous slopes and measures against landslides.

Liu told the press after the meeting that more than 300 units of prefabricated homes have been finished to date by the armed forces, who have spent a combined total of over 1 million hours working on relief projects. The provisional residences, assembled with materials from Japan, were deemed better than expected by those who have already moved in.

Liu further indicated that a total of 4,500 units of prefabricated houses can be finished by mid-November. The first batch of prefabricated houses contained some household electric appliances that had been donated by the Red Cross Society, and the government will encourage other groups to make similar donations for the next set of homes, he added.

Regarding preventive measures against landslides, officials of the Soil and Water Conservation Bureau under the Council of Agriculture pointed out in the meeting that there are 16 places where slopes have collapsed and landslides have occurred, each measuring over 10 hectares.
Academic researchers have been working on the matter to avoid a second disaster resulting from those dangerous slopes, said the officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES, INDEX FUTURES DOWN

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed down Thursday as investors' confidence waned in the final moments of the session and eroded solid early gains.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index dipped 11.74 points, or 0.2 percent, to close at 7,654.9 on a turnover of NT$69.29 billion (US$2.18 billion).

The index opened 1.6 percent higher, boosted by an overnight Wall Street rally, where the Dow Jones index jumped 1.84 percent and the technology-heavy NASDAQ index bounded 3.72 percent, and by news that the Ministry of Finance was again mulling over the feasibility of cutting the operational tax on banks.
Dealers said that Thursday's turnover was even smaller than Wednesday's NT$71.88 billion, and it indicated that local investors were too cautious to place much faith in the new rally on Wall Street.
In the short term the local bourse is expected to experience consolidation or even fall further to around the 7,400-point level where it would find resistance, dealers added.

Paper-making issues took the lead among share categories, posting 1.46-percent gains, while the plastics sector and chemical issues suffered the largest losses, reporting 1.71-percent and 1.65-percent losses, respectively.
Declining stocks led advancing stocks 207 to 197, with 124 shares unchanged.
The over-the-counter market shed 1.5 points to close at 175.83 on a turnover of NT$9.17 billion.

Shadowed by the shoddy performance of the stock market and weak investor confidence, most TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) -- except next March and next June futures -- posted losses, among which November futures suffered the largest losses.
TAIEX Index Futures for November moved down 17 points to close at 7,683 with 2,301 contract transactions. Those for December shed 2 points to finish at 7,688 with 24 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for next March rose 10 points to close at 7,730 with one contract transaction, while those for next June bounded 13 points to end at 7,737, with four contract transactions. Those for next September dropped 17 points to end at 7,951. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: 2000 PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION NOT TO BE AFFECTED BY EARTHQUAKE

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's 10th presidential election will be held on March 18, 2000, as scheduled, and the promulgation to officially begin the election process will be issued by the Central Election Commission on Nov. 15.

The Central Election Commission on Thursday approved election procedures, dissolving speculation about postponement of the election that had arisen with the announcement of an emergency decree in the aftermath of the Sept. 21 earthquake.
According to the procedures, after the election promulgation is issued on Nov. 15, the commission will accept registration of candidates between Nov. 16 and Nov. 20.

The list of qualified candidates, comprising both party nominees and recommended candidates, will be announced on Feb. 18. From Feb. 19 to March 17, those candidates will be permitted to engage in election campaign activities.

After the March 18 vote, the commission will officially announce the names of the new president and vice president on March 25, and the newly elected officials will be presented with their credentials on March 31.

DOC.HEADLINE: MACAU SHOULD PROMOTE CULTURE, NOT GAMBLING, SAYS OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Macau's future government should concentrate on culture, not gambling, said Fernando Chui Sai-on, Macau's post-handover secretary for social affairs and culture.

Chui said in an interview with the Portuguese-language daily Tribuna De Macau published on Wednesday that the future government should further develop the territory's Chinese and Portuguese cultural heritage.
He said the future government should cultivate the values of the territory's multicultural society, and gambling should not be allowed to dominate Macau's social development.
Chui, 42, is the youngest official in Chief Executive Edmund Ho Hau-wah's team of five Cabinet secretaries.

DOC.HEADLINE: RICE-GROWING AREA TO SHRINK BY 50,000 HECTARES AFTER WTO ENTRY

TEXT.P: In order to help balance the huge debt of the Food Regulating Fund, Taiwan plans to decrease the area used for growing rice by 50,000 hectares when Taiwan joins the World Trade Organization (WTO), said an agriculture official on Thursday.

The official of the Council of Agriculture under the Executive Yuan said rice-growing areas would be decreased by 20,000 hectares before Taiwan enters the WTO, with a further reduction of 30,000 hectares after admission, he said.

The Food Regulating Fund, which was founded to regulate the market price of rice, has accumulated NT$10 billion in debt resulting from repeatedly purchasing farmers' rice at much-higher-than-market prices since it was founded in the 1960s.

The reduction in rice-growing areas would help balance rice production and the market, he said, adding that the annual volume of rice stored in Taiwan should be kept between 280,000 and 470,000 metric tons. (By Edward Chen) EENDITEM ZCZC CEP024 10-21-99 MORE FALUNGONG PRACTITIONERS ARRESTED IN CHINA

Hong Kong, Oct. 21 (CNA) Seven Falungong practitioners were arrested by police Thursday morning when they did their meditation exercises together in a park in Chengdu in southwestern Sichuan province, a human rights group said.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China said that the whereabouts of the people arrested were unknown, and that they might be detained for 15 to 30 days.

Mainland Chinese authorities have recently stepped up the crackdown on Falungong practitioners in mainland China, the information center said, adding that at least 500 of them have been arrested this month in such big cities as Beijing, Tianjin, Shijiazhuang, Chengdu, Chongqing, Jinzhou, Changchun, Shenyang, Changsha, Harbin, and Wuhan.
The mainland Chinese government outlawed and began to crack down on Falungong and its practitioners nation-wide in July.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Oct. 21, or the 13th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1520: Ferdinand Magellan, Portuguese navigator, and his expedition are blown by storms into a strait that separates South America from Tierra del Fuego and other islands south of the continent and also connects the southern Atlantic and Pacific oceans. The strait now bears his name.
1727: The Ching court and Russia sign a new border treaty at the trading town of Kiakhta in Outer Mongolia.
1760: Katsushka Hokusai, Japanese painter, engraver and printmaker, is born. His Japanese color prints continue to be sold worldwide.
1789: Martial law is imposed in France.
1805: Admiral Sir Horatio Nelson is mortally wounded by a French sniper in the Battle of Trafalgar with the British fleet under Nelson victorious over the French and Spanish Allied fleets.
1833: Alfred Nobel, Swedish industrialist and chemist who invented dynamite, is born. He founded the Nobel Prize to award the world's leading scientists, artists and peacemakers.
1879: Thomas Alva Edison, US inventor, successfully tests an electric incandescent lamp with a carbonized filament at his New Jersey laboratory.
1916: Austrian Prime Minister Sturgkh is assassinated by Friedrich Adler, the pacifist son of the leader of Austrian Socialism.
1923: The world's first planetarium opens at the Deutsche Museum in Munich.
1934: Government troops capture Juichin, communist capital in Kiangsi. The main force of rebels is wiped out and the remaining ones flee to the northwest.
1938: Japanese troops finally capture the Chinese city of Canton after months of bombing.
1946: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the National government, and Madame Chiang arrive in Taiwan for the first time for an inspection tour.
1950: Chinese communist forces begin their occupation of Tibet.
1952: The first worldwide Overseas Chinese Conference opens in Taipei.
1953: The first Overseas Chinese Day is celebrated in Taipei.
1954: The United States, Soviet Union, Britain and France agree to end the Allied occupation of Germany.
1956: Anti-Communist revolution breaks out in Hungary.
1958: John Foster Dulles, US secretary of state, arrives in Taipei for a visit. He pursued a policy of opposing the USSR largely through economic and military aid to US allies.
1960: Queen Elizabeth II launches HMS Dreadnought, Britain's first nuclear submarine.
1960: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Mali.
1964: Yang Chuan-kuang, the ROC decathlon champion who won the ROC's first Olympic silver medal in 1960, announces his retirement after winning a fifth place at the Tokyo Olympics.
1979: Moshe Dayan, prime minister of Israel, resigns over the government's refusal to negotiate with Palestinians.
1979: Willy Brandt is elected chancellor of West Germany.
1970: Norman E. Borlaug, US agriculture scholar, wins the Nobel Peace Prize for his role in developing high-yield grains that increased food production in developing countries.
1975: The second naphtha cracking plant of the Chinese Petroleum Corp. begins production.
1987: Ho Ying-chin, a Chinese general who received the formal surrender of Japanese forces in China from General Okamura in Nanking on Sept. 9, 1945, dies at the age of 97.
1989: Tens of thousands of Hungarians demonstrate, demanding an end to communism on the anniversary of the 1956 uprising.
1994: The United States and North Korea sign a landmark deal under which Pyongyang would freeze and then dismantle its nuclear program.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In another place in the Book of Song it is said, `His virtue is light as hair.' Still a hair is something material. `The workings of Almighty God have neither sound nor smell.' There is nothing higher than that."

DOC.HEADLINE: ESTRADA HAILS WAHID'S ELECTION AS INDONESIAN PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Philippine President Joseph Ejercito Estrada expressed confidence Thursday that the election of Abdurrahman Wahid as Indonesia's new president will usher in political stability in the world's fourth largest country.

"On behalf of the Filipino people, I want to congratulate the people of Indonesia for having elected a new president, President Wahid," Estrada said in an interview with reporters after delivering the keynote address to the 13th General Assembly of the Pacific Economic Cooperation Council (PECC) in Makati City.
"And I think this will start the political stabilization of the nation," Estrada added.

Wahid, better known by the nickname Gus Dur, meaning "teacher of his people," was elected by Indonesia's 700-member assembly Wednesday, replacing B.J. Habibie as president of the world's largest Islamic country in terms of population.
It was the first free and contested election for the head of state in Indonesia's 54 years of independence.

The new Indonesian leader, who was left half-blind after suffering at least two strokes in recent years, is committed to democracy and pledged to push for better international trade and political relations.

Indonesia's political and economic stability have been challenged by violence, instigated by anti-independence militia at the alleged direction of the armed forces, that erupted after the people of East Timor voted overwhelmingly to break free from Indonesia, which had illegally annexed and then brutally ruled the former Portuguese territory for 24 years.
Estrada had dispatched Philippine soldiers to East Timor to join a United Nations force of peacekeepers from countries such as Australia, Malaysia, New Zealand, the United States and Canada.

Regarding a security arrangement for the Asia-Pacific region, Estrada proposed that nations explore the options of: revitalizing the ASEAN Regional Forum, expanding the mandate of the ASEAN Plus Three (mainland China, Japan and South Korea) Summit, and creating a new security mechanism altogether.
Estrada emphasized that a new forum should be given the mandate and the capability to undertake preventive diplomacy, conflict-prevention and conflict-resolution initiatives.

He noted that the new forum's function should not be limited to responding to ongoing disputes but also preventing or resolving conflicts peacefully before they worsen into armed confrontation. (by Timothy Sun)

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMOSA GROUP'S MERCURY-TAINTED SLUDGE ALLOWED TO STAY IN KAOHSIUNG
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, Oct. 21 (CNA) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) under the Executive Yuan decided Thursday to allow Formosa Group's notorious mercury-contaminated sludge to remain stored in Kaohsiung Port warehouses for another year until December 31, 2000.
This was the fourth time the EPA granted such permission to Formosa Group since the sludge was repatriated from Cambodia last April.

The last period of permitted storage expired on Oct. 19. The EPA gave the nod to Formosa Group's request for another year of storage after the industrial giant offered a sum of NT$50 million as collateral and a document promising that the conglomerate is trying to seek an import license from a third country.
Officials of Kaohsiung Port have requested that Formosa Group strengthen protection measures to prevent further contamination from the toxic waste.

Some 4,000 metric tons of mercury-contaminated sludge were brought back to the island from Cambodia, after Formosa Group's attempt to rid itself of the industrial by-product was foiled by protest over the dangerous nature of the material.
The toxic sludge is now stored in 357 containers at Kaohsiung Port's Pier No. 63.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, PRC LIKELY TO JOIN WTO NEXT SPRING: ANALYST

TEXT.P: An analyst with the National Security Council (NSC) said Thursday that Taiwan and mainland China are likely to enter the World Trade Organization (WTO) next spring.

Tsai Ying-wen, a member of the Consultation Committee under the NSC, made the remarks while delivering a report at the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council on the WTO issue and the prospects of cross-Taiwan Strait economic relations.
It is quite difficult for Taiwan and mainand China to join the WTO this year, because no concrete draft for protocol for mainland entry has been completed, she said.
Furthermore, Tsai pointed out, mainland China is required to engage in bilateral talks with more than 20 WTO countries before its entry.

Judging from the time required for the entry procedures and to solve other related problems, she predicts that Taiwan and mainland China will probably be able to enter the WTO at the same time next spring.
Regarding future development of cross-strait economic and trade relations, Tsai said that "political judgment" will play a major role.
She noted that even after Taiwan has joined the WTO, Taipei might not completely lift restrictions on establishing direct trade, transportation and communication links with the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: ESTRADA RENEWS CALL FOR ASIA-PACIFIC SECURITY ARRANGEMENT

TEXT.P: Philippine president Joseph Ejercito Estrada renewed his call Thursday for Asia-Pacific nations to establish mechanisms for an effective political and security cooperation arrangement.
Estrada urged the creation of an agreement that would encompass not only containment of potential flash-points in the region but also non-military concerns such as stamping out transnational crime.

Speaking before the 13th General Assembly of the Pacific Economic Cooperation Council held in Makati City, Estrada underscored the importance of founding an Asia-Pacific regional security agenda to ensure sustained economic growth and quality of life.

Estrada expressed concern over the tension in the Taiwan Strait, missile development on the Korean Peninsula, nuclear buildup in South Asia, and recent developments in South China Sea, which he said, are "potential flash-points" in the region.
The Philippines, along with mainland China, Vietnam, Taiwan, Malaysia and Brunei, are involved in a territorial dispute over the Spratly Islands located in the South China Sea.

Regarding a security arrangement for the Asia-Pacific region, Estrada proposed that nations explore the options of: revitalizing the ASEAN Regional Forum (ARF), expanding the mandate of the ASEAN Plus Three (mainland China, Japan and South Korea) Summit, and creating a new security mechanism altogether.
Estrada emphasized that a forum should be given the mandate and the capability to undertake preventive diplomacy, conflict-prevention and conflict-resolution initiatives.

He said the region's security agenda should also cover cooperation to eradicate terrorism and other transnational crimes such as drug trafficking, money laundering, and trafficking in women and children.

Estrada stressed that governments of East Asia must strive for greater transparency and must push for reforms to strengthen corporate governance, including tougher bankruptcy laws and greater corporate disclosure and accountability.
He said his vision of the Asia-Pacific region in the next century includes the following:
-- A spirit of openness and partnership through ASEAN, with APEC as the major vehicle for promoting multilateralism;
-- Domestic structural reforms and international initiatives to remodel the global financial system and prevent another financial crisis; and
-- Greater regional cooperation accompanied by a common East Asian currency and market. (by Timothy Sun)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Friday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Reconstruction of power transmission systems included under Emergency Decree protection umbrella.
The China Times:
Timetable for the 2000 Presidential election is expected to be publicized in days; Kuomintang issues warnings prohibiting party members from signing any campaign endorsement.
The United Daily News:

Soong and his two friends surnamed Wu turn upbeat for presidential campaign.
The China Post:
