The Taiwan News:
Megawati elected vice president -- Victory brings calm to streets of Jakarta but unrest remains in stronghold of Bali.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAGNITUDE 6.4 EARTHQUAKE JOLTS TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A strong earthquake measuring 6.4 on the Richter scale jolted Taiwan on Friday morning, causing a fire at a university's chemical laboratory and a blackout in 90,000 households in southern Taiwan, according to the Central Weather Bureau (CWB).
The temblor occurred at 10:19 a.m. with its epicenter located at 2.5 kilometers northwest of Chiayi City, southern Taiwan at a depth of 12.1 kilometers, the CWB said.
Unconfirmed reports say there were people injured in the tremor.
The hardest hit areas were Chiayi City and Mingchien township in Nantou County, with the quake registering a magnitude 6 on the Richter scale. The registered magnitude in Taipei was 2.
A chemical laboratory at National Chung Cheng University caught fire when the tremor caused containers of chemicals in the laboratory to fall to the ground.
The quake damaged some electricity distribution networks in southern Taiwan, causing power outages in 80,000 households in Chiayi district, and in 10,000 homes in the Yunlin and Paiho districts.
The CWB said the earthquake was not an aftershock from the "921 Earthquake."

DOC.HEADLINE: PM SIEW CALLS ON SPECIALISTS TO HELP IN SPIRITUAL REHABILITATION

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Friday called on psychologists and other professionals involved in spiritual healing to help in post-earthquake rehabilitation.
Siew said the armed forces were the first to pitch in with rescue and relief work in central Taiwan immediately after the devastating magnitude 7.3 earthquake struck on Sept. 21.

Members of the armed forces, having sustained severe psychological shocks during the rescue work, are also those most in need of spiritual healing and rehabilitation after the actual victims of the quake, Siew noted.
Siew made the remarks during a meeting with Mark V. Hansen, author of the best-selling book "Chicken Soup for the Soul," who called on Siew Friday morning at the Executive Yuan.

The premier told Hansen, who took part in spiritual reconstruction in Los Angeles after a cataclysmic earthquake hit in 1994, that brotherly love and compassion among people are the major driving forces behind efforts to rebuild Taiwan in the wake of the killer quake.

DOC.HEADLINE: US SCIENTIST LINKS HEART DISEASE FATALITIES TO DEPRESSION

TEXT.P: People suffering from depression are much more likely to die of heart disease than those who don't, according to a leading American scientist.

The head of Duke University's psychiatry and behavioral sciences, Professor Redford Williams discovered that over a period of between five and 10 years, healthy people with no history of coronary disease were twice as likely to have a heart attack if they suffered from even mild depression, the Sydney Morning Herald reported on Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: ILLEGAL IMMIGRANTS TO AUSTRALIA UP SHARPLY

TEXT.P: Illegal immigrants from mainland China and other countries entering Australia rose by leaps and bounds between July 1, 1998 and June 30, 1999 due to thriving people smuggling operations, according to the Immigration Department.

The department on Thursday released a report showing 926 illegals entered Australia by boat in fiscal 1998-99, up 223 percent from the previous year. The number arriving in Australia by plane also jumped 36 percent to 2106 people during the same period.

In the last seven months, nine boats carried 471 Chinese nationals to Australia unlawfully while 29 vessels arrived from Indonesian ports, carrying 441 people from the Middle East, North Africa and southern Asia, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ZEALAND'S CURRENT ACCOUNT DEFICIT TO RISE

TEXT.P: New Zealand is expected to suffer from rising current account deficits over the next three years due to increasing imports and higher oil prices, according to the Australian Financial Review on Friday.

The Herald quoted the Treasury as reporting the current account deficit, now hovering at 6.5 percent of the country's GDP, is expected to surge to 8.3 percent by March 2000. It also forecast New Zealand's economic growth at 3 percent over the next three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S BUDGET SURPLUS TO DROP DUE TO E. TIMOR COSTS

TEXT.P: Australia's budget surplus is expected to plunge sharply this fiscal year and next due to the huge costs of deploying its troops in East Timor, according to Defense Minister John Moore.

In his letter to Prime Minister John Howard, Moore estimated the deployment of 4500 soldiers in East Timor could cost Australia up to A$1.8 (US$1.2) billion for the 1999-2000 period and could rise to A$2.5 (US$1.67) billion the following fiscal year.

Australia will propose to the United Nations that Thailand take the leading role in East Timor so that Canberra can reduce its costs on the one hand, and ease tensions between Australia and Indonesia on the other.

DOC.HEADLINE: US REP CANCELS CHINA TRIP BECAUSE OF ANGER OVER SPYING

TEXT.P: US Rep. F. James Sensenbrenner Jr., chairman of the House Science Committee, has canceled a planned trip to the US-PRC Joint Science Policy Seminar next week in Beijing in protest of China's suspected misuse of US military and nuclear technology, and has also urged the National Science Foundation to withdraw its support for the meeting.

Sensenbrenner Jr. pointed out that Tuesday's indictments of McDonnell Douglas Corp. and mainland China's National Aero-Technology Import & Export Corp. in the sale of equipment routed to the Communist Chinese military was a major factor in his decision to cancel his planned participation in the three-day seminar scheduled to begin Sunday.
He noted that a seminar involving senior White House officials and members of the US Congress could "convey to the Chinese a business-as-usual attitude in our relationship."
"I don't intend to allow anyone to misinterpret my opposition and outrage for the illegal efforts made by the Chinese" to obtain sensitive US military technology, added the congressman.

He also said he was angry about China's state-controlled media using a meeting last week between members of the House International Relations Committee and a visiting delegation of the Communist Chinese National People's Congress -- the first since the Tiananmen Square massacre -- to downplay US concerns about suspected Communist Chinese spying.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN BREAKTHROUGH IN GENETICALLY MODIFIED ANIMALS

TEXT.P: A Canadian bio-technology firm has succeeded in having mice pass an artificial chromosome on to their offspring, a breakthrough that could spark a revolution in gene therapy, scientists said Thursday.
Scientists have altered genes of individual animals before, but this development would allow genetic changes to be passed on to succeeding generations.
Although the Canadian company has no intention of recreating the experiment in people, some scientists said the technology could be used to prevent inherited diseases in humans.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE HEART DISEASE DOWN THE ROAD FOR CANADIANS

TEXT.P: Rising obesity and smoking among young Canadians will result in more cases of heart disease down the road, according to the Canadian Heart and Stroke Foundation.
Although advances in medical treatment have brought down mortality rates, the cases of heart disease and stroke continue to grow, the foundation said in a report released Thursday.

Cardiologist Andreas Wielgosz, a spokesman for the foundation, said the number of deaths from heart disease, already the number one killer of Canadians, is increasing. He cited the declining fitness of Canadian youth as the most disturbing factor in the rise and noted that the number of young smokers is again on the rise after declining for decades before the 1990s.
During the last 20 years the incidence of obesity among boys has risen to 22 percent from 16 percent, and to 26 percent from 15 percent for girls, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SIEW RUSHES TO CHIAYI AFTER QUAKE

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew rushed to Chiayi Friday immediately after a magnitude 6.4 earthquake struck the southern city at 10:19 a.m. to inspect the tremor's impact on the area.
As of Friday noon, nearly 60 aftershocks, including one of a magnitude of 6, were detected in southern and central Taiwan.
The quakes epicenter was 2.5 kilometers north of Chiayi City and 12.1 kilometers beneath the surface of the earth, the Seismology Center of the Central Weather Bureau reported.
According to Lu Pei-lin, deputy director of the center, the Chiayi quake was independent of the devastating magnitude 7.3 earthquake that struck central Taiwan on Sept. 21.

This quake helped release energy building up underground in the southwest region, which is believed to experience a strong quake about every 30 years. The last time a killer jolt rattled southwest Taiwan was in 1964, killing several hundred people and destroying thousands of houses, Lu added.

According to the Central Disaster Prevention Center, as of noon on Friday, 38 people have been reported injured in Chiayi City, the surrounding county and in Tainan City while 16 people have been rescued.
The center has also received 12 reports of damage to structures, 12 reports of fires, 19 reports of gas leaks and 11 reports of people trapped in elevators.

Property damage included a fire in National Chung Cheng University's chemical laboratory and another fire in a chemical processing plant of the Formosa Plastics Group, both in Chiayi County, according to reports the center received.
An aftershock of magnitude 6 was detected around 11:10 with its epicenter located at 4.9 kilometers north of Chiayi City and at a depth of 7.2 kilometers.

The temblor had an intensity of 5.0 in Tainan, Mt. Ali and in Mingchien in Nantou County, an intensity of 3.0 in the offshore island of Penghu and the eastern city of Hualien, and an intensity of 2.0 in the central city of Taichung and the southern city of Kaohsiung.
The seismologists are checking now to determine whether the quake was caused by a break in the Meishan Fault Line which is located only 10 kilometers from the epicenter of Friday's quake.

DOC.HEADLINE: VISA PROSPECTS FOR ROC ENVOY IN HONG KONG UP IN THE AIR

TEXT.P: A ranking official in charge of the Republic of China's policies on mainland China declined to speculate Friday whether Taipei's liaison officer in Hong Kong will be rejected for visa renewal when the current one expires next month.

Rumors have circulated that Hong Kong authorities rejected a visa renewal application filed by Cheng An-kuo, director of Chung Hwa Travel Service Hong Kong, the de facto representative of Taipei in Hong Kong, because Beijing was angry about Cheng's remarks in July amplifying President Lee Teng-hui's "special state-to-state relations" theory to redefine cross-strait relations.
Lin said he could not comment on unconfirmed reports at the moment.

According to Lin, the Mainland Affairs Council, Taiwan's top agency responsible for formulating policies related to the mainland, has been highly satisfied with Cheng's performance in Hong Kong, particularly with efforts to facilitate mutual exchanges between Taiwan and Hong Kong.
Cheng assumed his post in Hong Kong nearly four years ago. His work visa is due to expire at the end of November.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 30,000 HITS TO GIO WEBSITE SINCE MASSIVE SEPT. 21 QUAKE

TEXT.P: People from other countries have accessed the website of the Government Information Office (GIO) of the Republic of China more than 30,000 times since the devastating Sept. 21 earthquake, said GIO officials Friday.

The officials noted that around 1,000 people per day visited the GIO website to learn about the situation in Taiwan in the wake of the magnitude-7.3 quake, which claimed more than 2,400 lives and led to extensive damages in central Taiwan.

The officials said English-language information on the website included statements by the government on quake relief and reconstruction, government officials' remarks, and related reports and comments by domestic news media.

As of Oct. 21, more than 30,600 hits were recorded at the site where Internet surfers can browse through Taiwan headlines for quake information and learn how the government and private sector have been dealing with the aftermath.

Overseas surfers who visited the GIO website come from 95 countries, with the greatest number of hits coming from the United States, followed by Japan, Canada, Singapore, Britain, Germany, France and Australia.
GIO officials said the English-language website "Taiwan Headlines" can be found at www.taiwanheadlines.gov.tw.
The GIO is scheduled to launch a Spanish-language Taiwan page by the end of the year to provide information to the ROC's Central American allies.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DOWN FOR FIFTH STRAIGHT DAY, INDEX FUTURES LOWER

TEXT.P: Affected by a strong earthquake during Friday's trading session, Taiwan share prices closed down sharply as investors worried about potential industrial losses and loan defaults following the magnitude-6.4 quake and its aftershocks.

The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index dipped 95.27 points, or 1.24 percent, to close at 7,559.63 on a turnover of NT$72.38 billion (US$2.28 billion). The index has fallen for five straight sessions, shedding 3.4 percent in all.

The index opened higher, but soon drifted lower as a selling frenzy was quickly sparked after the quake due to investor fears that more losses would be reported by microchip makers. That directly led the technology sector to dip, ending the day posting the largest losses among the eight major stock categories.
The temblor caused several buildings to collapse, and one person in the southern city of Chiayi was killed. The quake and a series of aftershocks were felt in many places across Taiwan.

The plastics and chemical sector as well as textile issues ended lower amid buying interests that switched to reconstruction-related shares, such as cement, steel and glass-making issues, which registered gains of 3.9 percent, 2 percent and 1.68 percent, respectively.
Without new leads, investors' concerns over the impact of the earthquake are expected to push the index down further in the near term, dealers said.
Declining stocks led advancing stocks 371 to 110, with 55 shares unchanged.
The over-the-counter market shed 4.99 points to close at 170.84 on a turnover of NT$7.38 billion.

Discouraged by the negative performance of the stock market and weak investor confidence, all TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) posted losses, among which next March futures suffered the largest losses.
TAIEX Index Futures for November moved down 86 points to close at 7,597 with 3,094 contract transactions. Those for December shed 33 points to finish at 7,655 with 64 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for next March dipped 129 points to close at 7,601 with six contract transactions, while those for next June shed 44 points to end at 7,693, with three contract transactions. Those for next September dropped 86 points to end at 7,865. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Oct. 22, or the 14th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1721: Peter I, known as "Peter the Great," is proclaimed Emperor of all of Russia. He extended his territory around the Baltic and Caspian shores and reformed the administration of the state.
1835: Sam Houston, US politician and general who fought in the Texan struggle for independence from Mexico, is sworn in as president of the Republic of Texas.
1873: Emperors of Russia, Germany and Austro-Hungary form an alliance.
1906: Paul Cezanne, French painter and leading post-impressionist figure, dies at the age of 67. His most famous paintings include "Mont Sainte-Victoire" and "The Card Players."
1909: Elise de Laroche, French aviator better known as Baronne de Laroche, becomes the first woman to fly solo.
1944: The Military Committee of the National government begins to draft young intellectuals for military service after Chairman Chiang Kai-shek urged 100,000 young men to enter the army on Sept. 14.
1947: Pakistan and India begin a war over Kashmir.
1947: Japanese spy Yoshiko Kawajima is sentenced to death by a Chinese military court.
1950: Popular elections of magistrates are held in Taiwan Province with Yang Chung-ching elected chief of Hualien County, and Chen Chen-chung as chief of Taitung County.
1951: Strong earthquake rocks Hualien, kiling 43 people and destroying many houses.
1953: Laos gains independence from France.
1962: US President John F. Kennedy makes his first major move in the showdown with the USSR over the building of ballistic missile sites in Cuba by announcing that Cuba will be placed under a naval "quarantine" -- a blockade -- until the Soviets remove them.
1962: William Vassall, a US admiral clerk, is jaied for 18 years for spying for the Soviet Union.
1964: Jean-Paul Sartre, French writer, rejects the Nobel Prize for Literature saying it would reduce the impact of his writing.
1966: KGB master spy George Blake, who had spied for the Russians for 12 years and was sentecned to 42 years in prison in 1962, escapes from the maximum security wing of Wormwood Scrubs prison in west London.
1975: Arnold Toynbee, British historian and philosopher, dies at the age of 86. His "Study of History" explores patterns of growth and the decay of civilization.
1976: The 34,000-ton tanker Tsaineng (Talent) calls at Taichung port as the first vessel to enter Taiwan's fourth international seaport.
1977: The first generator of the first nuclear power plant in Taiwan becomes operational.
1986: Yeh Chien-ying, one of the senior leaders of communist China, dies in Beijing at the age of 89. With the support of Yeh, who at that time (1976) commanded a wide following in the army and among senior cadres, Hua Kuo-feng was able to purge the "Gang of Four" and become Mao Tse-tung's successor.
1986: The Executive Yuan approves a raise in the minimum wage to NT$6,900 per month effective from November.
1992: Belgian Foreign Trade Minister Robert Urbain visits Taipei to relay a message of welcome to Taiwan business leaders intending to invest in Belgium and pledges support for the ROC's bid to join GATT.
1993: Boris N. Yeltsin, president of Russia, signs a decree governing private farms, paving the way for breaking up state-controlled farms to move toward a free market economy.
1995: Independent presidential candidate Chen Li-an names Wang Ching-feng, a Control Yuan member, as his running mate.
1996: Some 25 prisoners are burned to death in a Venezuelan jail after guards fire tear gas canisters that start a blaze.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN LAWMAKER TO ASK BEIJING TO STOP PERSECUTING FALUNGONG
DOC.DATELINE: Ottawa, Oct. 21 (CNA) (By S.C. Chang and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: A Canadian lawmaker on Thursday decided to organize a signature-collecting activity to urge Beijing to stop persecuting Falungong practitioners in mainland China.

Rob Anders, a parliamentarian elected from Calgary, Alberta, made the decision after meeting three Falungong practitioners and hearing that others in mainland China have been persecuted by Beijing authorities.

Anders has contacted several senators and members of the House of Commons. Most agreed that Beijing is unjustified in its treatment of Falungong practitioners, which includes: not allowing arrested practitioners to have defense lawyers, preventing third-party investigations of whether practitioners were even involved in unlawful activities, and detaining and torturing practitioners just for being Falungong believers or for refusing to stop practicing.

Anders plans to ask the Canadian government to express its concern to Beijing and to encourage other members of parliament to jointly sign a letter urging mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin to stop persecuting Falungong practitioners.
Anders began his efforts on Oct. 1, the 50th anniversary of the founding of the Beijing regime.

Anders refused to enter Beijing's consulate in Calgary to extend his congratulations on the occasion; instead, he stood outside the consulate with Falungong practitioners and members of Canada's Taiwan and Tibetan communities to protest Beijing's persecution of human rights.

The resolute anti-Communist Canadian parliamentarian and Keith Martin, another Canadian lawmaker, yelled "Butcher!" during a parliamentary session when the speaker introduced visiting mainland Chinese Judicial Minister Xiao Yang to the audience of Canadian lawmakers.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose 0.005 to close at 31.761 against the greenback on the Taipei Market on Friday.
The currency opened at the day's low of 31.764, and experienced a high of 31.748 during the session. Interbank US dollar trading amounted to US$312.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: 3 MAINLAND CREW MEMBERS OF TAIWAN FISHING SHIP RETURNED TO KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: Maritime police escorted three mainland Chinese fishermen of a Taiwan boat back to Kaohsiung Harbor in southern Taiwan on Friday morning.

Four Taiwanese crew members of the ship, Cheng Lung Hsing, are still missing despite a 72-hour search involving two maritime police patrol boats in seas around the Tungsha (Pratas) island group 240 nautical miles southwest of Taiwan's southern port of Kaohsiung.
During questioning, the three mainland crew members affirmed that the ship had capsized because of rough sea conditions on Sunday.

But family members of the four Taiwanese crew members suspected that there had been a fight on the boat and that the three mainlanders may have killed the Taiwanese crew and thrown their bodies into the sea.
Police promised to make further investigations to clear up the case.
Cheng Lung Hsing, a 19.35-ton tuna boat, is registered in Tungkang, Pingtung County. It went out to sea Oct. 11. The ship was reported capsized northeast of the Tungsha island group.

Taiwanese captain Lee Tsai-fa and other three Taiwanese crew members went missing, while the three mainland crew members were rescued by a Kaohsiung fishing boat and later picked up by a maritime police patrol boat.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI STILL WAITING FOR BEIJING'S RESPONSE TO KOO'S OFFER: MAC

TEXT.P: Taipei is still waiting for Beijing's response to Koo Chen-fu's recent offer that he himself to go to the mainland to invite his counterpart Wang Daohan to visit Taiwan, said an official of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Friday.

Lin Chung-pin, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level MAC, was referring to an assertion made by Zhang Jincheng, secretary-general of the mainland Association for Relation Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), that it would be inconvenient for Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo to go to mainland China again if the "two states" theory is not retracted.
Zhang made the comment when he attended a press conference held at the mainland Consulate General in Osaka on Thursday.
However, MAC's Lin dismissed Zhang's remark as not necessarily representing Beijing's stance in regard to Koo's initiative, especially since Zhang was currently traveling abroad.

Koo, Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China, took a new initiative last week on the occasion of the first anniversary of the Koo-Wang meeting in Shanghai. The offer was designed to break the impasse in cross-strait relations resulting from President Lee Teng-hui's "special state-to-state" statement in July regarding relations between Taipei and Beijing.

Wang, chairman of ARATS -- the mainland's semi-official body which handles contacts with Taiwan -- postponed his visit to Taiwan indefinitely after Lee's comment. Wang had also said in July that "the basis of contact, exchange and dialogue between ARATS and SEF no longer exists."

Although Beijing has not announced the cancellation of Wang's visit to Taiwan, originally set for October, it did say that Wang's trip to Taiwan is impossible if Lee's "two states" theory is not retracted.
Against this backdrop, the ARATS secretary-general answered a similar question on Sunday when he took part in a seminar sponsored by overseas Chinese in Japan.

On that occasion, Zhang did not directly answer questions concerning Koo's offer to meet Wang again in Shanghai; Zhang just reiterated the old rhetoric by saying that as long as Taiwan does not retract and continues to insist on the "two states" theory, it will be impossible for Wang to pay a visit to Taiwan.
Nevertheless, Taipei is still waiting patiently for Beijing's response and hopes that Beijing authorities seriously consider Koo's kind suggestion, said SEF Vice Chairman Lin.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DEMANDS RESPECT IN TAIPEI-MANILA AVIATION TALKS

TEXT.P: Taiwan called for aviation negotiations with the Philippines under the circumstance that the latter respect the Republic of China's national dignity, a high-ranking official in transportation affairs said on Friday.
Chang Kuo-cheng, deputy director-general of the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA), made the call at a public hearing in Taipei on the Taipei-Manila aviation rights dispute.
Relevant officials and private representatives from the two sides were invited to attend the hearing, sponsored by Taiwan's opposition Democratic Progressive Party.

Eva Eastrada Kalaw, chairwoman of the Manila Economic and Cultural Center, said the Philippines is hoping that the misunderstanding that has led to aviation disputes between the two countries could be resolved in no time.

However, Kalaw noted, the Philippines is indeed suffering from "fifth freedom" violations by two Taiwan air companies plying the Taipei-Manila route in which the airlines picked up more passengers than allowed from Manila and then flew to third-country destinations such as the United States.

She stressed that in the 1996 Taipei-Manila aviation agreement, the Philippines had only agreed to offer Taipei "third and fourth freedom" rights, but China Airlines and EVA Airways expanded the rights without authorization, resulting in severe losses suffered by the debt-ridden Philippine Airlines (PAL).
The Philippines has no political motive to trigger such a dispute by demanding reduction of Taiwan's passenger loads, Kalaw noted, calling on the two sides to continue their aviation negotiations.

Chang protested that Manila's accusation is not based on fact. He said the Philippines has accused Taiwan of violations on flights from Manila to Taiwan but based their punishment on operations from Manila to Hong Kong. He called the situation "confusing."

Moreover, Chang added, Manila authorities have reiterated that their aviation accord with Taiwan is merely a "civil technologic agreement" because there are no official diplomatic ties between the two countries and that the "agreement" can be abolished under domestic laws of the Philippines.
If the Philippines would randomly cancel the bilateral agreement signed with Taipei, Chang asked, "how can we proceed with the negotiations?"

The dispute began in late July when negotiations between Taiwan and the Philippines on the four-year-old air link accord broke down, with the latter threatening to suspend the agreement to force Taiwan to accept its demand for a reduction in the number of passengers allowed to be carried by Taiwan airlines.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE THAN 320 INJURED BY EARTHQUAKE

TEXT.P: More than 320 people were injured by the powerful earthquakes that jolted southern Taiwan Friday morning, said the Central Disaster Prevention and Rescue Center.

The earthquake, measuring 6.4 on the Richter scale, struck the Chiayi-Tainan area in southern Taiwan at 10:19 a.m. Friday. It was followed by a magnitude-6 aftershock at 11:10. The temblors were felt almost islandwide.
Officials of the center said that 17 residents were rescued from the rubble after one house was completely destroyed and 13 others were half-collapsed.

The earthquake, with its epicenter pinpointed at 2.5 kilometers northwest of Chiayi City and its focus, or underground center, at 12.1 kilometers beneath the earth's surface, also damaged several provincial highways in the Chiayi area, officials said.
Houses were found to have been damaged in Yunlin and Nantou counties as well.
President Lee Teng-hui, who was inspecting reconstruction work in Nantou County on Friday morning, rushed to Chiayi by helicopter that afternoon to inspect areas rocked by the quake.
Seismologists said that Friday's temblor was unrelated to the deadly one that struck Central Taiwan on Sept. 21, killing more than 2,400 and was triggered by the Meishan fault line in Chiayi County.

DOC.HEADLINE: MONETARY AID TO TAIWAN QUAKE VICTIMS FROM US, CANADA REACHES US$ 24 M.

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Friday extended its gratitude to overseas Chinese and other people in the United States and Canada for their concern following the "921 Earthquake" and for their monetary aid to quake victims.
Liu Chih-kung, director of the American Affairs Department under MOFA, extended the gratitude at a press conference.

Liu said that following the massive temblor that caused significant casualties in the central part of the island, US President Bill Clinton immediately issued a statement to extend his condolences over the loss of life and property in quake-stricken zones.

Liu noted that overseas Chinese in the United States and Canada as well as the general public in the two countries have been enthusiastic in providing monetary aid to quake victims. So far, a total of US$24 million has been donated.
Liu said that the US Senate and House of Representatives passed resolutions in late September and early October, respectively, to express their concerns over the strong quake.
Thirty US state governors have sent letters to President Lee Teng-hui and the government of the Republic of China to express their sympathy.
Liu thanked Clinton, Congress, governors, overseas Chinese and the general public in the United States and Canada for their concern and assistance.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC SAYS SEIZURE OF MAINLAND FISHING VESSEL LEGAL

TEXT.P: The maritime police seizure of a mainland fishing trawler early Wednesday was legal and essential to maintain national security as the vessel had illegally entered Taiwan's territorial waters, said Vice Chairman Lin Chong-pin of the Mainland Affairs Council Friday.

Lin made the statement in response to media questions on the arrest of 18 crew members of an iron-hulled mainland Chinese fishing vessel, who were detained five miles off the northern Taiwan coast on suspicion of violating the Statute Governing Relations Between People on Taiwan and the Mainland, after they approached the crash site of a twin-seat Mirage 2000-5 jet fighter.

According to the statute, relevant law enforcement organizations are entitled to disperse any mainland Chinese vessels entering Taiwan territorial waters without permission, confiscate their fishing equipment and detain crew members for no longer than three months.

The seized vessel, Min Chin Yu No.5318, had been previously chased off by maritime police after approaching the northern coast of Taiwan; it reappeared and remained for two days in the area where the warplane had plunged into the sea.
The 18 crew members had been sent to northern Hsinchu's mainlander detention center for questioning.
Sources revealed that the 18 crew members were unanimous in denying attempts to salvage pieces of the French-made Mirage 2000-5 or to gain national defense information.

However, maritime police said they had found advanced satellite navigational aids and sonar depth-finders in their ship, and a notebook with detailed notes on sea conditions off western Taiwan was found in the captain's hold.

After interrogating the 18 crew members separately, maritime police said that two of them "did not behave like fishermen" and were suspected of spying. Police added that further investigation will be required to determine the facts of the situation. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STUDENTS DEMONSTRATE IN LONDON AGAINST BEIJING LEADER
DOC.DATELINE: London, Oct. 22 (CNA) (By Mark Chun-lin Ou & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A group of Taiwan students demonstrated Thursday night outside Beijing's embassy in London while mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin gave a banquet for his British hosts.

One month after Taiwan suffered the most deadliest earthquake in a century, the Taiwan students, who are studying in Britain, protested against what they called Beijing's attempts to achieve political gains from the international community's aid to the island.

They accused Beijing of illegally assuming sovereignty over Taiwan by demanding that other countries ask for its approval before offering aid or dispatching rescue teams to Taiwan, and by shamelessly thanking them on behalf of the ROC.
Ironically, the Beijing embassy where Jiang threw the banquet was the same place where ROC founding father Sun Yat-sen was detained in 1896 by the Ching Dynasty officials.

In his speech at the banquet, Jiang recalled the episode 103 year ago as he boasted that the People's Republic of China, 50 years after replacing the ROC in mainland China, has achieved the goals Sun struggled for when he overthrew the Ching Dynasty in 1912 and established the ROC.
The ROC moved to Taiwan after losing a civil war with the Chinese Communist regime in 1949.
Several other groups also demonstrated outside the Beijing embassy Thursday night, including Tibetan activists and a group of Chinese dissents.
Jiang arrived in London on Monday for an official visit and is scheduled to leave for France on Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PURCHASE OF F-16 JET FIGHTERS FROM TURKEY NEVER HEARD BY JASON HU

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Jason Hu of the Republic of China told the local press Friday that he never heard the ROC will purchase F-16 jet fighters from Turkey as Turkish mass media had reported.
Hu also said that relations between Taiwan and Turkey are not close enough as to be concerned with political affairs.

According to a Friday news release by the Turkish Trade Office in Taipei, Taiwan placed an order with Turkey to buy F-16 jet fighters. A Turkish official told the Central News Agency that the press release quoted Turkish mass media as reporting the purchase.
Officials at that office said they did not know when the order was made, the quantity of aircraft, or the amount of money involved, since the transaction was not realized through them.
Hu answered related questions raised by the local press after he presided over an award presentation ceremony at the ministry on Friday afternoon.

"Our relations with Turkey are very common. We just held talks with them on the relief work, and no political affairs were involved. I never heard that the ROC will purchase F-16 jet fighters from Turkey," said Hu.
In related news, Replica of China Air Force officers denied the Turkish media reports of the purchase.
A spokesman for the ROC Air Force Command Headquarters said that by seeing its purchasing budget, one could understand that the Air Force has no plan at present to procure more F-16 jet fighters.

"We, the Air Force, purchased F-16 jet fighters directly from the US aircraft manufacturing company," he said, adding that the US company might purchase some spare parts and components from Turkey to be used for F-16 jet fighters Taiwan had ordered.
Taiwan has purchased 150 F-16 jet fighters from the United States, but delivery of those jets has not yet been completed, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ACE BASKETBALL PLAYER SET TO JOIN SHANGHAI TEAM
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Oct. 22 (CNA) (By H. M. Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan basketball player Cheng Chih-lung is expected to sign a contract with a mainland basketball team by the end of the month.
Cheng will be the first Taiwan basketball player to join a mainland team after he officially signs the contract with the Oriental Sharks, a Shanghai team.
Cheng passed physical tests Thursday in Beijing, running 3,000 meters in 12 minutes and 50 seconds; the standard time is 13 minutes and 30 seconds.
The ace player wore the jersey and sneakers of his new team and began training with other team members in a Shanghai stadium Friday.
The mainland team's head coach Li Quioping said that he hopes the addition of Cheng will increase the team's offensive power.
Mainland China's professional basketball association will begin its new season on Nov. 21, and Li is hoping that the team can make it to the final four this season.
Cheng's contract with the Sharks will be for only one season. Cheng is expected to play at least 25 games before the season ends next March or April.
All members of the mainland team are under 22 years old, except for two players, aged 25 and 26. The 30-year-old Cheng will be the oldest player on the team.
Cheng said that to play in the mainland will be challenging and that he hopes to make good marks with the Sharks.
Cheng also said the team had agreed that he return to Taiwan to play in a charity game at the end of the month.

Cheng, who belonged to the Hungkuo team in Taiwan, said previously that as the Taiwan professional basketball alliance has suspended games since March, he has to play in the mainland to maintain his form.

Cheng, 190 centimeters and 85 kilograms, is a forward, and was twice elected as the league's most-valuable player. His team Hungkuo won three consecutive pennants of the Chinese Basketball Alliance between 1996 and 1998.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HAS TO PROMOTE UNDERSTANDING IN US: ROC OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The results of a recent US opinion poll inspired Taiwan to consider strengthening efforts to promote understanding in the United States, said a Foreign Ministry official on Friday.
Liu Chih-kung, director of the Foreign Ministry's North American Affairs Department, told the media that Taiwan would learn from the survey.

The survey showed that only 26 percent of the American people replied "yes" when asked whether the United States should continue to help defend Taiwan through arms sales and other means, even if it hurts US relations with Beijing.

The survey, conducted last June by the Henry Luce Foundation and released in Washington on Tuesday, also indicated that only 35 percent of the American public supported US defense of Taiwan if the island comes under attack from mainland China.

According to a Central News Agency dispatch from Washington, Susan Shirk, deputy assistant secretary of state for Asia and the Pacific, said she was "struck" by what she considers "a very small percentage of the public" supporting continued security assistance to Taiwan.
Commenting on the results of the survey, Liu said that US intellectuals usually favor more support for Taiwan than the average US citizen.

Therefore, he said, Taiwan should in the future step up its efforts in communicating with the American public so as to improve understanding about Taiwan and the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
Liu stated that US foreign policy is normally influenced by the president, the administrative branch, Congress, opinion leaders and public opinion.
He said the survey reflected the current views of the American public on the Taiwan issue, and it would inspire Taiwan to review its work regarding the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: 7 DIGNITARIES RECOGNIZED FOR PROMOTING TIES WITH FOREIGN COUNTRIES

TEXT.P: Seven outstanding dignitaries were recognized by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) for their contributions to promote diplomatic relations with foreign countries.

At a MOFA ceremony on Friday afternoon, Foreign Minister Jason Hu presented certificates of merit to: Chin Hsiao-yi, curator of the National Palace Museum; Wang You-tseng, chairman of the General Chamber of Commerce of the Republic of China; Kao Chin-yen, chairman of Chinese National Federation of Industries; Wu Kuan-hsiung, vice chairman of the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA); Wu Tung-chin, chairman of Shin Kong Life Insurance Co.; Tai Tung-yuan, director of National Taiwan University Hospital; and Chang Chin-wen.

Since the certificates of recognition were first awarded in 1996, the ministry has also recognized: Venerable Master Cheng Yen, founder of the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation; Hsu Shui-teh, president of the Examination Yuan; Jeffrey Koo, chairman of Chinatrust Commercial Bank; Chang Jung-fa, president of Evergreen Group; and Cardinal Paul Shan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINES EYES SENDING MORE TROOPS TO E TIMOR

TEXT.P: The Philippine government is planning to send more troops to augment rehabilitation efforts in East Timor, following reports that Philippine soldiers have been receiving praise for their "excellent" performance.
"There are 240 Philippine troops there now. Perhaps that number would increase to 600 in November," Secretary Orlando Mercado of the Department of National Defense said in a radio interview.
He said reports of the Filipinos' performance in East Timor have been encouraging, with their superiors describing their work as "excellent."
The Filipinos there, Mercado pointed out, are assigned to locations away from the border, and they basically engage in rehabilitation, medical and social work.
"The feedback is that it's really hard work for our soldiers, who are engaged in humanitarian work there," he said.
Mercado added that the Philippines has received assurances that the government would be reimbursed for allowances and other expenses of Filipinos stationed there.
"Don't worry about reimbursement. The Philippines is on top of the reimbursement agenda. What we want is more Philippine troops be sent to East Timor," he quoted the officials concerned as saying.

President Joseph Ejercito Estrada has so far ordered the deployment of 247 Philippine troops to East Timor in response to a call by the United Nations and Indonesia for the international community to help restore normalcy and peace to the area. (by Timothy Sun)

DOC.HEADLINE: JASON HU TO VISIT PANAMA AND DOMINICAN REPUBLIC

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Jason Hu and his wife will leave Taipei Saturday for an official visit to the Dominican Republic and Panama at the invitation of the two countries' governments.

Hu and his wife will be accompanied by a group of Chinese entrepreneurs and will call on President Leonel Fernandez of the Dominican Republic and other government officials during their stay in Santo Domingo.

Hu will express thanks from the government and people of the Republic of China to the government and people of the Dominican Republic for their firm support of ROC bids for membership in international organizations and for their condolences after the Sept. 21 earthquake rocked Taiwan.
Hu will also take the opportunity to exchange views on the international situation in general and the two countries' bilateral cooperative ties in particular.

During his stay in Panama, Hu will call on Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso, Foreign Minister Jose Miguel Aleman and other government officials to exchange views on how to strengthen established cooperative relations between Panama and the ROC.
Hu and his accompanying entrepreneurs will return to Taipei on Nov. 2.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORCE IS NO LONGER DISPUTE-SOLVING MEANS, OFFICIAL WARNS BEIJING

TEXT.P: Noting that violence has been renounced as a way to solve disputes in the post-Cold War world, a Taipei official expressed regret Friday that Beijing has stuck to an outdated mindset in believing military strength is a panacea for any problem.

The increasing integration of the world's economies has made it almost impossible for any state to use force against another without hurting its own economy, said Lin Chong-pin, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council.
Instead of force, dialogue and negotiation are the order of the day during the post-Cold War era, said Lin.

He also alerted Washington to the subtle shift in Beijing's stance toward Taiwan, from considering the island as an inalienable part of its territory to seeing it as a vital post in its universal strategy.
Lin made the remarks after being asked to comment on reports that Beijing could resort to force in its desperate efforts to bring Taiwan into its fold.

The reports quoted a Pentagon study as predicting that Beijing, if it were to attack Taiwan, could use half of its newly built-up missile arsenal to knock out the island's air defense system and command-and-control chain, while keeping the other half to deter Washington from coming to the island's aid.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WON'T RETRACT 'STATE-TO-STATE' STATEMENT, SAYS MAC CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui's redefinition of cross-Taiwan Strait relations as a "special state-to-state relationship" will not be retracted, said Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Su Chi on Friday.
Beijing leaders have pressed Taiwan to retract the statement Lee made in July, as a condition for resuming cross-strait exchanges.

In an interview with TVBS television station, Su stated that it is impossible for Taipei to retract the "state-to-state" statement, because the 22 million people on Taiwan will not accept Beijing's view that the ROC is not a sovereign country.
He said if Beijing disagrees with Lee's statement, both sides can sit down for talks, and even if the talks hit a snag, both sides can still maintain different views of the definition of "one China."

Regarding China's future unification, Su noted that Beijing probably has no so-called timetable for China's unification. "The unification issue should be resolved slowly when the time is ripe," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Saturday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Magnitude-6.4 earthquake jolted Chiayi at 10:19 Friday morning, injuring 234 people but no reports of death.
The China Times:
The entire island felt the shake as an earthquake measuring 6.4 on Richter scale hit southern county of Chiayi Friday, leaving 254 people injured. Seismologists said the jolt was related to movement of the Meishan Fault Line.
The United Daily News:
Chiayi earthquake victims entitled to same standards of relief aid as that granted to people who were injured or whose houses damaged in the "Sept. 21 earthquake."
The Liberty Times:
A total of 249 people injured in Friday's magnitude-6.4 earthquake in Chiayi.
The Commons Daily:
Strong quake shook Yunlin, Chiayi and Tainan counties.
The China Post:
Fresh quake shakes island; Over 234 injured, no deaths.
The Taiwan News:
Another big one -- Buildings collapse, people hurt but no one dies as 6.4 quake centered in Chiayi hits Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: AFTERSHOCKS HIT CHIAYI

TEXT.P: Three aftershocks rocked central Taiwan during Friday night and early Saturday morning, one day after a 6.4 magnitude earthquake wreaked havoc in the region.
The aftershocks, measuring 4.5, 5.3 and 4.1 on the Richter scale, hit Friday at 11:40 p.m. and Saturday at 1.57 a.m. and 6.38 a.m., according to the Central Weather Bureau (CWB).
Friday night's aftershock centered on a area 22.3 km southeast of Sunmoon Lake, Nantou County while the epicenters of the other two were in the area around Chiayi City, said CWB seismologists.
No casualties or major property damage from the aftershocks were reported.
Earlier, on Friday morning, a magnitude 6.4 earthquake had hit Chiayi. Several buildings collapsed during the quake and more than 300 people were injured.
It was the second major earthquake to rattle the island since a 7.6 magnitude earthquake hit central Taiwan on Sept. 21, claiming the lives of more than 2,400 people.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Oct. 23, or the 15th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1812: An anti-Napoleonic faction in Paris, headed by General Claude Francois de Malet, tries to mount a coup d'etat, believing Napoleon to be dead in Russia.
1906: Alberto Santos-Dumont, Brazilian aviator and inventor, wins the Deutsch-Archdeacon Prize for making the first officially observed powered flight in Europe.
1921: John Boyd Dunlop, Scottish veterinary surgeon who invented the pneumatic bicycle tire, dies at the age of 81.
1924: During China's warlord era, Feng Yu-hsing, Hu Ching-yi and Sun Yueh form an allied force to launch a military coup resulting in the resignation of Tsao Kun who was elected president of the Peking government in Oct. 5, 1923.
1926: Leon Trotsky is expelled from the Soviet Communist Party.
1928: The National government formally establishes the Ministry of Education.
1936: The "West Wind," Burlington's passenger diesel, travels up to 133.3 kph, a new speed record for passenger trains.
1942: The British Eighth Army opens a massive offensive against Field Marshall Rommel's Afrika Korps at El Alamein. Since the inconclusive first battle at Alamein in July, the British have been resupplied and brought up to strength (230,000). The Axis forces number just 80,000.
1948: Chungchun, a city in Kirin Province in northeastern China, falls to communist troops.
1952: Selman A. Waksman, Ukrainian-born microbiologist, wins the Nobel Prize for Medicine or Physiology for discovering the antibiotic streptomycin, an agent effective in the treatment of tuberculosis.
1955: Ngo Dinh Diem is elected president of South Vietnam.
1956: Hungarian students and workers demonstrate in Budapest against Soviet occupation.
1957: Vice President Chen Cheng is elected deputy director general of the Kuomintang.
1958: President Chiang Kai-shek and US Secretary of State John Foster Dulles issue a joint communique reaffirming solidarity between the two countries and stating that the Kinmen and Matsu islands were "closely related" to the defense of Taiwan and Penghu under present conditions.
1964: The 10th Conference of the Asian Peoples' Anti-Communist League opens in Taipei.
1966: The Ministry of the Interior sets aside today (the ninth day of the ninth lunar month) as Double Ninth Festival, also known as the Chung Yang Festival, to honor senior citizens.
1968: Nigerian President Hamani Diori arrives in the Republic of China for an official visit.
1969: The United States starts pulling out its troops from Vietnam.
1970: Gary Gavelich, American driver, breaks the world land speed record in his rocket-propelled car "Blue Flame," driving at 631.367 mph (1,010 kph) on Bonneville Salt Flats, Utah.
1980: Soviet Prime Minister Alexei Kosygin resigns and is replaced by Nikolai Tikhonov.
1982: Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, 1970 Nobel Literature Prize winner, delivers a speech entitled "To Free China" at Taipei City Hall.
1983: Moslem suicide bombers blow up the US and French headquarters in Beirut, killing more than 200 US marines and French paratroopers.
1989: Hungary makes sweeping revisions in its constitution. Matyas Szuros is chosen to serve as president until multi-party elections are held.
1992: Emperor Akihito of Japan arrives in Beijing for a six-day visit.
1997: Hong Kong's stock market falls victim to Southeast Asia's economic turmoil with the Hang Seng index falling more than 10 percent in its biggest crash in history.
1998: A Tokyo court hands down the first death sentence to a member of the Japanese doomsday cult that carried out a 1995 Tokyo subway gas attack.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING TO EXTEND REFORM DEADLINE FOR STATE FIRMS

TEXT.P: A number of senior mainland Chinese officials have indicated their desire to extend by seven years the deadline for turning loss-making state firms around, the South China Morning Post reported today.

Relatively conservative officials, including President Jiang Ze-min, are inclined towards extending the period for restructuring state-owned firms to 10 years to help maintain stability, the report said.

Jiang and his aides reportedly indicated that should Beijing join the World Trade Organization in the coming year or so, it would be better for state firms to have an adequate period of time to absorb the shock.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WINS 15 MEDALS AT SWIMMING CHAMPIONSHIP

TEXT.P: Taiwan finished second with 15 medals in the 1999 Pan Pacific Master Swimming Championship held in Perth, Australia.
Professor Horace Ho-mu Chen, the leader of the 10-member Taiwan swimming group, said he was pleased that his team finished so high, behind only the United Kingdom.
Taiwan six gold medals, four silvers and rive bronze medals. In 1997, Taiwan won 11 medals in the same event held in Hawaii.
The Pan Pacific Master Swimming Championships are held every two years for athletes over the age of 25. (by Peter Chen)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN QUAKE CAUSES GLOBAL COMPUTER DELIVERY DECLINE
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 22 (CNA) (By J.J. Huang and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's "921 Earthquake" will cause a decline of 2 million units in its fourth quarter global computer deliveries this year, the Wall Street Journal and New York Times reported Friday.

Reports quoted Merrill Lynch Securities estimates as saying that Taiwan's computer delivery quantity will now only reach 35.3 million units during this year's fourth quarter, which is still higher than the 29.9 million units delivered in the same period last year.

Acer Inc., a major Taiwanese computer manufacturer, had a fourth quarter target of 600,000 units for portable computer deliveries prior to the quake, but that number has been reduced by 10 percent due to the effects of the massive quake on production and distribution. However, this number will still represent an 18 percent increase over the same period last year.

At present, Taiwan-made computer memory chip exports account for 12 percent of the global total. However, analysts worry that the fact that the machines which produce "logic chips" were damaged in the "921 Earthquake" and will require a long time to be repaired will have a major impact on the market.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN VESSELS ASKED TO HELP SEARCH FOR MISSING TAIWANESE CREW

TEXT.P: Maritime police on Saturday enlisted the assistance of foreign ships to help search for four missing Taiwanese crewmen after their ship capsized on Sunday.
Three mainland Chinese crewmen on the ship, "Cheng Lung Hsing," have been rescued while four Taiwanese crewmen remain missing despite a 72-hour search by Maritime police patrol boats.

Maritime police officer Kuo Chi-tsai said that the families of the missing crew members suspect there may have been a fight on the boat and that the three mainlanders might have killed the Taiwanese crew members and thrown their bodies into the sea.
Kuo said that the most urgent task now is to locate the missing Taiwanese crew members so as to help clear up the case.

He said that the maritime police have asked fishing boats operating in the Tungsha (Pratas) island group to help in the search effort. In addition, it is contacting the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to ask for Philippine and other foreign ships to join the search.
The Tungsha island group is located 240 nautical miles southwest of Taiwan's southern port city of Kaohsiung.
Cheng Lung Shing, a 19.35-ton tuna boat, was registered in Tungkang, Pingtung County. It went out to sea on Oct. 11, but was reported capsized northeast of the Tungsha island group on Sunday.

Taiwanese captain Lee Tsai-fa and the other three Taiwanese crew members went missing, while the three mainland crew members were rescued by a Kaohsiung fishing boat and later picked up by a maritime police patrol boat Friday.
Maritime police said the three mainland crew members were only slightly injured. The wound didn't appear linked to the possible scuffle on the boat, they added.
To ease the misgivings of the families of the Taiwanese crew members, maritime police are continuing their investigation.
The three mainland crew members will not be moved to a detention center for repatriation for the time being.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHIAYI QUAKE CAUSED BY MEISHAN FAULT SEPARATE FROM "921 QUAKE"

TEXT.P: The earthquake that hit Chiayi Friday morning was a separate quake and and neither an aftershock from the one that rattled central Taiwan on Sept. 21 nor a precursor to another major earthquake, said an official at the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) on Saturday.

In an attempt to allay public fears that another major shock is on the cards, Shin Tzai-chyn, deputy director-general of the CWB, said that the Friday quake, measuring 6.4 on the Richter scale, stemmed from the movement of the Meishan fault which runs from north to east through Chiayi.

This was substantiated by the fact that the compression wave detected by the CWB in Chiayi during the quake was in the same direction as the slip movement of the two blocks along the Meishan fault line.

He disputed the claims by some private seismologists that Friday's earthquake was an aftershock of the magnitude 7.6 earthquake of Sept. 21 which was triggered by the collision of blocks divided by the Chejungpu fault.
Hsin said that Friday's quake was the main shock rather than a minor precursor to a larger quake.

Hsin cited the fact that the temblor was followed by more than thirty minor shocks, at an average frequency of less than 10 per hour, measuring only between magnitude 3 and 4 on Richter scale, as proof that the movement of the blocks was subsiding quite rapidly.

Warning that spreading false information is punishable by a fine, Hsin urged the so-called private seismologists who have been active since the Sept. 21 quake not to cause public panic by issuing unsubstantiated tremor warnings.

DOC.HEADLINE: ABNORMAL PHENOMENA SEEN PRIOR TO QUAKE
DOC.DATELINE: Chiayi, southern Taiwan, Oct. 23 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Abnormal phenomena were witnessed in the days prior to the magnitude 6.4 earthquake that struck Chiayi county Friday, injuring 250 people and damaging dozens of structures, according to local sources.

A hunter in Shanmeitsun near Mt. Ali said he caught 13 pangolins without making any effort in the two days before the earthquake. The scaly ant eaters, which are usually seldom seen, were wandering about in the open by the roadside making them easy targets for the hunter.
Meanwhile, a farmer in Meishan County said he saw wild eels jumping out of a small brook when he was on his way to his rice paddy after dawn on Thursday, a phenomenon not seen in decades.
In Chiayi County's Chungpu Township, clear spring water has been seen coming from a normally black mud pool since early Friday morning.
The thick, slow flowing 120 square meter pond began springing forth black mud in July 1998 at the time when a magnitude 6 earthquake struck in nearby Meishan Township.
Residents in the neighborhood never realized how deep the pond was until a buffalo accidentally stepped into it, got stuck, and began sinking deeper until it disappeared under the surface.

In neighboring Tainan County's Houpi Township, a rice paddy was found to have water and fine black sand springing from it after the magnitude 6.4 earthquake hit Chiayi Friday. Several holes also appeared on a patch of dried and deserted land, sprouting out black water and mud, some to the height of an average man.

A senior villager said he saw a similar phenomenon in 1964 prior to and after a devastating quake hit Paiho, Tainan County. Some 200 people were killed and while numerous houses collapsed in that quake.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT$ 367 MILLION TO RECONSTRUCT SCHOOLS: PM SIEW

TEXT.P: It will take about NT$367 million (US$11.54 million) to reconstruct school buildings damaged by the devastating earthquake of Sept. 21 so that students can return to them to study, Premier Vincent Siew said on Saturday.
Siew called for private organizations to adopt or financially support schools in need so as to help facilitate the school reconstruction efforts.

Some 2,250 buildings and structures at primary and junior high schools in earthquake-stricken areas in central Taiwan were reported to be in need of repair or rebuilding at a total cost of NT$367 million.
So far, 76 schools have been adopted by business corporations and public interest groups.
Meanwhile, Siew noted, the central government will take the responsibility of reviewing the safety of school structures islandwide, freeing school authorities from the burden.
The central-government agency will also give "physical health checks" to all school structures islandwide if financially possible, Siew added.
Siew, who rushed to Chiayi Friday immediately after a magnitude 6.4 earthquake struck the southern county, continued his fact-finding tour of the area on Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: PENTAGON WARNS OF PLA MISSILE BUILDUP

TEXT.P: Mainland China is developing "one of the most daunting conventional theater missile challenges in the world which could have significant implications on regional stability," says a new Pentagon report.

The 40-page report, dealing mainly with the implications of mainland China's military modernization, has much discussion on the threat to Taiwan posed by the PRC's missile buildup. This includes a Beijing, having acquired an overwhelming offensive advantage, being more inclined to use force even if Taiwan does not declare de jure independence.
This in turn could lead Taiwan to seek stronger deterrents, including renewed efforts to develop a nuclear device.
It is believed that the PLA currently has deployed 150 to 200 short-range ballistic missiles opposite Taiwan and Western sources believe the number will increase to 650 over the next several years.

Conscious of likely US intervention, the PLA has indicated a willingness to use missiles against US targets, including key bases in Japan and aircraft carriers operating in the Western Pacific, the report says.

The report also says that ballistic missiles are emerging as the backbone of conventional PLA theater operations and that mainland China is concentrating on three systems- the short-range DF-15 (M-9), DF-11 (M-11) and the medium-range DF-21.
Currently the PLA is working on terminal guidance and missile defense countermeasures to improve the accuracy and lethality of these systems.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE UNIVERSITY STUDENT JOIN QUAKE RECONSTRUCTION EFFORT

TEXT.P: A group of 50 Japanese university students arrived in Taiwan on Saturday to help with reconstruction in earthquake-ravaged areas in central Taiwan.
The 50 students from Asia University drew public attention when they arrived at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in their trench coat uniforms on Saturday morning.
They were greeted there by Kuomintang officials and Miss Lien Hui-hsing, daughter of Vice President Lien Chan and the executive director of a foundation named after her grandfather Lien Chen-tung.
Lien shook hands with the students and expressed her thanks for their help in the reconstruction effort.

The students headed for Shenkang rural township in Taichung County Saturday afternoon. Their Taiwan contacts said they will help with the clean-up of the disaster area, removal of debris, cooking for refugees, and the mental rehabilitation of traumatized children during their one-week stay in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE OLYMPIC ORGANIZERS BRACE FOR PUBLIC BACKLASH

TEXT.P: Officials of the Sydney Organization for the Olympic Games Committee (SOCOG) are bracing for a public backlash over revelations that as few as one in 10 tickets to some of the best events would be made available to Australians in the first round ballot.

SOCOG board members on Friday told reporters that they were given a breakdown of tickets available for about six high-profile events, including the opening and closing ceremonies, and the swimming, basketball and gymnastics competitions.

They said the number of tickets allocated for the Australian public was below 10 percent while most of the tickets were to go to sponsors, the media, international patrons, VIPs, athletes, sports federations, International Olympic Committee members and premium ticket buyers who had been guaranteed access as part of contracts entered into many years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: `ONE COUNTRY, TWO SYSTEMS' HAS NO MARKET IN TAIWAN: MAC HEAD

TEXT.P: Mainland China's campaign for "one country, two systems" has no market in Taiwan, and the overwhelming majority of its citizens will not accept the model, said Su Chi, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), on Saturday.
He said that although mainland China is trying hard to promote the "one country, two systems" formula to the world, it has had little effect.
Su made the remarks when mainland China's President Jiang Zemin again presented the formula during his present European trip.
Su urged the international community to understand that communist rule is the cause of separate rule on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait over the past five decades.
Beijing has campaigned on a "one country, two systems" model to facilitate the takeover of Hong Kong and Macau mainly because the people of those places are not in favor of communism, said Su.
He also mentioned that the world is now aware that the Republic of China on Taiwan is crucially different from Hong Kong, having its own constitution, army, and foreign relations.

Su stressed that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait must unite under the principles of democracy, freedom and prosperity, saying that the gap between the two sides will only get wider if Beijing does not engage in political reforms.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL SHOWS MOST VOTERS DON'T WANT PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION POSTPONED

TEXT.P: A majority of the Taiwanese public does not approve of a postponement of the next presidential election scheduled for March 2000, an opinion poll showed.

The poll, designed to gauge public opinion in the "921 Earthquake's" aftermath, found that 58.3 percent of Taiwanese adults don't want the election postponed despite the fact that the quake dealt a heavy blow to Taiwan socially and financially.
Slightly more than 27 percent of the respondents said they think the election should be postponed to give the island time to heal.
The poll, conducted by National Sun Yat-sen University, also found that former Taiwan Governor James Soong still led four other hopefuls, with the support of 24.8 percent of respondents.

Soong was followed by the ruling Kuomintang's presidential candidate Vice President Lien Chan, backed by 20.9 percent of those interviewed. Trailing Lien was Chen Shui-bian, the candidate of the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), supported by 16.8 percent of interviewees.
Two other hopefuls, independents Li Ao and Hsu Hsin-liang, had a support rate of only 0.9 percent and 0.6 percent, respectively.
Thirty-six percent of the respondents said they were either undecided or had no comment.
Meanwhile, the poll found that Vice President Lien Chan is considered most likely to be elected as the next president of the Republic of China, with 39.1 percent of the respondents agreeing.
Lien was followed by Soong, with 27.2 percent of respondents and Chen with 6.3 percent. Twenty-seven point three percent of respondents gave no answer to this question.
The island-wide poll was conducted by telephone between Oct. 16 and 19 with 1,042 eligible voters.
The poll found that the Sept. 21 earthquake and related relief efforts in its aftermath had an impact on the prospects of the presidential candidates.

In a Sept. 5 poll, only 10 percent of the eligible voters said they would vote for Lien if the presidential election was held the following day. Thirty-three of the respondents said they would vote for former Governor James Soong while 23 percent said they would cast their vote for the DPP's Chen Shui-bian.

DOC.HEADLINE: FRENCH SEISMOLOGIST SUGGESTS TAIWAN ENHANCE BUILDING CONSTRUCTION
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, Oct. 22 (CNA) (By Tzou Ming-jhie and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Seismologist Jacques Angelier of France on Friday suggested Taiwan should list "solidity" as its top priority in its reconstruction of school buildings which collapsed during the killer earthquake that devastated the island on Sept. 21.
Angelier came to Taiwan in the wake of the quake to inspect tremor-stricken areas and to study the phenomenon of aftershocks.

During his three-week stay in central Taiwan, the area which sustained the heaviest quake damage, the seismologist said, he has found most buildings were actually endowed with certified anti-quake capability, except those that were jerry-built.

The bottom floors of many buildings constructed on a fault line either caved in or bulged out during the magnitude 7.6 earthquake, but they did not entirely collapse, Angelier said. He also noted that the fact that many school buildings in quake-devastated areas were severely damaged doesn't mean they were poorly constructed.

That the buildings were designed with large classrooms and wide corridors to allow sunlight to provide most of the lighting light sources was the reason for the reduction of their anti-quake capability, he postulated.
Because of this, he thinks "solidity" should be the major consideration as Taiwan begins its post-quake reconstruction, Angelier said.

In his analysis of the "921 Earthquake," the French seismologist said that the tremor was a movement of massive energy release by the "Tse Lung Pu" fault line, situated west of Taiwan's largest Central Range that extends from Suao in the north to Oluanpi in the south.

The energy had been accumulating below the Central Range for some 100 years, produced by a steady westward movement of the lower Philippine Sea plate into the thicker Eurasian plate, to which Taiwan is attached.

Angelier said he believes that the 100-kilometer-long Tse Lung Pu fault line will not produce any more devastating earthquakes in the wake of the one on Sep. 21, but the fault lines in the Miaoli and the Chianan plane possibly might in the future.

In fact, by being situated in the midst of tectonic plate movement, Taiwan can never be entirely safe from earthquake activity, the expert said, suggesting Taiwan make significant efforts to erect strong and solid structures with anti-quake capabilities.
Meanwhile, Angelier revealed that France will cooperate with the Taipei-based Academia Sinica in researching earthquakes on the island by providing advanced equipment and technology.

The destructive Sep. 21 temblor was recorded as Taiwan's largest of the century, claiming more than 2,300 lives and injuring over 100,000 people islandwide. Thousands buildings were either damaged or destroyed, leaving numerous people temporarily homeless.
On Friday another powerful earthquake of magnitude 6.4 jolted Chiayi, in southern Taiwan, resulting in more than 300 injuries.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINES TRYING TO RESTART AIR TALKS WITH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Philippine Foreign Undersecretary Franklin Abdalin is currently in Taipei trying to restart talks on resolving an air dispute which has halted direct flights between the two countries since early October.

Sources from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said that Abdalin, who flew into Taipei Thursday, has met with officials from the MOFA, the Civil Aeronautics Administration and Taiwan's two international carriers China Airlines and EVA Airways, for talks on a new air service agreement.
According to MOFA officials, representatives on the Taiwan side did not turn a cold shoulder to Abdalin, but they stressed that what Taiwan insists on would not be changed.

The Taiwan-Philippine air dispute began in late July when negotiations between the two sides on the 1996 air link accord broke down, with the latter threatening to suspend the agreement to force Taiwan to accept its demand for a reduction in the number of passengers allowed to be carried by Taiwan airlines.

Manila authorities also termed the Philippines' aviation accord with Taiwan as merely a "civil technical agreement" because of the absence of formal diplomatic relations between the two countries and that the "agreement" could be abolished under Philippine domestic law.
Manila wanted China Airlines and EVA Airways to restrict passengers to 3,000 per week, down from 9,600 during the pact.
Taipei responded by suspending quotas for Philippine laborers who could legally work in Taiwan.
The suspension has dealt a heavy blow to the Philippine government which has sustained widespread criticism from the Philippine private sector for its handling of the affair.
MOFA officials said a turnaround in the new-round of talks is possible if Manila puts forth proposals that could serve as a basis for further negotiations.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOCTOR SPECIALIZING IN FACIAL DEFECT BIDS FAREWELL

TEXT.P: Hundreds of patients and their families bid farewell to Dr. Samuel Noordhoff, the American doctor who specialized in treating a facial a defect, in Kaohsiung's Chang Gung Memorial Hospital.
Noordhoff, nicknamed "granddad" by all his cleft lip palate patients, and his wife, or "grandmom," were warmly received during the farewell party.
Noordhoff, who speaks fluent Taiwanese, said he was most gratified to see the patients with cleft lip palate coming out of the shadows to take their place in society.
He thanked everybody for the kind assistance he received over the past four decades, saying that he and his wife will always cherish the memories of that time.
Noordhoff said that although he will retire to his home country on November 12, he will still take time out to occasionally come back to see his friends in Taiwan.

Noordhoff came from his hometown in Michigan to practice medicine in Taiwan in 1949. He first served as the president of Mackay Memorial Hospital. At that time, he helped solicit donations totaling US$5000,000 to bring the hospital back from the brink of closure and begin the development that would bring it up to its present day scale.
He also helped established the Mackay nursing school and was the first president of Chang Gung Memorial Hospital. He now holds the position of permanent emeritus president of the hospital.
He also established the Noordhoff Craniofacial Foundation in 1989, and has so far treated nearly 10,000 patients with the facial defect.

Another farewell party for the couple will be held in Taipei on November 3, during which the Department of Health is scheduled to give the doctor a medal in recognition of his contribution to the people of Taiwan over the past 40 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE RECEIVES HIGHEST APPROVAL FOR HANDLING QUAKE

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui was the government official most recognized by the public for his handling of relief efforts in the wake of the Sept. 21 earthquake, according to a survey released on Saturday.
The survey conducted by the National Sun Yat-sun University in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan showed that more than 51 percent of those interviewed were satisfied with Lee's performance,
Trailing closely behind was Vice President Lien Chan, with an approval rating of 48.1 percent.

Premier Vincent Siew received the approval of 33.8 percent of those interviewed, while Nantou County Magistrate Peng Pai-hsien received 37.2 percent approval and Taichung County Magistrate Liao Yung-lai got 33.7 percent. Taichung and Nantou were the areas hardest-hit by the quake.

In comparing the responses of the different levels of government, the central government's approval rating was 49.1 percent while the local government's was 40.7 percent, with the Taichung County Government receiving a 35.1 percent approval rating and the Nantou County government getting 36.1 percent.

In the category of political parties, the ruling Kuomintang, which controls the central government was approved by 45.3 percent of respondents, while the Democratic Progressive party, which runs the counties of Taichung and Nantou lagged far behind at 23.2 percent. The New Party and the Independence Party got approval ratings of 12.3 percent and 6.4 percent, respectively.

Ironically, the performance of the mass media, widely criticized by the public for hindering research and rescue efforts by posting huge flocks of reporters at disaster scenes won the approval of 63.1 percent of the respondents.
About 92.7 percent of the respondents praised the volunteer work of the general public after the quake.
The survey was conducted by face-to-face interviews with 1,042 adults around Taiwan between Oct. 16 and 19.

DOC.HEADLINE: LET PEOPLE FREELY CHOOSE THEIR LEADER, SAYS SOONG

TEXT.P: Allowing people to make political choices free from fear is an important democratic principle, former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong said on Saturday.

Soong made the remark when commenting on reports that the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) was prohibiting party members from joining the signature sponsoring activity aimed at collecting the required number of signatures to allow him to run in the 2000 presidential election as an independent.
Independent candidates must collect at least 224,429 signatures to qualify to run for president in the 2000 election.

Earlier in the year, the KMT leadership had hesitated in accepting party members' call to invite Soong to be the running mate of Lien Chan. Soong announced on July 15 that he would run for the presidency as an independent.
The KMT on Aug. 29 formally put forth its Lien (Chan)-(Vincent) Siew ticket for the presidential election.

The KMT Central Standing Committee had originally planned to finalize its disciplinary measures against Soong at its weekly meeting on Sept. 22 but temporarily shelved them when the earthquake struck on Sep. 21.

Denying the KMT's claim that support for the party-nominated candidate by its members is a matter of course, Soong said that in a democratic society, people should be able to freely choose their representatives.

Soong has been receiving the highest approval ratings among the candidates in a series of recent polls. He thanked his supporters for their support and expressed that he will do his best to have the people's choice truly reflect their voice.

DOC.HEADLINE: WILD BIRD FESTIVAL OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Members of 18 wild bird societies in Taiwan and numerous foreign bird lovers from around the world gathered at a wildlife preservation park in Kuantu, suburban Taipei, on Saturday to join in the opening of an international wild bird festival.

The two-day festival was jointly sponsored by the Taipei City Government, Hotai Motor Corp. and the Taipei Wild Bird Society (TWBS) to invite people to appreciate the natural beauty of the various migratory birds that fly to Kuantu from Siberia every year.

The gray heron was the featured bird at this festival, according to the TWBS, which stated that the activity is aimed at inspiring public respect for the Earth and all the life forms which inhabit it.
Around 7,000 wild migratory birds are now residing at coastal areas in Kuantu, including hundreds of dunlins that usually gather at marshes.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOONG SELLS AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS AT BAZAAR FOR QUAKE VICTIMS

TEXT.P: Former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong on Saturday attended a bazaar held to raise funds for victims of the 921 earthquake.
Hawking at the bazaar held at the Ta An Park in Taipei, Soong marketed vegetables and fruits produced in quake-stricken zones.

The independent 2000 presidential election candidate stressed that after having helped victims deal with the immediate problems caused in the wake of the quake, the most important thing now is to assist them in re-establishing their livelihood. Only when this issue is solved, can post-quake reconstruction be truly complete, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER ON 10-DAY VISIT TO LATIN AMERICA
