TEXT.P: The Republic of China's Foreign Minister Jason Hu, accompanied by a group of 20 entrepreneurs from Taiwan, departed Saturday evening for Latin America for a 10-day visit to the Dominican Republic and Panama.

Hu said at the airport that on behalf of President Lee Teng-hui he would extend the heartiest appreciation to President Leonel Fernandez of the Dominican Republic and President Mireya Moscoso of Panama for their concern over the Taiwanese people after a killer earthquake jolted Taiwan on Sept. 21.
The minister added that he would also discuss with ranking government officials of the two countries to seek cooperation possibilities.

In Panama, Hu will sign an agreement with the Panamanian government on exchange of voluntary workers. It is expected that these voluntary workers can contribute in expanding trade and agricultural cooperation between the two countries.

Referring to the large business group accompanying him in the 10-day trip, Hu emphasized the importance of economic and trade cooperation in the ROC's external relations. He said the entrepreneurs will study investment environment in the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Oct. 24, or the 16th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1632: Antonie van Leeuwenhoek, Dutch microscopist who was the first man to see bacteria, is born.
1648: France and the Holy Roman Empire sign the Treaty of Westphalia, ending the Thirty Years' War.
1861: The chief justice of California sends the first US transcontinental telegram from San Francisco to President Abraham Lincoln in Washington.
1891: Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina, dictator of the Dominican Republic from 1930 until his assassination on May 31, 1961, is born.
1901: Mrs. Ann Edison Taylor, 43, a teacher, is unhurt after going over Niagara Falls in a padded barrel to help pay the mortgage.
1908: Taiwan's West Coast Railway Trunk Line from Keelung to Kaohsiung is opened to traffic. An inauguration ceremony is held at the Taichung Park.
1922: The Irish parliament adopts a constitution for an Irish Free State.
1929: Share prices collapse as nearly 13 million shares change hands in panic selling on the New York Stock Exchange in what became known as "Black Thursday."
1931: Notorious Chicago gangster Al Capone, who has dominated organized crime for the past six years, receives an 11-year sentence and an $80,000 fine for tax evasion.
1931: The Council of the League of Nations adopts a resolution urging Japan to withdraw its troops from Northeast China by Nov. 16.
1937: Jean Batten, New Zealand aviator, breaks the record by flying from Australia to England in just five days, 18 hours, and 18 minutes.
1944: The Japanese battleship "Musashi," one of the largest ever built, is sunk by US planes during the Battle of Leyte Gulf.
1945: The United Nations Charter, adopted by the San Francisco Conference in June 1945 and ratified by 26 nations, formally comes into force.
1945: Vidkun Quisling, former head of the "puppet" government established in Norway by the Nazis in 1940, is executed at Akershus Fortress in Oslo.
1957: Christian Dior, French fashion designer, dies at the age of 52. He was noted for his "New Look" of 1947 that emphasized narrow shoulders, tight waists, and long, full skirts.
1960: Communist China and Mali establish diplomatic ties.
1964: Northern Rhodesia becomes independent from Britain as the Republic of Zambia with Kenneth Kaunda as president.
1976: Chiang Ching, who was dragged from her bedroom by armed guards on Oct. 6 and charged with treason, finds the going rough now that her late husband Mao Tse-tung is no longer around to protect her.
1986: Cheng Tsai-tien, 26, a communist Chinese pilot, lands his MiG-19 jet fighter in South Korea from mainland China's Shantung peninsula to seek asylum in the Republic of China.
1989: Jim Baker, American television preacher, is sentenced to 45 years in jail and fined US$500,000 for swindling his followers out of millions of dollars.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Sunday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The government will finance an estimated NT$36.7 billion to repair and rebuild school buildings damaged by Sept. 21 earthquake and Friday's jolt in Chiayi.
The China Times:
The government will take over the construction of school buildings.
The United Daily News:
The government will finance NT$36.7 billion to improve school buildings.
The Liberty Times:
National defense law draft stipulates that the government can carry out mobilization after the President proclaims the emergency decree.
@The Commons Daily:
Taiwan Independence Party will issue a controversial lottery to solicit funds for the presidential election next March.
The China Post:
Chiayi residents pitch tents after quake.
The Taiwan News:
That shaky feeling: how the quake has stressed people and how people can cope.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO ADOPT MEASURES TO HELP TOURISM INDUSTRY: LIEN

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan said the government will adopt several measures to assist the domestic tourism industry in the wake of the devastating Sept. 21 earthquake.

Lien made the remarks Sunday when he attended a seminar sponsored by the domestic tourism industry to seek methods for revitalization following the deadly temblor. Tourism Bureau officials were also invited to the seminar.

Tourism industry officials noted that the killer quake has dealt a serious blow to the industry -- not only did the number of foreign visitors coming to Taiwan plummet, but domestic and outbound tourism also suffered.
They said the hotel, entertainment, restaurant and bus tour industries have all been in the throes of business decline, which they said has threatened the livelihood of those in the tourism industry.

Stanley C. Yen, president of the Taiwan Tourism Association, said that though the epicenter of the deadly temblor was located in central Taiwan, its effect has been felt islandwide, and the subsequent downturn in tourism was inevitable.

Yen noted that more than 90 percent of foreign tour groups abandoned plans to travel to Taiwan after the quake. Up to 210,000 air travelers canceled their bookings, and the occupancy rate of domestic hotels plunged from the usual 90 percent to between 30 and 40 percent.
Yen expressed the hope that the government will help the domestic industry get back on its feet.

Lien, after listening to the concerns of the tourism industry, noted that he was struck by the extent of damage caused by the massive quake, saying that he had visited more than 200 quake-stricken areas since the deadly temblor last month.

But he also said that many of the collapsed houses in the stricken areas have been demolished, and the assembly of prefabricated housing units and the distribution of relief payments are now nearly complete, which he believed is quite a remarkable feat by the government.
Lien said people should not dwell on the gloomy shadow of the jolt, which claimed the lives of more than 2,400 and caused extensive damages, but should look to the future and rebuild.

Lien said he would ask the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and the Government Information Office to jointly promote tourism, targeting the United States, Japan and Europe, the traditional sources of Taiwan's tourist market.

As the sight of collapsed houses and rubble left by the quake is no longer visible, Lien said that domestic tourism should be put back on track gradually and that residents of the island should be encouraged to again visit scenic spots in central Taiwan.
Lien also mentioned Sun Moon Lake, saying that few other places can match the breathtaking beauty of the mountain lake, adding that the Tourism Bureau should make an overall plan for the area.

Noting that the Ministry of Economic Affairs will offer NT$50 billion (US$1.57 billion) in long-term low-interest loans to small- and medium-sized industries, Lien said he will suggest that the government also provide such loans to the tourism industry to help it tide over during this difficult period.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOTED CHILEAN EDUCATOR GERARDO ROCHA ARRIVES FOR WEEK-LONG VISIT

TEXT.P: Gerardo Rocha, rector of the University of Santo Tomas in Chile, flew into Taipei on Sunday for a week-long visit at the invitation of the Ministry of Education.
Rocha, also board chairman of the International Council for Universities of Santo Tomas, will be received by President Lee Teng-hui, whom he will invite to accept honorary membership in the council.

Rocha will also call on government officials and the rectors of Providence University, Fu Jen Catholic University, Tamkang University and Tunghai University to discus educational cooperation problems with them.

The international council, at its third convention, held in Canada last September, had decided to invite Lee to become an honorary member of the council in recognition of his great achievements in academia and politics.
Rocha will also attend a seminar on China and traditional Eastern philosophy sponsored by Providence University.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER TO VISIT SANTO DOMINGO ON MONDAY
DOC.DATELINE: Panama, Oct. 23 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Minister Jason Hu, accompanied by his wife and a group of 20 entrepreneurs, will arrive in the Dominican Republic Monday for a three-day official visit to that Caribbean country.

During his stay in Santo Domingo, Hu will call on President of the Dominican Republic Leonel Fernandez and Hu's counterpart Eduardo Latorre to exchange views on economic and trade cooperation between the two countries.
Hu will also attend the ground-breaking ceremony of a science technology park, to be held on Oct. 27.
According to official statistics, the Republic of China enjoyed a US$10 million trade surplus with the Dominican Republic in 1998.
Hu and ROC entrepreneurs will also visit two export processing zones and one industrial park to feel out investment possibilities.
Hu will proceed from Santo Domingo to Panama on Wednesday for a three-day visit, while the entrepreneurs will continue on to visit Haiti Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: RELATIONS BETWEEN ROC AND PANAMA ARE VERY STABLE: JASON HU

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister of the Republic of China Jason Hu flew to New York Saturday night for a one-day stopover before continuing on to the Dominican Republic for a three-day official visit.
At a press conference held at Newark Airport, Hu told the media that relations between Panama and the Republic of China were very stable.

He went on to say that Beijing's intention to hurt the diplomatic relations that the ROC has maintained with foreign countries has remained unchanged. "We, the ROC, can not relax our efforts and should sincerely and substantially enhance our relations with our friendly countries," he stressed.

Responding to questions raised by the press over why the ROC government has still not decided what kind of high-ranking official to send to the Panama Canal Transition Ceremony scheduled for Dec. 14 in Panama, Hu said that the Panamanian government has not yet extended its invitation.

Some Americans have expressed deep concern over Beijing's influence regarding the Panama Canal, following the US transfer of canal administration to Panama after the Hong Kong-based Hutchison Group won administrative rights over Baboa Port at the canal's Pacific-entry end and Colon Port on the Atlantic side.

Hu said that Beijing should conduct a self-examination and review why everyone has shown a lack of confidence in Beijing when approaching the mainland government. The free world has expressed concern over rights for using the Panama Canal, with the hope that the canal would not be contaminated by political interests, Hu noted.

He said his upcoming trip to the Dominican Republic is to return an ROC visit that President Leonel Fernandez made last month after the massive earthquake to personally express deep concern from the government and people of the Dominican Republic to victims of the Sept. 21 temblor.

The earthquake had an impact on several ROC-Dominican Republic cooperative projects, Hu said, adding that the ROC government decided to send him and experts to the Dominican Republic to help realize a proposed science technology park in that Caribbean country.

Hu, accompanied by a group of 20 entrepreneurs, will leave New York for Santo Domingo on Monday. From the Dominican Republic he will proceed to Panama on Wednesday for a three-day official visit. (Romulo Huang & Edward Chen)

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJOR AFTERSHOCKS STRIKE CENTRAL TAIWAN

TEXT.P: At least five major aftershocks rocked central Taiwan Saturday night and Sunday morning, after an earthquake, measuring 6.4 on the Richter scale, hit the region Friday morning.

The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said aftershocks measuring 5.2, 4.2, 5.1 and 4.8 hit the Chiayi area on Sunday at 1:42 a.m., 2:29 a.m., 5:53 a.m. and 11:07 a.m., respectively; another at magnitude 4.9 struck the Nantou area at 10:39 a.m.
No casualties or major property damage from the aftershocks was reported, the CWB said.
A total of 13,307 aftershocks have rocked central Taiwan since the killer Sept. 21 earthquake, as of 4:00 p.m. Sunday, said the CWB.
Meanwhile, 290 aftershocks have hit the Chiayi area since the magnitude-6.4 earthquake rattled the Chiayi-Tainan area Friday.
The number of hourly aftershocks has since declined to a single-digit figure, the CWB added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO MARK 54TH TAIWAN RETROCESSION DAY TOMORROW IN TAICHUNG

TEXT.P: The Republic of China will mark the 54th anniversary of Taiwan Retrocession Day on Monday at a ceremony to be held at the National Taichung Library in Taichung with Governor Chao Shou-po presiding.
Due to the impact of the devastating 921 earthquake, the annual gala cocktail reception will be called off this year.
Taiwan returned to the Republic of China's jurisdiction in 1945 after having been under the control of Japan for 50 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREST WORKER HAS BRIEF ENCOUNTER WITH BLACK BEAR

TEXT.P: A man who works for a central Taiwan forest recreation area was reported in good condition in hospital on Sunday, one day after he was attacked by a black bear.

Cheng Chen-chung, a lanky 48-year-old of medium height who belongs to the Ami tribe of Taitung County, said, "I thought I would definitely die when I saw the huge animal charging at me with its mouth open and fangs glistening with saliva." He spoke to the press from his hospital bed at a medical facility in Tunghsih, Taichung County.
Cheng, currently employed by Tahsueshan (Great Snow Mountain) Forest Recreation Area in Taichung County, recalled the frightening experience of his brief encounter with the black bear.
Cheng said that he was on his way down the mountain after he and his partner had finished cutting weeds near Tienchi (Lake in the Sky) Saturday morning.

Cheng said he was walking far behind his partner when he heard a noise that sounded like animals in the brush drinking from a pond. He didn't pay much attention, as he was trying to catch up with his partner. But then he heard some footsteps in the bushes behind him, and, thinking it was a wild dog lurking about, he turned around to find the large black animal right in front of him.
He instinctively used the weed-cutting machine he was carrying to strike the bear, which was standing erect at about 160 cm in height.

Cheng said the black bear charged directly at him and pushed him to the ground by the pond. With the animal's two large paws clutching his shoulders, and bear biting at his jaw, Cheng thought he would die, but somehow managed to summon all his strength and punch the bear in the face, which frightened it off, along with a small cub that was nearby.
Cheng's jaw was ripped open, and he suffered injury to his left calf, requiring three hours of surgery.
Doctors said Cheng was very fortunate -- if the wound at his jaw had been two centimeters deeper, it would have reached an artery, and his life would have been in grave danger.

Officials of the forest recreation area pointed out that the attack, which took place near the famous scenic spot of Tienchi, 2,300 meters above sea level, was unusual because black bears have not been seen there since the opening of Tahsueshan recreation area.

They noted that they were surprised to learn of black bears in the area, saying that after the magnitude-7.3 earthquake on Sept. 21, traffic to the recreation area had been disrupted for three weeks, and roads only became clear more than a week ago.
Black bears may have tried to move to lower elevations because of the recent lack of visitors, they said.

They noted that black bears are very sensitive animals that usually stay in the high mountainous areas. The officials would not rule out the possibility that the bears might have come down because their living environment changed or because they feel uneasy in the wake of the earthquake.
They said a group of experts will go the area for a field study to learn more about the ecological situation of the area.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD STATIONERY AND GIFT ITEMS AUTUMNAL SHOW OPENS MONDAY

TEXT.P: The World Stationery and Gift Items Autumnal Exhibition organized by the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) will open Monday at the Taipei World Trade Center Exhibition Hall with more than 1,006 manufacturers and traders from home and abroad participating.
An official of CETRA said the exhibition will center on the demonstration of individual character and concepts of environmental protection.
Seventy-one manufacturers and traders from 14 countries will take part in the four-day exhibition which will close on Thursday.
Those foreign traders come from Hong Kong, Sri Lanka, India, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, Switzerland, Thailand, Britain, and the United States.
Admission will be allowed only for foreign buyers and related businessmen, the CETRA official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO ISSUE LOTTERY TICKETS FEATURING QUAKE-RELIEF EFFORT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Finance (MOF) will issue lottery tickets featuring quake-relief efforts in the wake of the massive earthquake last month, Bank of Taiwan said on Sunday.

Bank of Taiwan, which was commissioned by the MOF to issue the lottery tickets, said that the MOF has selected a set of pictures connected with earthquake relief efforts to represent the lottery's theme.
Bank officials noted that one picture showing the army taking an active part in the quake-relief effort is most likely to be chosen.

The officials noted that after the devastating Sept. 21 temblor, which claimed more than 2,400 lives and caused extensive damage in Taiwan, the army was mobilized to provide all kinds of assistance and has won accolades from people representing all walks of life.
The officials said the MOF and the bank, after careful consideration, decided to choose quake-relief as the theme of the lottery.
The much-anticipated lottery tickets are scheduled to be issued in early December.

DOC.HEADLINE: 97% OF SMALL- AND MID-SIZE MANUFACTURERS IN QUAKE AREAS BACK ON TRACK

TEXT.P: Ninety-seven percent of small- and medium-sized industries in quake-stricken areas in central Taiwan have resumed production one month after the devastating earthquake, a survey conducted by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) showed on Sunday.

MOEA officials said that the figure showed the resilience of small- and medium-sized industries in Taichung and Nantou counties, two of the counties hit hardest by the magnitude-7.3 earthquake on Sept. 21.

The survey found that about 40 percent of the manufacturers suffered varying degrees of losses during the massive temblor, but 83 percent of them resumed production within two weeks, and 97 percent resumed production in a month.
Losses of machinery equipment and inventory in central Taiwan are slight, the survey found, with initial losses estimated at US$300 million.

The areas that suffered severe damages during the temblor are the Nankang Industrial District Administrative Center in Nantou County, the Tali Industrial Administrative Station and the Taiping Industrial Zone. The majority of manufacturers suffered losses ranging up to US$30,000.

The survey found that only 28 buildings in the Nankang Industrial District Administrative Center and a mere three buildings in the Tali Industrial Administrative Station require demolition, adding that they have now resumed full production to avoid the losses of orders to other countries.

The survey said that though export manufacturers have seen some delay in meeting delivery dates in the wake of the temblor, the delays, usually between two and four weeks, have not caused the losses of orders.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEMOCRATIZATION OF CHINA MAY HELP UNIFICATION: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The democratization of communist China will make the task of national unification between Taiwan and the mainland easier, a high-ranking official from Taipei said here Saturday.

Chang Jung-kung, director of the ruling Kuomintang Department of Mainland Research, said at a meeting of overseas Chinese in New York that there has been a sharp contrast in democratization between Taiwan and mainland China.

He said that, Taiwan has developed into a full democracy, while mainland China has been in a quagmire of socialism. "In fact, communist China is trying to save socialism at the expense of its people and society," he said, adding that the government in Beijing is afraid of free elections.
"A political party, which is unable to lead in peaceful evolution, will have to face the danger of violent change," Chang stressed.

The Democratization of mainland China is important to the maintenance of peace in both the Taiwan Strait area and the Asian Pacific area, and is conducive to national unification between Taiwan and the mainland, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 127 FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS PASS Y2K COMPUTER TEST

TEXT.P: A total of 127 financial institutions islandwide on Sunday completed Y2K inter-banking computer systems tests, the results of which satisfied Finance Minister Paul Chiu and assured those taking part in the tests that Taiwanese financial institutions are able to get through the Y2K challenge.

Chiu visited the headquarters of the Bank of Taiwan and Land Bank of Taiwan on Sunday morning to supervise inter-branch and inter-bank computer systems trial tests. He personally tested computer connection functions using an Automatic Teller Machine (ATM), and supervised use of tellers' computers to conduct transactions relating to savings, cash withdrawals and wiring money. All of the functions worked well.

Chiu, while hailing the positive results of the tests, attributed the success to long-term efforts by the banking industry and urged the industry to continue to engage in relevant work to prevent any Y2K computer failure.
The Ministry of Finance has demanded that all financial institutions complete a set of emergency measures to combat Y2K problems by the end of November.
The final trial tests of inter-branch and inter-bank computer systems must be finished by Dec. 26, Chiu added.

Taiwan's financial institutions started working on potential Y2K problems with inter-banking systems in 1997, and the systems have passed tests and have been recognized internationally. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: 13,000 FALUNGONG PRACTITIONERS SEND LETTER TO BEIJING LEADERS

TEXT.P: More than 13,000 practitioners of the banned Falungong sect in mainland China jointly sent an open letter to mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin and Premier Zhu Rongqi last week, a human rights group said here Sunday.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China said that, in the letter they asked the government to lift the ban on Falungong and on the books authored by its founder Li Hongzi. They also asked the government to allow them to practice Falungong in public places.

They also said in the letter that Falungong is not a "pernicious cult" as government propaganda has characterized it. It is a kind of traditional Chinese qigong, which combines meditation and breathing techniques together for daily practice. It is estimated that there are millions of Falungong practitioners on the Chinese mainland. Falungong is also the name of the organization founded by Li.
The government banned Falungong in July, believing that the huge but amorphous organization may destabilize the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: PICKUP TRUCK OVERTURNS, KILLING 1 AND INJURING 21
DOC.DATELINE: Chiayi, southern Taiwan, Oct. 25 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: One person was killed and 21 injured when a pickup truck for tea leaf picking overturned and fell into a valley beside an industrial road in Alishan, Chiayi County on Monday morning.
Chen Su-ying, a tea leaf picking woman, died at the accident site. Ten of the 21 people who were injured in the accident suffered seriously wounds.
All the injured persons were rushed to Chiayi Christian Hospital for treatment.
According to one of the passengers, the truck overturned while she was talking to the driver.
Investigation into the cause of the accident is still underway.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW INDONESIAN PRESIDENT OUTLINES CHANGES IN FOREIGN POLICY

TEXT.P: Indonesia's newly elected President Abdurrahman Wahid indicated a shift in his country's foreign policy away from traditional allies like the US and Australia toward mainland China, Japan and other Asian countries.
Wahid said he planned to visit China and other Asian countries within weeks, signaling a shift in emphasis away from the United States, Australia and other Western nations.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN OFFICIAL WARNS AGAINST 'YES' VOTE IN REFERENDUM

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Alexander Downer, a monarchist advocate, has warned that Australia's ability to take a major role in Asia and the Pacific region could be undermined in the longer term if voters support the flawed republic model on offer in the November 6 referendum.
Australian people are to vote either "yes" for their country to become a republic with a president elected by two thirds of parliament or "no" and thereby maintaining the present political system.
Downer on Sunday said on Sunday that Australia's reputation for stability contributed to its high standing around the world and that a cut in ties with the UK could jeopardize that reputation.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA HAS PLAYED MAJOR ROLE IN CHANGING ASIA

TEXT.P: Australia has played a major role in Asia as the face of region's political map has changed, according to the Sydney Morning Herald.
The region has recently weathered a major financial crisis, the birth of a new nation in East Timor and a change of leadership in Indonesia.
Throughout these changes, Australia has been in the forefront of international efforts to help the region, according to the daily.

DOC.HEADLINE: PENTAGON WARNS OF PLA MISSILE BUILDUP

TEXT.P: Mainland China is developing "one of the most daunting conventional theater missile challenges in the world... which could have significant implications for regional stability", according to a Pentagon report completed in September.

The report, titled "The PLA's Strategic War Fighting in the 21st Century: Space and Theater Missile Development," deals mainly with the implications of mainland China's theater missile development as a major focus of the PLA's modernization.
The 40-page report contains a lot of discussion on the threat to Taiwan posed by the mainland's missile buildup and possible countermeasures.

"In the most likely scenario for their use," the report says, "the PLA's (People's Liberation Army's) growing arsenal of highly accurate and lethal theater missiles, and a preemptive doctrine could give Beijing a decisive edge in any future conflict with Taiwan."

The danger of this is that the Beijing leadership, having acquired an overwhelming offensive advantage, might be more inclined to use force even if Taiwan does not declare de jure independence. This in turn could lead Taiwan to seek stronger deterrents, including renewed efforts to develop a nuclear device, says the report.

The report also points out that, as Taiwan's national security community debates the need for a stronger deterrent, there may be increased domestic pressure for tactically offensive counter force operations, to include preemptive strikes.

In the section which details operational concepts associated with a possible PLA theater missile campaign, the report says that mainland China would seek to quickly strip Taiwan of its war fighting capability.
The PLA would try to achieve air superiority, sea superiority and information dominance by large-scale, preemptive missile strikes carried out in conjunction with air strikes and special operations.
The report quoted PLA writings as saying that half of its theater missile inventory would be used in the initial strike phase.
It is believed that the PLA currently has deployed 150 to 200 short-range ballistic missiles opposite Taiwan and Western sources believe the number would increase to 650 over the next several years.

Conscious of likely US intervention, the PLA has indicated a willingness to use missiles against US targets, including key bases in Japan and aircraft carriers operating in the Western Pacific, the report says.

For Taiwan to counter a large-scale theater missile threat, the report says, the only effective way is "through jointness and innovative war fighting concepts" associated with the Revolution in Military Affairs.

The report says that ballistic missiles are emerging as the backbone of conventional PLA theater operations and mainland China is concentrating on three particular systems, namely the short-range DF-15 (M-9), DF-11 (M-11) and the medium-range DF-21.
Currently the PLA is working on terminal guidance and missile defense countermeasures to improve the accuracy and lethality of these systems.

Also, the PLA's first-generation land attack cruise missiles could be operational early in the next century. These missiles, probably air-launched, will be more accurate, more difficult to defend and less costly to make than ballistic missiles.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD MAKE ITS OWN DECISIONS, SAYS WEINBERGER

TEXT.P: Former US Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said Monday in Taipei that Taiwan should make its own decisions and the United States has the obligation to help Taiwan with its defense capabilities.

Weinberger, in his capacity as chairman of the biweekly business magazine Forbes, is currently on a two-day visit to Taipei. In a meeting with the local press, he voiced his concern about Taiwan's status and also made an appraisal of Taiwan's ability to weather a crisis.

Emphasizing America's commitment to Taiwan's self defense, Weinberger said that during the missile crisis in the Taiwan Straits in 1996 President Clinton was right to deploy two air-craft carriers. In line with the spirit and letter of the Taiwan Relations Act, "we would not tolerate any attack against Taiwan," said the former defense secretary, who served as chairman of the board of the USA-ROC Economic Council between 1991 and 1994.

Weinberger, together with 22 other leading US conservatives and foreign policy experts, in late August signed a statement calling on the US government "to deter any form of Chinese intimidation of the Republic of China on Taiwan and declare unambiguously that it will come to Taiwan's defense in the event of an attack or blockade against Taiwan."

In Taipei, the military and foreign affairs expert again stressed the importance of the US government clarifying the situation regarding supplying the ROC with defensive weapons and fulfilling its obligations to Taiwan's security.

While some observers of international affairs have suggested that the American administration has applied ambiguity in its China policy to maintain the cross-strait status quo, Weinberger said that President Clinton during his 1998 trip to mainland China broke that ambiguity and adopted mainland China's position.
Describing Clinton's concessions to Beijing as a "disaster," Weinberger said that after June 1998, the Clinton administration's policy of "ambiguity" has been favorable to mainland China.
Weinberger has been visiting Taiwan as publisher and business executive of Forbes almost once a year and has constantly familiarized himself with Taiwan's various developments.
When asked to comment on the controversial "state-to-state" theory, Weinberger said that it only stated a fact and was nothing new. "It is a restatement, not an outcry," as he sees it.
Believing that the will of the people of Taiwan should be honored, Weinberger said "I hope the situation in Taiwan will change when the people want it to change."

The publisher and columnist was also concerned about the Sept. 21 killer earthquake's impact on Taiwan's economy. Recognizing Taiwan's restoration capabilities, Weinberger expressed his optimism that Taiwan would accomplish its reconstruction very quickly.
Weinberger arrived for his two-day visit Monday morning accompanied by Forbes Vice Chairman Christopher Forbes and Managing Director for Asia William P. Adamopoulos.

During his stay, he will call on President Lee Teng-hui and Premier Vincent Siew, Director-general Chen Chien-jen of the Government Information Office and Vice Chairman Wu Kuan-hsiung of the China External Trade Development Council.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1999 JOBLESSNESS RATE PREDICTED TO SET RECORD

TEXT.P: Taiwan's unemployment rate is expected to set a record high of more than 2.91 percent for the whole of 1999, the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) reported on Monday.

As the island's joblessness rate already averaged at around 2.92 percent during the first nine months of this year, the figure for the whole year is likely to surpass the previous record high of 2.91 set in 1985, the DGBAS said.
Taiwan's unemployment rate maintained its high level in September following the Sept. 21 earthquake, the worst to hit the island in one hundred years, according to the DGBAS.
It added that the number of employed workers declined by 53,000 from August to 9.37 million in September, while the number of jobless workers hit around 298,000 at the end of last month.

In the short term, the jobs of around 125,000 workers will be negatively affected by the earthquake, the DGBAS analyzed, noting that and an additional 43,000 people were already forced to temporarily leave their workplaces last month due to the disastrous results of the massive temblor.

Since the country's economic situation will still be the leading factor in job creation in the coming three months, the DGBAS said Taiwan's 1999 employment rate is very likely to break the 1985 record.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN INAUGURATES MEMORIAL MONUMENT TO MARK TAIWAN'S RETROCESSION DAY

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan on Monday presided over the inauguration of a memorial monument in downtown Taipei to mark the 54th anniversary of the Republic of China's victory over Japan and the return of Taiwan to its fold.
Taiwan's Retrocession Day, falling on Oct. 25, marks the return of the island to the ROC after 50 years of Japanese colonial rule.
The monument is located in front of Chungshan Hall, right on the spot where the Japanese army officially surrendered control of the island to the ROC army in 1945.

Delivering an emotional speech during the dedication ceremony, Lien said that people tend to forget too easily their shared history, and that if such shared experiences and memories are lost, the feelings that connect the people of this land will also be lost.

Lien said that this was the reason why he actively promoted the building of the memorial monument four years ago when he served concurrently as Premier. He hopes that it will evoke shared memories about the land among citizens, whether they came here earlier or later.

The vice president also said that over the past month, the people of Taiwan have experienced unprecedented trauma due to the massive earthquake that struck Sep. 21, but he noted that the killer jolt has rekindled a brotherly feeling among the people, which he said had been fast disappearing from this land.

Lien expressed the hope that in the long reconstruction period ahead, the local people will continue to display the "Taiwanese spirit," which is characterized by resilience, confidence and solidarity, just like their forebears did.
Lien's speech received an enthusiast response from the audience.

Lin Cheng-chih, chairman of the cabinet-level Council for Cultural Affairs, said Lien's speech was significant in that he used the post-quake suffering and the history of Taiwan's retrocession to invoke brotherly feelings among the people.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN MARKS 50TH ANNIVERSARY OF VICTORY IN BATTLE OF KUNINGTOU

TEXT.P: The Kinmen Defense Command on Monday observed the 50th anniversary of victory in the Battle of Kuningtou with a ceremony to worship the servicemen killed in the battle.

The ceremony was presided over by Lt. Gen. Chu Kai-sheng, commander of the Kinmen Defense Command, and was attended by more than 300 representatives from all walks of life who live on the Republic of China's anti-Communist frontline island.

More than 20,000 Chinese Communist troops sailed across the sea to land at Kuningtou, northwestern Kinmen, to invade the isle on Oct. 25, 1949, in an attempt to occupy the Kuomintang-held island to pave the way for "washing Taiwan with blood."
After three days of fierce fighting, all the Communist troops had been killed or captured by Kuomintang troops, laying the foundation for security across the Taiwan Strait 50 years into the future.
Chu offered incense, laid a wreath, and led ceremony participants to bow and pay tribute to those servicemen killed in the Battle of Kuningtou.
Following the ceremony, Chu shook hands and posed for photographs with some 30 former soldiers who had fought in the battle as a way to pay his respects to them.

DOC.HEADLINE: CRASHED MIRAGE FIGHTER LOCATED

TEXT.P: The Navy reported on Monday that its rescue team has located the fuselage of an advanced jet fighter that crashed off the coast of Hsinchu in northern Taiwan 10 days ago.
The team pinpointed the location of the Mirage 2000-5 jet fighter Monday morning. Divers found that the plane, except for damage to its right wing, is relatively intact on the seabed.

The armed forces, which in the past commissioned foreign salvaging companies to retrieve submerged hardware, will conduct retrieval work on its own this time, using sophisticated equipment from the Navy.

On Oct. 15, the pilots of the two-seater fighter reported engine damage after flying into a flock of birds during takeoff from Hsinchu Air Base on a routine training mission. The aircraft was ordered to return immediately, but it then crashed into the sea.
The two pilots were able to eject and were later rescued in satisfactory condition.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LABOR FORCE DECREASED BY ALMOST 70,000 IN SEPTEMBER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's labor force decreased by 69,000 to 9,674,000 in September compared with that of the previous month, said officials of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) on Monday.
The island's unemployment figure for September still remained high at 298,000, while the number of those employed decreased to 9,376,000, the officials added.

Due to the impact of the 921 earthquake, a total of 125,000 workers have been affected; about 42,000 workers were affected in September alone, according to officials of the DGBAS under the Executive Yuan.

Among those affected workers, some have become unemployed, while most left their jobs temporarily but have not yet found new jobs, mainly due to continuous aftershocks or having been busy with reconstruction of their homes.

With the beginning of reconstruction efforts, those who left their jobs temporarily will soon rejoin the labor market, said the DGBAS officials. And, in view of the fact that about 50,000 quake victims have applied for "work in exchange for relief" offered by the Council of Labor Affairs, the unemployment situation on the whole should not have been affected much by last month's devastating temblor, the officials added.

According to a human-resources survey conducted by the DGBAS, for the month of September, employed people totaled 9,376,000, or 53,000 fewer than in August; the number unemployed totaled 298,000, which was 15,000 fewer that the previous month. The figure translates into an unemployment rate of 3.08 percent for September, 0.14 percent lower than that of August, a drop that was not as large as expected.
The decline in unemployment for September is mainly because the number of those seeking first jobs was down 11,000 from that of August, the DGBAS officials disclosed.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA UNAWARE OF TAIPEI-MANILA AVIATION TALKS

TEXT.P: Clarifying foreign wire service reports that Taiwan and the Philippines have reopened talks on a new bilateral air agreement, the ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Monday it had not heard of such a situation and is currently trying to verify the reports.

Meanwhile, China Airlines and EVA Airways Corporation, Taiwan's two leading airlines which operated flights between Taipei and Manila before the suspension of direct air links on Oct. 1, said they, too, were unaware of such developments.

Citing a Manila-dispatched story, AFP reported that Taipei and Manila have resumed negotiations on a new bilateral air pact and that the two sides will reach a new agreement on Monday afternoon or Tuesday morning.
According to the AFP report, Philippine Transportation and Communications Secretary Vicente Rivera said that Taiwan's demand to increase its weekly passenger load was "not a problem."
CAL and EVA Airways suspended flights to Manila on Oct. 2 after rejecting the Philippine government's demand that they reduce their combined weekly passenger load from 9,600 to 3,000.

Chang Kuo-cheng, deputy director-general of the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA), stressed that the precondition to resume bilateral aviation negotiations is that the Philippine side be sincere in doing so.
MOFA had demanded last week that the Philippine Foreign Ministry first correct its "inadequate remarks" made early this month toward Taiwan, before the two sides resume bilateral negotiations.
According to Chang, the Philippines has not shown sincerity since July when two-way talks on renewing direct air links broke up.

Taipei had originally agreed to reduce its combined weekly passenger number from 9,600 to 7,800, then to 6,500, but Manila required that the number be lowered to 4,000, and then to 3,000, he noted, adding that passengers flying between the two cities must now change carriers in Hong Kong or elsewhere, which costs them double the time and money.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S UNEMPLOYMENT RATE WILL SET NEW HIGH THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: Taiwan's unemployment rate hit 3.08 percent in September, increasing the monthly average to 2.92 percent for the first nine months of 1999, announced the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics on Monday.
The 1999 unemployment rate will set a new high since 1985, at no less than 2.92 percent, estimated the government agency under the Executive Yuan. The unemployment rate averaged 2.91 percent in 1985.
Affected by the 921 earthquake that claimed more than 2,400 lives, the number of employed persons decreased by 53,000 , and the labor force also decreased by 69,000 in the month of September alone.
The number of those unemployed increased by 43,000 persons for the month.
The nation's record unemployment rate is in response to economic indicators changing from a green light to a yellow light in the wake of the Sept. 21 earthquake.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHARE PRICES, INDEX FUTURES BOTH UP

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) rallied on Monday, with the weighted price index, the market's key barometer, surging 121.24 points to close at 7,680.87.
Dealers attributed the rise to strong buying of financial, electronics, and plastics and chemical issues.
Monday's turnover totaled NT$54.38 billion (US$1.71 billion), far less than last Friday's NT$72.38 billion.
Gainers led losers 297 to 154, with 75 shares remaining unchanged.
The over-the-counter market gained 2.67 points to close at 173.51, on a turnover of NT$5.76 billion.
Electronics futures and financial futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares (TE) and financial shares (TF), both closed higher.
November TE futures were up 5.8 points to close at 364.3, with 270 contract transactions, while November TF futures rose 28 points to close at 1,004, with 156 contract transactions.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Oct. 25 (CNA) (By David Hsu) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Taipei, Oct. 25 (CNA): The New Taiwan dollar rose 0.004 cents to close at NT$31.757 against the greenback on the Taipei market on Monday.
The currency opened at the day at NT$31.759, and experienced a low of NT$31.761 and a high of NT$31.755. Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$186.5 million.

DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Tuesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Jolt victims in Chiayi area entitled to same treatment as victims of the Sept. 21 earthquake.
The China Times:
Motorists prohibited from using cell phone on highways or freeways; Violators will be fined NT$3,000.
The United Daily News:
Finance Ministry agrees to expand scope of tax-cut.
The Liberty Times:
US decides to allow financial sector to cross over to operations in other sectors.
The Commons Daily:
Lien, Soong camps exchange fire over poll results.
The China Post:
DPP white paper attacks KMT disaster response.
The Taiwan News:
Sept. unemployment rate reaches 3.08 percent -- Reconstruction expected to lower figure in short term.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT HAS NO PLAN TO INCREASE TAXES AT PRESENT: SIEW

TEXT.P: The government has no plan to increase taxes to cope with the large burden of post-"921 Earthquake" reconstruction and resettlement, Premier Vincent Siew said Tuesday.
Premier Siew made the remark at the Legislative Yuan when replying to interpellations on above related issues.

Siew said that post-quake reconstruction and resettlement did indeed increase the government's financial burden. However, he added, the government will raise NT$80 billion by issuing government bonds. These funds, plus the Cabinet's NT$19 billion reserve fund and some budget adjustments will solve the issue in the short term, he said.

He stressed that the government will do its best to economize on its expenditures in order to cope with the post-quake reconstruction and resettlement expenses and presently has no plans to increase taxes.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIA SOCIETY PROVIDES ONLINE INFORMATION ON AIDS IN ASIA

TEXT.P: Asia Source, a new online resource developed by the Asia Society, has produced a comprehensive report on AIDS in Asia to correspond with the 5th International Congress on AIDS in Asia and the Pacific to be held in Malaysia between Oct. 23 and 27.

The report, located at www.asiasource.org, provides an overview of the medical, economic, political and cultural issues surrounding the AIDS epidemic. Also available is specific AIDS information on women, the gay movement in Asia, the economics of the disease, and human rights issues. The report also provides links to sites with country specific data for numerous Asian countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: US MUST REMAIN RESOLUTE IN DEFENSE OF TAIWAN: EXPERT

TEXT.P: The United States must remain resolute concerning Taiwan's defense needs to minimize the threat to its national security interests in the Asia-Pacific region and prevent conflict with Communist China over Taiwan, Peter Brookes, principal adviser on East Asia with the US House International Relations Committee, stressed Monday.

A theater missile defense should be employed in East Asia as soon as practicable in order to persuade Communist China of the futility of building a large ballistic missile arsenal, said the former director of the Asian Studies Center at the Washington-based Heritage Foundation wrote in the latest issue of Defense News weekly
"Should China continue to expand its deployment of missiles arrayed against Taiwan, the United States should provide theater missile defense to Taipei," said Brookes.

Unfortunately, he pointed out, Communist China continues to refuse to renounce the use of force against Taiwan, and Premier Zhu Rongji's recent comments that sooner or later the future of Taiwan will have to be resolved militarily make that threat all the more ominous.

Therefore, the United States should continue to meet its security commitments to Taipei under the 1979 Taiwan Relations Act. "A failure to meet Taiwan's legitimate defense needs will make China's military dominance of the Taiwan Straits a reality," noted the senior policy analyst.

Brookes wrote that Beijing's perceptions of Taiwan's growing defense vulnerability could increase the likelihood of them taking military action against the island. Enhancing Taiwan's ability to defend itself promotes US security interests in the region and may convince Communist China that a peaceful resolution to the Taiwan question is the prudent route.

The military technology that Beijing acquired from the United States through espionage or US companies poses an increased threat to US national security and that of America's allies and friends, including Taiwan. It is clearly not in the interest of the United States to assist in Communist China's military modernization, and a strong People's Liberation Army with significant power projection capabilities could be a highly destabilizing force in Asia, he said.

Consequently, Brookes added, it is appropriate for the United States to reauthorize the lapsed Export Administration Act and ensure that American technology is not going to improve the military capability of the Communist Chinese military.

He stressed that national security interests must remain paramount in American foreign policy and how to deal with a rising Communist China is central to a successful American security policy in Asia.

The Beijing government must be left with no doubt that America will resist any attempts by any power to dominate Asia or resolve Taiwan's future militarily. But it must also be made to feel that, within limits, the United States is prepared to engage in a constructive relationship with mainland China and to integrate Beijing increasingly into the current international order, wrote Brookes.

He noted that the greatest challenge for America's policy-makers will be to manage mutually acceptable approaches to regional security, especially with regards to Taiwan. But until that strategic understanding comes to pass, the United States must clearly define red lines for Beijing, maintain the security system that has created stability in the region, remain resolute on Taiwan's defense needs, and revive export controls.

"Only then will the United States successfully minimize the threat to its national security interests in the Asia-Pacific region and prevent conflict with Beijing over Taiwan," concluded Brookes. (by Nelson Chung)

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Oct. 26, or the 18th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1440: After one of the most extraordinary trials in French history, nobleman and valiant soldier Gilles de Rais, 35 is hanged in Nantes. He was charged with a catalogue of crimes by two courts. His 140 or so alleged victims were children.
1524: Spain surrenders Milan to France.
1860: Guiseppe Garibaldi, Italian soldier and hero of the Italian movement for unification, proclaims Victor Emmanuel King of Italy.
1879: Leon Trotsky, Russian communist leader who, with Lenin, organized the October Revolution, is born. He was forced into exile by Stalin, sentenced to death in a Soviet court, and murdered in Mexixo, where he had found asylum.
1905: Norway becomes a truly independent nation with the accession to the throne of Prince Charles of Denmark, who would thereafter be known as Haaken VII. He was chosen, according to Scandinavian style, by election.
1919: Francois Mitterand, French president from 1981, and founder of the French Socialist Party, is born.
1931: Japan turns down a proposal of the Council of the League of Nations which adopted on Oct. 24 a resolution urging Japan to withdraw its troops from Northeast China by Nov. 16.
1937: Chinese troops begin a withdrawal from Shanghai to the northern Soochow River after Japanese troops capture Tachang. Shanghai was captured by the Japanese on Nov. 11.
1942: US aircraft carrier Hornet is sunk after being hit by Japanese aircraft in Solomon Islands battle.
1944: After three days, the battle of Leyte Gulf in the Philippines ends with victory for the United States. Over 30 ships are sunk in the great sea battle, most of them Japanese, including their last four aircraft carriers.
1947: Hillary Rodham Clinton, American first lady, is born.
1954: Britain and the United States end their occupation of Trieste and return control of the area to Italy.
1951: Winston Churchill is appointed British prime minister for a second time.
1955: The Republic of South Vietnam is proclaimed under Ngo Dinh Diem.
1961: Outer Mongolia is admitted to the United Nations.
1964: The Republic of China opens a consulate in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.
1964: The Republic of China and Panama sign a trade agreement in Panama City.
1965: The four members of the Beatles pop group are formally presented with MBEs by Queen Elizabeth II at Buckingham Palace.
1971: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with Belgium as the latter establishes ties with mainland China.
1973: President Richard Nixon prepares to launch World War III after hearing that the Russians are sending arms to the Middle East War.
1979: Park Chung Hee, president of South Korea, is slain by Kim Jae Kyu, the head of the Korean intelligence agency.
1984: Surgeons at the Loma Linda University Medical Center in California make history by replacing the malfunctioning heart of a two-week-old baby with the healthy heart of a young baboon.
1988: Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev promises to free all political prisoners by the end of the year.
1989: A China Airlines passenger plane crashes near Taiwan's Siulin Village in Hualien County on its way from Hualien to Taipei, killing 54 people on board.
1993: The ROC and Mexico sign a pact to promote investment and technology transfers.
1994: Israel and Jordan sign a peace treaty in a ceremony at their border attended by US President Bill Clinton, ending 46 years of hostility.
1995: Russian President Boris Yeltsin is hospitalized in a Moscow hospital with an apparent heart attack, the second in four months.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "The sages are of the same species as ourselves."

DOC.HEADLINE: JINSA ASKS US GOV'T TO CLARIFY COMMITMENT TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Jewish Institute for National Security Affairs (JINSA) passed a resolution Monday asking the Clinton administration to clarify the US commitment to defend Taiwan in the event of Communist Chinese aggression and provide Taiwan with defense weaponry, including anti-missile systems to offset the Chinese missile threat.
The "China Resolution" passed unanimously by its Board of Directors at its autumn meeting said that the US Congress passing the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act would be a strong first step.

Before putting the resolution to a vote, Harvey Feldman, a former State Department official in charge of ROC affairs, told the board meeting that the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act is a necessary upgrade of the Taiwan Relations Act, because the Clinton administration has not properly implemented the American law.

JINSA pointed out in the resolution that the Beijing government continues to engage in behavior which threatens the security of Taiwan, and the Taiwan Relations Act of 1979 requires that US arms sales to Taiwan be determined solely by Taiwanese defense needs.

The JINSA board added that it is in full agreement with former CIA Director R. James Woolsey's statement, "I believe that clear, not ambiguous, American support for Taiwan's right to be protected from the use of force by Beijing is an essential part of maintaining peace in the Taiwan Straits."

Therefore, the institute resolved that the US government should clarify US commitment to defend Taiwan if the mainland attacks, increase surveillance of it's military activities to reduce the chances of a surprise attack, maintain a strong US military presence in Asia, and provide Taiwan with defense weaponry, including anti-missile systems capable of offsetting the Communist Chinese missile threat.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA WELCOMES UN RESOLUTION ON EAST TIMOR

TEXT.P: Australia on Tuesday welcomed the historic resolution by the UN Security Council to authorize the creation of the UN Transitional Administration in East Timor (UNTAET), describing it as a key event in the progress of the territory to independence.
In a statement faxed to the CNA on Tuesday, Foreign Minister Alexander Downer said the UNTAET will take on the governance of East Timor for the period leading up to full independence.

UNTAET is charged with establishing an effective administration, assisting in the development of civil and social services, and ensuring the coordination and delivery of humanitarian assistance and rehabilitation.

It is also charged with supporting the transition to self-government, which will include drafting a constitution and the organization of elections and the establishment of conditions for sustainable development.

DOC.HEADLINE: TANG: PLA MAY ACHIEVE COMBAT SUPERIORITY IN THREE TO FIVE YEARS

TEXT.P: Mainland China may achieve combat superiority over Taiwan in three to five years if it continues to beef up its war fighting preparedness while the Republic of China does not do the same, Defense Minister Tang Fei said on Tuesday.

Commenting on a US assessment that the People's Liberation Army (PLA) is now capable of achieving air superiority, sea superiority, and information dominance, as well as paralyzing Taiwan in 45 minutes, Tang said the ROC armed forces are not that fragile, but the scenario could become fact if Taiwan fails to upgrade its preparedness as fast as mainland China.
Tang made the remarks during an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan.

The Pentagon, in a recent report on the PLA's strategic war fighting in the 21st Century said that the PLA's growing arsenal of highly accurate and lethal theater missiles and a preemptive doctrine could give Beijing a decisive edge in any future conflict with Taiwan.

The danger of this is that the Beijing leadership, having acquired an overwhelming offensive advantage, might be more inclined to use force even if Taiwan does not declare de jure independence, according to the report.

Citing other American allies as having said that if Taiwan does not strengthen its defensive capabilities, the PLA would acquire an overwhelming offensive advantage over Taiwan sometime between 2005 and 2010, Tang stressed that a military balance across the Taiwan Strait can be achieved if Taiwan increases its war fighting capabilities.

Above all, however, Tang said, the key to victory is solid esprit de corps and high morale. Without a strong psychological preparedness for war, like the people of Israel possess, all its advanced military equipment would only be superficial, he added.

Meanwhile, Tang made an appeal to legislators that current wildlife conservation laws be revised to allow military bases to use eagles to help in the Air Force's efforts to scare away birds that have proven to be one of the major causes of jet fighter accidents, a problem not confined to Taiwan alone.

He added that the real causes behind one of the Air Force's Mirage 2000-5 crashing into the Taiwan Strait on Oct. 15 remained to be investigated, although it has been confirmed that a bird was sucked into its engines, damaging its turbo blades, within 15 minutes after taking off.

If the military bases are allowed to keep eagles, the feathered animals will help the Air Force control the number of wandering migratory birds and racing pigeons, substantially lowering the chances of the further downing of expensive war planes, Tang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOTORISTS TO BE PROHIBITED FROM USING CELL PHONES, WATCHING VCD

TEXT.P: Motorists and motorcyclists will soon be prohibited from talking over cellular phones while driving, under a new government initiative to improve traffic safety.

The Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) on Monday revised the current road safety law to prevent motorists from talking on cell phones behind the wheel. Violators could face a fine of NT$3,000 (US$94).
However, a motorist who talks on a cell phone without holding a handset will not be penalized, according to MOTC officials.
Motorcyclists and drivers of motor scooters will be prohibited from using any kind of cell phone, whether or not handset-free, while driving. Violators will be fined NT$1,000 (US$31.44).
The new regulations will be effective as soon as they are passed by the Legislature, said MOTC officials.

Meanwhile, MOTC is also considering prohibition of VCD (video compact disc) use, as more and more automobiles are expected to be equipped with the electronic gear, which could distract drivers' attention.
