DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-AUSTRALIAN TIES IMPROVING: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The year 1999 marked a gradual improvement in bilateral relations between Taiwan and Australia, an official said here Tuesday.
In an interview with the CNA, Liu Polun, Taiwan's representative in Australia, said bilateral trade between the two countries is expected to rise steadily.

He estimated the two-way trade at well over A$7 (US$4.6) billion in 1999, up slightly from last year's US$4.5 billion. In the first 9 months of 1999, the volume was US$3.58 billion, up from US$3.41 billion in the same 1998 period, according to official figures.

Taiwan's trade deficit with Australia fell to US$834 million in the January-September period from US$956 million a year earlier. Liu believed the trade deficit will drop to about US$1.2 billion by the end of this year from last year's US$1.33 billion.
He attributed the decline in the trade deficit to rising exports from Taiwan to Australia this year. Australia's exports also rose in the 9 month period, he said.

Liu said that there is more room for expansion in trade between the two countries and that this would depend on whether Australia could sell more products, particularly its liquefied natural gas, to Taiwan.
Prospects are bright for cooperation among academics and schools of the two countries, Liu pointed out.
Australia's TAFE schools are successful in producing skilled people and such achievements are attractive to many Taiwanese students, he added.
Currently there are 6000 Taiwanese students doing long-term and short-term studies in Australia. If the number of children of Taiwanese immigrants is added, the figure rises to about 9000, Liu said.
Liu said cultural ties are important and should be strengthened because people-to-people contact can better serve the interests of the two countries.
Liu said the overall prospects of bilateral relations between Australia and Taiwan are encouraging.

The economies of Taiwan and Australia complement to each other. "By working together cooperatively, we can mutually benefit because Australia and Taiwan have their common ground -- a free market system and democracy," Liu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES, INDEX FUTURES UP

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed slightly higher on Tuesday as booming buying sentiment in the financial sector, electronics shares and paper-making issues buoyed the index up.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index climbed 19.42 points to close at 7,700.29.
A total of 1.74 billion shares changed hands on a slowing turnover of NT$68.7 billion (US$2.16 billion).

The market opened higher on early trading boosted by financial stocks, technology shares and paper-making issues. The broader market index once shot up 106.51 points to the session's high of 7,787.38, but later profit-taking by short covering eroded most of the earlier gains and sent the index back down to finish with only small gains.
A sell-off in late trading was also triggered by concerns over third-quarter performance results of electronics companies.
All listed firms are required to release their third-quarter results by the end of October.

Among the eight major stock categories, the paper-making sector took the lead, ending the day with 1.6-percent gains, while financial shares rose 0.7 percent following Monday's upward momentum with news of possible mergers among local banks.
Finance Minister Paul Chiu has pledged to forge at least one major bank union by the end of the year.
Declining stocks outnumbered advancing stocks 239 to 189, with 106 shares unchanged.
The over-the-counter market dropped 0.54 points to close at 172.97 on a turnover of NT$5.75 billion.
TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) posted solid gains despite the limited advances in the stock market.
TAIEX Index Futures for November moved up 48 points to close at 7,736 with 2,695 contract transactions. Those for December rose 54 points to finish at 7,730 with 44 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for next March advanced 60 points to close at 7,760 with three contract transactions while those for next June climbed 66 points to end at 7,796 with six contract transactions. Those for next September had no transaction records.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Wednesday were 7,688 points for November, 7,676 points for December, 7,700 points for next March, 7,730 points for next June, and 7,700 points for next September.
Electronics futures and financial futures, which are sub-index futures and based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares (TE) and financial shares (TF), both reported gains.
November TE futures gained 0.3 point to close at 364.6 with 233 contract transactions; December TE futures climbed 2.8 points to end at 366.8 with nine contract transactions.
There were no transaction records for March, June or September TE futures.
November TF futures moved up one point to close at 1,000.5 with 184 contract transactions, while TF futures for other months had no transaction records. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: NANKANG SOFTWARE PARK INAUGURATED

TEXT.P: A software manufacturing park, said to be the largest in Asia, opened in suburban Taipei on Tuesday.
President Lee Teng-hui, while presiding over the opening of Nankang Software Park, said the park's inauguration marks a milestone in the development of the nation's software industry.
Lee predicted that the production value of the domestic software industry could reach US$14 billion by 2005, representing 40 percent of the domestic information technology industry.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs will also set up a software incubator center and an international research and development cooperation center in the park to introduce foreign technology and products.

Century Development Company, a joint venture of 19 domestic and foreign companies, developed the software park after being commissioned by the Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

Huang Mao-hsiung, chairman of the Century Development Company, said on the same occasion that more than 20 manufacturers have set up and conducted businesses in the park, and that he estimated that the park could offer up to 6,000 job opportunities by the end of the year.
Vice Economics Minister Chang Chang-pang, Minister Without Portfolio Yang Shih-chien, and Presidential Office Advisor Hsia Han-ming also attended the inauguration ceremony.
IDB statistics showed that total investment in the four-year-long first stage of park construction on four hectares of land totaled NT$12.8 billion (US$402.51 million).
The second stage of construction, on adjacent land of the same size, began in April and is expected to be completed in 2003 after NT$19.1 billion (US$600.62 million) in investments.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE CONFERS MEDAL UPON WEINBERGER

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Wednesday conferred a Propitious Clouds Medal with Grand Cordon upon former US Defense Secretary Caspar Weinberger in recognition of his long-term contributions to promoting relations between the Republic of China and the United States.

The ceremony took place at the Presidential Office and was witnessed by a score of dignitaries, including senior presidential advisor Koo Chen-fu, Government Information Office Director-General Chen Chien-jen, and American Institute in Taiwan Taipei Office Director Raymond F. Burghardt.
Thanking Lee for personally decorating him with the medal and hailing it as a great honor, the defense expert vowed to continue boosting bilateral ties.

Weinberger, who served as defense secretary in the Reagan administration and as chairman of the board of the USA-ROC Economic Council between 1991 and 1994, arrived in Taipei on Monday for a two-day visit in his current capacity as chairman of the biweekly business magazine Forbes.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar closed higher against the greenback on the Taipei market on Tuesday, rising 0.004 to close at 31.753.
The local unit opened at 31.753 and was traded between 31.749 and 31.756. Interbank US dollar trading reached US$307.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOY MAKES 5,000 ROTATIONS A DAY AFTER NOSE INJURY

TEXT.P: A nine-year-old boy who hurt himself in the nose while playing at an after-school nursery six months ago now cannot eat nor speak, and makes 5,000 rotations a day if not stopped.
The boy's parents told the sad story at a press conference Tuesday, hoping the owner of the nursery would take responsibility for healing the boy, if there is any such chance.

According to Mrs. Chia, she was on a visit abroad while her son was injured. Upon her return three days later, she was not greeted by the healthy, cheerful son she had before, but by a boy whose injured face was so swollen that he could not open his eyes.

Nursery authorities said the boy was taken to Yangming Municipal Hospital for treatment right after the accident. He received several stitches on his nose, and doctors X-rayed his brain. He was dismissed after a one-hour observation period, according to a spokesman for the nursery.
The boy's condition, however, did not improve. He took a turn for the worse as time went by, said Mrs. Chia.
First he suffered from a phobic disorder, accompanied by urination difficulties. Later, he was unable to walk, speak or eat.
He was sent to Veterans General Hospital and National Taiwan University Hospital for further checks. Doctors said the boy's brain was damaged.

After two months of treatment and rehabilitation at the hospitals, the boy could walk again, and returned home in August. Now, he still cannot speak, but has developed a new habit: standing up and using both feet, he spins around -- about 5,000 times per day if he is not stopped.
While the parents accused the nursery of neglecting its duties, the nursery argued that it did all it could and should not have to shoulder any responsibility for the boy's recovery.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ECONOMIC GROWTH IN 1999 TO BE OVER 5.5%: TIER PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economic growth in 1999 will be between 5.5 percent and 6 percent, and its estimated economic performance next year will be better still, said the head of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) Tuesday.

TIER President Wu Rong-I said the impact of the devastating 921 earthquake on the island's economy was limited to just a short period resulting from temporary electric power rationing, and Taiwan's economic prospects for next year are likely to be robust.

Taiwan's composite economic indicator for September, made public by TIER, is 106.65 points, an index figure which marks the second high since January -- second only to July's 106.71 points. The economic indicator's rise despite the killer quake seems very optimistic for the island's economic prospects, said Wu.

TIER researchers deemed that although the island's third- and fourth-quarter economic growth in the wake of the temblor will not be as good as expected, the trend of improving economic prospects remains unchanged.
Judging from various economic indicators, the negative effects of the tremor on the island's economic growth have not been very strong, the researchers added.

However, the quake is likely to negatively affect Taiwan's economic growth in 1999 by 0.5 percent, which is much higher than the previous assessment of 0.1 to 0.5 percent following an on-the-spot survey conducted by some TIER members.

The on-the-spot survey, conducted in early October, showed that damage caused by the tremor was heavier than expected, with losses worth NT$360 billion in the manufacturing sector, accounting for about 4 percent of the gross domestic product.

According to the team's initial assessment, the island's economic growth in 1999 would not be able to achieve the 5.5 percentage goal set by the government; the group estimated a 5.4 percentage growth would be more likely. However, that figure was dismissed by Wu as too pessimistic.

A revised edition of the domestic economic growth forecast for the fourth quarter will be released by TIER on Nov. 10, and it is expected to provide complete data for the island's economic performance in 1999.

DOC.HEADLINE: RADAR DOME OF CRASHED FIGHTER JET RETRIEVED

TEXT.P: Divers have retrieved the largely intact radar dome of a crashed French-made jet fighter, said an official at Hsinchu Air Force Base Tuesday.

Colonel Lei Yu-chi, deputy base commander, said during a press conference that a dummy missile used for training was pressed down into the seabed by the plane's fuselage, and that the aircraft was largely intact.
Lei said the Navy retrieval team will dive as long as sea conditions permit.

The Air Force General Headquarters released an underwater video recorded off Chiting, Hsinchu County, on Tuesday -- the tape shows that the Mirage 2000-5 fighter was largely intact, except for a clipped right wing.
Colonel Lei said fishing boats and hoisting equipment will be used to tow the crashed plane, noting that due to tidal variations, it is not feasible to use Navy vessels for the operation.
He said that after the crashed plane is salvaged, and the airborne video tape recorder and flight data recorder are retrieved, investigation into the real cause of the incident could proceed.

Though an initial investigation attributed the cause of the crash to birds being sucked into the engine, it was noted that the engine had temporarily lost power before the incident, so further examination of the damaged engine will be required.

Lei said that after the airborne video tape recorder and flight data recorder are recovered, analyzed and compared, assessments can then be made regarding the fighter's speed and altitude, pilots' telecommunications and other factors, in order to determine the true cause of the accident.

The Mirage 2000-5 crashed into the sea off Hsinchu during a routine training mission on Oct. 15. Two pilots ejected in time and later saved in satisfactory condition. It was the first time an advanced fighter of that type crashed in Taiwan.
The Air Force has lost four US-made F-16 fighter jets in less than two years. (By Lilian Wu) EDNITEM ZCZC CEP021 10-26-99 DPP TO STAGE RALLY TO SUPPORT COUNTY MAGISTRATE CANDIDATE

Taipei, Oct. 26 (CNA) The main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will stage a rally through the coastal towns of Yunlin County, southern Taiwan, on Saturday to drum up support for the party's candidate for Yunlin County magistrate.

Former Yunlin County Magistrate Su Wen-hsiung died of liver disease in August, and the by-election to replace him is scheduled to be held on Nov. 6. Campaigning will formally begin on Wednesday for a race which is being widely seen as a warm-up for the 2000 presidential election.
At present, three candidates are vying for the magistrateship -- DPP-nominated Lin Chung-li, the ruling Kuomintang-nominated Chang Cheng-hsiung, and Chang Jung-wei, who is running as an independent.
The DPP is urging some 400,000 supporters hailing from Yunlin County and now living in other counties and cities to return to their home county to work together to put their man in office.
Chen Shui-bian, the DPP's presidential candidate for the 2000 presidential election, will also go to Yunlin to stump for Lin.
Lin had the highest support rate from Yunlin County citizens in a recent poll, followed by the KMT's Chang.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO TAX HIKE PLANNED FOR NEXT FISCAL YEAR: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew reassured the Legislative Yuan Tuesday that there is currently no plan for a tax hike, as this year's financial situation will definitely allow government financing of post-quake reconstruction.
Siew made the statement in response to questioning by opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislator Lian Mu-yang at the Legislative Yuan.
Lian demanded that Siew clarify whether his Monday declaration of "no tax hike for the moment" meant taxes would not be raised until after the presidential election next March.
Lian went on to say that if the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) overturns its own decision and starts to levy more taxes after the election, the KMT would be cheating people out of their money.

In response, Siew said the government can only assess the current financial situation, and therefore it makes no sense for him to make a long-term promise. Any tax hike would be subject to government policy changes aimed for national development, Siew added.

The NT$140 billion designated for post-quake reconstruction has already been secured, since the emergency decree following the devastating Sept. 21 earthquake empowered the government to issue public bonds worth NT$80 billion and make other allocations, Siew noted.

The government taxation plan is based on the financial situation of one fiscal year and has nothing to do with politics, Siew said. He therefore asked legislators not to politicize a simple issue. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: 64 ILLEGAL MAINLAND CHINESE IMMIGRANTS ARRESTED OFF NORTHERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Republic of China maritime police arrested 64 illegal immigrants from mainland China off the coast of Taoyuan county in northern Taiwan on Tuesday morning.

The illegal immigrants, 58 men and six women, were discovered hiding in secret compartments on Taiwan fishing boat, the Maitai No. 2, when maritime police intercepted the ship. Four Taiwanese crewmen aboard the vessel were arrested.
The maritime police had been tipped off earlier that the crew was soliciting illegal immigrants in mainland China, assuring them that the ship would bring them safely into Taiwan.
Maritime police patrols then monitored the movements of the Maitai 2 and stepped up patrols in areas around the northern Taiwan coast in recent days.
Around 4:30 a.m. on Tuesday morning, the ship was spotted drifting after having lost power about 10 nautical miles off Kuanyin, Taoyuan.
An investigation is underway into the case, which is believed to be the largest of its type in the last seven years.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA FOLLOWS ROC SUCCESS TO HOST APEC TECHNO MART IN GOLD COAST

TEXT.P: Australia is banking on Taiwan's 1998 success with plans to host the Third APEC Techno Mart in hope of securing sizable business deals during the exhibition Nov. 1-6 in Gold Coast, one of Down Under's most scenic spots.
Taiwan secured on-the-spot business contracts worth US$100 million when it hosted the Second APEC Techno Mart in Taipei last year.

This year, hundreds of delegates from Taiwan, mainland China, Hong Kong and most of the 21-member Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum are expected to take part in the six-day exhibition, seminars and face-to-face contacts between buyers and sellers of various products at the technology market in Gold Coast, organizers said Tuesday.
Taiwan will be represented by three or four companies, including Acer, displaying their products, including computers, components, and medical equipment and devices, at the exhibition.
Mainland China is expected to send one of the biggest delegations among the APEC member economies and will display its products at the same event, organizers said.
In addition, Taiwanese delegates will hold a seminar to introduce the investment climate in Taiwan in hope of attracting more foreign businesses to invest on the island.

Australia is expected to display many of its products such as computer hardware and software, some with aerospace and aviation applications, to try to secure contracts with foreign businesses and to seek joint ventures, organizers said.

In addition to doing business and networking, participating delegates will be able to see the beautiful beaches of the Gold Coast and have some fun, blending business with pleasure, they said. (by Peter Chen)

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST-EVER TRIAL OF BREAST CANCER PREVENTION DRUGS SET FOR AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: Australia will become the first country to conduct a trial of drugs designed to prevent breast cancer in women at very high risk for the disease.

Announcing the trial, slated to begin within five months, Professor John Forbes, head of the Australia-New Zealand Breast Cancer Trials Group, told reporters he was looking forward to a new era in the management of breast cancer.
Twenty five women aged between 35 and 45 will be asked to take two drugs for six to 12 months, he said.

"I feel, for the first time in 25 years, some cautious optimism about the events that are occurring in breast cancer," he said. He said the trial is open to women with an abnormality in the gene BRCAI, which gives them a 50 percent of getting breast cancer by the age of 50, and an 80 percent chance by the age of 70.
It is also open to women with a very strong family history, such as four close relatives with breast or ovarian cancer, or a close relative with an abnormal gene, he added. (by Peter Chen)

DOC.HEADLINE: US DIPLOMAT TALKS ABOUT PRESS FREEDOM IN HONG KONG

TEXT.P: US Consul General Michael Klosson said here Tuesday that Hong Kong must maintain its freedom of expression and the rule of law so that it will be able to maintain its competitiveness in the world market.
Speaking at a luncheon meeting, the highest US diplomat in Hong Kong said the press should be able to regulate itself.

He made the remarks amid an ongoing debate on establishing a media monitoring organization. The Law Reform Commission has recommended the Hong Kong government to establish a "press council" to regulate the press.
By doing so the government might dampen the willingness of foreigners to invest in Hong Kong, Klosson said. The government might also be blamed for attempting to gain control on the press, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREST FIRE ON KINMEN EXTINGUISHED

TEXT.P: Firefighters on Tuesday extinguished a forest fire which they had battled for nearly 10 hours on the Taiwan-controlled offshore island stronghold of Kinmen.

The firefighters reported that the fire broke out at around 7 p.m. on Monday in a forested region between Lungko and Kuanyin Mountain where communist Chinese and Republic of China troops fought fiercely during the famous Kuningtou Battle half a century ago.
The raging fire twice threatened to engulf two nearby ammunition depots, and actually reached one of them, forcing the army to defuse or evacuate the ammunition stored there, along with personnel.

Up to 70 firefighting vehicles were mobilized at the height of the blaze, and around 200 soldiers were put on standby to provide additional assistance. The shrieking of ambulance sirens wound the island into a mood of high tension.

Firefighters finally brought the fire under control at around 1 a.m. For safety reasons, the military ordered troops stationed at an anti-airborne attack watchtower near the site of the fire to withdraw, while all military personnel and ammunition, including a number of artillery pieces developed by the army and installed islandwide, were withdrawn to safe areas.
Kinmen Defense Command has just finished observing the 50th anniversary of victory in the battle of Kuningtou on Monday.
In the battle, more than 20,000 communist troops landed at Kuningtou, northwestern Kinmen, on Oct. 25, 1949, in an attempt to occupy the island to pave the way for "washing Taiwan with blood."
After three days of fierce fighting, all the communist troops had been either killed or captured, laying the foundation for security across the Taiwan Strait which has lasted for 50 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI WILL MATCH MANILA'S GESTURE IN AVIATION TALKS

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui was quoted as saying on Tuesday that Taipei will match Manila's gesture in offering to reopen aviation talks between the two countries.

Lee said he will ask the Foreign Ministry as well as Ministry of Transportation and Telecommunications to contact their Philippine counterparts with the hope of restoring suspended air links between Taipei and Manila, according to ROC Ambassador-at-Large Jeffrey Koo, who relayed the offer from Philippine President Joseph Estrada to Lee.
As to the weekly passenger load assigned to carriers of each country, this "should be worked out by the airlines themselves," Lee was quoted as saying.

Koo, who is a business tycoon with good connections with the Manila authorities, said Estrada made the offer to him in mid-October when the two met at a gathering of the Pacific Economic Cooperation Council.
The Manila authorities are said to be eager to reopen the talks because they have come under great pressure since a 1996 aviation pact between the two countries was scrapped by Manila on Oct. 1.
Since then, about 120,000 Filipinos working in Taiwan have had to travel via Hong Kong on their way to and from Manila.

DOC.HEADLINE: CETRA OPENS OFFICE IN BOMBAY

TEXT.P: The China External Trade Development Council (CETRA), a private trade promotion organization of the Republic of China, opened a branch office in Bombay on Tuesday.
The inauguration of the new office was presided over by CETRA Chairman Lin Chen-kuo, and was attended by hundreds of ROC and Indian political and business leaders.
It was followed by a series of campaigns aimed at promoting Taiwan's trade with India.
CETRA originally set up an Indian office in 1993 in Bombay, but moved it to the Indian capital of New Delhi, with this most recent move carried out for "business reasons."
Taiwan registered two-way trade with India worth US$987 million in 1998, with US$526 million-worth of exports and US$461 million-worth of imports.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT RECEIVES JAPANESE PARLIAMENTARIAN

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui on Tuesday received Japanese Lower House member Sadanori Yamanaka, and expressed his gratitude for Yamanaka's concern over the devastating earthquake that rocked central Taiwan on Sept. 21.

Yamanaka visited Lee at the Presidential Office in his capacity as chairman of the Dietmen's Council on Japan-ROC Relations to extend sympathy and concern for the casualties and damage caused by the 7.3-magnitude temblor.

During the reception, Lee explained the rescue and reconstruction operations of the ROC government and civilian groups, and expressed his appreciation for the assistance and concern from the Japanese government and people.
He also lauded Yamanaka for his efforts to persuade the Japanese government to promptly provide prefabricated housing units for displaced people in the disaster areas.
Yamanaka for his part said he was impressed by the effectiveness of the rescue and reconstruction operations being carried out in the quake-stricken areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACER MOVES TO DELIST SUBSIDIARY

TEXT.P: As part of a bid to make Acer the number one PC brand in Asia, the Acer Group is planning to buy out one of its subsidiaries -- Acer Computer International (ACI) -- listed on the Singapore stock market, the computer giant said on Tuesday.
The Monday news release indicated that the buy-out will be carried out by Acer Inc., one of the group's six sub-groups, which operates computer development and processing.

Delisting ACI is part of the Acer Group's efforts to integrate its resources and expertise to maximize efficiency and sharpen the business group's competitive edge in the Southeast Asian and mainland China information technology industry, Acer said.

According to the proposed arrangement, Acer Inc., which currently owns a 63.43-percent stake of ACI, is set to acquire all of the remaining shares listed on the Singapore stock market, paying US$1.2 per share for a total cost of about US$83 million, the newspaper reported on Tuesday.
Singapore-headquartered ACI was set up to run Acer marketing and exporting, with its operations spanning the Asia Pacific, South Asia, Africa and the Middle East.
Acer is a top-10 PC brand worldwide, with 1998 revenues of US$6.7 billion. It employs more than 28,000 persons working for 120 affiliates in countries around the world.
Last year Acer produced 7.5 million PCs, making it the world's third-largest PC maker, according to the company.

DOC.HEADLINE: CORRUPTION-FIGHTING AGENCY RELEASES 1999 REPORT

TEXT.P: Transparency International, a Berlin-based global non-profit organization dedicated to fighting corruption, released on Tuesday its 1999 report.
The report listed Denmark as the country most free from corruption, while Taiwan was ranked 28th among 99 countries surveyed by the agency.
The report also revealed what it called "a shocking picture" showing that companies from many leading exporting nations are widely seen as using bribes to win business.

Transparency International's fifth annual Corruption Perceptions Index (CPI) relates to perceptions of the degree of corruption as seen by business people, risk analysts and the general public, and ranges between 10, highly clean, and 0, highly corrupt.

According to the ranking, Singapore, at seventh place, is the only Asian country among the top ten scorers, the others being Denmark, Finland, New Zealand, Sweden, Canada, Iceland, The Netherlands, Norway and Switzerland, in that order.

Among the Southeast Asian countries included in the survey, Japan was placed 25th, Taiwan 28th, Malaysia 32nd, South Korea 50th, the Philippines 54th, mainland China 58th, Thailand 68th and Vietnam 75th.
At the bottom of the list were Cameroon, Nigeria, Indonesia, Azerbaijan, Uzbekistan, Honduras, Tanzania, Yugoslavia, Paraguay and Kenya.
In the agency's brand new Bribe Payers Perceptions Index (BPI), it ranked 19 leading exporting countries in terms of the degree to which their corporations are perceived to be paying bribes abroad.

The BPI revealed that mainland China, including Hong Kong, was seen as having the greatest willingness to pay bribes abroad, followed by South Korea, Taiwan, Italy and Malaysia. Sweden, Australia and Canada achieved the most favorable results.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT NAMED HONORARY DIRECTOR OF CHILEAN UNIVERSITY

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui on Tuesday accepted an appointment as honorary director of Chile's International Council of Universities of Saint Thomas Aquinas (ICUSTA).
Lee was accorded the honor in recognition of his achievements in the fields of academia, politics and economics. He described his appointment as "significant."
The letter of appointment was presented to Lee by ICUSTA Executive President Gerardo Rocha during a visit to the Presidential Office.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Wednesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
US House's International Relations Committee passes the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act (TSEA) despite boycott from the Administration.
The China Times:
The International Relations Committee under the US House of Representatives passes the TSEA in a vote 32:6.
The United Daily News:
US House passes TSEA in heated debates.
The Liberty Times:
Violence shadowing Yunlin magistrate by-election.
The Commons Daily:
The ruling Kuomintang is rigging votes prior to the presidential election, and is believed to raise taxes after the election.
The China Post:
Siew promises no post-quake tax hike.
The Taiwan News:
Chinese ranked most willing to pay bribes -- Taiwanese follow as the third top bribers in index rating world's major exporters.
