DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Oct. 27, or the 19th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1505: Ivan III, known as "Ivan the Great," the first Tsar of Russia, dies at the age of 65.
1662: Charles II of England sells Dunkirk to Louis XIV for 2.5 million livre.
1728: Captain James Cook, English navigator, is born. His voyages in the ship Endeavour led to European discovery of Australia, New Zealand and the Hawaiian Islands.
1792: French troops invade the Austrian Netherlands.
1858: Theodore Roosevelt, US statesman and president, is born. He won the Nobel Peace prize for his efforts in ending the Russo-Japanese War.
1871: Britain annexes the diamond-rich region of Griqualand West (Kimberley) in South Africa.
1921: Yen Fu, a noted Chinese translator who introduced Western culture to China, dies in his hometown of Minhou in Fukien Province at the age of 67.
1922: The Italian government resigns under increasing pressure from the fascist movement of Benito Mussolini.
1927: Mao Tse-tung leads his followers and reaches Chingkangshan mountain in Kianghsi Province to establish a stronghold for the Chinese Communist Party.
1930: The Wuhsheh Incident occurs when Taiwan's aborigines in the Wuhsheh area of Taichung County launch their resistance against Japanese rule and kill 134 Japanese.
1931: Representatives from Nanking and Canton meet in Shanghai for peace negotiations.
1942: Madame Chiang Kai-shek leaves for the United States to address a joint session of the US Senate and House of Representatives.
1947: The Ministry of the Interior announces that the "Democracy Alliance" is an illegal organization subject to crackdown in accordance with current law.
1947: The Sino-American Relief Treaty is signed in Nanking under which US$30 million worth of relief goods will be shipped to Taiwan.
1955: Taiwan's first sex-change operation is successfully carried out at the Army First Hospital.
1961: The 16th United Nations General Assembly votes in favor of admission of Outer Mongolia. The Republic of China abstained from the vote.
1964: The Republic of China and the Republic of Korea sign a treaty of amity in Seoul.
1971: The Republic of Congo changes its name to the Republic of Zaire.
1978: President Anwar Sadat of Egypt shares the Nobel Peace Prize with Premier Menachem Begin of Israel.
1979: St. Vincent and the Grenadines becomes independent from Britain.
1983: US President Ronald Reagan defends his decision to send a 2,000-strong force of Marines and Army Rangers to the Caribbean island of Grenada.
1986: An international conference on "Chiang Kai-shek and Modern China" opens in Taipei and more than two hundred Chinese and foreign scholars attended the four-day meeting.
1987: A referendum in the Republic of Korea approves constitutional reforms, including establishment of direct presidential elections.
1990: Moscow City Mayor Gavriil H. Popov arrives for a formal visit to the ROC to discuss the strengthening of ROC-Soviet trade relations.
1994: The Legislative Yuan passes revisions to the "Wildlife Conservation Law," greatly toughening penalties against violators and stipulating that the breeding of endangered animals in captivity must cease within three years.
1997: The Dow Jones index drops 554.26 points, its largest one-day decline in terms of points.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "The sense of mercy is in all men; the sense of shame is in all men; the sense of courtesy and respect is in all men; the sense of right and wrong is in all men."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPORTS TO MAINLAND CHINA ON THE RISE

TEXT.P: Taiwan exported US$1.92 billion worth of commodities to mainland China in August, up 18.1 percent over the same month last year, the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) reported on Wednesday.
August exports to mainland China constituted 17.9 percent of Taiwan's total exports for the month, the highest monthly total this year, according to BOFT officials.

Taiwan's two-way trade with mainland China totaled US$16 billion in the first eight months of this year, up 7.8 percent over last year's level. The amount was 10.8 percent of Taiwan's entire foreign trade in the eight-month period, BOFT tallies showed.
Between Jan. 1 and Aug. 31, Taiwan's exports to the mainland amounted to US$13.17 billion, up 8.7 percent over last year and constituting 16.9 percent of Taiwan's total exports in the period.

The officials attributed increased Taiwan exports to the mainland over the past eight months to mainland China's increased domestic demands, its increasing export trade and to the economic recovery in the United States and other Asian countries.

Meanwhile, Taiwan imported US$2.83 billion worth of goods from mainland China in the first eight months of this year, up 3.9 percent over the same period a year ago. The figure was 4 percent of Taiwan's total imports registered in that period.

In August alone, Taiwan's imports from the mainland totaled US$397 million, up 21.1 percent over the same month in 1998, marking two-digit growth for the third consecutive month, according to BOFT tallies.

DOC.HEADLINE: US HOUSE PASSES TAIWAN SECURITY ENHANCEMENT ACT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 26 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The International Relations Committee of the US House of Representatives on Tuesday amended and passed the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act (TSEA), aiming at expanding US-Taiwan security ties.
Supporters of the act hoped that it would be debated in the full House and resolved before the next recess.
After two hours of heated debates, the House International Relations Committee passed the TSEA by a margin of 32-6. An earlier proposal to shelve the act was overruled 30-9.
The act was modified considerably from the original bill drafted by Rep. Tom DeLay. The original bill would have authorized the sale of specific weapons to Taiwan.

The amended bill, put forth by the committee's Republican chairman, Representative Benjamin Gilman, keeps provisions calling for Taiwanese military officers to have an increased number of slots at US military training facilities, and for the establishment of direct communications between the armed forces of both countries.
Nearly 40 representatives of the 49-member committee took part in the heated debate before voting for the amendment and passage of the act.
Although most of the members stressed the commitment to Taiwan's security, some representatives questioned the necessity and timing of the bill.
Meanwhile, administrative officials reiterated the State Department's set policy of opposing the act and would not comment on the bill's passage by the committee on Tuesday.
If the TSEA is passed in the full House, it would then be sent to the Senate for debate, House resources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE INSISTS ON PARITY IN CROSS-STRAIT TALKS
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 27 (CNA) (By Huang Kwang Chun)

TEXT.P: ROC President Lee Teng-hui called on the international community and Beijing to recognize the reality of the ROC on Taiwan and insisted cross-strait talks be conducted on the basis of parity.

Lee wrote in an article in the New York bimonthly magazine "Foreign Affairs" that if peace and stability are to be maintained in the Taiwan Strait area, the perceptions underpinning policies involving Taipei and Beijing must be more firmly grounded in reality than in ideological wishful thinking.

Lee's article, titled "Understanding Taiwan: Bridging the Perception Gap," stated that sustained economic growth, unprecedented prosperity, and the evolution into a full democracy have outstripped prevailing perceptions of what Taiwan is and how it should fit into the global order, he indicated.

The ROC has been a sovereign state since 1912, he stressed, adding that both sides of the Taiwan Strait have been separately ruled in the last 50 years since the "People's Republic of China" was founded, with neither subordinate to the other.
The facts have been distorted by Beijing and overlooked by the international community for many years, the president stated.
The cross-strait ties now form a "special state-to-state relationship" because Taiwan and the Chinese mainland share the same culture, historical origins and ethnic bonds, he explained.
What is most important is that the two sides are willing to work in concert and consult on an equal basis to pursue the future reunification of China, President Lee emphasized.

If the two sides can recognize and appreciate this special relationship, they can transcend political differences and jointly develop a relationship conducive to the peaceful and democratic reunification of the Chinese nation one day, he affirmed.

However, President Lee said some obstacles must be overcome if cross-strait relations are to flourish in the years ahead. These include the lack of mutual trust between Taipei and Beijing, the Beijing authorities' refusal to renounce the use of force as a means to solve the Taiwan Strait issue, and the vast differences between the political, social and economic systems of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait caused by five decades of separate rule.

Beijing's refusal to renounce the use of force against Taiwan presents a large, insurmountable obstacle to improving relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, and the authoritarian nature of the communist regime is the key factor alienating the people of Taiwan from the Chinese mainland, President Lee pointed out.
Taipei and Beijing can cooperate to maintain peace in the Taiwan Strait and promote the welfare of all Chinese, he suggested.

During the past few years, Taipei has made numerous concrete proposals, providing the Chinese mainland with the know-how to fight floods, assisting agricultural improvements on the Chinese mainland, exchanging ideas about reorganizing state-owned enterprises, and cooperating to find ways of coping with the after-effects of the Asian financial crisis.
These proposals are aimed at creating a win-win situation for both sides of the Taiwan Strait, he stressed.

Taipei does not rule out discussing political issues once meetings with Beijing resume on a basis of parity, but priority should be given to outstanding issues that affect people's everyday lives, he added.

What Taiwan has done in the past decade is remarkable for the speed and scope of its economic and political changes and for the peaceful way in which such changes have been achieved, President Lee said.
It is in the best interest of regional and even global peace and stability for Beijing to embrace democracy rather than try to contain it, Lee concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: ETHNIC CHINESE APPOINTED INDONESIAN ECONOMIC MINISTER

TEXT.P: The appointment of an ethnic Chinese at the Cabinet level in the new Indonesian government of Abdurrahman Wahid is a key factor in luring foreign investors, especially wealthy Chinese businessmen back to the world's largest Islamic country, says an Australian expert.

In an interview with the CNA on Wednesday, Dr. George Quinn of the Australian National University said the appointment of Kwik Kian Kie "represents a symbolic reconciliation between the mainstream and the minority groups in Indonesia," a relationship strained since the riots in May of 1998.
Kwik is a reformer whose name will reassure the markets and international institutions, including the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, other experts said.
Experts believe the new government under Wahid is trying to make a clean break with past corrupt regimes and is trying to convince wealthy Chinese to return to Indonesia and continue doing business.

Kwik is the second ethnic Chinese to hold a ministerial position in an Indonesian government. The first was Bob Hassan who was appointed by Suharto in early 1998 to head the finance ministry, but his term was short-lived due to the downfall of Suharto.

There are only about 7 million ethnic Chinese in a country with a population of 210 million. But they hold significant economic power and their wealth has been estimated to be at least 40 percent of the national wealth.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENHANCED TAIWAN SECURITY MORE CONDUCIVE TO PEACE SAYS EXPERT

TEXT.P: For the United States, enhancing Taiwan's security, rather than increasing its vulnerability, is most conducive to peace and stability as well as freedom and prosperity for both sides of the Taiwan Straits, stressed an American China expert Tuesday.

Stephen Yates, senior policy analyst in the Asian Studies Center at the Washington-based Heritage Foundation, wrote in an analysis titled "Why Taiwan's Security Needs To Be Enhanced," that Taiwan's security is still threatened by communist China's escalating military modernization and buildup across the Taiwan Strait because America is failing to faithfully implement the legislative intent of the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA).

He pointed out that the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act, cosponsored by Senators Jesse Helms (R-NC) and Robert Torricelli (D-NJ), calls on the US government to recognize Taiwan's changing defense needs in light of mainland China's determined military modernization and the more general revolution in military affairs from which Taiwan is diplomatically isolated.

The TRA instructs the US government to enable Taiwan to maintain a sufficient self-defense capability, but today Taiwan clearly is at a military disadvantage, noted Yates. Beijing has a 65 to 4 advantage in submarines and a 4,500 to 400 numerical advantage in aircraft, an edge increased by its acquisition of advanced foreign technology primarily from Russia, but also from Israel and the United States.

Taiwan will never be communist China's military equal, but parity with communist China is not Taiwan's objective and it should not be the objective of the United States. Nevertheless, "the US remains obliged under the Taiwan Relations Act to sell Taiwan defense articles and systems based solely on Taiwan's defense needs," Yates wrote.

He added that because of Beijing's overwhelming hardware advantage, emphasis on missile modernization, and a willingness to use missiles to intimidate Taiwan, "Taiwan needs to increase its reliance on high technology, including missile defense. The alternative is near total vulnerability or total reliance on US intervention."

Yates said American policy-makers should discount arguments warning that enhancing Taiwan's security will encourage it to move toward independence and a regional arms race. In his opinion, such alarmist views ignore the history of cross-strait dialogue which has progressed at times when Taiwan has felt secure.

DOC.HEADLINE: BAUER CHALLENGES BUSH TO STATE HIS CHINA POLICY

TEXT.P: US Republican presidential hopeful Gary Bauer Tuesday criticized former President George Bush for his erroneous assessment of Communist China's military threat and challenged Texas Governor George W. Bush to tell the American people whether he shares his father's dangerous view of Beijing's military intentions.

Former President Bush the other day told Fox Sunday News that "China is not seeking hegemony. I see no evidence, and I'd like one person who's a critic of China on the Republican right or the Democratic left to tell me why they think they are seeking hegemony?"

Bauer responded Tuesday by asking if President Bush had forgotten that China conducted missile tests off the coast of Taiwan in 1995 and 1996 and whether he was aware that their military held missile attack exercises against mock US troops within the past year.

"I am appalled that former President Bush would adopt the mantra of the Clinton-Gore administration, which can only encourage military aggression by the repressive government of China," said the conservative Republican leader.

He pointed out that a Pentagon report completed in September concluded that Communist China is developing "one of the most daunting conventional theater missile challenges in the world...which could have significant implications for regional stability.
"I am very concerned that this misguided view of China's intentions is shared by Bush's son, George W. Bush," said Bauer.

Commenting on Gov. Bush's recent call for a relaxation of US supercomputer export controls, Bauer stated that "at a time when China is using such technology to design and test nuclear weapons, it is shocking that a Republican presidential candidate would advocate a policy that shows less regard for our national security than the current irresponsible policies of the Clinton-Gore administration."
Bauer added that "Gov. Bush needs to immediately tell the American people whether he shares his father's misguided and dangerous view of China's military intentions."

DOC.HEADLINE: JIANG ORDERS FAST ACTION ON ACTIVISTS

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin recently gave new instructions that all challenges to the government be "nipped in the bud", the South China Morning Post reported today.
The dictum, which Jiang laid down before he left for his multi-nation tour, has been issued to party, government and PLA units, the report said.
"All cadres must maintain a vigorous fighting spirit in the political, social and military fields," it quoted diplomatic sources in Beijing as saying.

The sources also said that on another occasion, Jiang decried the "new threat" posed by cults and quasi-religious units such as the Falun Gong. Following Jiang's orders, security forces have in the past week adopted extra tough tactics against Falun Gong affiliates as well as members of underground political parties, according to the report.
It noted that authorities were disturbed by the rise of rioting and demonstrations, particularly in the northwest and southwest.

"While some protests were led by laid-off workers and over-taxed farmers, a surprisingly large number of instances of disorder were caused by underground religious units," it quoted another source as saying.
It is estimated that there are about 100 Qi Gong sects in mainland China, and most of them claim at least several thousand members.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA DOES NOT NEED A REPUBLIC SAYS PM

TEXT.P: Prime Minister John Howard, a strong monarchist advocate, has challenged supporters of a republic within his own government, arguing that Australia doesn't need to change its political system and the present constitutional system would be weakened under the republican model.

In a dramatic intervention in the republic debate on Tuesday night, Howard said Australia's handling of the East Timor crisis had demonstrated its independence to the world and undermined republican arguments for constitutional change.

He also pointed to the 1975 political crisis involving the sacking of the Whitlam government as proof that the governor-general was the "effective head of state of Australia because he does not take instructions" from the British Queen.

A new public poll released by the Australian media on Tuesday indicated Australians are moving to deliver a comprehensive defeat to the republic cause in all states with support dropping from 49 percent during September 17-22 to 41 percent during October 22-24.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA PROMISES TO WORK CLOSELY WITH NEW INDONESIAN GOVERNMENT

TEXT.P: Australia on Wednesday promised to work closely with the new Indonesian government to build a productive and beneficial relationship between the two countries while describing the election of Abdurrahman Wahid and Megawati Sukarnoputri as a boost to investor confidence in Indonesia.

In a statement faxed to the CNA, Foreign Minister Alexander Downer welcomed the announcement of Indonesia's new Cabinet, saying the new "line-up reflects depth and experience, as well as a number of new figures. The balance and quality of the Cabinet is a credit to the judgment and political skill of President Wahid."
He said he believes the new Cabinet is likely to be positively received by the international community and has been a boost to investor confidence.

Downer added that "the Australian government looks forward to working closely with the new Indonesian government, across a range of portfolio interests. We have had good relations with a number of the new Indonesian ministers and look forward to developing these contacts further."

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA TO USE NEW METHOD TO DETECT HEPATITIS C

TEXT.P: The Canadian Blood Services said Tuesday all blood donations will be screened with a new, more accurate Hepatitis C testing method.

The blood agency said NAT, or Nucleic Acid Amplification Testing, can detect low levels of genetic material in the blood when an infection occurs but before the body begins to produce antibodies to fight the disease.
The period from the time of infection to the point where tests can pick up evidence of the virus can be reduced to between 14 and 28 days from 70 days with older methods, the CBS added.
It estimates that four to six more cases of Hepatitis C could be detected in donations each year and up to 13 new infections prevented.

DOC.HEADLINE: VIAGRA FOR WOMEN TO HIT MARKET IN 3 YEARS

TEXT.P: With the huge success of Viagra with impotent men around the world, the wonder drug is now aiming at women with sexual problems, Australia's Channel Nine TV Network reported on Wednesday.
The Australian network quoted a British doctor as revealing that a series of tests on 800 women have been conducted and the results have been satisfactory.
He said more than 40 percent of females in many countries have sexual problems and the number might be higher.
He said Viagra for women would hit the market in about three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC LAWMAKERS BLAST RUSSIAN ASSAULT ON CHECHNYA

TEXT.P: The Foreign Affairs Committee under the Republic of China's Legislative Yuan unanimously passed a resolution on Wednesday condemning Russia's attack on neighboring Chechnya.

The committee called on the international community to jointly blast Russia's "savage behavior," and urged the Russian government to call a cease-fire immediately and hold talks with the Chechen authorities to achieve a peaceful resolution to the crisis.

Democratic Progressive Party lawmaker Parris Chen, head of the committee, said Russia's military attacks on the breakaway republic constitute a violation of international law and human rights, and pose a threat to world peace.

The committee suggested that the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund and other international organizations should suspend loans and other forms of economic assistance to Moscow until it can reach an agreement with Grozny.
It also passed an unrelated resolution urging the ROC government to pay heed to national dignity and economic interest as it reopens aviation talks with the Philippines.
The committee set forth the following three preconditions for the resumption of flights between Taipei and Manila:
-- Manila should officially declare that it recognizes the previous agreement signed by the two countries in 1996;
-- Manila should apologize for its unilateral decision to scrap the 1996 aviation accord and for its suspension on Oct. 1 of Taipei-Manila airlinks; and
-- Manila should provide a guarantee that it will respect Taiwan's position in the talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN 1999 ECONOMIC GROWTH TO DROP FROM ORIGINAL PREDICTION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economic growth rate will slide to 5.3 percent this year from the 5.5 percent quoted in an earlier assessment, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said on Wednesday.

C.Y. Hu, director of CEPD Economic Research Department, indicated that the downward modification resulted from the Sept. 21 earthquake that devastated several townships on the island and claimed more than 2,300 lives.

However, Hu said, post-quake reconstruction efforts are expected to cause the island's general economic performance next year to bounce back from its current sluggishness caused by the quake, to a predicted 6.1 percent.

At the same time, both the CEPD and the official Chung-Hua Institute for Economic Research assessed that the economic growth in the upcoming fourth quarter of this year will show a drop to about 5 percent, in contrast to previous figures which reflected an economy recovering from the global recession brought about by the 1997 Asian financial storm.

Meanwhile, in a separate report, the CEPD announced that the earthquake and the temporary power rationing which followed caused the economy to flash a "yellow-blue" light, signaling a slowdown in economic development, for September.

In the CEPD-devised five-color rating system, a "green" light marking steady growth was seen in June, July and August. September's change should serve as a warning that efficient government measures should be taken to prevent further deterioration of the economy, the report said.

September's overall economic performance received a score of 20 points, down three points from the August level, according to the CEPD report which indicated that the drop was mainly caused by an immense decline in export value. The minimum score for a healthy green rating is 23 points.

Despite that, a monthly CEPD survey of local manufacturers conducted in September found that 36 percent of respondents expected the business climate to take a turn for the better in the next three months, up from the 27 percent who held that opinion in an August poll.

Forty-eight percent of those surveyed expected the business climate to remain unchanged, down from 57 percent in August; and 10 percent thought it will deteriorate, the same figure as that polled in August.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA WELCOMES PASSAGE OF TSEA BY US HOUSE INT'L RELATIONS COMMITTEE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Wednesday welcomed the passing of the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act (TSEA) 32-6 by the International Relations Committee of the US House of Representatives.

Speaking at a press conference, MOFA spokesman Henry Chen said that if the act can win bipartisan support in the US Congress and if it can gain backing from the US executive branch, "we will be glad to see it succeed."
Attention is focused on whether the act will be passed by the US House of Representatives next week, as it faces opposition from the Clinton administration and strong protest from Beijing.

The Clinton administration opposes the TSEA on the grounds that the United States has been keeping its promise to provide Taiwan with defensive weapons since the enactment of the Taiwan Relations Act in 1979, and that the promulgation of the TSEA would probably bring about an adverse effect on stability across the Taiwan Strait.

The altered bill removes the original version's mention of specific arms which the president could transfer to Taiwan under the bill, but it reserves provisions calling for the establishment of a direct communications channel between high-ranking military officers of both countries, as well as the sponsoring of joint military drills.

DOC.HEADLINE: `FATHER OF BIRTH CONTROL PILLS' VISITS TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Dr. Carl Djerassi, long noted as the world's "father of the birth control pill" and a prolific writer, arrived in Taipei recently to publicize the Chinese-language edition of his latest novel.
A chemistry professor at Stanford University, Djerassi synthesized the world's first oral birth control pills in 1950, when he was just 26.

Nearly five decades later, Djerassi confirmed the contribution to society of oral contraceptive pills, saying they allow women to be in control of their bodies and to plan their families according to their means and desire.

Djerassi stressed, however, that people today need more than pills prescribed by a doctor, and that there is a great need for more diverse birth control choices which should be available like commodities displayed on supermarket shelves.
Most of all, he said, people should have a mentality that is tolerant towards diversified birth control options.

Djerassi was chosen one of the 30 most influential people of the millennium by Britain's "Times Weekly" in September for his contribution to mankind. The 76-year-old professor was the only living nominee on the prestigious list, which also included Karl Marx, Albert Einstein, William Shakespeare, Martin Luther and Napoleon I.

Although he is a scientist by profession, Djerassi is also a writer, having completed five science fiction novels and two plays. This is the third visit to Taiwan by Djerassi and his wife. They were here in 1960 and paid their last visit in 1989.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG DONATIONS FOR 921 QUAKE VICTIMS REACHES US$ 11 MILLION

TEXT.P: Monetary donations to Taiwan from the people of Hong Kong had accumulated to more than HK$90 million (US$11.54 million) as of Tuesday, the director of Hong Kong affairs under the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said on Wednesday.

Tsai Chi-chung expressed deep gratitude on behalf of the Republic of China government and people for the outpouring of donations to the victims of the massive earthquake that devastated Taiwan on Sept. 21, killing 2,400 people and leaving thousands more injured and homeless.
Thousands of the victims are still living in tents, shelters and temporary housing units after seeing their homes destroyed by the quake.

Tsai denied several reports from Hong Kong claiming that Taiwan had given the cold shoulder to the Hong Kong donations, and pointed out that during a meeting with visiting representatives of the Hong Kong donors, Premier Vincent Siew also extended his gratitude for the kind donations.

The MAC official also pointed out that each and every letter of condolence from Hong Kong residents concerning the 921 quake which were delivered to the ROC government have been answered by relevant executive officials, showing clearly the government's heartfelt appreciation for the aid.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO NEW MRT LINES TO OPEN BY YEAR-END

TEXT.P: Two more new lines of the Taipei mass rapid transit (MRT) system are scheduled to begin operations by the end of this year, the Taipei Rapid Transit Co. said on Wednesday.

With the inauguration of the two new lines -- the southern section of the Hsintien Line and the Pannan Line (connecting Lungshan Temple and the Taipei City Government headquarters) -- the system's daily passenger load is expected to increase from the current level of 390,000 to 700,000, as the lines will pass through Taipei's commercial center and several populous residential areas, the company pointed out.

In addition, the opening of the Pannan Line will help the MRT network take a more all-encompassing shape, providing commuters with more convenient and faster north-south and east-west services and allowing access to any station in the city within a maximum of one hour from any other station, according to company officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar closed higher against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Wednesday, appreciating 0.006 to close at a two-year high of 31.747.
The currency opened at the day's low of 31.748, and experienced a high of 31.74.
Interbank US dollar trading expanded to US$447.5 million during the session, the largest single-day volume over the past month.
Continuing weakness of the US dollar on the international market resulting in a strengthened Japanese Yen inspired a common appreciation among Asian currencies, according to Taipei dealers.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIRLINES MULLING CANCELLATIONS OF CERTAIN Y2K FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: In an attempt to avoid the Y2K computer bug that might confuse certain navigational computer systems, some airline companies plan to cancel certain flights between Dec. 31 and Jan. 1, 2000, airline service providers said on Wednesday.

Among the flight routes likely to be affected, Europe-bound routes that have to pass through Indian and Pakistani airspace are on high alert because the two countries' navigational computer systems are not expected to be Y2K compliant in time, the airline service providers added.

Although some airline companies are mulling the cancellation of certain flights and resuming services only when suspect computer navigation systems have completed Y2K testing, bookings are still being taken for the end of December, and no decisions on cancellations will be taken until nearer the time, according to the airline service providers.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE GOVERNMENT URGED TO RECOGNIZE TAIPEI-MANILA AIR AGREEMENT

TEXT.P: Philippine Airlines (PAL) on Wednesday urged the Foreign Ministry of the Philippines to immediately recognize the air agreement signed in 1996 between Taipei and Manila.
PAL's move was seen as being aimed at re-establishing air-links suspended on Oct. 1 following a dispute over passenger quotas for air carriers of the two sides.

The 1996 Air Service Agreement, signed by the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) and the Manila Economic and Cultural Office (MECO), was terminated by the Philippine's Civil Aeronautics Board (PCAB) in late September when the dispute reached an impasse.

However, Leo Li-ming Sung, PAL's adviser in Taipei, on Wednesday re-interpreted PCAB's previous decision, saying that only the sub-contract involving passenger quotas was terminated, rather than the main agreement which is therefore still in effect.

Officials of the Republic of China's Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) said that Taipei's stance has not changed, and that Taipei has always stressed its respect to the spirit of the agreement. Negotiations can be resumed only if the Philippines takes concrete action to remedy the situation, the officials added.

Passenger quotas remains the most contentious point at issue. Under the 1996 agreement, each side is allowed to transport up to 9,600 passengers per week, but Manila demanded that this number be slashed to just 3,000. Taipei agreed to a lowering to 6,500, a figure which was not accepted by Manila.

The dispute has affected 32 flights shared by China Airlines and EVA Airways of Taiwan, and nine PAL flights. Filipino travel agents reportedly have warned that the dispute could cost the Philippines up to US$146 million in lost annual tourism revenue.
In addition, since the termination of direct airlinks, travelers between Taipei and Manila currently have to travel via a third destination, doubling both travel time and cost.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES CLOSE MARGINALLY HIGHER, INDEX FUTURES MIXED

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed marginally higher on Wednesday as late profit-taking set in and triggered selling pressure across the broader market to erase limited earlier gains.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index climbed 0.93 point to close at 7,701.22.
A total of 1.58 billion shares changed hands on a continually slowing turnover of NT$61.99 billion (US$1.95 billion).

The market opened 33.88 points higher and reached a high of 7,780.21, a 1.04-percent intra-day rise boosted by purchases in financial and technology shares. But in late trading, the index dipped 0.4 percent before buying resumed to pull it back slightly above the break-even point.

Brokers said the market's unusually slow turnover in recent days triggered caution. The daily turnover, which in recent months had averaged between NT$110 billion and NT$120 billion (US$3.4 billion to 3.7 billion), has languished below NT$80 billion in the past nine sessions and once dropped to NT$54 billion.

According to brokers, investors' mood will hinge in coming days on the release of key companies' third-quarter corporate results, as the investors are waiting to see the actual impact of the devastating Sept. 21 earthquake on key firms' results.
All listed firms are required to release their third-quarter results by the end of October.
Among the eight major stock categories, only electronics shares and financial shares posted gains, ending the day with 0.6-percent and 0.1-percent gains, respectively.

The rest all reported losses, among which construction shares suffered the largest losses of 2.1 percent, followed by cement issues and plastics and chemical issues, both of which ending with 1.4-percent losses.
Declining stocks outnumbered advancing stocks 320 to 130, with 86 shares unchanged.
The over-the-counter market rose 0.71 points to close at 173.68 on a turnover of NT$5.92 billion.
All TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) opened lower but ended with small gains, except for next June futures.
TAIEX Index Futures for November moved up 1 point to close at 7,737 with 1,811 contract transactions. Those for December rose 5 points to finish at 7,735 with 43 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for next March advanced 44 points to close at 7,790 with five contract transactions, while those for next June shed six points to end at 7,790 with two contract transactions. Those for next September hiked 22 points to finish at 7,770 with two contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Wednesday were 7,736 points for November, 7,730 points for December, 7,746 points for next March, 7,796 points for next June, and 7,748 points for next September.
Electronics futures and financial futures, which are sub-index futures and based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares (TE) and financial shares (TF), reported mixed results.
November TE futures gained 2.3 points to close at 366.9 with 272 contract transactions; December TE futures shed 0.6 point to end at 366.5 with three contract transactions.
There were no transaction records for March, June or September TE futures.
November TF futures moved up 1.6 points to close at 1,006.6 with 93 contract transactions, while TF futures for other months had no transaction records. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: ENTHUSIASM WANES FOR TAIWAN VISIT BY ARATS HEAD

TEXT.P: The people of Taiwan seem to be less enthusiastic about a planned visit by mainland China's top negotiator with Taiwan, according to the results of a survey released on Wednesday.

The survey, conducted by National Chung Cheng University and commissioned by the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), shows that 61.6 percent of those surveyed still welcome a delayed visit by Wang Daohan, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).

But the figure was down 25.3 percent from a similar survey conducted in August, with some 69 percent of the respondents saying that it is unreasonable for the mainland to set preconditions for the visit.
MAC Vice Chairman Lin Chong-pin said the main reason behind the waning support for Wang's visit is probably linked to Beijing's stalling and setting of preconditions to the visit.

Beijing demands that Taiwan retract President Lee Teng-hui's redefinition of cross-strait ties as "a state-to-state relationship," and that Lee must meet Wang in his capacity as chairman of the ruling Kuomintang and not as president of the country.

The survey also found that 57.2 percent of those polled believe that mainland China's assistance in the wake of the Sept. 21 earthquake was politically motivated, and that 54.9 percent said they do not think mainland China's donation of US$100,000 in the wake of the Sept. 21 killer jolt was a goodwill gesture at all.
Up to 85 percent said that it was unreasonable for the mainland to ask foreign countries to seek prior approval from Beijing before sending specialized rescue teams to search for quake survivors.

The survey also found that only 10.1 percent polled consider themselves Chinese, down 3 percent from the August survey. Some 39.7 percent said they consider themselves Taiwanese, and some 45.7 percent said they are both Taiwanese and Chinese.
The university conducted the survey among people over the age of 20 between Oct. 13 and 17, and obtained 1,119 valid replies.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CRITICIZED FOR MISHANDLING PIRACY CASES

TEXT.P: The Singapore owner of the tanker Petro Ranger, which was found in the South China Sea after a hijacking, has strongly criticized mainland Chinese authorities over this and other piracy incidents, reported The Business Times Wednesday.
The Malaysian-registered tanker was hijacked off the east coast of peninsular Malaysia on April 16 of last year.

The tanker was intercepted off the island of Haikou by mainland Chinese authorities while transferring its cargo of diesel and kerosene to another ship, 10 days after it had gone missing. The authorities detained the ship's crew and 12 suspected Indonesian pirates found aboard the vessel and also confiscated the cargo.

"These seem to be a pattern of expediently slapping a label of smuggling in order to confiscate cargo," said Alan Chan, chairman of Petroships, in a strongly worded keynote speech at a piracy seminar organized by the Singapore Shipping Association (SSA) last week.
Mainland officials have previously charged that the Petro Ranger and some crew members were involved in smuggling.

"Despite the murky picture, it can be surmised that a plot is hatched in Southern China for cargo to be 'obtained' and delivered. In those cases where the hijackers get caught, the cargo is too good to be returned to its rightful owners," alleged Chan.

The tanker was carrying a cargo of 10,000 tons of diesel and kerosene estimated to be worth US$1.5 million. "Our stand is that the cargo or its auction proceeds belongs to the rightful cargo owners in Vietnam," he said.

Another speaker, Jayant Abhyankar, deputy director of the International Maritime Bureau (IMB), also repeated statements he made last month that Southern China had "safe ports" where hijacked ships could berth and unload cargo without any questions being asked.
Despite the accusations leveled by Chan at mainland Chinese authorities, there are signs that the mainland is acting to clamp down on cases of hijacked ships found in the country's waters.

Thawatchai Simaroj, managing director of Siam Monkol Marine, told the conference that the mainland returned its hijacked cargo ship the Siam Xan Xan on Oct. 19, along with US$1 million in cash, proceeds from the sale of the ship's cargo.
The 12 suspected Indonesian pirates have been charged with smuggling and could face the death penalty if found guilty.
Abhyankar told reporters that the news that mainland Chinese authorities had charged the suspected hijackers was a "very welcome move".
He added that they hoped to see a decline in incidents as a direct result of such tough action by the mainland authorities. (by Sherman Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: 15 PEOPLE INDICTED FOR JERRY-BUILDING CONDOMINIUM

TEXT.P: Fifteen people were indicted Wednesday on charges which included accidental killing, after nearly 40 people died in the rubble of the collapsed "Doctors' Home" residential building when a devastating earthquake hit Taiwan on Sept. 21.

Chen Ming-hsiang of the district prosecutor's office in Panchiao filed the indictment after an investigation into the deadly incident implied that it was mainly caused by the building's fragile structure as a result of builders cutting corners on construction.
In the rubble of the collapsed condominium, located in Hsinchuang in suburban Taipei, rescuers had found metal cooking-oil containers in major pillars of the jerry-built structure.

Chen said the 15 people, including the architect Lien Chih-chien and several co-owners of the construction company that built the ill-fated condominium, should each be punished with the maximum sentence of seven and a half years' imprisonment.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD ESTIMATES PRIVATE SECTOR CONSUMPTION WILL DECREASE BY NT$ 26 B.

TEXT.P: Private sector consumption will decrease by NT$26 billion, and the real growth rate will be set at 5.2 percent, a new low since 1981, according to an estimate released on Wednesday by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).

Hu Chung-ying, director of the CEPD's Economic Research Department, said that Taiwan's economic growth rate will decrease by 0.4 percent to 5.3 percent as a result of the earthquake which jolted Taiwan on Sept. 21, claiming more than 2,400 lives. Taiwan's trade surplus is expected to exceed US$10 billion as of the end of 1999, as the earthquake has affected domestic demand more than foreign demand.
Public sector consumption will show negative growth of 3.7 percent.

Private sector capital investment will also decrease by NT$9.4 billion for a 2.7 percent growth in real terms, and public sector investment will increase 7.3 percent. In general terms, fixed capital investment will drop slightly by 0.2 percent to 3.7 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE RECEIVES OKLAHOMA GOVERNOR

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui received Governor Frank Keating of the US state of Oklahoma at the presidential office on Wednesday.

Lee first expressed his heartfelt gratitude to Keating for the condolences and concern for Taiwan's "921 Earthquake" victims that he had communicated immediately following the quake and for his visit to Taiwan to personally express his sympathy.

Lee said that shortly after the occurrence of the 921 Earthquake, Taiwan's Central Weather Bureau detected the epicenter within two minutes, and the army rushed to quake-stricken zones to proceed with the rescue work within two hours.

Lee said the top priority of quake relief work was to rescue people trapped under the rubble. It took four to five days to complete that most difficult task. The rescue work was followed by the promulgation of an emergence decree to expedite resettlement of quake victims and reconstruction of quake-stricken zones.
He said he believed that under joint efforts made by the government and the people of Taiwan, the island's post-quake reconstruction will be completed soon.
Keating said that soon after he took the post of Oklahoma state governor, the massive explosion at an Oklahoma office building occurred, resulting in significant casualties.

This year, his state suffered from a powerful tornado that caused heavy losses of life and property, Keating said, adding that he is willing to share his experience in dealing with natural and human-made disasters for the Taiwan government's reference in post-quake reconstruction.

Before their discussion, Keating presented Lee with a check for US$30,000 that had been donated by overseas Chinese in Oklahoma for quake relief. Lee extended his gratitude and said he will send the check to the Cabinet's post-921 quake reconstruction foundation.

Keating was accompanied by Vice Foreign Minister David Lee and Director Raymond Burghardt of the American Institute in Taiwan while meeting with Lee. Also present were Ding Mou-shih, senior adviser to the president, and Lin Pi-chao, deputy secretary general to the president.

DOC.HEADLINE: ICELAND TRADE DELEGATION TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A trade delegation from Iceland will arrive in Taipei Thursday for a business promotion visit, said the China External Trade Development Council on Wednesday.
The delegation comprises manufacturers and traders of frozen fish products, mineral water and computer software, and representatives of the telecommunications and investment consultation industries.
The delegation will hold a business exhibition and investment consulting meeting at the exhibition hall of the Taipei World Trade Center on Friday.
Those local traders who are interested in trade with Iceland are invited to attend the meeting.
Iceland, situated in the North Atlantic, is noted for its abundant fish products and related industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER VISITING DOMINICAN REPUBLIC

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu, leading a business delegation, arrived in the Dominican Republic Monday for a three-day visit, according to a Wednesday press release from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

The press release said that Hu called on Dominican Republic Foreign Minister Eduardo Latorre, and both sides discussed the progress of several cooperation projects currently underway between the two nations.

Hu and his counterpart then signed a protocol for agreements on cooperation in the fields of medical care, forestry, agriculture and education, and a memorandum on the Republic of China helping the Dominican Republic build an information and technology industrial park.
Hu then called on Dominican President Leonel Fernandez, conveying greetings from President Lee Teng-hui, Vice President Lien Chan and Premier Vincent Siew.
Hu also thanked Fernandez for his concern and support during his visit to the Republic of China in the wake of the devastating Sept. 21 earthquake.
The Dominican president, who visited Taiwan on Sept. 27 for a three-day state visit, was the first foreign leader to visit the island after the killer jolt.
Fernandez expressed his appreciation for ROC government encouragement of businesses to invest in his country and for ROC assistance in developing the nation's technology.

He also expressed concern for the two brothers in Taiwan who were miraculously saved after being trapped under the wreckage of a multi-story building for nearly six days after the massive temblor last month.
The president, who visited the brothers at a hospital during his stay in Taiwan, again extended his invitation that they visit the Dominican Republic for a holiday.

While in the Dominican Republic, Hu toured a technology institute and an export processing zone, and attended a computer exhibition and the ground-breaking ceremony of an information and technology industrial park presided over by President Fernandez.
After concluding his stay in the Dominican Republic, Hu flew to Panama on Wednesday to continue the trip.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY HOPES TO RAISE MAXIMUM FINE FOR DRUNK DRIVING TO US$ 2,830

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday that city representatives will consult with the central government to raise the maximum fine for drunk driving to NT$90,000 (US$2,830).
Ma said raising the maximum fine is not aimed at confrontation, explaining that the city's intention is the same as that of the central government -- to curb drunk driving by imposing a stiff fine.
Ma made the remarks in a radio interview during which he explained the intention to raise the fine for drunk driving and to regulate places that serve alcohol.

The Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) had proposed that the fine be raised from the present NT$15,000 (US$472) to NT$45,000 (US$1,415). But Ma has proposed that the fine be set between NT$30,000 and NT$90,000 because Taipei is a city with high per-capita income, compared with the rest of the island, and if the fine is kept too low, then it will have no intimidating effect.

Ma stressed that the city is not trying to confront the central government, adding that city officials have held discussions with the MOTC to set the fine at between NT$15,000 and NT$90,000, so that Taipei City can adopt the maximum standard.

Ma also explained about regulating places that provide alcoholic drinks, saying that several states in the United States, such as New York, California, Indiana and Michigan, have laws stating that bars which provide alcohol must shoulder some social responsibility for drunk driving.
Ma said that raising the maximum fine for drunk driving is one option being mulled by the city, and another is extending the period for suspension of driver's licenses from six months to a year.
The government is considering raising the fine for drunk driving in the wake of several fatal accidents in recent days that involved drunk driving.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD-FAMOUS GOLFERS TO OFFER CLUBS, BAGS FOR CHARITY TOURNEY

TEXT.P: The Johnnie Walker Classic Golf Charity Tournament will be held at the Ta Shee Golf and Country Club Nov. 9-12.

A representative of the organizing committee said golf clubs and bags belonging to world-famous golfers, including Tiger Woods of the United States, will put up for sale on Nov. 11. Proceeds from the sale will be used as relief aid for 921 earthquake victims in central Taiwan.
The organizing committee decided at its meeting Wednesday that the charity items will be sold at prices ranging from NT$20,000 to NT$5 million. A breakdown of items and prices follows:
-- The honor of hosting the celebrity bar at a party on Nov. 12, to be sold at the price of NT$5 million;
-- Golf clubs offered by Tiger Woods, which will be sold for NT$4 million;
-- 45 minutes of golf instruction by Tiger Woods, quoted at a price of NT$500,000;
-- Qualification to participate in a professional-amateur pair match, with slots going for NT$20,000 each.
Admission tickets for a charity party to be held on Nov. 12 will be sold for NT$1,500 each.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WELCOMES ACTION FAVORABLE TO SECURITY: ROC MINISTER

TEXT.P: Republic of China Defense Minister Tang Fei said on Wednesday that the ROC government welcomes any foreign action that is helpful for the island's security.
Tang made the remarks to legislators while commenting on the passage of the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act (TSEA) by the US House International Relations Committee on Tuesday.
The defense minister was visiting the caucuses of all political parties at the Legislative Yuan to seek their support for bills on the national defense organizational law and the coast guard law.
When asked to comment on the TSEA by the legislators, Tang said the Ministry of National Defense welcomes all bills and actions that will help strengthen Taiwan's security.
However, he told the lawmakers that "advanced weapons are important, but high morale is more important," and urged his countrymen to be determined to defend the country with their own strength.

Regarding the recent evaluation by a US research institute that mainland China is capable of gaining supremacy in the air over the Taiwan Strait in 45 minutes, Tang described that as "somewhat exaggerated."
He said that international military analysts have radically contradicting opinions on mainland China's military strength, and Taiwan's view is that over-estimate and under-estimate should be avoided.
Tang disclosed that in the coming three to five years, Beijing will spend over NT$300 billion (US$9.4 billion) to continue improving mainland military equipment.
If Taiwan becomes satisfied with the existing defense establishment, he said, it may lose its bargaining power with the mainland in the future.

When asked about the possibility of mainland Chinese military action against Taiwan before next March's presidential election, Tang said that judging from the domestic and international situations, it seems unlikely that the mainland would attack Taiwan during this period.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE URGES WORLD TO GIVE TAIWAN ITS DUE

TEXT.P: Saying Taiwan's rapid developments in democracy, economy and prosperity have outstripped prevailing perceptions of what Taiwan is, President Lee Teng-hui urged the world to update its view of the island and fit it properly into the global order.

In an article published in the US-based bimonthly Foreign Affairs on Wednesday, Lee regretted that his idea of the "new Taiwanese" -- referring to those who live in Taiwan and are willing to fight for their country's prosperity and survival -- has not been fully understood by the world, especially by Beijing.

Dismissing as a "straw man" Beijing's claim that Taiwan is a "renegade province," Lee said Being has never exercised jurisdiction over the island and has no legal claim to the island under international law.
Lee pointed out in his article that the Republic of China (ROC) in Taiwan has remained a sovereign state since 1912, and it is the world's 19th-largest economy and the 15th-largest trading country.
In the 50 years since the People's Republic of China was founded, both sides of the Taiwan Strait have been ruled separately, with neither subordinate to the other, said Lee.
He regretted that these facts have been distorted by Beijing and overlooked by the international community.

Defending his claim regarding Taiwan's state-status, Lee said Taiwan would place itself in an unequal position in negotiations with Beijing by calling itself -- as it did before -- a "political entity," which is not in accordance with reality.
When any two states conduct a dialogue, they do so on an equal basis, and there is no reason for the cross-strait dialogue to be any different, said Lee.
Besides Beijing's reluctance to engage with Taiwan on the basis of parity, Lee said there are three remaining obstacles to be overcome before cross-strait relations can flourish, namely:
-- the lack of mutual trust between Taipei and Beijing: people in Taiwan remain highly suspicious of the Chinese communists;
--mainland authorities' refusal to renounce the use of force as a means to solve the Taiwan Strait issue, which has intensified calls in Taiwan for declaring independence; and

-- the vast differences between the two sides of Taiwan Strait caused by five decades of separate rule, especially the authoritarian nature of the communist regime, which has alienated the people of Taiwan from the Chinese mainland.

Noting that it is not in anyone's interest to aggravate cross-strait tensions, Lee reiterated that the ROC government is willing to take a pragmatic approach toward improving relations with Beijing, and will not rule out discussing political issues once meetings with Beijing resume on a basis of parity.

That is where the international community has a crucial role to play, first by updating its perceptions of what has taken place on Taiwan, and according Taiwan the international status it deserves, said Lee.
Lee is the first ROC President ever to write for the magazine, which is published by the US Council on Foreign Relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CONSORTIUM TO ACQUIRE FOODSTUFF MANUFACTURER IN HONDURAS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's giant foodstuff manufacturer President Enterprises Corp. will acquire 50-percent stakes in Honduras' largest food firm Cressida in a deal worth US$100 million.

President Enterprises will come up with US$90 million for the venture, with the other US$10 million coming from the Taiwan-based Central American Development Company, said Kao Chin-yen, chairman of President Enterprises on Wednesday.

Cressida, which produces non-alcoholic beverages, food products and detergents, is expected to yield profits of US$30 million to US$40 million from among revenues of US$230 million in the first year after the takeover, said Kao.

DOC.HEADLINE: MA, CHEN HONORED AMONG 20 YOUNG ASIAN POLITICAL LEADERS BY HK WEEKLY
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Oct. 27 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and the presidential candidate of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party Chen Shui-bian are among 20 young political leaders in Asia honored by a Hong Kong weekly.
The English-language Asia Week said the 20 young leaders were all born after World War II. Within 10 years, the publication predicted, they will rise to prominence that nobody dare ignore.

The magazine's reports said that after Ma was elected Taipei Mayor, he earned a reputation as "Mr. Integrity," adding that the 49-year-old has become an important policy maker under President Lee Teng-hui, and a major player in the formation of Taiwan's present policy toward mainland China.

The reports also said that Chen, who lost his Taipei mayorship to Ma, has not ceased political activities, having entered the presidential election as the candidate of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party.

In addition to Ma and Chen, the 18 young leaders in Asia are Priyanka Gandhi, 27, the next torchbearer of the Gandhi dynasty; Chandrababu Naidu, 49, chief minister of Andhra Pradesh from India; Kazuo Shii, 45, secretary of the Japanese Communist Party; Yoshimi Watanabe, 47, Liberal Democratic Party lawmaker; and Seiko Noda, 39, LDP Lawmaker and former Minister of Post & Telecommunications from Japan.

Hishammuddin Tun Hussein, 38, acting United Malays National Organization Youth chief; and Lim Guan Eng, 38, Democratic Action Party deputy secretary-general from Malaysia; Chaturon Chaisang, 43, New Aspiration Party secretary general; Abhisit Vejiajiva, 35, Minister to Prime Minister's Office from Thailand.

Leung Chun-ying from Hong Kong; Munir from Indonesia, 33, human rights activist and lawyer; Choo Mi Ae, 41, former judge, National Congress for New Politics lawmaker; and Kim Min Seok, 35, former student activist from South Korea; Teo Chee Hean, 44, Education Minister; and George Yeo Yong Boon, 45, Trade and Industry Minister from Singapore.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Thursday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
President Lee stresses importance of quality control in post-quake reconstruction projects.
The China Times:
Earthquake seen to shatter 1999 economic growth by 0.2 percent to 0.5 percent; The 2000 growth, however, is predicted to reach 6 percent.
The United Daily News:
Armenian prime minister killed in parliament shooting; Five other officials and parliamentarians were also dead and several dozens of lawmakers were held hostage by gunmen.
The Liberty Times:
The two sides of the Taiwan Strait should treasure their special state-to-state relations, says President Lee Teng-hui.
The Commons Daily:
More than 60 National Assembly deputies covertly support former Taiwan Governor James Soong, casting a shadow on Kuomintang's prospects in upcoming presidential election.
The China Post:
US House panel bill boosts military ties; ROC government officials cautiously welcome security package approval.
The Taiwan News:
Key indicators drop first time in seven months -- Index reflects quake's economic damage; Rebound expected on demand for exports.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER TO SIGN VOLUNTARY SERVICE PACT WITH PANAMA
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Oct. 27 (CNA) (By H. T. Chung and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu is scheduled to sign an agreement with the Panamanian government Thursday on voluntary service between the two countries.

Hu, who is scheduled to arrive in Panama Wednesday evening, will also meet with ranking Panamanian officials, including newly-inaugurated President Mireya Moscoso, to exchange views on matters of mutual concern, sources from the ROC Embassy in Panama said.

Under the voluntary service agreement, Taiwan will send volunteers to Panama to work in rural areas to help improve farmers' living and educational standards and to promote public sanitation, the embassy officials said.
Currently, the ROC has volunteers working in Honduras, Costa Rica and Senegal.
During his stay in Panama, Hu will also meet with his Panamanian counterpart, Minister Jose Miguel Aleman, in an effort to bolster bilateral ties between Taiwan and Panama.
Hu vowed recently in Taipei that he "would not allow the devastating Sept. 21 earthquake to shake Taiwan's diplomacy."
His visit to Panama is of particular significance as rumors abound that mainland China is close to forging formal diplomatic relations with Panama.
Before proceeding to Panama, Hu, heading a Taiwanese business delegation, stopped in the Dominican Republic for a three-day visit.
During the visit, Hu met with President Leonel Fernandez, Foreign Minister Eduardo Latorre and other officials for discussions on ways to further strengthen bilateral cooperation.

Hu and Latorre signed a protocol for agreements on cooperation in the fields of medical care, forestation, agriculture and education, as well as a memorandum on the ROC helping the Dominican Republic build an information and technology industrial park.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Oct. 28, or the 20th day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important event that have occurred on this date in the past:
1492: Christopher Columbus discovers Cuba on his first voyage to the New World, and claims it in the name of Spain.
1636: Harvard College is founded at Cambridge by the General Court of Massachusetts on the comparatively modest sum of US$740, part of US$1,440 bequeathed to the college by Mr. John Harvard, assistant pastor of the First Church of Charleston.
1746: An earthquake completely destroys Lima and Callao in Peru, killing more than 18,000 people.
1794: Robert Liston, the Scottish doctor who performed the first operation in Britain on an anesthetized patient, is born.
1831: English physicist and chemist Michael Faraday succeeds in inventing a device that converts mechanical energy into electrical energy.
1886: A statue called Liberty Enlightening the World, the largest present ever sent to the American people from the French, is inaugurated on Liberty Island in the Upper Bay of New York Harbor by President Grover Cleveland.
1891: Strong earthquake rocks the Niphon Islands in Japan, killing 10,000 people and leaving more than 300,000 others homeless.
1901: Taiwan's first Shinto shrine is inaugurated on Yuanshan in Taipei during Japanese colonial rule of Taiwan.
1912: Sir Richard Doll, the British cancer researcher who proved the link between cigarette smoking and lung cancer, is born.
1914: Jonas Salk, the American microbiologist who developed a polio vaccine, is born.
1914: George Eastman, American inventor and industrialist, announces a color photographic process, following his invention in 1888 of the Kodak camera, containing wind-on celluloid film to replace the paper-based film he patented in 1884.
1918: Czechoslovakia becomes independent upon the dissolution of Austria-Hungary.
1950: Finland establishes diplomatic relations with communist China.
1953: A launch ceremony for the first batch of US-provided fishing boats to Taiwan is held in the southern port city of Kaohsiung.
1962: Soviet leader Nikita Krushchev informs US President John F. Kennedy that work on missile sites under construction in Cuba will be halted and that missiles already delivered will be shipped back to the USSR.
1966: Wu Chen-nan, former leader of the "Taiwan Independence Revolutionary Council" in Japan, returns to Taiwan.
1971: The British House of Commons votes in favor of joining the European Economic Community by a vote of 356-244.
1972: Two pandas, a gift from communist China to Japan, arrive at the Ueno zoo in Tokyo.
1977: Taiwan's first experimental geothermal power plant goes into operation in Ilan.
1982: Felipe Gonzales, 40, becomes Spain's first socialist prime minister in a landslide victory.
1989: More than 10,000 rally in protest of the government on the 71st anniversary of Czechoslovakia's independence.
1992: Australian Tourism and Resources Minister Alan Griffiths visits Taipei to promote closer bilateral trade relations. He is the first Australian minister to visit Taipei since 1972.
1993: An explosion occurs at Taiwan Power Company's Hsintienlun power plant in central Taiwan, killing six people and injuring 26 others.
1993: Communist China resumes trade relations, cut off since July, 1960, with South Africa.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "He who attends to his smaller self becomes a small man, and he who attends to his greater self becomes a great man."

DOC.HEADLINE: RENOWNED JAPANESE WRITER SONO BRINGS CASH DONATION TO QUAKE VICTIMS

TEXT.P: Renowned Japanese writer Ayako Sono arrived in Taipei Thursday, bringing with her a considerable cash donation and immeasurable compassion for Taiwan's earthquake victims.

Sono, a devout Catholic and prolific writer, is expected to make a donation of 300 million yen (US$2.88 million) to help beef up post-quake rehabilitation efforts in central Taiwan, according to sources from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

She was accompanied by representatives of five Japanese business conglomerates. They will proceed to Taichung and Nantou counties -- the hardest hit areas of the devastating Sept. 21 earthquake -- to gain a better understanding of the plight of the residents there in the aftermath of the quake.
Sono, in her early sixties, is the wife of former Education Minister Shumon Miura, who is also a devout Catholic.
