DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CITIES VIE FOR HI-TECH ZONE

TEXT.P: Fierce competition has broken out between Beijing, Shenzhen and the Pudong district of Shanghai to operate the mainland's first hi-tech export processing zone, according to the South China Morning Post today.

A report by the paper quoted a source in Beijing as saying that the leaders of the three cities had lobbied top leaders, including President Jiang Ze-min and Premier Zhu Rong-ji, for funds to start the hi-tech export zone, which will enjoy special privileges, including low taxes.
Leaders, including Zhu, have ruled that only one such zone will be allowed to develop in the foreseeable future in order to avoid duplication.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOBEL LAUREATE IN TOWN FOR MEETING

TEXT.P: Chinese American physicist and Nobel laureate Chen-ning Yang is currently visiting Taipei, mainly to lobby for upgrading the functions of Taiwan's sole theoretical science center.

Yang, Nobel Prize co-winner with another Chinese American Tsung-dao Lee for physics in 1957, attended a meeting at the National Science Council (NSC) to push for efforts to upgrade the National Center for Theoretical Sciences (NCTS), a "virtual" research center temporarily located at National Tsinghua University, into a formally standing science organization.

If the NCTS, currently under the auspices of the NSC, is transformed into a real research center with regular staff and budget, it could become an important hub for scientific research in Asia, with Taiwan's solid scientific and technological research background, Yang noted.
He added that in Asia, the countries of Japan, South Korea and mainland China have similar establishments.
Yang, who became the top adviser to the NCTS when the center was established three years ago, retired from his professorship at the State University of New York at Stone Brook in May.

Yang was chosen by South Korea in 1996 to head the Seoul-based Asia Pacific Center for Theoretical Physics because of his past contributions to scientific development in the region and his towering stature in physics.

DOC.HEADLINE: "ONE COUNTRY, TWO SYSTEMS" SAID GOOD FOR TIBET, XINJIANG

TEXT.P: If Beijing claims that what it learned in Hong Kong ensures the success of the "one country, two systems" formula in Taiwan, then perhaps what Communist China learns in Macao in adopting the same formula can also be applied in Tibet and Xinjiang, argued an American Asia specialist Wednesday.

Mark Moore, a research associate at the Washington-based Center for Strategic and International Studies recently wrote that because of certain similarities to minority communities on the mainland, Macao's return to Chinese sovereignty on Dec. 20 might prove a unique lens through which to foresee how Beijing could someday apply a "one country, two systems" policy to Tibet and Xinjiang.

In his article in the recent issue of "Hong Kong Update," Moore said the two unique religious and cultural groups found on the mainland, Buddhist Tibetans and Muslim Uighers, have been a constant source of irritation to the Communist Chinese government. Separatist movements have arisen in Tibet and Xinjiang and the regions are usually mentioned as the most likely dominoes that could fall should Taiwan succeed in its claims for independence.

The Tibetan's and Uigher's long-standing disagreement is based on the limitations on freedom of language and religion imposed by Beijing. An interesting contradiction emerges when one compares Macao's Basic Law with long-standing language policies in Tibet and Xinjiang, pointed out Moore.

Macao's Basic Law states that both Portuguese and Chinese will be official languages even though less than ten percent of the population of 450,000 is Portuguese. And of the estimated 88,000 students enrolled in secondary and primary schools there, more than 40,000 are attending and will continue to attend Catholic schools, resulting in Catholicism retaining some measure of social significance, wrote the specialist

Moore stressed that if Beijing boasts Macao is a second testament to the "one country, two systems" formula's success, then perhaps Tibet and Xinjiang can view language and religious tolerance in Macao with hope.

"The argument can be made that if Beijing claims what it learned in Hong Kong ensures success in Taiwan, then perhaps what it learns in Macao can also be applied in Tibet and Xinjiang," Moore concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA SET TO INCREASE INTEREST RATES

TEXT.P: The Reserve Bank of Australia is set to raise its official interest rates following the release of a higher-than-expected inflationary rate in the third quarter of 1999.

The Australian Bureau of Statistics on Wednesday reported the annual inflation rate, measured by the Consumer Price Index, jumped 1.7 percent between July 1 and September 30, the highest increase in four years.

RBA Governor Ian Macfarlane, in a statement faxed to the CNA, indicated that the interest rates are set to rise, as soon as next week by about 0.25 percentage points. The current official rate is 4.75 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA-INDONESIA TENSIONS EASE AFTER MEETING

TEXT.P: Tensions between Australia and Indonesia are showing signs of easing following a 45-minute meeting in Jakarta between newly elected President Abdurrahman Wahid and the Australian ambassador to Indonesia.

Australian media on Thursday quoted Australian Ambassador John McCarthy as saying the latest development was much different from a month ago when Australia was solely blamed by Indonesia for its leading role in East Timor.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIBERAL LEADER, 3 FORMER PMs JOIN TO PROMOTE REPUBLIC

TEXT.P: A few leaders of the Labor Party and the Liberal Party have joined hands to promote the "yes" vote for a republic in the upcoming referendum after Prime Minister John Howard strongly advocated for the monarchist system.
A new public poll shows the support for a republic has fallen behind backing for maintaining the present political system with its ties to Britain.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI TO GATHER 3,500 SETS OF TWINS TO FORM "HOPE TREE"

TEXT.P: The Taipei City government is calling for twins from all over Taiwan to join its "big tree-building" event, aimed at focusing public attention on parent-child relations.

The city government and co-sponsor Taipei Twins Association hope at least 3,500 sets of twins will gather on the square in front of City Hall on Nov. 12 to be positioned in formation to create a record-breaking "big tree" signaling "hope," said city officials Thursday.

At a press conference, Taiwan's oldest twins, nicknamed A-Shun and A-Jou, were invited to speak about their life experience. The twin grandmothers are now over 80 years old, and both are in good shape.

Taiwan's famous show business twins, Lee Chih-hsi and Chih-chi, also took part in the press conference to help publicize the call for event participants and to support the association's attempt to build a twins data bank for the island.

In hosting the Nov. 12 event, the association hopes the anticipated number of 3,500 sets of twins will help Taiwan achieve a new Guinness world record for gathering the most twins. The current record is held by the United States for bringing together 2,900 sets of twins.

According to the Taichung-based Guinness Museum of World Records, existing world records related to twins include one that was set by Peggy Lynn of Pennsylvania in the United States. On Nov. 11, 1995, Lynn gave birth to a girl, whose twin brother was not born until 84 days later.
The world's oldest twins are Kin-san and Gin-san of Japan, aged 107, according to the museum, which also houses information on the world's shortest, tallest, and heaviest twins.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SAVINGS RATE STILL DECLINING: CEPD

TEXT.P: Taiwan's saving rate has continued to decline over the past 10 years, signaling a possible change in the government's approach to securing financial backup, said Taiwan's top official in charge of economic planning Thursday.
P.K. Chiang, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), said Taiwan's annual savings rate declined to 23.5 percent in 1998 from 38.5 percent in 1987.
Taiwan's average annual savings rate, 27.7 percent between 1988 and 1998, is much lower than Japan's 31.5 percent, South Korea's 33.6 percent and Singapore's 46 percent, Chiang noted.

Chiang attributed Taiwan's declining savings rate to rising household spending, expanded government spending coupled with slow growth of government revenue, and declining savings in the private business and industrial sectors.

Citing the fact that abundant cash savings in the private sector had been one of the most important sources of government financing in the past, Chiang said the reduction of savings is now having an indirect impact on Taiwan's out-bound investment and government ability to maintain mid-level economic growth.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose 0.004 to close at 31.743 against the greenback on Thursday on the Taipei foreign exchange market.
The currency opened at the day's low of 31.743, and had a high of 31.737. Interbank US dollar trading reached US$271 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: M'LAND DISTILLERS PROHIBITED FROM RICE WINE BIDDING

TEXT.P: Mainland China distillers have been prohibited from taking part in rice wine bidding sponsored by the Taiwan Tobacco and Wine Monopoly Bureau, said a bureau official Thursday.

According to regulations stipulated by the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) of the Ministry of Economic Affairs, Taiwan has prohibited import of wine or related products from mainland China, and it is therefore impossible for mainland distillers to bid, according to the official.
Other foreign distillers interested in bidding should submit rice wine samples along with certificates of product originality for approval, the official said.
The official made the statements in response to news reports that mainland distillers were planning to take part in the bidding via Hong Kong.

The bureau has planned to import 15 million bottles of rice wine through the international bidding process, which is to be conducted by China Trust Corp.; further details will be made public in mid-November.
If everything goes smoothly, the first batch of 5 million bottles of rice wine will arrive in Taiwan at the end of December.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DOWN FOR FIFTH STRAIGHT DAY, INDEX FUTURES LOWER

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed down slightly Thursday as investors stayed on the sidelines for lack of new incentives.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index dipped 19.37 points, or 0.3 percent, to close at 7,681.85 on a turnover of NT$61 billion (US$1.92 billion).
The market open higher but finished lower after news of a downward correction to this year's economic growth rate sparked caution among investors.

Dealers expect further directionless consolidation on Friday and Saturday amid persistent concerns over third-quarter corporate results, but the index is expected to escape the recent consolidation to start a solid trend next week since most investors still see a sound outlook for the economy in 2000.

Only the plastics and chemical sector displayed a positive performance, ending the day with 0.81-percent gains, while the electronics and financial sectors showed early strength but lost steam amid late selling.
Financial issues, which had rallied for three straight sessions, once rose 0.91 percent but ended with a 0.48 percent decline as investors locked in recent profits.
Construction shares, cement issues and paper-making stocks suffered from serious losses of 2.23 percent, 2.2 percent and 1.93 percent, respectively.
Declining stocks led advancing stocks 323 to 133, with 81 shares unchanged.
The over-the-counter market shed 0.86 points to close at 172.82 on a turnover of NT$5.53 billion.

Discouraged by the negative performance of the stock market and weak investor confidence, all TAIEX International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) posted losses, among which next March futures suffered the largest losses.
TAIEX Index Futures for November moved down 10 points to close at 7,727 with 1,150 contract transactions. Those for December shed 4 points to finish at 7,731 with 25 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for next March dipped 34 points to close at 7,756 with two contract transactions, while those for next June remained unchanged to close at 7,790 with one contract transaction. Those for next September dropped 10 points to end at 7,739. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: REESTABLISHMENT OF TAIPEI-MANILA AIR LINKS STILL FAR FROM REACH

TEXT.P: A new turn in talks between Taiwan and the Philippines over reestablishment of air links between the two sides has made resolution of the issue intangible once again, said government officials on Thursday.

The Philippine government reportedly earlier agreed to officially recognize the air agreement signed in 1996 between Taipei and Manila, probably due to the fact that Philippine Airlines (PAL) on Wednesday urged the Philippine Foreign Ministry to immediately recognize the agreement.

The 1996 Air Service Agreement, signed by the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) and its counterpart the Manila Economic and Cultural Office (MECO), was terminated by the Philippine Civil Aeronautics Board (PCAB) in late September when the dispute reached an impasse.

Leo Li-ming Sung, PAL's adviser in Taipei, on Wednesday reinterpreted the PCAB's previous decision by saying that only the subcontract involving passenger quotas was terminated, rather than the main agreement, which is therefore still in effect.
The development was reportedly seen by Taipei as a "nice gesture."

However, Sung changed his tune on Thursday by saying that no written recognition of the 1996 air agreement by the government is necessary, since members of the Philippine aviation panel appeared last week before the Legislative Yuan explaining Manila's position on the air talks, and inviting Taipei to restart direct flights while they are working on a new air agreement.

In response to the capricious attitude of the Philippines, officials of the Republic of China Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) said that negotiations can be resumed only if the Philippines notifies Taipei officially in written form that the 1996 air agreement is still in effect and immediately resumes the original quota of 9,600 passengers allowed to be transported per week.
This being the case, another stalemate has thus resulted. The issue between Taipei and Manila has come back to where it started.

Under the 1996 agreement, each side is allowed to transport up to 9,600 passengers per week, but Manila demanded that this number be slashed to just 3,000. Taipei previously agreed to lower it to 6,500, a figure that was not accepted by Manila.

Franklin Ebdalin, Philippine foreign assistant secretary and a member of Manila's Civil Aeronautics Board, visited Taipei earlier this month for talks on passenger quotas. Weekly passenger volumes remain the most contentious point at issue, and no concrete solution has been in sight to date.
In addition, it has been confirmed by Sung that Taiwan will not send a delegation to Manila for air links negotiations next week.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT'S RELIEF EFFORTS PRAISED: POLL

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan's performance in dealing with post-quake relief and reconstruction affairs has won the public's praise, according to survey results released Thursday.

Researchers from Shih Hsin University in Taipei contacted qualified voters around Taiwan on Oct. 23 and 24. A total of 1,093 effective responses were collected, and the margin of error was 3.03 percent.

The results show that more than 70 percent of respondents thought Lien has dealt "well" or "OK" with relief and reconstruction affairs in the aftermath of the Sept. 21 earthquake, in which 2,400 people died and many thousands were injured or made homeless.
Fifty-five percent of those surveyed said they believed Lien's performance in the relief effort will benefit his campaign for presidency in the 2000 election.

When asked who they would support if the presidential election were held the following day, 24.8 percent of those polled answered that they would vote for former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong, 22.9 percent would select Lien, and 14.4 percent would cast their votes for former Taipei Mayor and opposition Democrative Progressive Party candidate Chen Shui-bian.
The margin between Soong and Lien has become smaller, compared with polls held before the "921 Earthquake," according to researchers with Shih Hsin's polling center.

As for the performance of the central and local governments in quake relief work one month after the temblor, the survey showed that 63.1 percent of those polled expressed satisfaction with the central government's relief efforts; 53.1 percent of respondents seemed satisfied with local governments' performance.
However, 60 percent of those polled said they are not familiar with the government's post-quake relief policies.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPERTS TO STUDY MAINLAND QUAKE EXPERIENCE

TEXT.P: About 50 Taiwanese citizens, including seismologists, architects and members of the Legislative Yuan, will travel to mainland China next week to gain expertise in earthquake-preparedness, the China Daily reported Thursday.

The report, quoting an official from the mainland's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), said the group will travel to Beijing and Tangshan, a city in northern Hebei Province that was hit by a devastating earthquake in 1976.
They will likely visit Shanghai as well, but it remained unclear whether ARATS President Wang Daohan would meet with them, the official said.
The multi-partisan delegation will include members from the New Party, the Kuomintang and the Democratic Progressive Party, said the official.

On Monday, seismologists from the mainland and Taiwan will hold discussions in Beijing on taking precautions against earthquakes and reducing the impact of such disasters, the report quoted a representative from the China Seismological Bureau as saying.

Some delegation members will also visit the Ministry of Civil Affairs and the Red Cross Society on Monday. The group will spend the next two days in Tangshan collecting information on how to undertake post-quake reconstruction, according to the report.
The Taiwan delegation will be the first of its kind to visit the mainland since the island was hit by a major earthquake on Sept. 21, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE PREDICTED TO BECOME CANADA'S 2ND LANGUAGE
DOC.DATELINE: Ottawa, Oct. 27 (CNA) (By S.C. Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Chinese may have become Canada's second language by early next century, an expert has predicted.

Basing his study on the 1996 census results, Jack Jedwab, executive director of the Montreal Association of Canadian Studies, forecast in his new book -- Ethnic Identification and Heritage Languages in Canada -- that Chinese (Mandarin and Cantonese) will replace French as the second leading language in the whole of Canada except Quebec by 2001 when the Canadian government conducts its next census.
French was still the second-most common language in the so-called "English Canada" when the most recent census was held in 1996.

Around 86 percent of the population of "English Canada" speak English at home, while some 589,000, or 2.9 percent of the total, speak French at home, according to the book. At the same time, about 553,000 people speak Chinese, and the small difference between the Chinese- and French-speaking populations -- 36,000 -- will disappear by 2001, it claimed.

Ontario, the most multilingual and multi-ethnic province in Canada, will be the first province where Chinese will surpass French as the most-spoken second language, Jedwab predicted, as the 1996 census results show that the French-speaking population was only 13,000 greater than those speaking Chinese.

According to Jedwab, the upward trend in the popularity of Chinese is based on national trends, as the country's Chinese-speaking population is mainly scattered throughout Ontario and British Columbia.
Some 25 years ago, Italian was the third-most popular language in the country, while German and Ukrainian were also more popular than Chinese.

However, the rising number of ethnic Chinese immigrants from Taiwan, Hong Kong, mainland China and Southeast Asian countries since the 1980s means that Chinese is becoming increasingly popular in Canada.
During the period from 1991 to 1996, the number of ethnic Chinese in Canada increased by 42 percent, totaling 736,000. Currently, it totals more than 900,000.

Jedwab attributed the ability of ethnic Chinese to preserve their mother tongue in Canada to less integration into local mainstream society, and to the existence of their own Chinese-language media. For instance, in Toronto alone, there are three major Chinese-language newspapers, in addition to radio and television stations.

Charles Castonguay, a mathematics professor at Toronto University, however, was reserved about Jedwab's viewpoints, claiming that "the outcome of which language will become Canada's second language must wait until 2001 after the next census has been conducted."

Castonguay said he does not think that Chinese will replace French as Canada's second language, explaining that while the question of whether Chinese will become Canada's second language may only be a matter of time, the situation may also change as the sources of new immigrants into Canada changes.

DOC.HEADLINE: WRECKAGE OF DOWNED MIRAGE FIGHTER FOUND

TEXT.P: The fuselage of a crashed Mirage 2000-5 jet fighter belonging to the Republic of China Air Force was retrieved on Thursday off the coast of central Miaoli County.

Air force authorities said the wreckage of fighter No. 2053 will be sent to air force headquarters in northern Hsinchu County for an in-depth investigation into the cause of the accident, while the aircraft's black box, retrieved the day before, had been sent back to its French manufacturer for analysis of the recorded flight data.
An initial investigation has shown that the engine of the NT$2 billion fighter may have been damaged by birds during a routine training exercise on Oct. 15 off the coast of Hsinchu.
The plane went down into the sea at 6:11 p.m., and the two pilots were rescued by air force and marine police rescuers after ejecting safely.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVERGREEN GROUP TO BUILD 25 CONTAINER SHIPS
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Oct. 28 (CNA) (By Romulo Huang & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Evergreen Group will soon build 25 container ships, half to be managed by Lloyd Triestino Co., an Italian shipping company acquired by the Taiwan industry giant last October, according to a Wednesday report by the Journal of Commerce.

The New York-based daily quoted Evergreen Group President Chang Jung-fa as reporting that Evergreen was planning to build up Lloyd Triestino with its 42 Panamanian-registered container ships and by adding new ships and hiring new staff.
Of the 25 new vessels, 20 will have capacities of 3,000 TEU (twenty-foot-equivalent unit) and five will be 6,000-TEU capacity ships.

Evergreen Group acquired Lloyd Triestino for US$35 million and shouldered its US$100 million in debts last October, while permitting the Italian company to retain its name and operate as a sister company to Evergreen.
Lloyd Triestino will develop new services, including expanded service to mainland China. The company recently started weekly service linking mainland China, the Mediterranean and Northern Europe.

Chang was quoted as saying that Evergreen Group was also planning to merge Evergreen Marine Corp. (Taiwan) Ltd., the world's second largest container carrier, with Uniglory Marine Corp., an Evergreen subsidiary.
If the merger is approved by the government of the Republic of China, Uniglory would become an intra-Asia trade department within Evergreen Marine, Chang said.

Chang was also quoted as saying that Evergreen will further strengthen its cooperation with mainland China's state-run China Ocean Shipping Co. (COSCO), with which it operates joint service in the Far East, South Africa and South America. Uniglory operates joint service with COSCO between the Far East and the Middle East.

DOC.HEADLINE: FALUN GONG DETERMINED TO CHALLENGE BEIJING DESPITE CRACKDOWN

TEXT.P: The members of Falun Gong are determined to challenge Beijing's decision to outlaw their exercise and meditation, despite the full force of the state being pitted against them, Canada's The Globe and Mail reported on Thursday.

The newspaper described Falun Gong as "a New Age sect that has sent jitters through China's communist regime," whose security forces fanned out on Tiananmen Square on Wednesday in an attempt to further crack down on practitioners there.

Protests at Tiananmen Square have escalated in the past few days because mainland China's rulers, meeting in the Great Hall of the People just beside the square, are currently discussing how to make the sect illegal, the paper said in a dispatch from Beijing.

"The seven-year-old sect's influence on Chinese society is deeper than Beijing thought," the report said, noting that Falun Gong members have been found in the military, police apparatus, students and society at large.

The Ottawa Citizen, another major Canadian daily, said the escalation of the conflict over religious freedom has become an embarrassment for the communist Chinese leadership, which had claimed victory over the banned group after a crackdown this summer.

In Canada, Falun Gong practitioners from Montreal and other eastern Canada cities are set to gather in Montreal on Saturday "to bring attention to the Falun Gong situation in China and to call for immediate international assistance," organizers said.

The Canadian followers plan to provide information about "inhumane treatment and torture deaths of Falun Gong practitioners and the current crisis in China." They will march through downtown Montreal before pausing at Philips Square to an exercise exhibition.

Over 100 Falun Gong practitioners have gathered in Ottawa twice in the past month to call for international attention to mainland China's persecution of religious freedom and civil liberties. At least one member of parliament has agreed to support them by collecting the signatures of other MPs in a petition.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINES PROTESTS TO VIETNAM OVER SPRATLYS

TEXT.P: The Philippines on Wednesday filed a second diplomatic protest with Vietnam after Manila confirmed the ongoing expansion of Vietnamese facilities on a reef in the disputed Spratly island group in the South China Sea.
The protest also concerned the firing of shots at a Philippine military aircraft that flew over the atoll.

Foreign Affairs Secretary Domingo Siazon Jr. said Vietnam was upgrading facilities at Tennent Reef, and that on Oct. 13, a Philippine Air Force reconnaissance aircraft sent to confirm the sighting was fired upon by Vietnamese troops, although it was not hit.
The protest came two weeks after the Philippines issued a similar protest over the expansion by the Vietnamese of facilities at Osmena Reef and De Jesus Reef in the Kalayaan island group.

Foreign Affairs Under-secretary Benjamin Domingo summoned Vietnamese Ambassador Nguyen Thac Dinh on Wednesday to officially express the Philippine government's grave concern over the latest developments in the area.

"We view with greatest concern these recent acts of Vietnam, coming as they have only a day after the Philippines had expressed its concern over the improvement of structures by Vietnam on Osmena Reef and De Jesus Reef," Siazon said.

He added: "These acts, particularly the firing of shots at Philippine aircraft, are a clear assault on the letter and spirit of various regional, multilateral and bilateral agreements and declarations entered into by both the Philippine and Vietnamese governments."
Siazon stressed that Tennent Reef "forms part of Philippines territory and is within the country's exclusive economic zone."

Based on reconnaissance photographs, Siazon said the Vietnamese are erecting a three-story octagonal-shaped concrete building similar to other structures that have already been established in other Vietnamese-held reefs in the Spratlys.

"In the spirit of preserving close bilateral ties and ASEAN solidarity and cooperation, the Philippines earnestly requests the government of Vietnam to reconsider its most recent action in Tennent Reef," Siazon said.

DOC.HEADLINE: `STATE-TO-STATE' THEORY DESCRIBES `OBJECTIVE REALITY': LORD
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 27 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Former US Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs Winston Lord said on Wednesday that Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui's "state-to-state" relationship theory is a description of "objective reality."
Lord made the remarks at a Senate confirmation hearing called by Jesse Helms (R-N.C.), chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, for new US Ambassador to China Joseph Prueher.

"What you have now, Mr. Chairman, is de facto two separate entities. And when President Lee spoke out recently, he was describing what is objective reality," Lord said while responding to questions raised by Helms on whether "one China" is going to happen, and under what circumstances.
"Taiwan has done very well with a de facto separation from the mainland. There should be no pressure on it. It should be able to determine its own future dealings with China," Lord said.
"But to make this de jure without consulting with the (US) administration I think did blindside the administration, did not serve Taiwan's interest," he added.
"There will not be `one China' completely until the mainland looks more like Taiwan; namely, freer. And Taiwan has no interest in joining up with it (the mainland) until that happens," he continued.
Lord also said that it is important for Washington to warn Beijing not to use force while seeking to solve its dispute with Taiwan.
Lord and several US congressmen present at the hearing also urged the US administration to be more consistent in asking mainland China to improve its human rights record.

Lord said that the United States should not adopt double standards while dealing with mainland China on the human rights issue, and should not remain silent on Beijing's arrest of the mother of leading mainland dissident Wang Dan.

Lord, who once also served as US ambassador to mainland China, said that the United States should again propose at the annual meeting of the United Nation's Human Rights Committee that mainland China improve its human rights protection if dialogue between Washington and Beijing on the issue cannot be conducted smoothly.

DOC.HEADLINE: US GOVERNMENT STILL OPPOSES MODIFIED TAIWAN SECURITY ENFORCEMENT ACT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 27 (CNA) (By Jay Chen & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: The US government on Wednesday continued to voice its opposition to the Taiwan Security Enforcement Act that was approved by the House International Relations Committee on Tuesday with minor modifications.
A White House spokesman described the bill as "not acceptable" to the Clinton administration, and said "it might destabilize the region."
At the same time, a State Department official said the bill "would diminish prospects for cross-(Taiwan) strait dialogue and peaceful resolution of differences" between mainland China and Taiwan.

Some sources predicted that the bill may not be enacted because it remains uncertain whether or not the Senate will approve it, and even if approved by the Senate, the bill may be vetoed by President Bill Clinton.
The State Department official stated that the legislation would erode the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA)'s commitment to an unofficial US-Taiwan relationship by formalizing military relations.
"This could have the serious, unintended negative consequence of weakening both Taiwan's security and our own security interest in the region," he said.
The official acknowledged that "we believe the bill is predicated on the incorrect assumption that the TRA is not working and needs a fix."

In fact, he pointed out, "the TRA is working well. It's not necessary to amend, strengthen or supplement the TRA." He also stressed that the US government "has steadfastly honored the TRA's mandates and helped ensure the security of Taiwan.
"We have successfully helped Taiwan to satisfy its legitimate defense needs in accordance with the security and arms sales provisions of the TRA, and we will continue to do so," he went on.

The official also said that the US government believes that certain sections of the bill would unconstitutionally interfere with the president's authority and with his ability to carry out his responsibilities regarding the conduct of US foreign relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: SALES OF AMERICAN CARS IN TAIWAN DECLINE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Oct. 28 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Sales of US-made automobiles in Taiwan declined 24.6 percent in the first eight months of this year, dragging Taiwan down to ninth place in terms of the United States' largest car export markets.

According to the latest statistics compiled by the US Department of Commerce, American car manufacturers, including General Motors, Ford and Chrysler, exported US$104 million worth of vehicles to Taiwan between Jan. 1 and Aug. 31, a one quarter decrease from a year earlier.

Only two years ago, Taiwan was the United States' fifth largest overseas market for vehicles but fell to ninth in 1999, behind Canada, Mexico, Germany, Japan, Britain, Belgium, Saudi Arabia and Australia, in that order, the Commerce Department statistics showed.

Reviewing the performance of all overseas markets for US-made cars, the Commerce Department reported that the newly-opened market of South Korea scored the highest growth rate, up 550 percent over last year, followed by Belgium which increased 48.1 percent and Germany, up 24.8 percent.
The statistics showed that the United States exported US$177 million worth of cars, trucks, vans and related parts to Taiwan in the Jan.-Aug. period, down 20 percent over the same period last year.

Meanwhile, the United States imported US$810 million worth of similar products from Taiwan in the same period, up 25.6 percent, leaving Taiwan with a surplus of US$633 million, the statistics indicated.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Oct. 29, or the 21st day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1618: Sir Walter Raleigh, English courtier, navigator, colonizer and writer, is beheaded in the Tower of London for treason against King James I at the age of 54. His literary works include poetry, memoirs and a world history.
1863: Henri Dunant, Swiss philanthropist, founds the International Red Cross. He was a joint recipient of the 1901 Nobel Peace Prize.
1881: The first national political party is founded in Japan.
1897: Joseph Goebbels, German Nazi propaganda chief who poisoned himself when the Allies entered Berlin, is born.
1911: Joseph Pulitzer, Hungarian-born American journalist and newspaper publisher, dies at the age of 64. He owned papers in St. Louis and New York City and established and endowed the Pulitzer Prizes.
1923: The Republic of Turkey is proclaimed, with nationalist leader Kemal Ataturk as its first president.
1927: Russian archaeologist Peter Kozlov discovers the tomb of Genghis Khan in the Gobi Desert.
1929: "Black Tuesday" follows "Black Thursday" on Wall Street as the crisis of confidence hits the New York stock market, leading to the Great Depression of the 1930s.
1932: The Normandie, one of the three most luxurious ships ever built, is launched in France. The 300 meter-long vessel crossed the Atlantic Ocean in just over four days. A fire destroyed the ship while berthed in New York Harbor in 1942.
1942: Nazi Germans massacre 16,000 Jews in Pinsk, Russia.
1944: In his capacity as supreme commander of the China Theater of War, Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek appoints US General Albert C. Wedemeyer as chief of staff of the China Theater of War. Meanwhile, US General Daniel L. Sultan is appointed commander-in-chief of the US Expeditionary Forces in India.
1945: Anna Rosenberg is given the first US Medal of Freedom ever awarded to a woman.
1953: The North American F-100 Super Sabre jet fighter sets a record at 1,215 kph, becoming the first jet that could be operated at supersonic speeds.
1956: Israeli forces cross into the Sinai Peninsula, pushing toward the Suez Canal.
1962: The ROC Foreign Ministry issues a statement refusing to recognize India's position of using the "McMahon Line" as the border line between India and China.
1964: Tanganyika unites with Zanzibar, becoming Tanzania.
1975: Helmut Schmidt arrives in Beijing, becoming the first West German chancellor to tour the Chinese mainland.
1977: Taiwan's first IC (integrated circuit) plant, under the Industrial Technology Research Institute, is inaugurated at Chutung in Hsinchu County.
1980: A declaration by Teng Hsiao-ping (Deng Xiaoping,) vice chairman of the Chinese Communist Party, that Mao Tse-tung made serious political mistakes during his rule, is made public.
1984: The Chinese team from Taiwan wins second place in the World Amateur Baseball Championship in Cuba.
1985: The first prototype of "Ching Kuo," the first ROC-developed and manufactured indigenous defense fighter, bursts its nose-wheel during a test flight at the Chingchuenkang Air Force base in Taichung.
1986: The Ministry of Economic Affairs announces that ROC-US trade talks on wine and tobacco imports are stalemated. Washington charged that Taipei failed to keep promises of providing greater market access for US beer, wine and tobacco, and said the United States would draft retaliatory measures against the ROC under Section 301 of the Trade Act of 1974.
1993: Indian forces in Kashmir fire tear gas to stop hundreds of Muslims from marching toward a mosque where separatist rebels had been surrounded for two weeks.
1998: John Glenn, US astronaut, blasts off aboard the space shuttle Discovery at the age of 77, 36 years after his first extra-terrestrial mission.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "When a ruler regards his ministers as his hands and feet, they regard him as their belly and heart; when he regards them as dogs and horses, they regards him as a common citizen; when he regards them as dirt and grass, they regard him as a robber and enemy."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO BEGIN INTRODUCING VIETNAMESE WORKERS ON NOV. 1

TEXT.P: Taiwan is scheduled to begin introducing workers from Vietnam on Nov. 1 to help alleviate the persistent labor shortage, said Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Chairman Chan Hou-sheng on Friday.
Initially, there will be no cap on the number of Taiwan-bound Vietnamese laborers, whom may be employed at construction sites, manufacturing plants, or work as household maids and nurses, Chan noted.

The introduction of Vietnamese workers here is expected to have its biggest impact on the Philippines, which is facing a freeze of laborer exports to Taiwan in the wake of a recent diplomatic dispute triggered by a bilateral aviation row between the two countries.
With the admittance of Vietnamese workers, the number of countries from which Taiwan imports laborers has increased to five, including Thailand, the Philippines, Indonesia and Malaysia.

The local brokerage agencies of foreign workers welcomed the opening of Taiwan to Vietnamese laborers, saying that the introduction increases potential Taiwanese employers' options. The opening will also help correct the over-priced brokerage fees and disputes between employers and employees, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI URGES HONG KONG TO BE RATIONAL ABOUT ENVOY'S FUTURE

TEXT.P: A Republic of China official in charge of policies on mainland China Friday urged Hong Kong authorities to be rational over Taiwan representative Cheng An-kuo's visa renewal so as to help bolster bilateral exchanges between Taiwan and Hong Kong.

Lin Chung-ping, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said the MAC is paying close attention to Hong Kong's decision on Cheng's visa renewal as his work visa is due to expire at the end of November.

Rumors have circulated that Hong Kong authorities rejected a visa renewal application filed by Cheng, director of Chung Hwa Travel Service Hong Kong, the de facto representative of Taipei in the former British colony, because of a political grudge Beijing harbors toward him.

Cheng was allegedly denied a visa renewal because Beijing was angry about Cheng's remarks during a Hong Kong radio interview in July amplifying President Lee Teng-hui's "special state-to-state relations" theory defining cross-strait relations, the rumors said.
Lin said Taipei has up until today still not heard any word from Hong Kong authorities about the prospects of Cheng's visa renewal.
He added that the MAC has been highly satisfied with Cheng's performance in Hong Kong, particularly with efforts to facilitate mutual exchanges between Taiwan and Hong Kong.
Cheng, who speaks flawless Cantonese, the most common language spoken in Hong Kong, assumed his post there nearly four years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC STUDIES TOPICS OF WTO SERVICE NEGOTIATIONS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China has agreed in its membership application consultations with the World Trade Organization (WTO) to relax restrictions on foreign nationals visiting the country, an official said on Friday.

The official from the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said that the ROC government has agreed that business visas for foreign nationals will be extended to 90 days, while foreign personnel working for multinational corporations here will be granted extendible working terms in Taiwan, with unlimited annual extensions after an initial three-year term.

In anticipation of a new round of WTO service negotiations scheduled to begin in 2000, the WTO Council for Trade in Services has prepared 21 background papers on a wide variety of service-related industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: SELLING WOMEN'S EGGS EXPOSES SOCIETY'S UGLY SIDE: ETHICISTS

TEXT.P: Canadian ethicists said Thursday auctioning the eggs of beautiful women is the ugly face of a biotechnology explosion in a society that believes money really can buy everything.

"People seem to believe that anything is possible and if anything is possible then anything is purchasable," said Dr. Douglas Kinsella, a University of Calgary physician and immediate past president of the Canadian Bioethics Society.

"I think it's a big mistake to be commodifying the materials of human reproduction," agreed Dr. Susan Sherwin, a leading international ethicist from Dalhousie University in Halifax. "It's not far from selling eggs to selling children."
Both spoke at the society's annual conference which runs through Sunday in Edmonton. Topics include genetic testing, artificially modified food, euthanasia and human eggs for sale.
The controversy over the sale of human eggs made front-page headlines this week when eggs of beautiful models were offered up for auction at a Internet site.
Sherwin said it is imperative that some kind of legislation be developed soon, not only to restrict questionable technologies, but to send a moral signal about our attitudes toward human life.

DOC.HEADLINE: US-JAPAN-PRC COOPERATION AFFECTED BY TAIWAN, HISTORY SAYS EXPERT

TEXT.P: The unresolved status of Taiwan and the deep, historic animosity between China and Japan are the greatest obstacles to improved trilateral cooperation between the mainland, Japan and the US, said an American Asia expert Thursday.

These were the conclusions reached by the assistant director of the Nixon Center in Washington, Greg May, after a week of meetings with foreign policy experts, politicians, and incumbent and former officials in Shanghai, Beijing and Tokyo in mid-October.

In his report titled "The future of China-Japan-US Trilateral Relations," May said that events in Taiwan have actually helped repair Washington-Beijing ties. He noted that several mainland Chinese experts praised the Clinton administration's response to Taiwan President Lee Teng-hui's attempt to redefine cross-strait relations as a "special state-to-state" relationship.

The Clinton administration's quick reiteration of its "one China" policy, US opposition to Taiwan's UN membership, and opposition to the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act were all cited as examples of Washington's "correct" handling of the Taiwan issue.

May also noted that there appears to be an almost universal belief in mainland China that cross-strait relations will improve after Taiwan elects a new president next March, particularly if James Soong, an independent who advocates a more accommodating approach to the mainland, wins the election.

He went on to say that discussions with Japan's Diet members and foreign ministry officials in Tokyo indicated that, over the long term, Beijing-Tokyo relations will continue to be strained. One of the reasons he mentioned was rising pro-Taiwan sentiment due to President Lee's popularity among Japanese politicians and the public at large.

Although Taiwan and the "history problem" remain the largest and most immediate obstacles to closer PRC-Japan relations, the argument over these two issues masks more fundamental tensions, including Communist China's fears of a remilitarized Japan and the latent competition between Beijing and Tokyo over the future leadership of the East Asia region, noted May.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA LOOKS UNLIKELY TO BE ABLE TO JOIN WTO TALKS IN SEATTLE

TEXT.P: Mainland China is likely to be unable to attend the new round of World Trade Organization talks set for Seattle on November 30 thanks to its inability to finalize negotiations for entry into the global trading body despite strong help from the new WTO director general.

In a dispatch from Hong Kong, the Australian Financial Review's correspondent Rowan Callick on Friday reported neither Europe nor the United States is likely to finalize its negotiations with China before the next multilateral session starts in Seattle next month.

The daily reported that the WTO director general, Mike Moore is a strong advocate for the admission of China and said indications have emerged that this cut-off date is no longer to be viewed as final.

DOC.HEADLINE: IOC INTERVENES IN OLYMPIC TICKETING FIASCO

TEXT.P: The International Olympic Committee is intervening in the ticketing fiasco which has paralyzed the Sydney Organizing Committee for the Olympic Games and shattered the staff's morale following widespread public anger over its secret premium package deals.

The IOC's official in charge of the 2000 Olympic Games, Dr. Jacques Rogge said "I hope emotions calm down because ultimately everything impacts on the organization and there is still a hell of a lot of work to do over the next 10 months."

At a meeting with the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) on Thursday, the SOCOG appeared ready to offer refunds to thousands of Australians who received tickets they did not really want.

Under secret package deals, the SOCOG had allocated most of the tickets to major events, including the opening and closing ceremonies, and the swimming and basketball competition finals, to corporations and rich Australians, leaving only tickets to minor and secondary events available to other Australians.

The SOCOG had charged companies and individuals three times the normal ticket prices to the major events, sparking widespread public anger. The ACCC itself is set to investigate the ticketing scandal soon.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT THANKS JAPAN FOR AID TO 921 EARTHQUAKE VICTIMS

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Friday expressed gratitude on behalf of the Republic of China government and people for Japan's generous donations, support and care to victims of the massive earthquake that rattled Taiwan on Sept. 21.

Lee offered his thanks during a meeting at the Presidential Office with visiting Japanese writer Ayako Sono, who is also the chairwoman of the Nippon Foundation, a charity organization founded in 1962 to strive for world peace and social welfare.
Lee told his guest that although the devastating quake resulted in a great deal of loss and damage, "we have the faith to pick ourselves up and stand tall again."

Sono told the president of the concern among Japan's business sector over the harm caused by the quake, and on behalf of the Nippon Foundation, read a statement of condolence announcing a further donation of 300 million yen (US$2.88 million) to boost post-quake rehabilitation efforts in central Taiwan, the worst-hit area.

Sono said Japan benefited from support and aid from many countries and international organizations, including the ROC, after a destructive earthquake jolted the city of Kobe in January 1995, killing nearly 5,300 people.

She blessed the thousands of Taiwanese victims of the Sept. 21 quake, and said she hoped those who have lost family members and their homes in the disaster will be able to overcome their difficulties and rebuild their homes.
Sono arrived in Taipei on Thursday for a two-day visit, accompanied by representatives of five Japanese business conglomerates.
Upon arrival, the high-profile group proceeded immediately to Taichung County, one of the hardest-hit areas, to gain a better understanding of the plight of the residents there.

DOC.HEADLINE: YOUNG PAINTER-POET'S BATTLE WITH CANCER REDUCES MANY TO TEARS
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, Oct. 29 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A 14-year-old boy who is about to lose a battle with cancer appeared in a concert in his honor at Kaohsiung Veteran General Hospital on Friday, reducing many to tears with his courage and the cruelty of life.

Wu Kuan-yi, a talented poet, writer and painter whose greatest wish is to receive a Nobel Prize, is displaying more than 100 paintings and poems, as well as essays, in the hospital's main hall, to a background of orchestral music played by young musicians from Kaohsiung's Tong Kuang primary school, of which Wu is a former pupil.
Wu, who weighs only around 30 kg because of a brain tumor, was present at the concert, lying weak and drowsy on his sick bed.

His teary mother kept talking to him about the occasion during his on-and-off consciousness. Wu managed to murmur a few words expressing gratitude for the concern and support that society has shown him.
Among the paintings was a self-portrait that Wu painted at the age of 12. The painting depicts a handsome young man looking cool and self-confident.

His paintings, poems and essays, all of which are considered to be of the standard of professional adult artists, will be collected and printed in the form of a book which is scheduled to roll off the presses at the end of November titled "A Major Jolt of Life," said Chou Ching-hua, founder the Chou Ta-kun Cultural and Educational Foundation.
Chou went on to describe Wu's work, saying the artist is telling us that despite his "concentrated" life, he can still bring light and warmth to people, even though he is dying.
Tong Kuang school principal, Hung Fang-lan, said Wu brings her new insight that life's value is not how much power you have but how much influence you have on other people.

Wu checked into Kaohsiung Veteran General Hospital last October because of weakness and fatigue. He was later diagnosed as having developed pineal gland leiomyosarcoma, a form of brain cancer. The tumor has now spread to his spine and his days are numbered, according to his doctors.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRIVATE SECTOR `ADOPTS' QUAKE-DEMOLISHED SCHOOLS

TEXT.P: Students of many schools demolished by the Sept. 21 earthquake may be able to return to their classrooms and schoolyards by September 2000, as Taiwan's private sector has pledged support to rebuild the schools.

Education Minister Yang Chaur-shin said on Friday that more than 800 schools, mostly in Taichung and Nantou counties in central Taiwan, have suffered damage to varying degrees, and that the cost of rebuilding and repairing has been estimated at NT$40 billion. The government on its own would have difficulty raising such a huge sum within a short time, he pointed out.

Among the total, 138 primary and secondary schools were almost totally demolished, and the private sector, including religious groups, educational foundations, benevolent institutions, media establishments, and enterprises, has pledged support with reconstruction by "adopting" the schools in question.

Several legislators convened a meeting on Friday with the participation of the education and finance ministries, and representatives from the construction industry, to discuss how to proceed with the reconstruction.

Yang reported that the private sector has so far adopted 79 of the schools, with the Tzu Chi Buddhist Compassionate Relief Association, for instance, having agreed to single-handedly raise funds for rebuilding 26 of the schools.

By adopting the schools, the private establishments can either proceed with the reconstruction work themselves, or donate the required sum for reconstruction and entrust the authorities to carry out the work.
The Education Ministry expects that more schools will be adopted over the next few weeks, and that an overall reconstruction plan can be finalized by the end of November.
If the reconstruction work can start in March 2000 as scheduled, the students will be able to attend their rebuilt schools after next summer's vacation, according to Yang.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar closed firmer against the greenback on Friday on the Taipei foreign exchange market, rising 0.003 to 31.74.
The local currency opened at 31.74, and experienced a fluctuation between 31.735 and 31.75. Interbank US dollar trading reached US$278 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA CALLS ON BUSINESSMEN TO BEWARE OF INTERNATIONAL FRAUDSTERS

TEXT.P: Taiwan businessmen seem to have become the target of international fraudsters, after three cases were exposed in Burkina Faso, a West African ally of the Republic of China, a foreign affairs official warned on Friday.

Liu Chen-kun of the African Affairs Department of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said at a regular news conference that the practice usually involves inviting local potential investors, purchasers, and contractors to visit Burkina Faso or other African countries for "business talks."

The criminals then stage elaborate "contract signing" ceremonies where the Taiwan businessmen are duped into paying out money, Liu said. He noted that the ROC Embassy in Burkina Faso has been notified of three such cases since August.

Although two of the scams failed when embassy officials intervened, Liu said local enterprises should still be on a full alert for similar fraudulent schemes. He added MOFA has included the warning on trade and economic publications in order to bring wider attention to the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WTO ENTRY TO BE FURTHER CLARIFIED AT SEATTLE MEETING

TEXT.P: Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang will lead a Republic of China delegation to the annual ministerial meeting of the World Trade Organization (WTO) in Seattle on Nov. 30, an official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Friday.

Hsia Li-yen, director of MOFA's International Organization Department, said that the question of whether or not Taiwan is admitted to the WTO at the end of 1999 will be further clarified at the Seattle meeting.
"Our stance remains unchanged and we have already completed the process of bilateral consultation. We hope that the entry procedures can be completed as soon as possible," Hsia said.

Hsia said that whether or not Taiwan is admitted at the end of this year, the fact that it is attending the meeting as an observer is "significant," and added that the island will continue to take all necessary measures to take part in any new rounds of negotiations.

DOC.HEADLINE: F-16 FIGHTER ACCIDENTALLY DROPS DUMMY MISSILE INTO POND

TEXT.P: An F-16 fighter jet of the Republic of China Air Force on Friday accidentally dropped a dummy missile into a fishing pond in Central Taiwan's Yunlin County during a routine training mission, Air Force Headquarters (AFHQ) revealed.
The unarmed missile was used for training purposes only and constituted no danger of explosion, AFHQ said.

The fighter, which took off from the Shuishang air base in centrl Taiwan's Chiayi County on Friday morning, was carrying out a training mission in which bombs were to be dropped into a target area. However, a faulty attachment device caused the missile to detach before the plane reached the target.
AFHQ said it has sent personnel to retrieve the missile and determine whether it remains usable.
Taiwan has lost three of the 150 F-16 fighters and one of its 60 Mirage 2000-5 fighters it purchased from the United States and France, respectively, in less than two years.
In the most recent accident on Oct. 15, a Mirage jet crashed into the sea off the coast of Hsinchu in northern Taiwan minutes after birds were sucked into its engine during takeoff.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANILA URGED TO RECOGNIZE AIR AGREEMENT WITH TAIPEI
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, Oct. 29 (CNA) (By Sun Ting-wu and Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: The Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in the Philippines (TECO) sent a letter on Friday to its Philippines counterpart urging the Philippine government to confirm its respect for the air agreement signed in 1996 between the two sides.

The letter, in which Taipei's stance regarding the re-establishment of air links was stated, was sent on the instructions of Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew, who outlined the following three principles for handling the aviation agreement:

-- The Philippines must issue an official announcement indicating its respect for the 1996 Taipei-Manila Air Service Agreement which was signed between TECO and its Philippine counterpart, the Manila Economic and Cultural Office (MECO);

-- Manila must respond with goodwill, and the negotiation cannot continue if Manila insists that Taipei reduce its combined weekly passenger quota on the Taiwan-Philippines route to 3,000 from the previous 9,600; and
-- Manila must accept that the air agreement is a legal document between the two countries, so that it has adequate legal weight.

TECO officials noted that an immediate response is not expected since the Philippines is embarking on a four-day long weekend, and an anonymous senior TECO official remained pessimistic over a goodwill response, accusing the Philippines of being capricious and "always using empty words without following up with concrete actions."

Since direct airlinks between Taipei and Manila were terminated on Oct. 2 by Manila, the Philippines has expressed its hope of resuming bilateral talks and re-establishing the links as soon as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: HP CHIEF EXECUTIVE VISITS TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The newly installed chief executive of Hewlett-Packard Co. (HP), the world's No. 2 computer maker, arrived in Taipei on Friday for a two-day whirlwind visit.

This is Carleton S. Fiorina's first visit to Taiwan and comes as part of an Asian tour which she is undertaking in the company of HP President Lewis Platt. She took over the post in July after quitting a position with Lucent Technology Co.

Fiorina, 44, who was named by the US-based Fortune magazine last year as the most influential female executive in the United States, called on Premier Vincent Siew on Friday and will leave Taipei on Saturday after holding a news conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHARE, FUTURE PRICES EDGE UP

TEXT.P: Taipei share prices opened high on Friday, encouraged by an overnight surge on Wall Street, but closed with only a slight gain after profit-taking by investors.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index moved up 24.82 points to finish at 7,706.67, on a turnover of NT$92.32 billion (US$2.91 billion).
The electronics sector enjoyed the heaviest buying during the session, ending the day with a 1.4-percent gain.

Construction issues dropped 1.8 percent, followed by paper and pulp shares, down 1.6 percent; foodstuffs and textile stocks, both declining 1.2 percent; plastic and chemical issues, down 1 percent; cement issues, down 0.8 percent; and financial shares with a slide of 0.5 percent.
The over-the-counter market rose 2.28 points to close at 175.1, on a turnover of NT$7.53 billion.

Meanwhile, the futures market performed somewhat better than the stock market in Friday's trading, with all Taiwan Stock Exchange International Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) posting gains.

TAIEX Index Futures for November surged 49 points to close at 7,776, with 99 contract transactions. Those for December gained 55 points to finish at 7,786, with 60 contract transactions, while March futures rose 64 points to 7,820, with four contract transactions, and June futures moved up 10 points to finish at 7,800, with two contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for September futures.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Oct. 30, or the 22nd day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1735: John Adams, the second president of the United States, is born. He was one of the signatories of the Declaration of Independence and negotiated the end of the War of American Independence.
1823: Edmund Cartwright, English inventor whose invention of the power loom contributed to the industrial Revolution, dies at the age of 80.
1838: Oberlin Collegiate Institute in Lorain County, Ohio, becomes the first college in the United States to admit women students.
1905: Under pressure from striking workers and oppressed peasants, Tsar Nicholas II of Russia agrees in his "October Manifesto" to grant civil liberties and elections in the hope of avoiding a revolution.
1910: Swiss philanthropist Henri Dunant dies at the age of 82. He founded the International Red Cross and shared the first Nobel Peace Prize with Frederic Passy of France in 1901.
1911: On the advice of the regent Prince Chun, Henry Pu Yi, the last emperor of the Ching dynasty, grants a constitution to combat growing support for the revolutionary army of Dr. Sun Yat-sen.
1918: Thomas Lawrence, known as "Lawrence of Arabia," shocks King George V by refusing to receive the Order of the Bath and the Distinguished Service Order from him.
1927: The Chinese Communist Party launches armed rebellions at Haifeng and Lufeng in Kwangtung Province.
1937: The National government decides to move the capital from Nanking to Chungking.
1952: The Federation of Overseas Chinese Associations is set up in Taipei following the first worldwide Overseas Chinese Conference which opened in Taipei on Oct. 22.
1953: Wu Ching-heng, former chairman of the Presidium of the Constituent Assembly, dies in Taipei at the age of 88.
1956: Anti-Communist revolution spreads swiftly through Hungary with Imre Nagy again becoming premier and declaring Hungary to be a neutral country. But the new government lasts only a few days.
1962: The ROC government rejects the McMahon Line as the boundary between China and India.
1972: Pierre Trudeau and his Liberal Party narrowly win a general election in Canada.
1973: Tsengwen Dam and Reservoir, the largest in Taiwan, is completed and dedicated as a birthday present to President Chiang Kai-shek.
1973: Economic Minister Y. S. Sun leaves for Saigon to take part in the eighth Sino-Vietnamese Ministerial Conference on economic cooperation.
1974: Muhammad Ali knocks out George Foreman in the eighth round in Kinshasa to regain his title as world heavyweight boxing champion.
1974: The first F5E Freedom jet fighter made in the Republic of China rolls off the assembly line.
1974: Nobusuke Kishi, former Japanese prime minister, and Mitsujiro Ishii, former speaker of the House of Representatives, arrive to join in birthday greetings for President Chiang.
1975: Ground for the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, named after the late president, is broken by Adm. Ni Yue-si, president of the ROC Amateur Athletic Federation, and Wang Yung-ching, the donor.
1975: Li Teng-hui, minister of state, leaves for Nakualofa as a special envoy to attend the 100th anniversary of the Constitution of the Kingdom of Tonga.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives US Rep. John B. Conlan (R-Ariz.) as well as French parliamentarians headed by Rene Radius.
1986: The Executive Yuan approves the establishment of National Chiang Kai-shek University in central Taiwan.
1986: The Executive Yuan approves the code on gold trading and importation, to be effective Nov. 1.
1986: The ROC-made "Sky Bow" and "Sky Sword" missiles are officially renamed the "Chung Cheng (Chiang Kai-shek) 100" series in a renaming ceremony presided over by Premier Yu Kuo-hwa.
1988: Rev. Sun Myung Moon, head of the Unification Church, presides over one of the biggest mass wedding ceremonies in history in Yongin in South Korea where 6,516 couples tie the knot.
1990: Communist China announces the results of a nationwide census which shows its population totals 1.13 billion people.
1990: The Republic of China establishes trade and consular ties with Bolivia.
1995: Voters in the province of Quebec vote in favor of remaining part of Canada in a referendum.
1995 Fire breaks out on a subway train below the streets of Baku, capital of the Republic of Azerbaijan killing 337 people and injuring at least 270 others.
1997: Mary McAleese, a Belfast lawyer, is elected President of Ireland.

DOC.HEADLINE: MALAWI DIPLOMATS TO RECEIVE 5-WEEK TRAINING IN ROC

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will start a five-week training course for 10 diplomatic personnel from the Republic of Malawi, a southeast African country with diplomatic ties to the Republic of China, beginning Nov. 1.
Led by Kester Kaphaizi, deputy director of the Malawian Foreign Ministry's Protocol Department, the 10 African guests will attend nineteen theoretical and practical training courses.
The classes to be taught during the five-week period will include international relations, international trade, disposing of crises, and relations across the Taiwan Strait.
The MOFA arranged the training course at the invitation of the government of Malawi.
The MOFA will also arrange for the Malawi diplomats to visit cultural and economic establishments in the ROC in the hopes of letting them further understand the ROC's national situation.
The Malawi diplomatic officials are scheduled to complete their training and depart for Malawi on Dec. 4.

DOC.HEADLINE: ICELAND URGED TO CONSIDER SETTING UP TRADE OFFICE IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: It is necessary for Iceland to establish a trade office in Taiwan as business and trade exchanges between the two countries have begun to boom, said the visiting mayor of the capital and largest city in Iceland, Reykjavik, on Saturday.

Reykjavik Mayor Ingibjorg Solrun Gisladottir and Secretary General Ricky Kao of the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) jointly presided over the Iceland Seminar & Trade Meeting at the CETRA headquarters Friday, mainly to promote Iceland's commodities and solicit Taiwanese businesses to invest in the Scandinavian country.
This is the first time that a large-scale Icelandic trade mission led by the capital's mayor has visited here to seek to become trade partners with Taiwan, according to CETRA sources.
The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) is also attaching great importance to the visit by Gisladottir, who is presently one of the most promising hopefuls to become the next prime minister.
Gisladottir's visit is considered by MOFA as a goodwill gesture after Vice President Lien Chan's visit to Iceland in 1998, which he called a "fruitful" and "ice-breaking" trip.

Addressing the opening of the seminar, CETRA chief executive Kao said Iceland, located in the North Atlantic, has rich resources of fish, inexpensive natural energy and commendable manufactured products, including down-filled garments.
During the seminar, Iceland's largest mineral water manufacturer, ThorSpring, solicited Taiwanese partners to jointly tap Taiwan's bottled water market.

ThorSpring, of which Coca Cola holds 40 percent of corporate shares, Hof Holding 40 percent and the Reykjavik city government 20 percent, has maintained distribution centers in Asia, including Singapore, Malaysia and Hong Kong.
Meanwhile, Icelandic firm Pedup forged an agreement with a Taipei software company to jointly promote Taiwan-developed children's software packages to Scandinavia and Europe.

Other members of the Icelandic trade mission included marketing executives from companies in the frozen fish industry, shark bone processing, investment consultation services, fish catch telecommunications and the down processing industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: OLYMPIC ORGANIZERS APOLOGIZE AND OFFER REFUND

TEXT.P: Organizers of the 2000 Sydney Olympic Games apologized and offered to refund money to 26,000 Australians who received tickets to events which represented their third choices.

Olympic Minister Michael Knight of New South Wales on Friday told a press conference that he and other organizers of the Olympic Games said the refund would total about A$5.4 (US$3.6) million if everyone of the 26,000 people chose the refund option.

Knight used the occasion to accuse the International Olympic Committee of "ducking for cover" over its involvement in the controversial A$100 (US$63) million premium packages for wealthy citizens in Australia, the United States and elsewhere.
The IOC said it had never given approval to the Sydney organizers for a premium ticket package program. But Knight said he rejected this IOC claim.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STILL PUSHING FOR WTO ACCESSION, SAYS COA HEAD

TEXT.P: Taiwan is still pushing for accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO) despite the fact that its prospects and those of mainland China for entry this year have become increasingly gloomy, top agriculture official Peng Tso-kwei said on Saturday.

Peng, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA), said the COA is presently reviewing Taiwan's granting of preferential "down payment" treatment to the United States and other WTO member countries, but he insisted that the top priority should be on continued efforts to gain WTO membership rather than canceling any preferential treatment.

In the meantime, he added, Vice Economic Affairs Minister Lin Yi-fu has left for the United States to meet with US officials to discuss bilateral issues concerning Taiwan's WTO bid. Lin hopes to reach further consensus with Washington beneficial to Taiwan's cause in the upcoming WTO ministerial meeting slated to open in Seattle on Nov. 30.

During the WTO talks with the United States last year, Taiwan promised "down payment" -- allowing the US to export to Taiwan 10,000 tons of chicken, 5,000 tons of pork and 7,500 tons of pork offal every year even before Taiwan's entry into the WTO -- so as to facilitate its bid to enter the trade body.

In May this year, other WTO members followed suit asking Taiwan for the same treatment. Taiwan has therefore agreed to provide global quotas to WTO members other than the United States, allowing imports of 1,600 tons of pork, 9,163 tons of chicken, 5,000 tons of pork offal and 2,500 tons of beef offal.

Taiwan previously expected to enter the WTO before the end of this year at about the same time as mainland China was to have entered. However, this dream seems to have almost faded as there has yet been no breakthrough in WTO talks between Beijing and Washington and between Beijing and the European Union.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLARS, LEGISLATORS URGE RECONSTRUCTION OF CULTURAL RELICS

TEXT.P: Scholars on cultural heritage, architecture and community development and several legislators on Saturday jointly pleaded for the proper renovation of many cultural establishments and relics damaged by the Sept. 21 earthquake.

The scholars earlier formed an ad hoc group dedicated to rescue of damaged cultural assets. They had suggested that the Executive Yuan should include cultural assets in the reconstruction list and allocate funds for this purpose.

The post-disaster reconstruction , concentrating on housing units, schools, industrial establishments and basic infrastructure, has already gotten under way. But the ad hoc group worries that in the process of rebuilding, many earthquake-damaged cultural establishments and relics will be forgotten.

For this reason, the group organized specialists and college students in related subjects to conduct an island-wide survey after the earthquake. The first-stage survey report indicated that 50 cultural relics and historical landmarks were known to have suffered damage of varying degrees.

In addition to the damaged cultural relics, many old buildings with historical significance also experienced natural as well as human catastrophe as owners have tended to tear the earthquake-damaged structures down to make way for new projects.

The specialists urged the Council for Cultural Affairs under the Executive Yuan to conduct a survey of damaged historical buildings and make a list of those that should be preserved. In the meantime, they asked the government to find ways to keep the cultural relics from being demolished, such as by providing incentives to the owners.
The council adopted an emergency measure in late October to provide special funding for the reinforcing of historical buildings. The government will provide a total of NT$10 million for this purpose.

Stating that the amount of government funding is definitely insufficient, the specialists called on the private sector to contribute to saving the cultural relics by participating in restoration work or by making donations.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF TO SPONSOR CROSS-STRAIT SEMINAR ON SEISMOLOGY

TEXT.P: The Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) will sponsor a seminar on seismology with the participation of scholars from both sides of the Taiwan Strait, SEF Deputy Secretary-General Jan Jyh-horng said on Saturday.
Jan made the announcement after a meeting with a group of mainland Chinese seismologists who are currently on a weeklong visit here.

Jan said SEF, a semi-official intermediary body authorized by the Republic of China government to handle exchanges with mainland China in the absence of official ties, will join forces with local professional academic institutes in organizing the seminar.
If necessary, Jan said, SEF will invite its mainland counterpart -- the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) -- to assist in organizing the symposium.
Jan expressed regret over media reports that Taiwan had rejected mainland China's offer for help shortly after a devastating earthquake hit the central part of the island on Sept. 21.
"Such reports were misleading," Jan said, adding that Taiwan has never rejected any offer for help from mainland China.
Several visiting mainland scholars also said that while some mainland seismologists had expressed concern about Taiwan's post-earthquake situation, none of them really applied for visits to Taiwan.
Jan said he had discussed with visiting mainland academics some details regarding the planned cross-strait seismological seminar, including key issues to be put on the agenda.
"The seminar will offer a forum for local and mainland scholars to exchange views and data concerning seismic observations, forecasts, engineering and research.
He added that SEF will present a detailed plan for the seminar to the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) for approval in the near future.

The seminar is tentatively scheduled to take place in late November, Jan said, adding that the symposium will provide opportunities for seismologists from the two sides to exchange information and data concerning major earthquakes that occurred in Taiwan and mainland China over past years.
