DOC.HEADLINE: MAC OFFICIAL INTERVIEWED BY SANKEI SHINBUM
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Oct. 30 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Mainland China is continuing its verbal attacks and military intimidation of Taiwan, Wu An-chia, vice chairman of the cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said in an interview published by Sankei Shinbum on Saturday.

Wu noted that currently there are two camps in mainland China holding differing views on the timing of Taiwan visit of iWang Daohan, mainland China's top negotiator with Taiwan. One camp maintains that Wang should visit Taiwan as soon as possible to resume high-level cross-strait dialogue.
The other view is that Wang should wait to visit Taiwan until after the island's presidential election next March, Wu said.
Wang and his ROC counterpart Koo Chen-fu had agreed during their talks on the mainland last year that Wang would visit Taiwan in the fall of 1999.

The mainland, however, reacted angrily after President Lee Teng-hui in early July redefined cross-strait ties as a "special state-to-state relationship" and insisted that Taiwan must retract the statement before Wang could visit Taiwan.

Wu said that those who think Wang should visit Taiwan earlier believe the "state-to-state relationship" rhetoric was only a statement of facts, and that it has not changed Taiwan's policy toward the mainland.

Those who are opposed to Wang's visit now believe that the trip is equivalent to a recognition of a "state-to-state relationship," Wu said, adding that those who oppose the visit have now gained the upper hand.
On the issue of President Lee Teng-hui's official status when receiving Wang, Wu said that Lee would not insist on seeing Wang in his capacity as the president.
On the prospect of cross-strait relations, Wu said that mainland China's policy toward Taiwan hasn't undergone any basic changes and that its military intimidation has remained.

Although the mainland did tone down its saber-rattling a little after Taiwan's devastating Sept. 21 earthquake and suspended its military exercises, these moves were aimed at avoiding the incitement of Taiwanese people's revulsion, Wu said.

He believes that mainland China's policy is basically to get Taiwan to rely more and more on the mainland's economy, and then to get it to rely more on the mainland politically, so as to woo Taiwan people and expand its influence over the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL SEMINAR ON MADAME CHIANG TO OPEN IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: An international seminar on Madame Chiang Kai-shek and her contribution to contemporary China is scheduled to be held in Taipei Nov. 1-3 under the auspices of the Kuomintang's Department of Party History.

The seminar, the first of its kind ever to be held in Taiwan, is expected to have 230 scholars, historians, and political figures from home and abroad take part, with 21 papers to be presented, said Chen Peng-jen, director general of the KMT Department of Party History.

Participating specialists from Canada, Japan, Russia and the United States are expected to bring invaluable historical archive materials regarding Mme. Chiang or Mayling Soong, and about China, particularly before and during World War II, Chen noted.

A total of 10 workshops are scheduled for the three-day seminar, which will include the thoughts of Mme. Chiang, her military perceptions as the wife of the wartime leader of China, her diplomacy philosophy towards the United States, women's movement in China at the time, Taiwan's charity activities initiated by Mme. Chiang, her love life, and her being the focus of attention by the world media and political observers.

Kuomintang Secretary General John Chang, son of late President Chiang Ching-kuo and grandson of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, will be invited to give a speech on his personal understanding of Mme. Chiang at the closing session of the seminar, Chen added.

Madame Chiang, hailed by historians as "the only remaining major figure of World War II," is now sound and healthy at the age of 101 and will turn 102 in March. In two months she will witness her third century when the year 2000 kicks off.
Chen said Mme. Chiang is not only a living national treasure of the Republic of China, but also a source of pride for all Chinese people.

Mme. Chiang spoke before the US Congress in 1943, when World War II was at its peak and China's war against Japan was in high gear. Mme. Chiang, a graduate of Wellesley College in Massachusetts, addressed a joint session of Congress at the invitation of President Franklin Roosevelt, calling for a concerted effort from the US in fighting against the Japanese militants.

The former ROC first lady than went on a 46-state speech tour around the United States between February and April of the same year, winning the hearts and support of US citizens with her eloquence and unique charisma.
Of all the Allied leaders and their wives during World War II, only Madame Chiang is still alive.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR MEETS DISABLED JAPANESE WRITER

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou on Saturday urged people suffering from disabilities to learn from Hirotada Ototake, a after meeting with the popular writer on Saturday.
Ototake, born without limbs, is a senior at Waseda University. Though he now relies on an electric wheelchair to get around, he plays basketball well and also swims and jumps rope.
Ototake, who arrived in Taiwan Thursday for a three-day visit, is here promoting the Chinese version of his autobiography, published by Yuan-shen Press.

The mayor of Taipei expressed the hope that people with disabilities could learn from Ototake and return to the regular education system. Ototake also said that the interchanges result in increased harmony by helping educate the public that people with disabilities should not be viewed as a problem.
Ma said that he was quite impressed by Ototake's zest for life, his optimism and the humorous touch in his book, saying that local youngsters could learn a lot from him.
Ototake's autobiography has sold more than 4 million copies in Japan while the Korean version was published in South Korea in May and its English version is due out next year.
When asked about his impressions of Taiwan, the popular Japanese youth said that the food is delicious and the girls beautiful.

The mayor and the author exchanged email addresses in order to keep in touch. Ototake also gave Chinese versions of his book to Ma to be donated to the quake-stricken areas in central Taiwan to help cheer up people there.
Ototake met with students from primary and middle schools Friday. The youngsters seemed amazed by his sparking smile, his optimism, and his ability to dribble a basketball around.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT URGED TO CREATE BASIC LAW ON POST-DISASTER RECONSTRUCTION

TEXT.P: Several female legislators of the ruling Kuomintang on Saturday urged the government to constitute a basic law on measures to cope with disasters and on measures to conduct post-disaster reconstruction as soon as possible.
The lawmakers made the proposal at a press conference held at the Legislative Yuan.

The legislators went to Osaka and Kobe, Japan on Oct. 24-26 to study the post-quake reconstruction work in the area. A magnitude 6.9 earthquake struck Osaka and Kobe in January 1995, claiming more than 5,000 lives.

Upon their return to Taiwan, they conveyed to the ROC government the four principles of reconstruction work proposed by the Japanese side. The four stated principles were government courage in tackling big problems, clarification of responsibility, prevention and control of infectious diseases, and psychological rebuilding.

Legislator Huang Chao-shun, a member of the study mission, indicated the main reasons why Japan's post-quake reconstruction had been so effective were the integration of ideas from the local and central governments, the establishment of community organizations, and the incorporation of volunteer and professional manpower.

Huang stressed that Japan's handling of reconstruction provides a good reference for the ROC government, pointing to the Japanese parliament's quick passage of relief bills enabling the government to quickly begin reconstruction efforts.
During their visit, the legislators called on Kobe's mayor and related officials and also officials of Hyogo Prefecture to exchange views on rehabilitation efforts.

The lawmakers also, on behalf of the people and government of the ROC, extended their heartfelt gratitude for the assistance and concerns of Japanese from all walks of life after the "921 Earthquake" hit Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE REAFFIRMS COMMITMENT TO NATIONAL UNIFICATION

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui reiterated on Saturday that the Republic of China has never forsaken its goal of promoting eventual unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Lee made the reaffirmation during a ceremony marking Veterans Day, which falls on Sunday.

The president told recipients of this year's model veterans awards that the ROC government's efforts to establish a free, democratic system in Taiwan is by no means aimed at promoting Taiwan independence.

"We have never abandoned our ultimate national goal of promoting China's unification under freedom and democracy," Lee said, adding that he believes Taiwan's democratization can help push mainland China's political reform.
Lee further stressed that national unification can be realized only after mainland China democratizes its political system.
In his speech, Lee also lauded retired servicemen for their contribution to local society, saying their contribution has been a driving force behind national development.

"You had dedicated yourselves to safeguarding national security during your service in the military and continued working hard at various positions after retiring from the military. I deeply admire your loyalty to our country and support for our government," Lee said.

Noting that the government has attached great importance to improve retired servicemen's quality of life, Lee said a package of constitutional amendments passed earlier this year has included a provision that requires the government to fully protect retired servicemen's rights and interests.
"With concerted efforts of various government agencies, I believe that all retired servicemen will be able to receive better care in the future," Lee added.
Earlier in the day, President Lee also presided over a ceremony marking the anniversary of the late President Chiang Kai-shek's birthday, which also falls on Sunday.
More than 500 government officials, military officers, parliamentarians and overseas Chinese representatives attended the ceremony held at the Presidential Office.
Control Yuan President Fredrick Chien delivered a report on the late president's political concepts and contribution to the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT DISCIPLINARY COMMITTEE DECIDES TO EXPEL SU

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang's disciplinary committee Saturday unanimously supported the Central Standing Committee's decision in early September to expel former National Assembly (NA) Speaker Su Nan-cheng from the KMT and consequently his status as an at-large member of the NA will be revoked.
The decision was made after the KMT disciplinary committee held a meeting focusing on Su's 20,000-word petition filed early last week in defense of his role in the tenure-extension amendment.

The KMT's Dept. of Organization Affairs sent a notice to the Central Election Commission, the island's highest authority overseeing election matters, immediately after the meeting to ask the commission to revoke Su's at-large membership in the NA.
The whole case will be submitted next Wednesday to the KMT's Central Standing Committee for reference.

The KMT has charged Su with violating the party line and public opinion by forcing through the passage of a bill allowing the incumbent National Assembly deputies to extend their tenures for two years to May 2002.

The passage of the self-serving tenure-extension amendment to the constitution immediately aroused public indignation with many blaming the KMT for its failure to influence its deputies, most of whom voted to support the term-extension.
Su was disciplined by the KMT afterwards by being expelled from the party. Su, an appointed NA deputy, was automatically deprived of office upon revocation of his party membership.
However, nearly two months after his dismissal, Su was found to be still conducting business at the Speaker's office, arousing public outrage once again.

According to Central Election Commission regulations, the KMT had informed the commission of Su's expulsion from the party on Sept. 9 but later withdrew the document. This was seen as the reason why the former Speaker continued showing up in his NA office through October. The devastating quake also played a role by temporarily diverting the public's attention away from Su's case.
Faced with the refocusing of public attention on Su, the KMT disciplinary committee took immediate action and unanimously upheld his expulsion.

KMT Spokesman Huang Hwei-chen pointed out that the whole KMT leadership, from Chairman Lee Teng-hui and Vice Chairman Lien Chan to Secretary-General John Chang, has been consistently and adamantly opposed to the tenure-extension proposal.
Former Taiwan Governor James Soong, who is an independent presidential candidate, doubted the KMT's punishment of Su was aimed at finding a scapegoat for the party's leadership.

DOC.HEADLINE: HP WON'T CHANGE DEVELOPMENT STRATEGY IN TAIWAN DESPITE EARTHQUAKE

TEXT.P: Hewlett Packard (HP) will not withdraw the effort and resources it has injected in the Taiwan market despite the effect of the Sept. 21 earthquake on the island's economy, the company's CEO and President Carly S. Fiorina said on Saturday.

Although the massive earthquake ended with tragedy in Taiwan, its impact on the island's industrial development and economic growth is expected to be only temporary, Fiorina said at a press conference prior to her departure after a two-day whirlwind visit in Taiwan.

She also said that although the operational performance of HP's Taiwan affiliate during the latest season has been disappointing, the company will maintain its development strategies for the local market, believing that Taiwan will soon recover and stand on its own feet again.

Citing that the number of Internet users in Asia is dramatically increasing, and that the popularity in the use and application of computer devices and Internet services in Taiwan has led those in other Asian economies, Fiorina indicated HP will put resources toward the ROC government's efforts to promote the globalization of local businesses in order to help them catch up with the global E-commerce era in time.
The chief executive also announced that HP has forged a strategic alliance with the Koo's Group in order to make inroads into the local E-commerce services market.

Meanwhile, HP has also formed cooperation ties with Tatung Co. to assist the giant local electronic manufacturer in the development and establishment of a planned Internet service system, designed to offer household sales and delivery services through computer ordering, the CEO noted.

However, Fiorina declined to disclose how much money is involved in the two mentioned partnerships or how much worth of Taiwanese products HP intends to purchase in the upcoming year. Instead, the CEO mentioned that HP had bought nearly US$3 billion-worth of goods in Taiwan in 1998.
HP has confidence in Taiwan, Fiorina stressed, noting her company will continue to increase its purchases from Taiwanese businesses.

This is Fiorina's first visit to Taiwan, and is part of her Asian tour undertaken along with HP Chairman of the Board Lewis E. Platt. She took over her present post in July after quitting a position with Lucent Technology Co.
Fiorina, 44, was named by the US-based Fortune magazine last year as the most influential female executive in the United States.
Following the less than 90-minute press conference in Taipei, the renown CEO left with Platt for Japan, the last stop on their Asian tour.

After their arrival in Taiwan on Friday, Fiorina and Platt called on Premier Vincent Siew and visited HP's key clients and partners in Taiwan, including Morris Chang of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing and Stan Shih of the Acer Group.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar closed higher against the US dollar Saturday on the Taipei foreign exchange market, prompted by active inflows of foreign funds.
The currency opened at 31.735, and was traded between 31.728 and 31.736 before closing at 31.736. The unit received an appreciation of 0.004 against the greenback during the session.
Interbank US dollar trading amounted to US$206 million, the largest Saturday turnover in the past two months.
Dealers predicted that foreign funds will continue to flow into the local market and that this expected situation may allow the NT dollar to challenge the 31.7-barrier against the greenback.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR EARTHQUAKES ROCK EASTERN TAIWAN IN JUST OVER AN HOUR

TEXT.P: Four mild earthquakes, measuring between magnitude 4.8 and 5.2, rocked Hualien in eastern Taiwan within just over an hour on Saturday afternoon, the Central Weather Bureau reported.
The four quakes were registered between 3:02 p.m. and 4:27 p.m., with all their epicenters located in the same area about 31.6 kilometers west of Hualien City.
Seismologists said the four quakes were aftershocks of the magnitude 7.3 Chichi temblor that ripped central Taiwan on Sept. 21 and caused more than 2,300 deaths.
Meanwhile, a magnitude 4 quake shook Chiayi at 11:39 a.m. on Saturday. The epicenter was located at 11.1 kilometers north of Chiayi City.
No casualties or property damage from the quakes were reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Oct. 31, or the 23rd day of the ninth month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1517: Martin Luther nails his 95 theses against papal corruption in Rome to the church door at Wittenberg.
1828: Sir Joseph Swan, the English chemist credited along with Thomas Edison for inventing the electric lamp, is born.
1864: Nevada becomes the 36th state of the United States.
1887: Chiang Kai-shek, the late president of the Republic of China, is born at Hsikou in Fenghua County, Chekiang Province.
1916: General Huang Hsin, leader of the Revolution that overthrew the Ching dynasty, dies in Shanghai at the age of 43.
1921: Benito Mussolini, prime minister of Italy, escapes an assassination attempt.
1922: Norodom Sihanouk, King of Cambodia, is born.
1947: The United Nations sets aside Oct. 24 as "United Nations Day."
1952: The China Youth Corps is organized with Chiang Ching-kuo serving as director.
1956: A bitter row erupts between Washington, London, and Paris over the bombing of Egypt by Anglo-French aircraft during the Suez crisis.
1957: Tsung Dao Lee and Chen Ning Yang share the Nobel Prize for Physics for work disproving the law of conservation of parity
1958: Nobel Prize winning author Boris Pasternak is expelled from the Soviet Writers' Union and is likely to be exiled for his "Dr. Zhivago."
1968: US President Lyndon B. Johnson orders a complete cessation of American bombing in North Vietnam.
1971: China Television Service, the third commercial TV network in the Republic of China, begins regular programming.
1972: The Southern Cross-Island Highway, which took four-and-a-half years to build and cost nearly NT$500 million, is opened to traffic.
1974: People throughout the Republic of China celebrate the 87th birthday of President Chiang Kai-shek.
1974: Alfred Jenkin, former deputy director of the US Liaison Office in Peiping arrives in Taipei for a visit.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan addresses leaders gathered to pay tribute to President Chiang Kai-shek on the late leader's 90th birthday, then breaks ground for the Chung Cheng Memorial Hall to honor President Chiang.
1976: Taichung port in west central Taiwan is formally opened.
1978: The Taiwan Area Freeway, with a total length of 377 km, is fully opened to traffic on the 92nd anniversary of the birth of the late President Chiang Kai-shek.
1978: The Sino-Saudi Arabian Bridge over the Choshui River in central Taiwan, which was built with low-interest loans from Saudi Arabia, opened to traffic as a part of the newly completed North-South Freeway.
1982: Wu Jung-ken, a 25-year-old MiG-19 pilot in the Communist Chinese air force who flew to a US military base outside Seoul on Oct. 16, arrives in Taipei.
1983: Taipei's Kuantu Bridge, the first Iron arch bridge in East Asia, opens to traffic. The construction of the bridge , 809 meters long, took three years and cost NT$700 million to complete.
1984: Mrs. Indira Gandhi, Indian prime minister, is shot dead as she walks in the garden of her home in New Delhi. She was 67.
1986: Madame Chiang Kai-shek presides over and addresses a mass rally at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall in Taipei to mark the 100th birthday of the late President Chiang.
1996: Former Polish President Lech Walesa visits the Republic of China.
Mencius' lesson of the day: "If you will practice a benevolent government, then the people will love all above them, and will die for their officers."

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PARTY MISSION HEADS FOR BEIJING FOR POST-QUAKE TASK

TEXT.P: A 36-member delegation of the opposition New Party departed for Beijing via Hong Kong on Sunday to attend a series of seminars on post-quake reconstruction in mainland China.

After arriving in Beijing later the same day, the mission will take part in two seminars in Beijing and Tangshan over the following two days, and will tour Tangshan on Wednesday to gain a better understanding of current developments in the city, which was largely devastated by a strong earthquake in 1975.

On Thursday, the delegation will proceed to Shanghai for a meeting with Wang Daohan, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait and mainland China's top negotiator with Taiwan.

Before flying back to Taiwan on Saturday, the group will head for Osaka and Kobe in Japan on Friday to obtain a first-hand understanding of the two cities' achievements in rebuilding their homelands after being hit by a major quake several years ago.

Lawmaker Lee Ching-hua, leader of the group and also head of the New Party's National Campaign and Development Committee, said they hope to collect valuable information to serve as references for the government to carry out its reconstruction task following the 921 earthquake, the worst to hit Taiwan in a century.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREAT FROM BEIJING HAS BECOME MORE SERIOUS: MND REPORT

TEXT.P: The threat from mainland China has increased since President Lee Teng-hui redefined cross-strait relations in July, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said in a report.

The report, which analyzes recent mainland troop movements and military exercises and their effect on Taiwan's security in the wake of President Lee's "state-to-state" statement on July 9, is scheduled to be delivered to the Legislative Yuan on Monday.

The report said that the MND believes that Beijing's recent defense budget increase , its purchase and production of advanced Sukhoi-27 and Sukhoi-30 fighter jets, K-class submarines and battle ships, and the beefing up of its artillery forces have all led to increased pressure on Taiwan.

The report noted that between July 13 and the end of September, mainland fighter jets have been frequently conducting exercises, adding that its planes twice crossed the mid-line in the Taiwan strait on July 25 and July 30.

The MND said that the planes were on patrol and reconnaissance missions, adding that they crossed over the mid-line of the strait in an attempt to put pressure on Taiwan, though there have been no drastic increases in the size of its air force.

With respect to the navy, the report said vessels from the mainland's East China Sea Fleet conducted anti-submarine and strategic exercises 90 nautical miles northeast off the coast of Keelung between Aug. 4 and Aug. 7.

Between Sept. 1 and Sept. 5, more than 30 vessels, in conjunction with the Nanking military region also conducted amphibious landing exercises off Zhejiang province in southeastern China. Between Aug. 10 and Aug. 12, vessels from its Nanhai Fleet conducted live missile firing exercises off the coast of Guangdong province, only some 500 nautical miles from Kaohsiung in southern Taiwan.
The report said mainland ground forces had also heightened combat readiness between July 13 and Sept. 25, though there were no unusual troop movements.
The Nanjing and Guangdong military regions have also conducted amphibious landing exercises in Zhejiang and Guangdong provinces.

Beijing has also flexed its military muscle by test firing its long-range strategic Dongfeng missiles on Aug. 2 so as to establish its status as a military power in the Asia and Pacific region and to intimidate Taiwan, according to the report.

In addition to military intimidation, the report said Beijing has actively incited anti-Lee fever within its military, and added that Taiwan should guard against Beijing's attempts to incite antagonism toward Taiwan.
Faced with this verbal and military intimidation, the MND urged Taiwan to heighten its guard so that Beijing doesn't dare begin a war.

But the MND also said that in the past decade, the budget for national defense has registered negative growth, representing a greater decrease in defense spending than that of advanced countries that face no immediate military threat.
He said that the situation has become more serious with the expansion of Beijing's military might, adding that the gap between the two sides has widened.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCIAL AND PSYCHOLOGICAL PROBLEMS MAIN CONCERN OF QUAKE VICTIMS

TEXT.P: Financial and psychological problems are the major concerns of the people in quake-stricken areas, a poll released on Sunday showed.

The survey, conducted by the National Poll Center at the Commission of the Television Society of the ROC, also showed that except for the handling of damaged houses, the people in the quake-stricken areas have been generally satisfied with the quake-relief efforts in resettlement, day-to-day care, epidemic prevention and emergency medical assistance.

Chu Yun-han, a researcher at Academia Sinica, the top academic body in Taiwan, said this shows that the government's efficiency in assessing and handling damaged houses in quake-stricken areas during the massive Sept. 21 earthquake have not met the expectations of the quake-stricken people.
Some 56 percent of those polled also said that the government should take the major responsibility in post-quake reconstruction, with private groups only playing a complementary role.
Chu also said that reviving the manufacturing industry and helping take care of quake-stricken people pose the greatest difficulties at present and require the most support.

As post-quake reconstruction efforts will require a lot of money, nearly 70 percent of the people polled also favored a delay in the implementation of the proposed national annuity project and the issuance of a public lottery.
Most of those polled also said they hoped the reconstruction works could be completed within two or three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T SHOULD ENCOURAGE POTENTIAL WORKERS TO JOIN WORK FORCE

TEXT.P: There were up to 5.25 million idle potential workers in Taiwan last year, a sign that human resources have not been used to the fullest extent, a report by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) showed on Sunday.

CEPD Chairman Schive Chi said that in light of the huge number of potential workers, scholars have suggested that the government should step up its campaign to encourage enterprises to provide flexible working hours to lure more people, especially women, into the work force.
The CEPD report said that most of the potential workers are women between the age of 25 and 49 with an education level of junior high school or lower.

CEPD officials said the willingness of women to join the work force has been increasing every year and that the government should strengthen its regulations governing equal pay for the two sexes in order to encourage more women to participate in the work force.

The CEPD said the definition of a potential worker is someone who has the ability to work but is not employed. In 1998, the number of potential workers totaled 5.24 million, accounting for 70 percent of the non-working population. Of that number, those who said they didn't work because they had to take care of their home accounted for 38 percent of the total, or 2.64 million potential workers.

The report said that although more women are entering the work force, there is still ample room for more growth, and the CEPD suggested a revision of labor policies to encourage more women to begin working.

The report also suggested an adjustment in the government's foreign labor policies to prevent an excessive number of foreign laborers from taking over basic jobs. Except in the case of major public construction projects or in areas of special concern, the government should reconsider the number of foreign laborers it allows into the labor market.
The CEPD also said that the government should set an example by providing alternative working hours for its own employees to encourage local enterprises to follow suit.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIVILIAN GROUPS TO CONTRIBUTE US$ 219 M. FOR SCHOOL RECONSTRUCTION

TEXT.P: Civilian organizations in Taiwan have pledged to contribute NT$7 billion (US$219 million) to rebuild 79 schools that were damaged or destroyed in the recent earthquakes, according to the Education Ministry on Sunday.
Education Minister Yung Chaur-shin will report on post-quake reconstruction work for schools before the Education Committee of the Legislative Yuan on Monday.

According to the survey by the Education Ministry, a total of 841 schools were damaged in two major earthquakes that ripped central Taiwan on Sept. 21 and rocked the Chiayi area on Oct. 22. A total of 306 students and 15 faculty members were killed.
The cost for the reconstruction of these schools is estimated at NT$39.03 billion (US$1.22 billion).

In response to the Education Ministry's call for help with the reconstruction of damaged schools, several charity foundations, religious organizations and private enterprises have agreed to sponsor the reconstruction of 79 schools.

The civilian sponsors include the Buddhist Tzu Chi Association, the Red Cross Society, the TVBS Caring Foundation, the United Daily Group, Minshih TV, Taiwan High-Speed Railway Corp., the King Car Education Foundation, the Fo Kuan Shan Foundation for Buddhist Culture and Education, and the Formosa Plastics Group.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRMO TO HELP AFRICAN COUNTRY WITH MEDICAL CARE

TEXT.P: A delegation from the Taiwan Roots Medical Organization (TRMO) left for a visit to four African countries to evaluate the possibility of providing medical care to one of them.
The TRMO, a famous civil medical organization that offers its medical services to Taiwan's aboriginal people, sent a team to offer its services to refugees from Kosovo in Macedonia last April.

The TRMO delegation will also call on the Paris-based Doctors without Borders, a non-government organization which won the 1999 Nobel Peace Prize to join the mission. The two medical organizations also worked together in Macedonia last April.

Liu Ming-chun, president of TRMO, said that Taiwan has received medical and humanitarian help from world religious organizations and other international organizations in the past years and that it is now time for Taiwan to give something back to the international community.
During its visit to Africa, the delegation will select one of the four countries to receive medical service from the TRMO next year.
The TRMO had also sent a delegation to visit Mongolia and India last July, resulting in the beginning of medical cooperation between Mongolia and Taiwan in the near future.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CANVASSES FOR KMT CANDIDATE IN YUNLIN BY-ELECTION
DOC.DATELINE: Yunlin, central Taiwan, Oct.31, (CNA) (By Amanda Chang)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui on Sunday morning personally went to Yunlin County to canvass for the ruling Kuomintang's magistrate candidate Chang Cheng-hsiung.

Lee and a considerable number of supporters mobilized by the KMT took part in the campaign activity dubbed "Love and Support President Lee, Vote for Chang", demonstrating the mobilization capabilities of the KMT's party machine.

In a bid to help Chang win the difficult by-election, Lee not only promoted the KMT candidate as the most competent of the three contenders, but openly promised to actively build the county, presently poor in tax revenue, into Taiwan's No.1 economic and industrial center within 10 years.

During the activity, the KMT candidate, in his bid to gain public support, theatrically pulled out a giant check to the Yunlin County Government signed by himself to dramatically illustrate his proposed county construction plans.

President Lee then endorsed the back of the check to demonstrate his full support for Chang's county construction plans while the audience taking part in the activity cheered on. Other central government officials also unanimously expressed their support for Chang and his plans.

The participants included high-ranking government officials such as Finance Minister Paul Chiu, Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang and Secretary-General to the President Huang Kun-huei, and KMT Secretary-General John Chang.

The situation in the lead up to the Yunlin County by-election on Nov.6 is becoming complicated as rumors of vote-buying, election violence, and libel suits filed by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party candidate Lin Chung-li against the KMT candidate Chang circulated in the media.

Chang, whose campaign aides reportedly said they received threats over the telephone and had their cars damaged by unknown people, signed an "Anti-violence announcement" and urged voters not to cast their ballots for any candidates connected to underworld crime syndicates.
Yunlin County Magistrate Su Wen-hsiung died of liver cancer three months ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALTERNATIVE MILITARY SERVICE DRAFTEES TO JOIN POST-QUAKE EFFORTS

TEXT.P: The first batch of 5,000 draftees of the planned alternative military service, slated to begin mid next year, will be used to help the government carry out its post-quake reconstruction task, according to a special report by the Ministry of the Interior.

The government will deploy the 5,000 draftees of its planned alternative military service, to take effect on July 1, 2000, in order to better manage the manpower devoted to post-quake reconstruction, Interior Minister Huang Chu-wen said in the report.

Huang, who will make a special report on the 921 earthquake to the Legislative Yuan's Home and Border Affairs on Monday, pointed out that the 5,000 conscripts will be used mainly to maintain public order and sanitation and offer services to residents in disaster areas hit by the 921 earthquake, the worst to jolt Taiwan in a century.

At the same time, the Social Affairs Department under the Interior Ministry has been working on drawing up relevant regulations to effectively govern the use of cash donations which have poured into all sorts of organizations following the 921 quake, said Huang.

Currently, donations from citizens from all walks of life for the wide-ranging reconstruction task have totaled more than NT$18 billion, he noted, adding that more than 393,197 police, military serviceman, medical personnel and private-sector volunteers have been mobilized to date for the rebuilding task.

The interior ministry also pointed out that it will be necessary to elaborate a law on disaster prevention and to establish special units in both the central and local governments in order to provide victims in disaster areas with swift assistance.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ACTS TO IMPROVE DEFENSE CAPABILITY

TEXT.P: Republic of China Defense Minister Tang Fei will report on plans to improve the island's defense capability in the coming years before the Legislative Yuan on Monday.

A prepared Defense Ministry report indicated that by fiscal 2002, Taiwan will complete the second-phase plans of its "strong-net" air defense system through the introduction of advanced jet fighters and early warning aircraft.

According to the report, all 60 French-made Mirage 2000-5 fighter planes have been received by the ROC Air Force, and the delivery of 150 American-made F-16 fighters and 130 indigenous defense fighters will be completed by the fiscal year 2000.
As the United States has agreed to provide two E-2T air defense warning systems, the report noted, the second-phase plans of the "strong-net" air defense system can be completed by fiscal 2002.

With respect to the ROC's naval power, the report said, seven Cheng-kung class, six Kang-ting class and six Chi-yang class missile frigates as well as the first Chin-chiang class coastal patrol vessel have all been in active service.
New procurement plans include an eighth Cheng-kung class missile frigate, 11 Chin-chiang class patrol vessels, 11 American-made S-70C anti-submarine helicopters, and one LSD38 landing vessel.

In the effort to improve the ROC's defensive capability against marine landings, the delivery of 63 AH-1W and 39 OH-58D tanks will be completed by fiscal 2001 and the delivery of 460 M60A3TTS tanks will be completed by the end of 2000.

Regarding missile deployment, the report said that in addition to the existing conventional Tien-kung and improved air defense missile systems, new missile units will be deployed and various additional missile procurements will be made, so as to improve the military's capabilities against blockades and landings.

DOC.HEADLINE: FALUN GONG MEMBERS STAGE SIT-IN DEMONSTRATION IN HONG KONG

TEXT.P: About 10 practitioners of the Falun Gong sect have staged a sit-in demonstration since Saturday evening in front of the Xinhua News Agency office in Hong Kong in protest against the passing of an anti-cult law by the legislature of China Saturday.

The new law outlaws Falun Gong as an evil cult. The demonstrators said they were afraid that it may pave the way for further government crackdown on Falun Gong. They said it is not a cult, and is not politically oriented.

Falun Gong, which was said to have up to 100 million practitioners in the world, combines traditional Chinese meditation, slow breathing techniques, and the teachings of Buddhism and Taoism for daily practice.
They said the demonstration will last until late Sunday night.
